column2: Earnings of Deere Co. declined in the quarter and six months ended April 30, despite higher sales. William A. Hewitt, chairman, reported yesterday that net income in the United States was larger than a year before but did not increase in proportion to sales.
In recent days, tension has again arisen along the armistice lines between Israel and the Arab states. The situation there is a matter of grave concern to the whole international community.

An organization of France's leading art dealers has recommended a permanent collaboration with the Art Dealers Association of America to exchange information about the international art market and to develop a program against forgers.
THE Lime Rock, Conn., course joins one of the Sports Car Club of America's big-time circuits next Monday and Tuesday in the presentation of a four-hour Trans-American championship sedan race.
THE American Children's Theater version of "Toby Tyler or 10 Weeks With a Circus" at the Bert Wheeler Theater in the Dixie Hotel is virtuous but not outstanding. The chief virtue is its ...
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Wednesday, May 24--Louie B. Nunn, a conservative Republican, appeared headed for a narrow victory early today in a bitter fight for the party's governorship nomination in Kentucky.
THE Hong Kong riots have led Wall Street to chal lenge the wisdom of Fairchild Camera's pioneering efforts to produce transistors and diodes with low-cost labor.
WASHINGTON, May 23-- Senator Edward V. Long, who has been accused of misusing a subcommittee during a wiretapping investigation, asked today for an increase in funds to continue the committee's work.
Horace Garner Reed, who had a 54-year career in corporate law, international law and Government service, died yesterday at Doctors Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived at 15 East 91st Street.

A truck with 18,000 cartons of cigarettes valued by the police at $36,000 was hijacked at a busy Brooklyn intersection at noon yesterday. The driver and his helper were released unharmed in Melville, Suffolk County after bring driven about in an auto for three hours.

The 97-year-old Young Women's Christian Association of the City of New York, always a reluctant debutante when it came to charity events, held the first city-wide benefit in its history last night. There were indications that there would be more such occasions in the venerable organization's future.
CLEVELAND, May 21-- Mayor Ralph S. Locher is under mounting pressure not to seek re-election this year.
Only bicycles and unicycles rolled over the streets in Central Park last night from 7 until 11 P.M.
By Sept. 1 all of the city's 11,772 taxicabs must be equipped with a timing device on off-duty signs to prevent the drivers from turning the signs on and off at will.
The stock market tried to get off its downward course yesterday but failed and prices were off for the fifth consecutive session.
BALTIMORE, May 23--The Yankees, who have found runmaking difficult in recent games, hit a low for the season tonight as they suffered their second straight shutout.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 23--The Security Council will meet at 10:30 A.M. tomorrow in response to an urgent request from Canada and Denmark that it consider the crisis between Israel and her Arab neighbors.

President Johnson's firm statement, U Thant's visit to Cairo and the summoning of the Security Council respond to a sharp worsening of the Middle East crisis and rising danger of a war that could quickly embroil the major powers.

WASHINGTON, May 23--In imposing a blockade on Israeli shipping though the Strait of Tiran, President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic has reopened the explosive legal question of whether the Gulf of Aquaba is an international waterway subject to free passage by ships of all nations.
A situation giving rise to anxiety from the viewpoint of the interests of peace and international security has been taking shape in the Near East in recent weeks.

A matter not on the agenda, the Jim Taylor case, attracted chief attention at the spring meeting of the two professional football leagues, National and American, which began here yesterday at the WaldorfAstoria.

HONG KONG, May 23-- Hong Kong, at least the nonCommunist segment of the population, has suddenly nothing but praise for its police force, which has long been the butt of criticism in letters to the press, accused of everything from corruption to incompetence.
There are two essentials for the future development of international civil aviation, Walter Binaghi, president of the Council of the International Civil Aviation Organizations said yesterday.
WHITE PLAINS, May 23-- Two founders of the Council for the Arts in Westchester have left its board of trustees under unusual circumstances.
To Franz Schoenberner, the last pre-Nazi editor of Simplicissimus, the disclosure that the once scathing satirical magazine will cease publication was neither surprising nor especially grieving.

The port of Elath is a settlement less than 20 years old at the head of the Gulf of Aqaba, which the United Arab Republic has announced it will blockade. The gulf is bounded by Egypt, Israel, Jordan and Saudi Arabia.

PORTLAND, Ore., May 23-- The General Assembly of the United Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A. took the 3.3-millionmember denomination to task today for "apathy, compromise and disobedience" in the field of racial justice.

New York Central Railroad officials indicated yesterday that a special safety system to permit two trains to ride the same rails in opposite directions had broken down Monday when two freight trains collided in upper Manhattan.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L. I., May 23--Mr. and Mrs. Douglas Bonner Bowring have made known the engagement of Mrs. Bowring's daughter, Miss Catherine Van Duzer Bowring, to John Abbot Sargent, son of Mr. and Mrs. Winthrop William Sargent of Concord, Mass. Miss Bowring, daughter also of Thomas Ashley Burton of Newtown, Conn., uses her stepfather's surname.

The New York Shakespeare Festival is again confronted with a financial crisis. The Board of Estimate yesterday voted an appropriation of $373,000, but Joseph Papp, producer of the free performances, had asked for $524,000.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, May 24--United States and allied forces resumed normal operations today after a 24hour cease-fire broken by 71 clashes and incidents that took the lives of 12 American soldiers and left 60 wounded.
WASHINGTON, May 23-- Senator Albert Gore introduced a new campaign financing and election reform bill today with the avowed aim of "safeguarding the ballot box from the improper influence of money."
The attacks on welfare and antipoverty efforts in general grow out of understandable frustration; but the poor are still here, summer is coming and positive answers are needed.
The Metropolitan Museum of Art will remain open until 10 P.M., five hours later than usual, for four Tuesdays starting next week.
Just for kicks, at the Belmont Ball, Nancy Sweet-Escott has been known to dance the twist or swing her leg above her head like a chorus girl.
Wolf's Gang and the Beethoven Bunnies, who usually play at Carnegie Hall, had themselves a ball game in Central Park yesterday afternoon.
Richard L. Schneider resigned yesterday as president of the Weber Heilbroner and Broadstreet's retail chains in New York.
LONDON, May 23--Britain dispatched her top diplomats to Washington and Moscow tonight in an effort to help resolve the crisis in the Middle East.
At 8:30 yesterday morning the gray grill gates at 3 East 53d Street swung open and a gracious little park with a rushing, waterfall was opened to the public.

DETROIT, May 23--James P. Hoffa, 26 years old, the son of James R. Hoffa, the imprisoned teamsters' union president, was defeated today in an attempt to win a seat in Michigan's House of Representatives.

Don Drysdale, the surviving member of the pitching partnership of Koufax Drysdale, overpowered the New York Mets on five hits last night as he pitched the Los Angeles Dodgers to a 7-0 victory in Shea Stadium.

Ben Schwartzwalder of Syracuse, the president of the American College Football Coaches Association, said yesterday that the association would poll its members within the next 30 days for an opinion on the new punt rule that is to be put into effect this coming season.
Directors of Eastern Air Lines, Inc., authorized yesterday a two-for-one split of the common stock, to be distributed June 30 to holders of record June 6.
In the opinion of Robert Cushman Murphy, Lamont Curator Emeritus of Birds at the American Museum of Natural History, man, "the interloper," is now threatening to swamp nature in the Antarctic.
Interest rates continued their upward course early in yesterday's bond market session, but about midday prices rallied and rates retreated from their highs.
Governor Rockefeller announced plans last night for a review of the state's antidiscrimination laws and procedures.
More than 18,000 unionized municipal employes filled Madison Square Garden last night to denounce a new state law prohibiting public employes from striking.

BROCKTON, Mass., May 23--Three masked men armed with submachine guns stole a Brink's, Inc., armored truck with more than $600,000 aboard today and escaped after transferring the loot to another car. The bandits ...
PARIS, May 23 (AP)-- Nine seeded men players swept through first-round matches without the loss of a set in the French tennis championships today.
DETROIT, May 23--The increase in the consumer price index today brought 2-cent-anhour pay rises for more than 800,000 employes of the automobile makers.
CHICAGO, May 23--Richard M. Nixon called today for the United States to resist actively the use of force by either Israel or the United Arab Republic in the Middle East crisis.
Made presentation of Presidential "E" awards to 10 U.S. manufacturing and business concerns for achievement in export expansion;

HUE, South Vietnam, May 23 --In the opinion of many informed civilian and military officials, the pacification program in South Vietnam's strategically important northern provinces has come to a stop and in some areas has begun moving backward.
FORT JACKSON, S.C., May 23--Capt. Howard B. Levy said today, through his counsel, that he had no desire to turn his military trial "into a general propaganda attack on United States foreign policy."

Fritz Jahoda, a man-aboutmusic who made his New York debut as a pianist in 1944 and subsequently went on to significant involvements in chamber music, operatic conducting and college teaching, returned to Carnegie Recital Hall last night to play his fourth piano recital here. After the first one in 1944, there was one in 1964 and another last year.

WASHINGTON, May 23-- These are hard days on the strutting dictators of the world. Sukarno in Indonesia, Nkrumah in Ghana, and Ben Bella in Algeria have all overreached and destroyed their power, and Gamal Abdel Nasser of Egypt seems headed for the same unhappy destiny.
MOSCOW, May 23 (AP)-- Svetlana Alliluyeva's son Iosif. disclosed today that he had sent her a letter denouncing her for having left the Soviet Union.
The city was urged last night to explore a plan for importing electricity from Canada to provide power for street lights, subways and public housing.

Jerry Pittman, who is the instructor at The Creek Club in Locust Valley, L.I., and occasionally joins the pro golf tour, was the pace-setter in yesterday's local qualifying trials for the United States Open championship.
The political tension in the Middle East restrained activity on the London Stock Exchange yesterday and most groups declined. Royal Dutch fell sharply, and leading industrial issues closed off.

The specter of another painful and crippling credit squeeze is haunting the money markets. Despite President Johnson's pledge to lower interest rates and the Federal Reserve's aggressive efforts to carry it out, long-term interest rates have been rising and expectations are widespread that the current escalation in rates will intensify.
A classy caravan crisscrossed Manhattan on Monday night in search of an image-- a new Premium image--for Ballantine beer.

WASHINGTON, May 23--A voluntary code of ethics, aimed at ending misrepresentations by door-to-door magazine salesmen, has been proposed by four major magazine publishers and was approved by the Federal Trade Commission today as not in violation of any law.

WASHINGTON, May 23-- President Johnson urged the United Arab Republic today to avoid an "illegal" blockade of the Gulf of Aqaba and asserted that the United States was "firmly committed" to the territorial integrity of all Middle Eastern nations.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 23--In a move that amounted to a complete break in diplomatic relations, Jordan has ordered the Syrian Ambassador to close his embassy and leave the country by Thursday.
QUANGTRI, South Vietnam, May 23--Two United States military advisers have been tortured, mutilated and killed by North Vietnamese troops, a Marine officer disclosed today.
The printers' union and The Long Island Press reached agreement last night on a new contract with the same basic terms as earlier settlements with The Daily News and The New York Times.
MONTREAL, May 23 (AP) --Canon Lionel Groulx, author, historian and spokesman for the Quebec Nationalist movement, died today. He was 89 years old.

WASHINGTON, May 23--A State Department official declared today that if Communist China were to intervene with massive forces in Vietnam, the United States would have to take action against mainland China with everything it has.

The First Western Financial Corporation, a holding company based in Las Vegas, Nev., disclosed yesterday that its principal subsidiary, First Western Savings and Loan Association, sustained a net operating loss of $19,706,000 in 1966.

JERUSALEM (Israel), May 23--Premier Levi Eshkol said tonight that President Gamal Abdel Nasser would be committing "an act of aggression against Israel" if he interfered with shipping through the Strait of Tiran.
AN extremely handy booklet on fishing in New York state has become available from the Conservation Department.
MADRID, May 23--Her foreign exchange reserves shrinking, Spain was reported today to have entered the world money market to obtain $113-million in general financing for development projects.
The Democratic-controlled Board of Estimate and City Council cut almost $6-million yesterday from Mayor Lindsay's executive budget for the coming fiscal year.
Seymour Poe, who one week ago, was re-elected executive vice president of 20th CenturyFox Film Corporation, severed all relations with the company yesterday.

PEKING, May 23--China's central leadership has launched a campaign aimed at justifying the purge of Communist ranks and reinforeing the contention that Chairman Mao Tse-tung's thoughts are the only source of orthodox guidance for carrying out domestic and world revolution.
CHERRY HILL, N. J., May 23 (AP)--Athen's Gem, the even-money favorite, won the Open Purse at Garden State Park today for her fourth victory of the season.

HONG KONG, May 23--After almost two weeks of riots, Hong Kong was generally quiet and orderly today. Local leaders of the residents sympathetic to Communist China did not test a British order issued last night prohibiting unauthorized public meetings and processions.

WASHINGTON, May 23--A fair-housing group charged today that two Federal agencies had not only ignored a Presidential directive calling for nondiscrimination in housing but had also actively obstructed it.
JERUSALEM (Israel), May 23--An American tourist walked up to Zvi Avrami, manager of the King David Hotel in Jerusalem, and asked him this evening, "Should I leave?"
WASHINGTON, May 23-- The Consumer Price Index rose substantially in April despite a continuing drop in food prices.
The most decorated veteran of Vietnam may be a boisterous grandmother who is currently kicking up her shapely legs in the Broadway show, "Hello, Dolly!"

More than 1,000 guests filled the main ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel in tribute to S.Y. Agnon, the Israeli author and winner of the 1966 Nobel Prize for Literature, who is on his first visit to the United States.

As part of that generation that preceded the Wrights, Ellisons and Baldwins, Langston Hughes knew that as with every creative Negro talent, he had to force his way into the consciousness of editors, impresarios and audiences.

The Supreme Court's refusal, on jurisdictional grounds, to pass on the Suffolk County reapportionment case leaves unsettled the question how far it will apply its one-man, one-vote doctrine to local governmental units. Its decision in the Virginia Beach City Council case indicates that the Court may be more flexible than many observers had expected.

Alexander E. Zagoreos, 29year-old former campaign aide to Mayor Lindsay, who is trying to oust Councilman at Large Lester Baum as a Republican district leader on Manhattan's West Side, charged yesterday that Vincent F. Albano Jr., the county leader, had intervened on Mr. Baum's side.
Twenty-five works of art that may or may not be by prominent artists may have been sold by auction at a City Sheriff's sale yesterday for a total of maybe $17,500.
Finally playing with some semblance of fluidity, the New York Generals presented a united backfield tonight and tonight and played a scoreless tie with the Baltimore Bays.
NEWARK, May 24 Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio warned today that the disruption of public hearings by protesting Negro groups and individuals was "out of bounds and cannot and will not be permitted."
WASHINGTON, May 24 An Army major decorated for service in Vietnam has sought political asylum in Cuba for what were described as "reasons of conscience."
LONDON, May 24 Prime Minister Wilson declared today that Britain would "promote and support international action" to keep the Strait of Tiran open to ships of all nations.

PARIS, May 24--Cino del Duca, head of a magazine publishing empire in France and Italy, film producer and race horse owner, died this morning in Milan, Italy, of a cerebral hemorrhage. He was 67 years old.
IT'S just an ordinary Sony television set and what appears on the screen seems to be an ordinary "talk" show.

Hopes for major improvement in the state's judicial system were strengthened yesterday when Anthony J. Travia, president of the Constitutional Convention, endorsed five highly controversial measures now under consideration by the Judiciary Committee.

SAIGON, May 24 Less than a month ago, a 20-year-old airman at Tansonnhut Air Base was scanning a film that two more experienced photo interpreters had discarded as worthless. What he found resulted in an attack on a missile site.

THE most unexpected material in "ByLine: Ernest Hemingway" makes a contribution to Canada's Expo 67. It is what he wrote exuberantly from the expatriates' Europe for The Toronto Star in his and our century's early 20's. I must say that these "selected articles and dispatches of four decades" otherwise run...
Ron Hunt, a torch in the darkness for the Mets in other years, blazed again at Shea Stadium last night as the second baseman of the Los Angeles Dodgers.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., May 24 (AP) Tom McCraw smashed three home runs and drove in eight runs today as the usually weak-hitting Chicago White Sox bombarded the Minnesota Twins with 21 hits in a 14-1 rout.
Mayor Lindsay disclosed yesterday that he had asked the city's Budget Director to look into the Board of Education's spending practices with a view to obtaining a better return.
"Depend on it," Samuel Johnson once said, "when a man knows he is going to be hanged in a fortnight, it concentrates his mind wonderfully."
IT'S been called the weekly Wednesday invasion. It begins around 9 A.M. when women with matinee tickets snug in their purses climb off buses and trains

WASHINGTON, May 24 Investors Overseas Services agreed today to terminate almost every aspect of its financial activities in the United States and to stop selling shares in its Fund of Funds to Americans, wherever they live.
WASHINGTON, May 24 Administration-sponsored amendments to strengthen the small Business Investment Company program were introduced in the Congress today.

The members of the American Academy of Arts and Letters and of the National Institute of Arts and Letters are discussing a consolidation of the two honor societies into a single organization with a membership of 75 to 100.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 24 American warplanes resumed attacks on North Vietnam today with strikes at three major railroad yards near Hanoi.
Atlanta, Seattle, Washington, D.C., and San Francisco are some of the areas generating the greatest interest among real estate developers and mortgage investors.
Prices continued to ease on the London Stock Exchange yesterday as trading was still under the cloud of Middle East tension.
Major intervention by the United States in any major war in the Middle East would require mobilization, if the testimony of military leaders is a guide.

About two and a half months ago E. William Dey Jr., advertising and sales promotion director of the Angostura-Wuppermann Corporation, after interviewing 31 agencies decided to put the bitters billings in Wyse Advertising.

WASHINGTON, May 24 Estimates accepted by the House Appropriations Committee show that the cost of the war in Vietnam in the fiscal year 1968 will be $6-billion higher than the $22-billion in President Johnson's budget in January. This could be so, the ...
The international reaction to Colonel Nasser's threat to close the Gulf of Aqaba would give pause to any rational leader concerned with his own future and the interests of his country.

CAIRO, Thursday, May 25 The United States has officially but privately warned the United Arab Republic that it considers the Egyptian blockade of the Gulf of Aqaba an "act of aggression" and will oppose it by all possible means.
MONTREAL, May 24 (Canadian Press) Shareholders of Midepsa Industries, Ltd., gave the company the green light today to proceed with a projected $100-milion deal with the Kaiser Aluminum and

BOISE, Idaho, May 24 Recall petitions are circulating in Idaho against Senator Frank Church, the first target in a right-wing move to punish Senatorial critics of the Vietnam war. Senator Church has been forced to come home to campaign in self-defense.
Golf officials have agreed to outlaw croquet putting and to speed play as part of a recommended revised code that would take effect Jan. 1, 1968.
WASHINGTON, May 24 Treasury bill rates rose from month-ago levels on nine-month and one-year bills, the Treasury disclosed tonight.

CHICAGO, May 24 Federal District Judge William J. Lynch declared a mistrial today in the perjury case of Paul (the Waiter) Ricca, long considered a leading member of the hierarchy in the Chicago crime syndicate.
Agnes Gordon, one of America's greatest women bridge players, died of cancer in Sisters Hospital, Buffalo, early yesterday morning. Her age was 61.
BALTIMORE, May 24 The New York Yankees turned on the Baltimore Orioles and blanked them, 2-0, in the series finale tonight.
WASHINGTON, May 24 A Senate-House conference committee agreed today on the final text of a much-delayed bill to restore tax benefits for business investment in equipment and buildings.
WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP) House leaders suggested today that Adam Clayton Powell make a new attempt to be seated in Congress.
Capitalizing on the long delays in Medicaid payment to practitioners, a private corporation is purchasing Medicaid bills and paying the practitioners 90 cents on the dollar.
DALLAS, May 24 The president of the nation's largest association of social workers accused his colleagues today of excessive professionalism, polittical naivete and in some cases racial prejudice.
A spokesman for American Jewish organizations said yesterday that Arab governments must be made to realize that a war with Israel "will not be a small skirmish between Arabs and Jews."
SAN MATEO, Calif., May 24 -Mr. and Mrs. Hyman E. Berman have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Robin Gay Berman, to Paul Burak, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Burak of New York.

KABUL, Afghanistan, May 24 The drive to modernize Afghanistan's politics as well as her economy reached a significant stage this week when the Political Parties Bill neared approval by both houses of the national legislature.

CHICAGO, May 24 (AP)--Adolpho Phillips beat a throw to the plate on a fielder's choice in the ninth inning, enabling the Chicago Cubs to win the second game, 4-3, and split a double-header with the league-leading Cincinnati Reds today.

ROME, May 24--Pope Paul VI appealed specifically today for the cessation of bombing of North Vietnam together with an end to acts of terrorism and the "infiltration of arms and war materiel into the South."
Two of four large new corporate bond issues sold out quickly yesterday, one had a "very good" reception and the other met investor resistance and was described as "moving slowly."

City Council leaders contended yesterday that they had found $25-million of "fat" in Mayor Lindsay's executive budget. They said the Mayor was trying to obscure this by accusing them of forcing him into deficit financing.

Inventory adjustments in several major paper-consuming industries adversely affected sales and earnings of the West Virginia Pulp and Paper Company in the second fiscal quarter, which ended April 30, the report of David L. Luke 3d, presient, disclosed yesterday.

FORT JACKSON, May 24 Defense witnesses in the courtmartial of Capt. Howard B. Levy testified today that the Green Berets had a permissive policy toward the torture of Vietcong prisoners by the South Vietnamese.

PORTLAND, Ore., May 24 The General Assembly of the United Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A.opposed today broadening the draft classification of "conscientious objector" to include persons conscientiously opposed to fighting in "a particular war." A sharp floor fight preceded the action.
Many motorists parked overtime escaped summonses yesterday as protesting meter maids stayed away from work for the second day. The maids are angry about what they describe as harassment by civilians.

LISBON, May 24--The poodle is the No. 1 breed in the United States, but in Portugal, he's just another dog. The most popular breed in Portugal is the German shepherd. "Our people like a good guard dog," said Dr. Antonio Cabral, who for the last 10 years has been president...
Steel shipments probably will rise in the final quarter of 1967, but business is slack and likely to stay that way for several months, industry leaders said here yesterday.

THE doctor's orders were specific. The sharp pains in the area of the appendix were too much of a warning to be ignored. Hence Ernie Revers was not to play football that day. It was a game between the Duluth Eskimos, the famed Iron Men of the North, and Milwaukee about

JOHN CROCE of the Bronx blanked the opposition and captured first prize in the recent Postal Chess Tournament of the Post Office Employes. This was a repeat performance by Croce, who finished 15-0. Second place went to H. C. Owens of Massapequa, L. I., 14-1, A. Woods of Springfield, Mass., was third, with 13-2.
Two vice presidents of the Borden Company were indicted here yesterday on charges of first-degree perjury in what the District Attorney's office described as an "enormous conspiracy."

MUENSTER, Tex., May 24 Much of Colonial Acres Farms, the estate of Ernest and Margaret Medders, perhaps the most unlikely couple ever to give $50,000 parties, will be sold here tomorrow to satisfy more than $1-million in debts.

The city's drive to develop a major containership terminal in the Stapleton area of Staten Island moved forward yesterday with the signing of a contract for use of the terminal by a new $25-million trailership now under construction.
LONDON, May 24 (UPI) The rush to buy gold sparked by mounting tension in the Middle East and continued unrest in the Crown Colony of Hong Kong and in Aden continued unabated here today.
WYANDANCH, L. I., May 24 Five members of a family were killed here early this morning in a fire that left only two survivors.

A new site for the United Nations International School is being proposed as an alternative to the present plan to build a school on a pier on the East River at 25th Street. So far, $1-milion has been allocated to prepare the pier as the school site.

ABSOLUTELY FREEEE," which opened at the Garrick Theater last night, will cost you threeee dollars a ticket. Whether you find the money well-spent will depend a great deal on how old you are, or wish you were.
Two unpublished short stories by Ernest Hemingway, carbon copies of typescripts that were apparently written shortly after World War II, were auctioned last night for $6,250 and $1,400.
WASHINGTON, May 23 Wives of African diplomats and African students modeled centuries-old native styles and colorful contemporary adaptations at a luncheon and fashion show held yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Thursday, May 25 The House passed a $3.5-billion school-aid authorization bill early today after Administration forces defeated a concerted Republican effort to give the states more control over use of the funds.

SO NEW YORK has finally made it finally caught up with New Orleans. In 1847, according to my friend the American dance historian, Lillian Moore, in New Orleans there were two theaters offering, on the same night, "Giselle." Well, 120 years is

The New York City Cultural Showcase Committee, designed to bring home to the public what the city offers in the arts, yesterday revealed its plans for the future, starting with an ambitious roster of events presented as a festival in the fall.

The recent retreat in the stock market developed into a full-scale rout yesterday. In the broadest setback in eight months, price declines on the New York Stock Exchange topped advances by a margin of almost 5-to-1.

MEXICO CITY, May 24 Left off the teams that lost to Spain in 1965 and to Brazil last year, Arthur Ashe of Richmond will play singles against Mexico in the American Zone Davis Cup tennis final here starting Saturday.

PEKING, May 24 British sources said that jeering Red Guards smeared the clothing of two British diplomats with paste in Shanghai today and spat in the face of one and tried to put a dunce cap on his head.
LONDON, May 24 A Government agency recommended emphatically today that Britain's banks stop collective fixing of interest rates and start competing more aggressively and imaginatively.

PRINCETON JUNCTION, N.J., May 24 At 156 miles an hour, the Federal Government and the Pennsylvania, Railroad ran the first public test today of the line's new high-speed passenger train. The four-car train hurtled ...
Dr. Robert J. McCracken, who will retire June 4 as minister of Riverside Church, received a $10,000 check from his congregation last night as a gift.

EDISON, N. J., May 24 After a hearing that lasted 10 hours, the Board of Education of Edison Township suspended a 17-year-old honor student from the Edison High School today for having sideburns that they considered too long.
The city enlisted private business yesterday as a new ally in its continuing war on the traffic-ticket scofflaw.
Politely of the Bohemia Stable made it "2 for 2" for the season as she won the $15,000 feature event at Aqueduct yesterday.
MINNEAPOLIS, May 24 A ban on all cigarette advertising on television before 9 P.M. local time was called for today in a resolution adopted at the 71st annual con

NEGEV, Israel, May 24 (UPI) The fine gray dust of the desert bakes on the faces of the young Israeli troops as they sit under camouflage netting and play backgammon, waiting for a war that may or may not come.
TOKYO Six years ago, Japan lost the world judo championship. But with this "export" of the title a boom has followed at home and abroad in the
The American Stock Exchange declined sharply yesterday along a broad front.
The Commissioner of Buildings, Charles G. Moerdler, fixed new regulations yesterday to curb speculative building on undersized lots that would downgrade established residential communities.

The Securities and Exchange Commission suspended trading yesterday in the common and preferred stock of the J.J. New berry Company because of ques tions the commission raised re garding the "validity" of a ten der offer for the concern's shares.
Three Reform Democrats in the Legislature and one in the City Council have refused to attend a June 3 dinner here honoring President Johnson because they object to Administration policy in Vietnam.

Mayor Lindsay is thoroughly justified in his bitter denunciation of the budgetary changes made by the Board of Estimate and the City Council. Their political handiwork has made a bad fiscal situtation infinitely worse.

ALBANY, May 24 After eight months of entanglement, architectural and engineering contracts to supervise construction of the South Mall complex of state office buildings here have been renegotiated for lower fees, state officials said today.

Unseasonal weather and continued indications of consumer uncertainty adversely affected the first-quarter earnings of several of the leading retail store chains that reported financial results yesterday.
CALCUTTA, India, May 23 At 10:30 on the night of May 11, Sankaracharya Maitra, who runs an ink factory here, promised all his workers a raise of 10 rupees a month.

WASHINGTON, May 24 A television repairman from the Bronx, a kind of Ralph Nader of the roadside, fascinated a Congressional subcommittee today as he offered pictorial evidence of how New York's highways had thousands of death traps built into them.

The Duke and Duchess of Windsor were at the Festival Theater last night for the long-awaited American premiere of "A King's Story," the widely heralded movie about the Duke's life. They were not alone.

WASHINGTON, May 24 In the present issue of Esquire, Gay Talese writes of the agony that John Corry underwent during his efforts as a New York Times reporter to write of the agony that William Manchester underwent in writing and publishing his account of the Kennedy assassination.
WASHINGTON, May 24 Exports rose more than imports in April, thus producing another small increase in the nation's trade surplus, the Commerce Department reported today.
JERUSALEM (Israel), May 24 The children of Jerusalem began today to sandbag their schools as Israeli officials moved to encourage wider participation in the nation's mobilization.

RENO, May 24 Raymond I. Smith, who parlayed a penny ante roulette game and two battered slot machines into a multimillion dollar gambling operation at Harolds Club, died in his sleep today. He was 80 years old. Mr. Smith had been in a hospital for the last 10 days and was being treated for cancer and other ailments.
Reva Rose and Austin Pendleton were named winners yesterday of the 1966-67 Clarence Derwent Awards for the best performances by an actress and an actor in nonfeatured roles.

ROCHESTER, May 24 The president of the Constitutional Convention, Anthony J. Travia, has given his "unconditional" support to a program of court reforms, including the elimination of the Surrogates Courts, the Court of Claims and all justices of the peace.

Young Ron J. Lagoc adjusted the glasses on his sunburned nose and approached the blackboard yesterday with all the authority of a 17-year-old high school senior who had just won a scholarship for building a "spacecraft" that flew from the water tower in his hometown of Oswego, N.Y.
Once again the Ivy League football coaches, at their annual meeting Tuesday, have asked their institutions to take steps toward the restoration of spring practice.
WASHINGTON, May 24 The "real issue," said the Gentleman from Oregon, was "what will be the respective roles of Federal authority, state authority and local authority in education?"
YONKERS, May 24 Starting tomorrow and continuing through July 24, there will be nightly Sundays excluded harness racing at Yonkers Raceway in Westchester County.
WASHINGTON, May 24--The Federal Maritime Commission today ordered a steamship conference unwilling to comply with commission subpoenas to show cause why it should be allowed to stay in business.
Some of the glitter rubbed off the silver futures market yesterday as holders of long positions with good profits sold or partially "fixed" their profits by selling another month.

Thomas J. Wilson, director of the Harvard University Press, will come to the New York publishing house of Atheneum on Jan. 1 as a vice president and a senior editor. The Brpoklyn Savings Bank announced yesterday the election of Willard G. Hampton as president and chief executive officer, effective July 1. Mr. Hampton, a 61 year-old native of Amsterdam, N.Y., will retire as executive vice president of the New York Telephone Company.

The advance that the construction industry appeared to be making in the first quarter of this year had a setback in April, when the value of contracts for future construction declined 13 per cent below the figure a year ago.

WASHINGTON, May 25 Walter Lippmann announced today that he is leaving Washington, but the reader should not be deceived. He is merely going away, as all men should, to the primary interests of his youth back to New York, back to philosophy, back to Europe but he is not really "leaving" Washington.
The first Stars and Stripes All-Star football game, scheduled for June 25 at Frankfurt, Germany, was canceled yesterday.

Stock prices rallied yesterday following Wednesday's broad selloff.

LONDON, May 25 British air-traffic controllers laid down special rules today to avoid collisions in the air over a 53-foot ketch in the Atlantic 300 miles southwest of England.

In a move calculated to discourage his selection in the approaching National Hockey League expansion draft, Bernard (Boom Boom) Geoffrion of the New York Rangers announced yesterday that he would retire as a player rather than report to one of the six new teams.

CLEVELAND, May 25 Charles Luna, president of the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen, in a news conference today, accused Secretary of Labor W. Willard Wirtz and his department of trying to force compulsory arbitration on railroad workers.

SYDNEY, Australia, May 25 New oil discoveries on the Australian mainland, plans to spend millions of dollars developing newly discovered offshore natural gas fields and an agreement between Australia's federal and state governments on offshore drilling rights have brought a revival of interest in oil here.

It snowed in Connecticut yesterday. In New Jersey, wind-driven tides flooded part of the southern shore.
Young Audiences, Inc., a nonprofit organization devoted to bringing live music to children, ended a two-day national conference at the St. Moritz Hotel yesterday, the first in its 18year history.

Mr. and Mrs. George Y.L. Wu of Taipet, Taiwan, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Linda Meirun Wu, to Frank Jung-hsi Liu, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ming-cheng Liu, also of Taipei. The wedding will take place June 25 at the chapel of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in Cambridge, Mass.
The American Stock Exchange announced yesterday that it had developed a computerized system of scrutinizing transactions of all of its member firms in all stocks listed on the exchange.

FAIRFIELD, Iowa, May 25 (UPI) Faculty members at Parsons College here voted almost 2 to 1 last night to ask the board of trustees to dismiss the school's controversial president, Dr. Millard G. Roberts.

Five Gimbels department store employes aided in the arrest yesterday of a Westchester man who tried to pass four $20 American Express traveler's checks, identified as part of a $620,000 shipment of checks stolen last month from a United States Line pier here, the police reported.

The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday obtained a temporary order through the United States District Court in Los Angeles restraining Albert J. Fenster, a Los Angeles apparel company executive, from carrying out a tender offer for the common stock of the J.J. Newberry Co.

NICE, France, May 25 (Reuters) The Earl of Avon, the former Sir Anthony Eden, who was the British Prime Minister during the 1956 Suez crisis, gave his approval today to present American and British stands in the Middle East. He said he believed war could be averted in the new crisis there.
The Amateur Athletic Union will honor Arthur Daley, the sports columnist of The New York Times, at a dinner at the Hotel Americana on Monday, June 5.

NAPLES, May 25 The United States Sixth Fleet's amphibious assault task force of 2,000 marines left Naples this morning for what its commander said would be routine exercises in the western Mediterranean.

Arthur Hull Hayes, president of the Columbia Broadcasting System's radio division for 12 years, resigned yesterday. He will be succeeded by Clark B. George, a divisional vice president and general manager of WCBS-TV (Channel 2).
President Johnson's message to Congress on political campaign expenditures substantially advances the effort to devise a mixed public-and-private system of financing election contests.

A shipment of pep-pill powder worth $1.75-million on the illegal market, said to have been ordered by a 22-year-old Long Island youth, was seized by Federal agents yesterday at a warehouse in Jamaica, Queens.

Loew's Theaters, Inc., is buying 29 movie houses in California and Arizona that belong to Statewide Theaters, a circuit owned by Fred Stein. The acquisition is subject to the ap proval of the Federal District Court in New York.

THE House voted yesterday to restore the 7 per cent investment tax credit and W. Ashley Gray was all smiles. "I feel like I just made the winning touchdown in a long, hard football game," he said.

WASHINGTON, May 25 Two dozen aroused members of Congress warned today that up to one million families in the New York metropolitan area would have their television reception blacked out or seriously scrambled for two to three years if the World Trade Center was built.

A union of handymen, doormen, custodians and elevator operators announced last night that it would strike 1,500 apartment buildings in Manhattan today, most of them rent-controlled. CARLISLE, Pa., May 25 A lawsuit seeking to suppress the judgment of a historian that Henry Clay Frick was a wagecutting industrial autocrat was dismissed today by Judge Clinton R. Weidner of the Cumberland County Court of Common Pleas.

WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP) The Senate used only a few minutes today to stamp final Congressional approval on a catch-all supplemental money bill appropriating more than $2billion, including $75-million more for the President's special summer program for jobless youths.

SYDNEY, Australia, May 25 (AP) Australia's challenger for the America's Cup, Dame Pattie, was loaded onto a giant freighter today along with thousands of cans of beer and enough food to feed a regiment for two months.
Gov. George Romney of Michigan urged the Federal Government yesterday to exercise restraint in regulating economic activities.
PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., May 25 Round Hill, of Greenwich, Conn., representing Westchester, won the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's intersectional team championship today.

FORT JACKSON, S.C., May 25 The first attempt in a United States military court to raise the war crimes doctrine of Nuremberg as a defense against the charge of willful disobedience was shot down today.

OKLAHOMA CITY, May 25 (AP) Jack Rule Jr., who hasn't taken a professional tour tournament since winning here in 1965, and Kermit Zarley, who has never won a tour event, shared the first-round lead of the $66,000 Oklahoma City open today with three-under-par 69's.

ALBANY, May 25--The State Board of Canvassers certified today that the election for a Bronx district delegate to the Constitutional Convention had ended in a tie and passed the problem on to the convention.

Miss Elizabeth Ann Murchison, assistant curator of the Curtis Museum in Alton, Hampshire, England, and H. Van Kirk Reeves, a lawyer with Coudert Brothers in their Paris office, plan to marry late next month in England.

A chase at speeds up to 80 miles an hour through the northeast Bronx ended last night when three burglary suspects were captured and the body of a nude woman was found in the trunk of their car.

Clergymen in many parts of the country, impressed by the establishment of an abortion service here by 21 Protestant ministers and rabbis, are making plans to set up similar organizations in their own areas.
The Citizens Budget Commission yesterday described Mayor Lindsay's budget dispute with City Hall Democrats as overblown.

Prayers are to be offered in synagogues tomorrow for peace in the Middle East.
Two unmanned fishing trawlers broke loose from a Yorkers dock in a high wind and heavy tide yesterday afternoon and drifted down the Hudson River.
WASHINGTON, May 25 A group of distinguished scientists took a strong stand today against the orbiting of giant reflectors that might light the Vietnamese jungles at night to spotlight the enemy.

The head of one of the nation's leading shipping trade associations pointed yesterday to an "ironic aspect" of the deadlock over future Federal shipping policy. He offered a 14-point analysis designed to help break the impasse.
BOISE, Idaho, May 25 For at least the last two years about eight conservatives have been subsidized secretly in propaganda and political activities in 11 western states.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., May 25 Ira Hawkins, a lawyer who specialized in public-utility law and was a senior partner in Simpson Thacher Bartlett of 120 Broadway in New York, died of a heart attack today in his home here at 15 Hemlock Road. He was 72 years old.
PARIS, May 25 (AP) Sergei Likhachev of the Soviet Union and Ken Fletcher of Australia led the way into the third round today in the rain-delayed French tennis championships.
George Rowland Stanley Baring, the third Earl of Cromer and formerly governor of the Bank of England, was elected yesterday to the board of the Union Carbide Corporation.
Secretary General Thant returned last night from a quick peace-making visit to Cairo. He would not say what he thought he might have accomplished.

Moving along in last place through most of the going, Spooky Joe released a powerful closing rally that enabled him to carry the silks of Milton Ritzenberg to success in the $11,300 Hitchcock Steeplechase Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 25 Israel's Foreign Minister, Abba Eban, flew here today to seek assurances that the United States would keep the Gulf of Aqaba open to international shipping. He spoke of an American commitment to do so.

Three new directors have been elected to the board of the Foreign Policy Association, Emile E. Soubry, chairman, announced yesterday.
AKRON, Ohio, May 25 (AP) A campaign against the purchase of products made by three struck rubber companies is being conducted by the United Rubber Workers.
Former Police Commissioner Vincent L. Broderick said yesterday that the State Constitution should protect citizens from unreasonable searches by health and welfare officials as well as the police.
About 1,000 laboratory and mortuary workers in municipal hospitals will strike on June 8 unless the city guarantees job security in its contracts with affiliated hospitals.
WASHINGTON, May 25 (UPI) The House voted to stop the paychecks of Government workers who incite riots or promote any civil disturbance.

ATHENS, May 25 Nine deputies belonging to the Center Union party were quietly arrested yesterday. The Government has not announced the arrests yet, although it is expected to. The arrests bring to 19 the number of party Deputies in jail.

Rudolf Serkin and his Steinway piano paid a visit to an East Side town house last night, The pianist arrived in a taxi, the piano came in Mr. Serkin's private truck. It was a night unlike most for either one.
CHAPPAQUA, N.Y., May 25 William A. Smyth, an auctioneer and appraiser with the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue, New York, died in his home here today. His age was 69.

OTTAWA, May 25 President Johnson paid a quick visit to Canada today to see the gay dome of the United States exhibit at Expo 67 and to discuss the Middle East and Vietnam with Prime Minister Lester B. Pearson at lunch.

MEXICO CITY, May 25 Tennis has been added to the official program of sports for the Olympic Games to be held here in 1968, it was stated today by Francisco Guerrero Arcocha, president of the Mexican Tennis Federation.

A 1965 law giving Federal aid to elementary and secondary schools was challenged in Federal Court here yesterday by four groups who contended that it violated the church-state separation guarantee of the First Amendment.

MORE skill and imagination goes into the New York Philharmonics Promenade Concerts than most people realize. The popular series opened its fifth season last night at Philharmonic Hall after a preview Wednesday.
Prices rebounded yesterday on the American Stock Exchange, erasing about one-half of Wednesday's losses.
RIVERHEAD. L.I., May 25--A self-help housing plan for migrant farm workers, described as the first in the state, was approved today by the Federal Office of Economic Opportunity.

LAGOS, Nigeria, May 25 Northern Nigerian troops are being withdrawn from Nigeria's Western region as a part of a broad plan to reduce tension in a nation torn by sectionalism.
LISBON, May 25 (AP) Glasgow Celtic of Scotland rallied to defeat Internazionale Milan oF Italy, 2-1, today and become the first British team to take the European soccer Cup of Champions.
NONGKHAI, Thailand, May 19 "They are very quiet these days," said the middleaged Thai official.

Lord Mancroft, deputy chairman of Cunard Line, said here last night that the British steamship line was seriously considering a proposal from Long Beach, Calif., authorities for the purchase of the 81,237ton liner Queen Mary.

WASHINGTON, May 25 The House passed tonight a bill extending the draft for four years but restricting President Johnson's authority to draft college undergraduates and to set up a selective service lottery. The vote was 362 to 9.

New contract agreements providing wage increases of 15 per cent for 27,000 workers in the women's and children's sportswear industries over the next three years were announced yesterday by the International Ladies Garment Workers Union.
The pressmen and The New York Times continued negotiations on a new contract yesterday, but failed to resolve differences over wage schedules for junior pressmen.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., May 25 (AP) Constance Cippollone broke into hysterical sobs on the witness stand in Dutchess County Court today when she was abruptly accused of the murder for which her boy friend is on trial.

Thirty-six years after he wrote his first newspaper column, Walter Lippmann announced yesterday that, tired of the pressure of remaining "continually and closely on the alert, so attentive, so up to the minute," he was stopping his regular newspaper pieces.
CHICAGO, May 26 The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. said today that he intended to "stir up trouble" in some of the major cities of the United States this summer.
PEKING, May 25 (Reuters) A Chinese spokesman announced support today for the United Arab Republic and accused the Soviet Union of collaborating with the United States in the Middle East crisis.

Ronny Graham will write the book for "Alley Oop,' a musical based on the cave-man comic strip by V.T. Hamlin. It will be produced for Broadway next season by David Sheldon.
WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP) Plans to lay up the nuclear ship Savannah were blocked today by the House Appropriations Committee.

ROME, May 25 Pope Paul VI, deploring the "wind of storms" blowing over the Middle East, called today for prayers to "exorcise the scourge of new conflict."

MONTREAL, May 25 (Canadian Press) President Zalman Shazar of Israel declared tonight that the Arab threat against his country was "an act of unprovoked aggression against a people whose only desire is to be left in peace and quiet."

AYR, Scotland, May 25 (AP) John Panton, a 50-year-old Scot, won the British Seniors' golf title today and the right to play Sam Snead of the United States in the world senior championship.

The proposed Election Reform Act of 1967 is corrective, remedying present inadequacies in the law. It goes hand in hand with the pursuit of another goal to provide public support for election campaigns.

WASHINGTON, May 25 (UPI) Senator Edward W. Brooks, said today that President Johnson's campaign against poverty was an administrative nightmare while the urban poor were becoming "a violent and revolutionary underclass."
Albert Appleton Lane, coowner of the Lane Paper Company in Cranford, N.J., died Wednesday in his home at 1711 Perch Hole Point, Point Pleasant, N.J. He was 70 years old.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, May 26 Fighting broke out anew yesterday inside the demilitarized zone between North and South Vietnam, United States military spokesmen disclosed today.

A $72-million urban-renewal plan in a 20-block area of Brownsville, Brookyn, was approved yesterday by the City Planning Commission.

Hopes were raised yesterday about easing tension in the Middle East, and grain prices went down but not by much. Some other Key commodities in world futures trading also drifted down.

George Rios, a 27-year-old Puerto Rican, picked up a piece of chalk and printed "Spic" on the blackboard. Most of the 20 Puerto Rican teenagers sitting around him looked shocked.

PITTSBURGH, May 26 (AP) --Plans were approved today for a merger of North American Aviation, Inc., RockwellStandard Corporation and Draper Corporation.

The New School Opera Workshop, which has been conducting an informal festival of nightly performances this week, ended the series last night with a program of four contemporary works and excerpts from a fifth.

CAIRO, May 26--One hundred and forty American women and children left here by plane tonight for Athens as the evacuation of dependents of United States Embassy personnel in Egypt began. A further 291 dependents are scheduled to leave in a day or two.

THE menu on the wall read: vegetable soup 10 cents; beef stew 35 cents; sandwiches: salami 25 cents, peanut butter 10 cents. However, at cloth-covered and flowerdecked tables on a recent evening, jacketed waiters served stuffed veal birds, pilaf, green beans with mushrooms and bisque tortoni.

VALENCIA, Venezuela, May 26 (UPI)--Governor Rockefeller of New York said here today that he might retire from politics when his term expires in 1970. However, he said such a possibility depends on "circumstances."
Enforcement of a Federal law banning job discrimination because of sex has been difficult and frequently impossible, a Federal civil-rights official said yesterday.
In a witty and forceful opinion a Pennsylvania judge has struck down the misguided attempt of Helen Clay Frick to alter her father's posthumous reputation by censoring history.

ITHACA, N.Y. May 26-- More than half-a-century ago, a multimillionaire industrialist, philanthropist and sportsman presented his wife with a wedding present. It was a 66-room house on a 25-acre estate in New Haven.

What looked like the perfect oil-industry corporate marriage was called off yesterday as Amerada Petroleum Corporation and the Ashland Oil and Refining Company announced the termination of their negotiations for consolidation.
TORONTO, May 26--The Ontario Securities Commission cleared the way today for an 11 per cent increase in securities commission rates across Canada, effective July 1.
Jerome S. Hollender, a vice president of Shearson, Hammill Co., Inc., stockbrokers of 14 Wall Street, died Thursday in his home at 150 East 69th Street. His age was 35.

WASHINGTON, May 26 (Reuters)--The International Monetary Fund announced today that it transferred yesterday to eight countries the money from Britain's advance repayment to the fund of $405million on outstanding drawings.

The Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor has started proceedings against a second stevedoring contractor in its campaign against the paying of what it believes are illegal commissions in the handling of ship cargo.

A 6-year-old drummer almost made his debut at a jazz concert at the Carnegie Recital Hall last night.
LAGOS, Nigeria ,May 26-- The Governor of Nigeria's Eastern Region, Lieut. Col. Odumegwu Ojukwu, called on Eastern representatives today to give him a mandate for declaring the region's independence.
CAIRO, May 26--The present crisis in the Middle East is not a problem of international law, President Nasser said in his speech tonight.
WASHINGTON, May 26--Unusual clusters of leukemia cases among unrelated persons who lived in the same houses have been reported by the United States Public Health Service.
The spot rate on the pound sterling cased yesterday in moderate trading here. The closing rate of $2.7946 was 10 points below the day before.
The Brooklyn Public Library is honoring the favorite month for wedding bells with an exhibition on "Love and Marriage," a show of old and new mementos and lore that will run through June 25.

CHICAGO, May 26--Judges Herbert C. Paschen said today that he would delay sentencing of Richard F. Speck for 30 days to permit specialists to examine the convicted murderer for brain damage.

Don Cardwell, a North Carolina boy who recoils from cold weather, survived the twin terrors of New York's spring gales and the hard-hitting Atlanta Braves last night.

WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) --The American Civil Liberties Union is looking into the procedures followed by the Senate ethics committee in its investigation of misconduct charges against Senator Thomas J. Dodd.

The Lindsay administration's proposals for provisions in a new state Constitution were subjected yesterday to the scrutiny of former Mayor Robert F. Wagner and former Controller Abraham D. Beame.

WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP)--Missouri asked the Supreme Court today to establish the state's right to land near the Missouri River being claimed by Nebraska.

PARIS, May 26 (UPI)-- President de Gaulle today opened an air show here dominated by United States-Soviet rivalry in the field of rocketry and winged aircraft.

Prices edged higher on the London Stock Exchange yesterday as trading volume picked up.

The New York City Department of Health, with a long tradition of outstanding leadership in the public health field, has fallen on evil days.
