BIRMINGHAM, Ala.--From a distance it is easy to make broad, resounding statements about the quality of intellectual and cultural life in Alabama. The view from the state's largest city is more complicated. Paradox and contrast are to be found on all sides.
Iberia Airlines of Spain has announced it will negotiate with the Boeing Aircraft Company for the purchase of three 747 jumbo jets. The purchase is subject to U.S. Government approval.

EDISON, N.J., May 28--A 3-year-old wirehaired fox terrier, Ch. Wintor Caracus Call Boy was named best in show today at the silver anniversary event of the Plainfield Kennel Club at the Raritan Center. The terrier, owned by J.R.T. Alford of Pinos Altos, N.M., was handled by Tom Gately.

Tens of thousands of art buyers jammed the streets of Greenwich village yesterday to view the 71st Washington Square Outdoor Art Exhibit, while strollers in Harlem and in the Village itself contemplated two rival shows.

PURCHASE, N.Y., May 28 --The New Haven Polo Club, defeated the Blind Brook team, in the opening game of the season at Blind Brook Polo Club today on Frank (Butch) Butterworth 3d's fourth goal of the game with 2 minutes 45 seconds left to play.

Mrs Anna Darby Merrill, an author of children's books and a former teacher, died yesterday in her home, at 44 West 69th Street, at the age of 85. She was the widow of George Bushnell Merrill, a Boy Scout executive in Providence, R.I.

MONTREAL, May 28--The building of a ballet company is a work of love and years. The Australian Ballet, which, as part of Expo 67's World Festival, has just made its North American debut at the Place des Arts here, is only 4 years old. Its progress in so short a time is amazing, for here, to all ...

PHILADELPHIA, May 28 (UPI)--Lou Brock slammed three hits and Roger Maris drove in two runs with a single and a triple today as the St. Louis Cardinals collected 13 hits and beat the Philadelphia Phillies, 8-3.

MILAN, Italy, May 28-- Luigi Longo, leader of the Italian Communist party, today reiterated Communist support for the United Arab Republic against the "intrigue" of American oil "imperialists" in the Middle East. He also called for the expulsion of the United States Sixth Fleet from Italian ports.
Council Majority Leader David Ross scoffed yesterday at a Lindsay administration charge that cuts by the City. He asserted that a $23-million cut in the reserve fund for ger a tax increase."

WASHINGTON, May 28--The head of the Rabbinical Assembly, an influential world association of conservative rabbis, called today for the abolition of the Geneva Convention so that war could be seen as a "denial of God," and not a "game to be played by gentlemanly rules."

Miss Frederica Komanoff, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Isidore Komanoff of Long Beach, L.I., was married last evening to Frank Miceli of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Salvatore Miceli of Sayville, L.I. Judge Maurice Bernhardt of the Family Court of Brooklyn performed the ceremony at the Plaza.

VERONA, N.J., May 28-- Miss Terri Millicent Agriss, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norton Agriss, was married this evening to Robert Peter Aaronson, son of Mrs. Ether Aaronson of Woodside, Queens, and the late Ira Aaronson. Rabbi Sydney Boner performed the ceremony at the Richfield Caterers.

State Tax Commissioner Joseph H. Murphy said yesterday that he would "feel easier" if the state had more outlets for its forthcoming lottery. He indicated that if the present outlets proved inadequate, he might ask the Legislature next year to add such new ones as department stores, liquor stores, and auto service stations.

About 80 French short films produced over the last two decades will be presented at the Museum of Modern Art today through June 15 and from July 17 through Aug. 4. Only about 20 of them have been shown in theaters here.

The appointment of Frank Aikman Jr. as president and general manager of the Long Island Rail Road was announced yesterday. He succeeds Thomas M. Goodfellow, who has been named president of the Association of American Railroads.

Buildings Commissioner Charles G. Moerdler said yesterday that within two weeks he would submit to Mayor Lindsay a "one-stop" method of approving building plans that he said would speed construction and reduce corruption.

NEXT to advice to the lovelorn, perhaps the most popular newspaper feature is the kind that contains household hints. It generally offers friendly, cheerful counsel ("Don't discard that steam iron; use it for a doorstop") on such matters as how to make instant miniskirts and what to do with empty coffee cans.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., May 28 --Mrs. Ruth Howlett Norton, director of adult studies at C. W. Post College of Long Island University, Brookville, died yesterday at Huntington Hospital. She was 40 years old and lived at Lloyd Neck.

DALLAS, Tex., May 28--The place of the modern layman in the Roman Catholic Church is being tested in the Dallas suburb of Richardson, where laymen have organized to protest the bishop's removal of four Paulist priests.

WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) --Agriculture Department scientists foresee amazing breakthroughs in agricultural practices through application of remote sensing techniques developed in conjunction with the space program.
Mrs. Jane West Walton, widow of Capt. Duncan Walton of the Naval Medical Corps, died yesterday of cancer in her apartment at the Wales Hotel, Madison Avenue and 93d Street. She was 70 years old.

It may be a tribute to the New York City Transit Authority that insurance companies are no longer asked to write policies specifically for subway travel. But, as the range and frequency of business and vacation travel widens, many thoughtful people are interested in accident and health insurance during a trip.
PHILADELPHIA, May 28 (AP)--More than 2,700 Philadelphia longshoremen have divided a $744,000 royalty fund, ending an issue that snarled work on the waterfront for two days earlier this year.
ATLANTA, May 28--An erratic pattern of racial progress and recalcitrance covers the South like a crazy quilt now that the civil rights movement has collapsed in the region.

LONDON, May 28 (Reuters) A crowd of 10,000 person, to day attended a "solidarity with Israel" rally in Hyde Park here, as leaders of world Judaism called on the West to support the Jewish state in the current Middle East crisis.

Mr. and Mrs. Edmund Patrick Coffey of 360 West 22d Street have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Monica Evelyn Coffey, to Richard Eryan McCormick, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard B. McCormick of West Falls, N.Y.
A Memorial Day service at sea, some 2,000 miles east of here, is scheduled for 11 A.M. tomorrow in honor of merchant seamen who gave their lives for their country.

AMMAN, Jordan, May 28-- King Hussein declared in an interview today that the chances of war between Israel and the Arabs had now reached their peak. "It could be a matter of days, it could be a matter of hours," he said.

PHILADELPHIA, May 28 (AP)--A large section of a highway bridge came down on the top of a Pennsylvania Railroad freight train here today after the train apparently ripped loose some steel supports under the roadway.
WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP)--A large wheat crop is in prospect this year in the Northern Hemisphere, raising the possibility that a record tonnage may be available for export markets.

TEL AVIV, May 28 (Reuters) --Premier Eshkol said in his address that the Israeli Cabinet had outlined policy lines intended to "obviate the necessity of Israel having to use her armed forces for her defense."
SAN FRANCISCO, May 28 (AP)--The Golden Gate Gales scored a resounding 6-1 victory over the Vancouver Royals today in the opening match of the new United Soccer Association scheduled at Kezar Stadium.

FORMBY, England, May 28 (UPI)--The British Amateur Golf championship opens tomorrow and Bill Campbell is favored to win the title and give the United States its first title in five years. The historic meet, which was first held in 1885, was won last year by Bobby Cole of South Africa, who has since turned pro.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 28--Secretary General Thant disclosed today that the first major stage in the withdrawal of United Nations forces from the Gaza Strip is scheduled to be completed by tomorrow with the airlift of the 720 Canadians to Italy.
OTTAWA, May 28 (Canadian Press)--Work will start June 9 on a $110-million project to build a eight-mile section of the Welland Canal, the St. Lawrence Seaway Authority has announced.

The City Commission on Human Rights has ordered the owner of a house in Whitestone, Queens, to offer it for sale to a Jewish man to whom it had been refused, and to stop discriminating because of race, color, creed or national origin.

GREENWICH, Conn., May 28 --Llewellyn S. Howe sailed his Flying Scot sloop, Aeolus, to victory today on Long Island Sound in the Belle Haven Club regatta, the third of the Yacht Racing Association's series for fleets based east-of-Rye. Aeolus won by 40 seconds and about 10 lengths.
AQABA, Jordan, May 28 (AP)--Two Israeli patrol boats sped out of Elath in the Gulf of Aqaba at sunset today and two Jordanian patrol boats carrying 20-mm. guns left Aqaba in pursuit 14 minutes later.

OKLAHOMA CITY, May 28 (AP)--Miller Barber, who had won only one tournament in nine years on the professional golf tour, ended a suddendeath playoff with Gary Player today by sinking a birdie on the third hole to capture the Oklahoma City open golf tournament.

CAIRO, Monday, May 29-- President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic declared last night that a negotiated peace in the Middle East was out of the question until Palestinian Arabs returned to their homeland--part of which is now Israel--and exercised sovereignty there.

PITTSBURGH, May 28-- The United Steelworkers of America, after trying for 30 years, has won its fight to organize production employes at the Mesta Machine Company in West Homestead, a mill town southeast of Pittsburgh.

ADENAU, Germany, May 28 (AP)--Udo Schuetz of Germany and Joe Buzetta of Smithtown, L.I., sped to victory in their 2-liter Porsche today in the grueling 622-mile Nuerburgring race for sports cars and prototypes.
John Ross Martin of 1158 Fifth Avenue, chairman of the board of the former firm of Davis, Collamore Co., importers of fine china, died here Saturday.

Atlantic Container Line has announced the launching of the second unit of a 10-vessel fleet, which is on order for the line's North Atlantic containership operations and scheduled to begin operations later this year.

STAMFORD, Conn., May 28--About 50 revived birds, including scarlet tanagers, warblers and rose-breasted grosbeaks, were released from the Stamford Museum and Nature Center today to continue their migration northward.

DUCPHO, South Vietnam, May 28--Circling over burning and burned-out houses this morning in his command helicopter, the colonel muttered: "We'll get a hundred of them by the time we've finished counting."

BOSTON, May 28 (AP)-- Robert H.W. Welch Jr., the founder and president of the John Birch Society, said today the right-wing organization had dropped plans to enlist one million members and would aim instead at "concentrated action."

The marriage of Miss Mary Harriet Rose, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Rose of Laurelton, Queens, to Dr. Theodore Ronald Kornreich took place here yesterday. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Kornreich, also of Laurelton. Rabbi Edward Singer performed the ceremony at the Rose home.

MADISON, N.J., May 28-- Dr. John Patterson, professor emeritus of Hebrew and Old Testament Exegesis at Drew University, died today in Morristown Memorial Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived in Florham Park.

That continuing process known as the "Americanization of Europe" has seen the supermarket, the hot dog, the twist and other folkways transplanted across the Atlantic. Now another item has been added-- the motel.

Commercial space in the Pan Am Building atop Grand Central Terminal has been completely rented with the leasing of the final store unit to Charles Plohn Co., an investment banking and securities firm, which will establish its fourth office in the 59-story skyscraper.
BUENOS AIRES, May 28 (Reuters)--Ecuador swept to an easy 4-1 victory over Argentina in their American Zone Davis Cup tennis series here today.

STAMFORD, Conn., May 28 --Palawan, the third yacht of that name to be owned by Thomas J. Watson Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., won the Storm Trysail Club's 200-mile race around Block Island. The 58foot cutter finished the event last night at 7:44 o'clock, but ...

SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 28--United States jets cut three rail lines in North Vietnam yesterday, hitting one at a point about 40 miles from the Chinese border, the United States Command reported today. It said ground fire had brought down one United States plane.

NEW DELHI, May 28--The curtailment of development spending in the balanced budget that the Finance Minister, Morarji Desai, presented last week has come close to reducing India's fourth Five Year Plan to a document on a shelf.
WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) --Eugene Fodor Jr., a 17-yearold violinist from Golden, Colo., won first place last night in the National Symphony's 11th annual contest for young violinists and cellists.

TOKYO, May 28--American businessmen interested in Japanese investment opportunities are studying the possible implication of an agreement whereby the Japanese Government has permitted the H.J. Heinz Company to acquire the majority stock in a joint venture with a local concern.
ENTEBBE, Uganda, May 26 --President Milton Obote entertained Under Secretary of State Nicholas deB. Katzenbach here tonight with a spectacular blend of African tribalism and European sophistication.

Miss Linda Kay Daro-Dawidowicz, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Simon Daro-Dawidowicz of New York and Bogota, Colombia, was married here yesterday afternoon to Wallace Robert Hodges, son of Mr. and Mrs. Wallace R. Hodges of Rochester, Mich. Rabbi David A. Seligson of the Central Synagogue performed the ceremony in the Carlyle.
MIAMI BEACH, May 28-- The world championship hopes of the North American team receded here this afternoon when it lost heavily to the famous Italian Blue team.

Thirty-two American university professors have sent an appeal to President Rene Barrientos Ortuno of Bolivia expressing concern for the fate of Jules Regis Debray, a 26-yearold French Marxist journalist charged with aiding anti-Government guerrillas in Bolivia.
Important battles over zoning are being fought in New York's suburbs. The outcome will determine the physical environment of the communities and, to a large extent, their quality of life.

FAIRBANKS, Alaska, May 28--The Defense Department is proceeding with plans to set off a series of deep underground nuclear tests within the next two or three years at Amchitka Island, in the Aleutian chain.

ROME, May 28 (Reuters)-- Leaders of the European Common Market were scheduled to meet here tomorrow for two days to hail the success of the six-nation trade group in its first 10 years of life and to lay the groundwork for even greater European unity.

Abe who? That's what several thousand people within 20 miles of Kingspoint, on Long Island's north shore, may have been asking at 7 P.M. yesterday, after a sky-writer spelled out "Happy Birthday Abe" 10,000 feet over the town.
CHARLOTTE, N.C., May 28 (AP)--Jim Paschal, a 41-yearold driver, won the World 800mile stock car race today in record time.
ATHENS, May 28-The military junta, or at least one faction of it, has been seeking to make it clear in the last few days that it intends to establish a long-term dictatorship in Greece.

LOS ANGELES, May 28 (AP) --George E. Stone, a character actor best known for his gangster roles, died Friday at the Motion Picture Country House and Hospital in Woodland Hills, Calif. He was 64 years old.
KANSAS CITY, May 28 (AP)--A three-run third inning and a four-run eighth gave the Kansas City Athletics a 7-2 victory over the Minnesota Twins and a split of their double-header today.

A strike by teachers here next September was called "pracrtically inevitable" yesterday by their union president because of the Board of Education's failure as yet to make any offer on salaries or major union proposals for educational improvements.
DOMODOSSOLA, Italy, May 28 (Reuters)--The French avant-garde writer Jean Genet was recovering in a hospital here today after taking a larger than usual dose of sleeping pills followed by cognac.
LONDON, May 28--Danger and exhaustion were the companions of Sir Francis Chichester for much of his solitary 28,500-mile circumnavigation of the globe in his 53-foot ketch, the Gipsy Moth IV.
WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP)--Senator John J. Williams said today that the best way to reduce the cost of presidential election campaigns would be to shorten the campaign period.
Jim Hines of Texas Southern and Dave Patrick of Villanova have much in common.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., May 28--President Johnson sought a few hours of relaxation at his ranch near here today, ap parently hoping that the Middle East tensions of the last week may yet be abated by diplomatic rather them military action.

Braniff International, which until early last summer did not have a single all-cargo service in operation, is planning to add four all-cargo jet flights this summer between New York and cities on the airline's South American routes.

A shattering blow to the city's right to preserve landmarks of historic or architectural merit has been delivered by a recent decision of the State Supreme Court. Over the objections of the Landmarks Preservation Commission, Justice Charles G. Tierney has authorized the trustees of Sailors Snug Harbor to demolish an extraordinary group of Greek Revival buildings, one of the city's finest examples of this handsome architectural style.

MIAMI, May 28 (AP)--John Hornor won overall honors and his day-old national speed record for unlimited outboard pleasure craft survived by 3 seconds today in the finals of the international invitation regatta here.
WASHINGTON, May 28-- Following are the votes of delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on the major roll-calls in Congress during the week ended yesterday:
The Northrop Corporation, the aerospace concern, announced over the weekend the election of Clair L. Peck Jr. as a director, increasing the board to 11 members.
Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public that will mature within 12 months amount to $97,874,960,847. They consist of Treasury securities as follows:

LOS ANGELES, May 28-- Since last fall the engineering department of the University of California, Los Angeles, has been quietly guiding 30 Negro high school students from the Watts area; scene of riots in 1965, in designing a scale model for a proposed $1-million entertainment park.

EL ARISH, United Arab Republic, May 28 (AP)--Egypt moved fresh troops and armor into the northern sector of the Sinai border today, apparently in the belief it would become the scene of a major clash if war with Israel comes.
PLYMOUTH, England, May 28--Gipsy Moth IV was designed by Illingworth Primrose of Emsworth, Hampshire, and built by Camper Nicholson, Ltd., of Gosport, Hampshire.

There is good reason for the high spirits of the negotiators who participated in the Kennedy Round. Their agreement not only confounded the pessimists who had been predicting a breakdown in the talks but exceeded the expectations of the optimists, whose hopes were surprisingly modest.
WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) --A 24-year-old Maryland man, the son of a prominent Washington physician, is being held without bail, accused of the rape-slaying of a Capitol Hill research assistant.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, May 28-- Under an agreement signed with the state-owned Petroleum Corporation of Ceylon, the International Cooperative Petroleum Association of the United States will set up a lubricating blending plant here.
LONDON, May 28--"He travels the fastest who travels alone." Rudyard Kipling might have written the line for Sir Francis Chichester.
The luxury liner Michelangelo, flagship of the Italian merchant marine, is scheduled to receive the traditional harbor welcome today when she arrives on her maiden call to Quebec City.
ALBANY, May 28--A total of $22-million in construction and facilities was added to State University campuses in the first four months of this year.

JERSEY CITY, May 28-- Msgr. John J. Cain, pastor of St. Bartholomew's Roman Catholic Church in Scotch Plains since 1960, died today of a heart attack shortly after he delivered the baccalaureate address at Seton Hall University in South Orange. He was 49 years old.

LIMA, Peru, May 28 (Reuters)--Commercial banks here were ordered to cut credit by 50 per cent to 20 large foreign companies within 30 days in a new move to shore up Peru's troubled economy, it was announced here over the weekend.

WASHINGTON, May 28-- United States officials said tonight that they thought the Middle Eastern situation had passed a critical stage in the last 24 hours, giving diplomats more time to try to reach a settlement without war.

THE Yonkers Grand Master Arthur Bisguier, with a rousing finish, won the recent second Westchester Open Chess Championship. By scoring 5 - in this six-round Swiss system at the Roger Smith Hotel, White Plains, Bisguier topped a strong 73man field.

MOORESTOWN, N.J., May 28--Dr. Atwood H. Townsend, professor emeritus of English at the New York University School of Engineering, died yesterday at the Cinnaminson Manor Hospital. He was 70 years old and had lived here since his retirement in 1961.
Despite the Memorial Day holiday and the Bond Club of New York outing Friday, a substantial volume of new corporate bond issues is expected to be offered for sale this week.

CLEVELAND, May 28-- Mickey Mantle's 11th home run of the season, Charlie Smith's first homer and five-hit pitching by Mel Stottlemyre enabled the New York Yankees to salvage a 5-0 victory today from a three-game series with the Cleveland Indians.

DENISON, Iowa, May 28 (UPI)--Fifty-seven students at Midwestern College appeared in Mayor's Court today on charges of disturbing the peace after two nights of campus disturbances that included the burning of some textsbooks.
BOSTON, May 28 (AP)-- Some 3,500 Boston University students received degrees today and heard Dr. Harold C. Case make his last formal address as university president.

DETROIT, May 28, (AP)-- Denny McLain pitched the Detroit Tigers to a 3-1 victory today over the Washington Senators before 52,357 fans-- the largest crowd in the major leagues this year. The triumph was the fifth of the season for McLain, who struck out 10.
TEL AVIV, May 28--The mobilization of Israel's armed forces is having a substantial impact on her economy.

Eastern Nigeria is now performing a frightening exercise in brinkmanship. The Governor, Lieut. Col. Ojukwu, has received authority from his Consultative Assembly to declare the region independent of the central Government in Lagos.
TEL AVIV, May 28--Premier Levi Eshkol indicated tonight that Israel would continue to negotiate with the major powers to find ways to reopen the Strait of Tiran to Israeli shipping.
Cardinal Spellman yesterday called upon the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York to observe tomorrow as a day of prayer for permanent peace, as requested by President Johnson.
HANNIBAL, Mo., May 28 (AP)--An 18-day search for three boys believed lost in one of the hundreds of caves that honeycomb this Mississippi River town was called off today.

DETROIT, May 28 (AP)-- The Detroit Tigers gave Johnny Klippstein, a pitcher, his unconditional release today and optioned Jake Wood, an infielder, and George Korince, a pitcher, to Toledo of the International League.
BALTIMORE, May 28--The Social Security Administration intends to stop nursing homes from taking advance payments from Medicare patients.
TEL AVIV, May 28--Party leaders inside and outside Premier Levi Eshkol's Government coalition have been urging the transfer of Mr. Eshkol's defense portfolio to one of two Israeli war heroes.

GENEVA, May 28--Secretary General Thant said tonight in a televised address to the Pacem in Terris conference here that the failure of governments to comply with their international obligations might bring another world war.
The apartment house strike has turned into a duel over rent control between landlords and City Hall. There is nothing resembling a conventional labor dispute at issue.

SAVANNAH, Ga., May 28-- Miss Davida Miriam Tenenbaum, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Meyer Warren Tenenbaum, was married this morning to Alvin Deutsch, of New York and Hadlyme, Conn. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo Deutsch of Forest Hills, Queens, New York.
Tommy Davis and Joe Torre turned a double-header at Shea Stadium into a Battle of Brooklyn yesterday.
PITTSBURGH, May 28 (AP) --Donn Clendenon's sacrifice fly scored Willie Stargell with the winning run in the eighth inning today as the Pittsburgh Pirates defeated the Cincinnati Reds, 3-2.

Exploding almost immediately with their carioca style of South American soccer, and then slowed to waltz time by the heat and the hard Yankee Stadium turf, the Cerro team from Montevideo, Uruguay, made as impressive entrance yesterday into the United Soccer Association.
CANTON, Conn., May 28 (AP)--Dr. Gilbert Whipple Heublein, a radiologist and a member of a family known in medicine and business, died yesterday at his home. He was 58 years old.

WASHINGTON, May 28--On the office wall of the junior Senator from South Dakota is a framed certificate bearing two printed words: "Why Vietnam?" Beneath these is bold handwriting that proclaims: "To George McGovern in my search for peace not only in Vietnam but in all the world. Lyndon B. Johnson."

PARIS, May 28 (AP)--Rosemary Casals of San Francisco was the only one of three American women to advance today to the third round of the rain-plagued French international tennis tournament. Miss Casals, seeded No. 5, defeated Monica Giorgi of Italy, 6-4 6-4.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 28-- Syria and Iraq signed a military agreement today for cooperation of their armies against Israel, according to the Damascus radio, monitored here.
WASHINGTON, May 28 (UPI)--A sampling of Senate mail on the resolution to censure Senator Thomas J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, shows public interest to be light, with opinion divided on his guilt.
TORONTO, May 28--A further integration of the Canadian and United States economies through increased trade and product specialization is foreseen by observers here as ...

The Maritime Association of the Port of New York has announced the election of Walter E. Maloney, a partner in the law firm of Bigham, Englar, Jones Houston, as president of the 93year-old trade association for the coming fiscal year. He succeeds Edward J. Barber, president of Barber Steamship Lines.

LAST night's live satellite edition of "Meet the Press" turned out to be a fiasco on the National Broadcasting Company network. The program in which seven world figures were interviewed in Geneva in connection with the "Pacem in Terris" conference was plagued by sound difficulties and lamentable production arrangements.
A PUCCI dress is just about worth its weight in gold (five ounces of Pucci, $155 to $180; five ounces of gold, $175). And like gold, apparently one can never have enough.

ST. CATHARINES, Ont., May 28--Jim Dietz of St. Helena's High School, the Bronx, won his third straight Canadian singles sculling championship today defeating George Przygocki of Theodore Roosevelt High School of Wyandotte, Mich.

Antoinette Sibley and Anthony Dowell were fatally swept along in an uncomprehending delirium of love at the season's last performance of the Royal Ballet's "Romeo and Juliet" on Saturday night at the Metropolitan Opera.
PITTSBURGH, May 29-- Steel mills were receiving some surprisingly large orders last week.
FORT KNOX, Ky., May 28 (AP)--Two helicopters on a training exercise crashed this afternoon, killing five soldiers and injuring 10 others.
WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP)--A business group challenged three of the Administration's public power projects today and said the needs for power could be met at least as economically by private sources.

Leandro Ferrer, a Coast Guard recruit weary of basic training and wistful about home, visited New York for the first time this weekend. He ate a $1.29 steak dinner in Times Square, saw "Hurry Sundown" at a 42d Street movie house and then returned to his $3.50 hotel room at 10:30 P.M. Saturday night.
The Interior Department has granted permits to four oil companies to start scientific studies along the Atlantic littoral known as the Slope, it was reported over the weekend.

The European Economic Community has a lot to celebrate on its tenth birthday. Yet the heads of the six states holding a summit meeting in Rome this week will probably spend more time in heated debate than in light-hearted rejoicing.
LOS ANGELES, May 28 (UPI)--Ken Rosewell upset Rod Laver in the final of a $25,000 professional tennis tournament at the Los Angeles Tennis Club today.
"The next guy who talks to me about tonnages is going to get his salary in tons, and we'll see how he converts that into dollars," John C. Lobb said.
WASHINGTON, May 28-- Senator Robert F. Kennedy charged today that Government regulation of business was "not as fair, equitable and expeditious" as it should be.

WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) --What the United States Chamber of Commerce call Federal intrusion into businessconsumer affairs will be examined by a new chamber Committee on Consumer Issues Arch N. Booth, executive vice president of the chamber, said today.
NEW DELHI, May 28 (AP) --Rioting between Hindus and Moslems in East Calcutta today left at least two dead, many injured and two factories and 10 shops burned.

CLEVELAND, May 28--Miss Marjorie Jean Limber, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph C. Limber of Needham and Vineyard Haven, Mass., was married today to Daniel Henry Lederer. He is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Henry D. Lederer of Richmond.
The International Longshoremen's Association will continue its boycott against cargoes to or from the Soviet Union, Thomas W. Gleason, union president, has told Congress.
PLYMOUTH, England, May 28--Sir Francis Chichester, waving and smiling, sailed into Plymouth Harbor at dusk this evening, home at last after his voyage alone around the world.
BALTIMORE, May 28 (AP) --Reggae Smith got two doubles and a single and scored three runs today to pace the Boston Red Sox to a 4-3 victory over the Baltimore Orioles.

LEXINGTON, Mass., May 28 (AP)--The unbeaten Britain and Ireland touring Lacrosse team defeated the 1967 United States team, 10-9, today in the national women's tournament at the Lexington High School. It was the visitor's 20th straight triumph.

ATLANTA, May 28 (AP)-- The public opposition of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. to the Vietnam war has cost the civil rights organization he heads some financial support, but he says that new contributors aligned with the peace movement have offset part of the loss.

BOSTON, May 28--Dr. Tilly Edinger, research paleontologist emeritus of the Museum of Comparative Zoology at Harvard University, died yesterday at Cambridge City Hospital of injuries suffered Friday when she was struck by a universityowned truck. She was 69 years old and lived in Cambridge.
Fifteen American steamship companies that use containers to ship cargo warned yesterday against attempts to incorporate odd sizes in official container standards.

BUFFALO, May 28--The president of Yale University warned today that the nation must be protected during the "anguish" of Vietnam against an "invasion of suppression from the right and disruption from the left" in domestic politics.

STREET signs have become a favorite furnishing in home bars, gardens and in children's quarters. Some observers trace the trend to Libby O'Brien, a New York public relations girl, who purchased 10,000 New York signs from the city two years ago for $478. The purchase came after the city began discarding its blue and white street signs in Manhattan and the Bronx and replacing them with yellow and black signs.

MOSCOW, May 28--Eighteen American companies, including International Business Machines, Westinghouse Electric and Coca-Cola, are winding up a two-week trade fair in Moscow's Sokolniki Park with decidedly mixed emotions.

The responsibilities of power rest upon the United States in the Middle East crisis. Despite President Nasser's distorted accusations, Washington's responsibilities are not entirely of Washington's choosing.
ST. LOUIS, May 28 (AP)-- The Baltimore Bays handed the St. Louis Stars their first National Professional Soccer League setback since opening day, 2-0, today before 5,908 fans.

In an effort to save the fastdisappeartng sidewalk newsstands from further decline, the city has decided to let them sell items other than newspapers and magazines, such as paperback books, pennants, rainhats and pretzels.
INDIANAPOLIS, May 28-- With two days to go before the 51st running of the Indianapolis 500-mile auto race, the argument over Andy Granatelli's turbine-powered car is getting harsher.

"DO you actually believe that people come out to see the Yankees lose?" The question was put to a reporter by Jim Turner, once and present Yankee pitching coach, in the Stadium press room one spring day in 1959. "People want to see the Yankees because they're fine best." Turner went on.
About 3,500 Negro men, women and children marched up Fifth Avenue yesterday in a tribute "to the memory of those who lost their lives in service to our country."
SAN FRANCISCO, May 28 (AP)--Gaylord Perry held the Los Angeles Dodgers to six hits today as the San Francisco Giants defeated the Dodgers, 4-1.
LAGOS, Nigeria, May 28-- Nigeria was on the verge of break-up tonight, awaiting a formal declaration of the Eastern Region's independence.
Ill health has forced Mary Martin to cancel her Saturday matinee appearance in "I Do! I Do!"

LONDON, May 28--Four months ago, when he was on the other side of the world from his native England, Francis Chichester was named a Knight Commander of the Order of the British Empire by his Queen, Elizabeth II.
A new service concerned with maritime arbitration has been announced by the Society of Maritime Arbitrators.

Mayor Lindsay met last night with owners of rent-controlled buildings to try to get them to change the "unreasoned position" that he blamed for the strike by employes in hundreds of Manhattan apartment houses.
Associated Bulk Carriers, Ltd., has obtained a contract from Hamersley Iron, Ltd., in Western Australia to carry 600,000 tons of Australian iron ore to Europe during 1967-69.

Dancing, waving blue-and-white pennants, cheerfully chanting and clapping their hands to the "Hava Nagila," the Israeli song of rejoicing, thousands marched up Riverside Drive yesterday to express their support of Israel in the crisis in the Middle ...
Dame Margot Fonteyn, dancing for what might be the last time in New York, was given a mammoth ovation last night at the Metropolitan Opera House.

A minister from Uganda and an ex-banker training for the Episcopalian priesthood shared a pulpit yesterday and debated what moral position American Christians should take toward South Africa with its policy of rigid separation between the races.

James Brown, the rhythm and blues singing star, attracted 11,500 persons to Madison Square Garden last night for a concert in which there was almost as much performing by the audience as by the musicians.
BRUSSELS, May 28--Philippe Hirchhorn, a 20-year-old Soviet violinist who began studying music at the age of 5, today won the $4,000 first prize in the Queen Elisabeth competition.
City Investigation Commissioner Arnold G. Fraiman urged yesterday that the jobs of city marshals be abolished and that their work be carried on solely by the Sheriff's office.
WASHINGTON, May 28--The country's rural electric systems must carry to the floor of the House their fight to win a new source of financing.

A Roman Catholic priest accused of disobedience by his bishop asserts in an article in the June 13 issue of Look Magazine that the church is giving "unrealistic" advice on birth control, running "obsolete" schools and producing frustration among many nuns by preserving outmoded tradition.

PATERSON, N.J., May 28 --John Garlepp of the Millrose Athletic Association took the lead after one mile and went on to triumph by more than 100 yards today in a four-mile road run that started and finished at East Side Park.

UPPER MONTCLAIR, N.J., May 28--Robert B. Crane, who retired in 1963 as secretary of the Life Insurance Association of America, died yesterday in his home, 211 Watchung Avenue, after a long illness. His age was 65.

District Attorney Jim Garrison of New Orleans said yesterday that the attorney for the late Jack L. Ruby wanted him disbarred because he "knows that I am going to connect Ruby with the conspiracy" to assassinate President Kennedy.
MERCEDES, Uruguay, May 28 (AP)--The United States team moved into the final round of the World Basketball Championships today, beating Mexico, 75-65, in a qualifying round.
READING, Pa., May 28 (AP) --Dick Mann of New York held the lead for all but two laps today in winning the $3,500 American Motorcycle Association 12-mile national at the Reading Fairgrounds.

MEXICO CITY, May 28-- Clark Graebner of Beachwood, Ohio, and Martin Riessen of Evanston, Ill., won the doubles match today to give the United States a 2-1 lead in the Davis Cup tennis series with Mexico.

Before a properly exultant audience, a properly exultant Dame Margot Fonteyn and Rudolf Nureyev led the Royal Ballet to the triumphant finale of its ninth New York season, at the Metropolitan Opera House last night.
Harold Woodbury Parsons, an art adviser and buyer for museums, died Saturday in Rome, where he had lived since the end of World War II. He was 84 years old.

The marriage of Miss Pearl Pat Ochacher, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Ochacher of Brooklyn, to Lanny Steven Sussman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Sussman, also of Brooklyn, took place yesterday evening at the Manhattan Beach Jewish Center. Rabbi Ezra Geilman performed the ceremony.

Mrs. Ida Dreher Munier of Peconic Bay Boulevard, Mattituck, L.I., widow of Leon L. Munier, president of Wolff Munier, Inc., mechanical engineers and contractors, died yesterday in the home of her daughter, Mrs. Raymond E. Fidellow of Oldwick, N.J. She was 75 years old.

The war in Vietnam is the first American conflict to be covered thoroughly by television. Therefore, working almost without precedent, TV editors scanning incoming combat film often have a difficult time deciding what to show the public.
NEWARK, May 28--A steadily growing unrest in the Negro ghetto here is forcing neighborhood leaders who have been in conflict to band together for the first time.
RAINBOW GRILL, R.C.A. Building, 50th Street and Avenue of the Americas, Ray McKinley and his band.

SAYVILLE, L.I., May 28-- Three skippers scored clean sweeps today as the Sayville Yacht Club's Memorial Day weekend invitation regatta came to a close with a double sail. The winners of all three races in the series were Knute Lee in the Raven Class, Kevin Donohue in the Sailfish Class, and Donald Gardner in the Class B Handicap group.

WASHINGTON, May 28-- Two prominent Western politicians, an American and a Briton, said tonight that the Arab-Israeli dispute over passage though the Strait of Tiran should be settled by the International Court of Justice.

PLYMOUTH, England, May 28--"When you sail a few days food does not matter, but after weeks at sea you tend to be choosy about what you eat," Sir Francis Chichester remarked about the provisioning of his voyage around the world that ended today.
WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP)--Dr. Donald B. McMullen, president of the American Society of Parasitologists and a winner of the Medal of Freedom, died yesterday at the age of 63.
HANOVER, N.H., May 28-- Bob Thomas of Dartmouth lined a single to right field with two out in the ninth inning today to drive in three runs and give the Indians a 9-8 victory over Boston College.
ANAHEIM, May 28 (AP)-- Jim McGlothlin pitched a sixhitter today as the California Angels defeated the Chicago White Sox, 5-0. It was McGlothlin's fourth victory against one loss.
J. Walter Thompson had two announcements for today that add up to: Good by, Whitehall Laboratories, and hello, Campbell-Taggert Associates Bakeries.

PRINK HILL, N.Y. FOR the first time since May, 1964, a torrent of water is spilling over the dam of the Schoharie Reservoir in the Catskills. It moves fast; it roars; it bursts into white foam when it strikes the runway below.
John B. McAnulty, an authority on travel who served the American Express Company for 20 years, died Saturday at his home in Massapequa, L.I. His age was 57.
BOGOTA, Colombia, May 28 --One of the major Alliance for progress loans of the year, a $100-million United States credit to Colombia, was received here today with outward political indifference.

WASHINGTON, May 28--A recent and largely unnoticed Administration decision to beautify a small section of a 10-lane interstate highway in downtown Philadelphia may have far-reaching consequences for both the highway program and President Johnson's efforts to develop closer working relationships with the cities.
BOYS TOWN, Neb., May 28 (AP)--Vice President Humphrey handed out diplomas to 227 boys graduated from Boys Town High School and Elementary School today in this Omaha suburb.
PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., May 28--Ivo Matkovic's DiDo captured Resolute Class honors today as 66 boats sailed in a Cow Bay area, Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound regatta on Manhasset Bay.
The Baltimore Gas and Electric Company is the latest utility to commit itself to atomic power to meet future demands.

J. Frederic Dewhurst, a wellknown economist and former executive director of the Twentieth Century Fund, died of cancer Friday at the home of his son, Richard, in Salt Lake City. He was 72 years old and lived at 23 Braeburn Drive in Princeton, N. J.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., May 29 (AP)-Edward R. Mathews, chief of the Saturn systems office at the Kennedy Space Center here, was named acting Apollo program manager today.
The United States faces a shortage of 20,000 librarians by 1973, even if no new libraries are constructed, the president of the Special Libraries Association said yesterday.
Steel production last week fell to the lowest level in more than a month, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

FORT KNOX, Ky., May 29 (UPI)--Army investigators sought today to determine whether two large UHID helicopters collided in the air during a training exercise yesterday before they crashed and burned, killing 10 soldiers and injuring 10 others.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., May 29 --President Johnson expressed cautious encouragement today that both Israel and the United Arab Republic were leaving time for diplomacy to ease the confrontation between them.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., May 29 (AP)--President Johnson today proclaimed Oct. 15 as "White Cane Safety Day" and urged citizens to exercise caution and courtesy to blind persons.

Love B. Woods, who was host at the Theresa Hotel on West 125th Street during the stay there in 1960 of Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba, died Saturday at Harlem Hospital after an illness of several months. He was in his eighties and lived at 290 Lenox Avenue.

The Waterfront Commission made known yesterday that it would seek to strip the Chet Maintenance Corporation of 17 Battery Place of its temporary Stevedoring license because it "might be a front for a notorious waterfront hoodlum."

ALLENTOWN, Pa., May 29-- Miss Susan Gould Rose and Bruce A. Ackerman were married here this afternoon. The Rev. William Sloane Coffin Jr., a Presbyterian minister and chaplain at Yale University, performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. R. William Rose, the bride's parents. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Ackerman of New York.
EL ARISH, United Arab Republic, May 29, (AP)--The entire Canadian contingent in the demobilized United Nations Emergency Force was removed from the United Arab Republic today.

TRENTON, May 29--Another conflict between the New Jersey and Federal courts over confessions erupted today when the State Supreme Court ruled that a trial judge could determine in the presence of a jury whether a confession was voluntary.
A loan equivalent to $3,450,000 to help build and expand water-supply facilities in 45 cities and towns of Panama was announced yesterday by the Inter-American Development Bank.
BONN, May 29-A Spokesman for the United States Army in Europe tonight denied that the Army was investigating reports of underground leftist groups said to be encouraging American soldiers to desert.
MONEY rates are rising these days and, in the context of last year's crippling credit squeeze, some people are wondering whether money won't soon be as tight as the bark on a tree.
The Merce Cunningham Dance Company will gain from a benefit to be given Saturday by Philip Johnson and Mr. and Mrs. John de Menil in the garden of Mr. Johnson's home in New Canaan, Conn.
LONDON, May 29 (AP) -- Lord Mancroft, deputy chairman of the Cunard Steamship Company, said yesterday that 10 offers have been received for the 81,000-ton Queen Mary.

Special to THE WALL STREET JOURNAL BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, May 29--In a muddy cow pasture in Argentina's vast and nearly empty flatlands called the Pampa, a looming monument to the memory of President Kennedy was dedicated today.
Planning for the increasing number of performing arts facilities will be the theme of this year's convention of the United States Institute for Theater Technology, Inc., opening here tomorrow night.

Dividend payments made by companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange rose for the 25th consecutive year in the first quarter of 1967, but the increase was the smallest for the period in four years, the exchange said yesterday.
Stan Irwin, a major booking agent for Las Vegas hotels and nightclubs, is the new producer of Johnny Carson's "Tonight" show.
WASHINGTON, May 29 (UPI)--A shipment of 9,100 pounds of ammunition is being sent from the United States to Israel, the Pentagon said today.
GENEVA, May 29--The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. joined Cambodian and Polish delegates to the private Pacem in Terris conference today in a bitter attack on United States policy in Vietnam.

FORT JACKSON, S. C., May 29--Sending Capt. Howard B. Levy to fail would have a "very severe effect" on the morale of other Army doctors, the man who set up the medical training program for the Green Berets testified today.

WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP)--American entertainment ranging from jazz to ballet will be provided at four White House dinners this month planned by President and Mrs. Johnson for visiting kings and prime ministers.
LOS ANGELES, May 29-- The Los Angeles Dodgers, with five substitutes in the line-up and a rookie pitcher on the mound, defeated Jack Fisher and the New York Mets tonight, 7-2.

The Rev. Charles A. Elliott, rector of the Episcopal Church of the Holy Communion, and Mrs. Elliott of 49 West 20th Street and High Acres in Chesterfield, N. H., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Elizabeth Elliott, to Robert Henry Woodrow 3d of Birmingham, Ala, He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Woodrow Jr. of Birmingham and Marwood Farm in Pell City, Ala.
CAIRO, May 29--Cairo residents staged a block party tonight on Boulak Street that underscored the potential grimness of the Middle East situation for Israel and the Arabs themselves.
WASHINGTON, May 29-- Prosecutors were given broader powers by the Supreme Court today to use evidence seized by the police in lawful searches of suspects' homes.

NEWPORT, R. I., May 29 --Miss Mary Olivia Cochran Cushing, known to her friends as Minnie, and Peter Hill Beard, will be married here on Aug. 12. Announcement of the couple's engagement was made here today by Mr. and Mrs. Howard G. Cushing, the future bride's parents. Mr. Beard is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Anson McCook Beard, of Huntington, L. I.
YONKERS, May 29--Eddie Cobb, one of the foremost horsemen in harness racing, was the most disconsolate person at Yonkers Raceway today.
SPARTANBURG, S. C., May 29 (AP)-Some 200 residents of Spartanburg County were evacuated today when a boxcar containing 220,000 pounds of TNT caught fire after a derailment.

We are here today to consider what means the United Nations--and specifically the Security Council-- should adopt to deal with the present crisis in the Near East. MANILA, May 29--Representatives of the Philippines, Malaysia and Thailand opened a three-day conference today to work out an agreement on a free-trade area of the counties of the Association of Southeast Asia.
PARIS, May 29 (Reuters)--A Soviet astronaut set foot for the first time inside a United States spacecraft during a visit to the American pavilion at the International Air Show here today.
Middle Eastern tensions continued yesterday to dampen trading activity on European stock markets, prices generally declined, with oils and other, international issues being particulary affected.

The Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railway; No. 24, United States v. The Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railway).
The appointment of Conrad Kunze as manager of industrial engineering at its Electric Boat Division has been announced by the General Dynamics Corporation.

Mayor Lindsay is scheduled to tell the Metropolitan Regional Council on Thursday that the City Council and Board of Estimate have approved a payment of $40,000 as the city's dues in the organization for the coming year.
PATERSON, N. J., May 29 Some time ago a friend gave 29-year-old Josephine Ramirez a roll of dark blue plaid cloth. She used it to make a dress.
WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) --Sweet Briar College got a helping hand from the Supreme Court today in its effort to admit Negro students legally.

WASHINGTON, May 29, (AP) The International Brotherhood of Teamsters announced today that 450,000 of its members had approved overwhelmingly a three-year national contract with the trucking industry providing increases of 76 cents an hour in wages and other benefits.

WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) --More than 55,000 Federal employes have been transferred to establish the new Department of Transportation, the Joint Committee on Reduction of Nonessential Federal Expenses reported today.

TORONTO, May 29 than Press) The former owners of the Standard Discount Corporation, a wholly owned subsidiary of the bankrupt Atlantic Acceptance Corporation, have offered to help liquidate its receivables in order to pay its debts and take over Standard Discount again.

WASHINGTON, May 29-The Treasury bill rate showed diverse movements at today's auction, with three-month bills dipping slightly further in average discount rate and the sixninnth rate rising from last week's level.

NEWARK, May 29-Forty motorists got flat tires today on an 11-mile stretch of the New Jersey Turnpike after a truck carrying scrap metal had spilled hundreds of sharp triangular metal pieces onto the southbound lanes.
AMHERST, Mass., May 29Stanley Ferdinand Teele, treasurer of Amherst College and former dean of the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration, died here today at the age of 61.
The children of five members of the Seafarers International Union, Atlantic, Gulf, Lakes and Inland Waters District, have won $6,000 Seafarers' college scholarships, the union has announced.

Louis A. Pincus, chairman and treasurer of the Jewish Agency Executive in Jerusalem, is scheduled to arrive in New York this week to explore the possibilities of an emergency fund-raising drive to counteract economic dislocations in Israel caused by the Arab-Israeli crisis.

Fifty Brooklyn residents who said they didn't get much sleep these nights anyway, blocked a street in their neighborhood until 1 A.M. yesterday to keep tractortrailers from making deliveries to the Fort Greene Meat Market.

SEOUL, South Korea, May 29 --The Agency for International Development, which administers the United States foreign aid program, has approved a $17.5 million loan to the Government owned Korea Electric Company The loan will finance the con struction of a thermal power plant at Ulsan, near Pusan.
FORMBY, England, May 29 (UPI)--Bill Campbell continued one of the hottest streaks of his long golfing career today to lead the American charge through the first round of the 1967 British Amateur.
WASHINGTON, May 29-In the Supreme Court of the United States today, the following proceedings were had;
DETROIT, May 29-Automobile manufacturers plan to build 775,000 cars in June, down 5.6 per cent from last year's June production of 821,000 cars.

TOKYO, May 29 (UPI)--The North Vietnamese News Agency said today that a captured American serviceman had written an open letter to all United States troops in South Vietnam "to protest the dirty, immoral and illegal war that our Government is waging."

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, May 30 (UPI)--American marines stormed a hilltop fortress just south of the Demilitarized Zone yesterday and routed North Vietnamese forces in a five-hour battle, the United States command reported today.

NORWALK, Conn., May 29--Another veterans group withdrew today from the Memorial Day parade to protest the presence of a float entered by the John Birch Society. The Disabled American War Veterans became the third group to withdraw from the parade.
The Zapata Off-Shore Company announced yesterday in Houston the acquisition of Sea Service,. Inc., for 140,250 common shares worth an estimated $8.7-million.

PARIS, May 29--The creation of a European Institute of Science and Technology was proposed today as one way of narrowing a technological gap between the United States and Western Europe. Its sponsors hope to have detailed plans for the school by the end of next year.

WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) The Air Force, pinched for experienced pilots and other seasoned officers, announced today a move to freeze on active duty up to 3,700 regulars who want to retire or resign from the service.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 29 (UPI)--Iraq's Oil Ministry today told three Western-owned oil companies operating in Iraq that the Government would cancel their licenses if they supplied oil to any country participating in aggression against Arab states.

CAIRO, May 29--President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic announced today that Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin of the Soviet Union had sent him what amounted to a pledge to guarantee an Egyptian blockade of the Gulf of Aqaba.
The appointment of Robert W. Parker as vice president in charge of the data processing center of the First Na-- tional City Bank was announced here yesterday.
For the 100th time, the nation will pause today to honor its war dead in Memorial Day observances.

TO his new line as head of America's radio broad casts abroad, John Charles Daly Jr. brings the talent and experience acquired in a 30-year career as one of the nation's hardest working and most aggressive newsmen.
BOSTON, May 29--Postmaster General Lawrence F. O'Brien said today that President John F. Kennedy's accomplishments were in danger of being obscured by hero worship.

WASHINGTON, May 29 (UPI)--A predominantly Protestant organization dedicated to church-state separation announced today that it would bring court action in an effort to prevent the Post Office Department from re-issuing its 1966 Christmas stamp.
WASHINGTON, May 29-- The Supreme Court refused today to grant Adam Clayton Powell a speedy hearing on his charge that he was unconstitutionally excluded from the House of Representatives.

WASHINGTON, May 29-- Staff experts of the Federal Communications Commission said today that American Broadcasting Companies, Inc., did not need to merge with the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation to obtain funds to strengthen its competitive position in television.

GEORGETOWN, Del., May 29 (UPI)-Frederick Stoddard, 43 years old, who was to have been sworn in today as deputy general counsel to the Small Business Administration, was stabbed to death last night. His wife, Elinor, 43, has been charged with second degree murder.
The teachers' union announced yesterday that it would guarantee new teachers coming to the city "the highest entrance salary in the United States."
IT looked like a crowd assembled for a night of bingo, but instead of playing games, the audience was asking questions about meat.
A man who is awaiting trial on a charge of cashing stolen United States bonds was arrested again yesterday by Federal agents who said he had cashed more than $250,000 in stolen and forged bonds.
MINEOLA,L.I., May 29 ---- A County Department of Consumer Affairs was established today to give Nassau residents information on buying and to protect them from fraud.

The Maritime Administration has announced the reallocation of five of eight Reserve Fleet C-4 troopships that originally were offered late last year to private unsubsidized ship operators for conversion into conventional dry cargo ships.
NEWARK, May 29-A hotel bellman collapsed while trying to lead guests from a fire in the Douglas Hotel here today and died while being taken to a hospital.

HONG KONG, May 29--The people of China were warned today that the present Cultural Revolution was only the first of several political purges and that such turbulence might last for decades or centuries.

Trading volume on most commodity exchanges moved slowly yesterday, probably reflecting the fact that many traders and businessmen were taking a long weekend and also that several exchanges were closed for the same reason.

KHARTOUM, the Sudan, May 29 (UPI)--The Sudan announced today that it had dispatched troops to her frontier with Ethiopia to counter an "aggressive" military build-up in the disputed border area between the two countries.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., May 29-Morris Golub, president of the Westchester County Bar Association, died today in New Rochelle Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived at 17 Pamela Lane. His office here was at 271 North Avenue.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex. May 29 --The White House announced today the President's intention to nominate Bruce E. Clubb, a Washington lawyer, to be a member of the Tariff Commission.
WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP)-The Supreme Court barred railroads today from refusing to let truckers use piggyback service at the railroads' regular rates.

BALTIMORE, May 29 (AP) --The Baltimore Orioles announced tonight that Mike Epstein, the rookie first baseman, who had refused to report to the minor leagues, had been traded to the Washington Senators for Pete Richert, a lefthanded pitcher. Frank Bertaina, an Oriole pitcher, was included in the deal.

JERUSALEM (Israel), May 29--The Israeli High Command reported that Israeli and Egyptian troops had exchanged shots across the Gaza Strip border for almost an hour today after the Egyptians opened fire on civilians and soldiers.

WASHINGTON, May 29-- The Supreme Court declared unconstitutional today the voter-approved amendment to the California Constitution that gave property owners "absolute discretion" in resale and rental of housing.

WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP)--The Supreme Court left standing today a $21,000 judgment against the American Guild of Variety Artists, won by William Smith over concellation of contracts to put or circus acts at 17 Midwestern county fairs in 1962.
CLEVELAND, May 29 (AP) --The Brotherhood of Locomo tive Engineers, bargaining for 40,000 members, has reached agreement on a new contract with the nation's railroads, the union announced today.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., May 29 (UPI)--Chiclero, a 4-year-old sun of Nashville, scored a length-and-a-half victory today in the $27,350 Hollywood Express. It was his second stakes triumph of the year. He won the Express last year.

MILL NECK, L.L., May 29-- Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Burdick have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Edwards Burdick, to Hoyle Clay Jones, son of Mrs. Hugh-Blair Grigsby Long and stepson of Mr. Long of Winnetka, Ill. A wedding on Dec. 2 is planned.

THE measure of the Middle East crisis was reflected yesterday in network cancellation of most late afternoon programs to carry the live pooled telecast of the acrimonious debate in the United Nations Security Council.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., May 29--Donald H. G. Mackenzie's Black Arrow II won both races in the annual dinghy-type regatta of the International Class on Long Island Sound off the Larchmont Yacht Club today.

PARIS, May 29-The General Electric Company, for $30-million, has arranged to get a majority share, at least temporarily, in the French computer business that it has heretofore run jointly with Compagnie Machines Bull.
ROME, May 29--Pope Paul VI named 27 Cardinals today, including four Americans. Three of the four head dioceses in the United States.

Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday that a search for a site for a new children's shelter had been ended after six years with the selection of a 1 -acre site just north of High Bridge I Park in Manhattan.

John Colrain, the playercoach of the Detroit Cougars of the United Soccer Association, was suspended indefinitely yesterday. Colrain was reported to have punched a linesman in the face during a game at Boston Sunday night.
DANANG, South Vietnam, May 29--A Vietcong frogman demolition team today blew up a hotel in Hue that housed members of the International Control Commission.

WASHINGTON, May 29-- Some precious time has been won in the Middle East by the decision of the Eshkol Government in Israel not to foreclose as yet "the continuation of political action in the world arena." Gordon B. Sherman was elected yesterday as president of the Midas-International Corporation, a Chicago manufacturer of automotive parts.

Despite its political upheavals and its inflation problems, South America now offers a better climate for private investment and enterprise than it has in former years, Merwin R. Haskel, president of United Merchants and Manufacturers, Inc., asserted in a recent interview.

MEXICO CITY, May 29-- Arthur Ashe of Richmond gained an overwhelming victory over Rafael Osuna for the deciding point in the Davis Cup tennis series with Mexico today, and the United States qualified to play Ecuador in Guayaquil in mid-June in the American Zone final.

A narcotics-smuggling trial involving defendants from Italy, the United States, France and Canada was moved here from Rome yesterday complete with Italian judges, Italian lawyers and the Napoleonic Code.

DEVON, Pa., May 29--Rod Jenkins, a 22-year-old professional from Orange, Va., rode three of his charges through the murk, rain and gloom to victories today and missed scoring with a fourth by just one second at the Devon Horse Show.

WASHINGTON, May 29--A group of about 30 Quakers held a "wait-in" at the Treasury Department today in an appeal to release funds raised to provide medical supplies for wounded civilians in North Vietnam.

LONDON, May 29 (AP)-- Jackie Ickx, a 22-year-old Belgian driver, thrilled the holiday crowd at the Crystal Palace course today by winning the International Formula Two auto race over 104.25 miles.

LONDON, May 29 (Reuters) -Sir Arthur Clark, director of information at the Commonwealth Office, who was Britain's first High Commissioner to Cyprus, died of a heart attach today. He was 58 years old.
DETROIT, May 29 (AP) -- Automobile production tapered off in United States assembly plants today because of the Memorial Dav holiday.

GENEVA, May 29--Of all the troubled peacemakers who have come to this city of disappointed hopes, few have seemed more depressed than the delegates to the current Pacem in Terris Convocation.

WASHINGTON,May 29 (AP) The Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today that the nation's savings and loan industry attracted an April record of $523-million in net savings while mortgage lending remained at the March level.

MANCHESTER, N. H., May 29--The marriage of Miss Barbara D. Greenspan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Saul Greenspan, to Carl Jacobson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Isadore B. Jacobson of Chestnut Hill, Mass., took place here this evening.

CAIRO, Tuesday, May 30 (UPI)--The semi-official Cairo newspaper Al Ahram reported today that an Egyptian Navy ship fired a warning shot across the bow of an American-owned tanker yesterday as the ship was entering the Gulf of Aqaba. The tanker turned around and headed back into the Red Sea "at full speed," the paper said.
The Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn is planning to build a $50-million medical school to provide physicians for its hospitals. The city's only Catholic medical school closed 48 years ago.
MOSCOW, May 29--The head of state of Syria, Nureddin elAttassi, flew here today and promptly went into conference with Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin on the Arab-Israeli conflict.
Tartan Stable's Dr. Fager and Mrs. Francis Genter's In Reality head a field of four 3-year-olds in today's $119,200 Jersey Derby at Garden State Park.

SANTA MONICA, Calif., May 29--Stars and celebrities inside the Civic Auditorium Saturday night, more dazzling than any in the night sky outside, paid $200,000 to aid retarded children of the Los Angeles community.

Dr. and Mrs. Put Po Chiu of Hong Kong have announced here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Yee-ha Chiu, to Donald Sinclair Sutton. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley C. Sutton of Amersham in Buckinghamshire, England. A December wedding is planned.
As the world grows more dangerous and more sorrowful for Americans,Decoration Day takes on an added measure of bitter-sweet memories.

The trustees of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations announced yesterday a vote of confidence in Rabbi Maurice N. Eisendrath, president of the union and the central figure in a dispute involving Temple Emanu-El of Manhattan.
GENEVA, May 29--Tran Van Do, South Vietnam's Foreign Minister, made public today a proposal that the war in Vietnam be ended by reinstating the provisions of the armistice of 1954.
The Brodin Line is resigning from the River Plate and Brazil Conferences effective June 17, it has been, announced by Garcia and Diaz, Inc., general agents for the company in this country.
In his 16th year of one of the great major-league pitching careers, Whitey Ford will disclose today his choice of the three options that affect his future.

The Securities and Exchange Commission announced yesterday it has lifted the trading suspension fin the common shares of Nylo-Thane Plastics Corporation, Farmingdale, L.I, which had been in effect since April 27. The stock is traded over the counter.

ACCRA, Ghana, May 29 -- Lieut. Augustus Owusu-Gyimmah, a 27-year-old army officer. and two civilians were sentenced to death by shooting today after a five-man military tribunal had found them guilty of conspiracy to overthrow the Government.

Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that he would look into a recommendation by Investigation Commissioner Arnold G. Fraiman that the position of city marshal be abolished and the marshals' duties be entrusted. to the Sheriff's office.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 29-- The 33 drivers who will compete in tomorrow's 51st annual Indianapolis 500-mile race sat under gray skies in a 50-degree temperature this afternoon to learn the details of the race regulations from Harlan Fengler, the chief steward.

SULTANPUR, India -- There are no telephones in this village, no water taps inside the houses and no electric fans to keep them cool during India's hot summer, But, since March, Sultanpur has had a "teleclub."
ESSEX, Conn., May 29-- --Norma Mitchell of Old Lyme, an actress and playwright, died here today. She was the wife of Wilbur Daniel Steele, the shortstory writer.

The United States Circuit Court of Appeals here rejected yesterday plans of the trustees of the bankrupt New Haven Railroad to transfer the carrier's operations and facilities to a merged Pennsylvania-New York Central system before proposing how to settle creditors' claims.

Harry Rapoport, owner of the widely known Rapoports Restaurant at 93 Second Avenue, near Fifth Street, died in his sleep Sunday night at his home, 411 East Walnut Street, Long Beach, L.I. He was 74 years old.

A solemn high mass was offered at 10 A.M, yesterday for Mrs. Vincent R, Impellitteri at St. Francis Xavier Roman Catholic Church, 30 West 16th Street. Nearly 1,000 people, from city officials to retired clerks, flocked to the old gray stone church to pay their respects to the wife of the former Mayor.
Four children were rescued yesterday when their mother dropped them 15 feet from her burning Bronx apartment to a passerby who caught them in his arms.

The City Council and the Lindsay administration are working on plans to loosen rent controls even more than Mayor Lindsay proposed in February, in an effort to end a... strike by building service workers.
DETROIT, May 29--The United Automobile Workers union has stopped sending money to the political activity fund of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations.
The statues of 58 Americans at the Hall of Fame on the New York University campus were blindfolded early yesterday morning in what one university spokesman described as a "springtime prank."
The American Council for Judaism urged American Zionists yesterday to cease efforts "to pressure the United States Government into always taking absolute and militant pro-Israel positions."
WASHINGTON, May 29 (UPI)--The Defense Department identified today the following servicemen from the New York area who have been killed in action in Vietnam:
ROME, May 29--President de Gaulle came to Rome today for a Common Market conference he had hoped to dominate. But he found instead opposition to his views on shaping Europe.
Your gift means more whenyou contribute to the Greater New York Fund because it does more.
BUFFALO, May 29 (AP)A $100,000 suit was filed today against law-enforcement officials by one of 36 men arrested May 8 in a raid on what the police had described as a "little Apalachin" meeting.

JERUSALEM (Jordan), May 29 (Reuters)--Lieut. Gen. Odd Bull, chief United Nations truce observer, called at the Israeli Foreign Ministry today to discuss the release of three Egyptian officers and two soldiers captured by Israel.

LAGOS, Nigeria, May 29-- The prospect of civil war in Nigeria hung in the balance tonight, with both the dissident Eastern region and the Federal military Government here still limiting the conflict to a war of words.

A Federal grand jury here is expected to indict five or six registered representatives of American Stock Exchange member firms before the end of the week on price-rigging and securities fraud charges, a Covernment source said yesterday.
It was a rainy day in New York yesterday, the embers of potential war continued to glow in the Middle East, and it was the day before the Memorial Day holiday.

WASHINGTON, May 29--The Acting United States Welfare Commissioner admitted today that a $238,000 grant approved for a "Community Alert Patrol" to reduce tensions in the Watts section of Los Angeles might have the opposite effect, further estranging the poor from the police.

VANDENBERG Air Force Base, Calif., May 29 (UPI)--Esro 2, the first satellite built by the 10-nation European space research organization, was launched from this base tonight but failed to achieve its polar orbit when ignition of the fourth stage did not occur.

Sixty-six per cent of the American people now believe that the assassination of President Kennedy was not the work of one man but part of a conspiracy, according to a Louis Harris poll published yesterday in The Washington Post.

BUFFALO, May 29--Martin Meyerson, a city planner who was acting chancellor of the University of California at Berkeley during the student unrest there in 1985, was inaugurated today as president of the State University at Buffalo.

The Travelers Aid Society of New York will benefit at a "fly by night" dinner dance Thursday in the La Guardia Terrace Restaurant at the airport in Queens. During the evening, 100 door-prize winners will be taken on a helicopter flight over the city.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 29 (AP)--Tom Haller, who entered the game in the fifth inning, drove in five runs to lead the San Francisco Giants to a wild 12-9 victory over the Philadelphia Phils today.

PLYMOUTH, England, May 29 (AP)--Policemen kept holiday crowds today away from a house overlooking Plymouth Sound, where Sir Francis Chichester rested after his lone 28,500-mile voyage around the world.

KINDERHOOK, N. Y., May 28-A 230-year-old brick farmhouse where Washington Irving courted the girl who inspired his fictional character, Katrina Van Tassel, has begun a new life as a possession of the Columbia County Historical Society.
WASHINGTON, May 29 (UPI)--Senator Carl Hayden, Democrat of Arizona, convened and adjourned the Senate today in eight seconds, but his time fell far short of the modern record.

WASHINGTON, May 29, (UPI)--The Supreme Court agreed today to review a ruling that the 1932 Lindbergh Kidnapping Law was unconstitutional because it placed a potential price of death on the right of trial by jury.
HANOVER, N. H., May 29 --Boston College defeated Dartmouth, 15-13, today to win the two-of-three National Collegiate Athletic Association semifinal regional baseball playoffs.
CHERRY HILL, N.J., May 29 (AP)--I'm Smiley, trailing for nearly six furlongs, rallied under Ray Broussard and won the Hero Fund Purse today in the rain at Garden State Park.

WASHINGTON, May 29-- John Charles Daly Jr., the television news analyst and program moderator, was named today director of the Voice of America. He will succeed John Chancellor, who will return to television news reporting. The appointment...

SUTATENSA, Colombia, May 29--A modernized patron of agriculture, St. Isidro, the tiller with a tractor, has been proclaimed to the peasants of Latin America with the blessing of a Roman Catholic cardinal, an Anglican bishop and a grand rabbi.

A $231,000 engineering study has offered new hope to families living in a low-lying section of Staten Island who have feared that proposed street embankments would rise over their doorsteps, surround blocks of ponies and turn their yards into marshland.

MIAMI BEACH, May 29-- The North American team battled its way back into contention in the world championship here this afternoon by crushing the strong French team, 83-52, and winning 17 victory points out of a possible 20.
The spot rate on the British pound firmed in brisk trading yesterday on foreign-exchange markets here.
WILDWOOD, N. J., May 29-- A total of 155 teen-agers were arrested over the weekend on charges of drinking, damaging property and other disorderly acts here and in North Wildwood.

CHEVY CHASE, Md., May 29 (AP)--Paul C. Aebersold, a pioneer nuclear physicist who worked on the first atomic bomb, plunged to his death today from the top floor of a 17story apartment building near his home. The county coroner ruled the death a suicide.

WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) --Contract negotiations continued today for 32,000 electrical workers at nine plants of the Radio Corporation of America, but a union spokesman said that the prospect for a peaceful settlement did not look good.
DAME MARGOT FONTEYN, dancing for what may be the last time in New York, was given an enormous ovation Sunday night by the Metropolitan Opera House audience.
The Londontown Manufacturing Company, a producer of rainwear, announced yesterday in Baltimore the election of Lowell E. Abramson as a vice president.

For its "objective" study of whether the Richmond Parkway should cut through the proposed Olmsted Trailway in the Staten Island greenbelt, the New York State Department of Public Works turned to consultants long involved in projects of the Robert Moses era. The study produced the predictable conclusion that the route Mr. Moses had originally picked would mix harmoniously with the trailway for hikers and bikers.

It was blue Monday on the American Stock Exchange yesterday as the list declined on very light volume.

A sublease for five years at $1-million in aggregate rents has been arranged for Avon Products, Inc., in the new 42story building at 299 Park Avenue, which occupies the east blockfront between 48th and 49th Streets.

Miss Victoria Janet Kaplan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Kaplan of Brooklyn, was married last evening to Samuel J. Fishman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Fishman of Lido Beach, L.I., at the East Midwood Jewish Center. Rabbi Harry Halpern officiated.

There's a strain in British blood that has responded through the centuries to the beauty and the awesome challenge of the seas. CAIRO, May 29 (UPI)--All women and children who are dependents of United States diplomatic personnel in Cairo and Alexandria have been evacuated from the United Arab Republic, a spokesman said today.

GLENBROOK, Conn., May 29 --G. William Bergquist, who as book detective of the New York Public Library won fame for tracking down book thieves and manuscript forgets, died of a heart ailment today in his home, 417 Hope Street. His aged was 84.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 29--A simple but urgent request by Arthur J. Goldberg, the United States delegate, for a 10-minute recess of the Security Council meeting on the Middle East today was blocked by the Soviet Union.
JERUSALEM, (Israel), May 29--Premier Levi Eshkol said tonight he expected action by the Western powers to open the strait and said it was a matter time."
NEW DELHI, India, May 29 --The possibility of an interruption in August of foreign food aid is causing concern among principal Indian Government officials.
Palmer Derby and Floyd T Wimberly have been elected vice presidents of the Raytheor Company.
The New York Life Insurance Company announced yesterday the election of Glen B. Gross as vice president in charge of personnel.

CINCINNATI, May 29 (AP) Dick Simpson's sacrifice fly with the bases loaded in the ninth inning gave the Cincinnati Reds a 7-6 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals and a split of their double-header tonight.

CLEVELAND, May 29 (UPI) The Cleveland Bar Association criticized Mayor Ralph Locker today for his."refusal" to meet with the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. It said he was building a "stone wall" against the city's Negroes.

SEOUL, South Korea, May 29 -To cope with South Korea's increasing demands for crude oil, a Seoul shipping company has placed orders for four oil tankers, totaling 471,400 deadweight tons, from British and Swedish shipyards.
Unionized workers in Bronx apartment buildings warned tenants there yesterday that they might interrupt some "nonemergeney services" to show sympathy for striking Manhattan building service workers.

Stephen Boyd, film star, has been signed to portray George Bernard Shaw in "The Bashful Genius." The comedy-drama by Harold Callen deals with Shaw's courtship of Charlotte Payne-Townshend. The author teaches playwriting at The New School.
