PINEHURST, N. C., May 29-- Col. Wallace W. Simpson, U.S.A.F., retired, and Mrs. Simpson have announced the engagement of the colonel's daughter, Miss Lucy Stevens Simpson, to John W. Douglas Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Douglas of Brookfield Center, Conn. A summer wedding is planned.

Net income of the Seeburg Corporation fell to $614,972, equal to 25 cents a share, in the second fiscal quarter, from $1,051,255, or 41 cents, in the corresponding 1966 quarter, it was reported yesterday. Sales slipped to $25,184,487 from $25,755,992 the preceding year.

Thomas P. F. Hoving, who championed the cause of bicyclists who wanted to use Central Park without the competition of automobiles, disclosed yesterday that two of his bicycles were stolen Sunday in the park.

GLENBROOK, Conn., May 29 --G. William Bergquist, who as book detective of the New York Public Library won fame for tracking down book thieves and manuscript forgets, died of a heart ailment today in his home, 417 Hope Street. His aged was 84.
The season's most promising new players, on or off Broadway, as selected by Theater World, a pictorial and statistical yearbook, were announced yesterday.

CAIRO, Wednesday, May 31 The United Arab Republic and Jordan entered a military alliance yesterday that appeared to commit Jordan to attack Israel if Israeli forces tried to break the Egyptian blockade of the Gulf of Aqaba.
Angry neighbors of two boys struck by a hit-and-run driver last night tried to wrest the driver from two policemen who had caught him.

ABROAD U.S.S. AMERICA, Off Crete, May 29 Shadowed by Soviet ships, the twin attack carriers of the United States Sixth Fleet were marking time today after a rendezvous in the Sea of Crete. The fleet was awaiting further orders from Washington.
CHERRY HILL, N.J., May 30 Dr. Fager, ridden too brazenly by Manuel Ycaza, led In Reality under the wire by 6 lengths in the $119,200 Jersey Derby today at Garden State.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 30 (UPI) The Philadelphia Phillies' pitcher, Jim Bunning, hit a ninth-inning home run today to break a tie and beat the San Francisco Giants, 5-4.

The spot rate on the British pound closed unchanged at $2.7946 on London's foreign-exchange markets yesterday. Initially the level had advanced 7 points.
ST. LOUIS, May 30 The muggy weather for which this city in the Middle West is famous had come early and the heat inside the one-room yellow building on Leffingwell Street was stifling.

YONKERS, May 30 Dr. Carmelo E. DeAngelis, director of pathology at St. Johns Riverside Hospital and of the Yorkers Bureau of Laboratories, died yesterday of a coronary attack, at the hospital. He was 55 years old and lived at 635 Palisade Avenue.

OXFORD, Miss., May 30 (UPI) Three government witnesses identified five white defendants today as men seen attacking Negro children or committing other violence last fall during desegregation of Grenana (Miss.) schools.

MIAMI BEACH, May 30 The North American team had a great day in yesterday's world championship play, making up for earlier defeats by France and Italy and moving up to the leaders from a position that appeared to have placed the team out of contention.
LISBON, May 30 Three men were convicted here today for an attempt to rob a bank to obtain funds for a rebellion.

ROME, May 30 (UPI) Informed sources reported today that negotiations on a new accord to give Italy increased commercial air traffic benefits in the United States broke down today.
WASHINGTON, May 30 Administration officials reported today that some progress was being made in lining up Western maritime powers to contest the Egyptian blockade of the Gulf of Aqaba.

FORMBY, England, May 30 Out of the British Amateur tonight went the favorite, Big Bill Campbell of Huntington, W. Va., beaten 4 and 3 by an inspired Tim Bull, a Northumberland sales executive still searching for county golf honors.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 30 Syria's Information Minister declared today that the Soviet Union had given assurances it would take a stand against any aggression against the Arab people by Israel and "by those who stand behind Israel."
WASHINGTON, May 30 The United States gained $50million in gold during April, the second consecutive monthly rise, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

BUENOS AIRES, May 30 Argentina's military Government indicated today that it planned to use the nation's press, along with public-opinion polls, as a substitute for the dissolved Congress and the strictly forbidden political parties.

AS colorful as a travel poster, and as undemanding as a television spectacular, the Ballet Folklorico of Mexico last night moved into the Metropolitan Opera House for a two-week stay. HARLECH, Wales, May 30 (Reuters) Lady Harlech, wife of Britain's former Ambassador to the United States, was killed near here today when her car collided with a bus.

The New York Philharmonic Promenades at Philharmonic Hall have taken on a distinctly Mediterranean air this week. The program, entitled "Ports of Call," is introduced by Jacques Ibert's symphonic composition of the same name ("Escales," in French). The work's three movements are subtitled "Palermo," "TunisNefta" and "Valencia."
THE HAGUE, May 30 (Reuters) Prince Bernhard announced today that he would present $200,000 to Harvard University on June 7 to establish a chair in Dutch culture.

Thirty-eight American Jews, mostly college students, left by plane for Israel last night to take jobs in kibbutzim, hospitals and nurseries left vacant by Israeli Army reservists called into active service.

New York City has had to postpone a projected sale of $96 million in bonds because of "unfavorable conditions in the money markets." And it has come under renewed criticism from Moody's Investor Service, Inc., one of the major credit rating agencies. Since New York's downgrading by Moody's and Standard Poor's, the city has attracted fewer bidders for its obligations even though it has offered very generous rates of interest.
TOKYO, May 23 The faces of brides and bridegrooms looking down from advertisements in subway cars are a sign of spring in Japan.

LONDON, May 30 Parliament, in recess for almost three weeks over the Whitsun holidays, will resume tomorrow with a debate on the Middle Eastern crisis.

Complaints of physical hardships and sanitation problems increased yesterday as a strike of apartment house employes went through its fifth day with no end in sight.

MIAMI, May 30 Cuba's sugar production the mainstay of the economy is slowly approaching 6 million metric tons, according to Havana Radio broadcasts monitored here. However, it appears unlikely that the final figure for the 1967 crop will exceed 6.2 million metric tons. A metric ton is equal to 2,204 pounds.

GENEVA, May 30 Marya Mannes, the New York writer, tonight bitterly attacked United States policy in Vietnam, terming it "as futile as it is brutal." She demanded "the end of bombing" as the "one act of trust which could open the only avenue to reason and peace."
ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 30 (AP)--Barbara Jerry, a 20-year-old nursing student from Syracuse, N.Y., will be the color girl for the 1967 graduation week ceremonies at the United States Naval Academy.
BOSTON, May 30 Andy Warhol's film "The Chelsea Girls" has run into trouble with the police.
Carl Lewis Estes, publisher of The Longview (Tex.) Daily News and The Longview Journal, died of a heart attack Monday night at his vacation home in La Jolla, Calif. He was 70 years old.

John Bunce McHale was a tall, brown-haired boy who lived in the Inwood section of upper Manhattan. He was born there, attended school there, and married a girl from the neighborhood six weeks before he left for Vietnam.
WASHINGTON, May 30 (UPI)--Gen. Earle G. Wheeler, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, expressed hope today that world leaders would someday settle their disputes by employing reason, not violence.

WASHINGTON, May 30, (UPI) The Department of Agriculture said today that American wheat growers are expected to grow enough wheat this year to meet both foreign and domestic demand and to add some to reserves.

The New York chapter of Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, will open a four-day art show on Sunday evening at the American Friends of the Hebrew University, 11 East 69th Street. Sponsors and benefactors of the show will gather there in the afternoon for a champagne cocktail party.

The three top collegiate lacrosse powers Maryland, Navy and Johns Hopkins have each placed three players on the South All-Star team that will meet the North on June 10 at the University of Massachusetts.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 30 Swoosh! Parnelli Jones and Andy Granatelli's controversial turbine-powered car rode silently from sixth place to the lead on the first lap of the 51st 500-mile race today. Swoosh! After 17 minutes 24 seconds of racing, rain fell on the course in sheets and the event was postponed until 11 A.M. tomorrow, New York time.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 80 Arab leaders warned the United Nations today that the new Middle Eastern crisis had brought determination in the Arab countries to fight together against offenses by Israel.
PITTSBURGH, May 30 (UPI)--A gunman shot and killed two men and wounded two others critically tonight in their motel room.

The American architect Buckminster Fuller has designed a domed theater for the Spoleto Festival in Italy, and the British sculptor Henry Moore will design the festival's new production of "Don Giovanni" this summer.

The American Broadcasting Company will present an original television production of "The Desperate Hours" during the 1967-68 season. The twohour color adaptation of the novel by Joseph Hayes will star George Segal and Robert Stack and will be shown on one of A.B.C.'s "Theater Nights."

It is not surprising that stock market prices on Wall Street are under some pressure. The surprising thing is that the market did not run into trouble earlier. The chief reason that Wall Street has been advancing while the economy has been marking time is that credit has been freely available.

LAGOS, Nigeria, May 30 Nigeria's Eastern Region seceded early today, declaring itself an independent republic, Biafra. The Federal Government immediately ordered a mobilization and said it would use force to thwart the secession.

HAMDEN, Conn., May 30 In Temple Mishkan Israel this evening, Miss Sara Jane Levine, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Levine, was married to Lieut. Robert Jay Fields, U.S.A., son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving S. Fields of Manhasset, L.I. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Robert Goldburg.
During Emy Schultz's time in the advertising business, about $500-million in print advertising contracts has gone through her hands.

LAUREL HURLEY, soprano, helped the Naumburg Symphony Orchestra open its series of summer concerts on the Mall in Central Park last night. But for 20 minutes or so Miss Hurley was wondering if she would make it.
The Boeing Company has under study a variety of motion picture systems for the entertainment of passengers on its 747 jumbo jets, which will go into service in 1970.
WASHINGTON, May 30 Dr. Willis A. Gibbons, who retired in 1953 as associate director of research and development of the United States Rubber Company, died Sunday in his home here. His age was 78.
JERUSALEM (Israel), May 30 Foreign Minister Abba Eban said today that the Israeli Government was pursuing a policy of prying open the Strait of Tiran "alone if we must, with others if we can."
PITTSBURGH, May 30 (AP) Donn Clendenon's runscoring double in the eighth inning gave Pittsburgh a 4-3 victory over Houston and a split of their double-header today.

The lonely sound of taps, the rustle of wreaths being placed on soldiers' graves, the slow marching step of aging veterans and the traditional speeches honoring the nation's war dead were heard in the country yesterday.

MADRID, May 30 (AP) The Spanish Government and the International Minerals and Chemicals Corporation of Chicago have started negotiations for commercial mining of what was termed the world's largest and richest untapped phosphate deposits, officials said today.
PEKING, May 30 (Reuters) Peking's young Red Guards are refusing to settle down to normal schooling after a year of activity in the Cultural Revolution, it was indicated here today.

PARIS, May 30 A French prosecutor asked today that a 20-year prison sentence be imposed on Lieut. Col. Ahmed Dlimi, chief of the Moroccan security police, for his part in the abduction of Mehdi Ben Barka, the Moroccan Opposition leader.

YONKERS, May 30 None of Romeo Hanover's supporters is taking anything for granted about Thursday night's $100,000 International Pace at Yonkers Raceway. Since Romeo Hanover, who has a 20-race winning string, never has gone 1 miles in competition, there has been a drastic change in the horse's usual training routine.

BONN, May 30 Walter G nther, who became medical director of West Berlin's Neuk lln Hospital without having attended a university or medical school, was sentenced by a West Berlin court to 18 months' imprisonment today on five counts of fraud and three counts of forging documents.
ATHENS, May 30 Twenty leading Greek jurists were named by the army-backed Cabinet today to revise the nation's Constitution by Dec. 1.

ROME, May 30--Pope Paul VI issued today a set of regulations for celebration of the Eucharist that virtually eliminates the possibility of a return to early Christian love feasts and the chance of the success of other efforts to develop radical new forms for the mass.

LONDON, May 30 The High Court ordered today the liquidation of the American-owned Gibraltar Insurance Company, Ltd., one of the British companies that have been selling auto insurance at so-called "cut rate" premiums.

Several apparel companies that depend on trucks for daily deliveries in the traffic-choked streets of Manhattan's garment center have been seeking and finding more accessible sites for warehousing and distribution points in northern New Jersey.
VIENNA, May 30 (Reuters) G.W. Pabst, the Austrian film producer and director, died here last night. He was 82 years old.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, May 30 Turkey, has granted the Soviet Union authorization to move 10 warships from the Black Sea through the Turkish straits into the eastern Mediterranean to reinforce its naval force there.

VENTURA, Calif., May 30 (UPI) Billy Casper, the United States Open champion defeated Al Geiberger, the Professional Golfers' Associaion champion, 71-72, in National Golf Day play today at Olivas Park Golf Course.
MANILA, May 30 The Philippines and Indonesia agreed in principle today to organize themselves into an economiccultural-technical association that would also include Thailand, Malaysia and Singapore.

A constructive call for prompt action on monetary reform has been made by the International Chamber of Commerce, which favors a contingency plan to create additional reserves to support increased trade and investment because there may not be enough gold and foreign exchange to go around.
MOSCOW--The Soviet Union's sweeping agricultural reforms, aimed at expanding and stabilizing output, face a major test of effectiveness this year as a result of uncertain weather conditions.
BALTIMORE, May 30 (AP)--Sam McDowell held the Baltimore Orioles to three hits today as the Cleveland Indians scored a 3-2 victory after the Orioles had taken the opener of a double-header, 5-4.

Mr. and Mrs. Stig Akermark of Stockholm have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lena Christina Akermark, to Jesse Reid Dietz of New York. He is the son of Mrs. Reid Dietz of Miami and Norfolk, Va. and Ernest Conrad William Dietz of Bronxville, N.Y.

ARMONK, N.Y., May 30 Dr. Margaret Gilbert Benz, associate professor of sociology at New York University and an authority on marriage and family life, died of a heart ailment Sunday in Northern Westchester Hospital in Mount Kisco. Her age was 68 and she lived on Mead Road.
SALISBURY, Conn., May 30 Miss Julia Pettee, a theological librarian and author, died today in a nearby nursing home. She was 94 years old.
Education received grants of $572-million last year from the nation's major foundations, the Russell Sage Foundation reported yesterday.

TORONTO, May 30 Canada's marathon public hearings into the financial troubles and collapse of the Atlantic Acceptance Corporation ended today with scandal tainting about 35 groups of persons running 286 companies in six countries.

AMMAN, Jordan, May 30 King Hussein appeared cheerful when he landed at the Amman airport this afternoon to be greeted by large crowds chanting Arab nationalist slogans and hailing him and President Nassar.

WASHINGTON, May 30 While progress has been made in the Christian-Jewish theological dialogue, full understanding is still impeded by "deep layers of Christian tradition" that are "infiltrated with antiSemitic bias," a prominent Jewish religious leader charged here today.
David Merrick will be involved in two more musicals, "The Girls Upstairs" and "The Apartment" the former with Leland Hayward in the fall and the latter on his own in the fall of 1968.
Miss Elisabeth Horne Fell of New York, whose ancestors include the Drexels of Philadelphia, will be married to Philip Dillon Allen, a nephew of C. Dougas Dillon, former Secretary of the Treasury.
WASHINGTON, May 30 (AP) Cap Peterson's homer in the 11th inning gave the Washington Senators a 4-3 victory in the second game and a sweep of a double-header against the Kansas City Athletics today.

OTTAWA, May 30 (Canadian Press) Commodity exports by Canada in January jumped 28.3 per cent from the level a year earlier, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics reported today. They totaled $926,516,000, against $722,930,000 in January, 1966.

HONG KONG, May 30 A young Englishman studying in Peking was quoted today as having said that Chinese Army units assigned to China's schools had been successful in helping students stamp out individualism and look at things "from a really Communist point of view."
DALLAS, May 30 (AP) Officials of the Texas Pacific Railway Company testified today that the proposed merger of two large railway concerns would adversely affect the Dallas economy.
BERKELEY, Calif., May 30 (AP) Dr. William Leonard Crum, former economics professor at Yale, Harvard and the University of California, died yesterday at his Berkeley home. He was 73 years old.
Four seeded players scored victories and one favorite was defeated in the second round of the Brooklyn men's tennis championship at the Knickerbocker Field Club in Flatbush yesterday.

The Carll Tucker home, 733 Park Avenue at 71st Street, will be opened Tuesday evening to benefit the Greater New York chapter of the Epilepsy Association. The event is being arranged by the Resources Council and interior designers who are redecorating the house.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange finished above their lowest levels yesterday after drifting down most of the day.

DETROIT, May 30 (UPI) Jim Northrop raced home on a throwing error in the eighth inning by a relief pitcher, Bob Locker, to give the Detroit Tigers a 4-3 victory over the Chicago White Sox today after the Tigers had won the opener, 4-2.
SAIGON, May 30 (UPI) American marines today destroyed North Vietnamese fortifications just below the border between North and South Vietnam.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., May 30 (UPI)--Because of bone growths on the front legs, the Argentine horse, Forli, an undefeated 4-year-old, has been withdrawn from Saturday's $100,000 Californian at Hollywood Park.

PHILADELPHIA, May 30--Grand opera came to Philadelphia on a grand scale last night when nearly 7,500 persons attended a performance of Puccini's "Turnadot" by the Metropolitan Opera Company of New York. It was the first of seven the troupe is giving here this week.
PARIS, May 30 (UPI) An American airline put in an order today for two BritishFrench Concorde supersonic jetliners and took an option to buy two more.

WILLEMSTAD, Curacao, May 30 The police of nearby Aruba, in the Netherlands West Indies, have arrested four men in connection with the theft of 25 gold bars valued at $975,000. Fifteen bars have been recovered.

On the occasion of Memorial Day, I wish to express to you, in the name of the Vietnamese people and in my own name, our most sincere gratitude for the valiant officers and men of the United States, who have made the supreme sacrifice of their lives to defend freedom and to ensure a just and durable peace in this part of the world.

The lobby of the DeMille Theater became as noisy and crowded as the first turn at Indianapolis Speedway yesterday when 66 patrons who had hoped to see the closed-circuit telecast of the 500-mile auto refused to leave until they received refunds.

SHORT HILLS, N.J., May 30 The engagement of Miss Mary Coleman Burke to David Trott Partridge, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter H. Partridge of Andover, Mass., has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Coleman Burke.
ROME, May 30 President de Gaulle and leaders of five other European countries decided here today to begin the examination of Britain's application for membership in the Common Market early next week.
WASHINGTON, May 30 (UPI) War veterans, mothers and clergymen gathered across the street from the White House today to protest against the Vietnam war.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., may 30 The President and Mrs. Johnson, their aides and employes at the ranch, attended Memorial Day services outside the ranchhouse this morning honoring the President's request for prayer throughout the nation.
THE leading contender for the Hard Luck Citation of the year would appear to be Hale (Ole) Erickson of Saratoga, Calif.
LOS ANGELES, May 30 The Los Angeles Dodgers continued to field a team of substitutes tonight and the substitutes continued to defeat the New York Mets.

CINCINNATI, May 30 (UPI) Tony Perez ruined Dick Hughes's bid for a perfect game tonight with an eighth-inning triple that sparked a two-run rally and enabled the leagueleading Cincinnati Reds to gain a 2-1 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals.

SIR JOHN GIELGUD'S revival of Chekhov's first full-length play, "Ivanov," was seen last night in a television version of the London stage production that preceded last year's presentation on Broadway. The TV adaptation had one notable advantage over the Broadway import the presence of Claire Bloom in the part of Sashabut in other particulars the work was not an occasion that found either Sir John or Chekhov at his most satisfying.

A newly former Vesper Boat Club eight of Philadelphia turned in a well-coordinated performance yesterday and defeated the New York Athletic Club heavyweight crew on the Orchard Beach Lagoon in the Bronx.
LIME ROCK, Conn., May 30 Peter Revson of New York, driving a factory Cougar for the first time, won the Lime Rock Trans-American auto racing championships today, outdistancing the field by two laps.

MERCEDES, Uruguay, May 30 (AP) The United States avenged itself tonight with the team that knocked it out of last year's world basketball championships when it defeated Yugoslavia, 76-71, in the first round of this year's tournament.
A car operated by an unlicensed 17-year-old girl went out of control yesterday in Harlem and crashed into a playground, killing one person and injuring nine others.

SIR JOHN GIELGUD'S revival of Chekhov's first full-length play, "Ivanov," was seen last night in a television version of the London stage production that preceded last year's presentation on Broadway. The TV adaptation had one notable advantage over the Broadway import the presence of Claire Bloom in the part of Sashabut in other particulars the work was not an occasion that found either Sir John or Chekhov at his most satisfying.

PARIS, May 30 The French Communist party published its first strong protest today against the Bolivian Government's arrest in April of Jules Regis Debray, a 26-yearold French writer-theoretician and supporter of Fidel Castro.
PERSIAN ROOM, The Plaza, Fifth Avenue and 59th Street. Jack Jones, singer, for three and a half weeks.

WASHINGTON, May 30 (AP) The Civil Aeronautics Board proposed yesterday to authorize United Air Lines to operate nonstop between San Diego, Calif., and major Eastern and Midwestern cities such as New York and Chicago.

The Medical Letter, an independent advisory service for physicians has found by testing that 22 brands of the same prescription drug varied to no significant degree in potency and general quality, but the most expensive cost 30 times more, wholesale, than the cheapest.

The Waterfront Commission was accused yesterday of harassment in its investigation of the Chet Maintenance Corporation of 17 Battery Place. The bistate agency is seeking to strip the company of its temporary stevedoring license because it "might be a front for a notorious waterfront hoodlum."
Last August a 10-year-old outfielder hit a foul ball that sailed across the street from a park in Bayside, Queens, and landed in the spaghetti of a resident who was having dinner on his lawn.

Two experts in the printing field, both with a union orientation, pointed yesterday to the potential advantages that the city's newspaper and commercial printing industries might derive through the introduction of modern, automated typesetting devices.
WASHINGTON, May 30 United States officials take the secession of Eastern Nigeria, and the resulting threat of civil war, seriously and are watching the situation closely.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., May 30 President Johnson deferred today a new threat of a nationwide railway strike for at least two months by forming an emergency board to review the grievances of conductors and brakemen.

The acquisition by Foodco, Inc., a distributor to the food service industry, of the Petersen-Owens, Inc., meat processors, has been completed, it was announced yesterday by George A. Richner, president of Foodco.
A critical one-mile section of Queens Boulevard, one of the city's most heavily traveled arteries, will be widened by two lanes to avoid traffic jams this summer and into the nineteenseventies.

Aeroflot, the Soviet carrier, will start operating two flight a week from Moscow to Montreal in early June, according to Tass, the Soviet press agency. This is to accommodate "the big inflow of Soviet tourists to the Expo 67 exhibition," Tass said.

RUXTON, Md., May 30 Mrs. William Harrison Gordon has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Sally Willson Gordon, to Alan Young Roberts, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Spurgeon Roberts of Ardsley-on-Hudson, N.Y.

MONTAUK, L.I., May 28 Manhattan corporations keep motel suites and yachts at the ready here for midweek conferences. Ghetto residents come by bus from the city to fish for food in the ocean. And scientists convene here each winter for seminars at motels.

OTTAWA, May 30--Prime Minister Lester B. Pearson said tonight that future United Nations peace-keeping forces must be firmly based in the international organization and preferably in the Security Council.

LUSAKA, Zambia, May 30 The world's four major copper exporting countries are expected to agree to cut production by up to 15 per cent immediately at a conference on pricing and marketing opening here Thursday.

WEST HARTFORD, Conn., May 30 Miss Carol Ann Greenblatt, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Harold J. Greenblatt of New Britain, was married this evening to Ronald Brecher, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Brecher of Great Neck, L.I. Rabbi Albert G. Silverman of Jamaica, Queens, performed the ceremony at Temple Beth El.
A 15-year-old high school freshman was held yesterday in the rifle slaying of his father.

The acquisition by Foodco, Inc., a distributor to the food service industry, of the Petersen-Owens, Inc., meat processors, has been completed, it was announced yesterday by George A. Richner, president of Foodco.
The Administration and Congress have just combined their talents to provide a stunning example of how not to operate flexible tax policy.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 31--A. J. Foyt Jr. of Houston won the 51st running of the 500-mile race today when auto racing's newest and fastest creation, a whispering turbine, went out of action with a broken ball-bearing holder in its gear box with only three laps to go and holding a 45-second lead.
TEHERAN, Iran, May 28-- An authoritative source has reported that the Soviet Union has offered to sell India at least 200 SU-7 jet fighter-bombers.
DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, May 31--In the sticky, oppressive heat of the decaying courtroom, 10 forlorn-looking black Africans stood in the dock, shifting uneasily as the charges were read to them.

BREWSTER, N.Y., May 31 --The engagement of Miss Dorothy Ann Flanagan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph T. Flanagan, to Gregory Arthur Markel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Markel of Sunny Gables, has been announced by the prospective bride's parents.

SPRINGFIELD, N.J., May 31--Arnold Palmer warned today that contestants in the 1967 United States Open golf championship had better inspect the flagstick placeon the greens before starting every round.
Rival Pet Foods is preparing to make its line national next year.
GROWING pains have always been New York's main malady. These galvanic symptoms, of course, include growing deterioration here and there. Up and down and up again, that's our story.
HONG KONG, May 31-- Hong Kong has asked Communist China for more water to help meet a critical shortage.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, May 31 (Reuters)--Nationalist China decided today to rebuild immediately its pavilion, which burned down yesterday at the Expo 67 fair in Montreal.

WASHINGTON, May 31 --Representative Paul A. Fino, Republican of the Bronx, continued his feud with Mayor Lindsay today, introducing legislation designed to block what he called the city's "Gestapolike plans to inspect one-and two-family homes while slums fester,"
General Lucius D. Clay resigned yesterday as chairman of the board of the Public Development Corporation, which was set up to promote business and attract new industries to the city.

LONDON, May 31--Britain is consulting with other maritime nations on a declaration that would assert that the Gulf of Aqaba is an international waterway through which all nations have the right of free passage.
OTTAWA, May 31 (Canadian Press)--Canada's telecommunications industry proposed today an immediate start on a Canadian-owned, multipurpose communications satellite system, to be operational by 1970.

A burial service for Harry Belcher Wheatcroft, a retired civil engineer who supervised the linkage of the New York and New Jersey segments of the Hudson Manhattan tubes more than 50 years ago, will be held at noon today at Mount Pleasant Cemetery, Newark.

ROCHESTER, May 31-- Mr. and Mrs. Donald F. Wolcott have announced the engagement of Mr. Wolcott's daughter, Miss Lynn Ellen Wolcott, to Fred Edward Chemerys 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Chemerys Jr. of New York.
PRINCETON, N.J., May 31--The Princeton Hospital will benefit from a dinner dance on Friday night and a fete all day Saturday, both on the campus of Princeton University.

LONDON, May 31--When President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic seized the Suez Canal almost 11 years ago, Western Europe suddenly found itself deprived of the lifeline for 80 per cent of its oil supplies.
The American Stock Exchange reported yesterday the changes carried below in the shareholdings of officers, directors and major stockholders of listed companies.
STAMFORD, Conn., May 31 --Henry Grady Chandler Jr., national sales manager for Revlon International of New York, died yesterday at his home, 340 Hycliff Terrace. He was 46 years old.
IT all started for Anthony John Foyt Jr. when he was 3 years old. He was presented with a blood-red miniature racing car.
New exits and traffic improvements will be opened at Kennedy International Airport today in an effort to cope with the anticipated summer travel rush.
NAHA, Okinawa, May 31-- More anti-American agitation is said to be in store for this United States defense bastion in the Western Pacific, an important supply base for war operations in Vietnam.
Miss Elizabeth Brooke Henry and John Lexow Kirsten Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Kirsten of Fairfield, Conn., plan to be married on Aug. 19 in Fairfield.

WASHINGTON, May 31--The awkward timing of the latest Middle East crisis demonstrates again the need for an International Bureau of Wars. The idea, which was first proposed twelve years ago at the Geneva Conference on Rational Warfare, envisions an international agency similar to the body that licenses world fairs.
Twenty-six poverty areas in the city will be served by the 10 legal corporations in a program to aid the poor.

Jim Bouton, 28 years old and a Yankee pitcher since 1962, was sent to Syracuse of the International League on option last night. In his place, the Yankees signed Bill Mombouquette, 30, a right-hander who was a free agent after nine years of American League pitching for the Boston Red Sox and Detroit Tigers.
Secret Service agents seized $500,000 in counterfeit $20 bills yesterday and arrested six men, five here and one in Cleveland, on conspiracy charges.

APDAILA, South Vietnam, May 31--On the January day when Sgt. Carroll Soape found out, he came back to the 10 other marines who man this hamlet outpost and said, "I'm not going to wrap myself in the American flag tonight."
DEVON, Pa., May 31--Nanticoke, the defending champion, went three clean rounds tonight and won the open jumper class at the Devon horse show.
ANKARA, Turkey, May 31 (Reuters)--Two Soviet Navy ships passed through the Bosporus and the Dardanelles today into the Mediterranean.
WASHINGTON, May 31-- Marcus Alfred Reno was restored today to the rank of major with an honorable discharge from the Army, 91 years after he fought with Custer at the Little Bighorn.

A committee of the City Council, seeking a solution to a strike of building service workers here, approved last night 13 Lindsay-sponsored amendments to the rent-control law that have already been rejected by the owners of rentcontrolled buildings.
ATHENS, May 31--The ruling junta published a law today making it a punishable offense for any salaried Greek to earn more than the $1,500 a month that the Premier gets.

Billy Strayhorn, jazz composer, arranger, lyricist and pianist, who was often called Duke Ellington's alter ego, died of cancer yesterday at the Hospital for Joint Diseases. He was 51 years old. He had worked for Mr. Ellington since 1939, and was the composer of the Duke's theme song, "Take the A Train."

NEW CANAAN, Conn., May 31--W.H. Hindle, a British journalist and author and a former consultant to the United Nations, died today in Norwalk Hospital after a long illness. He was 63 years old and lived here on Mill Road.

ALBANY, May 31--The State Department of Social Welfare today directed local welfare departments to make retroactive Medicaid payments for three months preceding the month in which a Medicaid form was filed by an applicant.
WASHINGTON, May 31-- Two Air Force helicopters left New York today to attempt the first nonstop helicopter crossing of the North Atlantic to Paris.

Dr. Richard Raskind of New York, back in tournaments after a long layoff, ousted Alan Davidson of Glen Cove, L.I., the No. 4 seeded player, 6-4, 6-3, yesterday in a third-round match of the Brooklyn tennis championship.
The new president of the American Institute of Architects is Robert L. Durham of Seattle, who has succeeded Charles W. Nes Jr. of Baltimore.

A national information system for assuring the availability of every significant scientific or technical document of whatever origin is "inevitable," a spokesman for the Atomic Energy Commission said yesterday.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 31--Associate Justice William J. Brennan Jr. told 572 women graduates of Douglass College today that he hoped they would not make the mistake his generation had made 40 and 50 years ago in assuming it could "make the world safe for democracy."

WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP)--Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara authorized the Navy today to spend $800,000 for exploratory demothballing of the battleship New Jersey to see how much it would cost to prepare it for service off Vietnam.
Mayor Lindsay announced plans yesterday for a $10-million Hall of Science building to be put up in the next 14 months at Flushing Meadow-Corona Park in Queens.

CLINTON, N.Y., May 31-- Dr. Robert W. McEwen, who retired following a heart attack last June after 17 years as president of Hamilton College here, died yesterday in St. Luke's Memorial Hospital Center in Utica after a long illness. He was 60 years old.
UNION BEACH, N.J., May 31--Thirty-one of the 46 elementary school teachers here are resigning on Saturday, two weeks before the end of the school term.
A six-foot boa constrictor, usually seen coiled around the neck of a belly dancer, was found wrapped around the branch of an elm tree in Central Park yesterday.

Weeks of intensive detective work, marked by the use of decoys and telephoned tips, came to an end last night when the Brooklyn police charged an 18year-old youth with the fatal stabbing of two men he had asked in vain for cigarettes.

CLEVELAND, May 31 (AP)--Owners of the lake freighter Cedarville and the Norwegian motorship Topdalsfjord admitted today that both ships were liable in the collision in May, 1965, that resulted in the sinking of the Cedarville. Ten lives were lost in the accident, which took place in dense fog in the Strait of Mackinac.

Eleanor Lee, a distinguished nursing educator and former director of nursing at the Presbyterian Hospital, died yesterday, apparently of a heart at tack, while visiting Maxwell Hall, the nursing student residence of the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. She was 71 years old and lived at 7 Craigie Circle in Cambridge, Mass.

DUBLIN--As long ago as 1844, a college professor wrote of his belief that mineral wealth lay in the limestone subsoil of Ireland, but no one then or for long afterward even bothered to investigate the possibility.

George E. McDonald, president of the Newspaper Mailers Union 6, said yesterday that there was a deadlock in negotiations between his union and The New York Times, The Daily News and The Long Island Press.

The 1967 Rheingold Central Park Festival at the Wollman Memorial Skating Rink will start Friday, June 23, with a concert by Louis Armstrong and Flip Wilson and will end Sunday, Aug. 27, with Lester Flatt, Earl Scruggs and Doc Watson.

PARIS, May 31--Paris gave an enthusiastic reception tonight to "Trumpets of the Lord," a theatrical presentation of old-time religion, rural American style, that blends Negro spirituals and sermons in the serio-comic fundamentalist vein by the late James Weldon Johnson.
Bond prices surged yesterday, making the rally that began last week as large as any this year.

WASHINGTON, May 31-- William S. Strauss, assistant general counsel at the Library of Congress until his retirement in March, died at the Georgetown University Hospital Monday after a long illness. He was 57 years old.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., May 31--The Rev. Dr. H. Franklin Paschall, pastor of the First Baptist Church of Nashville, was re-elected today to a second term as president of the Southern Baptist Convention.

ABOARD U.S.S. AMERICA, in the Sea of Crete, May 31-- Vice Adm. William I. Martin, commander of the United States Sixth Fleet, asserted today that Soviet vessels closely monitoring his fleet's movements "frequently endanger our ships."

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 31--The United States proposed a Security Council resolution today to get the "breathing spell" that Secretary General Thant has said is vital to achieve a settlement of the Israeli-Arab crisis.

MIAMI BEACH, May 31-- The North American team beat Thailand by 27 international match points in the 10th round of the world bridge championship here this afternoon and gained 17 victory points out of a possible 20.
CHICAGO, May 31 (UPI)-- The Chicago Daily Defender one of the nation's most prominent Negro-circulation news papers, has asked readers for ideas on preventing violence this summer.

The Middle East crisis hung a sword of Damocles over some commodity futures markets yesterday, threatening to sever price relationships based on the fundamentals of supply and demand. The psychology of the situation continued to spur prices higher.

Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that the so-called hippies involved in Tuesday's clash with the police in Tompkins Square Park had been "engaging in "noisy but generally harmless activity," and that "the fracas might possibly have been averted."

WASHINGTON, May 31-- The Federal Home Loan Bank Board announced today that the ceiling on interest rates that savings and loan associations can pay to savers would remain basically unchanged after July 1.

The Board of Regents, which controls education in the state, urged the Constitutional Convention yesterday to write into the State Constitution a provision for higher education as well as for elementary and secondary training.

Galahad is a 21-year-old who, until early last December, lived in Kansas City. He now lives in the East Village and operates a commune, an apartment where anyone can stay for a night, a week or as long as he likes.

PHILADELPHIA, May 31 (UPI)--The Philadelphia Phillics purchased John Boozer, a right-handed pitcher, from San Diego in the Pacific Coast League today and asked waivers on Pedro Ramos to make room for him.
A STAR is born on Seventh Avenue as infrequently as on Broadway, but instant success came last week to Jeannene Booher with her first fall fashion collection for Claret.
FORT JACKSON, S.C., May 31--The Army put four doctors on the stand at Capt. Howard B. Levy's court-martial today to defend its practice of "political medicine" in Vietnam.
WABC-TV in New York plans to show Alfred Hitchcock's "Psycho" on June 24. It will be the first time that the 1960 film about a homicidal psychopath will be telecast.

Chief Justice Warren's magisterial dissent in the Perez v. Brownell denationalization case in 1958 is one of his most impressive opinions in his service on the Supreme Court. That opinion has now nine years later achieved vindication in the Court's ruling this week in the case of Afroyim v. Rusk.

The workings of an international narcotics smuggling ring said to have been headed by Stefano Magaddino, reputed Mafia leader, were disclosed yesterday in a trial transferred here from Rome earlier this week.

LOS ANGELES, May 31 (AP)--George F. Knoop, who admitted faking his own drowning to collect Social Security payments, was sentenced today to a maximum of 10 years in prison on each of three counts, to run consecutively.

Two firemen who have seen people die because their escape from a burning building was blocked by security gates installed in windows demonstrated a device yesterday that they hope will avert future tragedies.
WASHINGTON, May 31-- The crisis in the Middle East has probably blocked an impending loan to the United Arab Republic by the International Monetary Fund.

MOSCOW, May 31 (UPI)--A Soviet newspaper told its readers today that Stalin's daughter, Svetlana Alliluyeva, was as "unhappy as a prisoner" in the United States. It also charged agents of United States "special services" are helping write her memoirs.

The present retail sales tempo represents a "curious kind of situation" in which there is a general lag in consumer buying but stronger sales in higher-priced than in lower-priced merchandise, Isidore Newman 2d, president of the City Stores Company, said yesterday--after the company's annual meeting.
Governor Rockefeller dismissed as a misunderstanding last night reports published in Venezuela that he was planning to retire from public life at the end of his current term in 1970.
PHILADELPHIA, May 31 (AP)--Fred Shabel, assistant athletic director at the University of Connecticut, was named athletic director at Pennsylvania today.

ROME, May 31--Charges that Pope Pius XII turned his back on persecuted Polish Catholics during the early years of World War II are challenged in the third volume of Vatican war documents, which was published today.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 31 (AP)--The police arrested tonight 35 open-housing demonstrators in the first significant protest in the civil rights controversy here in about three weeks.
CAIRO, May 31--Iraq began airlifting troops to the United Arab Republic today for a force that is to watch the Strait of Tiran, reliable Arab sources reported.

The Rockefeller interests have taken another step toward consolidating their already substantial realty holdings west of the Avenue of the Americas. Rockefeller Center, Inc., has signed a contract to purchase the 994seat Playhouse Theater at 137 West 48th Street, between the Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue, for a reported price of $1.5-million.
LEWISTON, N.Y., May 31 (AP)--Tom Heffron Jr., of Groton was named all-round champion yesterday at the New York skeet championships.

New York University is canvassing tenants of its residential buildings on Washington Square North this week, to determine whether they want the semiannual Washington Square Outdoor Art Exhibit on their doorsteps.

WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP)--House Republicans, aided by some Democrats, finally came up with a victory today in a drive to cut proposed Federal spending by 5 per cent during the fiscal year starting July 1.
TOKYO, May 31 (AP) -- Japan's 1966 gross national product was $97,045,277,777, the Economic Planning Agency said Wednesday.

The apartment house employes' strike, increasingly a threat to the health of hundreds of thousands of tenants, is obviously being used by a segment of the landlords as a weapon to destroy rent control. Mayor Lindsay is right in refusing to yield to what he has described as "a gun held at the city's head."
Still fuming over the disqualification of Dr. Fager in Tuesday's $119.200 Jersey Derby, Manuel Ycaza said yesterday he would try to "get away from it all" by taking his family on a vacation.
HONG KONG, May 31--Efforts in Communist China to combine schooling with a classroom revolution are not working well.

A FLOCK of toddlers, shepherded by their mothers, happily bade farewell yesterday to four experimental swings in the park playground near 77th Street and Central Park West. The bucket swings, installed late last fall to replace the old, steel models, had brought consternation and complaints.
WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP) --Though John Charles Daly Jr. has not even started his new job as head of the Voice of America, his view of the task has already evoked criticism in the House.

On the eve of the International Pace, a mile-and-a-half contest for a gross purse of $100,000 at Yonkers Raceway, Martin Tananbaum, the president of the harness racing course, began a move yesterday to have more and better horses coming from New Zealand and Australia to the United States in a reciprocal arrangement.
WASHINGTON, May 31-- Manufacturing inventories rose slightly more than $600-million in April, the largest increase since January, the Commerce Department reported today.

WASHINGTON, May 31-- The election year 1968 is beginning to look like 1948, when Strom Thurmond's States' Rights party and Henry Wallace's Progressive party operated on either edge of the usual political spectrum.

The United States Steel Corporation said yesterday that its new president and chief administrative officer would be Edwin H. Gott, executive vice president for production. The announcement ended months of conjecture in the steel industry.

WASHINGTON, May 31-- Secretary of the Interior Stuart L. Udall announced today an "enforcement conference" to be held in New York on June 13 and 14 on the polluted waters of the Raritan Bay between Staten Island and New Jersey.

LUSAKA, Zambia, May 31-- The Chilean and Zambian delegations to a four-nation copper exporters conference denied today that they had already agreed on a plan for future pricing and marketing policies.
ALBANY, May 31 (AP)-- The one-man, one-vote concept does not apply to the composition of the State Board of Re gents, the Court of Appeals held today.

LAGOS, Nigeria, May 31--A mobilization of troops and exservicemen began today under orders of Lieut. Col. Yakubu Gowon, head of Nigeria's Government, following the secession yesterday by the Eastern region.

WASHINGTON, May 31-- Secretary of State Dean Rusk said today that he hoped the resources being spent by the world on arms could be diverted into the development of natural resources, a move that would make "allies of us all."

Elia Kazan will receive $500,000 for the screen rights to his best--selling novel, "The Arrangement," and $500,000 to produce and direct the movie for Warner Brothers. In addition, the company will pay him up to 50 per cent of the profits of the picture, according to Benjamin Kalmenson, president of the company.

DETROIT, May 31 (AP)-- Ralph C. Wilson Jr., a Detroit multimillionaire, today pledged his $10-million football club-- the Buffalo Bills of the American Football League--as security for any property settlement in a pending divorce hearing.

ZURICH, May 31 (Reuters)-- The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development will borrow 60-million Swiss francs ($13.9-million) at 5 per cent on the Swiss capital market early next month, banking sources said here today.

Dr.Leo Loewe, a pioneer in the use of penicillin to cure infectious diseases of the heart, died Tuesday in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 70 years old. His office was at 940 Park Avenue, and he lived at 201 East 79th Street.

WASHINGTON, May 31-- Diplomatic sources reported today that Britain, the Netherlands and Portugal had pledged support to a concerted effort by maritime powers to contest the Egyptian blockade of the Gulf of Aqaba.
The City Commission on Human Rights reported yesterday that there was still bias in the building industry here.

A state judge politely, but forcefully, admonished a lawyer defending a client yesterday against a charge that she was in contempt of court for refusing to testify in an investigation into waterfront corruption.
TEL AVIV, Thursday, June 1 --Proposals for a shuffle of the Israeli Cabinet were discussed in the Dan Hotel here in a midnight session last night.
MADRID, May 31--The Cortes (Parliament) opened debate today on the regime's bill to increase the power of its National Movement.

Place Nina Perera Collier in a desert or on a mountain and she will find a way to make the arts bloom. When she was living in Baltimore, which is neither desert nor mountain, she helped to start what has become a powerful nationwide force known as Young Audiences.
WASHINGTON, May 31-- The Department of Health, Education and Welfare named a special panel today to recommend within six months whether to include prescription drug costs in the Medicare program.

WASHINGTON, May 31-- Following a sharp two-hour debate, the Rabbinical Assembly, an influential organization of Conservative rabbis, defeated today by a substantial majority a resolution that favored Federal aid to private and religious schools.
WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP)--The Government forecast today that nuclear power plants would be furnishing enough electricity by 1980 to meet the needs of about 150 million people in the United States.

WASHINGTON, May 31 (UPI)--Representative Richard Ichord, Democrat of Missouri, said today that the only thing wrong with the M-16 rifle was that there were too few of them. He said that the continued controversy over the weapon would cause a morale problem in Vietnam.
BALTIMOPE, May 31--A local civil rights leader has criticized what he called "the New York bosses" of the Congress of Racial Equality's target city project here.
HONG KONG, May 31 (AP) --The State Department has warned nearly 100 Americans living in nearby Macao to leave the Portuguese territory following anti-British demonstrations.
The American Stock Exchange turned in its worst performance in nine months yesterday as declines outnumbered advances by more than 8 to 1.
A campaign to raise $36,500 for a summer pilot program of church-sponsored youth centers in Harlem and upper Manhattan was announced yesterday by the Protestant Council of New York.

WASHINGTON, May 31-- Only one out of five of the delegates to the Republican National Convention that nominated Barry Goldwater in 1964 will be voting at the 1968 convention, if past political patterns prevail.

BOSTON, May 31--The National Committee of Negro Churchmen called today for a national campaign to complete "the unfinished American revolution" through a multimillion dollar fund for economic development of the Negro community.

PHILADELPHIA, May 31-- Invoking a policy of "restraint," Richard M. Nixon resisted today what he called the dual temptation of telling President Johnson what to do and thus getting attention in the headlines.

The fracas that erupted in Tompkins Square Park on Memorial Day was as unnecessary as it was unfortunate, and it illustrates the vital need for the utmost in tact and restraint on the part of the police to prevent minor incidents in coming months from blossoming into major riots.
The leaders of four United States maritime unions urged President Johnson yesterday not to agree to a compromise on the international status of the Gulf of Aqaba.
LYNN, Mass., May 31 (AP) --The Boston Shamrock Rovers and New York Skyliners played to a scoreless deadlock in a United Soccer Association game tonight before 3,850 fans at Manning Bowl.

ANCHORAGE, May 31--The development of Alaska's vast mineralized Arctic areas, where Eskimo villages represent some of the nation's deepest pockets of poverty, is about to be put under scrutiny by a blue ribbon commission.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 31-- At 8 o'clock this morning the sun timidly emerged from the clouds. That did it. For thousands of persons who were vacillating about going to work, the decision was made: go to the race and see if the cars can catch up with "that airplane."

Martin B. Stecher, Reform Democratic candidate for the Civil Court in Manhattan's Fifth District, challenged yesterday Deputy Borough President Leonard N. Cohen's right to call himself "the Reform choice" in the June 20 primary.
INDIANAPOLIS, May 31 (UPI)--Denis Hulme of New Zealand was elected rookie of the year today a few hours after he placed fourth in the 500-mile auto race postponed from yesterday.

PARIS, May 31 (AP)--Annette Van Zyl of South Africa defeated top-seeded Mrs. Billie Jean King of the United States, 6-2, 5-7, 6-4, today as a wave of upsets marked the women's quarter-finals of the French international tennis championships.
SHREVEPORT, La., May 31 (UPI)--Torrential rains of up to 12 inches triggered flash floods today from the Central Plains to Louisiana.
Stock market prices tumbled yesterday in the broadest and sharpest decline in seven months. Losses on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbered gains by an 8-to-1 ratio.

Four stories by Hans Christian Andersen are depicted in rugs of English wools made by Egetaepper, Inc., of Denmark. Suitable for either the walls or floors of children's rooms, the rugs measure 28 by 43 inches and cost about $56 in stores across the country. In New York they are at Norsk, 114 East 57th Street.
WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP)--The Senate voted today to extend for three years and expand the federal food stamp program for aiding needy households with grocery bills. The action came by voice vote.
LONDON, May 3--A British Government White Paper declared today that the rights and liberties of Britons would not be weakened or destroyed if Britain joined the European Common Market.
CINCINNATI, May 31 (AP) --Rich Nye got three hits, scored two runs, drove in a run and pitched the Chicago Cubs to a 6-5 victory tonight over the Cincinnati Reds.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., May 31 (AP)--Open-housing legislation, which could determine whether a $370-million atom smasher will be built in Illinois, suffered a major setback today.

SHREVEPORT, La., May 31 (AP)--Twenty Roman Catholic nuns of the Daughters of the Cross order based here announced today that they were giving up their church vows to establish an experimental religious community in Wisconsin.
The State of New York goes into the lottery business officially today, selling $1 sweepstakes tickets for the support of education. The first tickets will be on sale in nearly...
CHARLOTTE, N.C., May 31--Mr. and Mrs. Warren Edward Rixon have announced the engagement of their daughter. Miss Cathleen Craig Rixon, to Kay Jackson Jennell Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Jennell.

ANY fisherman who thinks society should conspire to inflate him to some sort of importance just because he catches fish of substance should be tried and sentenced to catch cod in the Rip off Montauk in January. And that's an opinion, baldly stated.

TRENTON, May 31--Gov. Richard J. Hughes signed into law today the new housing program of the State Department of Community Affairs. The major elements of the program are middle-income housing and new powers for the department to fight slums.

Thaddeus A. Tillotson proved himself a minor prophet as well as a major winner last night as he pitched the New York Yankees to a 3-0 victory over the Kansas City Athletics with some ninth-inning help from Dooley Womack and some batting support from Steve Whitaker.

The Interstate Commerce Commission rejected yesterday proposals that it consolidate two railroad merger cases on which its examiners presently are holding hearings. The commission said consolidating the proceedings at this time would "serve no useful purpose."
The spot rate on the British pound slipped yesterday in quiet trading on foreignexchange markets here.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 31--Following is the text of a statement made today by Arthur J. Goldberg at a meeting of the Security Council to introduce a United States resolution on the Middle Eastern crisis:

THE way Mrs. G.C. Aubertin of Greenwich, Conn., described it, the showing of dogs in Italy was sometimes fun to the point of hilarity. Practices that were commonplace there would bring sharp censure at America's ruleridden events.
DETROIT, May 31--The Chrysler Corporation said today it had completed the purchase of Redisco, Inc., a financing company, from American Motors Corporation.
DETROIT, May 31 (AP)-- Luis Tiant pitched a six-hitter and drove in two runs as the Cleveland Indians gained a 9-0 victory over the league-leading Detroit Tigers tonight.

The Union of American Hebrew Congregations has named Rabbi Alexander M. Schindler as vice president, it was announced yesterday. The union is the congregational body of Reform Judaism in this country and Canada.

ROME, May 31--President de Gaulle met with Pope Paul VI today for a discussion of subjects including the war in Vietnam and the crisis in the Middle East. He told the Pontiff that peace had "never been more blindly threatened."
Of those mentioned as possible new members of the Israeli Cabinet, the best-known outside of Israel, is Moshe Dayan, who gained world-wide attention in 1958 in the Sinai campaign.

The Common Market remains undecided about Britain's bid for entry. The summit conference of the Six has agreed to examine her application and the effect that her admission might have on the community. But they have deferred opening negotiations with Britain until they are convinced that her entry is negotiable.
The Campbell Soup Company announced yesterday in Camden, N.J., that its net income fell sharply in the third fiscal quarter and first nine months despite an increase in sales.
WHITE PLAINS, May 31-- A state appeals board ruled today that a newspaper editor who quit his job rather than print an editorial he disapproved was not entitled to unemployment pay.

HARVARD won the Boston Metropolitan 1966-1967 Chess League Championship with 13 - match points and 55 -14 game points. Second place went to Massachusetts Institute of Technology with 10-4 match points and 43-27 game points. Boylston was third with 9-5 match points and 41 -28 game points.
WASHINGTON, May 31--J. Edgar Hoover said today that civil rights leaders who named cities where riots might occur this summer were issuing an "open invitation" to violence.
Although they have charged three men in the Bronx murder last week of Dr. Elena Gall, a 55-year-old Hunter College professor, the police are still baffled about the motive for the slaying.
The New York Society of Security Analysts elected its first woman president yesterday.
BONN, May 31--The state visit of the Shah of Iran to West Germany is giving Bonn a small Middle East headache of its own.
ONE of the busiest and most engaging of Manhattan's marketplaces is a six or seven-block stretch of Bleecker Street in Greenwich Village.
A Georgia businessman has offered $2.4-million for the Cunard liner Queen Mary and plans to convert the 31-year-old British vessel into a trade fair ship to display United States products abroad.

Angel (Junior) Tomas Cordero has realized an ambition he has nursed ever since he came to the United States five years ago. He has finished on top in the jockey race for the 60day Aqueduct spring meeting, which ended yesterday.
RIO DE JANEIRO, May 3l-- This city's harried bus drivers, who generally wreak mayhem in the crowded streets without so much as a backward glance, were driving today with what passes for care.
The Metropolitan Museum of Art will present a week of live drama on the premises starting next Monday.

WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP)--The Senate passed by voice vote and sent to President Johnson today a compromise bill restoring major business tax incentives suspended last October as an anti-inflationary move.
AMMAN, Jordan, May 31-- The crowds at the airport were ecstatic last night when King Hussein returned from Cairo with his new defense agreement with President Gamal Abdel Nasser.
Harold Becher, a chemical engineer, consultant and designer, died on Saturday in Paterson, N.J., where he was visiting friends.

Glenn O. Kidd, vice president and a director of the DysonKissner Corporation, 230 Park Avenue, an investment company, died Tuesday in Harkness Pavilion, of Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 51 years old and lived at 55 Arrowhead Way, Darien, Conn.

TEL AVIV, May 31 (Reuters ) The Israeli Chief of Staff, Maj. Gen. Iitzhak Rabin, called tonight for continued alertness among his troops and expressed confidence in their ability to defeat the Arab armies "in their own land."
A two-state project will give New York's City Center Joffrey Ballet a summer residence in the Pacific Northwest.

ITHACA, N.Y., May 31-- Investigators here said today they were convinced that three recent fires in buildings housing Cornell University students, including one in which nine persons died, were caused by an arsonist.

Tenants of a 16-story apartment house on West End Avenue at 97th Street have become volunteer elevator operators and garbage men of their struck building.

AKRON, Ohio, May 31 (AP) --The Firestone Tire Rubber Company obtained a court order today limiting pickets at its plants after striking United Rubber Workers prevented salaried and office personnel from entering Firestone and the B.F. Goodrich Company here.
PARIS, May 31 (AP)--The magazine Jeune Afrique has decided not to publish articles on Communist China by Simon Malley recently published by The Chicago Daily News, an official of the magazine said.
About SOO of the 1,400 persons who had paid $6 on Tuesday to see the closed-circuit telecast of the Indianapoolis 500-mile race at the DeMille Theater here used their rainchecks yesterday.

CAIRO, May 31--Except for news correspondents, Britons and Americans have virtually disappeared from the streets of Cairo in recent days. But Cairo residents themselves are carrying on very much as usual despite international tensions.
The wholesale commodity price index maintained on Monday the level it reached on Friday, which was 99.7.

SHORT HILLS, N.J., May 31--Mr. and Mrs. Samuel W. Lambeth have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen Swaine Lambeth, to Ronald Ahley Dwight, son of Mrs. Edmund T. Clavette of North Attleborough, Mass., and Dr. M. Walter Paydos of Providence, R.I.
One of the values of positive thinking is that it can help to avoid a heavy tax bite on property and cash donated before death.
JOHN HAY WHITNEY'S long-rumored plan to let the public share in a part of his communications empire is now definitely on the way.

OXFORD, Miss., May 31 (UPI)--A young Negro testified today that he was kicked and beaten by angry whites in Grenada, Miss., last fall after he had left a formerly all-white elementary school that had been integrated under a Federal Court order.
Deputy Mayor Timothy W. Costello will go on the air to inform New Yorkers about food prices, it was announced yesterday.

ALBANY, May 31--The Constitutional Convention, in its first party-line split, voted tonight to ask Governor Rockefeller to call a special election to fill a disputed delegate's seat from the Bronx. The vote was 98 to 83.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 31--The United States military command appears to have begun a new campaign to discourage unfavorable reports--through official or journalistic channels--about the performance of the South Vietnamese Army.
LOS ANGELES, May 31 (AP)--Bill White's first hit of the season drove home Johnny Briggs in the 11th inning tonight and the Philadelphia Phillies went on to beat the Los Angeles Dodgers, 6-0.

FORMBY, England, May 31 --Nine Americans, including seven from the Walker Cup team, reached the fourth round of 32 in the British Amateur golf tournament tonight as a warm sun and light breeze finally made playing conditions familiar.

ROCHESTER, May 31--A $15-million trust to be used to establish endowed professorships at the University of Rochester has been created by Mr. and Mrs. Joseph C. Wilson. Mr. Wilson is board chairman and chief executive officer of the Xerox Corporation.
HOUSTON, May 31--The New York Mets lost to the Houston Astros, 6-1, tonight and fell into 10th place in the National League for the first time since October 1965.

Three suits have been filed in the State Supreme Court seeking to block the Board of Education from transferring 260 white students from Jamaica and Queens Village to Andrew Jackson High School in Cambria Heights. Nearly half of those now enrolled at Jackson are Negroes.
SAIGON, May 31--Navy fighter-bombers flew through heavy antiaircraft fire and surface-to-air missiles today to bomb two petroleum storage areas within four miles of downtown Haiphong.
CONCORD, N.H., May 31 (UPI)--Senator Robert F. Kennedy will apparently be a candidate in next year's New Hampshire Presidential primary whether he likes it or not.
CINCINNATI, May 31 (AP) --A sunken barge that had blocked Gate 5 of the Markland Dam and caused a traffic jam on the Ohio River was removed today, the United States Army Engineers reported.
Michel Saint-Denis, European actor, author, director and producer, will serve with John Houseman as co-director of the projected Drama Division of the Juilliard School.
Last month was almost the coldest May on record. It came in second.
WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP) --The Defense Department listed today the names of 38 men killed in connection with the war in Vietnam.

NEW HAVEN, May 31-- Trustees of the New Haven Railroad have notified the Federal District Court in New Haven that they have signed new agreements with the States of Connecticut and Rhode Island for additional subsidy assistance that assures continuation of passenger service on the line through the end of the year.

GENEVA, May 31--American, Malaysian and New Zealand participants complained about the anti-American tone of the proceedings as the second Pacem in Terris conference ended today with renewed attacks on United States policy in Vietnam.
Mayor Lindsay suggested last night that Rube Goldberg, the cartoonist, become the city's "commissioner of magic," since that "is the only thing left to solve the building strike."

MONTREAL, May 31--The first of the really big musical attractions to play at Expo 67 came to Montreal last night. The Royal Opera of Stockholm opened its run with a performance of Verdi's "A Masked Ball," and it was not as odd a choice as might offhand appear.
The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday it would buy nine and a half acres in the northern part of Oradell, N.J., "for possible future use as a site" for its central computer operation.
Prices on the London stock market continued to drift downward yesterday in slow trading.
PARIS, May 31--The Arabs and Israelis increased their pressure on France today to declare herself one way or the other in the Middle Eastern crisis.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., May 31-- The Suffolk County Human Relations Commission charged today that "unwarranted political interference" had blocked the reappointment of a civil-rights activist to the commission.

WASHINGTON, May 31-- The State Department reported today that the press secretary of the Hungarian Embassy had defected to the United States. His defection is the second by a Hungarian diplomat to be announced in two weeks.
RIO GRANDE CITY, Tex., May 31 (AP)--Texas Rangers arrested 12 persons today on charges of mass picketing near La Casita Farms, a union spokesman said.

Mrs. Aaron Dudley Lancaster of Stuttgart, Germany, has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Karen Marie Lancaster, to Alexander White Wellford Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Wellford of Memphis, Tenn. The wedding is planned for Aug. 2 in Kleiningersheim, near Stuttgart.

MINEOLA, L.I., June 1-- Nassau County Sheriff Joseph F. Maher, the Democratic candidate for Supervisor of the Town of Hempstead, pledged today to abolish the position he is seeking as "wasteful and unnecessary."

GALWAY, N.Y., June 1-- Paul Hodges, who retired in 1963 as assistant to the chairman of the Cities Service Company in New York, died of a heart attack yesterday in his home here on South Line Road. He was 62 years old.

A $36-million ship conversion program, designed to add seven container vessels to the fleet of Sea-Land Service, Inc., was announced yesterday by McLean Industries, Inc., Sea-Land's parent company; Litton Industries, Inc., and National Bulk Carriers, Inc.

ADEN, June 1--Britain is building up a force of warships in Aden Harbor. The aircraft carrier Hermes is here from the Far East with her escort frigates, the Brighton and the Leopard. Also in the harbor are two frigates, the Nubian and the Ashanti, from the Middle East Squadron. A sixth warship is expected.

CHICAGO, June 1--Fund raisers gave their ideas today for increasing contributions.

ALBANY, June 1--The Court of Appeals today reduced the death sentence imposed on Winston Moseley, who was convicted of the first-degree murder of Catherine Genovese in Kew Gardens, Queens, to life imprisonment.

BUENOS AIRES, June 1-- The imminent formation of a new Secretariat of Broadcasting and Tourism has been violently attacked by the morning newspaper La Presna as a threat to freedom of the press in Argentina.
