DETROIT, June 1 (AP)-- John O'Donoghue, a pitcher, hit a grand-slam home run tonight to lead Cleveland to an 8-2 victory over Detroit that knocked the Tigers out of first place in the American League.
LAGOS, Nigeria, June 1 (AP) --The United States Embassy is making plans to begin to evacuate 700 Americans in the Eastern Region of Nigeria.

WASHINGTON, June 1--The United States has drafted and is seeking the approval of maritime nations for a declaration asserting the right of free passage for ships of all nations through the Gulf of Aqaba.
HARTFORD, Friday, June 2 --The Connecticut House of Representatives approved a bill to set up a state lottery late last night. The lottery would raise money for education.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., June 1-- Louisville civil rights leaders announced today a new tactic in their drive to get an enforceable law to open housing to Negroes throughout the city.
BOSTON, June 1 (AP)-- Dean Chance pitched a fivehitter and Russ Nixon and Bob Allison belted home runs today as the Minnesota Twins defeated the Boston Red Sox, 4-0.

WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) --The deputy chief of naval operations for air describes the controversial F-111B aircraft as an easy plane to fly, with outstanding low-speed qualities, and predicts it will be an impressive airplane once engine improvements are made.

SEOUL, South Korea, June 1 --Campaigning for South Korea's National Assembly elections on June 8 was marred today by the fatal beating of an opposition campaign worker and the arrest of an opposition candidate on charges of violating national security and antiCommunism laws.
GENEVA, June 1--The 17nation disarmament conference was speechless today for the first time since it began more than five years ago. It recessed after 10 minutes.
Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday that an ocean-liner superterminal proposed on the Hudson River in mid-Manhattan would be the focus for extensive redevelopment of the whole area.
CINCINNATI, June 1 (AP)-- Tommy Helms's bases-loaded single climaxed a two-out, three-run rally in the ninth inning that lifted the Cincinnati Reds to a 7-6 victory over the Chicago Cubs tonight.

WASHINGTON, June 1-- More than 900 partygoers filled the Shoreham Hotel's Regency Ballroom at tonight's fifth annual Hope Ball, and this made Dr. William Walsh, president of Project Hope, more than a little proud.

FORT SILL, Okla., June 1 (UPI)--A summary courtmartial today convicted Pvt. Andrew D. Stapp, a self-described "revolutionary socialist," of refusing to obey an order and gave him the maximum penalty for the offense.

ALBANY, June 1--Following are excerpts from the Court of Appeals decision today upholding the state's Textbook Loan Law. The majority opinion was written by Associate Judge John F. Scileppi and the dissenting opinion by Associate Judge John Van Voorhis.

NEW DELHI, June 1--The Health Ministry maintains 16,283 family planning clinics to help reduce a birth rate that threatens India's development. Dr. Dorothy Dunning Chacko maintains three clinics to help Indian couples have children.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., June 1 --A new, round Roman Catholic church, among the first to conform with architectural guidelines set two years ago by the Vatican Council, was dedicated here today by Cardinal Spellman and other church dignitaries.
HONG KONG, June 1--As she struggled to gain control of the Cultural Revolution, Mao Tsetung's wife used up "two tons of paper" revising a Chinese opera, in the words of her exasperated enemies.

WASHINGTON, June 1--A Forest Service plan to permit commercial logging in the midst of one of the largest wilderness areas in the country was halted today by Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freeman.
LOS ANGELES, June 1 (AP)--A.C. Rubel, retired board chairman of the Union Oil Company of California, died yesterday at Good Samaritan Hospital. His age was 72. He recently underwent heart surgery.

Touring golf professionals threatened yesterday to boycott the 1967 Professional Golfers' Association championship unless they gained greater control in the management of the game's $4.5-million circuit.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 1--American forces in Vietnam had 2,929 combat casualties last week, a military spokesman said today. This was the highest weekly total of the war and reflected the heavy fighting in and near the demilitarized zone at the border between North Vietnam and South Vietnam.

A witness before a Federal grand jury investigating a fraud conspiracy charged yesterday in Federal Court that he had been subjected to "a constant barrage of abuse, threats and accusations" by an assistant United States Attorney.

PHILIP ROTH, whose first collection of a novella and five short stories, "Goodbye, Columbus" (1959), won him a National Book Award for Fiction, is one of the country's finest, most forcefully intelligent and serious contemporary writers of what might be called, without denigration, conventional narrative fiction.

MOSCOW, June 1 (AP)--Soviet scientists at a remote Arctic base are launching singlestage rockets into the upper layer of the atmosphere as part of an international study of weather conditions, the Russian press agency Tass said today.
Dr. Bernardo Mendel, president of Lathrop C. Harper, Inc., dealers in rare and fine books at 8 West 40th Street, died of a heart attack yesterday in his home at 220 Central Park West. His age was 71.

FORT JACKSON, S.C., June 1--The first attempt in the history of military justice to raise medical ethics as a defense for willful disobedience was rebuffed today by the Army's senior trial judge at the general court-martial of Capt. Howard B. Levy.
JERUSALEM (Israel), June 1--Maj. Gen. Moshe Dayan, the hero of Israel's 1956 Sinai campaign against Egypt, became Israel's Defense Minister tonight.
WASHINGTON, June 1-- President Johnson sent to Congress today his long-delayed plan to give residents of the District of Columbia the framework of representative city government.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 1--The United States today turned over to the South Vietnamese Air Force 20 Northrop F-5 jet fighter planes.
PHILADELPHIA, June 1--Stockbrokers and dealers from the Philadelphia area met here today to express their opposition to proposals by the Securities and Exchange Commission affecting mutual funds.

DAMASCUS, Syria, June 1 (AP)--Yemeni Royalists reported that Egyptian jets dropped 50 gas bombs Monday on villages in the Beni Hashish area, 12 miles from the Yemeni Republican capital of Sanna, the Mecca radio reported.
SAIGON, June 1--American economic officials acknowledged today that prices are rising in South Vietnam twice as fast as they had predicted.

WASHINGTON, June 1--Authoritative sources said today that the Hungarian diplomat whose defection to the United States was disclosed yesterday was actually an officer in the Hungarian intelligence service.
The city sealed up apartment house incinerators for the first time yesterday in its drive to force compliance with the stringent new air pollution control law.

Russia's present rulers are more cautious than Nikita Khrushchev, but the game they are now playing in the Middle East could prove almost as risky as the Cuban missile adventure that nearly incinerated the world and ultimately cost Khrushchev his job.

John Steinbeck's "Of Mice and Men" will be televised next season on the American Broadcasting Company with George Segal, Nicol Williamson, Franchot Tone, Joey Heatherton and Donald Moffat in starring roles.

SUE LAWLESS and Ted Pugh are young comics with a lot on the ball--not quite enough to bring off an evening's entertainment all by themselves, as they try to do in "In the Nick of Time," but enough to make parts of the evening a delight.
MOSCOW, June 1 (UPI)-- The Soviet Union launched an unmanned satellite today into an orbit similar to the one Col Vladimir I. Komarov rode to his death.
Mr. and Mrs. Martin Rosenzweig of Hollis Hills, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Gitta R. Rosenzweig, to Bernard Yaker, son of Mr. and Mrs. Solomon Yaker of Brooklyn.

AREA A--Each day shows an improvement in fishing along the coast as the water recovers from the northeaster of 10 days ago. Around Atlantic City, blues and stripers are being caught in Great Bay along with winter flounders and a few early fluke.
PRINCETON, N.J., June 1-- St. John's and Rider College got superb pitching performances today in winning first-round games of the National Collegiate District II baseball playoffs.
RAHWAY, N.J., June 1-- Mayor John T. March today announced the appointment of Acting Police Chief Herbert T. Kinch, a Negro, as head of the city's police department.

WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP)--Twenty-six National Guard generals have petitioned Congress to scrutinize critically a proposal to abolish 15 Guard divisions. They contend such a move would cut down the nation's combat effectiveness "and dangerously impair the military prestige of our country in this period of international crisis."

Jerome B. Tobias, a 52-yearold lawyer, was reported last night in critical condition at Bellevue Hospital, where he was taken after suffering a head injury early yesterday during a scuffle with an unidentified man outside Arthur, the discotheque at 154 East 54th Street.

Silver prices set records in the New York and London markets yesterday, as they continued a rapid, two-week rise. Developments reflecting the higher quotations were reported from Mexico, Canada and India.

The indictment handed down yesterday by a Federal grand jury charging fraud and manipulation in the sale of securities calls attention to the role of the stockbroker, the key man in every trading situation.

The mothers of five Harlem youths now serving life sentences for the murder of a shopkeeper on April 29, 1964, were rebuffed yesterday in their attempt to submit a petition with 3,000 signatures to the Appellate Division.
ENGLEWOOD, N.J., June 1 --A team from New Jersey won the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's annual Golf Illustrated Trophy today over the Englewood Golf Club course.

PARIS, June 1--The economic authorities of most of the world's industrial powers examined their collective and individual pulses in the last two days and found that, by and large, conditions are about to improve--they hope.

MIAMI BEACH, June 1-- North America's dwin dling prospects of qualifying for the world championship final playoff match improved here this afternoon. The Americans recorded the biggest win of the week in crushing Thailand, 127-14, and scored the maximum 20 victory points.

AS soon as the Braves knew that they would be forced to play a lame-duck season in Milwaukee in 1965, they ex pected hostility from the few fans they would draw. They got it. The saddest moment that year for young Wade Blasingame, the left-handed bonus pitcher, came in a game against the Mets. He had been spectacular for 7 2/3 innings. Then a derisive voice spoke the words he preferred to have unspoken.

YONKERS, June 1--Romeo Hanover answered the only remaining question--"can he go the distance?"--by the manner in which he captured the $100,000 International Pace tonight before 23,050 harness-racing devotees at Yonkers Raceway.

ENUGU, Nigeria, June 1-- With the rest of Nigeria mobilizing troops and tightening the economic stranglehold over the secessionist eastern region, the East's military governor here sees civil war as inevitable.
WASHINGTON, June 1-- Prime Minister Harold Holt of Australia visited President Johnson today and once again pledged his country's support in the Vietnam struggle.
LONDON, June 1--Britain was urged today to abolish the right of crimnial suspects to remain silent under questioning by the police.
Mayor Lindsay intensified yesterday the pressure on landlords who are balking at a contract agreement with the striking building service workers.
"I am one of the dead," the slender, scholarly looking man said as he rose from his seat at a luncheon table in the Towers Hotel in Brooklyn to challenge a previous speaker.

MONTREAL, June 1--The space age was sure to generate a space opera, and Sweden's Karl-Birger Blomdahl came in just at the commencement. His was the first post-Sputnik opera--Sputnik I was launched in 1958 and Mr. Blomdahl's "Aniara" appeared in 1959.
SEOUL, South Korea, June 1 (UPI)--South Korean troops killed two North Korean infiltrators yesterday in a gun battle south of the demilitarized zone, Seoul military officials announced today.

A 42-year-old bookkeeper who has refused to testify before the Waterfront Commission on alleged criminal infiltration into the Chet Maintenance Corporation was found guilty yesterday of contempt of court.

GLADWYNE, Pa., June 1 --The engagement of Miss Liese Ober Hess, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. H. Ober Hess, to Arleigh Pritchard Helfer Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Helfer of Arcadia, Calif., formerly of York, has been announced by her parents.
The city began the month of June yesterday with 468.3-billion gallons of water in its reservoirs, or 98.3 per cent of their capacity of 476.5-billion gallons.
To the poet's question, "And what is so rare as a day in June ?" the weatherman replied yesterday that--at least for the Northeast United States-- the days this particular June will not be so rare."

VIENNA, June 1--In spite of the Middle East crisis, another planeload of emigrants left Vienna for Israel today. Among the group were about 40 women and children. They are refugees from Austria's Communist neighbors.
ALBANY, June 1--The Court of Appeals upheld today the constitutionality of the state law requiring public school systems to lend textbooks to pupils of parochial and private schools.
PARIS--Her name is Gin, pronounced as if it were spelled Jeen.

Pennsylvania's varsity and junior varsity eights, rated as the East's strongest entries in their divisions in the championships of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association, drew lanes 13 for the regatta on Onondaga Lake at Syracuse on June 17.

CHICAGO, June 1 (AP)-- Michael (Mickey Dee) D'Alessio, 54 years old, was acquitted today of Federal charges of an interstate hijacking conspiracy at the direction of Judge Bernard M. Decker in United States District Court here.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 1-- Maryland's limited open occupancy law, which already contains a built-in delay until 1968 in its effective date, suffered another setback last night as opponents of fair-housing legislation completed the first step to force the measure to a referendum.
The stock market turned around yesterday and marched up the hill it had marched down on Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, June 1--The Defense Department has reduced funds needed to counteract radar-controlled air defenses over North Vietnam "substantially below" what was considered the minimum requirement, a top Air Force general said in Congressional testimony released today.

Bond prices yesterday once again carved out gains, extending the sharp advance that began a week ago. Corporate issues took over from the Government sector in supplying the best advances and the most interest.
WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) --The House easily turned back an economy thrust aimed at its own expenses today and passed a bill appropriating $228-million for next year's operations.

Jonathon Pitchford, an 18year-old Brooklyn youth, pleaded not guilty yesterday to charges that he fatally stabbed two men he had asked to give him cigarettes. He was sent to Kings County Hospital for psychiatric examination.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 1 (AP)--Gaylord Perry limited Pittsburgh to two hits today as the San Francisco Giants posted a 7-1 victory.
Intelligence officers think that the reinforcement of Soviet naval forces in the Mediterranean is far more significant than its effect on the Middle Eastern crisis.

Rick Owens, a University of Pennsylvania football halfback, won the I.C.4-A 220yard dash yesterday, five days after the race was run.

MEMPHIS, June 1 (UPI)-- Dave Hill of Jackson, Mich., took the first-round lead in the $100,000 Memphis open today with a 5-under-par 65 despite three tee shots on one hole that he said could have kept him out of the tournament.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., June 1--Mr. and Mrs. Robert G. Werner of Scarsdale and East Hampton, L.I., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lynn Elizabeth Werner, to Albert Frederick Stevenson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Henry Stevenson of Bethesda, Md. The wedding is planned for Aug. 19.

CAIRO, Friday, June 2--The United Arab Republic will consider any country that attempts to break the blockade of the Gulf of Aqaba an aggressor and will deny its vessels access to the Suez Canal, the authoritative Cairo newspaper Al Ahram reported this morning.
Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary yesterday called better communication between the Police Department and the public one answer to the problem of crime in Harlem.
During the nineteen-fifties, after Sidney Bechet exiled himself to France, the only jazz musician regularly playing the soprano saxophone in the United States was Steve Lacy.
LAWRENCE of London, which helped bring the raincoat in out of the storm by making water-repellent coats that serve more than one purpose, is 20 years old.
Uniformed and plainclothes police swarmed into the Lower East Side last night as tensions between hippies and anti-hippies rose against a background of protest music in Tompkins Square Park.
Liberian-flag shipping was ordered yesterday not to enter the Gulf of Aqaba.
The election of John G. Moran, 39 years old, as a vice president of the National Bank of North America, West Hempstead, L.I., was announced yesterday.

DEVON, Pa., June 1--Sharon Maloney took a long, puzzled look at her 4-year-old chestnut gelding, Crags Corner today after he had clinched a tie for the green conformation hunter championship at the Devon Horse Show and shook her head.
There was a double bill on the charity circuit last night: A titled couple starred at the St. Regis Roof, and a swing into the sky by helicopter was the piece de resistance at La Guardia Airport.

Damascus, Mrs. Edith Bancroft's formidable colt, will be in the familiar role of favorite when the gates are sprung for the Belmont Stakes at Aqueduct tomorrow. With a field of ten likely to start in the 99th running of the famous test of 1 miles, Damascus is quoted at 6 to 5 on the long-range overnight line.

The United Network, which had hopes of becoming a fourth national television chain, formally ceased operation yesterday after one month's showing of the Bill Dana interview and variety program from Las Vegas. The loss to investors is expected to run to $2.2-million.

There were songs from Broadway shows, svelte models in cotton bikinis, jokes by celebrities of the stage and a friendly argument over who deserved the credit for yesterday's sunny and pleasant weather at Bryant Park.

AMMAN, Jordan, June 1-- Ahmed Shukairy, head of the Palestine Liberation Organization, declared today that it was "quite possible, in fact very probable," that the Jordanian Army might start a war against Israel.
ATHENS, June 1--The Greek Ministry of Public Order warned all Greeks tonight to show greater respect for the Greek flag or be punished.

SAYVILLE, L.I., June 1--Dr. Roland Binning of the Gardon City Country Club scored 43, 38 --81, to win low gross honors in the first Long Island Senior Golf Association tournament of the season at Island Hills Golf Club today. Binning from the Class D (60-64 age group) led a field of 148 over the par-71 course of 6.473-yards.
Fractured Nigeria, where the Eastern Region has now declared its independence, is a case in African incompatibility. The villains are tribalism, regionalism, religion, fears, suspicions, hatreds.

HONG KONG, June 1--Despite the closing of the British consulate and the departure of its staff, Macao Communists are continuing anti-British activities in concert with protestations here and in Communist China against British rule in Hong Kong.
Two detectives spotted a blinking red light on top of the dashboard of a white 1967 sedan yesterday afternoon. They ordered the driver to stop at Broadway and 95th Street.

Two Department of Buildings inspectors were arrested yesterday and accused of accepting $300 from the manager of a large apartment project in the Bronx in exchange for overlooking supposed building code violations.
WASHINGTON, June 1-- Two Senators began a campaign today to make sure that car buyers would not be overcharged for the new safety devices required by Federal law.
OCEANPORT, N.J., June 1 --Monmouth Park opens its 21st season tomorrow faced with a top-heavy turnout in its Miss Woodford Stakes that has caused the track to set up the fixture in two divisions.
HOUSTON, June 1--The New York Mets got only three hits off Mike Cuellar tonight, lost to the Houston Astros by 4-1 and sank a little deeper into last place.
ST. KITTS, June 1 (AP)-- The British Government was asked today to send ships and troops to quell a revolt on the tiny island of Anguilla in the British West Indies.

PLYMOUTH, Mich., June 1 --Mr.and Mrs. Kenneth L. Hulsing have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Hulsing, to David Anderson Brownlee, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Simpson Brownlee of Mount Lebanon, Pa.

WASHINGTON, June 1-- preliminary designs for a new $75-million Library of Congress branch building were called "functionally inadequate" today by an advisory committee of the American Institute of Architects.

ATHENS, June 1--Two Los Angeles lawyers, Edmund G. Brown, former Governor of California, and James Schwartz, interceded today with Greece's Government in behalf of Andreas Papandreou, the 48-yearold Greek politician awaiting trial for high treason.
ALBANY, June 1--Adam Clayton Powell lost his hope in the state's courts today of obtaining a review of a contempt conviction. The conviction made him liable to arrest any time he comes into New York.

BOSTON, June 1--The General Board of the National Council of Churches listened with some reservations today to a prediction that the decline of religious pluralism may lead to an American church with Roman Catholicism at the center.
ON all of the island of Manhattan, only nine private dwellings have been built since the end of World War II, which makes Helmut Jacoby a member of a very exclusive group.
PARIS--The United States never even pretended to have a Middle East policy prior to World War II, and now that we do pretend to have one few people are convinced.

HARRISBURG, Pa., June 1 --Gov. Raymond P. Shafer proposed today to the Legislature a new tax program designed to raise $266.6-million and balance his first budget of $1.791-billion for the fiscal year 1968.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 1 (AP)--Gov. James A. Rhodes signed a bill today banning racial discrimination in the hiring of workers for public works projects.
If Arthur Cohen played cautious tennis, tomorrow's Belmont Stakes probably would have a horse in it named Nehoc's Lob or Nehoc's Chop.

WASHINGTON, June 1-- The Justice Department's antitrust division has "under investigation" two recent mergers involving communication companies, it was disclosed today.
DETROIT, June 1--The Ford Motor Company's Lincoln-Mercury Division said today that sales in the final third of May were 13,226 cars, up 36 per cent from the 9,691 retail deliveries a year ago.

Widespread fractional declines marked trading on the London Stock Exchange yesterday. Although the Middle East situation remained the decisive factor, Wednesday's fall on Wall Street and the weakness in sterling also influenced sentiment.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost of dining in any particular establishment.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., June 1 (AP)--Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower received today a model of a proposed have to be built on the grounds in England where he fixed the date for D-Day.

WASHINGTON, June 1-- Six grants totaling $6.5-million for one-stop health centers that could serve 130,000 poor persons were announced today by Sargent Shriver, head of the Office of Economic Opportunity.
BONN, June 1--West Germany's Cabinet voted unanimously today to approve the sale of 20,000 gas masks to Israel.
CAPETOWN, June 1--South Africa will stop contributing to United Nations activities against South Africa and her policy of apartheid, Prime Minister Balthazar J. Vorster said in the Senate today.

Dr. Harry L. Levy, retiring vice chancellor of the City University who threatened to resign less than two years ago, was awarded the first Chancellors Medal at a ceremony yesterday in Bryant Park, at commencement exercises of the university's graduate division.

PARIS, June 1 (AP)--Tony Roche, the defending champion, and top-seeded Roy Emerson set up an all-Australian men's singles final today as the last of the Americans bowed out in the women's doubles quarter-finals of the French tennis championships.

Senator Long of Missouri, under criticism for allegedly manipulating his subcommittee's investigation of wiretapping in such a way as to help James R. Hoffa, has produced the politician's equivalent of the Good Housekeeping Seal of Approval: a letter of commendation from Federal Bureau of Investigation Director J. Edgar Hoover.

NEW HAVEN, June 1-- Mrs. Margaret Fogarty Rudkin, who built a loaf of bread into a $50-million a year baking business at Pepperidge Farm Inc., died of cancer today at Yale-New Haven hospital. She was 69 years old.
Pat Lynch, a New York newspaper reporter for 34 years, was appointed yesterday as assistant to the president of the New York Racing Association.
WASHINGTON, June 1-- Atomic batteries may be brought back to earth from future spacecraft instead of being designed as they are now to burn up in the atmosphere.

Disposable theaters that could be used for a couple of years and then replaced by another theater in a different style were suggested yesterday by Ralph Burgard, executive director of the Associated Council of the Arts.

MIAMI BEACH, June 1-- The Southern Baptist Convention, largest of the nation's Protestant denominations, voiced solid support today for a continuation of the war in Vietnam until "an honorable and just peace" could be achieved.
TORONTO, June 1--Call options on gold and silver bullion will be offered in a few days by Kippen Co., a Montreal brokerage concern.
The Federal Reserve appears to be continuing its twopronged effort in the money and capital markets. Its aims seem to be easier credit and less upward pressure on longterm interest rates.

ITHACA, N.Y., June 1--A Cornell University official disclosed today that the school had posted uniformed patrolmen at about 10 student residences, following three suspicious fires in the campus community in the last two months.

The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company announced yesterday in Akron, Ohio, that earnings in the second fiscal quarter, ended April 30, declined to $24,204,628, or 83 cents a share, from $25,302,912, or 87 cents a share, a year earlier.
Duplication is almost synonymous with United States Army, which, if it had a motto, might very well use "two each."
An all-out attack on the airline industry's strike insurance pact is about to be launched by six air transport unions.

DES MOINES, Iowa, June 1 (AP)--The Domocratic Governors' caucus will meet July 1 in St. Louis, primarily "to discuss ways of strengthening the organization," Gov. Harold E. Hughes of Iowa the caucus chairman, announced today.
The Courier is the "sittingest" ship in the United States Coast Guard.

Zambia is playing host to a tight little conference of copper-producing countries responsible for more than 70 per cent of the world's copper supply. The objective is a commodity agreement designed to stabilize the price of the metal by controlling its production.

Six men were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury in New York on charges of conspiracy, manipulation and fraud involving the Pentron Electronics Corporation, whose stock is listed on the American Stock Exchange.

Mayor Lindsay declared a health emergency in Manhattan early today and ordered immediate steps to clear the streets of garbage that has been accumulating here for six days as a result of the strike of apartment house maintenance workers.

WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) --A bill that would expand benefits under the cold war G.I. Bill of Rights was passed by the Senate today.
DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, June 1--President Julius K. Nyerere declared yesterday that he does not recognize Malaiois claim to the Tanyaman side of Lake Malawi.
ONITSHA, Nigeria, June 1-- Heavy seasonal rains poured down this morning on this bustling riverside market town.

Pinhas Sapir, Finance Minister of Israel, said yesterday that Israel had enough essential food supplies and raw materials for six to 12 months. He added that a prolonged Arab-Israeli military confrontation could seriously damage his country's economy.
ALBANY, June 1 (AP)--The police may not use evidence obtained in searching a person when he is being arrested simply for a traffic violation, the state's highest cour held today.

The annual pilgrimage of New York City Mayors to Albany, hat in hand, to ask the Legislature to grant the city additional taxing powers is an old story. A top official of the New York City Central Labor Council urged yesterday that a labor bill of rights, including the right of public employes to strike, be included in a new state Constitution.
LOS ANGELES, June 1 (AP) --Rich Allen drove in four runs and Larry Jackson scattered eight hits tonight as Philadelphia scored its second straight victory, 6-1, over the Los Angeles Dodgers.

WASHINGTON, June 1--The chairman of the House Banking and Currency Committee predicted today committee approval of his bill to prevent virtually all banks in New York State from selling lottery tickets.

The mixed-media program at the Black Gate Theater last night, "music, dance, shadows, light, film" by Mary McKay, dancer, Calo Scott, cellist, and Cassandra and Mordi Gerstein, filmmakers, left one, like Goethe, desperately wanting more light.

ROME, June 1--The Vatican issued today a rare public correction of statements contained in a communique distributed by the Indian Embassy here following a papal audience granted on May 26 to Dr. Sripati Chandrasekhar, the Indian Minister of Health and Family Planning.

FORMBY, England, June 1 --A fantastic eagle 2 at the home hole brought Marty Fleckman all square and provided the inspiration for his last-ditch triumph over Michael Attenborough on the 19th as four Americans gained the last eight in the British Amateur golf tournament today.

Sugar and silver attracted speculators yesterday, resulting in relatively heavy trading volume and higher prices for both.

Frank Stanton, the president of the Columbia Broadcasting System, and E. Mitchell Simon, a New York real estate man, have sold four commercial properties in Manhattan, Buffalo, Cincinnati and Montclair, N.J., to Fischer-Landis, a realty investment partnership of Milton H. Fischer and Milton Landis of 10 East 44th Street.

Dr. James A. Robertson died Wednesday after a brief illness in Carson T. Peck Memorial Hospital, Crown Street and Albany Avenue, Brooklyn, where he was co-director of obstetrics and gynecology. He was 57 years old and lived at 47 Plaza Street, Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) The National Aeronautics and Space Administration appointed Jerome Lederer, a leading authoriy on aviation safety, to a new post as head of its astronaut safety activity today.

Engelhard Industries, Inc., which makes chemicals and products of precious metals sold here and abroad, plans to acquire the Minerals Chemicals Philipp Corporation by an exchange of shares. The proposed basis of exchange values Minerals and Chemicals at about $250-million.

PEARL RIVER, N.Y., June 1--Millions of doses of polio vaccine for the armed forces were carried to Kennedy and Teterboro Airports in two helicopter trips today over the International Chemical Workers picket line at Lederle Laboratories.
WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) --The death of a young paratroop officer after drinking required at an initiation party brought a crackdown today on such practices in the armed services.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 1-- An undisclosed number of Iraqi fighter planes took off today from the airbase at Habbaniya, 45 miles west of Baghdad, to be stationed on the "front" with Israel, the Baghdad radio reported.

WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) --Elected Democratic Negro officials at their first national meeting pledged support to President Johnson today, but one spokesman warned against attempts by white politicians to divide Negroes.

PARIS, June 1--Two United States Air Force helicopters landed at Le Bourget Airport at lunchtime today, 30 hours and 48 minutes after they had left Floyd Bennett Naval Air Station in Brooklyn. It was the first nonstop helicopter crossing of the Atlantic Ocean.

SPRINGFIELD, Va., June 1 (AP)--Six Fort Belvoir soldiers, erecting a flagpole at a Little League baseball park as a gesture of Army goodwill, were electrocuted today when the pole swayed onto a high-voltage power line.

PHILADELPHIA, June 1-- James Dugan, who wrote several books on undersea exploration, died in Panama City, Fla., today, apparently of a heart attack, according to word received by his wife at their home here. He was 55 years old.

Mr. and Mrs. David Stuart Racusin of New York and Stamford, Conn., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Agatha Ellen Racusin, to Jonathan Kevin Ocko. He is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Felix Hugh Ocko of Piedmont, Calif. A December wedding is planned.

Dr. Grover C. Emery, a general medical practitioner at 519 Lincoln Place in Brooklyn, died of a heart ailment yesterday at the New York Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived at 1801 Dorchester Road in Brooklyn.

Mr. and Mrs. Melvin London, who live on the 17th floor of 170 Second Avenue, were offered a suite at the Pierre Hotel by Mr. London's employer for the duration of the building employes' strike. They refused and stayed home to organize a tenants' committee in their apartment house.
JERUSALEM (Jordan), June 2--Government sources reported today that King Hussein had complained to the United States Ambassador, Findlay Burns, over what he called Washington's proIsraeli policy.

BONN, June 2--With an expression of "heartfelt thanks" from the German people, Chancellor Kurt Georg Kiesinger joined other West German and American leaders today in a ceremony observing the 20th anniversary of the Marshall Plan.

WASHINGTON, June 2-- The Federal Communications Commission today ordered that hearings be held in New York City next month to find out what effect the construction of the twin 110-story towers at the World Trade Center will have on television reception.
A moonlight cruise with champagne aboard a Circle Liner next Saturday will benefit the Margarite Weinig Scholarship Fund of the Casita Maria Settlement House.

The Puerto Ricans and Slavs living in the Tompkins Square Park area resent the hippies who congregate there, and the resulting conflicts have heightened old tensions among the many racial and ethnic groups that live in that Lower East Side neighborhood.

PATERSON, N.J., June 2 (AP)--A new complication has entered the investigation into the bizarre case of a 29-year-old woman who died in a hospital here with the denial of a textile firm that it was the source of a bolt of cloth linked to her death.

COOKIES are always in demand, whatever the season or the weather. They can satisfy youngsters' needs for a snack, accompany a light fruit dessert, or go on a picnic. The easiest to make are bar cookies, followed closely by drop cookies. Here are recipes for both kinds.
TORONTO, June 2 (AP)-- The Toronto Falcons defeated the New York Generals, 2-1, tonight for their second victory of the National Professional Soccer League season before 1,861 fans.

MEMPHIS, June-2 (UPI)-- Dave Hill continued his mastery of the tough Colonial Country Club course today, firing a four-under-par 66 to take a four-stroke lead in his bid for top prize of $20,000 in the $100,000 Memphis open.

Mrs. Florence Millar Hehmeyer, wife of Alexander F. Hehmeyer, a member of the board and chief counsel of the American Heritage Publishing Company, died yesterday in her home at 32 Washington Square.

Mrs. Ellen Breed Williams, daughter of William C. Breed Jr. and the late Mrs. Ellen Whitman Breed, was married yesterday to Foye Fawcett Staniford Jr., a partner of Pershing Co., stockbrokers here. The disgraceful exhibition at City Hall yesterday by riotous followers of Vito Battista, the perennial tax rebel, will do nothing to aid landlords in their fight against rent control. Nor will it speed an end of the strike that is visiting unnecessary hardship on hundreds of thousands of tenants.

LAGOS, Nigeria, June 2-- The United States moved swiftly today to evacuate American dependents from the rebellious Eastern Region and adjacent areas of Nigeria, which could become a battleground in the event of civil war.

United Air Lines, Inc., announced yesterday it had filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a new issue of $130-million of subordinate convertible debentures which would mature July 1, 1992.

WASHINGTON, June 2-- Secretary of Transportation Alan S. Boyd has agreed to defer to the states to a large degree in the control of highway billboards.
MOSCOW, June 2--The Soviet Government charged that United States planes bombed a Soviet merchant ship in a North Vietnamese port today.

ST. LOUIS, June 2 (UPI)-- Judy Kimball carded a twounder-par 67 today to take the lead in the first round of the $13,500 Ladies Professional Golf Association tournament.

The American Stock Exchange turned mixed yesterday on comparatively light trading. During the morning the list moved ahead and for a time it appeared it was well on its way to recovering some more of the ground lost on Wednesday.
Five college professors, all experts on urban affairs, will spend the summer working in city agencies on projects of their own choosing, Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday.

It is birds still singing, meadows and pastures lush, brooks still busy and chattering, trees in full leaf at last, cool shade, morning dew, the air fragrant with blossoms. We think of June as a special time for enjoyment.

REVERBERATIONS are still being felt from the Government's renewed efforts last month to control the silver situation. Although market gyrations have calmed somewhat, the problem continues to draw a great deal of domestic and foreign attention. And the interest stems from sources both within and outside of the hobby, since the controversy involves both silver coins and bullion.

MRS. GISELA KAHN GRESSER, scoring 8-2, captured first place in the 1967 U.S. Women's Chess Championship that was played at the Henry Hudson Hotel. A close second was Miss Mona May Karff, New York, with 7-3. Third place went to Mrs. Mary Selensky of Philadelphia with 6-4 and fourth went to Dr. Helen Weissenstein of New York with a score of 5 -4 .
WASHINGTON, June 3-- President Johnson appointed an 18-member committee today to determine how the resources of private business and labor can be mobilized for a broad attack on city slums.
Kennedy International Airport is now generally described as a saturated air terminal. Nevertheless, millions of dollars are still being poured into the vast complex in expanding facilities.
ANGLERS are as biased a group of curious creatures. as one could ask for. More than a few tend to be hardheaded about their sport.

IN the current American Express series of National Football League films the one to be presented tomorrow night (Channel 9, 10:30) concerns quarterbacks, four of them. This is a worthwhile show because in it Sonny Jurgensen disagrees sharply with Fran Tarkenton...

POTTSTOWN, Pa., June 3-- Mr. and Mrs. Robert Handel Morgan have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Morgan, to Charles Lockwood Gold. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Sedgwict Gold of Cream Hill Farm in West Cornwall, Conn.
NEWPORT, R.I., June 3-- Yachts and music will dominate the Newport social picture this summer, and will probably give this old queen of society resort its merriest whirl in recent decades.

The Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith accused the John Birch Society yesterday of exploiting "American anguish over Vietnam" through a nationwide campaign to convince the American public that the "war effort is under Communist control."

DUCHESNE, Utah--An earth-shattering blast three miles from this ranch community last Wednesday signaled the start of construction on the $325-million Central Utah Project, a mammoth water development expected to have a major impact on the state's industrial, agricultural and recreational development for decades.

TOKYO, June 3 (AP)--China's Foreign Minister, Chen Yi, was quoted today as having said that there was a possibility that the United States might extend the Vietnam war into China-for which he said his country was fully prepared.

PARIS, June 3--The threat of an Arab-Israeli war has moved many Frenchmen to an intensely emotional identification with Israel that is in sharp contrast with the Gaullist Government's policy of neutrality.

DALTIMORE--This is a city that is lifting itself by the seat of its pants. A 33-acre section of rundown buildings, the threadbare fabric between its two major pockets of commerce, has been replaced by one of the nation's most successful downtown renewal projects.

Harry Scherman, board chair man of the Book-of-the-Month Club, announced yesterday the awarding of $3,000 grants to 14 college seniors to help them undertake creative writing projects. The winners were elected by a board of judges made up of Phyllis McGinley, Paul Horgan, Walter Kerr and Louis Kronenberger.

PARIS, June 3--Roy Emerson of Australia won the French men's singles title today and kept alive his goal of winning the Big Four tennis championships in the same year. In the final, he defeated Tony Roche of Australia, 6-1, 6-4, 2-6, 8-2.

Under a new ruling of the Department of Buildings, property owners may have nonhazardous violations dismissed when the department's inspectors have failed on two occasions to gain entrance to an apartment to determine whether the violations have been remedied.

CAIRO, June 3--The crisis in Cairo is evident in small ways, not all of them bad. Swissair from Geneva is very careful. It stops for almost twelve hours at Athens in midafternoon to avoid landing here after dark, and goes on next morning at 4 o'clock, tilting down over the blazing Egyptian desert at sunup.

MONTREAL--"From now on, housing is our most serious problem," said a high Expo official last week. With attendance soaring past seven million after the first month, Montreal's glamorous world's fair already has proved its drawing power. But the existence of shabby and costly lodging, and unsatisfactory arrangements for booking accommodations with proper amenities and generally expected qualities, have threatened to spoil it all for out-of-towners planning summer holidays here.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 3-- Russell D. Heath, manager of petroleum and chemical sales of the Russell Stoll Division of the Midland-Ross Corporation, 125 Barclay Street, New York, died yesterday at Mountainside Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived in Cedar Grove.

LIVERPOOL, England-High on a hill overlooking the center of this city and its port, both now undergoing a traumatic metamorphosis, is a drab, fading thoroughfare that bears the name of Hope Street. WASHINGTON. LAWYERS and visitors to the marble chamber of the United States Suprme Court sat in fascination one day recently as Justice Abe Fortas leaned forward and spoke from the traditional junior seat at the far left of the Chief Justice. His subject wes the country's juvenile courts and by the time he was through, in less than an hour, it was clear that Fortas had rewritten the basic premises of juvenile court law.

MIAMI BEACH--The impressive form of the French team was a surprise to the public in general and the North American team in particular when the world championships began here last weekend. To lose to Italy in the first of the three qualifying round robins was no disgrace, especially as the world champions were in irresistible form, but the disaster against France, which collected 19 victory points out of a possible 20, was quite unexpected.

WESTON, Conn., June 3 -- The marriage of Miss Adeline Honour Howe, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Herbel Howe, to Miller Parker Longbotham Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Longbotham of Aye, N. Y., took place here this afternoon.

A 114-line poem by Ezra Pound intended for his 1911 volume, "Canzoni," which got as far as galley proofs but was deleted, has finally been published in a small Australian magazine. It is entitled, in a typically Poundian way, "Redondillas, or something of that sort" and appeared in April in Poetry Australia, No. 15.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 3 --Mr. and Mrs. George Childs Rose have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Ann Rose, to Walter Franklin Peace Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Peace of Plainfield, N.J. An October wedding is planned.

The Greater New York Auxiliaries of the City of Hope medical center in Duarte, Calif., will honor Joseph Roth as Man of the Year next Sunday at a benefit dinner dance in the New York Hilton. Mr. Roth is president of the Karbra Company, gold and platinum casting.

Mrs. Edith Bancroft's Damascus, the 4-5 favorite, won the 99th Belmont Stakes by 2 1/2 lengths at Aqueduct yesterday. Cool Reception was second and Gentleman James third. Ridden by Willie Shoemaker and trained by Frank Whiteley Jr., Damascus, the Preakness winner, covered the 1 1/2 miles in 2:28 4-5 and returned $3.60 for $2 to win.

THE eye that movie producers keep on Broadway is, like Cyclops' single orb, never closed, and most of the great, good or interesting plays that manage to hit the Big Street are pounced on by the watchful film buyers. The latest is Harold Pinter's "The Homecoming," which is enjoying a comfortable run at the Music Box. The play, recipient

American Eagle, Constellation, Intrepid and Weatherly will begin tomorrow the long, grinding, expensive process that will make one 12-meter yacht the defender of the America's Cup against the challenge of Australia's Dame Pattie.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., June 3 --Miss Sandra Crain Lamb, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Burnham Lamb, was married this afternoon in Christ Episcopal Church to William Prescott Wolcott, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel H. Wolcott Jr. of Milton and Gloucester, Mass.

The possibilty of a compromise solution to the Middle East crisis grew decidedly more remote last week, in the view of Western observers in Cairo. The only prospect they saw for improvement was one of gradual demobilization of the military forces that confront each other in the area. The question was whether Israel or the Arabs could better stand the strain of maintaining big armies on their frontiers.

The nation's vast research and development complex is making increasing use of a scientific version of a baseball utility infielder, the independent research laboratory.
Public service corporations will increase their tax payments to Virginia by more than $2-million this year, the State Corporation Commission has reported.

SOMETIME between noon and 2 P.M. on Tuesday, on a sightseeing boat out in the Hudson River, Mayor Lindsay is scheduled to bestow a crown upon Miss Nancy Davison, 24 years old, pretty and a redhead. If all goes well, another "New York Is a Summer Festival" season will have officially begun with the crowning of the Festival Queen, and all hands will turn to the task of spreading the word.
STAMP collectors are prepared for what is likely to be a rather long summer of new issues con cerned with Expo 67, the international fair at Montreal.

Mayor Lindsay has made a special appeal to the city's Congressional delegation, most of whose members are Democrats, to push for Federal legislation that could bring millions of dollars in additional aid to the city.

WOULD you spend a vacation in a Bowery flophouse or eat at a Salvation Army soup kitchen? No? Then our advice, after trying to do Europe on one of those lowlow-cost tours, is to think twice--or better still, not even once.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 3-- Navy, trailing 5-4 early in the fourth period, rallied to defeat the cadets, 7-5, in lacrosse today.

STAMTFORD, Conn., June 3-- Miss Sandra A. Schiaroli, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis P. Schiaroli, was married this afternoon to Benjamin Joy Jameson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Chesterton Jameson of York Harbor, Me.

SEATTLE--The steep, downhill, two-block stroll from this city's massive, modern downtown shopping center to the colorful vegetable stalls of the Pike Place Market is a quick return to bygone times.

ALF, Germany-Just around the corner from the busy Rhine there is a wine festival somewhere every weekend. In the quiet, and still largely unspoiled, Moselle Valley, where this village lies, the countryside overflows with hundreds of vineyards. The summer months are, in effect, one long wine party, interrupted each week by only four work days.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, June 3 (AP)--Japan moved into an unbeatable lead over the United States in the three-day, five-ofnine series of the semi-final round in the Thomas Cup badminton championships by sweeping tonight's three singles matches.
LONDON, June 3--The London Stock Exchange has reported record payments to customers of member firms that failed.
The Defense Department's plan for another reorganization of the Army Reserve and Army National Guard has encountered considerable military opposition and some, though muted, Congressional criticism.
Theodore W. Kheel, the chief mediator in the New York newspaper negotiations, said yesterday the outlook was good for more contract settlements this week.

Samuel Hughes Garvin, rector of St. Peter's Episcopal Church here, and Mrs. Garvin.

Prices on the over-the-counter market and the American Stock Exchange took a sharp midweek pounding and, despite a moderate recovery on Friday, closed the week on lower ground.

THE New York season by Britain's Royal Ballet, which ended last weekend at the Metropolitan Opera House, was the longest to be presented by any visiting company for nearly 30 years; it attracted the largest audience and, for that matter, the largest gross. FORT JACKSON, S.C.--The courtmartial of Capt. Howard Brett Levy, which ended here Saturday when he was sentenced to three years at hard labor and dismissal from the service, may not stand out as a towering landmark case in the evolution of military justice. But his trial on charges of willful disobedience of orders, seeking to promote disloyalty and culpable negligence was significant for a number of reasons.

CHEVY CHASE, Md., June 4--Miss Emily Ann Haas, daughter of Mrs. Emil Haas of Kansas City, Mo., and Mexico City and the late Mr. Haas, was married today to Bruce Davidson of New York, son of Mrs. Lester Petchaft of Great Neck, L.I., formerly of Rochester. CHICAGO, June 4 (UPI)-- Harry I. Kirk, former president of the American Automobile Association, died today at the age of 84.

Boston has become the unlucky first among the country's big cities in experiencing a 1967 taste of the riotous upheavals that rock America's racial ghettos when hot weather sets in. The sparks that set off these explosions differ, but their roots always lie in the frustrations of poverty, the emptiness and despair of slum life.

PHILADELPHIA, June 4 (AP)--The Pennsylvania Railroad expects to charge passengers 50 cents to $1 more for its high-speed New York-toWashington train service set to begin Oct. 29, a high-ranking Pennsy official said yesterday.

The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) plans a bond offering of 60 million Swiss francs (about $14-million) in Switzerland on Friday. An underwriting syndicate of leading Swiss banks will manage the sale of the 5 per cent 18year issue at a price of 99 .

Tickets to the Rheingold Central Park Music Festival will go on sale today in six places: three Korvette stores, on Fifth Avenue, Fulton Street in Brooklyn, and Bruckner Boulevard in the Bronx; at Stern Brothers' main store on 42nd Street and the Bergen Mall Store in New Jersey, and the Record Shack at 125th Street and Eighth Avenue.

M. Judah Metchik, a partner with his father, Reuben, of the Metchik Press, 154 West 18th Street, died yesterday of cancer at Beth Israel Hospital. He was 38 years old and lived at 250 West 99th Street.

MONZA, Italy, June 4 (UPI)--Giancarlo Baghetti, of Italy, driving a Branca, won the 16th Monza Autodrome Formula Three Cup today in a race that was marred by injury to the favorite, Boley Pittard of Britain.

LOS ANGELES, June 4-- The Wolverhampton Wanderers, representing the Wolves of Los Angeles, survived an early goal today and beat Cerro of Montevideo, masquerading as the New York Skyliners, 2-1. It was an excellent United Soccer Association game, and the 7,064 fans in the huge, sunlit stadium reacted with heartening enthusiasm.

STOCKPORT, England, June 4--An airliner loaded with British vacationers plummeted into the center of this northern industrial town today, killing 72 persons aboard the plane. Twelve persons survived. No one on the ground was reported injured.

NEWTOWN SQUARE, Pa., June 4--Stingray of Derryabah, a Lakeland terrier owned by Mr. and Mrs. James A. Farrell Jr. of Darien, Conn., scored his fourth American best-in-show triumph today at the Delaware County Kennel Club fixture. Last February, Stingray was best in the famed Crufts show in London.

THE American Ballet Theater brought its New York season to a close at the New York State Theater last night. Perhaps the happiest and most illuminating comment that can be made about this season is that next season Ballet Theater will play two New York engagements in place of the traditional one. Nothing exceeds like sucess.

William H. Booth, Chairman of the City Commission on Human Rights, said yesterday that his agency was "starting disciplinary proceedings where we're charging discrimination against certain union practices."

ST. LOUIS, June 4 (AP)-- Kathy Whitworth repeated as the winner of a tournament for the first time in her nine-year professional career today. She carded a final 71 for a 209 total and a two-stroke victory in the $13,500 St. Louis women's invitation golf open.
The defense of Masada in the Judean wilderness nearly 2,000 years ago, will be reconstructed in October at the Jewish Museum.

SHAKER HEIGHTS, Ohio, June 4--Miss Johanna Shaw, daughter of Robert Shaw, the conductor, and Mrs. Shaw of Shaker Heights and Nantucket, Mass., and Dr. Pierce Gardner plan to marry in Nantucket next month. The future bride's parents have announced her engagement to the son of Walter R. Gardner of Chevy Chase, Md., and the late Mrs. Gardner.

KINSHASA, The Congo, June 4 (Reuters)--Congonese voted today in a nationwide referendum of a new constitution that would provide for a strong presidential Government, a onechamber Parliament and no more than two political parties. The constitution was advanced by President Joseph D. Mobutu.
NAVARRE, Ohio, June 4-- Garnet L. Patterson, general counsel for the United Rubber Workers Internation Union since 1942, died yesterday of a heart attack in his home. He was 62 years old.

Since Herbie Mann, more than 10 years ago, became the first jazz musician to make the flute his primary instrument, he has tried many different settings for the instrument. Thus, he helped start the Latin jazz bandwagon rolling.
MEMPHIS, June 4 (AP)-- Dave Hill, the first player to lead all the way, won the $100,000 Memphis open golf tournament today and earned $20,000, the biggest check of his 10-year pro career.

The engagement of Miss Susan Adler to Jeffrey Philips, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard J. Philips of the Bronx, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Adler of Kew Gardens Hills, Queens.
LOS ANGELES, June 4 (AP) --Roberto Clemente drove in four runs with his 11th and 12th homers today as he led the Pittsburgh Pirates to a 4-1 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers.

ANAHEIM, Calif., June 5 (UPI)--The Baltimore Orioles pitcher, Steve Barber, turned up at Anaheim Stadium well before tonight's game with the California Angels and denied he had any thoughts of quitting the club when he walked away from his teammates minutes before their plane took off from Baltimore yesterday.
Retail business and manufacturing in Philadelphia, Wilmington, Newark and smaller cities were hard hit in yesterday's blackout.
WASHINGTON, June 5--Unemployment continued to hold essentially steady at a low level in May, despite the five-month slowdown in the economy, the Labor Department reported today.

HARTFORD, June 5--The Connecticut House of Representatives approved Gov. John N. Dempsey's $1.03-billion general budget this evening, after repeatedly defeating the Republican minority's efforts to incrase it during a seven-hour debate.

The city's Welfare Department began an investigation yesterday of charges that five Harlem pharmacies had shortchanged Medicaid patients on prescription dosages and then billed the city for the full amount.
Today's questions for the class: Are there people gainfully employed to teach fish to swim and can you catch a 5 -pound fish that actually weighs a pound less?

The marriage of Miss Barbara Dale Smith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dale K. Smith of Belle, W. Va., to John Philip Suval, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ira Suval of New York, took place here yesterday evening. Rabbi David L. Seligson performed the ceremony at the Gotham.

EAST WILLISTON, L.I., June 5--Ed Furgol, the winner of the United States Open golf championship in 1954, the last time it was played at The Baltusrol Country Club, won't be able to go for the title at the Springfield, N.J., course next week. He failed to make the grade in the Metropolitan district qualifying tests held at the Meadow Brook and Wheatley Hills clubs today.

The excitement of learning, which some people (if they are lucky) discover at some point in their lives, appears to be the natural condition of the students attending the experimental Nova Elementary School in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. Some of that excitement was conveyed in last night's National Educational Television documentary on Channel 13, "My Name Is Children."

AMMAN, Jordan, June 5-- Clouds of black smoke rose over the Amman airport today as four Israeli jet bombers circled and dived, apparently more or less at will. Only light antiaircraft and machine-gun fire appeared to be opposing them as they bombed and strafed aircraft and installations in four attacks.

Two members of the House of Representatives called on the city yesterday to hold up approval of the World Trade Center until the Federal Communications Commission determines the extent to which the centers towers would interfere with television reception.

ADEN, June 5 (Reuters)-- British authorities tightened security arrangements and clamped a curfew on parts of Aden today after a retired British officer and eight Arabs had been killed in a fresh outbreak of violence.
MOSCOW, June 5--The Soviet Government rejected tonight a denial by the United States that American fighter bombers attacked a Soviet merchant ship, the Turkestan, in a North Vietnamese port Friday.

BRUSSELS, June 5--Jean Rey, the 64-year-old Belgian who headed the Common Market's negotiating team in the Kennedy Round on tariff reductions, was named today to the chief administrative post of the three European Communities.

The Association of Art Museum Directors has recommended that the Internal Revenue Service establish an advisory panel of art experts to lessen abuses of income tax laws governing charity donations of art works.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 5--Saigon found itself tonight in the unusual position of having been upstaged.

LONDON, June 5--Britain declared today that her policy in the Arab-Israeli conflict was "not to take sides."

ABOARD U.S.S. AMERICA, in the Eastern Mediterranean, June 5--Capt. Donald D. Engen, commander of this Sixth Fleet Aircraft Carrier, told his ciew this morning that he expected her to remain at her present position despite the outbreak of fighting between Israel and the Arab states.

MINNEAPOLIS, June 5--I suppose that when director Tyrone Guthrie decided to exhume the John Brown material once more by producing "Harpers Ferry" with the Minnesota Theater Company, he must have put himself to a good bit of Civil War research. Certainly he seems to have memorized the lyrics of "Dixie." He has his actors look away, look away a great deal.

SINGAPORE, June 5--The Governments of Singapore and Malaysia jointly announced today agreement on the interchangeability of their separate currencies, to be issued starting next Monday. Each other's currency is to be treated as "customary tender" and exchanged at par without any bank charges.

The primary fight to unseat Councilman Lester Baum as Republican leader in the 67th Assembly District, on Manhattan's West Side, collapsed yesterday when his opponent conceded in court that his designating petitions were invalid.

Just half a block from the spot in downtown Philadelphia where Benjamin Franklin flew the kite that helped bring in the era of electricity, teams of investigators began their search yesterday for clues to the origin of the four-state power failure.

Mrs. Dora Marcus Cohn, widow of Justice Albert C. Cohn of the State Supreme Court and mother of Roy M. Cohn, lawyer and industrialist, died last evening at her home, 1165 Park Avenue. She would have been 75 years old on Thursday.

Doris Pines played quite well from the beginning to the end of her recital at Town Hall last night, and since her program, was both substantial and interesting, the evening was one of solid musical values.
WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP) --The Supreme Court announced today that it planned not to wind up the current term next Monday.

CEDARHURST, L.I., June 5--John F. Finerty, a retired trial lawyer who handled many major civil liberties cases, died yesterday in South Nassau Communities Hospital after a long illness. He was 82 years old and lived at 103 Cedarhurst Avenue.
WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP) --Despite lowered mental standards, more than 176,000 American youths were rejected for the draft last year because they were unable to meet even those requirements.

The two largest upstate New York utilities--the Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation and the New York State Electric and Gas Corporation--announced yesterday that they were undertaking studies aimed at a possible merger.
BOSTON, June 5 (AP)-- Mrs. Beatrice Thayer Pittman, was elected today president of the Church of Christ, Scientist for the coming year.
The Humble Oil and Refining Company announced yesterday that it planned to build blending and storage facilities at its Bayonne, N.J., plant for 700,000 barrels of low-sulphur heavy fuel oil.

Long Island's North Shore region of the Women's American Organization for Rehabilitation Through Training, or ORT, will hold its 13th annual honor-roll luncheon at noon today in the Americana Hotel. About 1,700 members from 31 chapters in Nassau and Suffolk counties are expected.

ALBANY, June 5--The State Constitutional Convention, which has been listening to piecemeal proposals for the last two months, was offered the draft of a completely new Constitution today.

RAHWAY, N.J., June 5-- Miss Lucinda Helene Burr plans to be married here Aug. 5 to William Lloyd Barnard Jr., who expects to receive a master's degree in business administration from Rutgers University this summer.

WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP) --The Supreme Court ruled today the Interstate Commerce Commission must consider anticompetitive factors before allowing the Greyhound Company to buy into the Railway Express Agency, Inc.

STAMFORD, Conn., June 5-- Intrepid and American Eagle became the first winners in the America's Cup preliminary trials today, but only after wide wind shifts and an interval of light-air ghosting had transformed one-sided runaways into reasonably good but unsatisfactory matches.

WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP) --The Supreme Court let stand today a holding by lower Federal courts that New Orleans must pay to the United States with interest $405,903 it collected in 1955 as a use on machinery installed in the federally owned Michaud ordinance plant.

OCEANPORT, N.J., June 5 (UPI)--Irongate scored a three-quarter length victory today in the $6,500 feature race at Monmouth Park to give Jorge Vasquez the third of his four riding victories for the day.

Investors purchased $438-million of Series E and H savings bonds last month and redeemed $377-million, the Treasury Department reported yesterday. Sales of E bonds, totaling $409million, were the highest for any May since 1945 and were 9 per cent above the May, 1966, level.
WASHINGTON, June 5-- The three-month Treasury bill rate continued its downward drift while six-month rates firmed slightly at today's auction, the Treasury disclosed tonight.
PEORIA, Ill., June 5--Richard F. Speck was sentenced to death in the electric chair today for the murders last summer in Chicago of eight young nurses.

GENEVA, June 5--The International Committee of the Red Cross has "made representations" to the United Arab Republic against the bombing of a Red Cross truck convoy that was on its way to help the victims of a poison-gas attack in royalist-controlled northern Yemen last month.

FORT DIX, N.J., June 5 (UPI)--A 23-year-old private who enlisted for a three-year tour of duty but who assert's he is a conscientious objector was in the base stockade today for refusing to wear his Army uniform.
CRANFORD, N.J., June 5 --"It collapsed like a balloon," said Noel F. Peters, an official of the City Federal Savings and Loan Association. "You know--whoosh."

MONTREAL, June, 5-- The Royal Swedish Opera, the first of six companiies to come to Expo 67, ended its six-performance run at the Place des Arts last night, or rather, early this morning, with Wagner's "Tristan und Isolde." Of the four operas presented, it was by far the most conventional.
Betty Grable will replace Martha Raye in the title role of "Hello Dolly!" next Monday night.
Prices sagged sharply yesterday on the American Stock Exchange after fighting broke out in the Middle East.
WASHINGTON, June 5--The dominant Congressional reaction today to the outbreak of hostilities between Israel and the Arab states was that the United States should take no unilateral action.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 5--United States planes bombed North Vietnam's war industry today and shot down three MIG interceptors near Hanoi. Military spokesmen said that the North Vietnamese had put up heavy air defenses.

The city's Parks Department yesterday ordered a stop to the evening entertainment at the amphitheater in Tompkins Square Park on the Lower East Side, the scene of recent disturbances.

The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) announced yesterday that construction would start shortly on a $25-million integrated pulp and paper mill in West Pakistan. The project is planned by the Pakistan Paper Corporation.

PITTSBURGH, June 5--Faculty members and students who gathered this morning for the 70th commencement program at Carnegie Institute of Technology received a surprise announcement. Their school will get a new name.

Plans to enlarge Battery Park and build a half-mile-high "space needle," a new trading floor for the New York Stock Exchange and a 60-story office building there were announced yesterday by a private group of consultants.

It was as if he had built a wall of concentration that shut off the rest of the world.

Passengers who arrived yesterday afternoon on the last American commercial flight from Tel Aviv before airline service was suspended, gave a picture of Israel as a country that is mobilized and ready.
LONDON, June 5--Arthur Ransome, a well-known author of children's books, died Saturday in Manchester. He was 83 years old.

The first comprehensive revision of the city's Housing Code in 40 years was approved yesterday by the Buildings Committee of the City Council. It now goes to the full Council, which is expected to pass it.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 5--United Nations sources denied today a news report attributed to "men around President Nasser" that the Egyptian leader had asked for only partial removal of the United Nations emergency force in Sinai and not the total withdrawal ordered, after the request, by Secretary General Thant.
Radio stations WOR-AM and WINS were silenced here by yesterday's power failure because their transmitters are in New Jersey.
R. Harcourt Dodds, a corporation lawyer, has been chosen by Commissioner Howard R. Leary to take charge of the legal affairs of the Police Department.

WEST POINT, N.Y., June 5--The highest ranking cadet of this year's graduating class of 584 at the United States Military Academy is Ernest C. Heimberg Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. E. Clayton Heimberg, 72 Fanar Road, Midland Park, N.J.

CHAPPAQUA, N.Y., June 5--Mr. and Mrs. Carl Eugene Rhodes have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lindsay Duncan Rhodes, to Paul Ellwood Sandt. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Ellwood Sandt.
McDonnell Co., member of the New York Stock Exchange, announced yesterday the appointment of James F. Keresey as executive vice president and a director.

A Public Service Commission official testified yesterday that "laxity of supervision" was responsible for the collision of two New York Central freight trains on May 22, in which six crewmen were killed and six injured.

One of the busiest spots at Young Rubicam is the 13thfloor reception desk--the entrance to the media department.

ST. LOUIS, June 5 (AP)-- Julio Gotay, just called up from Oklahoma City, drove in two runs on a double and two singles tonight in pacng the Houston Astros to a 5-2 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals.
MANCHESTER, England, June 5 (AP)--Tory Fretz of Los Angeles, Lynne Abbes of Orinda, Calif., and Kathy Blake of Santa Monica, Calif., advanced today in the North of England tennis championship.

PARIS, June 5--President Johnson, marking the 20th anniversary of the Marshall Plan to rebuild postwar Europe, called today for the same "energy, imagination and courage" in an effort to build the underdeveloped two-thirds of the world. "Today's challenge is more stubborn, more complex and fully as urgent," he said.
The first edition, 600,000 copies, of "The Death of a President" by William Manchester has been sold out in two months and 25,000 copies are being printed as a second edition.

YONKERS, June 5--The concern over the possible absence of Romeo Hanover from Thursday night's Good Time Pace at Yonkers Raceway was dispelled this morning when Ted Gibbons, the racing secretary, opened the entry box and found his name among the eight entries.

The United States Senate and the Canadian Government took separate actions yesterday designed to increase the supply of Silver. The moves also would tend to moderate the threeweek-old price spiraling of the precious metal.
Charles R. McNamee, a lawyer here for more than 40 years, died Sunday in Prospect Heights Hospital, Brooklyn. He was 65 years old and lived at 431 East 20th Street.
WASHINGTON, June 5-- State Department officials declined formal comment today on a Soviet note rejecting a denial that American aircraft had bombed a Soviet vessel in North Vietnam.

GENEVA, June 5--The League of Red Cross Societies issued a statement today reminding belligerents in the Middle East of their obligations under the Geneva Convention of 1949 regarding treatment of the mounded, prisoners of war and civilians.
Charles O. Porter, former Democratic United States Representative from Oregon, has been chosen one of the twoco-chairmen of Citizens for Kennedy--Fulbright, it was announced yesterday.

WHITE PLAINS, June 5-- Architects presented their plans for the $28,320,000 Westchester County Courthouse Center here to the Board of Supervisors today. The buildings in the new center would replace an outmoded courthouse nearby.

The winter events of the first John F. Kennedy International Memorial Games will be held in Lake Placid, N.Y., at dates to be determined during the 196869 winter season, Col. Donald F. Hull, the executive director of the Amateur Athletic Union, announced yesterday.
Steel production fell to the lowest level of the year last week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

BAGHDAD, Iraq, June 5 (Reuters)--The Arab oil-producing countries decided unanimously today to stop the flow of Arab oil to any country attacking or taking part in an attack on any Arab state or territorial waters.
MOSCOW, June 5 (UPI)-- The communist party newspaper Pravda has udged hippies to be good revolutionaries.

PARIS, June 5--Gen. Mohammed Oufkir, the Moroccan Minister of the Interior, today was sentenced in absentia to life imprisonment by a French court in connection with the kidnapping and presumed murder of Mehdi Ben Barka, a Moroccan opposition leader.
Leon C. Greencbaum, chairman of the Hertz Corporation, was elected yesterday to the board of the Radio Corporation of America.
The constitutionality of the State Education Law requiring teachers to take an oath to support the State and Federal constitutions was unanimously upheld yesterday by a threejudge Federal Court.

PAPEETE, Tahiti, June 5 (UPI)--France detonated a nuclear device today at her atomic-proving grounds at Muroa Atoll, 800 miles southwest of Tahiti. The device was suspended over the South Pacific atoll by a balloon.

Kathryn B. Martin, senior vice president of The Christian Herald, 27 East 39th Street, in charge of the book division, died yesterday of cancer at St. Clare's Hospital. She lived at the Peter Cooper Hotel, 130 East 39th Street, and her age was 59.
The bond market took in stride yesterday the news of fighting in the Middle East.

SOUTHAMPTON, England, June 5 (AP)--Cheers and handclapping from 300 Britons crowding the dock greeted the Duke and Duchess of Windsor today when they landed from New York to be guests of Queen Elizabeth II at a memorial tribute to the Duke's mother, Queen Mary.

WEST NEWTON, Mass., June 5--Judge W. Lloyd Allen and Mrs. Allen have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Melody Lloyd Allen, to Will Stewart Brown 3d. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. Brown 2nd of Boston and Boothbay Harbor, Me.

Mrs. Betty Rosenquest Pratt of Maitland, Fla., has been named captain of the United States Wightman Cup team, Robert J. Kelleher, the president of the United States Lawn Tennis Association, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 5--The Supreme Court ordered the Federal Power Commission today to hold hearings on possible Federal construction of a dam on the Snake River at the High Mountain Sheep site between Idaho and Oregon.

BRUSSELS, June 5--The European subsidiaries of United States oil companies may be adversely affected if measures agreed to by oil experts of the six European Economic Community, or Common Market, countries are adopted. WASHINGTON, June 5--The electric utilities in the Pennsylvania-Jersey-Maryland power pool have known for some time that this would be an "anxious" summer with threats of power failures, Lee C. White, chairman of the Federal Power Commission, said today.

Patrick B. Duncan, a former white leader against apartheid in his native South Africa, and son of the late Sir Patrick Duncan, onetime British Governor General of South Africa, died Sunday in Westminster Hospital, London, of aplastic anemia. He was 48 years old.

TUCSON, Ariz., June 5 (AP) --Arizona, with three men on the first team, and the champion, Arizona State, with two, dominated the National Collegiate Athletic Association AllDistrict 7 baseball team today.

The General Aniline and Film Corporation announced yesterday it would begin a $16-million expansion program this month at its Binghamton, N.Y., plant. One project will be a photographic paper-coating and finishing facility, and the other a film-coating laboratory--and pilot plant.

GREAT NECK, L.I., June 6 --Milton I. Hauser, a partner in the law firm of Garey Garcy, 110 Wall Street, New York, died of a heart attack Sunday while visiting Newton, Mass. He was 63 years old and lived here at 71 Piceadilly Road.

GENEVA, June 6--The International Wheat Council is to meet in London on June 19, to make plans for a special session to draft a new wheat pact based on an accord reached at the Kennedy round of trade negotiations.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) --Congress was urged last week by Senator Philip A. Hart, Democrat of Michigan, to stimulate St. Lawrence Seaway traffic by prohibiting cutrate railroad fares on Government freight.

Dr. R. Gordon Hoxie, chancellor of Long Island University, asserted yesterday that the university and other institutions situated in downtown Brooklyn "desperately need" additional land to "survive and grow."
The election of Mrs. Elaine Herman as a trustee of Congregation Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue and 65th Street, was announced last night by Alfred R. Bachrach, president of the congregation's board.
An economic war broke out yesterday amid the shooting war in the Middle East as the Arab world began to make good on threats to cut off oil supplies to those it considers its foes.
PHOENIX, Ariz., June 6-- A tiny courtroom here was jammed today with lawyers for 92 persons and institutions all eager to undertake scientific research to prove the existence of the human soul.

Recent clashes between Texas Rangers and striking Mexican-American field hands in the Rio Grande Valley point up the desirability of prompt Congressional passage of a bill establishing procedures for the unionization of farm workers.

Paperboard production rose five-tenths of 1 per cent with 444,100 tons in the week ended June 3, from 441,900 tons in, the corresponding 1966 week, the Paperboard Group of the American Paper Institute reported yesterday.
