The big redhead was the first to achieve such a sweep.

WASHINGTON, June 6--A half-dozen big-city mayors and one governor strongly urged Congress and the Administration today to keep the Office of Economic Opportunity as the Government's central antipoverty agency.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., June 6 --Suffolk County Executive H. Lee Dennison said today he was shocked at the size of the bill presented to Suffolk for operating and maintaining Long Island Rail Road stations in the county.

CHRISTIANSTED, St. Croix, V.I., June 6 (UPI)--A fire today destroyed the building in Christiansted where AlexandeHamilton worked as a boy Losses, exclusive of inventories were established at $1-million. The building housed the Alex under Hamilton hardware story on its first floor and Hamilton House restaurant on the second floor.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 6--The Security Council appealed tonight to Israel and the Arab states for a cease-fire and an end to all military activities in the Middle East.

LA CROSSE, Wis., June 6 (AP)--Henry Mead Kaiser, a grandson of the industrialist Henry J. Kaiser, will be married June 17 to Miss Margaret Jane Fuller, daughter of an executive of the Trane Company. The engagement of Miss Fuller and Mr. Kaiser, son of Edgar F. Kaiser of Lafayette, Calif., was announced about a year ago.
The oil industry has changed a great deal since the last time the Middle East was up in arms, but it still remains heavily dependent on sources of supply in the Arab world.

CAIRO, June 6--The Egyptians closed the Suez Canal today to all shipping and broke relations with the United States over charges of American support for Israel in the two-dayold war in the Middle East.
MRS. CARLL TUCKER took an unofficial tour of her East Side town house Monday and was alternately delighted and mildly shocked by the changes wrought there in the name of charity.

BEVERLY FARMS, Mass., June 6--Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Wigglesworth have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Anne Wigglesworth, to Ens. Graham McKelvy Walker, U.S.N.R., son of Mr. and Mrs. James H. Walker Jr. of Bethlehem, Pa.
N.Y. STOCK EXCHANGE Stocks rallied yesterday, recovering most of Monday's losses, in slower trading. Volume, 9.23 million shares.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 6--Before they start toward South Vietnam, North Vietnamese infiltrators spend a few days at a settlement called "Ho Village," according to an American intelligence summary.
MANCHESTER, England, June 6 (UPI)--Tony Roche, the world-ranking Australian, was upset by Brian Fairlie of New Zealand, 3-6, 7-5, 7-5, in the North of England grass-court tennis tournament today.
TOLEDO, Ohio, June 6--Miss Martha Ellen Wheelock and Dallas Gene Alinder plan to be married on July 1 at St. Thomas Episcopal Church in New York.
Prices rebounded on a broad front yesterday at the American Stock Exchange.

BOSTON, June 6 (AP)--The State Supreme Court ruled yesterday that an Avon selectman who served as a newspaper correspondent had violated the conflict of interest law. The ruling posed a problem today for municipal officials and newspapers.

Dr. Willard M. Bright, vice president for research and development of the R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company, has been elected president of the Industrial Research Institute. He succeeds Dr. Donald W. Collier, vice president for research, Borg-Warner Corporation. W.E. Hanford, vice president of the Olin Mathleson Chemical Corporation, has been elected senior vice president of the institute, which represents about 200 of the nation's largest corporations.
WASHINGTON, June 6--The United States took the first steps today to evacuate 40,000 American citizens now in the Middle East.
President Rosemary Park and the Class of 1967 together bade farewell to Barnard College yesterday.
LINCOLN, Neb., June 6 (UPI) --The Nebraska Legislature, brushing aside a recommendation of Gov. Norbert T. Tiemann, today killed a statewide open housing bill. The roll-call vote was 28 to 21.

TRENTON, June 6--Acting State Education Commissioner Joseph A. Clayton refused today to allow Micah Bertin, the 18-year-old former president of the Edison High School senior class, to be graduated with his classmates next Monday. The youth has sideburns.
Todd G. Cole, senior vice president of finance and administration of Eastern Air Lines, has been named chairman of the Air Transport Association of America's airport facilities advistory committee.

BUFFALO, June 6 (AP) --Buffalo Harbor personnel were warned of a chemical cargo's hazardous nature by the Coast Guard eight days before a flash fire in the Norwegianowned freighter Thorstream killed four longshoremen last Friday, a Coast Guard investigation revealed today.

Through the wise provision of Article XIV of its present Constitution, New York State has kept unspoiled for more than seventy years its magnificent Forest Preserve. This noble heritage must not be endangered by any weakening of its constitutional protection in the new charter now being drafted in Albany.
MIAMI BEACH, June 6-- Elliott Roosevelt was defeated today in his attempt to win a second term as Mayor.

BERLIN, June 6 (AP)-- Canada, West Germany, South Africa and Italy won firstround matches today at the start of the Federation Cup tennis competition for women. The event is the counterpart of the men's international Davis Cup tournament.
WITH ISRAELI FORCES IN EGYPT, June 6 (Reuters )-- Israeli forces pushed into Egypt in such strength today that traffic jams built up in the Sinai Desert.
A 27-year-old prisoner, pretending illness, eluded two detectives yesterday and escaped into the IRT subway tunnel at 149th Street and Grand Concourse.

CHAPPAQUA, N.Y., June 6 --A home here for convalescent children of unlerprivileged families will be closed by the Children's Aid Society of New York City.

MONTREAL, June 6--The Melbourne Symphony Orchestra traveled half-way around the world to give two concerts here this week as part of Expo 67's World Festival of Music. It is the fifth large foreign group to come since the opening April 29.

ATLANTA, June 6 (AP)-- Joe Torre drove in his second run of the game with a single in the eighth inning tonight, breaking a tie and sending Atlanta to a 3-2 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers. The victory snapped the Braves' fivegame losing streak.

WEST HEMPSTEAD, L.I., June 6--Voters today adopted a school budget of $4,817,228 for the 1967-68 fiscal year by a vote of 1,610 to 1,499. The same budget proposal had been defeated last month by a margin of 22 votes.
MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, June 6--The United States may or may not have won tonight's basketball game against the Soviet Union in the final round of the fifth world championship tournament.

ROME, June 6--Nearly 150 American high-school students, the children of businessmen throughout the Middle East, arrived today on a United States chartered plane from Beirut, Lebanon, where they had attended school.

Alfred H. Drewes, president of National Lead Company and a director of many corporations, died yesterday in the Harkness Pavilion of the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, after an illness of several months. He was 53 years old and lived at 191 South Woodland Street in Englewood, N.J.
Major securities and commodities exchanges here and abroad continued to boil yester day following Monday's sharp reaction to the outbreak of war in the Middle East.
The Columbia Broadcasting System has strongly denied charges that it told soccer players to fake injuries to allow for time-outs for commercial interruptions.
WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP) --The White House announced today that Chancellor Kurt Georg Kiesinger of West Germany would visit the United States as President Johnson's guest July 7-8.

The appointment of George S. Dillon as general chairman of the 1968 March of Dimes fund-raising campaign in New York City was announced yesterday. Mr. Dillon is president of the Air Reduction Company.
TRENTON, June 6--They State Supreme Court ruled today that voiceprints must be tested for accuracy in court before they can have the same standing in evidence as fingerprints.

Kenneth Campbell, chairman of the board of directors of Mannington Mills, Inc., a floor covering manufacturing business, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home in Salem, N.J. He was 75 years old and lived at 286 Woodstown Road.
A rift developed in the peace movement yesterday as Communists and other leftists sided with the Arabs in the Middle Eastern war while moderates deferred to Israel.

NAHA, Okinawa, June 5-- Sentiment here appears to have swung over to a "gradual" return of Okinawa to Japanese civil jurisdiction instead of the imediate reversion widely demanded in the past.
Nathan Katz, vice president of Pharmacia Laboratories, Inc., of New Market, N.J., died Sunday in Midtown Hospital. He was 61 years old and lived at 100 West 12th Street.

Commodity futures retreated on a broad front yesterday, reflecting at least two factors. There was more confidence that the shooting war in the Middle East might be shorter-lived than expected earlier, and some speculators wanted to consolidate their positions by taking profits.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 6--A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. John Winsor Pratt on May 24 at Wyman House of Mount Auburn Hospital. Mrs. Pratt is the former Miss Joy Wilmunen, daughter of Mrs. Alvina Wilmunen of Duluth, Minn. The child, who has been named Samuel Frederick Wolsey, is also a grandson of Mrs. F. Wolsey Pratt of Concord.

WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP) --The spread of hepatitis through groups of narcotic addicts sharing the same needle apparently is a serious cause of the spreading of the liver disease in the United States, Public Health Service officials said today.

CINCINNATI, June 6 (AP) --A two-run homer by Tony Perez and a bases-empty clout by Vada Pinson enabled the league-leading Cincinnati Reds to down the San Francisco Giants, 3-2, tonight. It was the Reds' fifth straight victory, each by one run.

The New York Yankees, exercising first choice in baseball's third annual June session of the free-agent, draft, selected a left-handed slugging prospect from Atlanta named Ronald Mark Blomberg yesterday. The 18-year-old first baseman was promptly tabbed "the new Mike Epstein," in reference to the Bronx-born, Jewish rookie the Baltimore Orioles traded to Washington last week.
WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP)--President Johnson consolidated the Government's motor vehicle safety and highway safety functions today in a single bureau to be known as the National Highway Safety Bureau.

RYE, N.Y., June 6--A country fair sponsored by the Ladies Philoptochos Society will be held on Saturday at the Greek Orthodox Church of Our Saviour on Westchester Avenue.

The Northrop Corporation, a manufacturer of electronic aircraft equipment, announced yesterday in Beverly Hills, Calif., that its operations in the three and nine months ended April 30 rose sharply from year-ago levels.
LONDON, June 6--Prime Minister Wilson today denounced Arab moves to cut off oil supplies to Britain and the United States as "blackmail" that might hurt the Arab countries more than the West.

Philippe Maury, director of information for the World Council of Churches, died yesterday in Lyons, France. He was 50 years old. He had undergone major surgery there for removal of his spleen and blood accumulation in an artery. He went into a coma Saturday from which he never regained consciousness.

ALBANY, June 6--Of the 186 delegates to the Constitutional Convention, 19 are judges, and their eligibility as delegates and the way in which they were chosen came under oblique criticism on two fronts today.

The marriage of Miss Phoebe Russell to Lewis Perry MacAdams Jr. took place yesterday afternoon in the library of the St. Regis, Rabbi Paul M. Steinberg, dean of Hebrew Union College, performed the ceremony.
The Ford Foundation announced yesterday that it had made 29 grants totaling $8,913,000 for educational and related purposes.
RYE, N.Y., June 6--A record field of 458 began play today in the 63d United States Seniors Golf Association championship at the Westchester Country Club and the Apawamis Club.

"La Belle Hollandaise," also known as "Hollandaise a la Coiffe," is one of Picasso's best-known works. Painted in 1905, at the end of his so-called Rose period, it portrays a seated girl, nude except for a Dutch hat, against a dark blue ground.

Mayor Lindsay swore in Walter J. McQuade as a member of the City Planning Commission yesterday and called on the agency to produce "a high quality of design" in its plans for city buildings and other public facilities.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 6 --The top man in the Class of 1967 at the United States Naval Academy is Richard W. Mies, son of Mr. and Mrs, Francis L. Mies of Chicago. He will be the first of 892 midshipmen to receive degrees from Vice President Humphrey at graduation exercises and commissioning ceremonies here tomorrow.

MONTREAL, June 6--After weeks of wheeling and dealing, with promises made in back rooms and hints of mutual back-scratching, the National Hockey League held its expansion draft today to stock the six new teams that will join the 50-year-old league next season.

The massive power failure that cut off electric service for thirteen million persons in four Middle Atlantic states Monday brought proof that the country's interconnected utilities have still not found a dependable way to guard against major blackouts.
Jewish children marched, sang and clapped their hands near the United Nations yesterday, and Jewish spokesmen made a series of calls for the United States to help Israel in the war.

THE SHARP rebound in the stock market yesterday, coming on the heels of Monday's panicky selloff, provided once again proof of the adage that the little guy is usually wrong on Wall Street. It also indicated that the big market forces, such as institutional investors, sometimes can cash in on the small investor's panic.

TRENTON, June 6--New Jersey's new legislative reapportionment plan was upheld here today by Superior Court Judge Frank J. Kingfield. However, opponents of the plan said they would appeal the decision to the State Supreme Court, which will make the final deter-' mination before the November legislative elections.
ALGIERS, June 6 (Reuters) Former Vice President Richard M. Nixon canceled a one-day Algerian visit today because crowds ransacked the United States cultural center here yesterday.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, June 6 (AP)--Indonesia's ousted President Sukarno celebrated his 66th birthday in the Presidential Palace here today despite a published order by Acting President Suharto forbidding such action.
NEWTON, Mass., June 6-- Nathan Schwartz, a philanthropist and business leader, died today at his home here at the age of 78.

Senator Edward W. Brooke 3d, Republican of Massachusetts, the first Negro ever to win popular election to the Senate, has been named as the winner of this year's Spingarn Medal, it was announced last night by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.

GRAND SALINE, Tex., June 6 (AP)--Sixteen trapped miners and their three rescuers were freed from a huge salt mine tonight, a little more than nine hours after the men had been trapped in jammed elevator.
The Museum of the City of New York has won a scramble over the Library of Congress for prized memorabilia from the careers of George and Ira Gershwin.
CHICAGO, June 6--The Chicago Symphony has canceled a contract that would have brought it a gift of $1.95-million toward the renovation of Orchestra Hall.

SYRACUSE, June 6--Mr. and Mrs. Jay R. Weiselberg have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss. Susan R. Weiselberg, to Jay Alan Ziskind, son of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Ziskind of Newport, R.I., and Surfside, Fla.

TEL AVIV, Israel, June 6 (UPI)--Two American newsmen have been killed in the Middle East fighting, one in Israel and the other on the Jordanian side, it was reported today.

PHILADELPHIA, June 6 (UPI)--Phil Linz singled home the winning run in the eighth inning tonight for a 9-8 Philadelphia Phillie victory over the Chicago Cubs after Johnny Callison's two-run single in the eighth had given the Phillies an 8-6 triumph in the opening game of a double-header.
A group of priests seeking a change in Roman Catholic canon law to permit priests to marry reported yesterday that a majority of younger priests polled in the metropolitan area favored such a change.

WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) --President Johnson filled two Republican vacancies on the Interstate Commerce Commission today with a Californian and a former agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation from Virginia.

SAN JOSE, Calif., June 6 (AP)--Vice Adm. Charles A. Lockwood, commander of the World War II Pacific Submarine Force, which sank more than a thousand enemy ships, died today of a heart attack. He was 77 years old. With headquarters at Pearl Harbor, Admiral Lockwood directed submarine operations that sank seven Japanese aircraft carriers, one battleship and five cruisers.

WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP) --President Johnson signed today the $21-billion military hardware procurement bill. The actual appropriation will be carried in another measure. The authorization includes aircraft, naval vessels, combat vehicles and other military hardware as well as money for research and development.
An experiment in seamen's sports that may lead to an annual "Olympic Games for Seamen" is scheduled to be held at two cities in the Netherlands June 9 to 16.

A Silverman-trained, John Chapman-driven trotter, Lariat Hanover, captured the opening mile race Tuesday night in 2:08.4/5, paying $8.20 for $2 to win. Lariat Hanover and Julia Slater, who took second ($17.60), resulted in a daily double that returned $78.80.

WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP) --A "retirement revolution" in the next 33 years, when some 65 million persons in this country will be retired, was forecast today by Senator Walter Mondale, Democrat of Minnesota. He said that one of every three Americans now alive will reach retirement age by the year 2000 and he questioned whether they or the nation are preparing for this.

The board of Republic Foil, Inc., omitted yesterday the quarterly dividend of 10 cents due at this time. John W. Douglas, president, attributed the decision to reduced demand for capacitator fuel. This slackening, he said, was due to excessive customer inventories of finished components and to a soft market for packaging foils, resulting in losses for the company.
KISIELICE, Poland, May 28 --The Roman Catholic church stands lonely on a knob overlooking the scattered houses of this small farming town. Cows graze around it.

WASHINGTON, June 6 (UPI) --The House, told that the United States must produce more food to meet Vietnam war needs and to combat starvation in Asia, voted today to halt a two-year-old program in which farmers are paid to divert cropland to other uses.

INCREASES FOR LABOR COSTS. Landlords can pass along to tenants increased labor costs if these costs have not been compensated for by other rent raises in the last year resulting from a turnover of apartments or a hardship increase. However, no tenant would pay more than a 7 per cent increase over three years, and the average is expected to be about 4 per cent.

WASHINGTON, June 6--The House Rules Committee cleared for floor action today legislation passed yesterday by the Senate that would free more than 100 million ounces of silver for sale to domestic users by the Treasury at $1.29 an ounce.

PEARLAND, Tex., June 6 (UPI)--One of the nation's newest astronauts, Maj. Edward G. Givens Jr., of the United States Air Force, was killed today when he missed a sharp left-hand curve in this little town near the manned spacecraft center and crashed his car off the road.

A banker-economist who suggested in February that interest rates might be close to their lows of the year said yesterday that long-term rates would decline over the next couple of months. George W. McKinney, Jr., vice president and economist for the Irving Trust Company, said the bond market had gotten ahead of itself in anticipating economic conditions.
The fourth wife of Lewis Rosenstiel, 75-year-old chairman of Schenley Industries, won an increase in alimony yesterday from $2,400 a month to $8,000.
WASHINGTON, June 6--The House of Representatives has approved an appropriation of $374,917,000 for the Maritime Administration for the fiscal year 1968, which begins on July 1.

LONDON, June 5--Lord Balfour of Burleigh, a former chairman of Lloyds Bank who spoke frankly on economic affairs, died here yesterday at the age of 83.

KANSAS CITY, June 6 (AP) --The league-leading Detroit Tigers backed the pitching of Earl Wilson and Joe Sparma with 22 hits that crushed the Kansas City Athletics, 11-1 and 7-1, tonight in a double-header that was marked by a free-forall in the second game.

The United State, Steel Corporation announced yesterday the appointment of Edgar B. Speer as executive vice president is charge of production. He succeeds Edwin H. Gott, whose election as president of the company was announced last week.

CHICAGO, June 6 (UPI)-- Tommie Agee's bases-loaded single scored Al Weis, a pinchrunner, and Ed Stroud with two out in the seventh inning tonight and gave the Chicago White Sox a 5-3 triumph over the Boston Red Sox.
TEL AVIV, June 6--After only two days of spectacular air and tank warfare, Israeli officials here are talking about their terms for peace.
WASHINGTON, June 6--The retail sales figure for April was revised upward by about $250-million today by the Commerce Department, meaning that sales reached a record in the month.

A few directory of farm and land brokers accredited by the National Institute of Farm and Land Brokers, an affiliate of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, has been published. It may be obtained from the institute at 155 East Superior Street, Chicago, Ill. 60611.

AUSTIN, Tex., June 6-- President Johnson's political peace mission to the governors wound up a four-month, 40state tour today. It saved the most elaborate appearance--to no one's particular surprise-- for Texas.
Lippincott Margulies is studying the image of Con Edison.
SAN SALVADOR, June 6 (API)--The Government ordered mobilization last night because of what it called a threat by Honduras to the territory of Salvador.
SYDNEY, Australia, June 6 (Reuters)--Burglars took a Picasso painting valued at more than $175,000 from the Queensland Art Gallery in Brisbane last night.
William C. Offutt has been elected worldwide coordinator of refining for the Gulf Oil Corporation, Pittsburgh, effective July 1.
MOSCOW, June 6--A measure of restraint was noticed here today in Soviet press and radio reports of the conflict between Israel and the Arab countries.
ROME, June 6--The Communist party newspaper L'Unita declared today that Arab recognition of "the reality of Israel" was essential to the re-establishment of peace in the Middle East.

BRUSSELS, June 6--More than one-third will be sliced from the tariffs of the major trading nations in the recently concluded Kennedy round, but though the agreements are in hand, no one is sure yet when all this trade liberalization will begin.

WASHINGTON, June 6--Because male mosquitoes from Fresno, Calif., are incompatible with females from Rangoon, Burma, scientists may have a new strategy for controlling one of mankind's most widespread infectious diseases, filariasis, a report suggested today.

FASHION designers are doing everything in their power to make women feel uneasy about stepping out of the house in their old clothes next fall. But they're being so disarming about it that hardly anyone can take offense.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 6-- Arab frustration and distress concentrated today on the "imperialist powers," the United States and Britain. Demonstrations against the Western embassies occurred in Damascus, Amman and Beirut.

The appointment of two members to the advisory board of the American Press Institute at Columbia University was announced yesterday by Dr. Grayson Kirk, president of the university. They will each serve for three years.
Washington at New York (2, 5 P.M.)--Moore (3-1) and Ortega (2-5) vs. Talbot (1-2) and Monbouquette (0-0).
PITTSBURGH, June 6--In their sixth season, the Mets have found the secret to success. It consists of batting against Elroy Face in the 10th inning.

Spartans Industries, Inc., announced here yesterday that it incurred a net loss of $3,143,000 in the 13 weeks ended April 30, compared with a deficit of $1,411,000 in the 1966 quarter. Sales eased to $241,795,000, from $241,926,000 the year before.

WEST NEW YORK, N.J., June 6--Rudolph S. Tedesco, who last month began his third four-year term on the West New York town commission, died today in North Hudson Hospital, Weehawken. He was 56 years old and resided at 216 67th Street here.

BOSTON, June 6--The city Welfare Director, Daniel I. Cronin, said today that an intermediary for a group of Negro mothers had raised hopes of an early settlement of the issues that led to four nights of violence in the streets of the Roxbury ghetto district.

The First National City Bank, an aggressively innovative bank that ranks third in size in the United States, announced yesterday a realignment of senior management, naming Walter B. Wriston, 47-year-old executive vice president, its new presi dent.
WARSAW, June 6--The Government declared in a statement today that the Polish people condemned with the "most profound indignation" Israel's "aggression" against the Arab countries.

Mrs. Ethel Cushman Parke, for nearly 50 years hostess to and owner of the Emily Dickinson House in Amherst. Mass., died Monday in Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center at the age of 90. She was the widow of the Rev. Hervey Coke Parke, former rector of Grace Episcopal Church in Amherst and of the Church of the Angels in Pasadena, Calif.
The following quotations are selling prices in United States dollars and cents for banknotes at New York. These rates do not apply to regular exchange business transacted by banks.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., June 6 (AP)--Herb FitzGibbon of Garden City, L.I., who is assistant tennis coach at West Point, led four other seeded players into the second round of the annual Blue-Gray invitation tennis championship here today.

Central Park fans will soon have the taxonomic equivalent of a scoreboard (without which casual fans cannot tell the ballplayers apart). It is a tree map and guide. The first section of it, just published, shows a circled number for each prominent tree.
WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP) --The House Judiciary Committee approved a bill today to make flag burning a Federal crime and moved to bring it before the House on Flag Day, June 14.
The Rockefeller Foundation has given $126,000 to the American Place Theater. The money will be applied toward operating and administrative costs on a dozen presentations between now and June, 1970.
Irving Spiegel, who has reported on Jewish affairs for 25 years for The New York Times, was honored last night by B'nai B'rith at a dinner in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
MIAMI, June 6--A mass of summer thunder showers moved over South Florida last night, ending nearly three months of searing drought.
WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP)--President Johnson today named Navy Capt. James A. Lovell Jr., who has logged more hours in space than any other person, as his special consultant for physical fitness.
TEL AVIV, June 6 (Reuters) --Israel has appealed again to the Soviet Union to join in an effort to bring peace to the Middle East.
WASHINGTON, June 6--Cash deposits and withdrawals, close of business, June 1:
SARASOTA, Fla., June 6 (AP)--Dr. Carl Coppolino, who was found guilty April 28 of fatally drugging his first wife has won a two-year court fight to collect her $25,000 life insurance.
WASHINGTON, June 6 (UPI) --The Senate Labor Committee approved today President Johnson's formula for averting a nationwide rail strike.
American Airlines, Inc., announced yesterday it had registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission a planned offering to its stockholders to $157-million of convertible debentures due 1992.

The election of Wright C. Cotton and Henry W. Welch as assistant general controllers and of John Quick as an assistant controller was announced yesterday by Frederic G. Donner, chairman of the board of General Motors.
The City Council passed last night a package of amendments to the rent control law that could mean higher rents for most of the 1.4-million rent-controlled apartments here.
PARIS, June 6--Intellectuals here are deeply concerned about the fate of Regis Debray, a brilliant young Parisian philosopher who faces trial as a guerrilla by a military court in Bolivia.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., June 6 --The California Senate voted today to liberalize the state's century-old abortion law.
TALLAHASSEE, Fla., June 6--An angry Governor Kirk charged today that the Florida Education Association was "a totally irresponsible group."

DEER PARK, L.I., June 6-- Officials of the Suffolk Sun, the first daily newspaper based in Suffolk County, reported this week that the paid daily circulation of the six-month-old paper was 51,641 as of last Thursday.

STRATFORD, Ont., June 6-- The Stratford Shakespearean Festival, Canada's biggest theatrical event, opens its 15th season Monday. The expected swarm of tourists should push attendance to a record total of 350,000.
Sales of several of the nation's leading chain-store organizations rose sharply in May after a poor performance in April, reports disclosed yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 6 (UPI)--The Right Rev. C. Kilmer Myers, Protestant Episcopal Bishop of California, said today that he hoped world church leaders would respond to his call for all Christians to recognize the Pope as their pastoral leader.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 6--The current special session of the General Assembly put off until a week from today the selection of a commissioner and an 11-member council to guide South-West Africa to independence.
HARTFORD, June 6--The Connecticut House of Representatives voted today to prohibit the kind of testimonials that figure in the censure recommendation that is pending against Senator Thomas J. Dodd.
A new stop in the Grand Central Terminal area of Manhattan has been added for users of Carey buses to and from La Guardia Airport in Queens.

The Monsanto Company announced yesterday price increases of 50 cents a hundredweight on its phosphorous trichloride and phosphorous oxychloride, effective July 1. The two chemicals are used as chlorinating agents in the manufacture of organic intermediates and dyestuffs, insecticides and phosphate plasticizers. The company traced the price rises to higher raw material, packaging and labor costs.

A summer wedding is planned by Miss Elisabeth Maria Esser and Peter C.M.S. Braun. Their engagement has been made known by Miss Esser's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Winand Esser of Cologne, Germany. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Conrad Braun of Greenwich, Conn.
MUSKOGEE, Okla., June 6 (AP)--Thurgood Marshall, Solicitor General of the United States, said yesterday that he is "afraid our young people are getting the wrong people to be their heroes."

AMMAN, Jordan, June 6--The battle for the west bank of the Jordan River swirled today around Jenin, a small town in the northwest of Biblical Samaria, and Jerusalem. Although they were in difficulties in many positions, the Jordanians appeared on the whole to be holding their own.
PARIS, June 6--France and West Germany announced plans today to launch a joint communications satellite called Symphonie in late 1970.
FORT SILL, Okla., June 6 (UPI)--Charges of disrespect for a superior officer were filed today against Pfc. Paul R. Ilg of Indianapolis. Trial by summary court-martial was scheduled for 8 A.M. Monday.

Rabbi Sigmund J. Rome, who retired in 1956 as spiritual leader of the Tree of Life Temple at 881 Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn, where he had served 20 years, died Monday in his home at 25 Eastern Parkway after a long illness. He was 73 years old.

WASHINGTON, June 6-- The Federal Power Commission tentatively identified today a high-voltage transmission line belonging to the Philadelphia Electric Company as the place where yesterday's Middle-Atlantic states power failure began. But the F.P.C. does not yet know exactly what happened on the line.
In ports all over the world yesterday, radios crackled with orders from shipping companies for vessels to alter their courses.

It is already clear that one of the most significant developments of the mid-20th century is the managerial revolution, which has increasingly replaced intuition by rational calculation as the basis for managerial decisions. In detail, this revolution rests upon a complex mathematical foundation-- linear programing, queueing theory, operations research and the like--which is beyond most business executives and is the provinces of specialists.

The New York Young Men's Republican Club's board of governors disagreed with its president on Tuesday night on the endorsement of a candidate. The dispute led the club to take the unusual step of supporting a candidate in Nassau County.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., June 7--Miss Margaret Goodman was married this afternoon to William Gar Richlin at the home of her parents, Dr. and Mrs. Stanley Goodman. Rabbi Herbert Weiner performed the ceremony. The bridegroom is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Padie Richlin.

BETHESDA, Md., June 7 --Mr. and Mrs. Robert N. Tomb have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Roberta Ann Tomb, to Capt. William Thomas Hardaker Jr., U.S.M.C., son of Captain Hardaker, U.S.N., and Mrs. Hardaker of Quonset Point, R.I.

TRENTON, June 7--The State Board of Education reversed the Acting State Commissioner of Education today and ruled that Micah Bertin, an 18-year-old Edison high school senior, could be graduated with his class on Monday with his sideburns intact.

WASHINGTON, June 7-- Israel has resorted to violence and won its victory. Among her friends and particularly those whose ties to her are of blood and the spirit, there can only be relief and exultation. Yet, victory is not necessarily settlement; and perhaps only as the battle ends will the enormity of what has happened come clear.
PARIS, June 7--France will legalize birth control, it was decided today.
Maj. Gen. Robert J. Fleming Jr. (U.S. Army ret.) has been appointed vice president and a director of Anderson-Nichols Co., Inc., Boston, engineering and management consulting concern.
Darryl Hickman and Charles Nelson Reilly, actors on Broadway, have organized a producing concern called Justin Productions. The offices are at 850 Seventh Avenue.
Tennis came into Madison Square Garden yesterday--in June, of all times--marking the start of what is expected to be a lasting and prosperous relationship for the professionals.

BERLIN, June 7 (UPI)-- Mrs. Billie Jean King of Berkeley, Calif., and Rosemary Casals of San Francisco each scored a singles victory and combined for another triumph in doubles today as the United States beat Rhodesia, 3-0, to gain the quarter-finals of the women's Federation Cup international tennis tournament today. The United States is defending the cup.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 7-- Vice President Humphrey called on Americans today to dedicate themselves to "a new Bill of Rights and Responsibilities" that would "fit new times and circumstances."

LONDON, June 7--Sir Francis Chichester, the 65-year-old yachtsman who sailed around the world alone, was admitted to the Royal Naval Hospital at Plymouth last night suffering from a bleeding ulcer.

Mrs. Elisa Levi Ottolenghi, until recently a private teacher of Italian language and literature to students intending to become opera singers, died Tuesday of cancer in her home at 552 Riverside Drive. She was 64 years old and the wife of Dr. Mario L. Ottolenghi, a chemical engineer and vice president and acting presideint of the Chemore Corporation, importers and exporters of chemicals.

The Citizens Union, a nonpartisan civic group, announced yesterday that it preferred Leonard H. Sandler over Francis H. Pecors for the Democritic nomination for Civil Court Judge in Manhattan's Second Municipal Court District in the June 20 primary.
PARIS, June 7--France proposed today an "international convention" guaranteeing free passage through the Gulf of Aqaba as a means of moving toward a lasting settlement of the Arab-Israeli conflict.
The Radio Corporation of America announced yesterday price cuts of $30 each on eight of its new 18-inch and 20-inch color television receivers.
ST. LOUIS, June 7 (UPI)-- The Houston Astros crushed the St. Louis Cardinals, 17-1, under a 23-hit barrage tonight and presented Bo Belinsky with his first victory of the year.

WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP) --Legislation spelling out the right of stockyards to turn away dealers they do not believe would benefit the livestock market was approved today by a House agriculture subcommittee.

The obscure choreographic gloom clouds that settled over "An Evening of New Dance Works" at the Kaufmann Concert Hall on 92d Street last night almost threatened to obscure the sparkling performances by Louis Falco, Sally Brayley, James Clouser, Cora Cahan and Sally Stackhouse.
An astronomical curiosity and an astrological delight will occur tonight when Venus and Jupiter will appear close to each other for the first time in three years.

CAIRO, June 7--The streets of Cairo lay darkened under the stars last night when a hoarse voice cried out to a passerby "Put out your cigarette!"

The treasurer of the ANTA Washington Square Theater, home of the hit musical play "Man of La Mancha," was arrested yesterday and charged with accepting $200,000 in excess ticket payments since Jan. 1, 1966, and with related violations of laws regulating boxoffice practices.

A smiling queen and a serious young king stepped out of a helicopter yesterday morning onto the roof of the Pan Am Building, from which the spire of the nearby Chrysler Building looked like a Thai temple shining in the sun.

The wholesale commodity price index fell to 100 on Tuesday from 100.3 on Monday.
The first of an expected total of 6,000 visiting pilots are due to fly into the Gen. Carl A. Spaatz Airport in Reading, Pa., today for the start of the annual three-day air show there.

Wool dresses are more to the taste of the designers who showed their new collections yesterday, the second big day of fall showings on Seventh Avenue. Silk and beads are for late at night.

WEST POINT, N.Y., June 7 --The "long gray line" of West Point graduates, which stretches back to 1802, grew longer today as 577 cadets were commissioned at the United States Military Academy here. Many are expected to see combat duty in Vietnam.
EL ARISH, Sinai, June 7-- Israeli troops on the road to Suez were flushed with victory today, but the fighting was by no means over.

LONG BEACH, L.I., June 7--Miss Joyce Claire Segal's engagement to Stuart Allan Davis has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. I. Daniel Segal. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold M. Davis.

Fifteen sewing machines-- five new and 10 used--were donated yesterday by a variety of donors to the Lower West Side branch of the Neighborhood Youth Corps. The branch was also given fabric and $600.

Schich Electric, Inc., demonstrated here yesterday one of the first commercial applications of sonic principles in the field of home appliances. The new product is a denture cleaner aimed at automatic home cleaning of dentures for the estimated 61 million or more Americans over 18 who have whole or partial dentures.
JERUSALEM, June 7 (AP)-- In the Israeli section of the Holy City, Jews laughed, shouted and danced in the streets.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, June 7 (UPI)-- The International Amateur Basketball Federation turned down today a Soviet protest of the United States' 59-58 victory in the world basketball championship last night.

New York State savings banks had a record net increase in regular deposits for May, in marked contrast to the situation a year ago, when depositors were attracted away from savings institutions by high interest rates on corporate and government bonds.
The bond market absorbed in good style yesterday another large batch of new corporate and tax-exempt offerings, including the week's largest of each kind.

TORONTO, June 7--A major decision is expected shortly from the United States Federal Power Commission on the controversial $200-million proposal by Trans-Canada Pipe Lines, Ltd., to supply eastern Canadian markets with western Canadian gas and penetrate the United States Middle West in the process.
VILLANOVA, Pa., June 7 (AP)--Jack Gregory, the assistant coach at Navy and one-time head coach at East Stroudsburg (Pa.) State College, was named today head football coach at Villanova University.

The New York Cotton Exchange has elected J. Raymond Stuart, a vice president of E.F. Hutton Co., as chairman of the board. Frank Knell, an active floor member of the exchange, has been named vice chairman and was also elected president of the Wool Associates of the exchange.

DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, June 7--Tanzania's biggest Cabinet shuffle since she gained independence in 1961 was announced by President Julius Nyerere today. He reduced the number of ministries from 15 to 11, dropped two ministers and shifted most of the others.
DETROIT, June 7 (UPI)-- A former school teacher left today in an old plane for an around-the-world flight following the same route mapped out by Amelia Earhart.
CANJILON, N.M., June7-- The New Mexico National Guard withdrew today from a mountain search for about 40 insurrectionists who claim a large part of northern New Mexico under old Spanish land grants.

WASHINGTON, June 7--A nonpartisan group of prominent businessmen proposed today that individuals be allowed to credit a portion of their state income taxes against their Federal income tax. The credit would come on top of the deduction of state income taxes now allowed.

Edward S. Greenbaum, Mrs. Alliluyeva's lawyer, said last night that she would not have any comment on the latest attack in the Soviet press.
DAMASCUS, Syria, June 7 (Reuters)--Syrian tanks were reported breaking into northern Israel tonight, heading toward Safad, which is about 10 miles from the Israeli-Syrian border.
The Shell Oil Company announced here yesterday the appointment of Robert M. Hart as vice president for transportation and supplies.
MOSCOW, June 7 (AP)-- The Soviet Union led Chile, 2-0, after victories in the opening singles of the semifinals in Davis Cup tennis today.

The engagement of Miss Gail Eve Sanger to Richard Eric Halperin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Halperin of South Salem, N.Y., and Brooklyn, has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Maury D. Sanger of Brooklyn and Atlantic Beach, L.I.
WASHINGTON, June 7--A mounting number of Arab and African countries broke diplomatic relations with the United States today in response to Egyptian charges that American planes had assisted Israel.
SAN JUAN, P.R., June 7-- The Casals Festival of Puerto Rico offered an unexpected and impressive musical prayer last night for the restoration of peace in the Middle East.

WASHINGTON, June 7-- Business investment in new plant and equipment is expected to rise only 3 per cent this year over the 1966 level, but it is expected to head up in the second half, the Commerce Department reported today.
Middle Eastern War
HONG KONG, June 7--ProPeking workers forced suspension of the main cross-harbor ferry service here today in a new Communist move against British authorities.

TARRYTOWN, N. Y., June 7 --steven C. Rockefeller, the 31year-old son of New York's Governor, declared today that he had been outraged by this nation's failure to intervene in the Hungarian revolution of 1956 and that he would "certainly support whatever we have to do to defend the rights and independence of Israel."

Mrs. John R.H. Thouron stood in the winner's circle at Aqueduct yesterday for several minutes, chatting pleasantly with her trainer, Tommy Kelly. Her 5-year-old horse Ginger Fizz had just finished first in the $30,500 Edgemerc Handicap, and all that remained was for the official sign to go up, and for Mrs. Thouron to receive the victory plate from Winston Guest.
The United States Steel Corporation and the New York Telephone Company are planning to build skyscrapers in Lower Manhattan.

The Lindsay administration is vigorously opposing a proposed amendment to the rent control law that would prevent the decontrol of any "class" of apartments. The administration feels the amendment might be unconstitutional and could open the way for a challenge to the constitutionality of the whole rent control law.

FLORENCE, Italy--High in the hills over this city of Dante and Michelangelo is a three-century-old villa, the residence of Commandante Paolo Contini. "As long as this house has been here, we Continis have always had dogs," said the retired naval officer.
Israel's swift capture of the Gaza Strip and rapid advance into Jordan has suddenly left her with the responsibility for many of the 900,000 refugees who fled 19 years ago from what is now Israel.
ANAHEIM, Calif., June 7-- Jim McGlothlin pitched a fourhitter for his third straight shutout and fourth consecutive victory tonight as the California Angels defeated the Baltimore Orioles, 2-0.

BROOKVILLE, L.I., June 7 --Thomas M. Goodfellow, president of the Association of American Railroads, told 1,129 C.W. Post College graduates today that "never in history has it been so urgent that the right words be used at the right time and in the right place."

RYE, N.Y., June 7--A 68 for 142 by the defending champion, George Haggarty of Grosse Pointe, Mich., helped produce a three-way tie among Haggarty, Robert B. Kiersky and David Goldman for first place in the 63d annual United States Seniors' Golf Association championship today.

One of America's early skiing enthusiasts, Gov. John A. Love of Colorado, visited the United States Olympic Committee yesterday to ask formally that his state be considered for the site of the 1976 Winter Games, with Denver the host city.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 7-- A run on banks was expected here Friday as the demand for dollars and Lebanese pounds soared as a result of the Middle East crisis.
PARIS, June 7--The French Government took steps today to "support" the country's decelerating economy.

ABOARD U.S.S. AMERICA, IN THE EASTERN MEDITERRANEAN, June 7--A Soviet guided missile destroyer that has been shadowing this Sixth Fleet carrier was joined this morning by a second Soviet destroyer as this aircraft carrier headed west, farther from the Arab-Israeli war zone.

CAIRO, June 7--An Egyptian military communique reported today that forces of the United Arab Republic had fallen back from some first-line positions on the Sinai Peninsula and were engaged in fierce fighting against Israeli troops from secondary positions.
TRENTON, June 7--Gov. Richard J. Hughes said today that he would consider invoking his emergency powers to cut the use of electricity during peak hours of demand this summer.

The New York chapter of the American Institute of Architects has installed William B. Tabler as its president. He had served as first vice president and presidentelect of the 1,505-member chapter. He succeeds Max O. Urbahn.

St. John's Episcopal Church in Greenwich Village was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Miss Alice Campbell King of New York and Biltmore, N.C., daughter of the late Dr. and Mrs. Edward King of Biltmore and New York, to the Rev. Walter Douglas Roberts, rector of the Episcopal Church of St. John-in-the-Wilderness, Flat Rock, N.C. He is the son of Mrs. Warren Roberts of Macon, Ga.
DETROIT, June--Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Automobile Workers, attacked an attempt to recall Detroit's Mayor, Jcrome P. Cavanagh.

For Bruno Pagliai, the Italian-born Mexican industrialist, imagination--on the soaring scale that produced the Renaissance--is the essential ingredient needed to make the proposed Latin American Common Market a reality.

The disaster that has befallen Egypt and its Arab allies has created a situation of deep embarrassment for the Soviet Union that cannot be covered by its propaganda attacks on Israel or even a break in diplomatic relations.
FRESNO, Calif., June 7--A high Indian embassy official contended today that Mao Tsetung, top Communist leader, had "erred in believing that he can alter human instinct and incentive."
The American Stock Exchange reported yesterday the changes carried below in the shareholdings of officers, directors and major stockholders of listed companies.

CHATTAPURA, India, June 3--Basmathia, a tall, goodlooking girl from Deenadag, a village five miles from this tiny town in the southern part of the state of Bihar, was carrying one clay jug on her head and another on her hip when she was approached near her home late this afternoon.
WASHINGTON, June 7-- Lieut. Gen. Lewis W. Walt defended the controversial M-16 automatic rifle today as the "finest weapon" American fighting men have ever had.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 7-- The suspension of The Sunday Ramparts, a newspaper published about every two weeks by the same group that publishes Ramparts magazine, was announced today.

CINCINNATI, June 7 (AP) --Willie McCovey's three-run homer for the San Francisco Giants in the eighth inning drove out Gary Nolan after the Cincinnati Reds' 19-year-old rookie had struck out 15 men, and the Giants pushed across a run in the ninth for a 4-3 victory tonight.
Employes of the city's Youth Board who work with idle youths in slum neighborhoods, picketed their office yesterday to press their demands for wage adjustments.

WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP) --A bipartisan agreement that would shift major responsibility for the Teacher Corps from Washington to state and local authorities was reached today in a House Education subcommittee.
A Columbia Broadcasting System news crew planned to follow the first blockade-breaking ship up the Gulf of Aqaba to the Israeli port of Elath, it was disclosed yesterday.
A backlog of more than 2,300 telephone calls from the United States to Israel was reported yesterday by the American Telephone Telegraph Co.

LANSING, Mich., June 7-- Gov. George Romney will quicken the pace of his unannounced campaign for the 1968 Republican Presidential nomination by making trips in the next few weeks to three states with Presidential primaries next year.
TOKYO, Thursday, June 8 (UPI)--Peking wall posters quoted by Japanese newsmen reported today that the Chinese Army had been ordered to take "appropriate measures" against civil strife.

The city's decision to pay annual dues of $40,000 to the Metropolitan Regional Council will help revive an organization that can play an important role in providing information, guidance and technical assistance to the 1,467 separate local governments of the metropolitan area.

Deane W. Malott, president emeritus of Cornell University, told 165 graduating doctors and nurses that they "dare not retreat behind the cloak of professional involvement" and he exhorted them to provide leadership in national and international affairs.

The marriage of Miss Jacqueline Ann Talian, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. Talian of Rahway, N.J., to Carl Hans Duisberg took place yesterday in the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral. The Rev. Edward J. Heavey performed the ceremony.

PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., June 7--A $2,155,341 school budget that voters here defeated by 130 to 104 on May 2 was adopted last night by 803 to 561. The budget adds $13.32 to the old tax rate of $54.88 for each $1,000 of assessed valuation.
A 17-year-old student and an unemployed 23-year-old man were booked yesterday on charges of homicide in the death of a 75-year-old man who died after being robbed of $6.
ROME, June 7--Pope Paul VI made an impassioned plea for an end to all war today and repeated his appeal that the holy city of Jerusalem be declared an "open city."

Despite the anguish voiced by die-hard tenants and landlords, the rent adjustments the City Council has just authorized represent a reasonable answer to the tangle created by the interaction of the apartment house strike and the necessity for a new vote on rent control.

BALTIMORE, June 7--Paul Hall, president of the Seafarers International Union, who is head of organized labor's 600,000member Maritime Trades Department, said today that maritime labor would not budge in its opposition to two controversial points in Federal ship policy proposals.
PARIS, June 7--The reports on the death of Marcel Cerdan Jr.'s boxing career have been greatly exaggerated.
Almost half the 20 million Americans who change residences each year will do so in the next 90 days--and for most, the transfers will involve expenses far above the cost of actual moving.

The Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art awarded degrees and certificates to 241 graduates at its 108th commencement ceremony last night in its Great Hall at Fourth Avenue and Eighth Street.

YONKERS, June 7--Romeo Hanover, the odds-on favorite, gets the opportunity to record his 22d straight victory and Stanley Dancer gets his wish for Cardigan Bay to start from a post position "inside" the favorite tomorrow night at Yonkers Raceway.

PARIS, June 7--According to reports reaching here today from Israeli sources in Egypt, young Egyptian officers, deeply embittered and humiliated by the defeat of the Egyptian Army, are seeking the overthrow of President Gamal Abdel Nasser and Field Marshal Abdel Hakim Amer.
BOSTON, June 7 (UPI)-- Negro leaders called on United States Attorney General Ramsey Clark today to investigate alleged Boston "police malpractices" in quelling weekend racial riots and unrest.
PHILADELPHIA, June 7 (UPI)--The graduating class of Women's Medical College was told today that this country tended to ignore two major sources of medical doctors-- Negroes and women.

WASHINGTON, June 7-- Senator John Stennis said today that the Senate ethics committee would give "early preliminary consideration" to charges of misconduct made against Senator Edward V. Long of Missouri to determine whether an investigation is warranted.
CAIRO, June 7 (Reuters)-- Four Israeli frogmen have been captured in Alexandria and a hunt is going on for six others who escaped, the newspaper Al Ahram said today.
JERUSALEM, June 7--Israeli troops wept and prayed today at the foot of the Wailing Wall--the last remnant of Solomon's Second Temple and the object of pilgrimage

WHITE PLAINS, June 7-- Two 20-year-old men were indicted by a Westchester County grand jury today on first-degree murder charges in the death of Frank B. Crippen, a 48-year-old assistant professor at Fordham University.
The Arab defeat in one of the quickest wars in history became a debacle yesterday.
The pleasant domination the New York Yankees had enjoyed over the Washington Senators came to an end last night in Yankee Stadium.

ALBANY, June 7--State Senator Seymour R. Thaler told a Constitutional Convention committee hearing today that the Rockefeller Administration would be "receptive" to a $1-billion state bond issue to improve hospital, medical schools and nursing homes.

I regret to inform the Council of the death of an U.N.T.S.O. observer, Commandant Wickham of the Irish Army, who was killed early on the 7 of June on the road between Quneitra and Damascus. I wish to express my sympathy and condolences to the Government of Ireland and the family of Commandant Wickham.

WASHINGTON, June 7--The Washington Whips, represented by the Aberdeen Dons of Scotland, took a 1-0 lead in the fourth minute of a United Soccer Association game tonight when New York's Julio Dalmao, trying to clear the ball from in front of the goal, clipped it with the side of his foot and it went into the net.

DALLAS, June 7 (AP)-- Civic leaders in Dallas and Tarrant Counties were stunned as Dallas County voters yesterday rejected a proposed regional airport authority--first step toward a $250-million spaceage airport midway between Fort Worth and Dallas.

The election of James O. Boisi, Clifford F. Scherer and Donald A. Stoddard as senior vice presidents of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company was announced here yesterday. All were formerly vice presidents.
Although there has been bitter fighting on several fronts since the outbreak of war Monday, there has been no mention of casualty figures by either side.
Governor Rockefeller stunned Harlem onlookers--and surprised himself--when he lobbed a huge steel ball against the wrong building yesterday at demolition ceremonies for a new State Office Building.

Israel claimed victory in the Sinai Desert after three days of fighting. Sharm el Sheik, guarding the entrance to the Gulf of Aqaba, fell after a paratroop attack, and the Israelis said the blockade of the gulf was broken. Other Israeli units were within 20 miles of the Suez Canal, and one Israeli report placed them in the eastern section of Ismailia, on the canal itself.
ROME, June 7 (AP)--There were rumors in Rome tonight that King Hussein had left Jordan by plane and would land at Rome's Ciampino Military Airport en route to Britain.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, June 8--A Marine company killed 63 North Vietnamese soldiers today near the scene of last month's 12-day battle at Khesanh in the extreme northwest corner of South Vietnam.
The election of Herman Fialkov to the new post of senior vice president for corporate development was announced here yesterday by the General Instrument Corporation.

WASHINGTON, June 7-- "Mid-career clinics" that would prepare the working middleaged for a meaningful and increasingly longer retirement instead of a life of useless boredom were urged today by the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare.
MARY QUANT, the British designer who has been called the mother of the mods, may find that her heirs have independent ideas.

WASHINGTON, June 7 (UPI) --Two pharmacology professors told Senate investigators today that drug industry hucksters were tricking doctors into writing needlessly expensive, and possibly harmful, prescriptions.

PURCHASE, N.Y. June 7-- "What the heck," an executive who usually gets his way said today after hooking a drive into the rough at the Century Country club. "This game is made to be enjoyed. It's a fun thing, a happening."
Lincoln Center: New York Philharmonic Promenade, Andre Kostelanetz conducting, with Leonid Hambro, pianist, and Marc Connelly, narrator, Philharmonic Hall, 8:30 P.M.
The women's division of the United Jewish Appeal will hold its annual art auction on Monday evening at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue at 77th Street.
Joel L. Tyler, the Commissioner of Licenses, cautioned high school graduates yesterday on overcharging by hansom cab drivers in Central Park.
Cointreau Liqueurs, an international company, is constructing a $2-million plant in Lawrence Township, N.J.

STAMFORD, Conn., June 7 --The victories in today's America's Cup trials were shared by Intrepid, American Eagle and Constellation and among them Intrepid was the star. She won twice, once against outclassed Weatherly by almost a mile and again against Eagle by a lesser, but also conclusive, margin.
SCARSDALE, N.Y., June 7-- John J. Doyle, highway commissioner here for the last 19 years, died today at White Plains Hospital. He was 61 years old and lived at 2 Coralyn Road.

An official of the Federal Aviation Administration reported yesterday that his agency was satisfied it had corrected a safety problem in a popular twin-engined plane used widely as a corporate and air taxi aircraft.
TEL AVIV, June 7--"The bulk of the Egyptian forces are fleeing in disorder, and we have occupied most of Sinai. We have fought with our own forces, and nobody has aided us."

Mahmoud Jaber, who said he was once a major in the Jordanian Army, stood in the doorway of the tiny Cafe Sharezad last night in Brooklyn's Arab neighborhood--a short walk from Borough Hall--and proclaimed his intention of returning to fight for the liberation of his homeland.
The Brooklyn Chapter of the Congress of Racial Equality called yesterday for the "immediate removal" of three public school principals and an assistant superintendent of schools.

Sanitation Commissioner Samuel J. Kearing Jr. signed a contract with the Uniformed Sanitationmen's Union yesterday that provides employes right to counsel in any investigation and "makes it virtually impossible to arrange job assignments on a basis of favoritism." The fact is supplementary to the union's wage agreement with the city.
WASHINGTON, June 7--If the day had been cooler, if the wind had been blowing, if it had been a few days earlier or a few days later, Monday's eastern states power failure would not have occurred.

Science has added yeasts and bacteria to the possible sources of cheap protein for the conquest of hunger in the world. The list already includes fish flour, algae and other microorganisms in the sea and leaves from tropical rain forests.
BRUSSELS, June 7--Alain Camu, economic adviser to the Belgian Government, said today that Europe faced difficult choices in meeting the challenge of ever-growing American investments.

Voluntary gifts for Israel from American Jews have been pouring in this week and at one luncheon the fund raising brought in $1-million a minute. Professional fund-raisers of the United Jewish Appeal have been amazed by the outpouring.
Industrial issues extended Tuesday's gains yesterday on the American Stock Exchange.
Forty-four former first classmen, members of yesterday's graduating classes at the four major service academies, became bridegrooms soon, after commencement exercises.
JERUSALEM, June 7 (UPI) --Israelis streamed through the Mandelbaum Gate today to claim all of divided Jerusalem as theirs.

Charles Adolphe Gutwirth, vice president and general counsel and a director of the Continental Grain Company, 2 Broadway, died Tuesday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 54 years old and lived at 40 Central Park South.

The shofar, blown by jubilant Israelis as they went through the Mandelbaum Gate yesterday into the Old City of Jerusalem, is the ancient musical instrument of the Jews. A curved wind instrument, it is made from the hollowed horn of a ram. Its sharp wail resembles the cry of a hunting horn.
CHICAGO, June 7 (AP)--Ed Sweetman of Greensboro, N.C., and Dr. G.R. Noss of Paducah, Ky., took the second-round lead today in the National Association of Left-Handed Golfers tournament.

THE national junior champion, Amikam Balsham, scoring 9 points out of a possible 11, and without a single loss, captured first place in the recent Armed Forces championship of Israel. The event, for the first time a Swiss system, with 32 players participating in 11 rounds, was held at the Tel Aviv Soldiers' Home.

BRASILIA, Brazil, June 7-- The Brazilian Supreme Court agreed unanimously tonight to extradite Franz Paul Stangl, commandant of Nazi extermination camps, to West Germany, where he faces charges of genocide and murder.
Leo Harvey, chairman of Harvey Aluminum, Inc., sold yesterday a $46-million block of the company's stock. An underwriting syndicate managed by Kuhn, Loeb Co. and Tucker, ...
J.O. Terrell Couch has been elected general counsel of the Marathon Oil Company, effective July 1, it was announced yesterday.

Preparing for his next start, the Bowling Green Handicap at 1 5/8 miles on the grass at Aqueduct on June 17, Ogden Phipps's Buckpasser had a workout at Belmont Park in the morning. The 4-year-old son of Tom Fool will attempt turf racing for the ...
SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 7--Anyone trying to see Gen. William Westmoreland, the American military chief in Vietnam, was out of luck for 90 minutes one recent morning.

Mayor Lindsay has designated today as A.P.A.-Phoenix Day in honor of the repentory company at the Lyceum Theater. The occasion was marked at City Hall yesterday with the presentation of a scroll by Richard Rosen, Mayor Lindsay's assistant, to T. Edward Hambleton and Rosemary Harris. Mr. Hambleton is the troupe's managing director and Miss Harris, one of its principal players.
TALLAHASSEE, Fla., June 7 (UPI)--The Florida Senate passed and sent to the House today a bill liberalizing the state's 99-year-old abortion law.

NEW DELHI, June 7--Sheik Mohammed Abdullah, the Kashmiri Moslem leader who has been detained in southern India for two years, will be brought to New Delhi tomorrow for medical treatment, the Home Ministry announced tonight.

Representatives of the United Federation of Teachers voted yesterday to call for mass resignations by city teachers next fall if the union and the Board of Education failed to agree on a new contract before then.
CAMP LEJEUNE, N.C., June 7--Ten thousand marines, representing major components of the Fleet Marine Force, Atlantic, honored their retiring commander today with a surprise parade and review.

FOUR, members of the great Italian Blue team, which won its tenth world title in Miami Beach four days ago, returned home yesterday. They were Pietro Forquet of Naples, Giorgio Belladonna and Walter Avarelli of Rome, and Camillo Pabis Ticcl of Florence.
WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP) --A spokesman for the Republican party today urged tax incentives to encourage political contributions, rather than Government financing of election campaigns.

PITTSBURGH, June 7--The Mets returned tonight to their more familiar role as subjects for baseball's war on poverty. They were limited to five hits, all grounders, by Tommie Sisk, a 25-year-old right-hander, in a 3-0 defeat by the Pittsburgh Pirates.

ALEXANDRIA, Va., June 7 (UPI)--Staff Sgt. Herbert W. Boeckenhaupt of the Air Force was sentenced today to 30 years in prison for having conspired to deliver United States defense secrets to the Soviet Union.
GREENFIELD, N.H., June 7 (AP)--Haydn S. Pearson, syndicated columnist and author, died today at Monadnock Community Hospital in Peterboro. He was 66 years old.
It's true, after all: Rheingold beer is sloshing over from Doyle Dane Bernbach to Grey Advertising. There's $6-million in advertising there, so that's a lot of slosh.

A near-capacity audience at yesterday's matinee of "Sweet Charity" at the Palace Theater was dismissed because a new $50,000 airconditioning unit failed to work properly. With the aid of 10 tons of ice, hastily ordered for a standby system, last night's performance went on.

A funeral service was held yesterday at the Central Synagague, Lexington Avenue and 55th Street, for Mrs. Dora Marcus Cohn, widow of Justice Albert C. Cohn of the State Supreme Court and mother of Roy M. Cohn, lawyer and chairman of the board of the University National Bank.

CHICAGO, June 7--Lester O. Hodges, vocal teacher and coach-accompanist to many singers, died last night at Hines Veterans Hospital in suburban Maywood. He was 69 years old and lived here the last eight years.

PEKING, June 7 (Reuters)-- British diplomats and Communist demonstrators fought today inside the British diplomatic mission after a crowd of about 100 had forced its way in, ripped to shreds a British flag and destroyed a picture of Queen Elizabeth.

Final entries in the recent annual Ann Arbor (Mich.) Film Festival will be shown to the public tomorrow and Saturday at the New School forr Social Research, 66 West Twelth Street. The 59 experimental, independently produced movies, averaging 12 minutes in length, are being circulated for group screenings at 31 national schools. Juries at each school will name the best pictures.
Armour Co., the meat packer, announced yesterday in Chicago the election of David L. Duensing and Charles R. Orem as senior vice presidents.
Prices continued to climb on the London Stock Exchange yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 7--Arab strategy underlying recent events in the Middle East is not as senseless as it seems once we understand its hidden goals. These were defined four weeks ago in a secret meeting in Cairo. A transcript of that conference, now being clandestinely circulated here, is reprinted below:

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, June 7--The engagement of Miss Elizabeth Ruth Schomer to Richard J. Barber, son of Mrs. Raymond L. Barber and the late Mr. Barber of Detroit, has been made known by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Schomer.
WASHINGTON, June 7-- President Johnson pledged today to do his best to help translate the new Middle Eastern situation into a more lasting settlement between Israel and her Arab neighbors.
AUCKLAND, New Zealand --Teachers found some remarkable comments and truisms in the results of a recent examination, in which the pupils wrote about prizegiving and school dances.
Myths are born easily in the Middle East and a new one is in the making.

The United States clearly has no desire to break diplomatic relations with the Arab countries, and can only regret that eight nations have already severed diplomatic links with Washington and that possibly more will follow.

The Baltimore Orioles selected the top prospect in the secondary phase of baseball's free-agent yesterday when they chose John Michael Adamson, a, 19-year-old righthanded pitcher from the University of Southern California as the No. 1 pick.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 7--The Security Council unanimously adopted a Soviet resolution today calling on the combatants in the Middle East to "cease fire and all military activities" at 4 P.M., New York time today.
An arrest warrant was issued yesterday in Federal Court for a 24-year-old Swiss national who set up a travel agency here and then allegedly bilked about 500 college students of more than $40,000.
PITTSBURGH, June 7--Mrs. Jessie Vann, until 1963 owner and publisher of The Pittsburgh Courier, a Negro weekly newspaper, died today in West Penn Hospital. She was 82 years old.

FOR Steve Barber of the Orioles it was a somewhat expensive visit. Disturbed by his lack of success this season, the brooding southpaw walked away from the California-bound plane at the Baltimore airport on Sunday and went A.W.O.L. After a brief stopover at the Wisconsin home of his wife's parents, he rejoined the squad in Anaheim. For this he was fined $250 by Manager Hank Bauer.

EPSOM, England, June 7 (AP)-- Royal Palace, the 7-4 favorite in a field of 22, stuck his nose in front a quarter of a mile from the finish and went on to score a 2 -length victory in the 188th running of the English Derby at Epsom Downs today. The time for the 1 miles was 2 minutes 38.4 seconds. The record is 2:33.8, set by Mahmoud in 1936.
New York City's Urban Corps will begin its second summer of operations on Monday, Deputy Mayor Tomothy W. Costello announced yesterday.
A 90-minute program depicting a difficult heart operation will be televised in color on Channel 5 Sunday, June 25, at 8:30 P.M.
GENEVA, June 7--A chartered four-engine transport plane, with the Red Cross insignia hastily painted on its wings, left for Beirut, Lebanon, tonight.

Dorothy Parker, the sardonic humorist who purveyed her wit in conversation, short stories, verse and criticism, died of a heart attack yesterday afternoon in her suite at the Volney Hotel, 23 East 74th Street. She was 73 years old and had been in frail health in recent years.

TEL AVIV, June 7--Israel proclaimed victory tonight in the Sinai Peninsula campaign against the United Arab Republic. On the eastern front, both the Old City of Jerusalem and Bethlehem were captured from the Jordanians.
AMHERST, Mass., June 7 --School officials here have refused to readmit a 12-yearold boy to junior high school until he takes off a black armband that he wears to protest the Vietnam war.
At times almost reluctantly, many of New York's 1.9-million Jews expressed fierce pride yesterday at the victories being won by the Israeli Army in the Middle East conflict.

WASHINGTON, June 7--A planned parenthood group proposed today that the Government subsidize a large-scale program in voluntary family planning in 56 key American counties to reduce the nation's toll of infant mortality.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 7--Jordan's representative, Muhammad H. el-Farra, accused Israel of preventing a United Nations cease-fire today by continued fighting to seize more territory.

OXFORD, Ohio, June 7--Dr. Arthur C. Wickenden, retired Miami University professor of religion and chairman of its department of religion, was found dead of a heart attack today in the garden of his home here. He was 74 years old.
MIAMI, June 7--William C. Baggs, editor of The Miami News, wrote yesterday that knowledgeable foreign diplomats believe Communist China may intervene in Vietnam in a few weeks.
HARTFORD, Thursday, June 8--The General Assembly last night overrode Gov. John N. Dempsey's veto on a bill to allow Connecticut residents to participate in the New York and New Hampshire lotteries.
KLM Royal Dutch Airlines, in which the Dutch Government holds a 50.5 per cent interest, announced here yesterday that its net income in fiscal 1967 increased by 40 per cent from 1966.
WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP) --The Commerce Department said today it would begin tomorrow a program to replace the standards for weights and measures in all 50 states.

A retrospective series of films made by Arthur Freed, the 72-year-old Academy Award-winning lyricist-producer, will be presented at the Gallery of Modern Art, Columbus Circle, from June 20 through Aug. 20. There will be two screenings daily, 3 and 5:30 P.M., Tuesday through Saturday, and at 2 and 4 P.M. on Sunday.
Lincoln Center: New York Philharmonic Promenade, Philharmonic Hall, 8:30 P.M.; Gabriel Banat, violinist, and Mario Miranda, pianist, Library and Museum of Performing Arts, 6:30.

WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP) --The Senate passed and sent to President Johnson today a $238-million bill authorizing a three-year extension of Federal aid for building and staffing community health centers.

MONTREAL, June 8 (AP)-- The Los Angeles Kings acquired the rights to Red Kelly in exchange for a young defenseman, Ken Block, tonight and immediately named the 39year-old star the coach of their new National Hockey League team.

WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP)--Assistant Attorney General Fred M. Vinson Jr. defended today the constitutionality of President Johnson's proposal for direct Government financing of Presidential election campaigns.

WASHINGTON, June 8--The Senate approved today a bill requiring that by the 1968 election no state have a population variance of more than 10 cent between its largest and smallest Congressional districts.

ABOARD U.S.S. AMERICA, in the Eastern Mediterranean, June 8--Two Soviet Warships, a destroyer and a small, highly maneuverable patrol craft, moved into the formation of this Sixth Fleet carrier task force group this morning and began systematically harassing the American ships.

ROCKVILLE, Md., June 8-- Two Negro brothers, whose 1961 convictions in the rape of a white girl were quashed last month when the prosecutor challenged the police testimony against them, have been reindicted on the same charge.

Geo. A. Hormel Co., a large meat packer, announced yesterday in Austin, Minn., a net profit of $4,385,262, equal to $3.66 a share, for the six months ended April 30. This compares with $425,791, or 36 cents a share, in the corresponding 1966 quarter. Sales rose to $259,978,630 from $234,732,386 a year earlier.
As the situation in the Middle East began to settle down, it appeared that the disruption and damage to American business had been less severe than anticipated.

OTTAWA, June 8--Prime Minister Lester B. Pearson urged the United Nations today to establish a demilitarized zone between Israel and neighboring Arab states as the next step in resolving the conflict in the Middle East.

MOSCOW, June 8--Soviet sources said today that the Kremlin's decision to join the United States in approving a United Nations resolution for an immediate cease-fire in the Middle East had come in the course of an all-night meeting of the 11-man Politburo.
New bond offerings by Textron, Inc., and the Pennsylvania Electric Company held most of the attention of investment bankers yesterday. Sales results were mixed.
The United Arab Republic accepted a United Nations cease-fire. Israel had previously agreed to stop hostilities if her enemies were willing to go along.

Communications authorities here said yesterday that President Nasser and King Hussein could have used a military radio circuit or facilities of the Cairo radio and Jordan's Amman radio for their conversation. One source said that Arab areas in the Middle East were supplied with Soviet communications equipment.
A net profit of $10,321,000, equivalent to $1.09 a share, was reported yesterday by the Ampex Corporation for its fiscal year ended April 29.
LONDON, June 8--According to official British sources, Jordanian military spokesmen conceded in Amman yesterday that no British or American planes had been seen in Jordan.
LONDON, June 8--Pamela Frankau, the novelist, died today at her home in Hampstead, London. She was 59 years old.
HONG KONG, June 8 (Reuters)--The police swung into action today against a new outbreak of strikes here and arrested more than 500 persons.
ROME, June 8--Pope Paul VI urged the warring parties in the Middle East today to comply with the Security Council's call for an immediate cease-fire.
The spot rate on the British pound continued a strong recovery yesterday in moderate trading on foreign exchange markets here.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 8--The United Arab Republic, the leader of the anti-Israel coalition, today accepted the Security Council's demand for a cease-fire in the Middle East provided Israel did the Same.

The United States Court of Appeals reserved decision yesterday on an appeal of a ruling by Federal Judge Constance Baker Motley upholding the right of a pupil suspended from public school to be represented by a lawyer at a hearing before a Board of Education district supervisor.

MILTON, Mass., June 8-- Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Role have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Lee Role, to Dr. Lorne Michael Mendell. He is the son of Mrs. Manuel A. Mendell of Montreal and the late Mr. Mendell, a lawyer.

TORONTO, June 8--The behavior or subsidiaries of United States and other foreign companies in Canada, often a target for political criticism, was judged in a Government report released today to be in general conformity with national practice.

Rodeo-style trick riding, daring tactics and a spill marked the running of the $11,550 Annapolis Hurdle yesterday at Aqueduct. Quashed, competing in the colors of Mrs. Marion S. du Pont's Montpelier Farm, won the 1-5/8-mile race by 10 lengths, with the odds-on favorite, Possibility, next in the field of 10 jumpers.

THE biggest charity tournament of the year was played Wednesday night at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. CHICAGO, June 8 (AP)-- Gary Bell, making his debut for Boston, scattered nine hits and rode a five-run second inning to a 7-3 victory over the Chicago White Sox today. The victory gave the Red Sox a split in their double-header.

WASHINGTON, June 8-- Vice Adm. Hyman G. Rickover has denounced the costeffectiveness approach to weapons development as an "ism," a "new religion" and a "fog bomb" that is keeping the nation from gaining technology that would save lives.
