CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 8 --Dr. Charles R. Cherington, who was forced by ill-health to give up his post as professor of government at Harvard University last year, died yesterday at Peter Bent Brigham Hospital in Boston. His age was 53 and he lived in Calais, Vt.
The daily double paid off handsomely at two Ohio tracks yesterday, with a return of $4,553,40 at Thistledown in Cleveland and $2,424 at River Downs in Cincinnati.

WASHINGTON, June 8-- Manufacturers expect to add even less to inventory in the second and third quarters of this year than the relatively low rate of accumulation in the first quarter, the Commerce Department reported today.
Prices continued to advance yesterday in moderate, selective trading on the American Stock Exchange.
Loans of New York and Chicago banks are providing more evidence of sluggishness in the economy.

A Constitutional Convention committee was accused yesterday of refusing to hear some spokesmen who favor the amendment that bars aid to parochial schools.

WASHINGTON, June 8 --An American naval vessel was mistakenly attacked by Israeli planes and torpedo boats today in international waters about 15 miles north of the Sinai Peninsula. Reports tonight listed the toll as 10 dead and 100 wounded. Twenty of the wounded were hurt critically.
Eight persons were arraigned yesterday in Federal District Court in Brooklyn on charges of smuggling cocaine.

WASHINGTON, June 8-- Secretary of the Interior Stewart L. Udall told Congress today that "we are not prepared --legally, institutionally, operationally and technically--to deal with a major crisis such as the Torrey Canyon disaster."

PARIS, June 8--The police disclosed today that they had arrested a Polish-born United States citizen who said that he wanted to kill Ambassador Charles B. Bohlen. Nearly 80 per cent of Harvard University's Far Eastern specialists have signed a protest against the Administration's policy in Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP) --The Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service said today it was seeking to set up new talks in the four-day strike of electrical workers against several Radio Corporation of America plants.

Attempts by violence to break up the marriage of a Connecticut couple by a man described by the Government as an "oldtime strong-arm Cosa Nostra racketeer in Westchester" were charged yesterday in Federal court.

MIAMI, Fla., June 8 (AP)-- Cuba's vital sugar harvest, approaching its end, has reached six million tons, Havana radio reported last night. This compares with a disappointing 4,455,000 tons last year and the all-time high of seven million tons in 1952. Premier Fidel Castro had set a goal of 7,500,000 tons for this year.

NEW ORLEANS, June 8 (AP)--Lawyers for the man accused of plotting to assassinate President Kennedy won their fight today to expose the private fund behind the investigation conducted by District Attorney Jim Garrison.

CAIRO, Friday, June 9--The Government told the Egyptian people this morning that it had conditionally accepted a ceasefire in the war with Israel.

WASHINGTON, JUNE 8-- Miss Halina Huntington Tappin made her debut here tonight at a dance given by her mother, Mrs. John Lindsley Tappin, at the Washington Club. Her godmother, Mrs. Frederick H. Bedford of New York and Greens Farms, Conn., gave a dinner beforehand at the University Club.
Sit-ins, sleep-ins, be-ins, wade-ins and stall-ins are out. Wed-ins are in.

CHICAGO, June 8 (AP)-- The nation's traffic deaths in April totaled 3,920, a sharp drop from 4,360 in April, 1966. This brought the total for the first third of 1967 to 2 per cent below the corresponding period last year.

WASHINGTON, June 8--The Office of Economic Opportunity has "on the whole done a spectacular job" in just two and one-half years of work to aid the poor and should not be dismembered, a Negro leader said today.

J.J. Dansill has been named vice president of field sales for the photographic division of Argus, Inc., manufacturer of photographic and other equipment for industry and the military agencies of the Federal Government.

Parks Commissioner August Heckscher walked along a narrow, debris-strewn stretch of sand at the Rockaways yesterday, surveyed the remains of a lifeguard station and torn staircases leading to the boardwalk and witnessed the burial of a dead sea gull. All were victims of recent storms that washed away a four-and-half foot layer of beachfront.

A 90-year-old newspaper tradition was continued last Sunday when The New York Times made its first appeal for The Fresh Air Fund. The Times' appeal Will help support the fund's annual campaign to attain its 1967 goal of $625,000 to provide free vacations for 15,000 boys and girls from the city's disadvantaged areas.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 8--Two longtime diplomats representing the United Arab Republic and Israel performed here today with professional aplomb.

The Museum of Modern Art is commemorating the 30th anniversary of Pablo Picasso's celebrated mural "Guernica" with a special summer-long exhibition of 38 preliminary stud ies for the work and 16 postscripts by the artist. The huge mural and the studies, now on view together, have been on loan from the artist since 1939.

William Robinson, a retired partner in the millinery concern of Robinson Press, died yesterday at Polyclinic Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived at the Bretton Hall Hotel, Broadway and 86th Street.

Hippies armed with electric guitars occupied the band shell at the Mall in Central Park yesterday and opened up with their musical artillery. An audience of about 450 withstood the two-and-a-half-hour barrage.
SANTA FE, N.M., June 8-- Gov. David F. Cargo said today that he believed the armed "revolution" of Spanish-speaking Americans in northern New Mexico was over.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., June 9 --Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower compared the Israeli military forces today to "the patriots army who stuck it out through the winter at Valley Forge." He said the Israelis had a dedication similar to those troops of George Washington.

J. Ray McDermott Co., which provides engineering and construction services to the offshore drilling industry, achieved record sales and earnings in fiscal 1967 for the fourth consecutive year, it was reported yesterday in New Orleans.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 8 (AP)--Harvard University announced today the names of 12 journalists appointed for the 30th class of Nieman Fellows for 1967-68.
A crowd gathered last night at Tompkins Square Park-- scene of the Memorial Day clash between hippies and the police--when a dog bit a 26year-old man.

PERRYSBURG, Ohio, June 8--Miss Victoria Thompson, a picture researcher with Time, Inc., in New York, and William G. Winterer, an investment banker with Goodbody Co., New York, plan to marry here Sept. 2.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., June 8 (AP)--Max Alvis, who led off the game with a homer, capped a four-run ninth inning with a two-run blast today, giving the Cleveland Indians a 7-5 victory over the Minnesota Twins.

CINCINNATI, June 8 (UPI) --Ollie Brown, who earlier had hit his 10th homer, singled home Willie McCovey from second base in the eighth inning tonight with the tie-breaking run as the San Francisco Giants whipped the Cincinnati Reds, 8-5.
LONDON, June 8--Britain lifted her suspension of arms shipments to the Middle East today because other major suppliers had not joined the embargo.

CHICAGO, June 8--The American Medical Association said today that prescription of generic drugs by physicians did not guarantee lower prices to patients because pharmacists were likely to fill the prescriptions with expensive brand name products anyway.
Worried money--seeking a haven from war in the Middle East--sought refuge in Switzerland last week, the Swiss National Bank reported yesterday.

RICHMOND, June 8 (AP)-- --Prince Edward County supervisors reported today that they had restored to the county treasurer $125,000 of the $180,000 in tuition grant money handed out in August, 1964, to parents of county children attending white private schools.
WASHINGTON, June 8-- Arab diplomats have been breaking social engagements in Washington this week as fast as their countries have been breaking diplomatic relations.
The head of the International Longshoremen's Association said yesterday that an overhaul of the port's seniority system would contribute to better utilization of the longshore work force.
ALBANY, June 8--The State University's board of trustees approved today the appointment of Dr. Kurt R. Schmeller as president of Queensborough Community College in New York City.

WASHINGTON, June 8--The Administration proposed today legislation aimed at reducing the likelihood of future widearea power failures by giving the Government authority to compel better planning and safer operation of both local and regional utility systems.

Paul Lazarus, 39-year-old president of a metals corporation, was named in a new indictment yesterday in Federal Court as a member of a conspiracy to blow up a railroad bridge in Zambia, He was released in $5,000 bail.
ANAHEIM, Calif, June 8 (AP)--Rich Reichart hit a two-run homer today in the sixth inning that brought the California Angels from behind to a 6-5 victory over the Baltimore Orioles.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Friday, June 9 (Reuters)--The Iraqi Government has ordered the United States charge d'affaires and the British ambassador in Baghdad to leave the country, the Baghdad radio said today.
A semiofficial survey of lottery sales indicated yesterday that in its first week in New York City, the lottery fell almost 20 per cent short of the state's forecast.
Three persons were killed in an automobile accident yesterday afternoon on Cross Bay Boulevard in the Broad Channel section of Queens.
"If you say you're from Canada, everybody says 'Isn't that nice.' If you say you're from Brooklyn, all you get is a big laugh."
TEL AVIV, June 8--The tapes purportedly recording the voices of the Egyptian and Jordanian rulers were played to the Arab world today by Israel's Arabic radio service.
Philip Johnson, who is usually wary of businessmen, asked several hundred of them yesterday what they have done for the city lately.
WASHINGTON, June 8--The operating chief of the Defense Department's civil rights program quit his post today, charging that the Pentagon had "betrayed" President Johnson's nondiscrimination policies.
Leon T. Kendall, vice president and economist of the New York Stock Exchange, was picked yesterday as the first full-time, paid president of the Association of Stock Exchange Firms.
WASHINGTON, June 8 (UPI)--The drinking patterns of chronic alcoholics in Boston will be studied under a grant awarded today by the National Center for the Prevention and Control of Alcoholism.

At Kennedy Airport, just before his departure last night for Israel, Mr. Eban spoke of the urgency of building "a new and more stable structure of relationships between Israel and the neighboring states."

FLOORS become scuffed, carpets soiled and walls fingermarked. Servants grumble, husbands leave home temporarily and insurance companies object. Yet an increasing number of householders repeatedly submit to, indeed welcome, mass visita tions from strangers on house tours.

PHILADELPHIA, June 8-- Miss Sharon Lynn Zukin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morris A. Zukin, was married today to John Pierce Rousmaniere, son of Mr. and Mrs. James A. Rousmaniere of Oyster Bay, L.I. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Sidney Greenberg at Temple Sinai.

SPRINGFIELD, N.J., June 8--Edward Cohill of 466 Meisel Avenue, a former power engineer for the Board of Education in Elizabeth and father of the Most Rev. John E. Cohill, Roman Catholic Bishop of Goroka, New Guinea, died yesterday at the John E. Runnell's Hospital, Berkeley Heights. His age was 94. He retired in 1941.

HARTFORD, June 8--The ornate chambers of the Connecticut General Assembly were dirty and deserted this morning, and some legislators were wondering as they packed their bags just what they had done there in the frantic hours before midnight.

WASHINGTON, June 8-- Thousands of Jews arrived today to demonstrate across the street from the White House for United States support of Israel and wound up participating in an unofficial victory celebration.

CHICAGO, June 8--Despite the disaster of eight defeats in 11 games on the road trip that resumes here tomorrow, the Mets appear to have discovered a man for all seasons, perhaps at least 10 or 12 of them. Bud Harrelson, the mini-shortstop, has solidified that position, so much so that Wes Westrum, the normally cautious manager, says that "at his age [23] we might be able to forget about shortstops for another decade, or more."
The equation of power in the Middle East has been materially changed by the sweeping Israeli victories.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., June 8-- Automobile exhausts and a slowlearning child--seemingly unrelated--may soon be linked by several hundred mice in a trailer parked on the campus of Hofstra University.

Governor Rockefeller declined yesterday to take a stand on the specifics of President Johnson's prosecution of the Vietnam war while continuing to assure the President general support in the conflict.
Fred Stolle took the first set from Rod Laver last night, one of the most extraordinarily fine sets of tennis ever played at Madison Square Garden, but Laver, the world champion, won the match.

David B. Charnay, a former public-relations executive and former corporate executive, brought a $30-million damage suit in the New York Supreme Court yesterday against Julian G. Sourwine and Herman W. Brann.

Third Naval District headquarters has announced visits next week by a United States submarine and by a Colombian destroyer transport. Both craft will be open to the public during their stay at Pier 88, Hudson River, at West 48th Street.

The board of directors of WNJU-TV has rejected the plan to transfer the station's transmittee and antennas from the Empire State Building to the top of the twin towers of the proposed World Trade Center.
DETROIT, June 8 (AP)-- Automobile production this week is expected to be the second highest for any week thus far in 1967.
Tense and weary United Nations delegates found a breath of fresh air last night as they gathered on the lawn of Gracie Mansion for a party in their honor given by Mayor Lindsay.

HEWLETT NECK, L.I., June 8--Martin M. Kolbrener, a Nassau County Court judge since 1964, died at his home here last night, apparently of a heart attack. He was 64 years old and lived at 165 Dolphin Drive.
AMMAN, Jordan, June 8-- A gaunt, weary, unshaven but still defiant King Hussein conceded today that the war was over for Jordan.
A rather select triple crown, the New York Racing Association's series for 3-year-old fillies, will be in its second phase at Aqueduct today with the running of the Mother Goose Stakes.
The small plaza at the intersection of Spruce and Nassau Streets and Park Row, known wince 1940 as Printing House Square, may be changed to Pace College Plaza.
WASHINGTON, June 9-- The House Appropriations Committee approved today a record $70.3-billion defense appropriations bill, including 20.3-billion attributable to the war in Vietnam.
The Universalist Church of New York City, situated at Central Park West at 76th Street for 65 years, will hold religious services tomorrow in Central Park.
WITH Beardsley revided, Erte could not be far behind, and sure enough the Grosvenor Gallery, at 25 East 77th Street, has done the job.

It is good for a man to know one small place intimately. He who enjoys woodlands, swamps, ridge tops, can breathe deeply in his personally chosen corner. It is an opening on a hillside above fields, meadows and swamps. On a pleasant, sunny day the place serves as a haven where a countryman can sit and contemplate the stillness of June.
Grains tumbled yesterday after gains earlier in the week attributed to the Middle East war. In fact, the rally lasted a much shorter time than the shooting.
CINCINNATI, June 9 (UPI) --The league-leading Cincinnati Reds exploded for three homers, one a three-run blast by Pete Rose in a six-run seventh inning, to defeat the Houston Astros tonight, 10-7
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., June 9 (AP)--The Minnesota Twins dismissed Sam Mele as manager today and named Cal Ermer as his successor.
The world's two top-rated professional tennis players strode with devastating determination and efficiency last night to the final of the $25,000 Madison Square Garden tournament.
THE STOCKS of Twentieth Century Fox and Rayette Faberge, Inc., two of the hottest in Big Board trading on Thursday, cooled down yesterday.

AUCKLAND, New Zealand, June 9--New Zealand timber interests have entered into partnership with a United States company to form a new shipping line for trade with the American Pacific Coast. It will be known as the New Zealand Pacific Line.

TEL AVIV, June 9--Israeli armored and infantry forces smashed deep into Syria today after the Syrians, according to Israel, had broken the ceasefire on the northern front and shelled 16 settlements along the 48-mile frontier.

LOS ANGELES, June 9 (AP) --Floyd Patterson got off the floor twice in the second round tonight and went on to fight to a bloody 10-round draw with California's young heavyweight, Jerry Quarry at Memorial Coliseum.

Senator Jacob K. Javits announced yesterday that he would introduce a bill next week--to be co-sponsored by Senator Robert F. Kennedy-- that would provide $60-million for day-care centers for the children of parents on welfare.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., June 9--Charles and Tom Fix of Kearny, the top-seeded team, defeated Leon and Andre Bernard of the Bronx. 6-2, 6-0, today and moved into the third round of the New Jersey State father-and-son tennis championships at the East Orange Tennis Club.
BOSTON, June 9 (UPI)-- Carl Yastrzemski and and Joe Foy each hit two home runs tonight as they led the Boston Red Sox to an 8-7 victory over the Washington Senators.
In the last five years Girl Scout Troop 276 of Davenport, Iowa, has made more than 46,000 pieces of fudge.
LONDON, June 9 (AP)-- the engagement of Robin Wilson, 23-year-old elder son of Prime Minister Wilson and Mrs. Wilson, to Margaret Elizabeth Crispin, 23, a student front Devon, was announced tonight.
DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, June 9--Oscar Kambona, who was appointed Minister for Local Government and Rural Development Wednesday in a major Cabinet upheaval, resigned today.

WASHINGTON, June 9-- Congress was told today that much waste oil from automobiles, formerly collected by plants that re-refined it, was probably being dumped and finding its way in increasingly large amounts into water supplies.
WELLAND, Ont., June 9--A $110-million Canadian project to improve transportation and reduce transit time through the 26-mile-long Welland Canal was begun here today.
WALLINGFORD, Conn., June 9 Dissent is essential to progress. David Rockefeller, the president of the Chase Manhattan Bank, paid at a commencement address today at the Choate School.

The Pacific Maritime Association and the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union were praised by the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service in the agency's 19th annual report, received here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 9 (UPI) --Government crop experts said today wheat growers in the United States would produce a record crop this year of 1.55 billion bushels, 18 per cent higher than last year and 28 per cent above the five-year average.
Senator Robert F. Kennedy yesterday proposed a State Department of Justice, modeled on the Federal system, as part of a wide reorganization for New York's law enforcement agencies.

A taxpayer's suit to block the Police Department from cooperating in the production of scheduled television series in the fall entitled "N.Y.P.D." was dismissed yesterday by State Supreme Court Justice Joseph A. Sarafite.

The Boston Maine Corporation has reached a tentative agreement with its major institutional bondholders for a threeyear extension of its $16,339,000 of 6 per cent bonds, Richard J. Mulhern, presdent, announced yesterday.
SEOUL, June 9 (UPI)-- South Korea's ruling party won an overwhelming victory in the parliamentary elections yesterday and the opposition immediately charged that the voting had been rigged.

Indicated net income of the Distillers Corporation--Seagrams, Ltd., in the third fiscal quarter declined to $8,697,000, equal to 50 cents a share, from $9,734,000, or 53 cents in the corresponding 1966 quarter, it was disclosed yesterday.
Dr. Lowell B. Eckerson, a retired specialist in internal medicine, died Thursday in Riverview Hospital, Red Bank, N.J. He was 76 years old and lived at 50 West Front Street, Red Bank.

The Celanese Chemical Company, a unit of the Celanese Corporation, said yesterday it was expanding formaldehyde capacity at a plant in Bishop, Tex., to add 150 million pounds a year to production. The expansion is expected to be completed in October.
ALGIERS, June 9--Demonstrators swept through the streets of Algiers tonight denouncing the Middle Eastern cease-fire accepted by the Arab countries as an act of treason and surrender.

WEST HEMPSTEAD, L.I., June 9--Mrs. Hazel Kane Clements, a newspaperwoman and magazine writer who used the pen name Hall Kane Clements, died yesterday at Meadowbrook Hospital. She was 75 years old and lived at 173 Hempstead Gardens Drive.
BERLIN, June 9 (AP)--The United States and Britain won matches today and advanced to the semi-finals of the Federation Cup tennis tournament.

GRAND BLANC, Mich., June 9 (UPI)--Tommy Aaron sank a 15-foot putt on the final hole to complete a two-under-par round of 70 that moved him into a tie at 142 with Bob Goalby today as the secondround leaders of the $100,000 Buick open.
A 71-year-old Bronx dentist was charged in Brow Criminal court yesterday with attempting to loot a patient's safety box, which he allegedly thought contained $100,000 in cash.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., June 9--The Secretary of the Treasury, Henry H. Fowler, indicated here tonight he expected the temporary surtax on corporate and individual income taxes to be enacted this year, but gave no hint on the date.

Charles Lehman, the founder and owner of Charles Lehman Advertising, 305 East 50th Street, died Wednesday in Lefferts General Hospital, Brooklyn, of peritonitis. He was 55 years old and lived at 1018 East 22d Street, Brooklyn.
READING, Pa., June 9-- From the air, it looked like one of the world's busiest airports, with hundreds of aircraft parked wing to wing and planes darting off and landing continuously.

Hamilton Fish, former United States Pepresentative from Orange County, and Mrs. Marie Choubaroff Blackton of 655 Park Avenue, widow of Nicholas Blackton, plan to be married June 22 in the chapel of St. James's Episcopal Church by the Rev. Dr. Gilbert Darlington.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., June 9 (AP)--Frank Robinson and Boog Powell cracked three-run homers tonight in powering the Baltimore Orioles to an 11-2 victory over Minnesota. The game marked the debut of the Twins' manager, Cal Ermer.
Columbia University announced yesterday a major shake-up of its central administration to bolster its academic and fund-raising strength.

Gamal Abdel Nasser announced his resignation as President of the United Arab Republic in a radio and television address to the nation, but he later put the question before the National Assembly, which was reported to have rejected his resignation.

The spot rate on the British pound eased yesterday in moderate trading on foreign exchange markets here. The final quotation of $2.7925 was nine points below the closing rate on Thursday. The decline was attributed to the usual weekend technical "positioning."

WASHINGTON, June 9-- Federal officials concerned with "intellectual property"--patents, trademarks and copyrights--will take part in a 5week conference opening Monday in Stockholm. The United States delegation is headed by Eugene M, Braderman, Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for Commercial Affairs.

The Rev. Leo McLaughlin, president of Fordham University, told Brooklyn College graduates yesterday they could become the first "older generation in man's history to understand that the next younger generation is not necessarily on the way to damnation." He spoke at the college's commencement exercises on the campus quadrangle.
TEL AVIV, June 9 (AP)-- Premier Eshkol told a political party meeting tonight: "We are now at a time when an entirely new reality is emerging in this region."

A 17-year-old student who was removed as co-editor of a Manhattan high school newspaper in January after publicly distributing an editorial banned by the principal has been restored to his former post by a Federal Court order.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, June 9--Two liberal theologians won a libel suit here today against a conservative theologian who had, in effect, accused them of trying to overthrow "the existing order."

Dance, like love, is where you find it. Last night it turned up in the gymnasium of Sloan House of the Young Men's Christian Association, where Merle Lister and Dance Company presented an engaging program. It will be repeated tonight and Sunday evening.

SINGAPORE, June 9--The Singapore Government proscribed today a 104-page book of Chinese songs and Mao Tsetung's thoughts.

TEL AVIV, June 9--The lights of this Israeli city went on tonight just as the political star of President Gamal Abdel Nasser seemed to be fading.

BALTIMORE, June 9--A threat to strike by the 6,000member Public School Teachers Association here evaporated today when only 200 members attended a strategy session.

The United States Steel Corporation announced yesterday in Pittsburgh the appointment of J.D. McCall to the new post of administrative vice president of the commerciai and chemicals division.
ALBANY, June 9--Supreme Court Justice T. Paul Kane dismissed today a suit seeking to seat a Conservative-Republican candidate for a, disputed Constitutional Convention delegate's seat in the Bronx.

WASHINGTON, June 9 (UPI)--Vice President Humphrey has entered Bethesda Naval Hospital for a checkup on treatment following a bladder infection, his office announced tonight.

LONDON, June 9 (Reuters) --Vanessa Redgrave, an actress, and a British nuclear scientist were among the 700 persons honored today in the Queen's Birthday Lists.

BOSTON HEIGHTS, Ohio, June 9 (UPI)--"Brutality and oppressive methods" by the Cleveland police appear to invite riots, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. said today.

SARATOGA, Calif., June 9 (AP)--Ranking Navy officers paid a last tribute today to famed World War II submarine force commander Vice Adm. Charles A, Lockwood at funeral service in St. Andrews Episcopal Church.
Four major lumber associations reported a decrease of 7.1 per cent in production for the week ended June 3, compared with the corresponding 1966 week.

KANSAS CITY, June 9 (UPI)--The Kansas City Chiefs added a prize prospect to their linebacking corps today by signing Jim Lynch, Notre Dame's all-American. Terms of the contract were not disclosed.
MADRID, June 9--BritishSpaniah negotiations over air space restrictions around Gibraltar broke down early today after four days of meetings here.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 9-- Mrs. Frederick H. Brooke, a former national president of the Girl Scouts of America and a member of the organization's national board for 40 years, died here at her home last night. She was 89 years old.

HAMILTON, N.Y., June 9 (AP)--Jasjit Singh of Notre Dame won the singles title of the 45th Eastern intercollegiate tennis championships today at Colgate University by defeating Mario Obando of Penn State, 6-2, 6-4, 9-7.

Holy Cross of Bayside, Queens, beat Archbishop Stepinac of Westchester, 4-1, yesterday at Sterling Courts, Flushing, and won the Greater New York Catholic High Schools Athletic Association tennis championship.
ANAHEIM, Calif., June 9 (AP)--George Brunet pitched a three-hitter tonight, breaking his nine-game losing streak, as the California Angels defeated the Detroit Tiger, 4-0.

The Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith said yesterday it would start a nationwide system to monitor broadcasts as a result of what the organization termed anti-Semitic remarks that had been heard on the air during the last few days in connection with the war in the Middle East.

WASHINGTON, June 9--The Committee on the World Food Crisis demanded today that the Administration stop talking and start doing something about the onslaught of massive starvation throughout underdeveloped areas of the world.

NAIROBI, Kenya--Africa, bedraggled continent of two score countries on the verge of splitting into more, is turning earnestly to the task of pulling herself together a bit to look more attractive to potential investors.

WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) --The Interstate Commerce Commission ordered the Chesapeake Ohio Railway today to continue operating for at least six months six passenger trains including the Fast Flying Virginian.
WASHINGTON, June 9-- President Johnson announced today the formation of a Cabinetlevel committee to try to improve conditions for poor Mexican-Americans.

AMHERST, Mass., June 9-- An Amherst student whose suspension for wearing a black antiwar armband was termed a disciplinary measure, lost his case today against the Amherst-Pelham Regional School Committee, and the school officials.

The bribery and corruption of housing inspectors by landlords and contractors revealed by the presentment of the New York County grand jury is nothing particularly new. It is an endemic condition that flares into public attention periodically, then subsides until vigilance has been relaxed again.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, June 10--Enemy gunners fired 127 mortar rounds today at the central highlands city of Pleiku and nearby American and South Vietnamese bases. A military spokesman said 2 Americans and 24 Montagnard tribesmen had been killed.

GREAT NECK, L.I., June 9, --Peter Fishbach of Great Neek, L.I., seeded fourth, upset the second seeded player. Hal German of Jersey City, 6-2, 6-1, today to reach the final of the Long Island men's tennis championships at the Great Neck Country Club with the favorite, Gene Scott of St. James, L.I.
The appointment of Arthur M. Quilty as president of the products division of the Warner-Lambert Pharmaceutical Company was announced yesterday in Morris Plains, N.J.
BRISTOL, Tenn., June 9-- Southern Presbyterians, confronted with a complex range of ecumenical impulses, named a supporter of church union today to their highest elected office.
The McDonnell Douglas Company has announced that Government certification of the DC-8 Super 63 jetliner for commercial service is expected next month.
The Interstate Commerce Commission will announce Monday afternoon its decision in two cases having a direct effect on the merger plans of the Pennsylvania and New York Central railroads.

TEL AVIV, June 9 (AP)-- The Arab mayor of Hebron, which was captured from Jordan on Wednesday, sipped Turkish coffee with Israeli newsmen today and said that he had considered it "madness" when King Hussein of Jordan flew to Cairo to seek a defense treaty with President Gamal Abdel Nasser.

WASHINGTON, June 9-- Opposing viewpoints on the desirability of making changes in the Interstate Commerce Act of 1942 were presented today at a Senate hearing. The proposed changes involve through and joint rates, along with the revocation procedures for certificated motor carriers.

WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) --The Commerce Department imposed restrictions on the export of nickel because of tight supplies today, and scheduled a meeting for Wednesday with industry representatives to discuss the matter.

Israel's seizure of Syrian territory north of the Sea of Galilee provides an opportunity to neutralize her most troublesome border and safeguard the headwaters of the Jordan River, on which her development depends.

ST. LOUIS, June 9 (AP)-- The Food and Drug Administration said today a Missouri company was recalling a million frozen coconut cream pies because of possible Salmonella contamination capable of causing intestinal and other disorders.

DETROIT, June 9--Striking firm workers along the Rio Grande Valley of Texas have been beaten and terrorized by the Texas Rangers, Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Automobile Workers, charged today.

PARIS, June 9--President do Gaulle was reported today to have barred state payment for contraceptives on the ground that they were used for pleasure, not health.

STAMFORD, Conn., June 9 --Intrepid sailed to a second victory over American Eagle today to complete the most successful record in the America's Cup preliminary trials that ended today. The time between them was 5 minutes 34 seconds, which represented a large amount of water in 10-to-12mile west-southwest winds.

WASHINGTON, June 9-- Pentagon officials disclosed today that a board of inquiry had been ordered to investigate the circumstances surrounding an air-sea attack yesterday on a United States Navy communications ship in international waters off Egypt's Sinai coast.
WASHINGTON, June 9--For the first time in at least three years, the United States had no major gold transactions with foreign countries in the first quarter of this year.

TOKYO, June 9 (AP)--Taro Yamashita, president of the Arabian Oil Company, the first Japanese organization to produce oil in the Middle East, died of a heart ailment at his home here today. He was 78 years old.
LAKE PLACID, N.Y., June 9--The frequently heard lament that the United States has not been represented adequately in international skiing's policymaking seems to be no longer valid.

POCANTICO HILLS, N.Y., June 9--Governor and Mrs. Rockefeller had a private dinner dance for 400 friends here tonight. It was the first large personal party the couple have had since their marriage in 1963. It was also a birthday party without billing. The hostess, well able to buy her own baubles, did not embarrass her guests by advance notice that they would be helping to celebrate her 41st birthday.

WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) --The General Services Administration announced today a change in its rubber disposal program. The G.S.A. said it would limit sale from Government stockpiles to 70,000 long tons a year or the actual Government use of rubber, whichever is higher. Curently, the Government offers stockpile sales of 120,000 long tons a year.
Sixten commissioners and top officials of the Lindsay administration developed plans yesterday to form an unofficial, nonpartisan and nonsectarian group to assist the United Jewish Appeal for Israel.
BETHLEHEM, Jordan, June 9--In the sun-baked square behind the Church of the Nativity, Israeli soldiers with submachine guns lounged in the shade beneath a tattered awning.

PHILADELPHIA, June 9 (UPII)--Agents of the Federal Food and Drug Administration are guarding the home and office of Daniel J. Addario, chief of the agency's drug abuse control section here.

NAHA, Okinawa--With three television stations and a continuous traffic jam along the dark ribbon of Highway 1, Okinawa bears scant resemblance to the quaint, semitropical island pictured in the hit play and movie of a number of years ago called "The Teahouse of the August Moon." Marlon Brando.

Gary Peters, a left-hander, hit a home run and pitched a four-hitter as the Chicago White Sox routed the Yankees, 9-0, yesterday at Yankee Stadium. It was Peters's sixth consecutive victory over the Yankees since Sept. 10, 1985. Don Buford also contributed a home run to the White Sox attack on three Yankee pitchers. Thad Tillotson took the loss, his first in the major leagues.
The Architects Council of New York City asked the Federal Government yesterday to "help avert a planning diaster" in the construction of a Civic Center near City Hall.

LENINGRAD Throughout the centuries when modern civilization was slowly emerging in the Middle East and spreading into Europe and Asia there was always the threat of invasion by "barbarians" from the north. These invaders came from the forests and steppes in the heartland of Eurasia, periodically sweeping away empires that had grown weak and vulnerable.

WASHINGTON, June 10 There is no special anxiety here over the angry and threatening statements that have come from Moscow in the last two days. United States officials consider most of the statements last-minute efforts to cover up and recoup the losses suffered by Soviet diplomacy in the Middle East this week.

SUNBURY, Pa., June 10 Mr. and Mrs. Sigfried Weis have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Anne Weis, to Dr. Joel Sidney Mindel. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Meyer Mindel of Pikesville, Md.

THE United States will issue a unique set of postage stamps on September 29, when twin adhesives will commemorate American efforts in space. A single horizontal design, depicting an astronaut during a space walk, will spread over the width of two normal size stamps.

THIS year the United States Christmas stamp will present a familiar and popular design the "Madonna and Child With Angels" by Hans Memling, the 15th century Flemish artist. The painting hangs in the National Gallery of Art in Washington. It was used for the 1966 Christmas stamp, but this year's edition will be almost twice the size of last year's issue, and it will show more of the original painting.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., June 10 The public got its first guided tour today of the Patriot's Path, a proposed 10-milelong strip of park along the winding Whippany River in Morris County.

AMHERST, Mass. The Quabbin Reservoir near here was built to supply water to the city of Boston. Over the years, however, it has grown into one of the major centers of outdoor recreation in New England. It offers fine fishing, a beautiful place to picnic, a haven for bird-watchers and magnificent scenery. But it was not always so.
Teachers at two Brooklyn schools have come to the defense of their principals against charges made by the Brooklyn Congress of Racial Equality.

THIS season, as last, Moscow's most avantgards and fashionable theater is a little, outof-the-way establishment on dusty Taganka Square. Swarms of petitioners appealing for extra tickets line the way from the square's metro station to the theater entrance every evening. How the Theater of Drama and Comedy achieved this remarkable success virtually overnight is the talk of the city's intelligentsia.

ORLEANS, France The Loire Valley is famous for its magnificent chateaux, but the French esteem it for still another reason. For centuries, they have called it the "garden of France" and have written a good many words about la douceur de vivre (the sweetness of living) here. In fact, valley people take the garden concept so seriously that towns and villages vie to grow the most beautiful flowers.
ANCHORAGE, June 10--Stewart L. Udall, Secretary of the Interior, is caught in a controversy that has spread from Alaska's southeastern panhandle and the Aleutian Islands north to the Arctic.

AFTER years in the wilderness, Paul Goodman has recently emerged as a major prophet. He is one of the very few of his generation (C. Wright Mills is another) whose experience the radical young consider relevant, whose integrity they trust, whose sympathy they value.

Adebo, Nigeria's respected delegate to the United Nations, wrote an article for this Magazine in which he rightly protested that too many Westerners think of "tribal" as the same as "primitive, when in fact "tribe" really means "ethnic group." OAKDALE, L.I., June 10 Degrees were awarded to 183 graduating students at Adelphi Suffolk college this morning at the institution's fifth commencement.

MYSTIC, Conn., June 10 Butterfly, skippered by John Spear Jr. sailed to a first-place finish today following a second place yesterday to win in Class A-1 at the 30th annual spring Off Soundings series.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., June 10 Steve Andrews's Gigi III led Bucky Moore's Mavoureen by three boot lengths today for Star Class honors as 23 boats sailed in the second of four Saturday regattas conducted by the Bay Club on Huntington Bay.
WASHINGTON, June 10 The Government declared an oil emergency today because of the Middle East crisis.
MIAMI BEACH Few people would attempt to walk the length of Miami Beach, but one can obtain a representative sample of this resort city by taking a short walking tour through a midtown section.

ALBANY, June 10 The payroll for the staff of the State Constitutional Convention has passed the $2-million mark and includes the names of at least seven former legislators and one former Representative.

Nearly $90,000 has been contributed toward the 1967 goal of $625,000 established by the Fresh Air Fund to provide vacations for needy youngsters away from the hot streets of the city.

TEANECK, N.J. June 10 Kenneth Todd Young, former United States Ambassador to Thailand, said today that this country should revise its approaches to Asia where "we all too often impose on them our particularity American notions and techniques."
WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) Mae Oliver, a former official of the Democratic National Committee, died at George Washington University hospital here today. She was 58 years old.

The 14th annual art auction for the benefit of the United Jewish Appeal will be held tomorrow at 8 P.M. at the ParkeBernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue. The yearly auction of donated paintings, sculpture, furniture, jewels and other precious objects is one of the projects of U.J.A.'s Women's Division, Exhibition, which opened last week, will continue tomorrow from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M.
YAMAGATA, Japan, June 10 Japanese tend to evaluate world events largely from the viewpoint of their effect on relations between Japan and the United States.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., June 10 Miss Elizabeth Julia Bissinger, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick L. Bissinger of Bronxville and Little Compton, R.I., was married here today in St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church to Dr. Nicholas J. Vianna. He is the son of Mrs. Nicholas L. Vianna of New York and the late Mr. Vianna. The Rev. Mark P. Geary performed the ceremony.

Two movements got under way last week aimed at giving the Catholic layman a more influential voice in the church. One action was official, the other unofficial.
Mayor Lindsay spent a few hours on hot sidewalks of Manhattan and the Bronx yesterday, taking the pulse of the city. He found it had its usual strong and exciting beat.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sunday, June 11 Syria and Israel have accepted United Nations arrangements for a ceasefire, but a heated Security Council debate over alleged truce violations continued into this morning.

A week ago, Woman's Day Encyclopedia of Cookery finished up the newspaper, television and radio promotion that began on March 20 to push volume one of the set of 12 off the shelves of 3,100 Midwest supermarkets.

EIGHTEEN months ago Sir Harold Nicolson's health collapsed completely, and he lives now, oblivious of the world which once entranced him, at Sissinghurst Castle, in Kent. The castle, with the garden that Nicolson planned in every classical detail, belonged formerly to his wife, the poet and novelist, Victoria Sackville-West, who died in 1962; and it was presented recently to the National Trust.

There is more to sour cream than something to dollop on borscht, more to yogurt than something to spoon from a cup. Both can be used to give admirable flavor and caste to the exceptional coffeecakes on this page.

THERE has been a notable shortage or shrinkage of Wasp novels lately. You still get the neutral ones which are white-Protestant by default, but few novels soaked to the marrow in white-Protestant culture; novels crawling and pungent like the work of Malamud or Baldwin, as opposed to odor-free and sclerotic novels by O'Hara and Auchincloss.
MIAMI, June 10 A drought that has parched Everglades National Park for about three months ended last week, but its effect on the park's rare tropical wildlife will be felt for years to come.

WAUWATOSA, Wis., June 10 Gov. George Romney of Michigan opened his unannounced campaign for the Republican Presidential nomination in the key primary state of Wisconsin today with a declaration that his most successful approach was likely to be a direct appeal to the voter.

THE objet trouv , that rogue of 20th-century art, is now crashing literature under the name "Found Poetry." On the B.B.C's Third Program, John Daniel has been reading poems he found in the London telephone directory, his insurance policy, a cookbook, "Das Kapital," and his grandfather's World War I diary.

Pearson, friends of Mrs. Lee George Sanella of Warwick Neck, gave a party and reception today at the Rhode Island Country Club to announce the engagement of Mrs. Sannella's daugher, Miss Frances Lee Sannella, to Bradford Allen Rochester.
Dr. Lowell B. Eckerson, a retired specialist in internal medicine, died Thursday in RiverHe was 76 years old and lived at 50 West Front Street, Red view Hospital, Red Bank, N.J. Bank.

THIS year 350,000 Americans one out of five who travel to Europe will go with Arthur Frommer. They will eat with Arthur Frommer and, as something of a witticism has it, sleep with Arthur Frommer.
SCARSDALE, N.Y., June 10 Mr. and Mrs. John R. Spiegel have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Linda Carol Spiegel, to Bernard Holzman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Holzman of Brooklyn.

The Social Service Employes Union threatened yesterday to stage a sit-in work stoppage on June 19 at various welfare centers if the city did not agree before next Thursday to arbitrate unresolved contract issues. Mrs. Judith Mage, president of the union, said the 6,300 caseworkers, home economists and children's counselors would stage a "work-in" at the 32 welfare centers, children's shelters and other facilities.

HADDAM, Conn. On the banks of the Connecticut River near here is an $88million nuclear power plant that will soon begin producing vast amounts of electricity. A special feature of the installation has already generated a substantial amount of tourist interest. Since the plant's Education and Information Center was opened last fall, more than 15,000 visitors have trooped past a variety of push-button displays that illustrate the conversion of nuclear energy into electric power.
The Boy Scouts got a merit badge and the beatniks a demerit from Robert Moses yesterday.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 10 (AP) Dr. Laura H. Zirbes, an educator in child psychology and former professor of education at Ohio State University, died yesterday in her home here. She was 83 years old.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 10 Navy planes from the carrier Bon Homme Richard today bombed North Vietnam's most important electric power plant, which is only 1.1 miles from the center of Hanoi.

MANCHESTER, Mass., June 10 The Emmanuel Episcopal Church was the scene today of the wedding of Mrs. Suzanne C. Herter of Cambridge, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Edward Decatur Clery of East Orange, N.J., and Plandome, L.I., to Richard F. Treadway of Boston. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. C. Rollin Fairbanks.

BOSTON, June 10 (AP) Frank Howard hammered his 13th and 14th homers for three runs and Camilo Pascual and Dave Baldwin combined for a six-hitter as the Washington Senators beat the Boston Red Sox, 7-3, today in 95-degree heat.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, June 10 (Reuters) Troops of the United Nations Emergency Force that had been withdrawn from the Middle East arrived in Famagusta today aboard a Swedish freighter.

THE Tri-River Rally, the fourth national Sports Car Club of America event of 1967, produced a close finish over the last weekend, only 14 points separating the first two teams after two days and 500 miles through southwestern Pennsylvania's coal-mining region and the tourist area of the Laurel Highlands.

IT IS the contention of Ben Green that, from the start, he never considered the horseand-mule business a real business. He claims that he always looked on the profession as some incurable disease a man had to learn to live with.

JERUSALEM, June 10 (Reuters) Thousands of Israelis made pilgrimages today to the holy places of old Jerusalem or strolled in streets that had been closed to them for 19 years.

STROUDSBURG, Pa. In this area of golf, boating, fishing, and sun-worshiping, resort owners have spent $6-million on improvements since last summer. Most of it, according to the Pocono Mountain Vacation Bureau, has nothing to do with fresh air. This summer the Poconos are pushing floor shows.

The state of Connecticut has warned the Interstate Commerce Commission that the "specter of liquidation" is hanging over the New Haven Railroad if it is kept waiting very long to join the pending PennsylvaniaNew York Central merger. It would be disastrous to the economy of southern New England and a serious blow to the national transportation system if this should happen.
DETROIT, June 10 Detroit's automobile makers are gingerly polishing their crystal balls to see if the future holds anything but four wheels and freeways.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., June 10 Cornelius (Glit) Shields Jr.'s Aileen won International Class honors today by overtaking Phil Dollin's Mabel on the final leg as 145 boats sailed with the Beach Point Yacht Club in the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound West-of-Rye Regatta.

BASSETERRE, St. Kitts, June 10 (Reuters) Gunmen attacked police headquarters here before dawn today with small-arms fire 11 days after Premier Robert Bradshaw's Government had proclaimed a state of emergency.

Furl Sail flew to victory in the $97,800 Mother Goose Stakes at Aqueduct yesterday, as an- ticipated by a great many in the crowd of 44,769. Mrs. Edwin K. Thomas's brilliant racer led all the way in the 1 1/8-mile event for 3-year-old fillies to score by three lengths, in the excellent time of 1:49 3/5.

LIME ROCK, Conn., June 10 Seventy-five cars competed here today in a race meeting conducted by a comparatively new group called the International Conference of Sports Car Clubs. The group is made up of private sports car organizations operating mainly in the northeastern and Pacific Coast states.

BARCELONA. SPAIN is currently going through a wave of ostensible liberalization: last year's press law abolishing censorship, the recent New Constitution referendum, and now the proposed Religious Freedom law. But all this is more apparent than real. Though some advances have been made, in other respects things are worse, as the regime has clamped down forcefully on anyone taking these measures too literally. One aspect of Spain's culture now feeling this pressure is art.

MIAMI The English meaning of the word Seminole is "the wild one." The translation is quite appropriate, for the Seminoles are among the last of the American Indians to yield to the ways of the white than. COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 10 (AP) Russell Knipp, 24 years old, a 164-pounder from Pittsburgh, won the middleweight division of the senior national Amateur Athletic Union weightlifting championship today, setting three national records in a total lift in three categories of 955 pounds.
BOWLING GREEN, an A division team, captured the 1967 Commercial League Championship by winning nine matches and drawing one. The runner-up was the Alumni team.

MOUNTAIN LAKES, N.J., June 10. Mr. and Mrs. Joseph William Mollek Jr. of Mountain Lakes and Deer Isle, Me., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Ann Mollek, to Patrick Moran Tynan, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Joseph Tynan of Yonkers and West Dennis, Mass.

WASHINGTON, June 10 Ernest Schein, a lawyer who specialized in private administrative practice and in foreign claims actions before Federal agencies and the Court of Claims, died today in George Washington University Hospital after a brief illness. He was 67 years old and lived here.

WORCESTER, Mass., June 10 Winning one race with a borrowed shell, the Vesper Boat Club of Philadelphia also captured the senior eight-oared shell event with its retrieved shell today in the American Henley regatta.

CONCORD, N.H. In 1966, the New Hampshire Commission on the Arts received a $25,000 grant from the Federally sponsored National Endowment for the Arts. This grant has been used to conduct a thorough study of New Hampshire's cultural resources and their relation to the state's population and economy.
RICHMOND, June 10 Mr. and Mrs. Edmund W. Lee have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dorinne Lee, to Nicholas Bayard Mason, son of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Mason of West Hartford, Conn.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., June 10 (UPI) The World Boxing Association rejected today a reinstatement appeal by the deposed heavyweight champion, Cassius Clay, and named eight fighters to compete in a tournament to determine his successor.

OLD GREENWICH, Conn., June 10 Mr. and Mrs. George H. Brown have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Peggy Hardin Brown, to Phillip Waite Estes, son of Mr. and Mrs. Allen C. Estes of Portland, Me. An August wedding is planned.

THERE is a general feeling that you really cannot re habilitate confirmed criminals, that most of them continue their unlawful ways after release from jail and are soon back behind bars. Certainly their rate of recidivism, as with narcotic addicts, is great. And this despite the efforts of sociologists, educators and penologists operating within the prisons and outside.

ELLENVILLE, N.Y. Getting to Sam's Point has always been easy, even when Sam himself fled there to escape the Indians. Less than a mile from the point are the ice caves, but until now the route could not be walked; it had to be mountainclimbed.

A mocking joke made the rounds of Cairo's foreign community last Friday. Field Marshal Abdel Hakim Amer, deputy supreme commander of the United Arab Republic's armed forces, met President Gamal Abdel Nasser, according to the story, on the way to the mosque. An old friend of Mr. Nasser's, Marshal Amer is supposed to have said, "Well, Gamal, you can't win them all."

HOLLYWOOD, June 10--Spencer Tracy, whose calm manner and rough-hewn face symbolized the justice-driven American man of action in scores of movies, died of a heart attack today in his Beverly Hills home. His age was 67.

FALL RIVER, Mass. The battleship Massachusetts came ashore here in the summer of 1965 to serve out the final chapter of an historic career as the Bay State's memorial to the dead of World War II. TEL AVIV, June 10 A Government official said today that if Israel were to assimilate the million Arabs who came under her rule with the conquest of the Gaza Strip and the western part of Jordan there might be an Arab majority in Israel by the first decade of the next century.
ST. LOUIS, June 10 (AP) Roger Maris hit a three-run homer in the 11th inning to give the St. Louis Cardinals a 5-2 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers tonight.
WEST HARTFORD, Conn., June 10 Miss Nancy Bowman Bland, daughter of Mr. and Miss. Herbert Remington Bland, was married here today to Horace William Baden Donegan 2d.

RIVER VALE, N.J., June 10 More than 1,000 persons attended the dedication today of the Lake Tappan dam, a 4-million-gallon reservoir built by the Hackensack Water Company.

The growth of the nation's air cargo business and the interchange of cargoes between the aviation and trucking industries may be deterred by insufficient or inadequate ground handling facilities, an Interstate Commerce Commission study warned last week.
BRIDGETON, N.J., June 10 Union officials disclosed today that organized labor had abandoned its drive to sign up Negro migrant farm workers in New Jersey this summer.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., June 10 Two members of this city's Human Relations Commission have touched off a controversy by posing as prospective employers who would not take Negro help.

OLD WESTBURY, L. I., June 10--Aires, owned and ridden by Danny Lopez--who still is looking for a mount to replace his two-time national jumper champion, Australis--won the green working hunter championship today at the 35th annual Helping Hand horse show.

BOSTON, June 10 (AP) Richmond Grays, 12 lengths off the pace in the early going, charged through the stretch to win the $15,000 Macomber Memorial Handicap by half a length from the favored Actor II at Suffolk Downs today.

YONKERS, June 10 Tom Gage, one of the few hammer throwers in Montana; Milt Sonsky of the Bruce Track Club, and Brian Kivlan, a Manhattan College sophomore, set meet records today in the 77th annual Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union senior track and field championships.

Senator and Mrs. Robert F. Kennedy are honorary chairmen for a benefit party opening the Electric Circus at 23 St. Mark's Place on June 27. Proceeds will go to the Children's Recreation Foundation, which the Senator helped to found last year.
WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) The nation's most powerful single rocket motor is to be test fired near Homestead, Fla., June 17.

ATLANTA, June 10 (AP) Home runs by Willie McCovey, Tom Haller and Jim Hart powered the San Francisco Giants to a 7-4 victory over the Atlanta Braves tonight. The Braves' winning streak was snapped at four games.

IN JUNIOR HIGH The Family Living program of Evanston's District 65 continues into junior high school seventh and eighth grades where the approach is, of course, more sophisticated and more detailed, for the students are now concerned with the physical changes in their own bodies and take a more subjective attitude than the fifth-graders.

AKRON, Ohio, June 10 The United Rubber Workers Union rejected offers made this week by tire companies. Three of five major tire companies have been struck for seven weeks with 52,000 workers made idle.

KINDERHOOK, N.Y., June 10 In St. Paul's Episcopal Church here at noon today, Miss Mary Worrall Tattle, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Franklin Benjamin Tuttle of Brooklyn, New York, and Kinderhook, became the bride of Norwig Rud Gerhard Debye. He is the son of Mrs. Mayon Debye of Ithaca.

WASHINGTON, June 10 The Israelis are now very popular in Washington. They had the courage of our convictions, and they won the war we opposed. Everybody here, however, is so pleased with the re-enactment of the David and Goliath story which, incidentally, took place on the very spot where the little guy slew the giant that the causes of the conflict are in danger of being lost.

In this slim, closely reasoned book, Howard Zinn of Boston University escalates his thought from an analysis of foreign criticism and interior disillusion with the United States' war in Vietnam to the conclusion that "the sanity of unilateral withdrawal is that it makes the end of the war independent of anyone's consent but our own. It is cleancut, it is swift, it is right."

WASHINGTON, June 12 (UPI)--The Defense Department disclosed today the names of 84 United States servicemen who were killed in the war in Vietnam.
William B. Cash, executive vice president and a director of the Keebler Company, the biscuit maker, said yesterday he had resigned from both posts, effective Friday.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 12 (AP)--A woman terrorist shot to death a United States Army officer on a street in Saigon today.

Iroquois Industries, Inc., in an effort to diversify further its activities, made a tender offer yesterday to buy about 44 per cent of the stock of the Syracuse China Company, a maker of chinaware.

ABOARD THE U.S.S. AMERICA, in the Eastern Mediterranean, June 12--Capt. Donald D. Engen, the captain of this aircraft carrier, told his crew today that the Arab-Israeli war appeared to be ending with the establishment of a cease-fire between Israel and Syria and that the carrier was thus "getting back to ils nomnal schedule" of air-training exercises.

Superintendent of Schools Bernard E. Donovan confirmed yesterday that he had offered to raise the minimum salary for beginning teachers in September to $6,000. The offer is $600 above the present minimum.
Steel production fell 1.3 per cent last week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, June 12--An action for defamation against Jack Howman, Minister of Information, began in the High Court here today. He is being sued by the company owning both Rhodesia's daily newspapers, and by their editors. Damages totaling $16,800 are claimed.

PITTSBURGH, June 12-- Thc Crucible Steel Company will ask the Illinois Supreme Court for permission to hold a special meeting, where stockholders would be asked to approve the issuing of additional stock to raise money for capital expansion, the concern announced here today.
WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP)--A consultant to the President's crime commission suggested today that even moderate drinkers might turn to potent drugs if sources of alcoholic beverages were shut off.

ALTENBERG, Germany, June 12--Gypies of Western Europe gathered in this quiet village in the hills east of Cologne today in the opening of a five-day meeting.

MIDDLEBURY, Vt., June 12 --One of President Johnson's chief foreign policy advisers warned today that the solution of the Middle East's "multiple splits and quarrels" lay in regional economic cooperation.

MOSCOW, June 12--A Soviet economist, criticizing a concentration of production in huge, state-owned factories, has urged a reform permitting the organization of small, worker-managed and profit-sharing subsidiary enterprises.

LUXEMBOURG, June 12-- Manlio Brosio, secretary general of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, said today the "adventurous and risky" Soviet foreign policy in the Middle East showed how difficult it was to procede with an East-West realization.

GENEVA, June 12--Laurence Michelmore, commissioner general of the United Nations Relief and Works Agency, today asked his Geneva office to send antibiotic drugs, bandages and other medical supplies to the Middle East on an emergency basis.

Sidney Poltier will make his Broadway directorial debut with "Carry Me Back to Morningside Heights." He will not appear in Robert Alan Aurthur's comedy, to be presented by Saint Subber.
FORT MEADE, Md., June 12 (AP)--Donald Hudson, who flew combat planes during World War I, died of a stroke yesterday at Kimbrough Army Hospital here. He was 71 years old.
Regular deposits in the nation's mutual savings banks registered a record increase in May for the sixth consecutive month, the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 12--A New Mexico poverty official told a Congressional hearing today that no Federal antipoverty money had been used to support the Mexican-American rebels who have been seeking to establish "free city states" in northern New Mexico.
Negotiators for The Daily News and the Newspaper Guild of New York resumed bargaining yesterday in an effort to speed a contract settlement.
KEARNY, N.J., June 12-- Dr. Hal German of Jersey City was extended today before advancing to the fourth round of the New Jersey State men's tennis championship at the Arlington Players Club.
A new Presidential "trial heat" shows further evidence that Republican "fears of a third party bid by George Wallace are well-founded," Dr. George Gallup said yesterday in The Washington Post.

Buckpasser, who, in the words of Tommy Trotter, "seems like the best around since Kelso," has been assigned the dramatically high impost of 135 pounds for the Bowling Green Handicap at Aqueduct on Saturday.
WASHINGTON, June 12--The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether states could enforce more stringent obscenity standards on material sold to children than on publications sold to adults.
HOUSTON, June 12 (UPI)-- Jim Wynn's three-run, two-out homer capped a four-run eighth inning tonight that sent the Houston Astros to a 5-2 victory over the San Francisco Giants.
NEWARK, June 12--A remark by a white man touched off a near fight between whites and Negroes at a hearing in City Hall tonight on the selection of a site for a medical college.

WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP)--President Johnson announced today that James P. Grant, director of the Agency for International Development mission in Turkey, would be nominated to be assistant administrator of the agency in charge of operations in Vietnam.

The S.S. Pierce Company, venerable Boston purveyor of groceries, is about to come under new ownership and the tutelage of a member organization of the New York Stock Exchange.
WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP)--Justice Tom C. Clark retired from the Supreme Court at the close of its 196667 term today. He described the occasion as "not a sad day, but a happy one."

WASHINGTON, June 12-- The Supreme Court, in two separate decisions, spelled out in some further detail today the limitations imposed by the Sherman Act on restrictive territorial arrangements and other restraints placed on the activities of dealers licensed by manufacturers.

ATHENS, June 12--After a week of uncertainty in the United Arab Republic and an uncomfortable 46-hour voyage from Alexandria, 556 Americans landed safely today in Keratsini, a military harbor near Athens.

A three-day national conference on the arts and the small community will be held at Madison, Wis., starting June 28, under the auspices of the University of Wisconsin.

MOSCOW, June 12--President Houari Boumediene of Algeria flew to the Soviet Union today.

LONDON, June 12 (AP)-- The United States Navy convened a court of inquiry today to investigate the attack on the American communications ship Liberty by Israeli planes in the eastern Mediterranean last Thursday.

LUSAKA, Zambia, June 12-- Zambian copper production is back at full capacity, a spokesman for the country's two mining groups, Anglo-American and Roan Selection Trust, announced here today.

Nickel beer, nickel hot dogs and nickel ice cream will be sold in Central Park a week from tomorrow night. The first day of summer will be welcomed with a mammoth costume party on the Central Park Mall.
