NEWARK, June 12--The proprietors of an alleged "house of torture" went on trial today on charges of conspiracy, lewdness and maintaining premises for lewdness and assignation.

Joe Yancey, the coach of the New York Pioneer Club, has been named the head track and field coach of the New York entry in the United States Youth Games that are scheduled here Aug. 17 through Aug. 20. The announcement was made yesterday by Mayor John V. Lindsay.
WAYZATA, Minn., June 12 --Lieut. (jg.) Judith Ann Helmstetter, Navy Nurse Corps, and Capt. David Todd Warden, U.S.M.C., plan to be married Aug. 26 in Sandwich, Mass.
THE General Presbyter of the New York City Pres bytery is officially defined as its chief executive officer. But unofficially, among members of the presbytery, he is called the pastor to pastors.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., June 12 (UPI)--Rich Rollins's grandslam homer marked an eightrun third inning for the Minnesota Twins tonight as they registered an 11-5 victory over the Detroit Tigers.
Herman M. Silverstein has been elected chairman of the board of Mid-American National Bank of Chicago, Gerard C. Specht has been elected vice president.
WASHINGTON, June 12-- The Johnson Administration is studying proposals that could result in a sharp escalation of the war in Vietnam.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 12--Arabs rejected today the call by Premier Levi Eshkol of Israel for bilateral negotiations outside the United Nations to arrange peace settlements.

The engagement of Miss Linda Jo Karmiohl to Arthur H. Sommer, son of Mrs. Martin Sommer of Flushing, Queens, and the late Mr. Sommer, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Arthur L. Karmiohl of Jamaica Estates, Queens.

WASHINGTON, Tuesday. June 13 (AP)--Paul Casanova's bases-loaded single in the 22d inning gave the Washington Senators a 6-5 victory over the Chicago White Sox this morning in the longest night-game in baseball history.

YONKERS, June 12--Romeo Hanover will not be a starter in next Thursday night's $50,000 National Championship Pace at Yonkers Raceway. Nor will True Duane, Overall and Nelson Guy be behind the mobile gate, as the field gets under way for the third and final race in the $200,000 international pacing series.
The United Jewish Appeal continued yesterday to receive heavy contributions, including large gifts from non-Jews, to carry out its humanitarian servives to 500,000 needy immigrants in Israel.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 12--The last week's marathon sessions of the Security Council have been trying for diplomats and bartenders. But the bartenders are paid overtime and the diplomats are not.

WASHINGTON, Tuesday. June 13 (AP)--Paul Casanova's bases-loaded single in the 22d inning gave the Washington Senators a 6-5 victory over the Chicago White Sox this morning in the longest night-game in baseball history.

HONG KONG, June 12--Local communists have called for a strike by all distributors and retailers of food supplies on Hong Kong Island tomorrow as part of a protest campaign against the British authorities here.

Helen Hall, the daughter of a Westchester manufacturer who has spent nearly half her lifetime climbing the dark stairways of swarming tenements on the Lower East Side, will retire, June 30 as director of the Henry Street Settlement.
LAGOS, June 12 (UPI)--The Government denied today radio reports from the Eastern Region that civil war had already begun.

Despite their indignant concern for social betterment, the young people of today will probably follow their elders' lead and trail off "into the apathy and disinterest of the young executive or professional," the graduating class of Yeshiva University was told yesterday.

President Nasser's plan to attend an Arab summit conference is apparently aimed at maintenance of the oil embargo declared when hostilities began. But it will not be easy to accomplish. Egypt, which has relatively little oil, and Syria and Jordan, which have none, ...
George Bernstein, an insurance broker at 100 William Street, died of a heart attack yesterday in his home at 305 East 24th Street. He was 70 years old.
International ship operators proceeded on the assumption yesterday that the Suez Canal would remain closed for some time as the result of the sinking of some shipping in the 103mile waterway.

DESIGNERS had fun with hemlines yesterday, but they made it clear that they were playing games. Take them or leave them, they seemed to be saying, but don't get too worked up about them. There's something for everybody, and if you're satisfied with the status quo, that's all right with us.

Litton Industries, Inc., from its headquarters in Beverly Hills, Calif., issued a statement yesterday denying that its decision to take part in an $830-million project to develop gypsum on the Greek island of Crete involved the discovery of new deposits of the mineral. It also declined to estimate the size of the gypsum deposits on Crete.
Robert Lowell, the poet, yesterday explained his reason for declining to sign a public appeal to President Johnson to support Israel in its recent war with the Arab nations.
WASHINGTON, June 13 (UPI) President Johnson talked hippie language tonight to a gathering of brainy teenagers. He told them they did not frighten him a bit.

Heavier-than-expected stocks in storage sent pork belly prices sharply lower yesterday. In fact, the July delivery slid the 150-point daily permissible limit and closed at that level 40.02 cents a pound in active volume of 1,927 contracts.

UNLESS the historians have been derelict in their duties, Sam Mele is the only manager who ever had his salary slashed by the club owner because of a disappointing team drop in the standings. That alone should demonstrate the singular lack of esteem in which Sad Sam was regarded by Calvin Griffith, the proprietor of the Minnesota Twins. It was as humiliating a move as could be devised.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, June 13 (AP) Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the Cambodian chief of state, said today that his Government was establishing diplomatic relations with North Vietnam and would exchange ambassadors.

TRENTON, June 13--The NAACP Legal Defense Fund, Inc., disclosed today that it would ask the Federal courts to knock down the no trespassing signs that are rising by the thousands around migrant labor camps on New Jersey farms.
DETROIT, June 13 New-car dealers sold 247,989 Americanmade cars in the first third of June, up 4 per cent from 238,864 in car sales a year earlier, the four major automobile companies have reported.

Dr. William M. Birenbaum, whose ouster as provost of the Brooklyn Center of Long Island University provoked a student strike this spring, has quietly left the university after having completed a course he was teaching on the Federalist Papers.

Dr. and Mrs. David Schwartz of 531 East 20th Street have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marilyn Karen Schwartz, to Barry David Wessler, son of Dr. and Mrs. Jack. Wessler, also of this city.
King Phumiphol Aduldet of Thailand said yesterday that the efforts of American soldiers in Vietnam were being undermined by antiwar activity at home and by what he called "a war of brainwashing."

TAMPA, June 13 National Guardsmen moved into a riotscarred Negro district again tonight to disperse rock-throwing teen-agers but withdrew after Negro leaders promised they could restore peace to the area.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 13--The Soviet Government asked today for an emergency session of the General Assembly to enforce the withdrawal of Israeli forces from the Arab states.

The notion that tax increases are needed to restrain a resurgent and inflationary economy is winning fresh support even though symptoms of a new inflationary upsurge or of a dramatic snapback in activity are conspicuously absent.
LONDON, June 13--Prime Minister Wilson confirmed today that Britain had decided against buying the Poseidon missile from the United States.

NASHVILLE, June 13 Mrs. Vance Walker Noel and Hayes Acklen Noel have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Vance Noel of New York, to Peter Matthiessen Duggan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen P. Duggan of New York and Cornwall, N.Y.

The Bristol-Myers Company, a leading domestic producer of proprietary drugs, toiletries and allied products, expects its earnings for the first half of this year to increase about 17 per cent over results for the period last year.

PARIS, June 13 The weekly newspaper Le Nouvel Observateur quoted a Soviet official today as having said that his government told President Gamel Abdel Nasser at the outset of the current conflict in the Middle East that it would protect him only against American intervention and not against the Israelis.
Womens Wear Daily, has accused the producer of the Chicago production of "The Philadelphia Story," in which Princess Lee Radzlwill will make her stage debut, of barring its drama critic.
SCARSDALE, N.Y., June 13 Dick Siderowf of the Birchwood Country Club of Westport, Conn., won the William Rice Hochster Memorlal golf tournament today over the Quaker Ride Golf Club course.

BOSTON, June 13 There was nothing wrong with the New York Yankee bats tonight in Fenway Park. A 12-hit assault beat the Boston Red Sox, 5-3, in the concluding game of the two-game series and broke the Yankee losing streak of four games.
The election of Arnold M. Picker as chairman of the executive committee of the United Artists Corporation was announced here yesterday at the annual stockholder meeting.
As the jockey of the beaten favorite in yesterday's first race at Aqueduct weighed out, a disgruntled chalk-player yelled raucously, "Tony, you re a bum!"
CHICAGO, June 13 (AP) Ron Santo's ninth home run of the season in the sixth inning gave the Chicago Cubs a 3-2 victory today over Los Angeles. The loss was the eighth straight for the Dodgers.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., June 13 Stokely Carmichael was released from jail in nearby Prattville tonight and led Negroes here in cries of "black power" as they marched to within a block of the white-domed State Capitol.

The United States Lawn Tennis Association, officially opposed to open tennis tournaments through an iron-clad resolution adopted four years ago, appeared to have relaxed its viewpoint yesterday at a special meeting held at the Hotel Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) The Administration's proposal for trying to settle the railway labor-management dispute was cleared by the House Rules Committee today for what promises to be a sharp floor fight.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 13 Thomas F. McDevitt, a vice president of the Marine Midland Grace Trust Company of New York, died there yesterday of a heart attack. He was 64 years old and lived at 104 Lee Road here.
A historic postwar tragedy may be about to repeat itself in the Sinai desert unless the United Nations or some other agency quickly intervenes.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, June 13 (Reuters) Indian troops of the United Nations Emergency Force lost 14 men and 24 wounded from Israeli tank and artillery fire in Sinai last week, the commander, Col. M.S. Brar, said here today.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 13 (AP) A student with a remarkable reputation for scholastic, business and social achievement has been leading a double even triple life in which he simultaneously attended the Harvard Law School and the Sloan School of Management at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
Ticketing a woman's car can prove to be a biting experience, a 35-year-old meter maid discovered yesterday.

They bond market readily absorbed three large new corporate offerings yesterday, but the sales were accomplished by raising yields to investors. A fourth corporate sale, the only one awarded at competitive bidding, was reported to be moving slowly.
BONN, June 13 Following a month of deliberation, Chancellor Kurt Georg Kiesinger today replied to a letter on intra-German relations addressed to him by Premier Willi Stoph of East Germany.

The United Shoe Machinery Corporation showed its second successive quarterly decline in revenues and earnings in the first fiscal quarter ended May 31. The Boston-based company, however, has shown consistent increases in results for the last several years.

Unable to flex their minimuseles against a taller and heavier team, the New York Skyliners relied on the short, sudden attack and gained a 2-2 soccer tie with San Francisco at Yankee Stadium last night.
Lorin Maazel; Sixten Ehrling, Seiji Ozawa and Alfred Wallenstein will conduct the third summer series of New York Philharmonic concerts in city parks.
JERUSALEM, June 13 (UPI) The star of David was hoisted tonight over Gebel Musa, the traditional Mount Sinai, on the Jewish Pentecost for the first time.
The American Stock Exchange made it six in a row yesterday, staging a solid advance on increased volume.

RICHARD M. ELMAN first visited Compton, Calif.--a city of 75,000 that lies just south of Watts, about half way between downtown Los Angeles and Long Beach--during the 1964 election. He had been sent there by an educational TV station to prepare a script about the community, which had been picked as a typically Democratic town and was to be paired with a typically Republican town in a voting-analysis TV program.

HONG KONG, June 13 (Reuters)--Communist China today ordered two Indian diplomats to leave the country after a public trial in absentia before 15,000 people in a sports arena had found them guilty of espionage.
ELIZABETH, N.J., (AP) A Rahway Councilman was found guilty today of common law bribery, misconduct in office and obstructing justice for fixing a traffic summons.

WASHINGTON, June 13 Following are the texts of a statement President Johnson read today on the appointment of Thurgood Marshall as an Associate Justice of the Supreme Court and of a news conference that followed:

"A Survey of Russian Painting from the 15th Through the 20th Centuries," said to be the most complete survey of Russian art presented here since 1923, opens today at the Gallery of Modern Art on Columbus Circle.
Arnold Forster, general counsel of the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith, defended yesterday the league's new program of monitoring radio broadcasts to record anti-Jewish remarks.
WASHINGTON, June 13 (UPI) Tommy John's threehit pitching and a three-run homer by Ron Hansen paced the American League leading Chicago White Sox to a 6-0 victory over the Washington Senators tonight.

WASHINGTON, June 13 A Federal appeals court upheld today the constitutionality of Government requirements that radio and television stations give free time to those who wish to answer broadcast attacks on themselves or onesided presentations of public issues.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., June 13 (UPI) Kelso was an almost unanimous selection to join thoroughbred racing's Hall of Fame in the National Museum of Racing in this year's elections, John C. Clark, the selection committee chairman, announced today.
DETROIT, June 13 A militant Negro group charged to day that the Detroit school system failed to educate Negro youngsters.

Manhattan College returned to its native borough yesterday to hold its 116th annual commencement exercise in the grand ballroom of the Hilton Hotel. Since 1922 the school's commencements had been held at its present campus in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

Tom Seaver and Ron Swoboda gave the loyal followers of the New York Mets something to cheer about at Shea Stadium last night in the course of a 7-3 victory over the Cincinnati Reds in the second game of a double-header.

THE United States Auto Club's Championship divi sion, headed by A.J. Foyt, Joe Leonard, Mario Andretti, Al Unser, et al, will compete in two races this week-end, one at Mosport, near Bowmanville, Ont., the other at Langhorne, Pa.
PIERMONT, N.Y. Mr. and Mrs. Don Blauhut can scarcely resist improving things, First it was their house; now it's their town.
LISBON, June 13 Thousands of sentimental Portuguese turned out today for the biggest wedding of the year, in honor of Portugal's saint of sweethearts, Saint Anthony of Padua.

WASHINGTON, June 13 The reform-minded Supreme Court, running short of dragons to slay after years of activism, is turning increasingly to the politically hazardous business of liberalizing the rights of criminal suspects.

Three evenings of poetry readings by seven foreign and seven American poets will be held here in the next two weeks. The sponsors are the Lincoln Center Festival '67 and the Poetry Center of the 92d Street Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association.
The wholesale commodity price index fell to 98.8 on Monday from 99.2 on Friday.
WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) The Federal Trade Commission, by a 2 to 1 vote, issued a modified plan of divestiture today in a Beatrice Foods antimerger company proceeding originating 10 years ago.

Paperboard production rose 4.7 per cent with 471,200 tons, a new high, in the week ended June 10 from 450,000 tons in the corresponding 1966 week, the Paperboard Group of the American Paper Institute reported yesterday.
JERUSALEM, June 13 "We're in King Hussein's office," the Israeli military governor said. "Just six days ago the King was sitting in it. It's hard to believe."
WASHINGTON. June 13--A rapid test for detecting toxoplasmosis infection in newborn babies was described today at an international meeting on parasite diseases.
WASHINGTON, June 13 The Department of Housing and Urban Development announced today a grant of $22.6million to improve the service of the Long Island Rail Road.

LA JOLLA, Calif. Two California prison officials who were concerned about relations between the staff and inmates at the San Diego County jail recently brought their problem to Western Behavioral Sciences Institute in this nearby beach community.
The city school system appears to be adrift on a sea of indecision. Whatever policies may have been proclaimed, the current impression is that nobody is keeping the vessel moving on a charted course.

MOSCOW, June 13 Mstislav Rostropovich, the Soviet cellist, is booked to return to the United States for concerts next January, it was armounced today, but not under the management of his usual impresario, Sol Hurok.
OCEANPORT, N.J., June 13 (UPI) Swoonaway, owned by E. Gay Drake, scored a 4 length victory today in the $7,000 featured allowance race at Monmouth Park to record his first victory of the year.
Manhattan's Borough President, Percy E. Sutton, yesterday promised the Manhattan Community College his support for a high-rise center on the site of the old Washington Market in downtown Manhattan.
LEEDS, England, June 13 (Reuters) England beat India by six wickets in the first cricket test today with 2 hours to spare, but the Indians fought gamely to the end.

Without waiting to be sworn in as Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, Covey Thomas Oliver will be off to Chile next week for a regional meeting of the United Nations Economic and Social Council. He is right to get the earliest possible start in an office that has resembled a revolving door in the Kennedy and Johnson Administrations.
John Paul Getty moved yesterday to combine some of his worldwide oil interests into one large company.

STRATFORD, Ont., June 13 The extraordinarily hand some new mounting of "Richard III," which opened the Stratford Festival season yesterday, ends in a decidedly curious, and perhaps meaningful, bit of business. Richard, weary of slaughter and weary of himself and weary of doing desperate battle to remain himself, whips out his dagger on the field and tosses it to his unarmed opponent. He invites death.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., June 13 The State Assembly approved and sent to Gov. Ronald Reagan today a bill to liberalize California's abortion law.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 13--The General Assembly elected an acting commissioner and an 11-member council today to administer South-West Africa until it is ready for independence.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Wednesday, June 14 An unmanned American spacecraft rocketed into space early this morning to join a Soviet Union vehicle that was launched early Monday in a four-month race to Venus.

ALBANY, June 13 The Appellate Division unanimously upheld today a lower court dismissal of a suit by a Conservative-Republican candidate seeking his seat as a district delegate to the Constitutional Convention.

PARIS, June 13 At last weekend's auto race at Le Mans, L'Equipe had eight writers and three photographers. For last year's World Cup soccer championships it sent nine writers and three photographers. For next month's Tour de France bicycle race, it will use 100 full-time workers and spend almost $1-million.
Mayor Lindsay's panel on school decentralization decided yesterday on the framework for the proposals it will make.

It is no surprise that the Supreme Court divided 5-to-4 in upholding the contempt of court convictions of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and seven other Negro ministers. The competing considerations almost balance out-but not quite.

BOSTON, June 13 About $100,000 was raised at a testimonial dinner last night to help Endicott Peabody pay $152,161 in campaign debts that were made public months after his unsuccessful race for the Senate last fall.
Operators of about 650 United States-flag ships-nearly two-thirds of the country's active merchant fleet are facing a threat of another major trike by deck officers on Friday.
Weathering occasional bouts of profit taking, the stock market forged its sixth consecutive advance yesterday.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, June 13 (Canadian Press) Authoritative sources in Tel Aviv say that Israel's next major military move may be to make the atom bomb.

LONDON, June 13 (AP) Royce Shaw, a 19-year-old Harvard freshman, set a record for his university tonight by running the mile in 4 minutes 3.4 seconds and helped a combined Harvard and Yale team post an 11-5 victory over Oxford and Cambridge in a track and field meet at London's White City Stadium.
RABAT, Morocco, June 13 King Hassan has told Arab chiefs of state that he is against holding an Arab summit conference at this time.

SPRINGFIELD, N. J., June 13--The touring golf professionals urged executives of the Professional Golfers' Association today to accede to their demands for greater control of the pro circuit "to obviate the necessity" of forming a rival organization.
CHICAGO, June 13--America's houseware producers, who make such household products as blenders, hair dryers, percolators, and pots and pans, are trying to telescope five months into five days here.

NEWARK, June 13-After failing twice in the last three weeks to complete a hearing on a site selected for a medical college, the city's Central Planning Board succeeded today in getting opinions for and against the proposal.
Around the trade, Delehanty, Kurnit Geller is known as a small but creative shop. They'd like to stay creative.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 13 Mohamed Mahgoub, the Arab League's commissioner general for the boycott of Israel, announced in Damascus today that the Arab boycott office was considering a blanket boycott of goods and companies of the United States and Britain in the Arab countries.
A three-story office building is being built in Princeton, N.J., the university town that has been attracting research and regional office facilities in increasing numbers during the last decade.

The foreclosure rate on all types of mortgage loans by Federally insured savings and loan associations fell slightly during the first quarter of 1967, according to a report made public yesterday by the Federal Home Loan Bank Boards.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 13 Dr. Nathan M, Pusey told Harvard seniors today that he dissented from the idea that civilization was beyond redemption.
The Board of Estimate and the City Council, with their large Democratic majorities, overrode 18 vetoes by Mayor Lindsay yesterday and cut nearly $6-million from his executive budget.

WASHINGTON, June 13 A clearing house to stimulate United States and Latin American private investment in Western Hemisphere economic development will be set up shortly as a result of agreements signed at the State Department today.

CAIRO, June 13--Informed Egyptian sources said today that King Hassan II of Morocco would probably visit the United States in the next few days in an Arab campaign to persuade the West to get Israel to relinquish her war gains.
Civil Court Judge Joseph A. Macchia, who was campaign manager of Mayor Lindsay's first race for Congress in 1958, suffered a judicial setback yesterday in his effort to win election to a full term.

BRISTOL, Tenn., June 13The General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the United States, the Southern Presbyterians, defeated tonight an attempt to sidestep adoption of a statement "repenting of discrimination" in the largely white denomination.

WASHINGTON, June 13 The Norfolk Western Railway asked the Federal District Court in Roanoke, Va., today to annul the Interstate Commerce Commission's order of yesterday directing it take over three smaller railroads: the Boston Maine, the Delaware Hudson and the ErieLackawanna.
WASHINGTON, June 13 Senator John Stennis, chairman of the ethics committee, told the Senate today that it could not afford to ignore or condone the conduct of Senator Thomas J. Dodd.

MATTHEWS, N. C., June 13--Mr. and Mrs. Donald J. Russell Jr. have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Patricia Annette Russell, to Barry William Feathers, son of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Feathers of Bedford Village, N.Y.

TRENTON, June 13 The state announced today that Woodbridge Township in Middlesex County would be a stop for the Pennsylvania Railroad's planned high-speed train service between New York City and Washington.
The executive director of Mobilization for Youth has been appointed executive director of the Henry Street Settlement House.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 13 United States bombers smashed again today at North Vietnam's rail links with China.

The United Presbyterian Synod of New York yesterday elected the Rev. Dr. Gordon W. Mattice, pastor of the interracial Lake Street Church in downtown Elmira, N.Y., as its moderator for a one-year term.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass. Within a short time General de Gaulle plans to use the special powers begrudgingly granted him by the National Assembly to start a social and economic reform in France. An integral text for this has been drawn by Premier Pompidou and will be presented this month.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 13 Jordan and Syria, backed by the Soviet Union, accused Israel today of having driven thousands of Arabs out of occupied territory in what the Jordanian delegate called a "pattern embarked upon in 1948," when Israel was established.

A MAN WHO CALLS himself "The Ferret of the Footnotes" has turned up in company balance sheets examples of unusually heavy pension costs that in some cases exceeded the sums left as net income in 1966.

In an effort to ease tension between hippies and different ethnic groups on the Lower East Side, the Parks Department outlined new ground rules yesterday for Tompkins Square Park that it hoped would be "compatible to everyone."
WASHINGTON, June 13 Federal antipollution officials announced today an investigation into the spill of lethal coal ash that has killed many fish in the Clinch River in Virginia and Tennessee.

HOUSTON, June 13 (UPI) Willie Mays hit the 550th homer of his career tonight with the bases filled and two out in the 10th inning, capping a 6-2 victory for the San Francisco Giants over the Houston Astros. Mays had entered the game in the sixth inning, when he hit into a double play with three men on.

WASHINGTON, June 13 Mrs. George Dixon has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Stanlee Ann Miller, to Wayne Coy Jr., son of Mrs. Coy and the late Mr. Coy, who had been chairman of the Federal Communications Commission.

WHITE PLAINS, June 13 Thomas A. Ruppert, convicted as the thrill-seeker who started the Yonkers Jewish Community Center fire that killed 12 persons in December, 1965, was sentenced today to life imprisonment.
"Real cool" was the term for the 25th-anniversary Christmas market of the National Association of Display Industries yesterday.

CINCINNATI, June 14 Ohio National Guardsmen with fixed bayonets were ordered into Cincinnati to join 900 policemen battling intense rioting that continued to sweep a large part of the city early today and spread to at least one suburban town.
DALLAS, June 13 (AP) An aluminum eight-wheeled vehicle that can travel the jungles of Vietnam or over water has been developed for the Army by LTV Aerospace Corporation, officials said today.

GAINESVILLE, Fla., June 13 (UPI) A University of Florida professor announced today that he had pinpointed the lethal component in the venom of black widow spiders.

WASHINGTON, June 13 President Johnson affirmed today an American commitment to protect the territorial integrity of all nations in the Middle East and expressed the hope that a peace could be achieved to protect the interests of both Israel and the Arab states.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., June 13 Mrs. Thelma T. Clark, a former teacher and Girl Scout leader, died today at the Glen Cove Community Hospital. She was 49 years old and lived at 26 Jefferson Lane, Glen Cove, and in Erieville, N.Y.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) The National Welfare Rights Movement listed 25 cities today in which demonstrations are scheduled on June 30 to protest alleged gaps between minimum needs and welfare payments.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 13 Yugoslavia joined the Soviet Union and its neighbors in Eastern Europe today in breaking relations with Israel.

A nontitle bout that could go a long way in deciding who might be the next world heavyweight champion was arranged yesterday when unbeaten Joe Frazier of Philadelphia signed to meet George Chuvalo of Toronto in a 12-rounder.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) Public schools of the nation's capital, which have a 91 per cent Negro enrollment, are to be governed by a school board with a Negro majority for the first time.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 13 Beirut was returning to normal, quickly today after a week of crisis.

Mrs. John F. Kennedy and her two children are to leave New York tonight for a vacation in Ireland, a spokesman for Mrs. Kennedy said yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, June 13 (UPI) Curt Flood got four hits tonight to lead the St. Louis Cardinals to a 7-4 victory over Pittsburgh despite a threehomer attack by the Pirates.
The Carpenter Steel Company and the Eastern Stainless Steel Corporation, both producers of specialty steels, announced yesterday that they had agreed to merge.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., June IS (UPI) Al Kaline and Willie Horton hit two singles each during a 10-run sixth inning that routed Dean Chance tonight and sent the Detroit Tigers to a 15-10 triumph over the Minnesota Twins.
WASHINGTON, June 13 The House passed today a $70.3-billion defense money bill described by Congressional leaders as the largest single legislative appropriation in world history.
LONDON, June 13 Britain is making another effort to settle her differences with the rebel regime in Rhodesia.

CARBONDALE, Ill., June 13 (UPI) Led by Stan Smith of Southern California, the eight top-seeded players advanced to the fourth round of the National Collegiate tennis championship today on the Southern Illinois courts.

ANAHEIM, Calif., June 13 (AP) Don Mincher drove in three runs and Jimmie Hall clouted a two-run homer in pacing the California Angels to an 8-3 victory over the Cleveland Indians tonight in the first game of a double-header.

The man a Manhattan school board wants as district superintendent because of his reputation for handling community relations found out yesterday that he lacks one of the requirements for a superintendent's certificate a course in community relations.

EXPERT observers of world championship play can generally estimate the fate of the contract before a card is played, because they have the advantage of looking at all four hands. But the players can sometimes surprise them, as on the diagramed deal from a match in the qualifying round between France and North America.
Industrial issues registered a strong advance on the London stock exchange yesterday.
More than 100 teachers at a Bronx school yesterday rejected a recommendation of their union for mass resignations and said they would rather strike to win a satisfactory contract.
LUXEMBOURG, June 13 The United States and Britain said today that a limitation of arms sales in the Middle East was essential to bring peace to the area.
MIAMI, June 13 Heavy rains continued to drench southern Florida today with the biggest downpour since Hurricane Inez swept through in 1966.
BECKENHAM, England, June 13 (UPI) Mrs. Donna Floyd Fales of New York won two matches today to gain the third round of the Kent lawn tennis championship, a tune-up for the Wimbledon tournament.
TO SIR, WITH LOVE, a comedy-drama set in a London high school, starring Sidney Poitier and directed by James Clavell for Columbia Pictures, at Cinema I, Third Avenue and 60th Street.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., June 13 Miss Melissa Hattersley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. Hattersley, was married this afternoon to William Schnirring, son of Mr. and Mrs. F.W. Schnirring of Larchmont, N.Y., and Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

YONKERS, June 13 The International Pacing Series still had one race to go, Thursday night's $50,000 National Championship Pace at 1 miles, but most of the talk around Yonkers Raceway today centered on trotters.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (UPI) Congressional sources said today that a Soviet proposal to put the world's major waterways, including the Panama Canal, under international control was being considered by State Department planners.

Soong Fu-yuan, a 30-year-old Chinese composer who has lived in this country for 10 years and who received his musical education here, is a busy, busy man. The program notes to the recital of his music at Town Hall last night say that he wrote nine string quartets durine 1966.

Resuming play after a 12-day layoff, during which they tried to learn why they are the lowest-scoring club in the National Professional Soccer League, the New York Generals meet the St. Louis Stars at Yankee Stadium tonight.
SPRINGFIELD, N.J., June 13 "Probably any one of 50 can win," said Arnold Palmer when asked today to predict the winner of the United States Open golf championship that begins here Thursday.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) Robert E. Kintner, former president of two major television-radio networks, is expected to resign soon as special assistant to President Johnson for health reasons. He faces surgery for failing vision.
WASHINGTON, June 13 (UPI) President Johnson signed tonight an administration bill giving businessmen a $1.7-billion tax break.

A crisis of integrity looms on the nation's intellectual and political horizons "in which powerful and influential people will have to consider the possibility of saying out loud that they were wrong," New York University graduates were told on the Bronx campus yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) Vice President Humphrey, describing himself as well but tired, checked out of Bethesda Naval Hospital today.

ATHENS, June 13 Helen Nahnikian, former secretary of the politician Andreas Papandreou, who is under arrest, was sentenced yesterday to two years in prison by an Athens court-martial on charges of having defied a Government decree that overnight guests must he declared to the police.

Edward K. Rhatigan, vice president in charge of American Airlines' Southern region since 1965, died Monday in Roosevelt Hospital after a brief illness. He was 49 years old and lived at 288 Park Avenue, Manhasset, L.I.

Maj. Marcos P. Reno was posthumously cleared of cowardice at the Little Big Horn recently but the Indians staged a comeback at Judson Church last night. Phoebe Neville and William Meyer in a Judson Dance Theater presentation opened their program with a "Mask Dance" and ended with a "Vision Presentation" of American Indian arts and crafts as seen through the glassed of Boy Scout realism.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 13 Dr. Robert F. Goheen, president of Princeton University, said at the 220th commencement exercise today that the school would study the feasibility at increasing its role in the education of women.
WASHINGTON, June 13 President Johnson said today that control of racial violence was primarily up to local authorities and "the good judgment of the people themselves."

Council President Frank D. O'Connor said last night that he had talked "two or three times" to John J. Burns, Democratic state chairman, about getting a bipartisan nomination for the Court of Appeals.

BETTY GRABLE, who left here 27 years ago to be come Hollywood's leading pinup girl in World War II, returned to Broadway Monday night as the match-making Dolly Levi in David Merrick's mother lode, otherwise known as "Hello, Dolly!"

WASHINGTON, June 13 Ninety-two United States Peace Corps volunteers serving in Chile have been warned to disassociate themselves officially from a circular protesting the Vietnam war or face possible disciplinary charges.
Two executive appointments resulting from the acquisition earlier this month by American Standard, Inc., of the Mosler Safe Company were announced yesterday.

Mrs. Jean William Bauer and Mrs. Edward Patterson, co-chairmen of the Debutante Cotillion and Christmas Ball scheduled for Dec. 22 at the Waldorf Astoria, gave a luncheon yesterday in the hotel's Jansen Suite to honor the hall's debutante committee. The ball is an annual benefit for the New York Infirmary.
Welfare Commissioner Mitchell I. Ginsberg complained yesterday that he had to operate his complex department "like a corner candy store."

WASHINGTON, June 13 The International Union of Electrical Workers is being torn by an internal dispute stemming from a Federal investigation of the financial affairs of its big New York-New Jersey district.
JERUSALEM, June 13 A sharp political struggle is simmering not very far below the unity produced in Israel by the triumph over the United Arab Republic, Jordan and Syria.
LONDON, June 13 (Reuters) London shipping underwriters today reduced war-risk rates they introduced at the start of the Arab-Israeli conflict.
HARRISBURG, Pa., June 13 (AP) Gov. Raymond Shafer proposed today "a sweeping program of reform" in Pennsylvania's insurance industry to be accomplished by more stringent state regulation.

The New York Botanical Garden announced yesterday a 25year, $40-million development program that will include a new conservatory to be "as magnificent a showcase for the horticultural arts as Lincoln Center is for the performing arts."
BRONXVILLE, N.Y., June 13 Curtis Person of Memphis, Tenn., opened the defense of his Eastern Seniors' Golf Association championship today by shooting a 38, 33-71 for the first-round lead.

BACK in the days when the household electronic en tertainment came in the form of a radio with two knobs, static and a long wire out the window, Tom Mix and the Old Wrangler used to caution kids nightly that "straight shooters always win."
ALBANY, June 13 The State Tax Commissioner announced today that drawings for a superprize of $250,000 in the state lottery would be held once at the end of each fiscal year, March 31.
ATHENS, June 13 United States diplomats evacuated from Alexandria, Egypt's main port, described today how they were assaulted by frenzied mobs last week.

One war tends to drive another out of the public mind. For ten days all eyes were on the Middle East, but the Vietnam war is still very much with us. In fact, reports are coming out of Washington that the Asian war may soon be escalated sharply.

WASHINGTON, June 13 State Department restrictions on travel by Americans to several middle Eastern countries probably will be relaxed shortly or else completely lifted, Administration officials said tonight.
More bicycle riding in city parks would be encouraged under a bill passed yesterday by the City Council.

GENEVA, June 13 An Ameriican Jewish leader said today that 600 Jewish men, including Grand Rabbi Jacques Nefoussi of Cairo, were being held in Egyptian jails as a result of the war between Israel and the Arabs.
The three-week-old mystery of the copper box was solved yesterday just in time for the symbolic ground-breaking for a 50-story office building on the site of the old Ziegfeld Theater.

WASHINGTON, June 14-- The Senate approved today the final text of a bill extending the military draft for four years but restricting President Johnson's authority to call up college undergraduates and barring a projected draft lottery.

The marriage of Mrs. Stephanie Hope Hammerschlag, daughter of Mrs. Max Leon Hammerschlag of 535 East 86th Street, to Leonard Henry Bernheim Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernheim, also of New York, took place yesterday afternoon at the Hammerschlag home. Rabbi Nathan Perilman of Temple Emanuel performed the ceremony.

CHICAGO--One day in 1939 a shy enginering student named Marvin Camras walked into the basement offices of the Armour Research Foundation and asked the dozen engineers there to look at the wooden box he was carrying.

DAYTON, Ohio, Thursday, June 15--Roving gangs of Negro youths went on a stone-throwing, window-smashing rampage in a 12-block area of the city's West End last night after a fiery speech by H. Rap Brown, chairman of the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee.

Lincoln Center: "La Gioconda," Metropolitan Opera, 8 P.M.; New York Philharmonic Promenade, Philharmonic Hall, 8:30; Opera Orchestra of the New York Chamber Ensemble, Library. and Museum of the Performing Arts, 6.

Prices were firm at the close of fairly active trading yesterday on the London Stock Exchange. The market was still buoyed by Britain's May trade figures but a shortage of sellers appeared to be the main prop.
The Little Church Around the Corner and its rectory were named city landmarks, yesterday by the Landmarks Preservation Commission.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, June 14--Soldiers of the United States First Infantry Division killed 60 Vietcong in a sharp battle yesterday in War Zone D, the Communist stronghold 50 miles north of Saigon.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 15, (UPI)--United States officers on the scene in War Zone D yesterday said the purpose of Operation Billings was to trap three Vietcong battalions of about 650 men each and choke off their lines of supply.
The Hansa Jet, Germany's first commercial jet airplane, will make its formal United States debut at the National Airport in Washington on June 22.
SPRINGFIELD, N.J., June 14--A spectacular 62 by Jack Nicklaus broke the monotony today of the final practice sessions for the United States Open golf championship starting tomorrow.
The New York Medical College will build the country's largest clinic for mentally retarded children as part of a planned medical complex on 106th Street between Madison and Fifth Avenues.

WASHINGTON, June 14-- Dollar amounts spent by Americans traveling to foreign countries and by foreigners traveling here each rose by about the same amount last year, leaving the "travel deficit" essentially unchanged at $1.6-billion, the Commerce Department reported today.

Mrs. John F. Kennedy and her two children left by plane last night for a six-week vacation in Ireland. They were accompanied by Mr. and Mrs. Murray McDonnell and seven of their children and were scheduled to arrive at Shannon at 8:30 A.M. today, Shannon Time.
Atlas Chemical Industries, Inc., announced yesterday in Wilmington, Del., the election to its board of Philip W. Scott, president of the Budd Company, a manufacturer of railroad cars.

OUT in the woods now the does are dropping fawns, beautiful, delicate creatures. For many, their life span can be measured in a bare seven or eight months, for next winter they will starve and perish.
WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP)--A spokesman for the American Newspaper Publishers Association supported as reasonable today the proposed postal rate increases urged by the Administration.

Eight hundred teachers and staff members from a third of New York State's operating school districts' will come to Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts this summer for fourday workshop-seminars designed to show them how to integrate the arts into the curriculum.

Columbia University will establish a library devoted to journalism that will contain 10,000 volumes on the subjeet and on important current issues, as well as a large reference file of clippings and selected television and radio tapes.

ALBANY, June 14--A Long Island fire official said today that there were hazards at the State University at Stony Brook, L.I., that could lead to a fire similar to the one at Cornell University in Ithaca, where nine persons died.

When the 11 directors of J. Walter Thompson got up from the big oval table in the agency's Resor Room yesterday afternoon they had a new chief executive officer: Dan Seymour, successful radio man turned very successful advertising man.

KINGSTON, N.Y., June 14 --Miss Cynthia Ann Haver plans to be married Sept. 9 to Frank G. Rigas, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. George Rigas of Youngstown, Ohio. Mr. and Mrs. LeVan Haver have announced their daughter's engagement.

SPRINGFIELD, N.J. June 14 --By the time the first threesome tees off tomorrow at 7:30 A.M. in the United States Open, the lower course at the Baltusrol Golf club will have been altered, subtly but strategically, from the layout on which Jack Nicklaus shot his practice 62 today.
JERUSALEM, June 14-- Tens of thousands of Jews prayed at the Wailing Wall, Judaism's holiest site, for the first time today, a week after its capture.

Directors of the Chicago Eastern Illinois Railroad authorized the railroad yesterday to file an application with the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to make an offering to its stockholders of rights to subscribe to new common shares.
A conference on pollution in Raritan Bay and its tributaries recommended a solution yesterday designed to eliminate a feared delay as a result of a proposed Federal timetable to clean the waters.

THE horn of fashion blew a medley last night and there was no disputing the authenticity of the sound. The women who revolve in and around the fashion industry were practicing what they have long preached--individuality.
In an effort to bring more unity to the civil rights movement, leaders of nine organizations met secretly in a Suffern, N.Y., motel Tuesday.
Police reinforcements patrolled last night around a Brooklyn park where a scrawl had amended the "closed" sign on the door of a work shed to read: "Park closed to niggers."

CHICAGO, June 14 (AP)-- The Crucible Steel Company of Pittsburgh, object of a struggle for control, asked the Illinois Supreme Court today for permission to hold a special meeting of its shareholders.
Bond prices sank again yesterday, driving Some interest rates up to near their highest levels this year.

WASHINGTON, June 14-- Senator Thomas J. Dodd told his colleagues today that if they believed that he had deliberately cheated the Government by double billing air fares they should change the motion of censure against him to one calling for his expulsion.

Almost one-fifth of the population has never been to a dentist, according to the United States Public Health Service. It reported in its last survey (1960) that, of the 39 per cent who do go at least once a year, most are driven by a toothache.
LUXEMBOURG, June 14-- Negotiators for the United States and the Soviet Union have agreed on all but one article of the draft of a treaty prohibiting the spread of nuclear weapons.
ST. LOUIS, June 14 (UPI)-- Thousands of people filed past the coffin of Joseph Cardinal Ritter today as his body lay in state at St. Louis Cathedral.
LONDON, June 14--British television is being reshaped under the impact of this week's reallocation of commercial channels.

LONDON, June 14 (AP)-- Igor Stravinsky paid $896 yesterday for one of his own music scores. The composer, who lives in Los Angeles, bid through an agent for a signed and annotated first edition of the piano arrangement of "Le Sacre du Printemps" ("The Rite of Spring") that belonged to Anton Dolin, the dancer.

OMAHA, June 14 (AP)-- Scotty Long of Auburn hit a run-scoring double off the leftfield fence in the last of the ninth inning and the Southeastern champions climinates Rider of New Jersey, 4-3, to-night in the college world series third round.
Roger Sanders, a former National Collegiate Athletic Association college division wrestling champion, was named varsity wrestling coach yesterday at New York University.
The spot rate on the British pound rose 3 points to $2,7920 in moderate trading on foreignexchange markets here yesterday.

A dance and cocktail party will be given by the young leadership division of the United Jewish Appeal of Greater New York on June 22 in the Crystal Room of the Delmonico Hotel. On June 27 another party will be held at the home of Roy Comart.

Management of the Standard Dredging Corporation and an insurgent group of stockholders that is seeking control of the company reached an agreement yesterday by enlarging the board of directots from seven to 12 members.

Whitlam, leader of the Australian Labor party; spoke to a group of 1,000 young people representing 500 rural electric systems in 25 states; met with his Cabinet; participated in swearing-in of Alexander Trowbridge as Secretary of Commerce; received the new Italian Ambassador to the United States, Edigio Ortona, and the New Zealand Ambassador, Frank Corner; saw Budget Bureau Director Schultze.
The Association of Contracting Plumbers here has set up a program aimed at opening the way for qualified members of minority groups to obtain work as plumbers.

Dr. M.T. Mehdi, secretary general of the Action Committee on American-Arab Relations said yesterday that he had appealed to the American Jewish Committee for a meeting to discuss the protection of all people involved in the Middle East conflict. The Jewish group rejected the appeal.

Without minimizing the great contributions some of them have made, we believe they are not.

BOSTON, June 14 (AP)-- Reggie Smith's pinch triple drove in two runs and sparked a four-run seventh inning that lifted Boston to a 6-1 victory over the Chicago White Sox in the second game of a doubleheader tonight.
Trade sources here reported yesterday that several of the Arab countries that had broken diplomatic relations with the United States were taking measures to maintain some commercial consular links,
WARRENTON, Va., June 14 (UPI)--A northern Virginia land developer has bought the 3,367-acre estate North Wales in hopes of dividing it into lots for suburban Washington residents.

An 18-year-old Puerto Rican who came here six months ago was arrested by the police yesterday and charged with arson after being accused of setting off a taxi explosion in a Bronx garage that burned 19 children, seven critically.

KEARNY, N.J., June 14-- John Buchman of Great Neck, L.I., upset top-seeded Dr. Harold German of Jersey City, 4-6, 8-6, 6-3, and led the way today into the quarter-finals of the New Jersey State men's singles tennis championship at the Arlington Players Club.

A TELEVISION portrait of Duke Ellington, composer, conductor, pianist, dreamer and realist, received a timely presentation last night on Channel 13, only two days after the musician was honored by Yale. The hour caught the artist at work and an contemplation, utilizing a cin ma v rit technique for an absorbing glimpse of the man's restless creativity.
Governor Rockefeller said yesterday that the Federal Government had approved $5.1-million in additional funds for a job-training program here.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., June 14--Curtis Person of Memphis, the first-round leader yesterday with a par 71, shot 36, 37--72 at Siwanoy Country Club today and retained his Eastern Seniors' Golf Association championship by six strokes.
NATCHEZ, Miss., June 14 (UPI)--A Negro has been named to the Natchez school board, culminating a long, hardfought battle for concessions from the white leadership of the community.

WARREN, Mich., June 14 (UPI)--The police blocked off tonight a four-block area surrounding the home of a white woman and her Negro husband that has been the scene of demmonstrations by white neigh bors for the past three nights.

HONG KONG, June 14--The Communist press here called today for the establishment of "struggle committees" in every street and district of Hong Kong as a new form of protest against the British authorities.
The Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc., announced here yesterday the election of Eugene F. Connolly to the post of vice president for management information systems.

TRENTON, June 14--The State Supreme Court today upheld the right of a gas transmission company to build an underground pipeline through the Troy Meadows, a 1,400-acre wildlife preserve in Morris County that conservationists regard as one of the finest fresh-water inland marshes in the Northeast.

KALANDIA, Jordan, June 14 --You probably will not find this village on any map, unless it is based on the ones drawn up by the United Nations Relief and Works Agency, which is charged with looking after Palestinian Arab refugees of the 1948 Arab-Israeli war.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 14--Statements by Premier Levi Eshkol and Defense Minister Moshe Dayan that Israel will not give up territory just won from her Arab neighbors have raised the question of the United Nations' power to force her to do so.

The Negro Teachers Association yesterday urged its members and "other concerned teachers" to withhold action on the campaign by the United Federation of Teachers for mass resignations as a lever in its contract negotiations with the Board of Education.
TEL AVIV, June 14--Nine Egyptian generals were captured in last week's war, Brig. Gen. Shmuel Eyal of the Israeli Army General Staff said tonight.
DETROIT, June 14--The American Motors Corporation is not worded about the necessity of paying off a bank debt of approximately $65 million by the Dec. 31 due date, its officers said today.
WASHINGTON, June 14-- Is the drought in the Northeast over?

Eddie Eagan, former chairman of the New York State Athletic Commission and Olympic boxing champion, died of a heart attack at Roosevelt Hospital yesterday. He was 69 years old and lived on Forest Avenue in Rye, N.Y.
LONDON, June 14--The Court of Appeal ruled today that employers must honor wage increases agreed to before the Government's wage and price freeze last July and subsequently blocked by that freeze.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 14--The Security Council rejected decisively today a Soviet draft resolution that condemned Israel as an aggressor and demanded the withdrawal of Israeli forces from territory they had occupied in the United Arab Republic, Syria and Jordan.

WASHINGTON, June 14-- Mickey Mantle broke the late Lou Gehrig's record for games played when he appeared as a pinch-hitter in the eigth inning of the secona game of a doubleheader that the New York Yankees split with the Washington Senators tonight.

Elisabeth Grammer's Elsa was the novelty in last night's repeat of Wagner's "Lohengrin," at the Metropolitan Opera, brought back from last season for the special Lincoln Center Festival. The tall blond soprano has had a distinguished career for some years in Europe. She made her Metropolitan Opera debut in a role that suits her well.

Miss Barbara Ann Stone will be married to Alfred John Mac Adam on June 28 at the home of her parents, Dr. and Mrs. Leonard Stone of 180 East End Avenue. State Supreme Court Justice Samuel M. Gold will perform the ceremony.
"THEY started applauding at the third number and didn't stop until the standing ovation at the end," Claudia Halley said of the second triumph in less in two years for her husband, George.
WASHINGTON, June 14 (UPI)--The House paid a warm tribute to the American flag today through song and speech in an old-fashioned Flag Day show og patriotism.

The retrial of a man accused of assaulting a police lieutenant wes barred yesterday by the Appellate Division because it said the trial judge did not give the jury sufficient time to deliberate. The jury had been out for 12 hours and 45 minutes.

CERTAIN exhibitions compel attention quite apart from their intrinsic artistic merit. They help to fill a void in our knowledge and understanding of a particular period, movement, or national tradition.

WASHINGTON, June 14-- For most of the nation, physicians' bills under Medicare are now being processed in less than three weeks, Robert M. Ball, commissioner of the Social Security Administration, said to day.

PEKING, June 14 (Reuters) --Hundreds of Red Guards beat and kicked two Indian diplomats in wild scenes at the Peking airport today. The Indians left for Hong Kong after being ordered out of China as spies.

LOS ANGELES, June 14 (UPI)--Widely separated parts of the Los Angeles area were shaken tonight by a sharp earthquake that interrupted some telephone communications but apparently caused no damage or injuries.

Aircraft flown by pilots "lacking professional ability"-- usually those in general aviation--are responsible for the most air accidents, according to a study made public yesterday day the Daniel and Florence Guggenheim Aviation Center at Cornell University.
WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP)--The Pentagon announced today that Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara would fly to Vietnam Sunday "to review all aspects of the war."
MARARONECK, N.Y., June 14--The four seeded players won the quarter-final matches of the New York State women's tennis championship tournament in straight sets today at Beach Point Club.
NEW CITY, N.Y., June 14-- John W. McNicholas, corporate control officer of the Continental Can Company, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home at 3 Bel Aire Terrace. He was 50 years old.

JACKSON, Miss., June 14 (UPI)--Morris C. Davis Jr., a Negro, refused today to be inducted into the armed forces. It was the first such move since civil rights leaders called for Negroes of military age to reject military service until draft boards are desegregated.

American and Soviet rockets are streaking across the enormous 200-million mile course to Venus, the brightest of the twinkling lights in the sky, but there is no need to regard these missions as a race, Rational men will be cheering, of course, for both Moscow's Venus 4 and Washington's Mariner 5 to be successful.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 14--The Security Council called on Israel today to "facilitate the return" of Arab refugees who fled areas occupied by Israeli forces in Jordan, Syria, and the Gaza Strip.

Union deck officers advanced their strike deadline by 36 hours yesterday and began to tie up United Statesflag ships in Atlantic and Gulf ports. The dispute involves the operators of nearly two-thirds of the nation's merchant fleet.

Haryou-Act, which now administers most of Harlem's antipoverty programs, will be transformed into an agency to develop, review and approve all proposals from local groups seeking antipoverty funds. It will no longer operate its own programs.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, June 14-- Ceylon's depressed rubber market is expected to recover soon following the United States Government's response to an appeal by Ceylon and Malaysia to cut down on releases from the United States robber stockpile. The releases, it is understood, have been halved.
NEW DELHI, June 14--The Indian Government expelled two Chinese Communist diplomats today in retaliation for the expulsions by Peking.

EAST HAVEN, Conn., June 14--Miss Nancy Lynne Cantwell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert T. Cantwell of Syosset, L.I., was married today to Clifton Aynesworth Mann, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Clifton Mann of Washington. The Rev. John A. Budding performed the ceremony in Christ and Epiphany Episcopal Church.

A leading dissident shareholder of the Boston Maine Corporation yesterday recommended that the road's shareholders reject the Interstate Commerce Commission's order to merge the company into the Norfolk Western Railway.

Weld, who founded it in 1893, and Helen Hall, who took over from her in 1933.

Moscow's attempt to turn the United Nations into a Soviet propaganda forum on the Middle East reveals such extraordinary cynicism that it will serve true Russian interests as little as the Kremlin's earlier miscalculations about Egypt and Israel which helped to bring on war.

BALTIMORE, June 14--Conservatives began organizing for Maryland's Constitutional Convention today following a special election yesterday in which independent and reform delegates captured a majority of the 142 seats.

The stock market's winning streak ended yesterday as profit taking produced the first decline in seven sessions. Leading indicators closed at or near their lowest levels of the day but the setback was not so broad as some averages indicated.
Six large corporations have signed to sponsor the 1968 Summer and Winter Olympics on the American Broadcasting Company for $20-million.

ATLANTA, June 14 (AP)-- The Atlanta Chiefs, taking a 1-0 half-time lead on a goal kicked by an opposing player, scored twice within one minute and 21 seconds of the second half to defeat the Philadelphia Spartans, 3-0, in a National Professional Soccer League game tonight.

HOUSTON, June 24 (UPI)-- Bob Aspromonte batted in four runs and Don Wilson, a rookie right-hander, pitched an eighthitter tonight to lead the Houston Astros to a 7-4 victory over the San Francisco Giants.
Gordon Kiddoo has been elected a vice president of the Standard Oil Company of Ohio. He is manager of new business and commercial development for the company's chemicals and plastics activities.
The Long Island Rail Road announced yesterday that it had reached contract agreements with three unions that had threatened to strike.
WASHINGTON, June 14-- The Johnson Administration applied heavy pressure today on a sharply divided House to approve the White House formula for averting a nationwide railroad strike.
