A nuclear physicist who has described as imprudent the way the Consolidated Edison Company developed its first nuclear plant was challenged yesterday by the company.

Three long-established professionals and a rapidly rising newcomer took control of a ball game for the New York Mets at Shea Stadium last night and produced a 4-0 victory over the league-leading Cincinnati Reds.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 14-- The war with Israel has left the Arab world in a state of shock. The awareness of its practical impact is spreading as the numbness of defeat wears off.
ALBANY, June 14--New York's chief judge joined the dispute over how to select judges by recommending today that they be appointed, not elected.
GAZA, June 1 (UPI)--Elsewhere the war is over, but in Gaza it is not completely so.

BRISTOL, Tenn., June 14-- Leaders of the Southern Presbyterian Church voted today to address a long list of "anguished" questions on United States policy in Vietnam to the 950,000 members of the Southern and Southwestern denomination.

YONKERS, June 14--The National Championship Pace at Yonkers Raceway, tomorrow night is likely to produce additional evidence of the low esteem that most of the harness racing public holds events featuring a prohibitive favorite.
BONN, Jyne 4--Chancellor Kurt Georg Kiesinger has proposed naming a deputy to discuss practical problems of the division of Germany with an equivalent representative of the East German regime.

The Georgia-Pacific Corporation, maker of plywood, paper and gypsum products, has reopened merger talks with the Kalamazoo Paper, James A. Wise, president of Kalamazoo Paper, told stockholders yesterday.
Pope Paul VI has contributed $25,000 in personal funds to an American-based Roman Catholic relief agency currently aiding refugees of the Middle Eastern war.
WAYNE, Pa.--The family of Dr. Robert D. May went on an Early American cooking binge several years ago, and the influence is still very much alive in their l8thcentury kitchen.

WASHINGTON, June 14-- Despite protests by civil rights groups, the Joint Atomic Energy Committee of Congress approved tonight the Administration's plan to build the world's largest atom smasher in Weston, Ill., a suburb of Chicago.
The subway trip from East New York or Brownsville to Times Square takes up to an hour.
It took the St. Louis Stars 23 minutes to get a shot on goal against the New York Generals last night at Yankee Stadium.

PITTSBURGH, June 14 (UPI) --A grand-slam home run by Tim McCarver in the first inning paced the St. Louis Cardinals to a 7-4 triumph over the Pittsburgh Pirates tonight and enabled Bob Gibson to post his eighth victory.

TOKYO, June 14--Jolted by the brief interruption of oil supplies from the Middle East in the Arab-Israeli war, Japan is charting a long-range program to develop other major sources of fuel for the country's industry.

An Italian court held a criminal trial hearing yesterday in the United States District Court in Brooklyn. It was believed to have been the first time a foreign tribunal functioned in an American courthouse.
ATHENS, June 14--The military junta forbade tonight the dissemination of statements likely to "arouse anxiety among citizens or lessen their sense of security and order."

S. Bryce Wing of Glyndon, Md., a 77-year-old retired steeplechase official and the president of the National Steeplechase and Hunt Association from 1948 to 1964, was named the winner of the F. Ambrose Clark award for 1967 yesterday.
A split in the ranks of longshoremen over current seniority rules is developing into a dispute between the "haves" and the "have-nots."
The deep-throated tones of operatic arias will be joined in Greenwich Village by the unscored symphony of tools at work on a building-modernization project.

DETROIT, June 14 (AP)--A fight betwen players fared in the closing moments of the Detroit Cougars' United Soccer Association game against Houston tonight, halting the game with 17 minutes still to play and Houston ahead, 2-0.
ATLANTIC CITY, June 14-- A Harvard Medical School physician reported evidence today that may link mongolism and other birth defects to acute infectious hepatitis.

ST. LOUIS, June 14--Mrs. Cynthia Pierson Barlow, daughter of Mrs. Charles E. Pierson and the late Mr. Pierson, was married today to Lunsford P. Yandell Jr. of New York and Dallas, son of Mr. and Mrs. Yandell of Greenwich, Conn., and Scottsdale, Ariz.
Subway trains with thousands of morning riders were stalled on the IRT East Side line between Bowling Green in Manhattan and the Atlantic Avenue station in Brooklyn for 36 minutes yesterday.
Mayor Lindsay has designated June as Medicaid Month, to bring to the attention of all New Yorkers the wide range of health benefits in the Medicaid program.
WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) --The number of card-carrying Communists all over the world increased in 1966 by more than two million, a State Department survey shows.

TAMPA, Fla., June 14--About 100 Negro youths were called on tonight to help prevent outbreaks of violence in Tampa's Negro districts, twice the scene of fires and looting this week in racial disturbances.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., June 14--Mariner 5, the unmanned American spacecraft bound for Venus, streaked through space today with an accuracy that encouraged scientists who hope the mission will solve the mystery of what lies beneath the planet's veil o clouds.

In December, 1956, after Israeli forces routed the Egyptians in a week-long desert campaign, thousands of Egyptian prisoners of war wandered without food or water back to Port Said or Cairo, across the Gulf of Suez.

WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP)--The Atomic Energy Commission ended today a 25year policy of secrecy on the capacity of the three gaseous diffusion plants that produce nuclear materials for weapons and for power reactor fuels.

A COLLEGE reunion can be a gaudy venture in group therapy. That's the way David Camerer develops this morning's singularly timely novel. Toward the end there are plotty manifestations of moral cures. Out of minithink tanks under northern New England elms emerge brisk ideas for regeneration.
Sgt, Robert Scanlon of the 46th Precinct stood in the intersection of Hoffman and East 187th Streets, the Bronx, yesterday and ordered two of his patrolmen to check the roofs.
The aluminum industry announced yesterday the development of new highway barriers using high-strength aluminum alloys.
The American Stock Exchange reported yesterday the changes carried below in the shareholdings of officers, directors and major stockholders of listed companies.
The Chrysler Corporation "is very encouraged by the current trend in automobile sales," Virgil E. Boyd, president, declared here yesterday.
Stockholders of the Diamond International Corporation and the Penobscot Company approved yesterday at separate meetings a previously proposed merger of the two companies.
Rexford G. Tugwell, a key mamber of Franklin D. Roosevelt's brain trust, has written that President Kennedy cannot be ranked with the nation's great Presidents.
WASHINGTON, June 14-- A planning grant of $967,010 has been made to a New York group for a program to improve diagnosis and treatment of heart disease, cancer and stroke.

London and New York may see Jose Ferrer, star of "Man of La Mancha," in the title role of "Quasimode," the musical version of Victor Hugo's novel "The Hunchback of Notre Dame." Mr. Ferrer said yesterday that he was "very excited about it" and that negotiations with Bernard Delfont, producer, "look very favorable."

MONTREAL, June 14--The Hamburg State Opera, one of the world's most upto-date companies, made its North American debut here last night, performing Hindemith's "Mathis der Maler" in the Salle Wilfrid Pelletier at the Place des Arts.

WASHINGTON, June 14-- Financial institutions bought and sold what appears to have been a record volume of stocks in the first quarter of this year, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.
A $22-million summer program to keep thousands of youngsters off the streets, and possibly avert racial tensions while educating or amusing them, was announced yesterday bY the Board of Education.
BOSTON, June 14--The Boston Stock Exchange formally opened today a new trading floor made necessary by the increase in business since a general reorganization of the exchange two years ago.

IN THE railroad business, a delay at a crucial mo- ment can send shippers to the competition--barge operators and truckers. Thus it did not take leading rail carriers long to respond to President Johnson's signature at the bottom of the newly reinstated 7 per cent investment credit.
The Meadow Stable of Christopher T. Chenery finished one, two in the filly division of the National Stallion Stakes at Aqueduct yesterday.

NEW DELHI, June 14 (Reuters)--The Indian Government warned today that it would take strong action against Christian missionaries who use famine conditions in some parts of the country to win converts.

South Street took on a fleeting reflection of the glory of its clipper ship days yesterday with the arrival of the Maltese barkentine Regina Maris, carrying a crew of 14; Pepe, a Canary Island parrot, and Greif, a German shepherd.

Two neighborhood groups from East Harlem and the South Bronx took over the conference room of the Council Against Poverty at 100 Church Street yesterday to protest cuts in funds for antipoverty programs this summer.
Personnel changes at Columbia University last week represent an attempt to deal with problems that confront the university with the possibility of gradual decline.

S. Sawyer Le Vay, a lawyer and the president and chairman of the board of governors of the New York Cardiac Center in Yonkers, died Tuesday in Flower and Fifth Avenue Hospital after a brief illness. He was 63 years old and lived at 585 West End Avenue. His office was at 551 Fifth Avenue.

BLOOMINGTON, Ind., June 14--In Trinity Episcopal Church this afternoon, Miss Ingrid Elien Winther, daughter of Prof. and Mrs. Oscar O. Winther, became the bride of James Ralston Scobie, son of J. Ralston Scobie and the late Mrs. Scobie.
The Metropolitan Museum of Art has taken the first step in effecting the organizational changes promised by its new director, Thomas P.F. Hoving, when he took office last April.

RICHMOND, Va., June 14 (AP)--A Federal appeals court said today that a prisoner granted a retrial on constitutional grounds cannot be given a sentence in the second trial greater than that handed down in the original proceeding.

WASHINGTON, June 14-- Recent poll results give Richard Nixon what appears to be a solid and commanding lead for the Republican Presidential nomination next year. Appearances are deceiving, however, as several bits of political intelligence from the West indicate.

CINCINNATI, Thursday, June 15--National Guard men and policemen dashed from one trouble spot to another in jeeps and squad cars last night and early today, dispersing rock-throwing bands of Negro teen-agers and snuffing out fires in this riot-torn city.

WASHINGTON, June 14-- Diplomatic sources reported today that the Soviet Union had informed ether Communist countries that it intended to continue some military assistance to the United Republic and other Arab countries.
The Southern New England Telephone Company announced yesterday the election of Alfred W. Van Sinderen as president.

OF all the nice things that have happened in Central Park since Thomas P.F. Hoving reclaimed it--so to speak--for the natives, the New York Shakespeare Festival's "Comedy of Errors" is one of the nicest.
FAMAGUSTA, Cyprus, June 14--Hundreds of Egyptian Jews are being arrested as a wave of anti-Jewish feeling is sweeping the United Arab Republic following its defeat by Israel.

ANAHEIM, Calif., June 14 (AP)--Bob Rodgers, who homered for California's first run singled in two more with the bases loaded and one out in the ninth inning, lifting the Angels to a 3-2 victory over Cleveland tonight.
PHUKET, Thailand--"We were never discouraged," Ralph S. McNair said with a grin. "But we were sometimes pretty beaten down."

MONTGOMERY, Ala., June 14 --About 225 Negroes marched close to the steps of the state Capitol in another demonstration tonight, but their leaders assailed Alabama's government without the "black power" threats of Stokely Carmichael.

BALTIMORE, June 14--Francis B. Burch, Maryland's Attorney General, said today he would appeal a Federal court decision upholding the newly extended minimum wage law that applies to state public school and hospital employes.
BOWLING GREEN, Ohio, June 14--Harold Anderson, former basketball coach at Bowling Green State University and the University of Toledo, died yesterday in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 64 years old.
DETROIT, June 14--A wren has wrecked an attempt by the General Motors Corporation to perform a good deed.
FAMAGUSTA, Cyprus, June 14--An eyewitness account indicating that the Egyptians themselves sank the ships now blocking the Suez Canal has reached a Western embassy in Cairo.

The House Judiciary Committee has reported a bill making it a felony under Federal law for anyone to "cast contempt" upon the flag by publicly mutilating, burning, defiling or trampling it, Representative Celler of New York, the committee chairman, who has resisted this measure for more than two years, fi
CHICAGO, June 14 (AP)-- The Los Angeles Dodgers snapped an eight-game losing streak today, with a 4-3 victory over the Chicago Cubs. For the Cubs, it was the end of a fivegame winning string.

WASHINGTON, June 14-- The Governor of New Mexico, David F. Cargo, told Congress today that generations of broken promises and "unbelievable" poverty had led a band of Spanish-Americans to revolt in the northern part of the state.

SEOUL, South Korea, June 14--Ten universities in Seoul and three in Pusan have been closed temporarily as the South Korean Government has sought to quell student protests over alleged rigging of the National Assembly elections last Thursday.
PELHAM MANOR. N.Y., June 14--Two teams were tied for the lead with 77's at the halfway mark today in the Grace Herbert Memorial bestball tournament of the Women's Tri-County Golf Association.
Mr. and Mrs. James W. Eben of 1 East End Avenue have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lisa Lenison Eben, to William J. Bergin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Bergin of Bayside, Queens.

Three publishers have completed plans for books on the Israeli-Arab war, and two others are considering book projects. Publishers forecast yesterday that this was the first trickle of what would become a flood.

CRANFORD, N.J., June 14-- Mrs. Gladys Dean Bryce of New York, widow of Chalmers K. Bryce, a former vice president of the Union Carbide Corporation, died of a heart ailment yesterday in Elizabeth General Hospital at the age of 78. She had come here earlier in the day from her city residence to spend the summer.
CARBONDALE, Ill., June 14 (AP)--All eight seeded players reached the quarter-finals of the National Collegiate tennis championship today.

RIVERTON, N.J., June 14-- Philadelphia's top women golfers won the Griscom Cup for the second straight year, scoring 32 points, to 26 for New York and 4 for Boston today in the 61st renewal of the intercity matches since 1900 at the Riverton Country Club.

IT has been quite a few years since Ben Hogan drew consideration as a prime contender for the United States Open golf championship. This is the most prestigious title golf has to offer and the bristling competition for it will begin today over the beautifully manicured acres of Baltusrol in Springfield, N.J.
WASHINGTON, June 14-- President Johnson accepted "with regret" today the resignation of Robert E. Kintner, the former television executive, as a White House Special Assistant.

YONKERS, June 14--Dr. Lone Liang, who was a diplomat for China before the Communists took over, died Monday in St. John's Hospital after a brief illness. He was 72 years old and lived at 49 Devoe Avenue.
KANSAS CITY, June 14 (AP)--Dave Duncan, a rookie, got three singles to spark three rallies as the Kansas City Athletics routed the Baltimore Orioles, 9-2, tonight.
CHICAGO, June 14--Seventy-six prominent residents of Chicago's exclusive northern suburbs called at 75 real estate offices last Saturday to seek housing for Negroes.
WASHINGTON, June 14--It was disheartening to open the newspaper the other day and discover that Biafra was preparing to defend itself against attack.
KANSAS CITY, June 14 (AP)--Dave Duncan, a rookie, got three singles to spark three rallies as the Kansas City Athletics routed the Baltimore Orioles, 9-2, tonight.
WASHINGTON, June 14--It was disheartening to open the newspaper the other day and discover that Biafra was preparing to defend itself against attack.

CAIRO, June 14 (Reuters)-- The impact of the four-day war with Israel, and of what President Gamal Abdel Nasser called "serious military setbacks" suffered in the Sinai Desert, is being felt here only gradually.
Louis Beck, the confidential assistant to Surrogate S. Samuel DiFalco, was named yesterday as a co-conspirator in an alleged conspiracy to obtain a suspended sentence for a convicted extortionist.
New gifts ranging from $1 to $25,000 have raised donstions to the Fresh Air Fund to $141,231.38.

IN Spain, the land of the siesta, the dog show fits very nicely into the scheme of things. Whereas in America, a major fixture will get under way at 8 A.M. and after a great deal of hustle and bustle, finish 10 to 12 hours later, in Spain there is a much more leisurely pace.
GENEVA, June 14--The International Committee of the Red Cross expressed deep concern today over the plight of thirsty stragglers from the Egyptian Army who are still wandering in the Sinai Desert.

RABAT, Morocco, June 14-- Many of Morocco's 50,000 Jews are staying at home behind locked doors as a flood of antiJewish propaganda is distributed throughout the country by Istiqlal, a traditionalist political group.

Yesterday was a bad day for olders of long positions in the wheat market. All five deliveris registered contract lows. The slump could be traced to good crop weather, the recent department of Agriculture estimate of record production this year and a slackening of export shipments.
The city plans to give a selected number of low-income families a guaranteed annual income if Federal authorities approve a proposal made by Welfare Commissioner Mitchell I. Ginsberg.

J. KODOR and Bernard Hill, in a dead-heat finish, scored 6 points out of 8, to tie for first place in the recent Queen's Club championship. Kodor, however, was awarded top honors on a tiebreak count over Hill, manytime titleholder.
CINCINNATI, June 14--The hangouts along battered Reading Road were locked up, and except for small groups of teen-age Negroes the street was nearly empty.

The swiftly spreading strike of deck officers on twothirds of the country's merchant fleet smashes the hopes of American ship operators that they had finally heard the last of the "me too" demands through which feuding maritime unions have repeatedly wrecked passenger and cargo schedules.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 14-- President Nureddin el-Attassi of Syria called upon the Arabs today to "uproot" the political and economic presence of Britain, the United States and other countries that "backed Israel."

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., June 14--Miss Margot Shera Vaughan., a graduate of Howard University, plans to be married here in August to Cecil R. Forster Jr., a graduate of Middlebury College and St. John's University School of Law.

WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP)--Government officials said today they would decide after next Monday whether permanent restraints would be imposed on United States nickel scrap exports, which have increased rapidly.
WASHINGTON, June 14-- The Joint Economic Committee of Congress announced today that it would hold hearings on the state of the economy from June 27 through June 29.
STOCKHOLM, June 14 (Reuters)--Three Swedish soldiers of the United Nations force said today that they were put before an Israeli firing squad in the Gaza Strip last week.

Mr. and Mrs. Harris J. Klein of Brooklyn and Petri Island, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carol Michele Klein, to Thomas Maxwell Hall, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles M. Hall of Buffalo.

Two United States banks disclosed plans yesterday to join three foreign institutions in the formation of an international bank to be based in London and to be called the International Commercial Bank, Ltd.

TOKYO, June 14 (Reuters)-- The police said today that fiveteen-age boys found dead in a fishing boat in Kure, in Western Japan, were victims of the latest craze--sniffing towels dipped in lacquer-thinner "for kicks."

A $1.74-million damage award that the Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company had been ordered to pay to the Penn-Ohio Steel Corporation for "injurious falsehood" was revoked yesterday by an appeals court here.
SPRINGFIELD, N.J., June 14--Plenty of daily tickets are available for the United States Open, which starts here tomorrow, Robert Finney, the tournament chairman, said tonight.

SPRINGFIELD, N.J., June 14--Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower was asked today by the nations golf writers to mediate the conflict between the touring golf professionals and executives of the Professional Golfers' Association.

BRISTOL, England, June 14 (AP)--Jim McManus of Berkeley, Calif., produced the biggest upset of the West of England tennis championships today when he beat Bob Hewitt, South Africa's Davis Cup player, 6-3, 6-3 and moved into the quarter-final round.
OCEANPORT, N.J., June 14-- --Lady Swaps, a 4-year-old bay filly owned by Circle M. Farm, gained a four-length victory in the $23,050 Regret Handicap at Monmouth Park today.
OCEAN BEACH, L.I., June 14--The summer people turned out between weekends last night to vote down a $275,000 expansion proposed for the Fire Island schoolhouse.

AMMAN, Jordan, June 14-- Two International Red Cross representatives waded across the Jordan River to Israeli-held territory today to deliver 17,000 messages to members of separated Palestinian families. This was a first step toward reuniting families split by the flight of more than 100,000 Arabs from the West Bank of the river to the territory to the east.
NORTON, Mass., June 14-- In Wheaton College's Cole Memorial Chapel this afternoon, Miss Jeanne Tolles Haseltine was married to Ens. Charles Burks Griffis Jr., U.S.N.

WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP)--The United States Tax Court ruled today that Maury Wills, the Pittsburgh Pirate shortstop, must pay Federal income tax on two prizes that he had won when he was with the Los Angeles Dodgers--one of the awards being the S. Rae Hickok belt.
Trading remained active but prices turned somewhat mixed yesterday on the American Stock Exchange.
CAIRO, June 14 (UPI)-- Many Egyptian soldiers have arrived here near collapse from thirst, fatigue and hunger. Some of their comrades are said to be dying on the desert.

PARIS. June 14--Several small European countries and Britain feel that the cutback of oil from the Middle East, whether by shutdowns or embargo, is a threat to them and that emergency action is necessary. But oil industry sources say that, as things stand now, everyone's requirements can be filled.

WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP)--The Voice of America has doubled its broadcasts in Arabic sine the outbreak of hostilities in the Middle East and is now sending news to the area in that language 12 to 13 hours

RONKONKOMA, L.I., June 14--A student pilot landed his plane on the 50-foot-wide grassy center mall of the Long Island Expressway here this afternoon after a temporary loss of power. Forty-five minutes later the pilot took off from the roadway as the police delayed traffic.

A $1.74-million damage award that the Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company had been ordered to pay to the Penn-Ohio Steel Corporation for "injurious falsehood" was revoked yesterday by an appeals court here.

Trading remained active but prices turned somewhat mixed yesterday on the American Stock Exchange.

RONKONKOMA, L.I., June 14--A student pilot landed his plane on the 50-foot-wide grassy center mall of the Long Island Expressway here this afternoon after a temporary loss of power. Forty-five minutes later the pilot took off from the roadway as the police delayed traffic.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., June 15 (UPI)--Gov. John H. Chafee said today that he intended to drum up support for Mr. Romney as the Presidential nominee at the Republican Governors conference.
LONDON, June 15--Qualified sources said today that Britain would undoubtedly agree to withdraw her troops if pressed by Libya.
The Society of the Classic Guitar presented its 114th concert last night at Carnegie Recital Hall, a pleasant, warmly received program by Victor Stern, violist, and Juan Mercadel, guitarist.
The fresh attempt this week to promote cooperative action among diverse elements of the civil rights movement offers a glimmer of hope on the eve of an ominous summer.

BONGSON, South Vietnam, June 12--The First Cavalry Division (Airmobile), whose more than 430 helicopters have made it the most mobile military unit in Vietnam, is involved in a police operation based on shanks' mare.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., June 15--The Parrish Art Museum will again be a center of summer activity in this fashionable beach community, although an occasional benefit for charity will be held at the Meadow Club and the Junior High School. Following are some of the events scheduled:
SPRINGFIELD, N.J., June 15--Martin Fleckman, an amateur, set the opening-round pace with a three-under-par 67 in the United States Open championship today before a thunderstorm interrupted play.
WASHINGTON, June 15-- "That will teach me to try to get elected on my brother Teddy's name."
Twenty-five surfers clad in bathing suits, T-shirts and windbreakers lugged their ninefoot-long boards to City Hall yesterday to protest the curtailment of surfing at the Rockaway beaches in Queens.

TIGER MORSE, fierce exponent of extreme pop fashion and self-styled queen of the way-out world, has abandoned the chic East 70's for the gaudler stamping grounds of the teeney bop pers. She has closed her Teeney Weeney Boutique at 922 Madison Avenue and has taken over the 14-month-old boutique at Cheetah, the discotheque on Broadway and 53d Street.

Nearly two dozen men prominent in the art world crowded into the State Attorney General's office yesterday to discuss the question of immunity: How can an expert give an opinion on the authenticity of a work of art without facing a lawsuit?
JERICHO, Jordan, June 15-- Hundreds of Jordanians left Israeli-held territory today across a damaged Jordan River bridge in an evacuation organized by Israeli officials.

AREA A--Something of a slump is afflicting this area. Some put the blame on coldwater temperatures and others cite a lack of anglers. In the Atlantic City section fishing is fair to mediocre. Off-shore blues up to 12 pounds are being caught but not frequently.
The city was urged yesterday to hold up approval of the $575million World Trade Center un til it was sure it would get the maximum income from the project.

WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) --An indictment charging 10 manufacturing companies and 14 individuals with conspiracy to fix prices on tickets, coupons and checks was announced tonight by the Department of Justice.

Odometers on all rental automobiles would have to be checked every three months and their degree of accuracy noted on the dashboard under terms of a bill considered yesterday by the City Council's Committee on City Affairs.
WASHINGTON, June 15-- Raymond H. Lapin of San Francisco, former president of the Transamerica Corporation, was named president of the Federal National Mortgage Association today.

J.J. Coyle, a former dancer, actor, choreographer and dresser, will make his Broadway debut as an author with "Ninety Day Mistress." The comedy is scheduled to open Nov. 6 at the Biltmore, where "Barefoot in the Park" is in its last weeks.

The Emerson Electric Company announced a new bid last night to control or merge with the Dodge Manufacturing Corporation, which had rejected an earlier merger proposal and had urged its shareholders not to accept an Emerson tender offer.

The Nassau County Police Athletic League, asked by the Southern New York Soccer Association to prohibit P.A.L. youngsters from participating in a soccer clinic at Yankee Stadium tomorrow, decided yesterday to defy the association edict.
OCEANPORT, N.J., June 15 (AP)--Jean-Pierre scored a 3 -length victory in Monmouth Park's featured race today after Don Brumfield took him to the lead on the outside on the final turn.
DETROIT, June 15--A fight for higher pay within the Detroit Police Department became an open rebellion with 300 policemen calling in sick today and the department suspending 61 for neglect of duty.
Shipowners operating approximately two-thirds of the nation's merchant fleet moved yesterday to end a two-day strike of deck officers by submitting their case to a Federal Court.
Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute's largest graduating class received degrees at the school's 112th commencement exercises yesterday at Cadman Plaza in downtown Brooklyn.

The Consolidated Edison Company sought to show at a public hearing yesterday that the financial risk it assumed in building its first nuclear plant in 1955 was no greater than that assumed by other utilities at the same time.
Government bond prices advanced for much of yesterday's session, but lost most of their gains in late trading.

LOS ANGELES, June 15-- The American Symphony Orchestra League honored the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's "Bell Telephone Hour" television program last night for "distinguished service to music and the arts."

WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP)--A bill to authorize a one-year appropriation of $60-million to provide day-care services for 500,000 more children was introduced today by Sen. Jacob K. Javits, Republican of New York.
DETROIT, June 15 (UPI)-- Cassius Clay, the former heavyweight champion, outclassed two opponents tonight without being hit solidly in two threeround exhibition matches.
The Commodity Exchange announced a new and unusual futures contract yesterday-- liquid propane gas. Trading is expected to begin after Labor Day. Elsewhere, it was a quiet commodity market.

The Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court yesterday stayed the Fifth Avenue Coach Company from examining the stockholder list of Austin Nichols Co., Inc., pending Austin Nichols's appeal of a lower court order permitting the examination.

Just as they said they would, Sullivan, Stauffer, Colwell Bayles, America's 19th largest ad agency, and Lintas International, Unilever's house agency with 27 offices in 26 countries, have agreed to be of service to each other.

Irving Mitchell Felt, the president of the Madison Square Garden Corporation, will serve as chairman of a new Israel Bonds Economic Reconstruction Committee that will seek to promote the sale of bonds to finance the recovery of Israel's economy, which was disrupted in the Middle Eastern war.
WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP)--The Government has lowered its general hiring age from 18 to 16 to improve employment opportunities for school dropouts.
CHICAGO, June 15 (UPI)-- Wes Parker slammed a two-run home run and Ron Hunt added a homer in a four-run seventh inning today as the Los Angeles Dodgers defeated the Chicago Cubs, 5-0.
The American Stock Exchange shook off a one-day bout of indecision and staged a strong advance in active trading yesterday.
JERUSALEM, June 15 (UPI) --Premier Levi Eshkol called his Cabinet into session tonight to draft special legislation making the Old City of Jerusalem part of Israel forever, informed sources said.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass.--If any one man could be called the father of American industrial research, he would be Arthur Dehon Little, who dropped out of Massachusetts Institute of Technology in 1886 to form a company to conduct ...
SACRAMENTO, Calif., June 15 (UPI)--Gov. Ronald Reagan reluctantly signed a bill today making California the third state in the nation to liberalize its abortion laws this year.

WASHINGTON, June 15 --The Secretary of Transportation published today an appeal to the Interstate Commerce Commission to take into account the danger of inflation before it approves the recent requests for rate increases by the nation's railroads and truckers.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 15 --Gov. Ronald Reagan told a cheering banquet crowd last night that the Democrats oppose him because "if we succeed they know it'll sweep this country all the way to Washington and they don't want that to happen."
HARTFORD, June 15 (UPI) --The American Tobacco Com pany won its case today against a cancer victim who sued the company for failure to warn him adequately of the dangers of cigarette smoking.

An unidentifiable but unignorable odor spread along the South Shore of Nassau County for several hours last night and early today, rousing suburban sleepers and generating hundreds of midnight phone calls to police, sewage-disposal and gas authorities.
BUENOS AIRES, June 15-- Nearly all of the flowers in the vicinity of Buenos Aires are dead in a cold wave.
WITH ISRAELI FORCES, on the Suez Canal, June 15 (UPI) --The thirsty, hungry remnants of Egypt's Sinai army straggled back to the Suez Canal from the blazing desert today.
WHITE PLAINS, June 15-- Alexander Aldrich, executive director of the Hudson River Valley Commission, is not only going to watch the river by day, he also intends to live on it at night.
LANSING, Mich., June 15-- Governor Romney recommended today the establishment of an international authority to help settle the Middle East dispute.
The erosion of synthetic fiber prices, already a major factor in the lower earnings reports of domestic chemical producers, suffered a decisive further push downward in Europe yesterday.
New York University has cleared what is probably the last legal obstacle to construction of its 15-story library on a park site at Washington Square South, at West Broadway.

DES MOINES, Iowa, June 14 --Gov. Harold E. Hughes of Iowa, who last year shocked the Johnson Administration by an outspoken attack on the President's relationships with the states, has high praise today for Mr. Johnson's efforts to promote Federal-state cooperation.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 15 --Harvard University awarded honorary degrees at its 316th commencement today to 14 persons distinguished in the arts, business and education.
WASHINGTON, June 15-- The Democratic majority of the House Ways and Means Committee brought out a new debt-limit bill today in a second effort to win favorable House action.

SEOUL, South Korea, June 15 (AP)--Student demonstrations and charges of election rigging swirled around the government of President Chung Hee Park for the fourth day today, echoing the disturbances that brought on the overthrow of President Syngman Rhee seven years ago.

HAVERFORD, Pa., June 15 --Charlotte Atwater of Lancaster, Pa., and Linda Rupert of Bethlehem, Pa., reached the final of the Middle States girls' grass court tennis 18-and-under division today at the Merion Cricket Club.

A crowd of 22,797 saw Jacques D. Wimpfheimer's Bubbles O'Tudor win yesterday's featured $12,000 Red Shoes from Mrs. T.C. Christopher's AmeriBelle by a half-length in completing the seven-furlong contest in 1:23 3-5. The winner returned $19.20 for $2 straight.

Deputy Borough President Leonard N. Cohen, a candidate for the Civil Court in Manhattan's Fifth District, said yesterday that he had been endorsed by four of the seven Reform Democratic clubs in the Upper West Side district.
NEW DELHI, June 15--India and Yugoslavia were described today as having agreed that the Arab nations could not be forced to negotiate with Israel "from a position of weakness."
The New York Jets traded Dainard Paulson, a defensive back, yesterday to the Oakland Raiders for Joe Krakoski, also a defensive back.

GENEVA, June 15--Aleksei A. Roshchin, Soviet representative at the Geneva disarmament conference, said today that he had not reached agreement with United States negotiators on the terms of a treaty to bar the spread of nuclear weapons.

Harold A. Levey, composer, conductor and arranger of music, died of a heart attack here yesterday. He was 73 years old and lived at 5225 Collins Avenue, Miami Beach, Fla.
Two slightly reluctant dromedaries, their legs flailing and heads rolling, ran a 50-yard dash yesterday as the highlight of the New York Zoological Society's 68th annual lawn party at the Bronx Zoo.
In his effort to defeat a motion of censure, Senator Dodd of Connecticut is attempting to turn the case against him upside down.

Frank C. Arricale 2d, Commissioner of Relocation, reported yesterday he had taken six steps to discourage collusive bidding when commercial businesses are moved from sites to be used for public projects.

WASHINGTON, June 15-- President Johnson set the stage today for a meeting with Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin by authorizing a statement saying he would be "glad to see him" during Mr. Kosygin's visit to the United States.

The marriage of Miss Ann Hillyer Medina, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold R. Medina Jr. of New York and Westhampton, L.I., to Philip Blakeley Lyons of Chicago took place yesterday afternoon in St. James Episcopal Church. The bridegroom is the son of Mrs. Charlotte Hilton Lyons of Cambridge, Mass., and Philip V. Lyons.

"Cy" Vance--as he is universally known in Washington--is a man to whom public service is part of life. His resignation, after three and a half years as Deputy Secretary of Defense, robs the Pentagon of a warm and honest human being who served without fanfare or undue aspiration for personal advantage.
Friday, June 30, will be a bonus day for the city's 20,000 patrolmen and 10,000 firemen. On that date they will receive nearly $500 each in retroactive pay increases going back to July 1, 1966.
For the first time the bulk of Federal ship construction aid has been allocated for the construction of specialized, not standard-type, merchant ships.

Tony's Italian Kitchen, 212 West 79th Street, TR 49017. The best thing to be said about Tony's is that the pasta is freshly made and the vegetables are freshly cooked. And that is saying a lot. The tomato sauces are good, the meat sauce standard. The food on the whole is competently prepared whether it be lasagne or boneless chicken Parmigiana. The portions are enormous. There is an extensive hot and cold antipasto table.
The Thalia, Broadway at 95th Street, today begins its 24th annual Summer Film Festival. The program of double bills will change daily through Oct. 5.
Six leading American apparel producers have decided to withdraw from participation in the United States trade delegation to the Odezhda Trade Fair, to be held in Moscow this August.

BERLIN, June 15--East Germany today rejected West Germany's proposal for talks between middle-level representatives and insisted on its demand for top-level negotiations between Premier Willi Stoph and Chancellor Kurt Georg Kiesinger.

WASHINGTON, June 15-- Personal income rose by $2.8billion in May, a gain that was about twice the size of the increase in April but less than the average monthly rise in the preceding months of this year.
LONDON, June 15--Lord Normanbrook, who as Secretary of the Cabinet was the confidant of four Prime Ministers, died at his home here today. His age was 65.

ST. LOUIS, June 15--The highest ranking Catholic clergymen in the country paid final tribute today to Joseph Elmer Cardinal Ritter at a funeral service that reflected the influence of Vatican Council II.

TOKYO, June 15--Japan has agreed to cut tariffs in half on about 1,600 import items as a result of the Kennedy round negotiations in Geneva, according to the authoritative business publication Nihon Keizai Shimbun (Japan Economic Journal).

BRYN MAWR, Pa., June 15 (AP)--Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower told his granddaughter, Anne, and 64 of her classmates who were graduating from the fashionable Shipley School for Girls today that "ankles are nearly always neat and good-looking, but knees are nearly always not."

WASHINGTON, June 15-- In All Souls Unitarian Church here this afternoon, Miss Mary Manning Cleveland, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Gran Cleveland of Washington, became the bride of Keith Block Roberts. He is the son of Alfred Roberts of New York and Oakhurst, N.J., and the late Mrs. Roberts, who was the former Miss Josephine Block.

A 56-page booklet outlining the early history of Puerto Rico was published here yesterday to help high-school students in the New York area gain a better understanding of their Spanishspeaking companions.

AMMAN, Jordan, June 15-- King Hussein today dismissed Wafsi al-Tall, the most outspoken anti-Nasserite in the top echelon of the Government. Mr. al-Tall was replaced as chief of the Royal Cabinet by his uncle, Hussein Ben Nasser.
More than 500 boys and girls will compete in the Police Athletic League city track and field championships tomorrow at Victory Field, Myrtle Avenue and Woodhaven Boulevard, Queens.

PHILADELPHIA, June 15 (UPI)--Steve Blass, the winning pitcher, and Donn Clendenon delivered two-run singles in a five-run first inning outburst that carried the Pittsburgh Pirates to a 5-2 victory tonight after Richie Allen had driven in three runs to pace the Philadelphia Phillies to a 4-1 triumph.
The General Signal Corporation reached an agreement yesterday to acquire the New York York Air Brake Company in exchange for stock worth about $66-million.

NEW HAVEN, June 15-- Dwight Hall Memorial Chapel of Yale University was the setting this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Susan Meredith Davenny to Yehudi Wyner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lazar Weiner of New York. The bridegroom changed his name. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ward Davenny of Orange.
The city's property owners can expect to pay a basic rate of $5.07 or $5.08 for each $100 of assessed valuation beginning next month, the president of the City Tax Commission estimated yesterday.

TOKYO, June 15--Gabriel (Flash) Elorde, the most durable boxing champion of his time, lost the world junior lightweight title to Yoshiaki Numata of Japan tonight by a decision in 15 hard-fought rounds.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., June 15 (UPI)--Negro leaders, denied a conference today with Gov. Lurleen B. Wallace to discuss a 10-point list of grievances, led a march tonight without police protection on the state capitol.
TEL AVIV, June 15--Diplomatic sources reported today that the Soviet Ambassador in Jordan had offered King Hussein a gift of 50 planes but that the King was stalling.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 15 --Senator Robert F. Kennedy has been defeated in an election of five members to the Harvard Board of Overseers.
The city announced plans yesterday for $26.3-million worth of summer antipoverty programs to help calm its slum areas.

WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP)--The Justice Department is investigating possible violations of civil rights in connection with violence in northern New Mexico by a group seeking vast areas of southwestern land under Spanish land grants.
ALBANY, June 15--The state wants to step up summer programs in an attempt to head off racial violence.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 15--Following is the text of a letter from Arthur J. Goldberg, United States representative, replying to Secretary General Thant's telegram requesting views of members on an emergency special session of the General Assembly:

HOUSTON, June 15 (AP)-- Jim Wynn hit three basesempty home runs behind Mike Cuellar's eight-hitter and the Houston Astros beat the San Francisco Giants, 6-2, tonight for their third victory in the four-game series.

WASHINGTON, June 15-- The United Arab Republic's closing of the Suez Canal is threatening a break in the food pipeline to India--a development that American officials hope will lead to Indian pressure ...
While 20 million investors were wondering yesterday about the stock market, John C. Hammerslough was talking with his electronic computer on Wall Street.

BONN, June 15--Hundreds of West German youngsters have volunteered for military service in Israel, thousands of Germans have held sympathy demonstrations for that country, and a million marks (about $250,000) has been donated for the Israeli people.
Trading declined and prices turned mixed yesterday on the London stock exchange.
DETROIT, June 15--The Ford Motor Company is recalling 35,000 trucks to correct safety defects. A few chassis used for buses are included in the recall.

NORWALK, Conn., June 15 --Raymond Darrow Ritchie, who retired in 1962 as head of the Ritchie Construction Company in Stamford, died yesterday at Norwalk Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived on Silvermine Avenue here.

GENEVA, June 15--An Egyptian diplomat accused "the Israeli aggressor" today of having allowed "tens of thousands" of Egyptian soldiers to perish in the Sinai Desert without water or treatment of their wounds.

WASHINGTON, June 15-- The House rejected tonight President Johnson's plan for imposing a settlement in the rail labor dispute and substituted a measure providing for 90 days more of nonbinding mediation.
HONG KONG, June 15--ProMaoist groups in Anhwei Province in China were reported today to be fighting among themselves and indulging in widespread theft, assault and other forms of lawlessness.
GRANADA HILLS, Calif., June 15 (UPI)--Richie Ginther, one of three American drivers to win on the international Grand Prix circuit, said today he was retiring from racing.

PROVO, Utah, June 15-- Charlie Greene of Nebraska tied the world record for the 100-yard dash tonight as the National Collegiate track and field championships began at Brigham Young University. Running in a trial heat, the 22-year-old Greene raced the classic sprint distance in 9.1 seconds.
Dr. Albert Edward Sobel, a research biochemist, died yesterday at the Jewish Hospital of Brooklyn after a long illness. He was 60 years old and lived at 207-15 39th Avenue in Bayside, Queens.

HALSTON delved into the past for inspiration for fall, and history has rarely looked so attractive. The milliner-in-residence at Bergdorf Goodman decided he liked the mood and feeling of the Renaissance, and Halston's decisions invariably go to a lot of heads.
FORT SILL, Okla., June 15 (AP)--Pfc. Paul Richard Ilg was found guilty at a summary court-martial today of showing disrespect to a superior officer.
CHICAGO, June 15--At the age of 34, Princess Radziwill is about to fulfill a long-standing ambition--to appear on the stage.
Miss Amy Beth Linker and Peter Frank Bonoff were married here last night at the St. Regis-Sheraton Roof by the Rev. Dr. Nathan A. Perilman, rabbi of Temple EmanuEl.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The New Haven railroad reached the next-to-last stop today on its long journey to an Interstate Commerce Commission decision on the timing of its inclusion in a merged Pennsylvania-New York Central railroad.
ALBANY, June 15--The Court of Appeals tonight unanimously rejected a ConservativeRepublican candidate's bid to be seated as a Constitutional Convention delegate from the Bronx.
Owens-Illinois Inc., and Rayonier, Inc., which were planning to merge through a $295-million exchange of shares, announced jointly yesterday that the merger discussions had been terminated.

The General Learning Corporation, a joint venture formed less than two years ago by the General Electric Corporation and Time Inc. in an effort to capitalize on the "Knowledge industry," has just emerged from a major reorganization.

Considering that there are much richer, and certainly much older, thoroughbred races than the $50,000 added Bowling Green handicap, tomorrow's 1 5/8,-mile feature on grass certainly created an unusual stir at Aqueduct yesterday.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 15 --The Arab countries are considering sending their premiers or chiefs of state to the expected special session of the United Nations General Assembly on the Middle East crisis, informed sources reported tonight.

The stock market got back on the uptrack yesterday with price advances on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbering declines by a modest margin. Prices reached their highest levels of the day in the early afternoon and then eased off a bit in later trading.
Dr. Bernard E. Donovan, Superintendent of Schools, challenged principals and teachers yesterday to "break the shackles of tradition" and introduce new ideas to help children learn.
WESTBURY, L.I., June 15-- The audience that circled the round, white stage of the Westbury Music Fair last evening came to cheer Judy Garland, to adore her, to be overwhelmed by her.

DARIEN, Conn., June 15-- Chumbo, who was a disappointment as a runner at Tropical Park less than six months ago, won two green jumper classes today and moved into a commanding lead for the championship at the opening session of the Ox Ridge Club horse show.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 15--The United States refused today to concur in the Soviet Union's request for a special session of the General Assembly to hear charges of Israeli aggression and demands that Israeli forces retire from areas overrun in last week's war.

SYRACUSE, June 15--This city faces the loss of Federal funds for its $4.2-million antipoverty program on July 1 unless a squabble for control, primarily between major institutions and the poor, can be settled.

MOSCOW, June 15--Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin plans to fly to New York tomorrow to head the Soviet delegation at a proposed special session of the United Nations General Assembly. The Foreign Ministry confirmed the plan tonight.

BONN, June 15--Vice Chancellor Willy Brandt and a dozen other senior members of his party, the Social Democrats, sought to reach common ground with leaders of West Germany's rebellious student movement at a six-and-a-half-hour meeting today.

Berkeley Bell, one of the nation's top tennis players a generation ago, died of a heart attack yesterday after taking part in a tennis tournament for veteran players. He was 59 years old and lived at 25 Mezzine Drive, Cresskill, N.J.
GENEVA, June 15--A Bulgarian attack on the United States and Israel was ordered expunged from the record today at the annual conference of the International Labor Organization.
WASHINGTON, June 15--A House education subcommittee acted swiftly today to save the Teacher Corps, due to expire in 15 days.

CARDIFF, Wales, June 15 (AP)--Vicente Saldivar of Mexico staged a late rally tonight, including a 14th-round knockdown, and outpointed Howard Winstone of Wales to retain the world's featherweight boxing title.

Unionized laundry workers and their families will fill the New York State Theatre in Lincoln Center tonight to enjoy "South Pacific." Tomorrow at a Waldorf-Astoria luncheon the Amalgamated Laundry Workers Joint Board will distribute $30,000 in college scholarships to fifteen sons and daughters of union members.

MILL NECK, L.I., June 15 --Four hundred persons attended a supper dance given by Mr. and Mrs. Sonio ColettiPerucca and Mr. and Mrs. Philip A.S. Franklin at the Coletti-Perucca home here to present to society Mrs. ColettiPerucca's daughter, Miss Mary Jacqueline Astor, and the Franklins' daughter, Miss Jeanne Kerr Franklin. The debutantes are members this season of the New York Junior Assemblies.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., June 15--Harmon Killebrew cracked his 17th home run of the season today during a four-run rally in the seventh inning that gave the Minnesota Twins a 6-4 victory over the Detroit Tigers.
ENUGU, Nigeria, June 15 (Reuters)--Dick Tiger, the world middleweight boxing champion, appealed today to sports writers not to associate his name with Nigeria.
EL QANTARA, United Arab Republic, June 15--At the Bir Gafgafa prison camp this morning I saw what the tortures of thirst can do to a man.

Two men convicted last month of first-degree murder in the 1964 Central Park slaying of Charles T. Gallagher Jr., a nuclear physics professor at Columbia University, were sentenced yesterday to life in prison by Supreme Court Justice Irwin D. Davidson.

IN a tradition born of common-sense necessity, book reviewers rarely reconsider in print their previously printed judgments. There are, for one thing, too many new books to be discussed to spend much time and space rehashing old opinions.
CINCINNATI, June 15--Rioting spread to Cincinnati's fortress-like city workhouse today after a municipal judge handed down one-year sentences to 12 Negroes convicted of violating the State Riot Act.

LAWRENCE, Mass. June 15 (AP)--The city's 15 elementary schools and one high school were ordered closed today when most of the 350 pulblic school teachers failed to report for duty in a contract dispute.

A Brooklyn man imprisoned upstate since 1963 on his plea of guilty in a state narcotics case was ordered freed yesterday because, a Federal court held, the police had... obtained evidence with a defective search warrant.
CARL and Susan Chase hadn't wanted anything elaborate--just a simple transAtlantic crossing in a 60-foot schooner. Then, like plans for a small wedding, the operation started growing.
DAYTON, Ohio, Friday, June 16 (AP )--A rash of fires, some reportedly touched off by gasoline bombs, broke out in Dayton's racially troubled West Side about midnight last night.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday the election of Joseph H. Brown, a partner in the member firm of Reynolds Co., as a governor. He succeeds Gustave L. Levy, who was elected chairman of the exchange May 8.
LAKE PLACID, N.Y., June 15--There is a strong possibility that the tight-money bind of 1966 may recur this year, most likely in the fall, many of the state's leading bankers believe.

OMAHA, June 15 (AP)-- Top ranked Stanford eliminated Auburn, 5-3, tonight in a College World Series fourth round game on an error-filled four-run fourth inning. Rain shortened the game to seven innings.
LONDON, June 14 (AP)--Sir Edward L. Ellington, marshal of the Royal Air Force, died here yesterday. He was 89 years old.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., June 15 (AP)--Bill Shoemaker was suspended for five days today by Hollywood Park stewards for a faulty ride, a penalty that will cost him the ride on Damascus in the Leonard Richards Stakes Saturday at Delaware Park.
FORTUNE Magazine's annual run-down of Indus try's First Five Hundred has turned up some surprising facts about the so-called "conglomerate" company.

SPRINGFIELD, N.J., June 15--Max Elbin, the president of the Professional Golfers' Association, today assured the 150 professionals threatening to boycott the organization's championship tournament that they need not fear suspension.
ALBANY, June 15--The chancellor of the State University urged the Constitutional Convention today to guarantee the autonomy of the State University and the City University of New York.

Met with Secretary of State Rusk: Secretary of Defense McNamara; special assistants, Rostow and Christian, and special consultant, McGeorge Bundy; signed National Coal Week proclamation; saw Philip Talbot, United States Ambassador to Greece.

Nine men including John Lombardozzi, brother of the alleged Mafia leader Carmine Lombardozzi, were arrested yesterday when detectives raided a Brooklyn warehouse where they said they had found 900 cases of stolen gin.
A change in senior management was announced yesterday in Pittsburgh by PPG Industries. This producer of glass, paint and chemicals, was formerly known as the Pittsburgh Plate Glass Company.

YONKERS, June 15--According to the judges, the track at Yonkers Raceway was "sloppy" for tonight's 1 -mile National Championship Pace. According to Jirn Dennis, who guided pintsized Adios Vic to his second straight victory, the half-mile oval was "heavy and tiring."

LONDON, June 15--Admirers of Richard Strauss's "Die Frau Ohne Schatten" found last night that the opera could be as impressive in an old, technologically underdeveloped house as in the Metropolitan, where it was introduced last season using all the mechanical marvels of a new stage.
The city put a ban yesterday on the use of lawn sprinklers on Staten Island because of a sharp rise in water consumption there.

WASHINGTON, June 15-- Mickey Mantle, returning to the Yankees' starting line-up after missing five games, smashed a 462-foot homer in the sixth inning and doubled in the ninth to power New York to a 2-0 victory over the Washington Senators tonight.
PARIS, June 15--President de Gaulle and Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin will confer about the Middle East crisis tomorrow when the Soviet leader stops here on his way to the United Nations.
Owners of Solvay et Cie., meeting in Brussels this week, voted to change from a limited partnership to a publicly owned company effective July 1.

Premier Nguyen Cao Ky of South Vietnam has pronounced judgment: 600,000 American troops are needed to win the war in Vietnam. He calmly, and with apparent confidence, made his desires known a few hours after the Pentagon announced that Secretary of Defense McNamara, Under Secretary of State Katzenbach and others are flying to Saigon Sunday.

SPRINGFIELD, N.J., June 15--Soaring high and straight, Arnold Palmer's drive landed in the middle of the 14th fairway and hopped a few more yards, a total of perhaps 270 from the tee. Behind the yellow ropes, a member of the gallery shook his head.

The marriage of Miss Nora Jane Roberts, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Roberts of Jamaica Estates, Queens, to William Alfred Leidesdorf took place yesterday afternoon at the St. Regis-Sheraton. The bridegroom is the son of Mrs. Joan W. Leidesdorf, who resides at the Stanhope Hotel, and Arthur D. Leidesdorf of 740 Park Avenue.
WASHINGTON, June 15-- The Senate will take separate votes on the charges of misconduct that form the basis of the censure resolution against Senator Thomas J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut.

Federal Judge Irving Ben Cooper yesterday cleared the Goodyear Aircraft Corporation, now called Goodyear Aerospace Corporation, of negligence in the crash of a Navy radar blimp on July 6, 1960, into the Atlantic Ocean off the New Jersey coast.
WASHINGTON, June 15-- President Johnson announced today that he planned to nominate Warren Miner Christopher, a Los Angeles lawyer, for the post of Deputy Attorney General.
TEL AVIV, June 15--Jacqueline Du Pre, the cellist, and Daniel Barenboim, the conductor-pianist, were married today in a private religious ceremony in Jerusalem.

William M. Miller, a vice president of the Singer Company before his retirement in 1958, died yesterday in Gracie Square Hospital after a long illness. He was 80 years old and lived at 200 East 66th Street.

Swift Co., the nation's largest meat packer, increased its profits 50 per cent in the half year ended April 28, despite a 3 per cent dip in sales from the year-earlier period, the company reported yesterday in Chicago.

The New York County Democratic organization urged the Constitutional Convention yesterday to include in the new State Constitution a provision permitting the use of public funds for political campaigns.

TRENTON, June 15--Gov. Richard J. Hughes signed a sweeping package of air-pollution-control measures into law today, including New Jersey's membership in what will be the nation's first interstate agency to control air pollution.
ALGIERS, June 12--President Nureddin el-Attassi arrived here today for talks with Algerian leaders.
In a friendly, but strange, country, without a letter from home and ashamed of their efforts on the field, the Cerro soccer club has become melancholy.
TEL AVIV, June 15 (Agence France-Presse)--A captured Egyptian general paid tribute today to Israeli tactics in the Sinai campaign of last week.

GENEVA, June 15--The International Committee of the Red Cross notified Dr. Gerhart Riegner, secretary general of the World Jewish Congress, today that it had obtained permission to visit Jews being held prisoner in Egypt.
NEW DELHI, June 15--The leaders of three Opposition parties vehemently denied today that they had received money from the United States before last February's election.

BRISTOL, England, June 15 (AP)--Jim McManus of Berkeley, Calif., turning in his second straight upset in the men's singles, and Stephanie DeFina of Hollywood, Fla., in the women's event, gained the semi-finals today in the West of England tennis tournament.
A shopping center in a onestory building has started to take shape in the northern Westchester community of Bedford.

Officials of Madison Square Garden, meeting with members of the New York State Athletic Commission yesterday, proposed measures to insure that there would be no recurrence of the rioting that had hit the Garden three times in the last two years, most recently on May 18.

For three weeks in September and October 1960, New York seemed to many to be an autumn nightmare as Nikita S. Khrushchev, Fidel Castro and other world figures darted around the city, pursued by demonstrators and guarded by policemen.
JERUSALEM, July 15 (UPI) --Israel offered today to exchange 4,500 Egyptian prisoners for the nine Israeli soldiers known to be held in Egypt.

TRENTON, June 15--Ralph A. Dungan, President Johnson's Ambassador to Chile and one of President Kennedy's closest aides, was named here today by Gov. Richard J. Hughes as New Jersey's first Chancellor of Higher Education.

SPRINGFIELD, N.J., June 15--He must have been a misplaced Met fan. He was trudging round the Baltusrol links, hid den in the thundering herd of galleryites but valiantly holding aloft a home-made sign. On one side it said: Arnie's Army." On the other side was a variation of a typical Shea Stadium exhortation, "Go Arnie, Go." When Arnie Palmer moves round a golf course, he never moves quietly.
With the presence of ships from four nations, including two sailing vessels, the Port of New York will be a ship-watchers' paradise for the next seven days.

WAGONER, Okla., June 15 --Mrs. Samuel S. Bradley has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Joan Etta Bradley of Brooklyn, New York, to Harry D. Mayo 3d, son of Mrs. Mae Clarke Mayo and Harry D. Mayo Jr. of Montclair, N.J.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., June 15--The police said in an autopsy report today that Miss Maren Bergrud, 43 years old, operator of a literary agency here and ernploye of the Right Rev. James A. Pike, Auxiliary Bishop of California, died of acute barbiturate poisoning yesterday.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 15 --Mrs. Stella McGehee Landis, former wife of the late James M. Landis, who was dean of the Harvard Law School and a Presidential adviser, died in her home here on Tuesday. Her age was 70.

Borrowing by businesses from major New York City banks in the week ended Wednesday rose by $463-million--a sharp increase by recent standards--although quarterly corporate tax payments were not due until yesterday.
ALBANY, June 15 (AP)-- The state's highet court ruled today that the National Renaissance party was entitled to use the Orange County court houses for meetings.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 15--Premier Nguyen Cao Ky said today that 600,000 American troops would be required to counter the increasing number of North Vietnamese troops in South Vietnam.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, June 15-- This morning, as she has most other mornings in the last month, Mrs. Janine Debray, Deputy Mayor of Paris, made the rounds of embassies and Government offices in this bleak capital for news of her son.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 15--South Vietnamese infantrymen supported by American helicopters, crushed a Vietcong battalion yesterday in a battle 84 miles southwest of Saigon, a South Vietnamese Army spokesman, said today.

The New York City police worked on plans yesterday to protect Soviet Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin, and possibly other world leaders, without--for the moment--the canceling of days off and the massive deployment that marked the comparable gathering for the 1960 United Nations General Assembly.
WASHINGTON, June 15-- United States officials said today that there had been "intimations" that the United States and Britain would be requested to withdraw from their bases in Libya.
Two community colleges of the City University of New York awarded diplomas yesterday in associate applied sciences and the arts at commencement exercises in the Bronx and Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, June 15-- When he was born in Shreveport, La., on Nov. 3, 1918, he was named for his father, Huey Pierce Long. But the Louisiana Kingfish, fearing that the name might be a burden to his son, soon renamed him Russell Billiu Long.

RYE, N.Y., June 15--Richard Stockton of Hackley School, Tarrytown, N.Y., seeded No. 1, defeated Walter Whiteley of Lawrenceville 6-2, 6-1, today to reach the final of the 36th annual Manursing Island Club Eastern interscholastic tennis championship.

WASHINGTON, June 15-- The number of major crimes in the United States during the first quarter of 1967 was 20 per cent higher than in the same period of 1966, J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, said today.
A flock of carpenters, electricians and stagehands has invaded the Sheep Meadow in Central Park to prepare for the Barbra Streisand evening there Saturday night.

SPRINGFIELD, N.J., June 15 --Although rain forced the International Business Machine Corporation to retract its computer-generated scoreboard alongside the 18th green in the closing hours of the United States Open today, a survey of spectators pronounced it a success.

IN some past world championships the North American team has lost points through excessive use of weak two-bids. This year in Miami Beach they were used more sparingly by the two American pairs and one Italian pair that employed them.

Three generations of the Morgan family, 22 adults and children, arrived by Rolls-Royce shuttle yesterday at Pier 86 from a midtown hotel, and sailed at noon aboard the superliner United States for a two-month holiday abroad.

WASHINGTON, June 15--Intercity truck tonnage and revenue freight traffic generated by carloadings on United States railroads in the week ended June 10 were both below the volume in the corresponding week of 1966.

WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP)--Several improvements have been made in the controversial M-16 rifle used in South Vietnam, Representative James J. Howard, Democrat of New Jersey, said today.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 15--Miss Linda Gayle McVeigh, the first woman managing editor of The Harvard Crimson, was married this afternoon to Thomas Jay Mathews 2d, who was executive editor of The Crimson. The Rev. James R. Blanning performed the ceremony in the Lindsay Chapel of the First Congregational Church here.

Representatives of performing dance companies will attend the first national conference of the Association of American Dance Companies in New York this weekend at the Park Sheraton Hotel.

DUBLIN, June 15--Mrs. John F. Kennedy and her two children, Caroline and John, were given a warm welcome today when they arrived to start a six-week vacation.

PARIS, June 16--The French Government today finally won special powers from Parliament to rule by decree in the economic and social fields during the next four months.

The naming of Lawrence S. Driever as a vice president of the International Nickel Company, Inc., was announced yesterday.
SPRINGFIELD, N. J., June 16--The American Broadcasting Company will televise play from 11 holes tomorrow in the third round of the United States Open at the Baltusrol Golf Club.

PASSAIC, N.J., June 16-- Abraham Preiskel, a retired architect and former Public Safety Director of Passaic, died in Beth Israel Hospital. Wednesday night as a result of head injuries received in a fall. He was 84 years old and lived at 198 Passaic Avenue.

TEL AVIV, June 18--Israel today accused the Soviet Union of hindering the search for peace in the Middle East.

Prominent figures in boxing paid their respects yesterday to Eddie Eagan, former State Athletic Commissioner and Olympic boxing champion.
A 33-year-old man killed his 22-year-old girl friend and himself yesterday, the police said, apparently because she had told him he was too old for her.

WASHINGTON, June 16-- An experimental program to im- prove relations between cities and the Federal Government and to give substance to Presi- dent Johnson's vision of new "creative federalism" will ap- parently be terminated June 30 as a result of Congressional opposition.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., June 16--The New York State Teachers Association reported today that 200 of the 730 Mount Vernon public school teachers had asked for jobs elsewhere next September because of the assertedly inadequate pay here.

Edward M. Gilbert, the form- et "boy wonder" of Wall Street, lost a key round yesterday in his effort to avoid serving a maximum prison sentence imposed on him after he pleaded, guilty to Federal and state charges of grand larceny, fraud and embezzlement.
The election of Alfred Katz as vice president of the Hat Corporation of America in charge of national sales for the Knox, Dobbs and Cavanagh divisions was announced yesterday.

The Central Branch Young Women's Christian Association, 610 Lexington Avenue (at 53d Street), is accepting registration for its "July Jubilee" for girls in the 7th through 12th grades.
BALTIMORE, June 16-- School teachers elected the Baltimore Teachers Union today as their bargaining agent with the school board.
The round of debut parties continued last night in the metropolitan area, in Washington and in the South.

The American Stock Exchange closed out a busy week yesterday by notching another gain.

Alfred E. Rosenhirsch of 120 East 81st Street, president of the International Commodities Corporation and board chairman of the International Commodities Export Corporation, both at 200 Park Avenue, died on Thursday at the Lahey Clinic in Boston. His age was 62.
WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP)--The Government extended export controls on copper and related products Friday for a two-month period instead of the usual sixmonth period.

DARIEN, Conn., June 16-- Gone Flyin' finally lost an open jumper class today at the Ox Ridge Hunt Club horse show, but he came right back and frustrated his rivals by winning the bonus-point stake to run his total to 17 points.
A slight improvement in waterfront employment in May over April was reported yesterday by the Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor.

MINEOLA, L.I., June 16-- Nassau County Executive Eugene H. Nickerson normally a placid individual, worked himself up into a mild rage today as he asserted that "under no circumstance" would the county pay the Metropolitan Commuter Transportation Authority's bill for maintenance and operation of the Long Island Rail Road.
PARIS, June 16--Freedom of speech may not be denied to conscientious objectors serving out their conscription periods in nonmilitary projects, it was ruled today by the Council of State.
CHICAGO, June 16 (AP)-- Heavy, serious flooding continued in central Montana today, although the Yellowstone River began to subside.

DUBLIN, June 16--A hundred scholars from 14 countries honored James Joyce in a two-day symposium that ended here today. BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 16--A leading Yugoslav newspaper suggested today that a power struggle might be going on in the United Arab Republic.

An incinerator explosion blasted a six-foot hole in a basement wall of the 16-story apartment house at 140 East 56th Street at 11 A.M. yesterday.

THE story goes (and rings true) that when Alfred H. Barr, Jr., approached Gertrude Stein on the subject of her leaving her collec tion to the Museum of Modern Art, she replied that she was not interested, since "You can be a museum or you can be modern, but you can't be both."
Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin and three Soviet diplomats took a brisk and unexpected march, in step, up a 12-block stretch of Third Avenue early yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP)--Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington, said today that Communist China's explosion of a hydrogen bomb made it imperative that the United States move swiftly to build a "light cover" missile defense system.

KUWAIT, Sunday, June 18 --An emergency meeting of 13 Arab Foreign Ministers unexpectedly broke up early today without any announced agreement on joint strategy to put pressure on the West to force Israel into withdrawing from occupied Arab territory.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 17--Troops of the First Infantry Division fought a savage three-hour battle today with the Vietcong's 271st Infantry Regiment in the dense jungle of War Zone D, in Binhduong Province, 43 miles north of Saigon.

PHILADELPHIA, June 17-- The Vesper Boat Club of Philadelphia scored its third straight victory of the season today by defeating the New York Athletic Club senior crew by six lengths against a strong head wind on the Schuylkill River. The winning time was 6 minutes 41.3 seconds.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., June 17--The marriage of Miss Frances Mary Poor to Benjamin Gaines, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. Gaines of Darien, took place this afternoon at St. Mark's Episcopal Church. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter S. Poor Jr. of New Canaan. The Rev. Grant A. Morrill performed the ceremony.

Not even the sympathetic presence of 2,000 nuns could spare the New York Mets from a kind of doomsday yesterday. They committed three errors, a wild pitch and a passed ball, made only five hits in their own behalf and were engulfed by the Chicago Cubs, 9-1.
READING, Pa., June 17 (AP) --Robin Roberts, the former Philadelphia Phillies's ace, said tonight he had pitched his last game for Reading in the Class AA Eastern League.
Loans totaling $24.4-million for fisheries and irrigation developments in two Asian countries were announced last week by the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank).

Renewed calls for additional American troops in Vietnam coincided last week with a continuing lull in the ground war. For the second week in a row, the number of Americans killed in action declined, but the trend since mid-February has been up, up and up again, and no one expected the present relative calm to last.

DARIEN, Conn., June 17-- The marriage of Miss Georgia Ellen Fowler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Woodruff Fowler, to James Lockwood Hazard took place this evening. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ellison Lockwood Hazard.

SYRACUSE, June 17--With distant thunder adding its voice to the applause of many in the crowd of 15,000 that lined the eastern bank of Onondaga Lake, Pennsylvania's varsity crew caught up with a victory today that had eluded the Quakers since the start of the century.

THE re-emergence of Antony Tudor as a major choreographer is now an established fact; perhaps the only question now is whether he ever really went away. The apparent facts of the matter are easy enough to see.

The appointments of five scientists to the new research advisory board of the Cities Service Company have been announced John L. Burns, chairman and chief executive officer. The board will concern itself with the new frontiers of science, such as in oceanography, nuclear energy and synthetic fuels.
WASHINGTON--Thurgood Marshall has much in common with the Supreme Court that he is soon scheduled to join--he made his name by demanding change, but many of those changes have now been made.
SPRINGFIELD, N.J., June 17--When Marty Fleckman shot a 67 to lead the first round of the United States Open on Thursday, he was asked if he had ever heard of Johnny Goodman.

Acid-tongued Vice Admiral Hyman G. Rickover unleashed verbal torpedoes at a major target the other day: Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara and the management revolution he has imposed upon the nation's armed forces.

A Transit Authority patrolman was shot and killed in Brooklyn Friday night, and yesterday the police said the events leading up to his death began five years ago when he told a passenger to take his feet off a subway seat.

MAN, for centuries a random hunter of the sea, is developing ways to farm it. Con fronted by the increasingly acute food shortage on land and visualizing much richer harvests than conventional agriculture can produce, pioneers in the new science of aquiculture, or mariculture, have plans to raise fish, shellfish and even plants by plowing the sea, warming areas by atomic energy, fertilizing and weeding the ocean, fencing off underwater farms electronically.

The parks Department's plan to provide 10 marriage caremonies and a mass reception outdoors in Prospect Park, Brooklyn, one Saturday this summer was severely criticized yesterday by City Clerk Herman Katz, who said "They would equate marriage with a common spectacle."

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., June 17--In the space vehicle assembly building here, an 82-footlong section of the Saturn 5 rocket lay on its side all week as technicians X-rayed every inch of its white aluminum alloy skin. They found a few hairline cracks.

Poker, not Buckpasser, was the ace in the hole for Ogden Phipps in the Bowling Green Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday. Competing as an entrymate with his much more highly regarded stablemate in the 1 5/8-mile race on the grass, Poker took the lead at the start, stayed there all the way, and finished a length and a half in front of the Cragwood Stable's Assagai.

During the fiercest fighting in Jerusalem week before last, two dozen men and women were engaged in a frantic mission to save the art and archeological treasures of the Israel Museum including some of the precious Dead Sea Scrolls.

WASHINGTON, June 17-- The Atomic Energy Commission, confirming that Communist China had exploded a hydrogen bomb, said today that the blast had an explosive force equal to several million tons of TNT.

John D. Rogers, who retired in 1962 as general manager of the Humble Oil Refining Company marine division, died of a heart attack Friday night in his home at 77 West 55th Street. His age was 69.

THE 36th annual rose festival of the Jackson Perkins Company will open at 10:30 A.M. Saturday in the company's 17acre rose garden in Newark, N.Y. It will continue through Sunday, July 2.

TWO disparate and widely held images of Dwight D. Eisenhower have been etched on the public mind by his long sojourn at or near the pinnacle of our national life. One, and by far the most prevalent, is an almost wholly romanticized picture of the soldier-statesman: a virtually idolatrous conception of the rugged and always amiable Good Guy, who capped a war hero's career with two practically fault-free terms in the White House.

WHEN making concrete repairs, or when building projects that involve working with cement or mortar, the home mechanic should remember that, to cure properly, cement work must dry slowly. The correct way to insure this in hot weather is to keep the fresh cement moist for at least two days-- by sprinkling periodically or by covering the surface with damp straw, pieces of burlap or even layers of old newspaper.

This week brings the end of spring and the start of summer, with the solstice next Wednesday evening. By coincidence, the moon reaches its full that night, but the solstice will not alter its radiance in the slightest. And the grass won't pause an instant in its growth, the pasture rose won't falter in its fragrance, the whippoorwill calling that night will keep right on calling. Thursday will be another June day.
