A 3,000-acre community situated amid the wooded hills and valleys of northeastern Tennessee is being offered for sale for $1-million.
ATHENS, Ga., June 17 (AP) Volunteers spending a noisy weekend in a simulated fallout shelter study dwindled from 750 to about 687 today, after a night spent sleeping on concrete floors.
Distribution of today's editions of The New York Times was delayed up to three hours by a work stoppage yesterday afternoon by the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union.

DURING the year thousands of trophies are of fered at the more than 500 dog shows held in the United States. But few have the significance of one that is to be awarded to the winner of the sporting group at the silver anniversary show of the Mid-Hudson Kennel Club at...

SPRINGFIELD, N.J., June 17--Putting has been responsible for Marty Fleckman's one-stroke lead after three rounds of the United States Open, judging by the statistics compiled by the International Business Machine computer at the Baltusrol Golf Club.

DARIEN, Conn., June 17-- Gone Flyin' completed the systematic destruction of his opposition today when he won the Ben O'Meara Memorial Trophy and clinched the open jumper championship of the Ox Ridge Hunt Club horse show.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 17-- Before darkness tonight, three starters in the Annapolis-toNewport yacht race were out of it because of disabilities, the committee boat had been damaged and one participant was in jeopardy of a penalty. Nobody was hurt.

A headquarters building with plastic windows will be erected in Greenwich, Conn., by the Society of Plastics Engineers. The society is an in ternational professional group with 13,500 members engaged in the chemical research, development and application of plastics.

McKesson Robbins, Inc., is scheduled to operate as three separate companies following its merger with Foremost Dairies, Inc., it was announced last week by Herman C. Nolen, chairman of the big pharmaceutical distributor. The three new companies would be the McKesson Robbins Drug Company, McKesson Liquor Company and McKesson Chemical Company.
Roger L. Stevens, chairman of the National Council on the Arts and Humanities, said yesterday that plans were being formulated to make grants for touring to four American modern-dance companies.

Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin of the Soviet Union arrived here at dawn yesterday on his first visit to the United States and on perhaps the most important mission he has undertaken in two and a half years in office.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., June 17 (AP)--A civil rights committee accused Texas Rangers today of harassing and intimidating Rio Grande Valley farm workers on strike in Starr Country and aggravating an already tense situation.
The Police Department unfolded one of the smallest and most compact security covers in recent history yesterday for Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 17 --George H. Kitendaugh sailed Niskayuna to victory in the Luders-16 Class race today during the season's ninth championship regatta for Yacht Racing Association fleets based East-of-Rye on Long Island Sound.
JOHN Creasey has the almost unprecedented ability to write as well as he intends to, and he does not always aim at the same level of quality.

NORFOLK, Conn., June 17-- Mrs. Dana Hyde Wynkoop Jones and Joseph Truesdale Talbot, both of New York, were married this afternoon in the Church of Christ (Congregational) by the Rev. Alan C. Hebard. A reception was held at the home of Mr. and Mrs. William Francis Russell, stepfather and mother of the bride.

Premier Kosygin's departure for New York, in the view of foreign observers in Moscow, highlights a sharp dilemma for Soviet foreign policy. The Mideast crisis erupted into a Kremlin already torn and uncertain about diplomatic goals around the world, and forced the Soviet leadership to make some basic decisions in a hurry.

ESCANABA, Mich., June 17 --George C. Wallace was greeted with frequent applause and three standing ovations tonight by American Legionnaires as he brought his unannounced campaign for the Presidency to Michigan.

WHITE PLAINS, June 17-- An important new Federal-state confrontation over jurisdiction over the Hudson River and a bitter civil-rights dispute took shape as the state prepared to disclose Thursday its preliminary plans for the Hudson River Expressway and for an adjacent shorefront park.

GEORGETOWN, Guyana, June 17 (UPI)--The Guyana Government said today that Jamaica had worked out a plan for mediation of the Anguilla independence crisis. Representatives of Trinidad and Barbados would assist Jamaica, it was reported.

AUSTIN, Tex., June 17 (AP) --Democratic officials in Texas said today that last night's affair here for $1,000-a-year members of the President's Club had wiped out the debt of the national Democratic party for the first time in 25 years.

STANTON, Del., June 17 (AP)--Damascus easily defeated five other 3-year-old colts as expected in today's $41,060 Leonard Richards Stakes at Delaware Park and became the stortest-priced winner in the track's history at $2.20 for $2.

Miss Barbara Anne Smith, daughter of Mrs. Royal Stone Smith of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Smith, was married yesterday to George Berton Delmhorst, son of Mr. and Mrs. Berton J. Delmhorst of Brooklyn and Stonington, Conn.

WASHINGTON, June 16--The Soviet Union is furious at Israel and no wonder. For the Israelis have destroyed the atmosphere of confusion, ambiguity, and deceit in which Soviet policy works best, and the Soviet Premier, Aleksei N. Kosygin, has arrived at the United Nations to restore it.

EXTREME sensitivity is coupled with several useful handling conveniences in the latest Weston exposure meter to reach the market. The unit is the Weston Ranger 9, a product of Weston Instruments, Inc. of Newark, N.J., which has been manufacturing meters since the 1930's. The price of the Ranger 9 is $70.

ENGLAND is the most astonishing of nations and perhaps the most nearly inexplicable. How did it happen that this "cold, foggy, mournful country"--the phrase is Emerson's-- isolated from the mainstream of history, small in population and meager in resources, torn by invasion and by internal wars, emerged in the 17th and 18th centuries as one of the great powers of the globe?

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 17--Under the impetus of a program to supply fresh vegetables to the United States Army, Vietnamese farmers who previously waded in muddy rice paddies are now growing bumper cash crops of such things as watermelons, hybrid corn and lettuce.
A concentrated effort is being made by the city to enroll all residents of the city who are eligible for Medicaid by July 1.

ATLANTA, June 17--The Army has denied a parole or bail for Capt. Howard B. Levy, the Brooklyn dermatologist, whose opposition to the war in Vietnam led to his conviction by a military court earlier this month.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, June 17-- For the first time in more than two years, the state-owned Bolivian Mining Corporation is facing a labor crisis.
GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador, June 17--The United States Davis Cup tennis team ran into surprising trouble from Ecuador today in the start of the American Zone final, but managed to take a 1-0 lead.
ADEN, June 17 (Agence France-Presse)--Nationalist terrorists last night blew up a vital pipeline that feeds oil to Aden from a British refinery in the desert 20 miles from here.

The first 14 passengers to step out of the silver Soviet airliner into the dawn at Kennedy International Airport yesterday were serious and rather rumpled-looking men. The 15th passenger was a woman with a pale but pleasant face and dark hair.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I. June 17--Miss Rowan Beaumont Gregory, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Alfred Thorne Gregory of West Hills, Huntington, was married this afternoon in St. John's Protestant Episcopal Church here to Thomas Leffingwell Shipman Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Shipman of Santa Fe, N.M.

DAVIDSON, N.C., June 17 (UPI)--Top-seeded Charles Owens of Tuscaloosa overwhelmed his high school teammate, Jim Ward, 6-0, 6-0, to win the junior crown in the Southern junior and boys' tennis tournament at Davidson College today.
PRINCETON, N.J., June 17 --Miss Elizabeth Morse, daughter of Prof. and Mrs. Marston Morse, was married this afternoon to Daniel B. Reardon 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Reardon of Hingham, Mass.
A continuing high level of imports and international travel was reported here last week for the New York Customs region by David F. Cardoza, acting Regional Commissioner of Customs.
THE growing of fuchsias along the Eastern Seaboard is a challenge, but it can be done with perseverance and a lot of know-how. Even where summers are hot and dry, fuchsias are not impossible to grow.

When the Soviet Union threatened to invoke sanctions against Israel several days ago, the Israeli state radio announced the report with appropriate gravity. An Israeli who had been in the Syrian fighting had a different reaction. "Sure," he said, "they will refuse to sell us spare parts for the captured Stalin tanks."
JACKSON, Miss., June 17 (UPI)--James H. Meredith announced today that he would resume his "march against fear" from the point where he was cut down by a sniper last year.

As Premier Alekkksi N. Kosygin left for the United Nations yesterday, a dozen Jewish men, wearing prayer shawls and skull caps, silently watched his departure from the portico of their synagogue opposite the Soviet Mission at 136 East 67th Street.

OCEANPORT, N.J., June 17 --T.V.'s Princess, owned by Mrs. J.A. Goodwin and ridden by Jorge Velasquez, drove to a convincing one and three-quarter length victory in the $29,250 Post-Deb Stakes at Monmouth Park today.

On Oct. 14, 1899, Reginald Denny appeared as Prince Charles in "A Royal Family" at the Court Theater in London. He was 7 years old. It was the first of hundreds of roles he was to play on stage and screen with leading stars on both sides of the Atlantic.
Representative Paul A. Fino of the Bronx accused Mayor Lindsay last night of knowing "very little about party regularity and party loyalty."

PARIS, June 17--Workmen this weekend began dismantling the "Toboggan, a rollercoaster like roadway erected beside the Louvre seven months ago to relieve traffic while the Seine Expressway was being built.

MOSCOW, June 17-Tass, the official Soviet press agency, delayed several hours tonight before reporting Communist China's explosion of a hydrogen bomb. The Tass report consisted of a 15-word announcement without comment.
An agreement to provide bank financing for legal services has been entered into between the Philadelphia Bar Association and the Philadelphia National Bank.

MADRID, June 17--A commission of the Cortes (parliament) this week approved the law of the National Movement, which shapes the political future of Spain as a perpetuation of the authoritarian Franco regime and ties it to a greatly strengthened Falangist one-party system.
PEKING, Sunday, June 18 (Reuters)--Hundreds of thousands of demonstrators took to the streets here today in celebration after the official announcement of the hydrogen explosion.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 17--The United States declared today, at the opening of the General Assembly's emergency session, that "all proposals" for peace in the Middle East must be debated, and not simply the Soviet call for condemnation of Israel.

DETROIT, June 17--Dave Duncan smashed a home run in the 19th inning tonight to give the Kansas City Athletics a 6-5 victory over the Detroit Tigers in the second game of a recordbreaking double-header.

BAY SHORE, L.I., June 17 --A moderate so'wester gave a fleet of 33 auxiliary cruisers a fine sail today in the annual invitation regatta for cruisers of the Bay Shore Yacht Club. The elapsed and corrected time winner for the 12-mile triangular race was Morris Goldsmith's Tamedur, the first across the line among the four competing classes.
CHICAGO, June 17--Undefeated Joe Horlen, with ninthinning help, won his eighth game today as the Chicago White Sox beat the New York Yankees, 1-0.

THE Beatles spent an unprecedented four months and $100,000 on their new album, "Sergeant Pepper's Lonely Heart's Club Band" (Capitol SMAS 2653, mono and stereo). Like fathers-to-be, they kept a close watch on each stage of its gestation.

The Right Rev. Jonathan G. Sherman, Episcopal Bishop of Long Island, has urged all clergymen and laymen in his diocese to refrain from buying state lottery tickets and to oppose the lottery "by whatever means their consciences dictate."

ESSEX FELLS, N.J., June 17--Miss Sally Sage Braddock, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Harold Braddock of North Caldwell, was married this afternoon to Robert Sunderland Dinsmore, son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Clay Dinsmore of Omaha. The Rev. Harry B. Whitley performed the ceremony in St. Peter's Episcopal Church.
HACKENSACK, N.J., June 17--The Eastern clay-court tennis championship began today at the Oritani Field Club with a flurry of opening-round matches, a surplus of enervating heat and some good news.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., June 17--Miss Norma Lynne Johannessen, daughter of Mrs. John MacPherson Brown of New Canaan and John Eric Johannessen of Englewood, N.J., was married here today to James Robert Saunders, son of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Saunders of New Canaan, Msgr. Francis X. McGuire performer the ceremony in St. Aloysius Roman Catholic Church.

WHITE PLAINS, June 17-- The marriage of Miss Carol Bennett and Kenneth Menno Brown took place tonight at the Ridgeway Country Club here. The couple's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Harvey Bennett and Mr. and Mrs. Joseph D. Brown, all of Eastchester. Rabbi Ludwig Nadelmann performed the ceremony.
JERSEY CITY, June 17-- Mrs. Sylvla Bergner has announced the enagement of her daughter, Miss Elisabeth Bergner, to Michael G. Steinberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Steinberg of Brooklyn.

THE first United States stamp ever to be produced by the gravure process will be the 1967 commemorative in the annual Famous American Artist's series. It depicts a painting by Thomas Eakins (18441916), "The Biglen Brothers Racing."

CAMP DAVID, Md., Jun 17--President Johnson maintained a reserved attitude today toward the presence in this country of Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin as the President ar- rived at Camp David for a weekend with Prime Minister Harold Holt of Australia.

WASHINGTON, June 17--Senior military analysts believe the announcement by the Chinese that they have, exploded their first hydrogen weapon will increase political pressures here for deployment of a missile defense around the United States.

TEANECK, N.J., June l7-- Oscar Godbout, the outdoors columnist for The New York Times, died early this morning at Holy Name Hospital here after having suffered a heart attack yesterday afternoon. He was 40 years old.

OLD WESTBURY, L.I., June 17--A 5-year-old boy romped gleefully this week over the split-rail and stone fences that separate the verdant fields of a magnificent 570-acre estate on Store Hill Road here.

NEW HAVEN, June 17--The marriage of Miss Katherine Louise Kersten, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard S. Kersten of Chatham, N.J., to Ens. Jonathan Miss Wallman, U.S.C.G.R., son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerold M. Wallman of Stamford, took place today.

BEDFORD VILLAGE, N.Y., June 17--Miss Muriel Terron Doyle, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Newsam Doyle 3d of Armonk, was married this afternoon to Scott William Sutherland, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Grover Sutherland Jr. of Perrysburg, Ohio.

SEOUL, South Korea, June 17 (AP)--About 3,000 students battled riot policemen today in Pusan, South Korea's second largest city, in continued demonstrations against alleged riggang of the June 8 elections. The streets of Seoul were quiet for the first time in six days.

HOLLYWOOD. A HOLLYWOOD actress awarded the lead in a television series was detailing the several ways in which, she was convinced, her agent had done nothing to help. "Of course, all agents are lice, except the ones that are snakes," she said composedly, even absently. Her friends nodded composedly, even absently.
Sixteen days before the arrival of summer, someone somewhere--apparently in Pennsylvania--turned on one light, air-conditioner or power tool too many and blacked out that state and three others.

THOSE who plan to see Morris Carnovsky recreate the role of Shylock in "The Merchant of Venice" at Stratford, Conn., need fair warning. Shylock has changed. In fact, the play opening Tuesday isn't the same as that in which Carnovsky scored one of the triumphs of his illustrious career when it was produced by the American Shakespeare Festival back in 1957.

Vito and Patricia Fontana had been living in a onebedroom apartment in Port Jefferson, L.I., for three years when they decided last summer, as many young married couples do, that a house is the best place to raise a family.
BRISTOL, England, June 17 (UPI)--Tom Okker of the Netherlands defeated Cliff Drysdale of South Africa, 6-2, 5-7, 8-6, in the final of the West of England lawn tennis championship.

NOROTON, Conn., June 17-- William H. Lynn Jr. of the American Yacht Club held a 2point lead over E. Chester Peet Jr. of the Larchmont Y.C. today after the first two races in the 25th Arms-White Trophy Star Class regatta were completed off the Noroton Yacht Club.
WASHINGTON, June 17-- The Federal Government will begin efforts next week to patch up one of its disputes with the building trades unions over alleged racial discrimination in construction.
Some men, like Michael Burke of the New York Yankees, have the presidency of a baseball club thrust upon them. Others seem to be born, or at least brought up, for this highly specialized task.
JERUSALEM, June 19--The Israeli authorities are moving quickly to make Jerusalem a single unified city before the issue of its status becomes a matter for negotiation.

CHICAGO, June 7--Middle West business leaders are urging the building of a foreign trade center in Chicago. Edwin H. Draine, a University of Illinois geography professor, asserts that the need for a coordinating center for greatly expanding foreign trade is critical because Illinois now tops all other states as the nation's leading exporter.

CEDARHURST, L.I., June 17--Miss Jean Meredith Herzog, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Herzog, was married tonight to Jeffrey Lee Forman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Forman of Roslyn Heights. Rabbi Edward T. Sandrow and Rabbi Alvan D. Rubin performed the ceremony in Temple Beth-el.

WASHINGTON, June 17-- Supporters of gun control legislation in Congress opened a campaign this week to stop what they described as a multimillion-dollar Defense Department subsidy of the National Rifle Association, the private civilian marksmen's and sportsmen's organization.
CINCINNATI, June 17 (AP) --The Cincinnati Reds called up Len Boehmer from their Buffalo farm club today to help fill the gap caused by injuries to two regular players.
ROCKINGHAM, N.C., June 17 (AP)--Jim Paschal and Richard Petty continue their duel for supremacy on the South's stock car racing circuit in the $75,000 Carolina 500-mile race tomorrow.

Miss Shirley Irene James, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Parker Kent James of Jackson Heights, Queens, was married there yesterday afternoon to John Peters Longshore Jr., son of Mrs. Longshore of Jackson Heights and the late Mr. Longshore. The Rev. L. Roper Shamhart performed the ceremony in St. Mark's Episcopal Church. Miss Irene Fahlander was maid of honor and Lynn Reed Patrick was best man.

I HAVEN'T read the other novels by Dick Francis, but if they are half as good as FLY ING FINISH (Harper Row, $4.95), I have something to look forward to. This magnificent thriller by an ex-steeplechaser never flags for an instant. Its chief asset is an offbeat hero who bucks the trend in suspense fiction by being a Spartan instead of a sybarite, though he likes girls too.

FIFTY years ago Frank Swinnerton published the book that made his name. Its title, "Nocturne," might fit his latest novel, which tells (in suitably muted tones) the story of a few women in the twilight of their lives.

The American maritime history course given each year in this country's most authentic marine historical environment --the annual Frank C. Munson Institute of American Maritime History--will get under way at Mystic Seaport, Conn., on June 26.

THE homeowner who enjoys having decorative plants or small shrubs near at hand on his porch, patio or terrace will find that he can do so most easily by building planter boxes in various sizes and styles.
ATHENS, June 17--About 800 more Greek political prisoners, banished to the deserted Aegean islet of Yiaros after the Army coup on April 24, were released today and allowed to return home.

MAHOPAC, N.Y., June 17-- Miss Naomi Barbara Waelsch, daughter of Mrs. Heinrich Waelsch of New York and Mahopac, and the late Dr. Waelsch, was married this afternoon to William Christopher Netzer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Netzer Jr. of La Crosse, Wis.

Ed Kolman and Harry Wright, familiar names to all Giant fans, are playing a behind-the-scenes role with Coach Allie Sherman's staff these days as the Giants prepare for the 1967 National Football League season.

REMNANTS of untamed countryside holding fast in the very teeth of the cities-- this is what Ann Sutton's latest book is about. "The Appalachian Trail," her ninth written with her husband, Myron, is an account of a wilderness environment, a guide to making one's way through it, and the testimony of two who were there. Well designed, mapped and illustrated, discursive, informative, it is a mountain-loving work, breathing fresh air.

CLEVELAND, June 15--A checkered pattern of progress and problems in the effort to clean up the nation's atmosphere emerged this week from an annual conference of 2,000 public officials, engineers and industrialists concerned with air pollution.

BLUE and red wooden apples, suspended in Connecticut apple orchards, are being used to lure apple-maggot flies-- hopefully to their ultimate doom. Coated with Tanglefoot, a sticky substance, the fake apples trap the flies so that growers can measure the extent of their activity and spray accordingly.

The basic police technique for controlling crime in Town Hall, as in every district of Chicago under Superintendent O.W. Wilson, is aggressive and massive preventive patrol. Intrepid, a strong contender for the defender's role in the America's Cup yacht racing series against Dame Pattie of Australia in September, broke her spare mast late Saturday afternoon in a practice session on Long Island Sound off New Rochelle, N.Y.
MILWAUKEE, June 18-- George C. Wallace returned to Alabama today, encouraged by friendly receptions to campaign appearances this weekend in Wisconsin and Michigan.
Who is the student activist --the collegian who demonstrates or organizes for civil rights, against the draft or the Vietnam war, or for more student freedom?
LISBON--Portugal is one of Western Europe's last low-cost labor frontiers, and an increasing number of foreign investors are responding to this incentive.
ATLANTIC CITY, June 18-- A special committee of the American Medical Assocition urged the parent group today to support the liberalization of abortion laws throughout the nation.
PARIS, June 18--Prime Minister Wilson arrived here tonight for private talks with President de Gaulle about Britain's application for membership in the Common Market.
STARS and stripes may not be with furniture forever, but they will last through fall, according to one producer exhibiting at the International Home Furnishings Market in Chicago.

In a 15-year leasing transaction carrying aggregate rent of more than $1-million, A.C. R. Advertising, Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary of Ted Bates Co., has taken 10,000 square feet on the 30th floor of a skyscraper being built on the east blockfront of Madison Avenue between 49th and 50th Streets.

JUNEAU, Alaska, June 18 (AP)--An Alaska educator and his 9-year-old daughter, whose light plane ran out of gas over the Yukon wilds Wednesday, were close to safety on their own when rescue came last night.
About the only things that are proliferating as fast as new products are the little helpers who want to help sell them.

Miss Laurie Jane Rosenthal, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Seymour Rosenthal of Woodcliff Lake, N.J., was married here last evening to Michael Roger Slater, son of Mr. and Mrs. James H. Slater of Rye, N.Y., and Boca Raton, Fla. Rabbi Jacob Shankman performed the ceremony at the Four Seasons.

CAMP DAVID, Md., June 18 (AP)--President Johnson and Prime Minister Harold Holt of Australia discussed today tensions in Asia and the Middle East and the special session of the United Nations General Assembly.
TEL-AVIV, June 18 (Reuters) --Israel today displayed a Soviet-built antiaircraft rocket that had been captured in the Sinai Deserrt.
BALTIMORE, June 18 (AP) --Woodie Held drove in two first-inning runs today, leading the California Angels to a 5-3 victory over the Baltimore Orioles.

China's entry into the ranks of the thermonuclear powers has often been forecast, especially since the explosion of Peking's first atomic bomb in October 1964. Yet its attainment at this particular time comes as a sobering shock to the rest of the world.

The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. said yesterday that the Negro in the United States has entered a new phase of selfassertion, in which he is no longer pleading for his equality but is simply demanding it.
MOSCOW, June 18 (AP)-- Departing Israeli diplomats reported today that the Soviet Union had withdrawn, at least temporarily, permission for Soviet Jews to emigrate to Israel to join relatives there.
Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin, who will plunge today into the furor of debate at the United Nations General Assembly, took the morning off yesterday to see New York at its Sunday best.
DETROIT, June 18 (AP)-- A strong showing by specialty cars, paced by Ford's Mustang, has played a major role in the rejuvenated auto sales market in recent weeks.

HOUSTON, June 18 (AP)-- Don Wilson, a 22-year-old rookie, pitched the first National League no-hitter in two years today, facing 30 Atlanta batters in hurling the Houston Astros to a 2-0 victory over the Braves.
Twenty-five white and Negro residents of the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn took a guided walking tour of the old Bedford Village neighborhood yesterday.
ALBANY, June 18--Governor Rockefeller said today that New York City had been given a check for $2,655,907 for work on the Seward Park Extension urban renewal project.
Former Mayor Robert F. Wagner, now vice president of the State Constitutional Convention, left the door ajar yesterday for a possible race next year against Senator Jacob K. Javits.
Printers of three of the city's newspapers voted overwhelmingly yesterday to ratify a three-year contract with The New York Times, The Daily News and The Long Island Press.
Alexander Slater, a lawyer here for half a century, died yesterday at the age of 76. He lived at 30 West 60th Street.

WESTPORT, Conn., June 18--Miss Margaret Ann White, daughter of John U. White of Darien and Mrs. Laura Schaefer White of Berkeley, Calif., was married this afternoon to Ilo Elmar Leppik, son of Mr. and Mrs. Eimar Emil Leppik of Beltsville, Md. The Rev. Edwin A. Lane performed the ceremony in the Unitarian Church in Westport.

Few experienced motorists will quarrel with the conclusion of the Automobile Club of New York that far too many highway signs remain obsolete, confusing, inadequate or deceptive. Improvements have been made in recent years, but a great deal more needs to be done.
PORT OF SPAIN, TrinidadTobago, June 16--Almost a generation ago, the Andrews Sisters were telling the world about American soldiers in Trinidad with a calypso tune called "Rum and Coca-Cola."
PASSAIC, N.J., June 18-- A. Theodore De Muro, a lawyer, died yesterday at St. Mary's Hospital here. He was 69 years old and lived in Nutley.

The Commissioner of Markets will hold hearings Wednesday on charges against a Queens milk bottler and a Queens milk distributor, accused of cheating customers by selling only partly full containers of milk.
CINCINNATI, June 18 (UPI) --National Guard troops pulled out of the city today after three nights of racial peace.

WHITE PLAINS, June 18-- Harry E. Taten, senior partner in the firm of Wasserman Taten, certified public accountants, of 501 Fifth Avenue, New York, died at White Plains Hospital yesterday of complications developing from diabetes. He was 65 years old and lived at 40 Hampton Road, Scarsdale.

NEW HAVEN, June 18-- Former Gov. William W. Scranton of Pennsylvania and Arthur K. Watson, a vice president of the International Business Machines Corporation, were elected today as trustees of Yale University.
Father's Day, and the three- day hot spell, ended with a heavy splash last night.
PARIS, June 18 (AP)--Manuel Santana of Spain defeated Roy Emerson of Australia today for the French international grass court tennis championship.

The Security forces guarding Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin were handed a tough and unexpected assignment yesterday: to improvise a security cover for the Soviet leader and his party during an impromptu 2hour and 40 minute tour of Manhattan.

The Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts is the major investor in Peter Ustinov's satirical comedy, "The Unknown Soldier and His Wife," to be produced by Alexander H. Cohen for the center's Festival '67. The play will open July 6 at the Vivian Beaumont Theater, and the center has put up $75,000 toward the $125,000 capitalization.
BARCELONA, Spain, June 18 (UPI)--Martin Mulligan of Australia upset Rafael Osuna of Mexico, 5-7, 7-5, 6-4, 6-3, today and won the singles final of the Conde de Godo international tennis tournament.

ELBERON, N.J., June 18-- In Temple Beth Miriam here this afternoon, Miss Elizabeth Ann Moore, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles B. Moore of Oakhurst, was married to Thomas Alan Mela, son of Mrs. Felix Mela of New York and the late Dr. Mela. Rabbi Aaron Lefkowitz performed the ceremony.

SPRINGFIELD, N.J., June 18--Jack Nicklaus won the United States Open golf championship today in record-breaking style. With a closing fiveunder-par 65, he finished with a total of 275, the lowest 72hole aggregate in 67 championships that have been played since 1895.

BARCELONA, Spain, June 18 (UPI)--Martin Mulligan of Australia upset Rafael Osuna of Mexico, 5-7, 7-5, 6-4, 6-3, today and won the singles final of the Conde de Godo international tennis tournament.

ELBERON, N.J., June 18-- In Temple Beth Miriam here this afternoon, Miss Elizabeth Ann Moore, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles B. Moore of Oakhurst, was married to Thomas Alan Mela, son of Mrs. Felix Mela of New York and the late Dr. Mela. Rabbi Aaron Lefkowitz performed the ceremony.

SPRINGFIELD, N.J., June 18--Jack Nicklaus won the United States Open golf championship today in record-breaking style. With a closing fiveunder-par 65, he finished with a total of 275, the lowest 72hole aggregate in 67 championships that have been played since 1895.
Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday the appointment of Herbert Berman and the Rev. Fr. James Oscar Lee and the reappointment of George D. Brown to nine-year terms on the Board of Higher Education.
TEL AVIV, June 18--In 130 hours of battle the week before last, Israel trounced the forces of three Arab nations and established herself as the paramount military power in the Middle East.
The Episcopal Church was urged yesterday to create its own permanent Board for Theological Education to help upgrade seminary education and to recruit better-educated men for the ministry.

What is astonishing about Chinese production of the Hbomb is not that the Chinese have been able to build one, but that they have felt they ought to. For a nation already armed with the thought of Chairman Mao Tse-tung, nothing would seem a more wasteful use of resources.

The National Broadcasting Company said last night it had learned that lie-detector tests had cast grave doubt on the testimony of two key witnesses in District Attorney Jim Garrison's investigation into the assassination of President Kennedy.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 19-- A storm that followed a protracted period of light-air sailing dismasted three yachts in the Annapolis-to-Newport race today and caused three others to withdraw for undisclosed reasons.

CLEVELAND, June 19 (AP) --Don Demeter's pinch homer and Fred Whitfield's run-scoring single in the eighth inning gave the Cleveland Indians a 2-1 victory over the Kansas City Athletics tonight and a sweep of a double-header. The Indians won the first game by 4-2.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 19--South Vietnamese, hardened to political campaign manipulations and electoral fraud over the years, are chuckling over a mimeographed opposition magazine listing 36 ways for the Government to cheat in the September elections.
The appointment of Richard Cole to the new post of president of the Lady Manhattan division of the Manhattan Shirt Company was announced yesterday.
BOSTON, June 19--The possibility of a national system for the distribution of water was suggested today to the National Watershed Congress.

SOUTH KENT, Conn., June 19--Mr. and Mrs. Eugene C. Quinlan of South Kent, formerly of New York, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Jane Quinlan, to Guy Alfred Peterson, son of Mr. and Mrs. C. Ernest Peterson of New Milford.

"Everyone is worrying about the long hot summer with its threat of riots," the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. said yesterday. "we had a long cold winter when little was done about the conditions that create riots."

SEOUL, South Korea, June 19--About 5,000 opposition party members and other citizens staged riotous demonstrations in downtown Seoul today in a continuing protest against irregularities and alleged vote-rigging in the National Assembly elections June 8.
The wholesale commodity price index rose to 98.6 on Friday from 98.4 on Thursday.

SEOUL, South Korea, June 19 --Four South Korean policemen and a villager were killed Saturday in a gun battle with four North Korean agents on a mountain near Taegu, 150 miles southeast of Seoul, it was announced today.

Interest rates on bonds continued to work their way higher yesterday. Prices of oustanding corporate bonds fell and a new issue to be offered today was priced to yield investors four basis points--or four-hundredths of a percentage point--more than a similar offering last week.
WASHINGTON, June 19 --Congressional hearings on the future of the campaign against poverty continued today with nothing but kind words from members of both parties about neighborhood health centers.

AS the summer solstice nears (it will be with us at 10:23 P.M. tomorrow, marking the official beginning of summer), a singular regularity in the performance of the New York Mets can be discerned--a regularity as marked, in its way, as the courses of celestial bodies.

GENEVA, June 19--The chief negotiators of the United States and the European Economic Community, or Common Market, met today in a bid to overcome last-minute obstacles in the Kennedy round of tariff bargaining.
WHITE PLAINS, June 19-- The Westchester County Board of Supervisors approved today a controversial, weighted reapportionment plan that it hoped would survive the oneman, one-vote test.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, June 19--St. Edward's Roman Catholic Church was the setting here this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Joan Victoria Rousseau, daughter of Mrs. Roberts Rousseau and Arsene A. Rousseau, both of Youngstown, to First Lieut. James Cameron Argetsinger 2d, U.S.A.R., son of Mr. and Mrs. Cameron Reynolds Argetsinger of Burdett, N.Y.

AMMAN, Jordan, June 19-- King Hussein urged the Arab world today to accept realities and make the disaster of the war against Israel "a turning point for the better." He called for "new policies, new thinking, a new approach."
ATLANTIC CITY, June 19-- Couples who elect to use birth control pills as a long-term method of contraception improve their emotional adjustments to marriage, a Cleveland psychiatrist reported today.
The United States and Foreign Securities Corporation, a closed-end investment company, announced here yesterday the election of John Lintner as a director.

EXTENSIVE television and radio coverage was ac- corded yesterday morning to President Johnson's address in Washington and to the emergency session of the United Nations General Assembly in New York. The combined proceedings preempted most programs from 9:30 A.M. to 1:30 P.M. on the networks and some independent outlets.
Japan's merchant marine, at 13 million gross tons the world's fifth largest, is scheduled to grow to 22 million tons by 1971.

Andrei Voznesensky, who was reported to have been under heavy attack from the conservative faction of the Soviet Writers Union, has canceled his poetry recitation engagement tomorrow evening in Lincoln Center's Summer Festival.

Today is the last day of spring--a season that seems to have lost its touch. The weather forecaster said it would be a cloudy, sullen day with occasional sprays of rain possible.

Mrs. Dorothy Friedlander Geller, wife of State Supreme Court Justice Abraham N. Geller, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital after a long illness. She was 56 years old and lived at 47 East 88th Street.

STANFORD, Calif., June 19 --Miss Carole Anita Proper, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clyde H. Proper Jr. of Bayside, Queens, New York, became the bride this afternoon of Michael Edward Grace, son of Mr. and Mrs. B.A. Grace of Vaucluse, Sydney, Australia, in Stanford Memorial Church. The Rev. B.D. Napier, an Episcopal minister and dean of the ohurch, performed the ceremony.

World sugar futures proved to be a one-way market yesterday--downhill. Early in the morning prices tumbled in reaction to a bearish rumor and then, when the report was denied, there was little reaction on the upside.

The Fedders Corporation had a sharp reversal in its operating results, showing a record profit on the third quarter ended May 31.

In a drizzling rain, the teachers' union turned out an estimated total of 5,000 members yesterday afternoon to march around City Hall Park and to pledge their resignations unless they achieve substantial pay and program gains.

Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin of the Soviet Union watched President Johnson's speech on television yesterday morning shortly before he drove to the United Nations General Assembly to deliver his own address on the Middle East.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 19 --Arthur H. Sherin of 10 Crestmont Road, who retired 11 years ago as a vice president of the Alcogravure Division of Publication Corporation, rotogravure printers of 640 Fifth Avenue, New York, died yesterday at Mountainside Hospital. He was 82 years old.
STANTON, Del., June 19 (AP)--Nick Shuk brightened a drab day at Delaware Park by winning his 2,000th race today on the same track on which he had his first winner in 1948.

TEAM events spread over a long period are becoming progressively more popular. One such contest is organized by the Long Island Industrial Bridge League, which ended its season last month. Twentytwo teams played a 10-session marathon to qualify four teams for a two-session final.

A lack of business is forcing the New York Trade Show Building at 500 Eighth Avenue, between West Thirty-fifth and West Thirty-sixth Streets, out of the transient trade show field.

The deck officers' union, which is striking against twothirds of the country's merchant fleet, was ordered yesterday to tell its members to return to work by tomorrow. Failing that, the union would have to put up $250,000 as part payment for passible damages.

ROANOKE, Va., June 19 (AP)--A special three-judge Federal panel was appointed today to hear the Norfolk Western Railway's suit against an Interstate Commerce Commission order that it include three smaller railroads in its system,
SAN DIEGO, Calif., June 19 (AP)--Two missing United States border patrolmen were found shot to death today in an isolated desert cabin.

As previously reported, the network found a fourth man alleging that the New Orleans prosecutor or his staff had offered financial inducements for testimony supporting Mr. Garrison's theory that the assassination was the result of a conspiracy.

A Channel 13 news program, which was forced off the air for lack of funds, will return next week thanks to a $30,000 grant from the General Motors Corporation.

Herman Boettjer, who retired in 1956 as general superintendent of Long Island State Park Commission, died yesterday in Brunswick General Hospital, Amityville, L.I., of cancer after a long illness. He was 78 years old.

Subscriptions for the American Shakespeare Festival's newly opened 13th season at Stratford, Conn., were reported to be the largest in the history of the nonprofit repertory troupe. The present enrollment of 7,000 represents a 100 per cent jump over last year, or $119,050 now, as compared to $57,000 in 1966.
WASHINGTON, June 19-- Yields on new issues of Treasury bills moved up today for the second week in a row.
The election of George W. Coalter as a trustee of the Bronx Savings Bank was announced here yesterday.
Manhattan Republicans will be on guard in today's primary against a move that would leave them without a Civil Court candidate in the Ninth District.

Welfare workers refused to perform their assigned duties at centers throughout the city yesterday, but the Welfare Department reported that all the centers were kept open and that no clients were turned away.

HOUSTON, June 19 (AP)-- Roger Maris's double in the 11th inning drove in Tim McCarver with the winning run tonight to give the St. Louis Cards a 5-4 victory over the Houston Astros and a half-game lead in the National League.
Scurry-Rainbow Oil, Ltd., reported yesterday that it had discovered a nickel-copper deposit bearing minor amounts of cobalt in northern Saskatchewan.
WASHINGTON, June 19--A senior Republican on the Joint Congressional Atomic Energy Committee reported today that Communist China tested an actual hydrogen bomb rather than an experimental prototype.

PASADENA, Calif., June 19 (UPI)--A series of radio commands was flashed to America's Mariner 5 spacecraft today, ordering it to perform a midcourse maneuver that put it on a more perfect path for a fly-by mission to Venus.
A group of Puerto Rican leaders charged yesterday that the Lindsay administration had failed to provide enough antipoverty programs for Puerto Ricans.

A graduation ceremony was held at Rikers Island yesterday for 115 young men in blue caps and gowns who had completed a job-training program credited with sharply reducing the number of youthful offenders who return to prison.

SLIGHTLY more than a dozen years ago Ben Hogan was blazing over the Augusta links on his final round with a five-stroke lead for the Masters championship and a clean shot at a record score. But when he reached the 15th, he cautiously played short of the pond on his approach to the green. Such a display of restraint puzzled Fred Corcoran, the golfing impressario, and he questioned the little Texan afterward.
Joe K. White, the president of the National Tuberculosis Association, died of a heart attack Saturday at his home in Noblesville, Ind. He was 80 years old.
TARRYTOWN, N.Y., June 19--Miss Judith Beth Robbins and Brian Sharoff of Lake Hiawatha, N.J., were married here this evening. Rabbi Paul R. Siegel performed the ceremony at the Tappan Hill Inn.
Bruno Sammartino retained his Madison Square Garden exhibition wrestling championship last night when his opponent, Prof. Taro Tanaka, was disqual-...
WARSAW, June 19--A warning to Polish Jews who support Israel was pronounced today by Wladyslaw Gomulka, the party leader.

MANHASSET, L.I., June 19--In Christ Episcopal Church here this evening, Miss Louise Helen Dowling, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Laurence Dowling of Munsey Park, became the bride of Dr. David Paul Roselle. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Roselle of Apollo, Pa.

MOSCOW, June 19--Almost the first thing to be noticed about the Bolshoi Ballet in its home town of Moscow is that after the Kremlin it is probably the No. 1 tourist attraction. For tourists, tickets are disturbingly easy to obtain. Each of the tourist hotels has a ticket agency, and you casually pay $3 or so for tickets the average Muscovite ballet-lover could not buy with teeth.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 19--A detachment of Soviet warships arrived today at the south Yugoslav port of Herceg Novi, on the Adriatic, the Yugoslav press agency, Tanyug, announced.

Mr. President, distinguished delegates: Representatives from al most all states of the world have gathered for the emergency special session of the United Nations General Assembly to consider the grave and dangerous situation which has developed in recent days in the Middle East and which arouses deep concern everywhere.
WASHINGTON, June 19-- Senate hearings on mutual-fund reform legislation, originally scheduled to start today, have been postponed until the end of next month.
Volume continued strong as prices edged up yesterday on the American Stock Exchange.

CAIRO, June 19 (Agence France--Presse)--Crowds shouted "Allah is great, we are with you, Gamal," when President Gamal Abdel Nasser appeared on television tonight, for the first time since he announced his resignation, later rescinded.
Braniff Airways said yesterday its net income in April fell to $93,000 from $1,720,000 a year before. The month's operating revenues climbed to $20,255,000 from $14,443,000.
WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) --The Pentagon announced today the elimination of a large backlog of Army national guardsmen and reservists who had been awaiting active duty training.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., June 19--A missile expert from private industry was named today to the new position of operations director at the Kennedy Space Center here.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 19--Secretary General Thant and the United Arab Republic disavowed today the late Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold's version of an agreement with Egypt to maintain United Nations forces on the 1956 armistice line with Israel.

BALTIMORE, June 19 (AP) --The Baltimore Orioles, beaten 4-0 tonight on three hits by Dave Boswell in the opener, routed the Minnesota Twins, 9-5, with a 15-hit attack in the second game of a twilight-night double-header.

Eleanor Holm, the former swimming star, has lost a $16million claim against the estate of her former husband, the late Billy Rose. She said that he palmed off two fake paintings on her when they broke up their marriage.

The Senate is called upon to express its opinion with respect to the conduct of the senior Senator from Connecticut. If the Senate decides to censure him, none of his Senatorial prerogatives and privileges will be withdrawn. He will remain the senior Senator from Connecticut.

MELBOURNE, Australia, June 19 (AP)--Lord Baillieu of Sefton, the Australian-born peer and millionaire industrialist, died Saturday after a long illness. Lord Baillieu, who was 77 years old, had been president of the Dunlop Rubber Company since 1957.

WASHINGTON, June 19-- The Chapel of the Resurrection in the Washington (Episcopal) Cathedral was the setting for the wedding of Miss Caroline Claire Willis to Bernard Keith Vetter, son of Bernard A. Vetter of Donaldsonville, La., and Mrs. Joel LeBlanc Vetter of Alexandria, La. The bride is the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William H. Willis of Durham, N.C.

DETROIT, June 19--Frank B. Woodford, former chief editorial writer of The Detroit Free Press and the author of nine books on Michigan history, died of a heart attack Saturday at his home here. He was 64 years old.
Rents in the New York area have risen faster in the last 10 years than in all but two of the country's 21 major cities, the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 19 (AP)--Home runs by Willie Mays and Jim Hart spurred the San Francisco Giants to a 6-3 victory over the crippled Cincinnati Reds today.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Tuesday, June 20 (Reuters)-- The Australian Davis Cup captain, Harry Hopman, expressed astonishment today at the United States defeat.
Americans are beginning to step up their buying of furniture--an important indicator of the state of consumer demand.
Alwin Nikolais was elected yesterday president of the Association of American Dance Companies.

LOS ANGELES, June 19-- The head of the rabbinic body of American Reform Judaism urged the Johnson Administration tonight not to enter into any "package deals" in an attempt to resolve the conflict in Vietnam, at the expense of Israel.

BIR GIFGAFA, United Arab Republic, June 12--When he met his Israeli victor, the captured Egyptian general handed him an engraved calling card It read: "Brigadier Ahmed E. Abd el Naby, Military, naval and air attache. U.A.R. Embassy, Pakistan."
OMAHA, Neb., June 19 (UPI) --Fifteen-hundred Young Republicans gathered today for their 15th biennial national convention and a week of political haymaking.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 19 (UPI)--The Iraq Petroleum Company began pumping oil again today across Syria to its Mediterranean Sea terminal in Lebanon. But officials said that none of the oil would go overseas.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, June 20--American infantrymen fought a major battle in the Mekong River delta last night and early this morning, killing 169 Vietcong.
LONDON, June 19--The Greater London Council is advertising in The New York Times for a $20,300-a-year traffic commissioner to help solve London's traffic problems.
The London Stock Exchange was irregular yesterday as investors remained on the sidelines.
Rheingold Breweries said yesterday that it would pay the total cost for cleaning the debris left at Barbra Streisand's concert in Central Park's Sheep Meadow Saturday night.

MARION, Mass., June 19-- Mr. and Mrs. Motley Sawyer have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Kathryn Margaret Sawyer, to Ewart John White 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. White of Princeton, N.J. The wedding is planned for late August.
OCEANPORT, N.J., June 19 (AP)--Mrs. C.F. Parker's Wild Note, ridden by Jacinto Vasquez, splashed to a 2 -length victory today in the six-furlong feature at Monmouth Park.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., June 19--Mrs. Raymond T. O'Connell, who was active in village politics and conservation movements, died yesterday at the United Hospital in Port Chester. She was 71 years old and lived at 748 Halstead Avenue.

WASHINGTON, June 19-- The great expectations of the Johnson Administration for quick and beneficial development of elected government in South Vietnam may have been premature. Like so many other aspects of the situation in that tortured country, the forthcoming elections are simply not going according to plan.
HARTFORD, June 19--A Federal court ruled today that a one-year residency requirement for payments under Connecticut's aid to dependent children law is unconstitutional.

Mr. and Mrs. Paul W. Kayser of 605 Park Avenue have made known the engagement of Mrs. Kayser's daughter, Miss Joan M. Harper, to Richard T. Grimm, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert T. Grimm of Sands Point, L.I.A September wedding is planned.

The Millard William Shroder Company, which has built a number of Manhattan office, hotel and apartment buildings, is moving its headquarters to new offices at 150 Purchase Street, Rye, N.Y., from 441 Lexington Avenue, where it has been for 10 years.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 19--A ceremony to mark the issuance of a new United Nations stamp was canceled today because of the emergency session of the General Assembly. However, stamps with first-day cancellations were available at the United Nations Children's Fund greeting card offices at 331 East 38th Street.

JERSEY CITY, June 19-- With an important assist from a 6-year-old boy, the police arrested two men and a woman today within two hours after they allegedly robbed the Western Slope branch of the First National Bank of Jersey City of $5,097.
TEL AVIV, June 19 (Reuters) --Former Premier David BenGurion suggested today that an autonomous Arab state should be formed on the west bank of the Jordan River, in the area now occupied by Israel.
DETROIT, June 19--A work stoppage by Detroit policemen erupted again today in the wage dispute between the city and the patrolmen's union.

YONKERS, June 19--Roquepine of France and Dashing Rodney of Italy, having passed the customary tests all foreign horses must undergo upon arrival in the United States, were vanned from the Department of Agriculture Quarantine Station at Clifton, N.J., to Yonkers Raceway late today. With the arrival of the pair of 6-year-old foreign aces, the entire field of eight for Thursday night's Gotham Trot was here.

Miss Elaine Beth Pezrow became the bride last night of Frederick E. Werbell, son of Mrs. Anna Werbell and the late Joel Werbell of Stockholm. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth J. Pezrow of 1020 Park Avenue.
The New York Giants signed Phil Harris, a second-year defensive back, and Bob Kenney of Yale, a rookie end, yesterday.

Yesterday's heavy rainfall forced the postponement of several sports events in the metropolitan area. The scheduled Yankee baseball game against the Boston Red Sox at Yankee Stadium was called off early in the day and rescheduled for Thursday night.

WUELFRATH, Germany, June 19 (AP)--Neal Shapiro of Brookville, L.I., riding San Pedro, took second place in the Equestrian Grand Prix tournament yesterday and two others United States team members finished in the top seven.
Sweden's ombudsman, the public's guardian against arrogant or bumbling bureaucrats, said yesterday that 90 per cent of the complaints he received proved to be unfounded.

Seventy-eight per cent of persons in a national cross section who were asked by the Louis Harris Poll about the extent of draft evasion said that some or a lot of young men engaged in the practice, according to an article yesterday by Mr. Harris in the New York Post. The poll showed that 13 per cent said there was little or no evasion and the rest were unsure.
Steel production fell 3.1 per cent last week to the lowest level for a non-holiday week in more than 18 months, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP)--Representative Melvin R. Laird, chairman of the House Republican Conference, said today that while he did not like the idea, he would probably have to support a sizable tax increase this year.
TAMPA, Fla., June 19 (AP) --Gov. Claude R. Kirk Jr. commended more than 50 Negro youngsters today for trying to calm Tampa's racial violence last week.
The Board of Higher Education took steps last night to create the first link between the City University of New York and a medical school.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 19--Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin asked the General Assembly today to demand Israeli reparations for war damage to the Arab states, to condemn Israel as an aggressor and to call for the withdrawal of her victorious forces from Arab territory.

NEWARK, June 19--The head of the New Jersey State A.F.L.-C.I.O, called on the trade union movement today to purge itself of Vietnam war critics who show disrespect for the flag or draft laws, or encouraged others to do so.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 19 (AP)--Barry Goldwater, the Republican nominee for President in 1964, said today that he felt his party's chances of winning the Presidency next year were not quite 50-50 as things stand now.

WASHINGTON, June 19-- Vice Adm. Randall Jacobs, who was described as the man who furnished the men for the Navy during World War II, died today in Bethesda (Md.) Naval Hospital after a long illness. His age was 81.
Wallachs, New York retail apparel chain, announced yesterday the appointment of Donald G. Carney as general merchandise manager.
LONDON, June 19--The Labor Government, in a major shift of policy, decided today to provide continuing military support for the Federation of South Arabia after it becomes independent next year.

TRENTON, June 19--Gov. Richard J. Hughes nominated a former Secretary of the Treasury, three other businessmen, a teacher, a publisher and a League of Women Voters official today to be members of the new State Board of Higher Education.

ACF Industries, Inc., increased earnings by $5-million to a new record for the fiscal year ended April 30, but fourthquarter earnings dipped from the corresponding final quarter earnings of the preceding year.

THIS new life of Jesus by an Italian editor and teacher expresses great admiration and respect for the man from Nazareth, but much less so for those who exploited--if that is not too strong a term--what he stood for and what he taught.

TRENTON, June 19 (UPI)-- The Appellate Division of Superior Court ruled today that New Jersey was not the proper jurisdiction for a suit brought by the trustee in bankruptcy of the Allied Crude Vegetable Oil Refining Corporation against a New York corporation.
LONDON, June 19 (UPI)-- The Sunday Citizen published its last issue yesterday. It was founded 117 years ago as Reynolds weekly newspaper.
CHINA'S weekend hydrogen bomb explosion re verberated in Wall street yesterday as traders sized up another threat to world peace.

Floyd B. McKissick, the executive director of CORE, said yesterday that the organization's coming 24th national convention was expected to move the CORE concept of black power "from slogan and philosophy to operational programs."

CAMDEN, N.J., June 19 (AP) --The rank and file of the International Union of Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers has turned down a new threeyear contract offer from the Radio Corporation of America.
The spot rate on the British pound closed 4 points lower at $2.7917, after very quiet trading on, foreign-exchange markets here yesterday.
The appointment of Robert W. Haigh as group vice president of the Xerox Corporation and general manager of its education division was announced yesterday in Rochester.

On any day, the Welfare Department's neighborhood center at 260 West 30th Street is a busy place. There are the aged, the disabled and the many welfare recipients who live alone in the area's rooming houses--all included among the 7,500 cases handled at the Amsterdam center.

The 12 teams of the United Soccer Association were warned yesterday by the league commissioner, Dick Walsh, that if disturbances by unruly spectators continued, the league would take disciplinary action. Walsh urged club officials to review crowd-control measures with stadium security officials.

FOR Stella Adler, there is no generation gap. On stage or off, she shakes up the members of the younger generation as she did their fathers before them. Any gathering in her home is likely to include a melange of ages, each sure of acceptance on its own level.
WASHINGTON, June 19-- The Government has, for some time, been concerned over shortages of doctors, nurses and other health specialists.
CHICAGO, June 19 (UPI)-- --A coroner's jury finally delivered a verdict of murder today in the slaying of eight young nurses more than 11 months ago.

WASHINGTON, June 19-- A Federal judge ruled today that segregation of poor Negro children in the public schools of the District of Columbia that results from neighborhood population patterns is as unconstitutional as segregation ordained by law.

BUENOS AIRES, June 19-- A new oil law that for the first time in 32 years permits foreign companies to own new concessions for the exploration and transportation of Argentine hydrocarbons is about to be decreed here.

MONTREAL, June 19 (Canadian Press)--The liner Sylvania, which ran aground Thursday on a shoal in the St. Lawrence River 100 miles downstream from Montreal, returned to the harbor here under her own power early today after being pulled free yesterday.

The Columbia Pictures Corporation, whose financial fortunes have taken a sharp turn for the better, had record earnings for any quarter in the three months ended April 1. And earnings in the fiscal first nine months were the second largest in history, Abraham Schneider, president, reported yesterday.
CINCINNATI, June 19-- Mrs. Jane Blach Warner of Cincinnati was married today to Dr. Albert Sabin, discoverer of an anti-polio vaccine.

HONOLULU, June 19--Mayor Jerome P. Cavanagh of Detroit formally opened the 1967 meeting of the United States Conference of Mayors today with a call to the cities to "step up the psychological and political fight for our programs."

LEXINGTON, Mass., June 19--Mrs. Olive Russell Frost has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Carol Frost, to Stephen Alan Ross. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur I. Ross of Brookline, Mass. A wedding in August is planned.

PARIS, June 19--A final round of negotiations on reform of the world's monetary, system began here today on one of the tangents to the fundamental issue of whether the world needs something new or simply an enlargement of the present system.

Senator Jacob K. Javits discounted yesterday former Vice President Richard M. Nixon's chances of winning substantial support for the Presidential nomination among the New York delegates to the 1968 Republican convention.
NEW DELHI, June 19--The Indian Government restricted the movements of Chinese Embassy officials here today in retaliation for a Chinese siege of Indian Embassy officials and their families in Peking.

WASHINGTON, June 19-- The chairman of the Interstate Commerce Commission said today that a decision on the petition of the trustees of the New Haven Railroad to have that carrier taken over by a merged Pennsylvania and New York Central Railroad could be issued by his agency by "late this summer."
The jet airplane is increasingly coming to the aid of its traditional rival, the ship.
DETROIT, June 19 (AP)-- The automobile industry scheduled further 1967 car cutbacks today as it headed toward next month's big phasing-out program of current models.
IF the labor movement in New York ever needs some one to organize "happenings," the name of Judith Mage could top the list.

ATLANTA, June 19 (UPI)-- A supermarket food-price war shaped up in Georgia today. The Kroger Company announced price cuts on 2,000 food items and said it was closing its stores today and tomorrow to mark down prices. It said the slashes would be effective in its Atlanta division and in Birmingham, Gadsden and Anniston, Ala.

Senator Robert F. Kennedy said yesterday after a helicopter and auto tour of air-pollution sources in the metropolitan area that despite increased concern, "we are just as close to an air-pollution disaster as we were last Thanksgiving."
WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) --Naval shipyards will be modernized in a $600-million improvement program, if the Navy has its way.

ELIZABETH, N.J., June 19 --Kinsey N. Merritt, formerly of this city, a retired vice president of the Railway Express agency, which he served 50 years, died yesterday at his home at Meadow Lake Village, Hightstown, of a heart attack. His age was 76.
HOUSTON, June 19--Cassius Clay, the former heavyweight boxing champion, went on trial in Federal court here today on a charge of refusing to be drafted into the United States armed services.

ATLANTA, June 19--The police fired pistols and shotguns into the air tonight to disperse a mob of rock-throwing Negroes that gathered near a shopping center after a fiery speech by Stokely Carmichael, black power advocate.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 19--There were only three mildly hopeful signs in the torrent of vindictive rhetoric in the Middle Eastern debate at the United Nations today:

SCARSDALE, N.Y., June 19 --George Fred Pelham 2d, an architect who designed many apartment houses in New York, including Castle Village in Washington Heights, died yesterday in his home, 281 Garth Road, after a long illness. His age was 70.

DETROIT, June 19 (UPI)-- Denny McLain pitched a fourhitter to give the Detroit Tigers a 5-1 victory tonight after the California Angels had won the opener of a twilight-night double-header, 2-0, on Rick Reichardt's two-run homer in the eighth inning.
MOSCOW, June 19--"Caviar? Where did you come from, the Moon? We don't have caviar any more."

CANTON, Ohio, June 19-- Mr. and Mrs. John Clayton Carver of Canton have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Carver, to James Bain Brickell Jr., son of Mrs. James McClenehan Mertz of Rye, N.Y., and Mr. Brickell of Easton, Md.
RAHWAY, N.J., June 19 (AP)--Herbert T. Kinch has been named police chief of this industrial city of 27,000, becoming the first Negro to head a police department in northern New Jersey.
The stock market closed on the fence yesterday with price declines on the New York Stock Exchange slightly exceeding advances.

GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador, June 19 (AP)--Ecuador's giant-killers ended the United States hopes to win the Davis Cup when Francisco Guzman beat Arthur Ashe, 0-6, 6-4, 6-2, 0-6, 6-3, to clinch the American Zone final series today.
Transamerican Trailer Transport, Inc., signed a lease yesterday for 10,000 square feet of office space in The Narrows, Staten Island's newest office building, at 358 St. Mark's Place.
WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The National Teacher Corps, due to expire in just 12 days, won a reprieve today from the House Education and Labor Committee.

ALBANY, June 19--The Constitutional Convention got the word today that it could begin debate on its first issue, but some delegates were caught unprepared. As a result, the convention adjourned for a week without taking any action.

NEW DELHI, June 19--The Indian Government is not planning to put any pressure on the United Arab Republic to reopen the Suez Canal, even though food assistance to India has been badly disrupted by the closing of the waterway.
NEW HAVEN, June 19--Federal District Judge Robert P. Anderson appealed today for Congressional legislation to save the New Haven Railroad from a financial "cataclysm" at the end of the year.
Thirteen of the 31 faculty members dismissed by St John's University in December 1965, agreed yesterday to accept the university's offer of arbitration.

Who's on Fifth? The question was asked recently by a client of a real estate firm. The answer found was: A growing number of different types of businesses besides the retail fashion shops that gave the famous shopping thoroughfare its reputation.

GENEVA, June 19--Willy Spuehler, Swiss Foreign Minister, said today that the aims of Swiss foreign policy were "identical" with those of the United Nations, but that the organization had not "until now" accepted the Swiss concept of neutrality.

WASHINGTON, June 19-- President Johnson served notice today that he would not press Israel to pull back her victorious armies from occupied territory until the Arab nations joined with Israel in efforts to promote a peaceful settlement.

WASHINGTON, June 19-- American Broadcasting Companies, Inc., informed the Federal Communications Commission today that at least 30 days would be required, after Government approval, for it to merge with the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation.

Don Wilson of Houston pitched the first indoor nohitter in major league baseball history on Sunday at the Astrodome against the Atlanta Braves. The fact that he had was conveyed to those in Shea Stadium, watching a doubleheader between the New York Mets and Chicago Cubs, by means of the message board.
LEONARD FISHER of Cartier's (Fifth Avenue at 52d Street) and Erwin Pearl of Veneto 57 (6 West 57th Street) have both come up with jewelry collections that draw their inspiration from Africa.

The Pennsylvania and New York Central Railroads filed a motion in Federal Court here yesterday requesting the court to have all the parties to the Erie-Lackawanna Railroad's court action to bring their pleadings up to date in view of a recent Interstate Commerce Commission decision. The ErieLackawanna previously asked the court to enjoin the proposed Pennsylvania-Central merger.

TRENTON, June 18--Gov. Richard J. Hughes's task force on migrant farm labor strongly urged a long list of reforms today, including subsidizing migrant parents who put their children in schools rather than to work in the fields.
A magazine article reporting that Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin had personally sought to dissuade Svetlana Alliluyeva from going to India in November was challenged yesterday by her lawyers.
A Harlem Cultural Festival, running the gamut from a Soul Music Night to a Boxing, Wrestling, Judo and Karate Night, was announced yesterday by the Parks Department.

TEL AVIV, June 19 (AP)-- Israel appealed to the world's Jews today to help her move from military victory to an era of greater economic growth.

WASHINGTON, June 19 (UPI)--Senator John J. Williams, Delaware Republican, said today that five American farms had received Government subsidy payments of at least $1-million each in 1966. He said that payments of more than $500,000 each went to 11 farms and 258 got payments of $100,000 or more.

In voting unanimously to invalidate Virginia's antimiscegenation statute, the Supreme Court has affirmed that choosing a husband or wife lies in the inviolable area of personal freedom that government may not enter.

Herbert Weichmann, MayorGovernor of Hamburg, arrived in New York from Montreal yesterday to attend a round of official functions in relation to the Hamburg State Opera's appearances at the Lincoln Center Festival '67.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, June 9 (UPI)--A Soviet submarine surfaced alongside a disabled Danish fishing boat and towed it into port yesterday, the vessel's owner disclosed today.

MONTECITO, Calif., June 19 --Fenimore Cooper Marsh, former president of the Baker Castor Oil Company, processors and refiners of castor oil, died Sunday of cancer after a long illness at his home here at 2840 Hidden Valley Road. He was 52 years old and also lived at his farm, Globe Hill Farms, Pine Plains, N.Y.

WASHINGTON, June 19-- Members of the Senate ethics committee, which proposed the censure of Senator Thomas J. Dodd, vigorously attacked today the defense put forward last week by the Connecticut Democrat and by Senator Russell B. Long, his chief defender.
New York State's southern Manhattan offices switched over to a new telephone prefix--488--yesterday, according to a state aide, but somebody forgot to tell the phone company's information operators.

The Boise Cascade Corporation of Boise, Idaho, said yesterday it had "reached an understanding" to acquire the DivcoWayne Corporation through an exchange of shares worth an estimated $40-million to $42million.

PLEIKU, South Vietnam, June 19--A soft drizzle fell on the bamboo and tropical broadleaf forest around Camp Enari early today--an omen to the American soldiers in the area, who are preparing for bitter combat in the weeks ahead.

Little hope for the survival of Webb Knapp, Inc.--at one time one of the nation's largest real estate concerns-- was held out yesterday by Mortimer M. Caplin, the concern's trustee in bankruptcy.

The international aspect of thoroughbred racing was quite prominent at Aqueduct yesterday, with the disclosure of plans to send Assagai to France to compete in the Grand Prix de St. Cloud, and with the announcement of the sale of Stupendous to a partnership made up of Tim Vigors and the English National Stud.
LATINA, Italy, June 20 (AP) Dr. Jack Henry Schulman, a professor of chemistry at Columbia University, drowned while swimming at nearby San Felica de Circeo on Sunday, the police reported today.
HOUSTON, June 20 Cassius Clay, the deposed heavyweight champion, was convicted by a jury tonight of violating the United States Selective Service laws by refusing to be drafted.

WASHINGTON, June 20 State Department officials were studying today what seemed to be a hint by Premier Kosygin that the Soviet Union might be interested in steps to curb a future arms race in the Middle East.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 20 Secretary General Thant said today that Israel's refusal to allow United Nations troops on her side of the armistice line with the United Arab Republic had impaired the peace-keeping plan of the General Assembly for the area.

The United States Court of Appeals in Philadelphia yesterday set a hearing for 10:00 A.M. tomorrow on an appeal filed by the International Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots challenging a ruling by a District Court Judge.
Criticism of the city's airpollution-control program by Senator Robert F. Kennedy on Monday drew a sharp retort last night from Austin N. Heller, Commissioner of Air Pollution Control.
BONN, June 20 The Middle Eastern crisis has imperiled the oil lifeline of West German industry and transportation, according to information available here today.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 20 With an eye to the future of their own talent supply, the New York Giants agreed today to give their full support to the Westchester Bulls, a farm team that will play in the Atlantic Coast Football League.

JERUSALEM, June 20 Israel today continued to plan moves aimed at integrating the former Jordanian sector of Jerusalem into the unified city envisaged by Government authorities.
THE phenomenon of Senator Robert F. Kennedy of New York received an hour's attention on television last night in an uneven profile carried on the Columbia Broadcasting System network.
ADEN, June 20 At least 18 Britons and two Arab policemen were killed and 25 others were wounded when South Arabian troops mutinied here today.
LONDON, June 20 (AP) Laurence, Olivier has cancer, but there is a good chance of a cure, his actress wife, Joan Plowright, said tonight.
ATLANTIC CITY, June 20 Dr. Milford O. Rouse, new president of the American Medical Association, urged doctors today to step up efforts to curb government planning in the field of medicine.

HAMILTON, N.Y., June 20 (UPI) Maurice D. Herbert, executive editor of The Newburgh News, today was elected president of the New York State Society of Newspaper Editors. Mr. Herbert succeeds Paul E. Neville, executive editor of The Buffalo Evening News.

KUWAIT, June 20 The royal family of Kuwait is walking a tightrope in the Middle Eastern crisis, trying to balance its vital economic and political links to the West with its strong impulse toward Arab solidarity against Israel.

CROTON-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., June 20 The marriage of Miss Lucy Ellen Bermont, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Bermont of Maplewood, N.J., to Peter Max Ascoli took place this evening. Rabbi Herbert Weiner performed the ceremony at Cliffdale Farm, the home of the bridegroom's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Max Ascoli.

Mr. and Mrs. Rawson Lyman Wood of 860 United Nations Plaza, Manhasset, L.I., and Squam Lake, N.H., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carolyn Frances Wood, to Dudley Thomas Moorhead 2d, son of Dean and Mrs. Moorhead of San Jose, Calif.

John F. Wharton resigned yesterday as consultant-director of the Legitimate Theater Industry Exploratory Commission, the commercial theater's organization designed to stimulate at tendance and to promote ethical practices.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) All the armed services have issued orders banning initiation ceremonies such as the Army hazing incident that led to the death of a paratrooper at Fort Bragg, N.C., the Pentagon announced today.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 20 The outlook now is for a long and increasingly boring debate at the United Nations on the Middle East crisis, and this may be precisely what is needed to give everybody time to adjust to the new realities in that part of the world.

WASHINGTON, June 20 The Federal Power Commission,in a unanimous opinion, today authorized the Great Lakes Gas Transmission Company to transport gas from western to eastern Canada across a portion of the northcentral United States.

ALBANY, June 20 A Constitutional Convention committee plans to propose retention of a two-house Legislature for New York and is considering seeking longer terms for the lawmakers, its chairman announced today.

MOSCOW, June 20 The trip to the United States of Andrei Voznesensky, the Soviet poet, appeared tonight to be on again, one day after he had cabled that his visit was canceled. But the poet said later that he was unaware that the trip had cleared.
Despite the recently low prices in many commodities, activity in futures trading has continued at record levels this year.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 20 In 1956, when the General Assembly convened in emergency session to consider the Israeli invasion of the Sinai Peninsula, the spokesman for Israel was 41-year-old Abba Eban, her chief delegate.

The Lebanese Army was saved from the late of neighboring Arab armies in the recent war with Israel because Gen. Emile Bustani, army commander in chief, refused an order to "open a front" on Lebanon's border with Israel, according to reliable reports reaching New York.
Paperboard production rose nine-tenths of 1 per cent with 464,300 tons, in the corresponding 1966 week, the Paperboard Group of the American Paperboard Institute reported yesterday.
BERNARDSVILLE, N.J., June 20--Mrs. Pat Cici of Cedar Brook, won the medal in the 64th annual Women's Metropolitan Golf Association championship here today with a 41, 38--79.
