HACKENSACK, N.J., June 20--The state's development proposal for Hackensack River meadowlands was both condemned and praised here today at a legislative public hearing.

The Supreme Court's five-to-four decision invalidating New York's eavesdropping law stops far short of a total ban on the use of electronic devices in the war against crime. The ruling leaves the door open for passage of a more carefully drawn statute that would give needed authority to law-enforcement officials without negating the rights of individual privacy guaranteed by the Fourth Amendment.

ATLANTA, Wednesday, June 21 A Negro man was killed and three other Negroes were wounded last night in a violent confrontation between the police and Negroes in a troubled neighborhood on the city's west side.

In the last two weeks, the city's Police Department has quietly organized small tactical patrol units composed of 10 patrolmen and a sergeant in 40 of its 79 precincts. The new units have been set up to get to local emergencies fast and to handle them as teams.

Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary has ordered his precinct commanders to inform suspects that they have a right to counsel, at the state's expense if necessary, before they need present themselves for identification by victims or witnesses.
Standard Poor's Corporation, the financial publisher and investment advisory concern, announced here yesterday the election of Edward Donahue as executive vice president.

WASHINGTON, June 20 Senator A.S. Mike Monroney charged tonight that lower echelon employes in the new Department of Transportation headquarters were engaging in "power grabbing and empire building." He said this threatened the independence of the Federal Aviation Administrator, William F. McKee.

HOUSTON, June 20 (UPI) Dal Maxvill broke a 2-2 tie with a triple in the seventh inning and Orlando Cepeda hit a threerun homer in the eighth tonight, leading the St. Louis Cardinals to a 6-2 victory over the Houston Astros.
Miss Rosie Tugendhaft, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Tugendhaft of Melbourne, Australia, was married last night to Rabbl Hillel M. Bick, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Bick of Forest Hills, Queens.

OSSINING, N.Y., June 20 Mrs. Letty Cooper Freeman, the wife of Charles K. Freeman, a theatrical and movie director and writer, died yesterday in Phelps Memorial Hospital, North Tarrytown, of cancer. She was 51 years old and lived at 18 Overlook Road here.
The invention of a new process for making metal alloys approaching the hardness of diamond was announced here yesterday by the General Electric Company.
West Point-Pepperell, Inc., textile producers, showed lower sales and earnings for the three and nine months ended May 27, the report from West Point, Ga., disclosed yesterday.

SEOUL, South Korea, June 20 A United States Air Force staff sergeant, Billy J. Cox, the first American serviceman to be tried by a South Korean court under the status-of-forces agreement reached last February, was fined 50,000 won ($185) today for an assault on a Korean taxi driver.
Governor Rockefeller acknowledged yesterday that Richard M. Nixon's chances of being nominated for President had climbed significantly in recent weeks.

Charles Gilman Sr., chairman of the board of the Gilman Paper Company, died Monday aboard the Michelangelo on his way home from Rome and an extended European trip. He was 69 years old and lived at 700 Park Avenue.
TRENTON, June 20 (AP) Peter Murray, administrator of Essex County's Legal Aid Association, was picked by Gov. Richard J. Hughes today to become the state's first Public Defender.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 20 (Reuters) President Podgorny interrupted his surprise mission to Cairo today to stop off for talks with President Tito.
DETROIT, June 20 (UPI) Al Kaline doubled home a run and scored on a single by Jim Northrup in the eighth inning to give the Detroit Tigers a 2-1 victory over the California Angels tonight.
Gottesman Plaza, a half acre park on West 94th Street, between Columbus and Amsterdam Avenues, held a double-dedication ceremony, yesterday.

Directors of the Realty Equities Corporation of New York and Countrywide Realty, Inc., approved a merger plan yesterday. The consolidated company would become the nation's largest publicly owned real estate complex, with combined assets of $205-million.

The Old Town Corporation announced yesterday it has completed the transfer of a block of its common shares. Roy M. Cohn, of the New York law firm of Saxe, Bacon Bolan, and persons for whom he is acting, were the purchasers.

RIVER VALE, N.J., June 20 The Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Gerald L. Clapsaddle have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Connie Beth Clapsaddle, to Wayne Sirois, son of Mrs. Hope Sirois of Presque Isle, Me., and the late Frank Sirois.
LONDON, June 20 Prime Minister Wilson said today that he and President de Gaulle had "agreed to work closely together" on policy to promote a lasting settlement in the Middle East.
Three Chicago men pleaded not guilty here yesterday to a 21-count Federal indictment accusing them of participating in a stock scheme said to have cost stock buyers more than $1.5million.
Stuart K. Hensley has resigned as president of the Gillette Company to accept the presidency of the Warner-Lambert Pharmaceutical Company, it was announced yesterday.

"An Introduction to the Metropolitan Opera House," an official guidebook, is now on sale at the publications desk in the foyer of the opera house at $2 a copy. It is available at the same price through the Metropolitan Opera Guild. It will also go on sale at book and music stores at a slightly higher price.
WASHINGTON, June 20 A House committee was told today that legal services for the poor were offering "a viable alternative to violence in the streets" justice in the courts.

WASHINGTON, June 20 New orders for durable goods, one of the key advance indicators of business activity, rose substantially in May and exceeded current sales of these manufacturers for the first time since December. The new-order total was still about $100-million below December's, however.

Further details on the prospective acquisition of the MacBeth Corporation by Kollmorgen Corporation were disclosed yesterday by representatives of the two companies. An agreement in principle had been accepted by directors of the two concerns a week ago.

HAMMOND, Ind., June 20 The Johnson Administration is alarmed by the prospect of rate increases for the railroad and trucking industries, fearing the inflationary impact they could have on the economy.
Two British stars will be seen here in the roles they played in successful London productions: Spike Milligan in "Son of Oblomov" and Alec McCowen in "After the Rain."

ATLANTIC CITY, June 20 An Australian scientist reported experimental evidence today that appeared to fill an important gap in man's knowledge of how the body combats the infections that constantly peril it.
Investors stepped up their trading pace sharply yesterday on the American Stock Exchange, which wound up with its fourth largest volume on record and a moderate advance in its price index.

PITTSBURGH, June 20 (AP) Chuck Hartenstein pitched 4 2/3 innings of scoreless relief while Ted Savage and Ron Santo cracked three hits apiece as the Chicago Cubs trimmed the Pittsburgh Pirates tonight, 5-3. The Pirates' loss snapped their three-game winning streak.
CHICAGO, June 20 Princess Lee Radziwill made her stage debut here tonight in "The Philadelphia Story."
Three Chicago men pleaded not guilty yesterday in Federal Court to an indictment charging fraud and manipulation of stock of the Pentron Electronics Corporation.
Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin's daughter, Mrs. Lyudmila A. Gvishiani, paid a visit backstage at the Metropolitan Opera last night during an intermission of "La Gioconda."
Ronald Mark Blomberg of Atlanta, the No. 1 baseball draft selection in the country, got his first look at New York yesterday and at his new employer, the Yankees.

YONKERS, June 20 Miss Frances M. Roller was married tonight to Barry M. Bloom, son of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Bloom of Hewiett, L.I. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James J. Roller of Eastchester.
WASHINGTON, June 20 The House completed Congressional approval today of a bill to continue the military draft for four years with statutory deferment rights for college undergraduates.

WASHINGTON, June 20 Four ice age relatives of the modern pig huddled together 17,000 years or more ago for shelter against the cold Arctic wind and blowing dust of what is now Kentucky's Fulton County.
A total of 250 singers and dancers from the soviet Union are coming to Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts next month.

Mr. and Mrs. Stanley A. Goldman of 1125 Park Avenue have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Catherine Muriel Goldman, to I. Ladd Weinberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Weinberg of Hartsdale, N.Y.

PECOS BILL King of the Cowboys" at Theater East has several tasty ingredients, among them an exuberant tune called "Right Over Your Shoulder" and a fresh audience-participation gimmick whereby the kids are turned into howling coyotes. But the ingredients have not jelled into a convincing show. Richard Niles plays the fabulous Pecos as if he were the boy next door in a cowboy suit a nice kid, but no cyclone buster.
CHICAGO, June 20 (AP) The Washington Senators capitalized on two unearned runs one on an obstruction play for a 4-2 victory over the Chicago White Sox tonight.
DOUALA, Cameroon, June 20 Cameroon cut the last communications link today with Nigeria's Eastern Region, which seceded from Nigeria three weeks ago.

City Councilman Joseph Modugno has recently returned from Rome, and he thinks his fellow legislators should do as the Romans did call themselves Senators, and their forum the Senate. The Queens Republican will introduce a bill to this effect today in the Council.
The Rebekah Harkness, Foundation will support two dance programs at Hunter College in the season starting next fall.
The spot rate on the British pound continued to ease here yesterday in quiet trading. The closing rate of $2.7912 was five points below the closing price a day earlier.

Mr. Barth became associated with Carl L. Norden in 1921, just about the time Mr. Norden was experimenting with the first crude model of what was to become the top-secret bomb sight credited with giving the United States superiority in precision bombing in World War II.
GENEVA, June 20 The United States and the European Common Market were reported tonight to have overcome their remaining differences in the Kennedy round of tariff bargaining.
WASHINGTON, June 20 Major American oil companies approved today a plan designed to overcome a possible world shortage of oil supplies because of the Middle Eastern crisis.
AMMAN, Jordan, June 20 Israeli soldiers shot in the air today to control one of the largest movements of refugees across the Jordan River in a single day since the end of the fighting here.

MARK DONOHUE of Stony Point, L.I., who has hopes of clinching the 1967 United States Road Racing Championship at Watkins Glen, N.Y., on Sunday, will have to beat 29 of the nation's leading professional sports car drivers to do it.
The Welfare Department suspended about 175 caseworkers yesterday for "interference with essential services" in the second day of the dispute between the city and the Social Service Employes Union.

FIVE years ago on a trip to England, Edward Fields met a Hoosier-born designer working for a mass producer of carpeting. She accepted his invitation to come to New York for a week to design a few rugs for him.

IT was another day of whirlwind activity for the shares of Goldfield Corporation, the subject of glowing if not too glowing reports in a brace of publications of Indicator Digest, Inc., Palisades Park, N.J.

George Gershon Shor, an executive of the Hearst newspaper organization for many years until his retirement in 1953, died yesterday while undergoing an operation for a tumor. His age was 82. He was a resident of Cold Spring, N.Y.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) United States officials have disclosed that an apparent North Vietnamese bid to hold peace talks in Rangoon in late 1964 was based on information from a relatively junior Soviet official on the United Nations Secretariat.

Arthur Freed, the film producer whose name in Hollywood is synonymous with the big, plush Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer musical film, was the guest of honor last night at a reception at the Gallery of Modern Art to mark the start of a nine-week retrospective of his films at the museum.

Huntington Hartford, the 56year old grandson of the founder of the Great Atlantic Pacific Tea Company, Inc., attended its annual meeting yesterday for the first time and immediately was embroiled in a public squabble with the management.

GLADSTONE, N.J., June 20 Mrs. Elizabeth McNeill Elkinton and Chalmers Handy of Far Hills were married today in the chapel of St. Bernard's School by the Rev. Charles P. Johnson, minister of the Reformed Church of Gladstone.

UNITED NATIONS, N,Y., June 20 The United Nations was told today that there must be immediate action if food was to be available for the million Arab refugees in the Middle East after the next three weeks.
BRUSSELS, June 20 The executive commission of the European Economic Community supported British membership in the community in a report issued today.

A woman who said she wanted to go to the Soviet Union "in exchange for Svetlana Stalin" spent three hours yesterday inside the Soviet Mission to the United Nations at 136 East 67th Street waiting to see Premier Aleksel N. Kosygin.
Donald G. Robbins Jr., vice president since 1955 of the Singer Company, was named yesterday to the new post of treasurer and chief financial officer.
BALTIMORE, June 20 (AP) Jim Palmer, baseball's hero last fall when he became the youngest to pitch a World Series shutout, was shipped to the minors today by the Baltimore Orioles
MINEOLA, L.I., June 20 Incumbents won re-election tonight in the villages of Old Brookville and Old Westbury, but lost in Atlantic Beach.

ASCOT, England, June 20 (Reuters) Short skirts and an Irish horse upset some of the traditionalists today at England's big annual event for horses and high fashion the opening of the four-day Royal Ascot race meeting.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., June 20 The Rev. David B. Wells, pastor of the First Church of Christ Congregational, has announced his resignation effective Sept. 1. He has been the subject of controversy because of his public views on Vietnam and action in organizing weekly peace vigils.
The United Fruit Company and the Hotel Corporation of America jointly announced yesterday that they had been holding talks looking toward a joint venture in the international hotel field.
LONDON, June 20--For the first time no American has been seeded in the men's division of the Wimbledon lawn tennis championships starting next Monday.
The stock market started with a bang yesterday but ended with a whimper.
OMAHA, June 20 The New Jersey Rat Finks, the militant conservative Young Republican group accused of racism, won a clear-cut victory over their state's regular Republican leadership here today.
AUSTIN, Tex., Wednesday, June 21 (AP) Mrs. Patrick J. Nugent checked into Seton Hospital early today to await the birth of her expected baby.
PRINCETON, N.J., June 20 Daniel M. Sachs, former Princeton football star and a Rhodes scholar, died this morning at his family's home in Bethlehem, Pa., after a long illness. He was 28 years old.
NEW DELHI, June 20--A restriction confining Chinese Communist diplomats and dependents to the premises of their embassy here will be lifted tomorrow morning.
WHITE PLAINS, June 20 An insurgent Democrat in New Rochelle appeared to have wrested control of the county party machinery tonight by upsetting the organization candidate in the mayoral primary.
PHILADELPHIA, June 20 Robin Hood Dell opened its 38th annual series of outdoor summer concerts here tonight before an audience of more than 26,000 people.

EAST STROUDSBURG, Pa., June 20 Mr. and Mrs. William Ashley Anderson have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eugenia Lewis Anderson, to Howard W. Ellis Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Ellis of Memphis

If it did not know before, Lincoln Center learned last night that all it takes to fill all the seats of Philharmonic Hall (including temporary ones set up on stage) is the presentation of the Stern-Istomin-Rose Trio playing Beethoven's Trio in B flat major (Op. 11), Ravel's Trio in A minor and Schubert's Trio in B flat major (Op. 99).

HACKENSACK, N.J., June 20 John Reese of Hewlett, L.I., the second-seeded player, was upset by Sam Levin of Lancaster, Pa., 5-7, 9-7, 6-2, in thirdround match between University of Pennsylvania teammates today in the Eastern clay-court tennis championship. Levin played No. 2 at Penn behind Reese.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 20 High seas and a slashing north east gale continued to punish the yachts in the Annapolls-toNewport race for the second day today. It was a case of one hand for the ship and one for the man.
There's fresh proof that the Johnson Administration is trying to formulate precise policies to "fine tune" the economy on the basis of statistical intelligence that is anything but precise.

G.I. Joe, the 6-inch tall soldier, marched out of Bruns Advertising last August and pitched his tent at the Fletcher Richards Company. Yesterday, he marched back to Bruns with about $5-million to $6-million in billings in his duffle bag.

Don Cardwell, on the disabled list since June 3 after having suffered a strained right elbow, threw in pre-game practice for the first time. He told Westrum he "felt good." He would be eligible to return to the active list on Saturday.

CLIFTON, N.J., June 20 Charles E. Windecker, a pioneer in the development of the metallic element beryllium for various purposes, died today of cancer in Mountainside Hospital, Montclair. He was 58 years old and lived at 140 Hepburn Road, Clifton.

WASHINGTON, June 20 President Johnson's efforts to arrange a meeting with Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin appear to have been stalled by the Soviet leader's rigid definition of his mission in the United States.
Gambling, racketeering and other evidences of organized crime are widespread is Westchester County, United States Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau said yesterday.
ASHAROKEN, L.I., June 20 An incumbent Trustee who led a year-long fight against a controversial zoning change was defeated today by the voters of this North Shore village.

The draft bill that Congress has now sent to the President is a small but regrettable victory for Representative Rivers of South Carolina and the knownothing sentiment prevailing in the House Armed Services Committee.
Svetlana Alliluyeva's memoirs will be published in the original Russian by Harper Row simultaneously with the English translation on Oct. 16.
TEL AVIV, June 20 Israeli Air Force intelligence officers, released tonihtg photocopies of Arabic documents said to be top-secret Egyptian maps and attack orders against Israel.
DETROIT, June 20 A civil rights group helped to negotiate a truce today between the city and police officers who have staged work stoppages since Thursday.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 20 Soviet sources said today that Moscow could not accept any controls on arms shipments to the Middle East until the military forces of the Arabs had been restored to a reasonable balance with the force of Israel.

JERUSALEM, June 20 Nineteen years of dust have covered the open notebooks and unfinished experiments in the classrooms and laboratories of the Hebrew University campus on Mount Scopus. Equations are scrawled on blackboards before rows of empty chairs. Birds soar from the broken windows on one side of a lecture hall to the sandbagged windows on the other side.
The wholesale commodity price index fell to 98.4 on Monday from 98.5 on Friday.
An architectural firm has been formed by Jack Freidin, Joseph Kleiman and Daniel Kelleher.
WASHINGTON, June 20 Angered by a recent rash of flag burnings, the House voted tonight to make it a Federal crime to publicly mutilate or otherwise desecrate the United States flag.
CLEVELAND, June 20 The touring professionals who had threatened to boycott the 1967 Professional Golfers Association championship made peace tonight with the executives of their organization.

WAREHAM, Mass., June 20 (AP) Theodore H. Barth, who aided Carl L. Norden in the development of the Norden bombsight used in World War I, died Monday in Tobey Hospital, after abdominal surgery. He was 75 years old.
Thomas P.F. Hoving yesterday succeeded August Heckscher, who had succeeded Mr. Hoving only a few months ago.
Sonny Fox is quitting as host of "Wonderama" after nine years to become the co-star in September of a new, live 2 hour daily series for women on Channel 5.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, June 20 (Reuters) A Dutch senator asserted today that he was a member of a group that helped 10 or 20 American soldiers stationed in Germany to desert from here to Paris in the last year.

SYDNEY, Australia, June 20 Bill Edwards, the president of the Lawn Tennis Association of Australia, said in Melbourne today that the defeat of the United States Davis Cup team by Ecuador was "not all that much of a surprise."

WHITE PLAINS, June 20 In the sanctuary of the Hebrew Institute today, Miss Sheri Grauer, daughter of Rabbi and Mrs. Murray Grauer, was married to Stanley Raskas, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Raskas of St. Louis.
American Airlines announced yesterday a revolutionary engine maintenance technique made possible by the use of computers and electronic recording devices.
WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP)--President Johnson announced today that he had selected Benjamin H. Oehlert Jr., a business executive, to be the new Ambassador to Pakistan.

HOLYOKE, Mass., June 20 The engagement of Miss Eva Johsnna D'Addario to Robert S. Franklin, son of Dr. and Mrs. John E. Franklin of New York and Merrick, L.I., has been made known by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Raymond D'Addario.

Stockholders of the Needham Packing Company authorized an increase in common shares from one million to two million and a new issue of no-par preferred yesterday at their annual meeting in Sioux City, Iowa.

Allied Stores Corporation, the country's second-largest department store chain, has improved its sales and earnings since the April quarter, Theodore Schlesinger, president, yesterday told the annual meeting.
ALBANY, June 20 The New York State lottery, which began June 1 with a prediction that sales would average a million tickets a day, may be in trouble. Early sales are only about half that prediction.
The split in the price of prime Western grade zinc, early May, was practically eliminated yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 20 The Senate adjourned late this afternoon in a stalemate over the plea of Senator Thomas J. Dodd to vote on the charge that he double-billed air fares before voting on the charge that he diverted political funds to his own use.
A new seven-inch portable color television set was introduced yesterday by the Sony Corporation of America.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 20 The United States called today for the establishment of a durable peace in the Middle East through negotiations assisted by a third party. Arthur J. Goldberg offered the plan in the form of a draft resolution at the General Assembly's emergency session.
Robert M. Allan Jr. has joined the corporate staff of Litton Industries and has been named president of the newly formed Litton International Development Corporation, a subsidiary.

RED BANK, N.J., June 20 Miss Jennifer Brooks Stanley was presented tonight at a supper dance given at home by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert Crooks Stanley Jr. About 400 guests danced to the music of Lester Lanin in a large pink and white striped marquee on the lawn overlooking the Navesink River.

A break in American shippropulsion tradition, which has been to equip large merchant ships with steam turbine machinery, appears possible as the result of last week's announcement by the Maritime Administration that diesal as well as steam engines would be considered in the construction of three large barge-carrying vessels. They are to be ordered for Lykes Bros. Steamship Company.
A three-judge Federal Court here dismissed a taxpayers' suit yesterday that had sought to block Federal funds for use in religious schools.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 20 Nureddin el-Attassl, the President of Syria, addressed the General Assembly this morning in Arabic. Although Arabic is the language of 91 million of the world's people, it seldom is heard in United Nations meetings.

CLEVELAND, June 20 (UPI) Luis Tlant, Who hasn't lost since April 14, won his sixth straight game and hit his first homer of the season tonight in leading the Cleveland Indians to a 5-3 victory over the Kansas City Athletics.
Two new compositions by Richard Franko Goldman will be played in Central Park tonight when the Goldman Band opens its 50th-anniversary season of Guggenheim Memorial Concerts in the city parks.
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., June 20 Edson J. Fifield, a former stamp dealer at 500 Fifth Avenue, New York, died here yesterday in his home at the age of 75. He came here a year ago from Bronxville, N.Y.
PEKING, June 20 (Agence France-Presse) The Communist party's ideological journal Hung Chi said today that the Maoist Cultural Revolution was "at present on an erratic course."

GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador, June 20 (AP) Cliff Richey salvaged a final singles victory over Miguel Olivera today to make the final score, 3-2, in favor of the jubilant Ecuador tennis team over the United States in the American Zone final of the Davis Cup tournament.

HONOLULU, Jue 20--Mayor Lindsay of New York told a group of the nation's mayors today that New York State had "a progressive and good government, but they know nothing about police science and control of crime."

NEW ORLEANS, June 20 (AP) A witness in District Attorney Jim Garrison's investigation into the assassination of President Kennedy said today that members of a National Broadcasting Company news team had sought his help "to wreck the Garrison investigation."

The men of the new unit stood in two ranks on a recent night at 6 o'clock in a grim,, green-walled rear room. The yellow glow from two globes hanging from a stamped metal ceiling lighted the room. MenWanted posters added no gaiety to the decor. Sgt. Earl Olmstead briefed the squad in its routine, which was illustrative of the new system.

WASHINGTON Maybe the most frightening lesson of the Arab-Israeli war is its vivid demonstration of how wrong Soviet information can sometimes be. If Moscow's intelligence appraisal of the Middle East was so lopsided, what must we assume about Moscow's intelligence appraisal in other areas Vietnam, for example?

The Roman Catholic Church will introduce several important changes in the conduct of the mass throughout the world on June 29 designed to simplify the sacred rite for both its celebrants and its participants.

Mr. and Mrs. James Bergman Jr. of 1085 Park Avenue and Centre Island, L.I., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Joanna Sara Bergman, to Anthony Alexander Dean, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederic M. Dean of Boston and Hampton, Conn.
"The Battle of Britain," a multimillion-dollar dramatization of the Royal Air Force's defense against the Nazi aerial assault in the fall of 1940, will be financed and distributed by United Artists.
Gold and green dragons and lions and pirates invaded Union square Park yesterday along with the children who imagined them.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 20 The United States will spend in South Vietnam this year the equivalent of $,500 for every man, woman and child in the country.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 20--The first river assault force used by the United States since the American Civil War has produced a major victory over a Vietcong battalion in the Mekong Delta, 17 miles south of Saigon.

A member of the New York City Advisory Council to the State Commission for Human Rights said yesterday that an investigation of the state agency had resulted in the recommendation that Commission Chairman George H. Fowler be removed.

LOS ANGELES, June 20 American Reform Judaism has been engaged in intensive research on ways to revise or replace its Union Prayer Book with one that would be "more congruent to the needs of contemporary man."

TRENTON, June 20 (AP) A $1.7-million gift to Elmira College by an aged niece of the late John D. Rockefeller Sr. was struck down by the New Jersey Supreme Court today on grounds that she was a victim of "synthetically effusive attention" and deception by executives of the New York college.
Angel Cordero Jr. outrode Praulio Baeza (five winners to two) at Aqueduct yesterday, but it was Cordero who offered to carry Baeza's saddle.

YONKERS, June 20 No longer is it unusual for a Billy Haughton, a Stanley Dancer (who owns his own plane) or a George Sholty to drive a horse in the first at Yonkers Raceway, then take off to fulfill an engagement that same night at Brandywine Raceway in Wilmington, Del.
Bond prices sagged again yesterday, driving up interest rates on several long-term issues beyond their levels of last year, the highest in about 40 years.

IN "A prelude," Edmund Wilson says how pleased he was to read that a reviewer had referred to him recently as a professional. This sentiment will surely surprise a great many readers who have thought of him in this way for many years, even without critical imprimatur. In fact, to them he has been our most complete man...
RIDGEWOOD, N,J., June 20 (AP) S. Inglis Leslie, chairman of the board of the Leslie Company of Lyndhurst, died at his home here today. He was 87 years old.

GENEVA, June 20 An exiled Greek publisher said today that the people of Athens were conducting "a form of passive resistance" against the new military Government by cutting down their purchases of the heavily censored newspapers.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 20 (UPI) Rick Barry, a star for the San Francisco Warriors of the National Basketball Association, announced today he had signed a three-year, contract with the Oakland Americans of the American Basketball Association. Barry's defection gave the A.B.A, its first superstar and seventh N.B.A. player.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) J. Arthur Younger, an eightterm member of the House of Representatives from San Mateo, Calif., died tonight at the age of 74. He had entered the Walter Reed Army Medical Center on April 18 for treatment of what he described as "a form of leukemia."

The short-interest position of shares traded on the New York Stock Exchange declined by 37,006 shares, to 14,888,812 in the month ended June 15 from the revised 36-year high of 14,925,818 set last month, the exchange reported yesterday.
An offering, of 225,000 shares of Rodney Metals, Inc., common stock was sold yesterday at $42 a share by a syndicate managed by Kuhn, Loeb Co. The stock closed at 45 on the American Stock Exchange.

While there are some good recommendations in the study of New York's outdoor recreation needs just completed for the City Planning Commission by the National Recreation and Park Association, the report as a whole falls short of offering a balanced program for adequate open space and recreational resources for New York.
A wildcat strike by a drivers' local cut service last night on Greyhound bus runs north of New York City.
PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., June 20 The American Yacht Club team of Mrs. Allegra Mertz and Mrs. Beverley Becker won the Morgan Cup today.
Prices were up on the London Stock Exchange yesterday, despite international political uncertainties.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) The United States formally expressed regret today for damage to the Soviet cargo ship Turkestan off the North Vietnamese port of Campha and gave assurances to Soviet authorities that every effort would be made "to insure that such incidents do not occur."

BEIRUT, June 20--The Arab leaders were reported tonight to have little serious hope that the United Nations could get Israel to withdraw from captured Arab territories on terms acceptable to the Arabs.
WASHINGTON, June 20 President Johnson invited Congress today to come forward with its own proppsals for emergency strike legislation if it was displeased with his failure to propose a bill.
Irish International Airlines has purchased two buildings for new North American headquarters two doors south of its present quarters on Fifth Avenue.

The General Aniline and Film Corporation's recent tender offer to purchase all of the 175,356 issued and outstanding shares of common stock of Shelby Business Forms, Inc., at $45 a share is now unconditional, Dr. Jesse Werner, chairman and president of Aniline, said yesterday.

FOR the 100 pretty girls who serve as guides at the United Nations, it hasn't been work as usual this week. The U.N. has been closed indefinitely to tourists, while the General Assembly debates the Middle East crisis. Some of the girls have been reassigned as receptionists and secretaries, and some are on leave. But all are getting relief from the question most asked by visitors to the world organization:

PHILADELPHIA, June 20 Larry Jackson, who has been tormenting the Mets longer than any other National League pitcher, did it for the 18th time tonight in a one-hit performance that provided the Philadelphia Phillies with a 4-0 victory.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 20 Federal investigative agencies are baffled in trying to explain why a wealthy young couple bought hundreds of guns and thousands of rounds of ammunition.
MOSCOW, June 20 Nikolai V. Podgorny, the Soviet chief of state, left today by plane for Cairo for talks with President Gamal Abdel Nasser, with a stopover in Yugoslavia to confer with President Tito.
The New York Post announced yesterday that it had reached agreement with Typographical Union 6 on a new three-year contract.

PARIS, June 20 Mrs. Jeannine Alexandre-Debray, mother of Regis Debray, the writer held prisoner in Bolivia, was reelected in her absence last evening as a vice president of the Paris Municipal Council.

Computerized education will begin in 15 schools of the city next February. Some 6,000 pupils will be able to get daily drills in reading, spelling and arithmetic and to find out immediately how they are doing.

LOS ANGELES, June 20 A nationwide third-party Presidential campaign on behalf of former Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama was announced today by a California organizer, who says he has the authorization of Mr. Wallace's headquarters.
Representative Paul A. Fino scored a decisive victory yesterday in his primary battle to keep insurgents who were backed by aides of Mayor Lindsay from ousting him as county leader in the Bronx.
YONKERS, June 21--Although eight horses will start in tomorrow night's $50,000 Gotham Trot at Yonkers Raceway, the oldest trotting event in the track's history will have only seven betting interests.

"We welcome the lottery," a policy gambling operator said yesterday. "Numbers players haven't quit us because they now realize that our odds are better. We pay off immediately and there's no waiting. And furthermore, no winner has to worry about paying income taxes."

PHILADELPHIA, June 21 Pitching in stifling humidity, Jack Fisher produced one of the masterpieces in Met history tonight, a 2-0 two-hitter against the Philadelphia Phillies. But Fisher will always wonder what might have been if Dick Groat had not been sidelined by an inflamed right ankle.

WASHINGTON, June 21 President Johnson's Administration was subjected to heavy attack today by both Republican and Democratic Congressional leaders for falling to develop a maritime policy to reverse the decline in the nation's shipping and shipbuilding posture.

SANTA FE, N. M., June 21 Reies Lopez Tijerina, the 41year-old sometime evangelist who reigns over the Political Confederation of Free City States, is scheduled to be arraigned here tomorrow at the old abode courthouse just off the plaza where the Santa Fe Trail ended.
Revenues of the American Telephone and Telegraph Corporation advanced in the three months ended May 31 from the year-earlier level but earnings were almost unchanged.

Hundreds, of welfare clients stood in long lines for hours at welfare centers yesterday as two-thirds of the city's caseworkers continued to report for work but refused to perform their regular duties.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 21 Al Goumhouria, the farthest left of the important Cairo newspapers, published what was viewed here as an extremely significant article today that appeared to critcize the Egyptian Army.

Miss Marina Pinto, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Salomon M. Pinto of Geneva, Switzerland, was married there yesterday to Stephen E. Kaufman. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Kaufman of 975 Park Avenue.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 21--Lancetilla, a Cal 40 sloop owned by Juan M. Cameron, a Washington economics writer who never had won a yacht race before, drove almost untroubled through all the high winds and seas of the Annapolis-Newport event to become winner today of the Blue Water Bowl that was the main corrected-ttime prize in the 473-mile passage.

WASHINGTON, June 21 The Fine Arts Commission rejected today controversial plans under which Octagon House, a Washington landmark, would become part of a new office complex for the American Institute of Architects.
Striking deck officers of the merchant marine called off their strike yesterday under pressure from an industry arbitrator whose previous order they had scorned.

LEXINGTON, Ky., June 21 In Christ Episcopal Church this afternoon, Miss Catherine Whitney Scott, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Thornton Scott, became the bride of Francis Inman Amory 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Amory Jr. of Beverly, Mass.
New gifts of $12,031.70 have brought total contributions to the Fresh Air Fund to $167,449.34.
One Queens milk company was fined $1,800 and another $75 yesterday for selling milk in containers that held less than they were supposed to.

WASHINGTON, June 21 In a humorous, but occasionally biting, vein, Secretary of Transportation Alan S. Boyd tried today to minimize charges that his new department was meddling in affairs of the Federal Aviation Administration.

THE handful of clubs in the metropolitan area that of- fer duplicate games every afternoon and evening was increased last Friday with the opening of the Bayview Bridge Club, 1185 Northern Boulevard, Manhasset, L.I. An instructional duplicate on Wednesday morning and a Monday morning game round out a full schedule under the direction of Abe Goldstein.

NOW that summer is one day here, it is time to indulge in that most pleasurable of pastimes with one of the oddest of names: the picnic. Like barbecue, the word has rather elusive origins. It is frequently said to have beginnings in France where such outings in fresh air are known as pique-niques, a blend of words vaguely meaning to pick or peck at a trifle.

HONOLULU, June 21--An attack on neighborhood controls over antipoverty programs in American cities was repulsed by the United States Conference of Mayors today at the final plenary session of its 1967 meeting.
CLEVELAND, June 21 Mr. and Mrs. Milton Goldberger have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Faye Goldberger, to Richard J. Trilling, son of Dr. and Mrs. Leonard J. Trilling of Washington.

A neatly dressed man carrying a loaded revolver and a hunting knife in a canvas bag strolled past more than a dozen policemen yesterday afternoon and got a foot in the door of the Soviet Mission where Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin was conferring with colleagues.

Michael J. Scandifia, a 49-year-old Mafia figure, was sentenced yesterday by Federal Judge Charles H. Tenney to six years in prison. He was convicted of interstate transportation of $410,000 worth of counterfeit bonds.

Mayor and Mrs. John V. Lindsay, who live in New York but are in Honolulu, and Mr. and Mrs. Robert R. Midkiff, who live in Honolulu but have been in New York this week, have temporarily swapped houses.

BOSTON, June 21, (AP) Good Knight, a completely overlooked chestnut horse with only one previous victory this year, charged through the pack in the stretch today and won the $61,775 Massachusetts Handicap, returning the biggest payoff in the 33-year history of the Suffolk Downs classic.
The amount of space leased in Manhattan's new office buildings during the first five months of this year is the largest five-month total for new structures in the city's history.

State Supreme Court Justice Arthur Markewich has rejected an attempt by Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz to enjoin 16 officers of building-trade associations from what the state had called a conspiracy to fix the system of bidding on statebuilding construction.

LANSING, Mich., June 21 Gov. George Romney prepared Michigan today for sharp cuts in his proposed spending for schools and mental health, layoffs of state employes and the elimination of all new state programs in the coming fiscal year.
For the estimated total of 19 million Americans who will be 65 years old or over this year two sociologists at Columbia University have completed a study they say proves these conclusions:

The Soviet Union and four East European countries have dropped out of Sunday's live international telecast called "Our World." They charge Western broadcasters with conducting "a slanderous campaign" against the Arab countries in the current crisis in the Middle East.

PAPEETE, Tahiti, June 21 Tahiti is celebrating the bicentennial of its discovery by Capt. Samuel Wallis, an Englishman, who was the first white man to step ashore on this South Pacific island. His arrival, on June 19, 1767, aboard the Dolphin, had been prophesied by Polynesian priests.
BOSTON, June 21 The Massachusetts Commission against Discrimination absolved Harvard Law School today of a charge of discriminating against Jewish graduates seeking jobs.

BALTIMORE, Md., June 21 Mrs. Catherine Bond Jackson, first president of the Women's Association of the Baltimore Symphony who was active in 1942 in forming the orchestra, died yesterday at her home, Venture, in suburban Stevenson. She was 74 years old.
The trading pace slowed a bit yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and prices turned down.

SHAWNEE-ON-DELA- WARE, Pa., June 21 (UPI) Steve Melnyk, a 215-pounder from the University of Florida who gave up football for golf, took a one-stroke lead with a three-under-par 69 today in the opening round of the 70th annual National Collegiate golf championship.
BUFFALO, June 21 (AP) A longshoreman told Coast Guard investigators today that he heard a shout and then saw white smoke pouring from the hold of a ship in which four coworkers perished on June 2.
WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) Vice President Humphrey will fly to Korea next Wednesday to witness the inauguration of President Chung Hee Park, the White House announced today.
JERUSALEM, June 21 Israel's Defense Minister, Maj. Gen. Moshe Dayan, said in Parliament today that "the road is still open" for Jordanians who wanted to leave the Israeli-controlled west bank.
NORFOLK, Va., June 21 (AP) Two sailors were scalded to death yesterday when a steam line ruptured in the engine room of the Raleigh, an amphibious transport dock.

CHICAGO, June 21 (UPI) A hundred park district workers fought a losing battle today with millions of dead fish that were being washed ashore along 20 miles of beaches faster than they could be removed by bulldozers.
ALBANY, June 21 The Public Service Commission expressed "concern" today to Governor Rockefeller about the potential supply of electric power in the New York City metropolitan area.

STRATFORD, Conn., June 21 In his new production of "The Merchant of Venice" at the American Shakespeare Festival Theater, Michael Kahn shows us that it is possible to stage the play as a sour little story in which nobody including Shylock comes off very well.
The election of Robert S. Hatfield as a director of the Continental Can Company was announced here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 21 Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff said today that he would vote against the censure of Thomas J. Dodd, his fellow Democratic Senator from Connecticut.

WASHINGTON, June 21 (UPI) The Senate Post Office and Civil Service Committee approved today a bill to provide at least $10,000 in life insurance to all Federal employes.
LONDON, June 21 The censorship that has guarded the morals and politics of the English stage for nearly 400 years today suffered what may be a mortal wound.

AMERICAN TELEPHONE that favorite of widows and orphans, has been popular with brokers and traders as well for the last few days. After lolling in a trough for weeks, the stock has been vying of late for honors on the active list. Trading zip has carried the stock up several points.
OCEANPORT, N. J., June 21 Iron Ruler, owned by October House Farm of Far Hills, N. J., won the Tyro Stakes at Monmouth Park today.
ALBANY, June 21 Governor Rockefeller, differing with Senator Robert F. Kennedy, urged the Constitutional Convention today to keep the state attorney general an elective post.

MOSCOW, June 21 (AP) Yuri V. Andropov, head of the Soviet secret police, was named today a candidate, or nonvoting member, of the Politburo, highest organ of the Communist party.

PASTEUR, Argentina It was 8 A.M., and a bitter cold Patagonian wind smelling of snow gusted across the open grasslands.

The first issue of a new magazine devoted to America's political and economic relations with Western Europe goes on sale today, Called Interplay, it will appear ten times a year simultaneously in America and Great Britain.

LINCOLN, Mass., June 21 Miss. Helena Keville Evans, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lucius Wilson Evans of Lincoln and Marion, was married to Georges Philippe Reiser this afternoon in St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church by the Rev. Ernest P. Pearsall.
Maj. Gen. John M. Franklin, the dean of American shipping executives, announced his retirement yesterday as chairman of the board of United States Lines for reasons of health.

PHILADELPHIA, June 21 Mrs. Aurore LeCroix Hay, a former concert pianist, died at Lankenau Hospital Monday after a long illness. She was 77 years old and lived in nearby Wynnewood. Her husband, Henry Homer Hay of New York City and Portland, Me., died in 1943.

MOCOW, Thursday, June 22 The Soviet Communist party's policy-making Central Committee declared today that the Soviet Union would "do everything necessary" to help the Arab nations administer a "resolute rebuff" to Israel.
Mrs. Carl John LaRocca has announced the engagement of her daughter, Mrs. Elizabeth Marie McNichol, to Eugene Henry Zagat, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Paul H. Zagat of New York.

WASHINGTON, June 21 President Johnson let fly today some of the emotion he has invested in his major domestic programs by charging that the opponents of urban reform and poverty programs were helping to produce convicts.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., June 21 Miss Carol Ann Walter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William L. Walter, and Richard Alan Shweder, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Shweder of Kings Point, L . I., were married this afternoon by Algernon Black, senior leader of the Ethical Culture Society, in the garden of the Walter home.
WEST ORANGE, N.J., June 21 Dr. Maurice Olinger of 7 Birchwood Avenue, who had practiced dentistry for 46 years in Hoboken, died today in the Mountainside Hospital in Montclair. He was 73 years old.
THANHAN, South Vietnam, June 21 They squat in front of their new homes, digging up fresh red soil, planting rice and silently watching armed American jeeps rumble over the twisting roads.

An international group of 36 business leaders Protestant, Roman Catholic and Jewish left Kennedy International Airport yesterday for Rome, where they will see Pope Paul VI to discuss his encyclical on the plight of poor countries.
The Stauffer Chemical Company announced here yesterday the election of Harold S. Mickley as a director.

Mrs. Lyudmila A. Gvishiani, the 38-year-old daughter of Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin, learned something about American tastes in refreshments and art during an unannounced visit yesterday to the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
An industrial development and contracting company, Feld Feld, has been established in East Orange, N.J., by two brothers who are developing industrial parks in six New Jersey counties.

VINA DEL MAR, Chile, June 21 The United States is coming under pressure from the Latin-American nations to make trade and other concessions so that the proposed regional common market can be inaugurated successfully by 1970.
CHICAGO, June 21 Princess Lee Radziwill's stage debut received lukewarm to poor notices from the four Chicago dramatic critics today.

Jewish fraternal organizations in the metropolitan area have bought nearly $24-million worth of State of Israel bonds in the current annual campaign, it was announced last night at a dinner at the Statler Hilton Hotel.

The chairman of a joint legislative committee charged yesterday that 4,000 girls were being suspended every year from city schools, never again to get another day's schooling, because they were pregnant. But a spokesman for the Board of Education denied the charge. "No pupil is expelled for pregnancy, in or out of wedlock," he said.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 21--Western oil experts reported today that Arab countries were now exporting nearly half their normal output despite threats in the wake of the Arab-Israeli war to withhold all Arab oil supply from the rest of the world.
ASCOT, England, June 21 (UPI) An Australian jockey, George Moore, scored his 2,000th career victory today when he triumphed with Fleet in the Coronation Cup at Ascot.

Mario Trombone, a New York public relations executive, pleaded not guilty in United States District Court here yesterday to charges of conspiracy, manipulation and fraud in connection with transactions in the stock of the Pentron Electronics Corporation on the American Stock Exchange.

Fordham University anounced yesterday that the Rev. ustav A. Wetter, a leading authority on Communist ideolo- gy at the Vatican, would be adjunct associate professor of Russian studies for the summer session of the Institute of Russian Studies.
WASHINGTON, June 21 The Defense Department has decided to let New York City use military bases in the city for summer youth programs.
For the first time in its 13 years, opera will be added to the series of free chamber music concerts in Washington Square Park.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 21 (AP) New floods erupted in Kansas and Missouri today in the wake of torrential rains.

MADRID, June 21--Spain's Ambassador to the European Economic Community, Alberto Ullastres, expressed confidence last night that Spain would be admitted to the Common Market but warned that his countrymen must refrain from adopting an "all or nothing" attitude if the national growth were to continue.
Art Wolff, 29-year-old production manager at Washington's Arena Stage, has been named resident director of Philadelphia's Theater of the Living Arts.

LAFAYETTE, Ind., June 21 (AP) Thomas R. Johnston, who retired in 1963 after 45 years as information director for Purdue University, died in a nursing home here yesterday after a long illness. He was 74 years old.
AMMAN, Jordan, June 21 The Jordanian Government today planned broadcasts to the inhabitants of the west bank of the Jordan River warning them against collaboration with the Israelis.

Interest rates continued at record levels yesterday as heavy purchases of new corporate issues by investors and buying of Government issues by the Federal Reserve braked further price declines in the bond market.

PITTSBURGH, July 21 (AP) Chicago tonight scored four runs in the first inning, and Curt Simmons and Dick Radatz made them suffice for a 6-3 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates. The triumph moved the Cubs into third place in the National League.
ROME, June 21 Pope Paul VI named today three new auxiliary bishops in the Archdiocese of Chicago.
Andrei Voznesensky, the Soviet poet, failed to appear last night for his scheduled recital in Philharmonic Hall.
The City Planning Commission yesterday gave its approval for the huge Williamsburg urban renewal project.
The New York Yankees and the Boston Red Sox fought each other with catcalls, beanballs and fists last night, with the Red Sox winning the main event, 8-1.

Miss Jane Ellen Leichtman and Joel Eugene Ewan plan to be married on July 1. Mr. and Mrs. Paul Leichtman of New York have announced their daughter's engagement to the son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Ewan of San Diego, Calif.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 21 President Nikolai V. Podgorny of the Soviet Union is reported in diplomatic circles here to be trying in his visit to Cairo to discourage President Gamal Abdel Nasser from any early attempt to renew hostilities with Israel.

MOSCOW, June 21 (Reuters) The literary future of a novelist who complained that he was being persecuted by Soviet censorship appeared brighter today following reports that the Soviet Writers' Union would come to his aid.

TORONTO, June 21 Investigations into a mutual fund registered in Panama and sold to United States residents led to the arrest today of two Toronto stock promoters on charges of conspiring to defraud the public.

The Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corporation announced yesterday in Toledo, Ohio, the election of Robert H. Knight and William W. Boeschenstein as directors.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., June 21 Gov. Claude R. Kirk Jr. vetoed the Florida Legislature's $1,536-billion general appropriations bill today, asking that he be sent one that is within the state's expected income of $1,335-billion for the next two years.
MINEOLA, L.I. June 21--Law-enforcement officials from New Orleans and Miami are due to testify tomorrow before a Nassau County grand jury investigating an alleged $100-million bookmaking ring.
ALBANY, June 11 Governor Rockefeller will name Robert J. Mangum, a Federal antipoverty official, to replace George H. Fowler as chairman of the State Commission for Human Rights.

PHOENICIA, N.Y., June 21, John Dwight Sullivan, a lawyer who had been state com mander of the American Legion and Deputy Controller of New York in the first two years of the La Guardia administration, died today in Benedictine Hospital, Kingston, following a long illness. He was 73 years old.
A new Building Code, designed to influence patterns of construction in the city for years to come, was officially received yesterday at City Hall by leaders of the City Council.

NEW ORLEANS, June 21 (AP) A Louisiana judge accused unnamed individuals today of "deplorable and contemptuous" disregard of court guidelines on pretrial publicity in the presidential conspiracy case against Clay L. Shaw.

INDEPENDENCE, Mo., June 21 (AP) Vice President Humphrey paid a 40-minute neighborly call on Harry S. Truman at the former President's home here today and discussed grandchildren their own and President Johnson's.

WASHINGTON, June 21 The Senate overwhelmingly rejected today a substitute resolution that would have "admonished" Senator Thomas J. Dodd to avoid future misconduct. This made a vote of censure against the Connecticut Democrat seem certain.

SPRINGFIELD, N.J., June 21 Barry F. Meglaughlin of 25 Forest Drive, former regional public relations manager for the Humble Oil and Refining Company of New York, died Monday at St. Barnabas Medical Center, Livingston. His age was 63.

WASHINGTON, June 21 The District of Columbia school board postponed today a decision to appeal a sweeping Federal Court decree ordering an end this fall to de facto discrimination against poor Negro students here. There were indications, however, that an appeal would be taken later.

WASHINGTON, June 21 The House approved today a two-step increase of $29-billion in the national debt limit de- spite solid Republican opposition. The vote was 217 to 196.

Secretary of State Dean Rusk and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko surveyed a broad range of outstanding issues between the Soviet Union and the United States last night with the possibility of a summit meeting hanging in the balance.
PARIS, June 21 Negotiations on reform of the world's monetary system adjourned again today with vital issues still unresolved.

A SUMMARY of innovations in elementary school ed ucation was offered last night by the National Broadcasting Company under the title of "The Learning Process." John C. Brackett, the founder in 1947 and president of Brackett Steels, Inc., died Monday in New York Hospital. He was 49 years old and lived at 1318 Summit Lake Road, Clarks Summit, Pa.

LONDON, June 21 (AP) The closing of the Suez Canal has cost British shipowners $5.6-million and this amount is rising at a rate of about $420,000 a day, an industry spokesman said today.

LONDON, June 21 Roy Emerson, four times champion here and the betting favorite for Wimbledon, was upset by Tom Okker in the fourth round of the London grass-court tennis championships today.

Samuel A. Weissman, chairman of the board of the Weissman Watch Corporation, watch importers, at 20 West 47th Street, died on Tuesday at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 82 years old and lived at 799 Park Avenue.

The Vulcan Materials Company, producer of construction materials and chemicals, has agreed to acquire Aluminum and Magnesium, Inc., of Sandusky, Ohio, through an exchange of stock. The transaction announced yesterday would involve in excess of $6.33-million.

WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) Two United States Government employes in New Jersey have saved taxpayers nearly $4.5-million, the Civil Service Commission said today.

DETROIT, June 21 The American Motors Corporation said today it would sell some 500 to 600 1968 cars at 1967 prices.

ADEN, June 21 (Reuters) British troops killed four gunmen in a seven-hour battle today against Arab nationalists during the second day of intensified violence in this British colony.

WASHINGTON, June 21 Research programs to curb jet engine noise, develop all-weather landing systems and design better helicopters and other aircraft that take off and land vertically were described today by officials of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 21 Mr. and Mrs. Gordon Grand have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Minette Dill Grand, to Shepard Krech 3d, son of Dr. and Mrs. Krech Jr. of Easton, Md.

Despite being involved in an incident at the start, Norman Bate's Triple Brook raced to victory in the $27,600 Vagrancy Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday. With Braulio Baeza guiding her into the lead shortly after the field of half a dozen older fillies and mares got away in the seven-furlong race, Triple Brook remained in front all the way and finished half a length in front of the heavily favored Mac's Sparkler.

Reform and old-line Democratic leaders in Manhattan agreed yesterday that the outcome of the fight for election of a county leader could be determined by a few district leaders not closely affiliated with either group.

GENEVA, June 21 Fred W. Friendly, former president of news at the Columbia Broadcasting System, told newspaper publishers and editors today that radio and television news coverage had advanced to the point where "you will never read a major event unless it is an exclusive story in a newspaper for the first time."

BERKELEY, Calif., June 21 (AP) The first group of defendants in the 1964 Free Speech Movement at the University of California appeared in Municipal Court today after the Supreme Court's decision not to review their cases.

ELIZABETH, N.J., June 20 William M. Glass of 815 Magle Avenue, sales manager of the Mueller Color Plate Company, 520 Fifth Avenue, Manhattan, died Monday night at St. Elizabeth's Hospital after a brief illness. He was 61 years old.
A mistaken effort to save money at the possible expense of human lives is prompting some states to push for low standards of highway safety.
The American Stock Exchange reported yesterday the changes carried below in the shareholdings of officers, directors and major stockholders of listed companies.
ROME, June 22 Pope Paul VI is expected to reaffirm the Roman Catholic Church's traditional practice of priestly celibacy tomorrow when he issues the sixth encyclical letter of his four-year reign.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., June 22 (AP)--The Illinois Supreme Court ruled today that the circuit court in Cook County (Chicago) should set a new date for the annual stockholder meeting of the Crucible Steel Company. The opinion reversed an appellate court decision that Illinois did not have jurisdiction over the Crucible Steel proxy battle.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 22 The man who is father and mother of 1.3 million Arab refugees from land now held by Israel has had a problem of communication with his charges because he prefers understatement to exaggeration.
A 14-story headquarters building will be erected at 308 West 43d Street, just west of Eighth Avenue, for Local 1199 of the Drug and Hospital Employes Union. The local has 27,000 members.

PITTSBURGH, June 22 (AP) An antitrust question will delay the planned merger of the Rockwell-Standard Corporation and North American Aviation, Inc., both companies revealed today. They said the Department of Justice raised the issue because both concerns manufacture executive jet aircraft.

HANOVER, N.H., June 22 Comdr. Raymond A. Robinson U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Robinson have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Judith Ellen Robinson, to Howard Emerson Bond, son of Prof. and Mrs. Howard W. Bond of Kingston, R.I., formerly of Bethesda, Md.
MAMARONECK, N.Y., June 22 Two Mamaroneck patrolmen, in a disciplinary hearing tonight, denied charges that they had failed to act on knowledge of police involvement with known gamblers.
WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) Gen. Franklin A. Hart, who retired in 1954 after 37 years in the Marine Corps, died today at Bethesda Naval Hospital at the age of 72.
CHICAGO, June 22--Fred A. Cuscaden, a retired banking and business leader here, died today in suburban Highland Park. He was 86 years old.
Major banks in New York City increased their lending to commerce and industry by a record amount in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) Dr. Charles Armstrong, a research pioneer in poliomyelitis, died today at the Bethesda Naval Hospital, where he had been a patient for two days. He was 80 years old.

The First Boston Corporation, investment bankers, announced here yesterday the election as vice presidents of Peter T. Buchanan, H. Thomas Cimiluca, Franklin D. Sanders and Daniel W. Taylor. They are members of the New York office.

Announcement has been made here by Mr. and Mrs. Chin-Seng Ong of Penang, Malaysia, of the engagement of their daughter, Miss AyWhang Ong, to Sven Erik Hsia. He is the son of Mrs. Suzanne Hsia of 35 East 85th Street and the late Sung Yo Hsia former charge d'affaires at the Nationalist Chinese Embassy in Stockholm.
Austin J. Tobin, executive director of the Port of New York Authority, and Miss Rosaleen C. Skehan, the authority's general attorney, plan to be married.

Shareholders of the Frank G. Shattuck Company, the restaurant chain, who have been almost starving lately for good news, heard some yesterday. They were told that the company expected to show a "sizable profit on continuing operations" in the ...

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., June 22 Dissatisfied with what they call municipal complacency over crime, housewives and young businessmen in this suburban city of big homes and developing slums have given Federal authorities evidence of crime in their own backyard.
NEW YORK has finally become a summer festival, at least for men.

WASHINGTON There are regrettable indications that Moscow has made a policy decision to revive the cold war or, in any case, to heighten tensions that had seemingly subsided. This is one conclusion from Soviet behavior at the U.N. Special Assembly, and is unlikely to be changed by Friday's meeting between President Johnson and Premier Kosygin.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 22 A Soviet military mission arrived unannounced in Belgrade yesterday and is conferring with Yugoslav military, leaders.
WASHINGTON, June 22 (UPI) President Johnson took more than one hour out of a crowded day today to attend the funeral of a Negro who had been a White House employe for 29 years.

A complaint filed by the Securities and Exchange Commission in Tulsa, Okla., yesterday charged the Community National Life Insurance Company, six individuals and a brokerage house with violations of the registration and antifraud provisions of the Federal securities laws.

The ruling on the Washington, D.C., school system handed down by Judge James Skelly Wright of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals is a monumental exercise in sociological jurisprudence. The opinion is thick with statistical data on the actual workings of the capital's public schools. On the basis of these facts, most of Judge Wright's specific findings seem valid. But the practicality of his decision in its larger implications is highly questionable.
Lincoln Center: Hindemith's "Mathis der Maler," Hamburg State Opera, Metropolitan Opera House, 8 P.M.
WASHINGTON, June 22 The Senate Interior Committee took action today that would effectively prevent a big dam from being built in the Grand Canyon.

American maritime labor leaders charged yesterday that officials in the United Arab Republic were detaining two American-flag ships in the Suez Canal in the hope of forcing one of them to unload her cargo of grain.

MOSCOW, June 22 Under the leadership of Yuri Grigorovich, Moscow's Bolshoi Ballet is now undertaking its perilous journey into what we in the Western dance world think of as the 20th century. It will be a journey not without its pitfalls, and some of those pitfalls were all too evident in a couple of recent Bolshoi programs.

The spirit in which President Johnson and Premier Kosygin will meet today is suggested by the location that has been chosen. Glassboro, N.J., is roughly midway between New York and Washington. Each leader will be coming half way to join the other.

The Johns-Manville Corporation, a producer of asbestos products, announced here yesterday the election to its board of William F. May, chairman of the American Can Company, and John P. Schroeder, senior vice president of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company.
The city's controversial hospital affiliation contracts were renewed yesterday by the Board of Estimate in an aura of reluctance and misgivings.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 22 (AP) Hank Aaron's two-run homer in the eighth inning of the second game and his runscoring double in the opener today helped the Atlanta Braves to defeat the San Francisco Giants 2-1 and 6-4.
"I think we got the best ballplayer to come out of college this year."

WESTPORT, Conn., June 22 Top Thorn, a thoroughbred who spent last year as a hunter, captured one jumping class and finished second in another today and took the lead for the open jumper championship at the opening session of the Fairfield County Hunt Club Horse Show.
The Chicago Mercantile Exchange, which has recently been setting records in volume and in the prices of memberships, added another record yesterday trading in pork bellies.

ATHENS, June 22 Expatriate Greeks who have been criticizing the army-controlled regime of Greece were branded today as turncoats or Communist agents by a Government leader, a trade union and the press.
BONN, June 22 Paul Sethe, one of West Germany's leading writers and political commentators, died of a heart attack today in Hamburg. He was 65 years old.

RYE BEACH, N.H., June 22 The marriage of Miss Caroline Johnston Davis, daughter of Mrs. Elliot Gould Fish of Exeter and Leverett Brainard Davis of Newcastle, Me., to Andrew Gumpert Janover took place here this afternoon. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Gumpert Janover of New York.
WHEN the Psychedelic Bus goes to the Times Square area tomorrow, two of its owners won't be on it.

One of Westchester's major bookmakers, John (Peanuts) Manfredonia, a reputed member of the Mafia, was sentenced in Federal Court yesterday to one year in prison and fined $6,000. Patsy P. Colarusso, an alleged collector for Manfredonia, received a three-month prison sentence and was fined $2,000.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 22 United States infantrymen and planes struck hard at enemy positions in South Vietnam, a military spokesman announced today.
The Washington Post has acquired the Book Week section of the defunct World Journal Tribune and will probably begin publication of the weekly literary supplement on Sunday, Oct. 1.
The Sherwin-Williams Company, Cleveland paint and varnish manufacturers, reported yesterday lower earnings on higher sales for the nine months ended May 31.
DETROIT, June 22 (AP) Al Kaline drove in three runs today with a pair of homers and Joe Sparma set down the Minnesota Twins on four hits as the Detroit Tigers won their third straight game, 5-2.
Stock prices declined in less active trading; volume, 9.55million shares.

OAK RIDGE, Tenn., June 22 Donald D. Cowen, public relations director of the Union Carbide Corporation's nuclear division, died today at Oak Ridge Associated Universities Medical Division Hospital. His age was 56. He had been suffering from Hodgkins disease.

LEONARD BERNSTEIN conducted the Mahler Second Symphony last night in Philharmonic Hall. He took the New York Philharmonic through the big work without an intermission; and it was the only work on the program. Fair enough. The score runs nearly an hour and a half.

"ARMS AND THE MAN" I sing not too loudly, lest it be concluded that the revival at the Sheridan Square Playhouse is all it should be, but loudly enough to suggest that it provides a pleasant evening's entertainment.

WASHINGTON, June 22 The Federal Communications Commission, by the same onevote margin as before, reaffirmed today its approval of the merger of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation and the American Broadcasting Companies, Inc.
WASHINGTON, June 22 A House committee agreed today with President Johnson that rats must go.
JERUSALEM, June 22 (AP) Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, took official possession yesterday of its longabandoned hospital on Mount Scopus.
ASCOT, England, June 22 The Empire's prestige was upheld today as horses from England finished one, two in the Ascot Gold Cup and the miniskirt dared to make its appearance at the grand old course.
A group of leading American retailers is planning to establish a joint buying office in Israel in order to increase their apparel purchases there and thus help the Israeli economy.
BAKERSFIELD, Calif., June 22 The Amateur Athletic Union's national track and field championships opened appropriately tonight with an American record in the first event of the two-day meet.
The highest real estate tax rate in the city's history was set yesterday: Property owners will be faced with a basic levy of $5.073 for each $100 of assessed valuation, beginning July 1.
The second massive power blackout in less than two years has spurred the Federal Power Commission to submit a comprehensive legislative program to guard against future breakdowns.

James Coburn, the actor, who was roughed up by a New York policeman Wednesday night while shooting a movie in Greenwich Village, received a basket of fruit and a note of apology yesterday from the office of Mayor Lindsay.

WASHINGTON, June 22 Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freeman has urged the Interstate Commerce Commission to make sure that any increase in motor freight transportation rates "are permitted only when fully justified by the carriers."
