The city police and Federal agents, substantially tightening their security ring around Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin, have barricaded the East Side block in which he is living and have imposed close scrutiny on everyone moving into and out of it.

BONN, June 22 Foreign Minister Willy Brandt was in Sweden today to start the second stage of a four-country swing through Scandinavia to woo for West Germany a region long neglected by the Bonn Government.
After more than seven years of often vituperative wrangling the World Trade Center received final approval yesterday.
LONDON, June 22--In another symbolic move toward the Continent, Britain is going to give up her insular time and set her clocks the same as those in Continental Europe.
WHITE PLAINS, June 22 Campaign contributions from criminal sources have been offered to Mount Vernon political parties, an unsuccessful candidate for office charged today.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 22 Following are the texts of two of the addresses on the crisis in the Middle East delivered today in the emergency session of the General Assembly:
The $200,000 bond posted by several persons during the abortive legal fight to save the old Metropolitan Opera House was distributed yesterday. But none of those who paid the money will get any back.
VINA DEL MAR, Chile June 22 The United States appears increasingly disposed to giving priority in foreign aid commitments to projects that further Latin-American economic integration.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 22 Excessive noise can be an "unsuspected triggering agent" for physical ailments such as ulcers and allergies, as well as mental illness, a professor of environmental medicine said today.

BERNARDSVILLE, N.J., June 22 Three players from New Jersey and one from Long Island reached the semi-final round of the 64th annual Women's Metropolitan Golf Association championship today over the 5,640 yard, par-72 Somerset Hills Country Club course.

WARRENTON, Va., June 22 The middlemen of the arts, the people who represent communities and states in their cultural activities, were told today by John Kenneth Galbraith that "Artists have always functioned best under the most lavish handouts of the state."

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost of dining in any particular establishment.

A 70-foot tripod of steel and aluminum at La Guardia Airport drew the praise of aviation officials yesterday. They said it had saved $1.5-million and would reduce the diversion of aircraft to other airports in bad weather. Some experts said privately that it would also mean safer landings.
venting intestinal adhesions, a grave complication after surgery, looks quite encouraging, surgeons reported today to the A.M.A. convention.
Pacific Air Lines, which startled the aviation industry recently with its shock appeal advertising campaign, has agreed in principle to merge with West Coast Airlines of Seattle.
Both the city and the state have acted this week to perfect machinery for strike-free labor relations in the civil service.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 22 A sound pricing policy for the transportation industry if required if the industry is to be converted from "the step-child of the investment community" into one with prospects as attractive as the general run of industry, a transport spokesman said today.

A professor of nuclear engineering at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology testified yesterday that the Consolidated Edison Company, in developing its first nuclear plant, had served the best interests of its customers, stockholders, employes and the nation.

Greyhound buses resumed normal service here after a wildcat strike by members of Local 1202 of the International Amalgamated Transit Union ended yesterday morning. The strike began late Tuesday in defiance of the parent union and its Eastern Council. The New York local represents about 1,000 drivers and terminal employes serving the area between New York and Montreal.

Connecticut's one-year residency requirement before payments could be made to welfare applicants and their children has been declared unconstitutional by the Federal District Court in Hartford. The judges thus recognized both the new mobility and the chance for all Americans to seek opportunity, regardless of the state they come from or go to.

Mr. and Mrs. Mike Wallace of New York have announced the engagement of Mrs. Wallace's daughter, Miss Pauline Perigord Dora, to John Macdonald Snyder, son of Dr. and Mrs. John Crayton Snyder of Milton, Mass.
The Securities and Exchange Commission suspended trading yesterday in the stocks of the Goldfield Corporation and Chemalloy Minerals, Ltd., through next Tuesday.
The following quotations are selling prices in United States dollars and cents for banking notes at New York. These rates do not apply to regular exchange business transacted by banks.

A long-standing feud between Negroes and Puerto Ricans in the city's antipoverty program broke into the open yesterday as 100 angry Puerto Ricans staged a demonstration in the program's central office at 100 Church Street.
Cushman Wakefield, Inc., has announced the appointment of Harold M. Mills as senior vice president and a director.
VINTON, Iowa, June 22 (UPI) A Texan was arraigned on a charge of murder today in the death of one of three persons killed last night in a gunman's rampage through the Iowa countryside.

A campaign to put the question of United States participation in the war in Vietnam before New York City's voters in next November's election was opened yesterday by the Fifth Avenue Peace Parade Committee.

WASHINGTON, June 22 A noted Republican economist said today that the management fees charged by mutual funds should be reduced because most of the managers did not give their shareholders anything for their money.

Two major bills of the Lindsay Administration were passed by the City Council yesterday. One would set up an Office of Collective Bargaining, and the other would establish a new Housing Maintenance Code.

WASHINGTON, June 22 Intercity truck tonnage and revenue freight traffic generated by carloadings on United States railroads in the week ended June 17 were both below the volume in the corresponding week of 1966.

LOS ANGELES, June 22 A leader in interfaith activities scored today what he described as the failure of the "organized Christian Church" to speak out more vigorously on behalf of Israel during the Middle East tensions and the ensuing conflict.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 22 (AP) Breaking and weakened levees caused concern along the flooding Missouri River today as major crests moved downstream across Missouri.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 22 Israel is discussing an agreement with world religious leaders to provide access to the holy places of Jerusalem for Christians, Moslems, and Jews.

RENO, June 22 Alfred L. Higginbotham, founder of the University of Nevada journalism department and a nationally known journalism educator, died of cancer today at St. Mary's Hospital. He was 71 years old.
The three major television networks will offer live color broadcasts from Glassboro, N.J., today when President Johnson meets Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin of the Soviet Union.

Paul Heischuber, a former New York stockbroker, pleaded not guilty yesterday in the United States District Court here to Federal charges that he fraudulently manipulated the stock of the Pentron Electronics Corporation on the American Stock Exchange.

Senator George S. McGovern rejected last night the argument of many "hawks" on Vietnam that it is inconsistent to oppose Administration policy in the Vietnam war and support Israel in the Middle East crisis.

NORTH SCITUATE, R.I., June 22 Col. Walter E. Stone, superintendent of the State Police, said today that he had ordered his troopers to "forget Miranda and Escobedo and become policemen again" in putting down a Rhode Island gang war.

SHAWNEE-ON-DELAWARE, Pa., June 22 (UPI) Steve Melnyk of the University of Florida fought off a driving rain to card a one-under-par 71 today for a one-stroke lead at 140, while the University of Houston won its fourth straight team title in the 70th annual National Collegiate Athletic Association golf championship.

The marriage of Miss Doris Catlin, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Daniel Catlin, to Douglas Thomas Yates Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Yates, took place yesterday afternoon. Both families are of New York and Islip, L.I.

OMAHA, June 22 An attempt by the Republican party to curb the independence of its outspoke n conservative youth wing was rejected on three of four counts tonight by the Young Republican National Federation.
Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin and his daughter, Mrs. Lyudmila A. Gvishiani, did not get to the Metropolitan Opera last night, but their flowers did.
"The food's not as good as at home. I like rice and beans every day, and they don't make it here. But it's good food."
LONDON, June 22 Prime Minister Wilson moved today to soften the impact of the speech by George Brown, the Foreign Secretary, to the United Nations General Assembly yesterday.

THE character who had the most profound influence on Eddie Eagan was Frank Merriwell and this was to prove something of a handicap. After all, Merriwell was not real, being a fictional creation of Burt L. Standish. Because the supersports hero at Yale was an idealist, representing all that was good and noble, Eddle also became an idealist.
The London stock exchange declined yesterday in light trading.

IRVINGTON, N.J., June 22 Charles J. Stauhs of 33 41st Street, formerly a credit manager for L. Bamberger Co. in Newark, died yesterday at the Beth Israel Hospital there, after a short illness. His age was 76.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 22 The question on this foggy and finally sunny day so far as prize winners in the Annapolisto-Newport race were concerned was which yacht got the firstplace award in three of the five divisions.

WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) The controversial proposal for a $375-million atomsmasher for Weston, Ill., cleared the House Rules Committee without opposition today and was sent to the House for debate next week.

WASHINGTON, June 22 Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara declared off limits today all segregated housing near the Andrews Air Force Base in Maryland in what may be the first of a series of similar actions designed to end housing discrimination against Negro servicemen.

CINCINNATI, June 22 Mr. and Mrs. David Kroger Homan have announced the engagement of Mrs. Homan's daughter, Miss Lucinda Kelly Schaefer, to Karl Richard Besuden Niehoff, son of Mr. and Mrs. Karl George Niehoff.

BOSTON, June 22 (AP) The Massachusetts Supreme Court set aside today the conviction of Frank S. Giles, former State Public Safety Commissioner, on two counts of perjury before the State Crime Commission.

Anne Fogarty, the fashion designer, was married last evening to Richard Tompkins Kollmar, radio personality, former actor and now owner of Richard Kollmar's Pastiche Inc., dealers in baroque and whimsical art, at 50 East 53d Street. The ceremony was performed at the home of Mr. and Mrs. H. Huber Boscowitz of 45 East 63d Street by Judge Kenneth B. Keating of the State Court of Appeals.
NEW HYDE PARK, L.I., June 22 Mr. and Mrs. J. Raymond Burkitt have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Arlene Mary Burkitt, to J. Read Smith Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Smith of Garden City.

The Welfare Department reported 10 arrests and 250 additional suspensions of nonworking caseworkers yesterday as groups representing welfare clients demanded an end to a union tie-up that began Monday.

WASHINGTON, June 22--For the second time in two days the Senate decisively rejected today an effort to soften the language of the resolution of censure against Senator Thomas J. Dodd. The vote was 87 to 9.

ADEN, June 22 (Reuters) British commandos and troops today controlled all roads into Aden's Crater district, the scene of two days of bitter fighting, while authorities considered whether British forces should ever assume responsibility for security there again.

THE master-point game is a mixed blessing both to duplicate bridge clubs and to the players who frequent them. It gives increased interest and increased attendance to one game in four, but at some cost: the fractionalpoint games at other times get poor attendances; some players appear only on masterpoint nights, robbing the regular attenders of their masterpoint prospects; and club loyalty is not developed.

Rain in the garden doused Jazz in the Garden at the Museum of Modern Art last night, canceling the opening concert in the 10-week series of Thursday night jazz presentations in the Sculpture Court of the museum.
JERICHO, Jordan, June 22 An Israeli remarked today that he did not enjoy, driving the territory newly conquered by his country, because "I don't like looking at a defeated people."

General Hart served in both World Wars with distinction. In World War I he was commanding officer of Company B, Machine Gun Battalion, Fifth Marine Brigade, in France. In World War II he won the Navy Cross while commanding the 24th Marines in the assault and capture of Roi-Namur Island, Kwajalein Atoll. For his leadership in the battles for Saipan and Tinian in the Mariana Islands he won the Legion of Merit.

The Securities and Exchange Commission filed a civil suit yesterday charging securities violations by General Electronics, Inc., of Newark, three of its officers, four stockholders, two stockbrokers and a Swiss corporation.
TEL AVIV, June 22 (AP) An authoritative economics writer reported today that Israeli plans to settle tens of thousands of Arab refugees in the Gaza Strip and on the west bank of the Jordan River.

THE theory of entropy at least as Michael Frayn proposes it in his latest, adroitly wacky novel suggests that the universe is wearing down and inexorably tumbling apart. EAST HAMPTON, L.I. June 22 Summer activities in this elm-shaded community are already under way. The Maidstone Club has been open for several weeks and the Devon Yacht Club will open on Saturday with a gala luncheon.

On the theory that the appetite of the professional football fan is insatiable, the National and American leagues will present 80 preseason exhibition games late this summer. The schedule, reflecting the merger of the leagues, will include 16 interleague contests.

WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) Interest rates on conventional home mortgages declined for the fifth consecutive month during May and reached a level more than one-fifth of a percentage point below the December peak, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported today.
Workmen this week began gilding the conical gray steel dome of a cathedral being erected at Second Avenue and 35th Street by the Armenian Church of North America.

OSSINING, N.Y., June 22 The State Department of Public Works disclosed its proposed route for the Hudson River Expressway tonight. The action was taken at a public meeting attended by both foes and friends of the project.

SANTA FE, N.M., June 22 Reies Lopez Tijerina, head of the Political Confederation of Free City States, and 17 of his followers were arraigned today at the old adobe courthouse here on charges of kidnapping and assault with intent to commit murder.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 22 An Interstate Commerce Commission decision on the merger plans of the Norfolk Western and the Chesapeake Ohio Railways could be issued some time next year, according to Paul J. Tierney, vice chairman of the commission.

PARIS, June 22 President de Gaulle was quoted today as having said that the war in Vietnam might be "the beginning of a third world war" and was "preventing Americans and Russians from reaching an understanding in other parts of the world."
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 22 Communist China is playing a much more important role in the calculations of the Russians in the Middle Eastern debate here than is generally realized.
Three Nobel laureates signed yesterday a statement by American Professors for Peace in the Middle East urging recognition of Israel's right to exist.

White Consolidated Industries, Inc., which is actively building its diversified industrial activities through acquisition, now is planning to add the National Screw Manufacturing Co. to its operations for stock worth more than $18million.
GENEVA, June 22 The International Press Institute ended its annual meeting today with a resolution "strongly" urging the release of journalists imprisoned by the new military Government in Greece.

The reconverted Ford's Theater in Washington, where Lincoln was assassinated, will be dedicated in January, Walter Pozen, assistant to Secretary of the Interior Stewart L. Udall said in a telephone interview from Washington.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 22 France's Foreign Minister today deplored Israel's plan to negotiate individually with each Arab state without defining her peace terms. He noted that the terms appeared to go far beyond freedom of navigation in the Gulf of Aqaba.

THE National Broadcasting Company appears to have come up with a bright and and cool summer replacement for its popular "Dean Martin Show." The program, which had its debut last night, suffered only from its unimaginative title, "The Dean Martin Summer Show." However anxious the network may be to keep its star performer's name before the public, the talented people who have sublet his place for the summer deserve a title plate of their own.

ALBANY, June 22 New York Telephone Company customers who orders color telephones, make many calls within the state, or pay mileage charges to be in an exchange area will have smaller bills starting next month, the Public Service Commission announced today.

LOS ANGELES, June 22 Critics of the United States's Vietnam war policies are plan ning a large-scale protest demonstration when President Johnson comes here for a $1,000-acouple Democratic banquet and ball tomorrow night. Their estimates of the possible number of participants ranged as high as 20,000.

Mrs. Marie Choubaroff Blackton of 655 Park Avenue, widow of Nicholas Blackton, was married yesterday afternoon to Hamilton Fish, a widower and former United States Representative from Orange County. The Rev. Dr. Gilbert Darlington performed the ceremony in the chapel of St. James Episcopal Church, where Hamilton Fish Jr. was best man for his father.

A sharply divided Appellate Division affirmed yesterday the murder conviction of a Harlem youth despite objections from his lawyer that the police had taken a statement from the defendant after being expressly told by the attorney not to do so.

LONDON, June 22--The trustees of Encounter magazine indicated today that they were still considering whether, in the long run, to make changes in its editorial direction following disclosures that it had indirectly received funds from the Central Intelligence Agency.

WASHINGTON, June 22 President Johnson and Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin will meet for several hours tomorrow at the home of the president of Glassboro State College at Glassboro, N.J., about halfway between New York and Washington.
IN the menus below, dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.
WASHINGTON, June 22 There was considerable banter all day today, especially at a White House luncheon for President Johnson's foreign guests, about the President's new status as a grandfather.
THE mutual funds, which have been cash-rich for some time now, were nevertheless urged yesterday along with other institutions to reduce their stockholdings.
NEW DELHI, June 22 The Government gave up today a plan to end the state of emergency in India, which has lasted nearly five years.

MISSOULA, Mont., June 22 (UPI) George Chuvalo, a heavyweight contender, and Don Fullmer, a middleweight title hopeful, scored impressive knockout victories tonight in a boxing card at the University of Montana fieldhouse.

Bobby Ussery took no chances with Julie Potatoes, the Pine Tree Stable's filly, in the feature race, the Summer Festival Purse at Aqueduct yesterday. Getting away first in the seven-furlong sprint for fillies and mares, Ussery guided his mount way to the outside to that part of the track that has come to be known as Ussery Alley.

TEL AVIV, June 22 Israeli Army officials acknowledged today that 40 per cent of the buildings in the Jordanian town of Qalqilya had been destroyed, but they insisted that the damage was done by shelling during the war.

The names of three more persons said to have been marked for assassination by an alleged ring of middle-class Negro revolutionaries were turned over to the Federal Bureau of Investigation yesterday by Queens District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., June 22 Frederick C. Bryant, who retired 10 years ago as president of Bryant Heffernan, Inc., New York customs brokers and freight forwarders, died here yesterday in his home at 16 Wood End Lane. He was 74 years old.
The rise in bond prices, touched off this week by the highest corporate yields in 45 years and Federal Reserve purchases of Treasury bonds, continued yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 22--A bill that would both broaden civil rights protection and curb outside agitators who incite riots was rushed through a House Judiciary sub- committee today. Prompt action by the full committee is expected early next week.
AUSTIN Tex., (UPI) June 22 President Johnson gave Luci and Patrick Nugent, the parents of his day-old grandson, a prize helfer calf today and a large ranch in central Texas.
NEW ORLEANS, June 22 The Metropolitan Crime Commission of New Orleans called today for an investigation of the operations of District Attorney Jim Garrison.

AURORA, Ohio, June 22 Wayne Yates of Atlanta took a one-stroke lead in the opening round of the $103,500 Cleveland open today with a four-underpar 66 at the Aurora Country Club. Jack Nicklaus scored a 72.

TRENTON, June 22 (AP) The New Jersey Educational Association proposed today that the state establish four educational television stations in the next two years at an estimated initial cost of $5.8-million.

White and Negro parents, along with children in the city's 21 More Effective Schools, joined with teachers, supervisors and at least eight principals yesterday in a demonstration seeking city aid against scheduled cuts in the system.
LOS ANGELES, June 22 (AP) Dal Maxvill capped a three-run rally with a tie-breaking single in the sixth inning tonight as St. Louis defeated Los Angeles for the sixth straight time this season, 7-2.

LONDON, June 22 Concern about the after-effects of the Middle Eastern war pushed the pound down in the foreign exchange markets today.

YONKERS, June 22 No one directly connected with Roque pine lost a measure of confidence in her ability to overcome all obstacles tonight, even though the 6-year-old Frenchbred mare was parked out for nearly a mile in the 1 -mile Gotham Trot at rain-soaked Yonkers Raceway.

Federal Judge Marvin E. Frankel ruled yesterday that the sale of the names of more than six million registrants by the Commissioner of Motor Vehicles to the highest bidder was not an invasion of privacy.
The P. Lorillard Company, producer of Kent, Old Gold and Newport cigarettes, announced here yesterday the election of Walter M. Aikman as a director.

NASSAU, Bahamas, June 22 (Reuters) The Monte Carlo Casino, one of three gambling establishments in the Bahamas, will close at the end of this month because of a $1-million gambling tax.

A first-degree murder indictment was returned yesterday against a Bronx man in the rape-strangulation last May 25 of Dr. Elena Gall, a 55-year-old Hunter College professor. Two brothers also were indicted as accessories after the fact because they allegedly tried to help dispose of the body.

Papper of Riverdale, the Bronx, was married here yesterday evening to William Lee Lupatkin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Lupatkin, also of Riverdale. Rabbi Abraham M. Heller performed the ceremony in the Cottage Room of the Hampshire House.

BERLIN, June 22 (AP) Ron Clarke of Australia spurted past Harald Norpoth of West Germany 10 meters from the finish and won a two-mile race in 8 minutes 25.4 seconds today.

The wholesale commodity price index fell to 98.4 on Wednesday from 98.6 on Tuesday.

N.B.C. News reported last night that Senator Robert F. Kennedy had been told by Mr. Garrison's chief investigator that there was "no basis in fact and no material evidence in Garrison's case for an assassination plot against the late President Kennedy."

PHILADELPHIA, June 22 (AP) The police said today that they had taken into custody eight persons whom they identified as members of the Revolutionary Action Movement. The arrests followed two separate police raids on reputed RAM headquarters.
PARIS, June 22 Policemen acting on a forgery complaint have seized 13 paintings priced at about half a million dollars in a Left Bank gallery.

RYE, N.Y., June 22 Mr. and Mrs. Burt J. Siris have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margot Siris, to Kenneth Helphand, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis A. Helphand of Yonkers.

LONDON, June 22 Little Nancy Richey has reached the semi-finals of the London grasscourt tennis championships. Today she demolished Lesley Turner of Australia, 6-3, 6-1, in half an hour with the ruthless accuracy of her ground shots.

Tarleton Winchester, who retired as a vice president of the United States Lines in 1961 after a 44-year career in the shipping industry, died Wednesday in Algeeiras, Spain, it was announced here yesterday. His age was 71 and he lived in Spain.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, June 23 (Reuters) All seven crew members of an American Super Constellation cargo plane were killed when it crashed after a midair collision with a United States Air Force Phantom jet last night, a military spokesman said today.

Miss Susan Price Carr, daughter of Mrs. Dorislee Kadis Carr and Lewis Bruce Carr of New York, was married last evening to Kenneth David Burrows, son of Mr. and Mrs. Selig S. Burrows of Great Neck, L.I., and New York.

UNITED NATIONS, June 22 The art of lying, which owes so much to diplomacy, seems to be in a slump at the United Nations these days. It is not that the present delegates at the General Assembly have given up the practice, but somehow they have lost their cunning.

BRICK TOWNSHIP, N.J., June 23, (AP) The Mayor-elect of this Ocean County township said today that he received a threatening telephone call demanding that he appoint someone favorable to the "family" to the planning board. The family is assumed to be a referance to the Cosa Nostra.

MONTREAL, June 23 As it has with a good many other groups, the World Festival program of Expo 67 lured the Bath Festival Orchestra of England across the Atlantic for the first time. Last night, it made its North American debut in the PortRoyal Theater in the Place des Arts cultural center here.

Leon Terry, who founded in 1912 the Newark (N.J.) Preparatory School, died Thursday of a heart attack at his home at 150 West End Avenue. His age was 80. He served as principal of the school, a coeducational college preparatory from its beginning until 1959.

Another once distinguished name in American journalism vanishes with the decision of The Boston Traveler to cease publication July 10. For many of for 142 years The Traveler was a sparkling evening newspaper, but in recent years it has been steadily declining in quality, circulation and advertising.

Particularly the people on the verge of paying their bill.

NYACK, N. Y., June. 25 Miss Martha Greene Bassett, daughter of Mrs. Maurice Ewing of Palisades and Preston. Rogers Bassett Jr. of Grandview-on-Hudson, was married this afternoon to Sergei Erastovich Geacintov, son of Mr. and Mrs. Erast Geacintov of Syracuse.

DARIEN, Conn., June 25 Dr. Jay C. Searer, a group vice president of the Hooker Chemical Corporation, with offices in New York, died of a heart attack today at his home here, 16 Old Parish Road. He was 54 years old.

REIMS, France, June 25 (Ap) Jochen Rindt of Austria took the lead in an exciting dash down the long finish stretch and beat Graham Hill of Britain by less than a yard today in the Reims Grand Prix auto race for Formula Two cars.

BETHPAGE, L.I., June 25 The Bethpage polo team con tinued its mastery over Brookville this season by scoring a 6-4 victory today at Bethpage State Park. Bethpage has beaten Brookville three times and tied once in four meetings."
WATKINS GLEN, N.Y., June 25 Mark Donohue won the annual 87-lap, 200-mile sports car race here today in a Lola-Chevrolet sponsored by the Sun Oil Company.

BATESVILLE, Miss., June 25 James H. Meredith carried his "march against fear" deeper into Mississippi today and urged Negroes along the way to prove their courage by voting in the Mississippi gubernatorial election this summer.

STAMFORD, Conn., June 25 James B. Grant's and Robert D.C. Meeker's Shields Class sloop, Blue Belle (by 3 minutes 45 seconds) and Jerome T. Coe's Luders-16, Sweet Sixteen (by a split second) were winners today of 8.1-mile races on Long Island Sound in the season's 12th East-of-Rye Yacht Racing Association championship event. The races concluded Stamford Yacht Club's annual two-day regatta.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., June 25 Miss Regene Eleanor Gronich, daughter of Mrs. Harry E. Gronich and the late Mr. Gronich, was married at her home here today to Kenneth Michael Prager, son of Mr. and Mrs. Max Prager of Brooklyn, New York. Rabbi Burton Mehler, uncle of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony.

Arbitration in the unusal eight-day strike of merchant marine captains and mates earlier this month has been completed and a decision of the arbitrator probably will be handed to the parties today.

ALEXANDER CARTWRIGHT was either a genius or was blessed with psychic powers when he designed the first baseball rules in 1845 and established 90 feet as the distance between bases. CHICAGO, June 25 (AP) Ernie Banks slammed two tworun homers behind the threehit pitching of Joe Niekro, a rookie, after Bill Hands had hurled a five-hitter today and the Chicago Cubs swept a double-header from the Houston Astros, 4-1 and 8-0.

GLASSBORO, N. J., June 25--President Johnson and Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin ended their two-day conference today with an agreement to keep in touch, but gave no hint that they had succeeded in narrowing their differences over the Middle East and Vietnam.

The Glassboro meetings of President Johnson and Premier Kosygin are now history. On the basis of the reports both men gave after they had left Glassboro, the conversations produced no immediate specific agreements or reductions of differences on individual international problems. Nevertheless, there is every reason to credit the President's assertion that "these have been very good and very useful talks."

TORONTO, June 25 The success of Expo 67 in attracting a flood of United States tourist dollars is prompting some economists to predict a substantial improvement in Canada's international payments deficit this year.

The work was so successful that it is being repeated in the 1967 Caramoor Festival now in progress.

The marriage of Miss Lisbeth Warms, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel J. Warms of Jackson Heights, Queens, to Charles Reiter Orgel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Orgel, also of New York, took place yesterday afternoon at the Forest Hills Inn in Queens. Rabbi Bernard Bamberger performed the ceremony.

THE Columbia Broadcasting System's news divi sion opened a four-hour inquiry last night into the findings of the Warren Commission report on the assassination of President Kennedy. GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 26 Capt. Lyle B. Ramsey and Richard Ramsey of Round Hill scored a 79-9 70 today to win the 48th annual Father-and-Son Golf Association championship at the Garden City Golf Club. Par was 37, 36 73 over the 6,318-yard course.

HONG KONG, June 26 Peking made its first formal protest to the British Government today over the recent rioting and demonstrations in Hong Kong, and renewed the series of demands put forward last month.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., June 28 Eugene J. Brinkman, assistant to the president of United States Steel International, Inc., New York, died today at Orange Memorial Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived here at 32 South Munn Avenue.

NARROWSBURG, N.Y., June 26 A dozen years ago Joe Purcell, a master mariner, returned home to this inland Delaware River village and opened a country store featuring guns, bait and tackle. PALM BEACH, Fla., June 26 Mr, and Mrs. Charles Ide Kane have announced the engagement of Mrs. Kane's daughter, Miss Mary Russell Marsh, to Alexander Hamilton Stephens of New York. He is the son of Lieut, Col. Alexander Hamilton Stephens, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Stephens of Fort Lauderdale.

WASHINGTON, June 26 The process of drawing up the balance sheet on the Glassboro summit is now under way, and while it is certainly not possible to call it an unmitigated success, there is little evidence so far of disappointment within the Johnson Administration.

PITTSBURGH, June 26 (AP) The Westinghouse Electric Corporation announced today it had been awarded a contract to provide major equipment for a 550,000-kilowatt nuclear power plant near Red Wing, Minn.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) The nation's Governors were accused today of ignoring the poverty in their rural areas by Representative Joseph Y. Resnick, Democrat of upstate New York, chairman of the House Subcommittee on Rural Development.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) An Interstate Commerce Commission board voted today to allow increases ranging from 3 to 5 per cent in truck freight rates to go into effect in the central states.

The American Savoyards, the Gilbert and Sullivan troupe, will become a subscription group with its 15th season, which will begin with previews Oct. 3 at the Jan Hus Playhouse, 351 East 74th Street. The formal opening will take place Oct. 12.

George Seewagen Jr. of Bayside, Queens, and Tony Vincent of New York, the top-seeded players, led the way into the third round of the New York State tennis championship at the North Shore Tennis and Racquets Club in Bayside yesterday.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., June 26--The 26th annual fair of Christ Church (Episcopal), called "America the Beautiful," will be held July 8 from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. in the Parish Hall and at the church grounds on East Main Street.

The New York Jets announced yesterday that Gerry Philbin and Paul Rochester, half of the club's defensive front four, have returned signed contracts for the 1967 American Football League season.

WASHINGTON, June 26 Depicting Washington as a "crime infested city," the House passed today a modified form of the anticrime bill for the District of Columbia that President Johnson vetoed last year. The vote was 355 to 14.

Mayor Lindsay has been warned by health authorities that New York faces an epidemic of taxi fatigue. PARIS, June 26 French officials said tonight that Premier Kosygin was likely to stop in Paris Wednesday on his way from Havana to Moscow.

The chief surgeon at the autopsy on President Kennedy says that X-rays prove an as sassin's bullet that hit the President" in the base of the neck did not strike any bony structures."

NEW CANAAN, Conn., June 26 Mrs, Howard M. Ogden has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Ruth Easter Ogden, to John Otis Carroll of Greenwich, son of Ralph C. Carroll of Norfolk and Vero Beach, Fla., and the late Mrs. Carroll, the former Miss Dorothy G. Smith.

ALBANY, June 26 William J. vanden Heuvel, fourth vice president of the Constitutional Convention, said tonight that he had been "told" that a subcommittee of the convention's Judiciary Committee would "recommend unanimously against" any court merger proposals at the convention.
WASHINGTON, June 26 Congress moved swiftly today to save the Administration's Teacher Corps, which is due to expire at midnight Friday.

WASHINGTON, June 26 The Administration is ready to start trading Federal land in California, including two national monuments and Pacific Coast beaches now used for defense purposes, to gain a Redwood national park.
A major reorganization of the city school system's Board of Examiners, which was ordered by a new state law last month, has begun with the election of Arthur Klein as the new chairman of the board.

CHICAGO, June 26 (AP) Successive home runs by Billy Williams and Ron Santo in the first inning sparked the Chicago Cubs to a 4-2 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies today and extended their winning streak to seven games, their longest since 1954.

BUTLER, Pa., June 26 Eric Ferguson, former assistant director of public relations for the Pittsburgh district of the United States Steel Corporation, died yesterday in St. Francis General Hospital in Pittsburgh. He was injured in an auto accident in Pittsburgh last Thursday. He was 72 years old.
HOUSTON, June 16 (AP) A Federal District Court jury found Joseph Stassi, 60 years old of New York, guilty today of masterminding a $4.5-million heroin smuggling operation.

KANSAS CITY, June 26 (UPI) Randy Matson, a shot-putter from Texas A. and M., and Ken Sitzberger, a diver from Indiana University, head a group of 22 student-athletes who were awarded postgraduate scholarships by the National Collegiate Athletic Association today.
GAZA, June 26 Able Nathan, the peace pilot, made another move today for ArabIsrael understanding, this time in an ice-cream truck.

BE it ever so sumptuous there's no place like a pal ace that is a home. "Palaces of a Queen," which exposed a succession of superb views of six British royal residences at the Guild Theater yesterday, stands as the colorful, definitive proof of the vast difference between say, Windsor and Westehester.
CANTON, Mass., June 26 (UPI) A handcuffed man was found shot to death today in a sandpit. The gangland style slaying was the 44th in 39 months in eastern Massachusetts.
Controller Mario A. Procaccino yesterday criticized Mayor Lindsay's first annual report, in which the Mayor expressed satisfaction and pride in the city's progress.

THE pronouncements of poets on their art on technical matters and on esthetics are common enough occurrences. Pope and Wordsworth, Pound and Eliot spring easily to mind. But what gives their utterances force are the poems themselves. It is the poetry that makes possible the dissemination, the acceptance and the influence of their remarks.

THE experts were agreed last spring that the Pirates would make a runaway of the National League pennant race if they got any sort of respectable pitching. Their pitching has dot been respectable. They are not making a runaway. In fact, they have been struggling and their current position in fourth place galls their intense and combative manager, Harry Walker.
Louis A. Stone, a former executive of Eversharp, Inc., died at New York Hospital yesterday at the age of 71. He lived at 710 Park Avenue.
The spot rate on the British pound closed unchanged from its Friday level of $2.7898 in moderate trading yesterday on foreign exchange markets here.
The trading pace slowed a bit and prices turned downward yesterday on the American Stock Exchange.

OCEANPORT, N.J., June 26 (AP) Milton Polinger's Decacean captured the $6,500 Polynesian Purse today in a driving finish at Monmouth Park before a crowd of 14,560. The victory completed a double for B.P. Hacker, the trainer, and Jim Johnson, the jockey.

The Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith has asked the City Commission on Human Rights to investigate what it describes as "blatant and vicious anti-Semitic outbursts and racist behavior" in four recent school-community controversies in largely Negro sections.

Jack Cohen, 45 years old, who was elected chairman of the board of H.C. Bohack Co., Inc., Brooklyn-based supermarktt chain, on March 30, has resigned, it was announced yesterday. Joseph Binder, 36, the company's president, will assume the functions of chairman in addition to his present duties.
Arthur Miller, regional administrator here of the General Service Administration, died Sunday night in Suffolk General Hospital after a heart attack. He was 57 years old.
CHICAGO, June 26 Little Parsons College of Fairfield, Iowa, dismissed today its controversial president, Millar G. Roberts.
CINCINNATI, June 26 (AP) Claude Osteen's five-hit pitching sparked the Los Angeles Dodgers to a 3-0 victory tonight over the Cincinnati Reds.
GREENVILLE, Miss., June 26 The Federal Government has drastically revamped its food aid program in Mississippi in an effort to reach more poor people.
The Aluminum Company of America has contracted to sell its manufacturing and office complex in Edgewater, N.J., to Irving Maidman for more than $2.5 million.
ROME, June 26 Pope Paul VI strongly reaffirmed today his call to grant international status to Jerusalem and made an impassioned plea for an end to "fratricidal war" in Vietnam and the Middle East.
Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin of the Soviet Union left New York yesterday in a jovial and almost exuberant mood, which contrasted sharply with the cool reserve he displayed on his arrival 10 days ago.

Jazz, which had been intended to be the opening offering of the Rheingold Central Park Music Festival last Friday until rain wiped out that program, finally reached the festival's stage in the Wollman Skating Rink last night.
Leonard Bernstein will conduct the Israel Philharmonic on July 9 on Mount Scopus.
Prices moved up in quiet trading yesterday on the London stock exchange.

Youth, it has been said, is a condition that is almost always outgrown. As the more responsible leaders of the Republican party contemplate the recent convention of the National Federation of Young Republicans, they can only hope that this is true.
KANSAS CITY, June 26 The New York Yankees recovered more of their lost arts of baseball tonight and ran their winning streak to four games by defeating the Kansas City Athletics, 5-2.

The Real Great Society, a social work group in the East Village, added a University of the Streets last night to its other activities: a karate department, a go-into-businessfor-yourself department and a stay-off-the-streets and outof-trouble department.

LOS ANGELES, June 26 A funeral service will be held on Saturday at the Barnert Memorial Hospital, Paterson, N.J., for Dr. Jacob Roemer. Dr. Roemer was director of the hospital's department of radiology from 1920 to 1940.

STONINGTON, Conn., June 26 Capt. Henry S. Morgan Jr., U.S.N., and Mrs. Morgan have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Catherine Adams Morgan, to Alec Mitchell Peltier, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward L. Peltier of Milwaukee.
STANTON, Del., June 26 (AP) Garth Patterson, the leading rider at the meeting, rode four winners at Delaware Park today, three of them in succession. Patterson, who ...
MOSCOW, June 26 The Soviet Union threw a little cold. water tonight on any hopes raised among Russians by the two meetings of Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin and President Johnson.
ANAHEIM, Calif., June 26 (AP) Two run-scoring singles by Bob Rodgers helped Jack Hamilton record his first victory for California as the Angels beat the Washington Senators, 4-3, tonight.
Samuel P. Mosher announced his resignation yesterday as chairman and director of Flying Tiger Line, Inc., the big airfreight carrier.
WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) The Senate confirmed today the nomination of James P. Grant to be assistant administrator for Vietnam in the Agency for International Development.

Singing "Solidarity Forever," some 500 caseworkers from the Welfare Department marched across the Brooklyn Bridge yesterday and joined caseworkers from other boroughs in a mass demonstration at City Hill.
THE METROPOLE, 725 Seventh Avenue, Gene Krupa, drummer, and his All-Star jazz combo.
WASHINGTON, June 26 Vice President Humphery made one of his shorter speeches today.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, June 27 (AP)--Premier Nguyen Cao Ky announced today that his running mate in South Vietnam's presidential election would be Nguyen Van Loc, a civilian who is chairman of the Army-People Council.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., June 26 (AP) Ted Uhlaender slammed a tie-breaking triple in the fourth inning and Al Worthington pitched out of trouble in relief in the eighth and ninth innings tonight as the Minnesota Twins beat the Boston Red Sox, 2-1.

The engagement of Miss Suzen Cheryl Kehaner to Jack Goldenthal has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Sol Kahaner of Jamaica Estates, Queens. Mr. Goldenthal is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Sot Goldenthal of Scarsdale, N. Y.
MOST of the bridge clubs in the metropolitan area devote their attention primarily either to rubber bridge or duplicate.

WASHINGTON, June 26--The Army said today that it had information "from a confidential source" that Capt. Howard B. Levy, an Army physician sentenced to prison for refusing to train special forces aidmen, had threatened to defect to a Communist country, if the Army freed him on bail.

WASHINGTON, June 26 Miss Janet Newbold Legendre, daughter of Mrs. Newbold Legendre and the late Morris Legendre of New Orleans, was married here this evening to Donald Roberts McClelland. His parents are Mrs. Herbert Martin of Detroit and the late Donald McClelland of Annapolis, Md.

Second-quarter operations of the Corning Glass Works and its subsidiaries declined from a year earlier, pulling down earnings for the first half of this year, according to the results announced yesterday.

GRIFFIN, Ga., June 26 (UPI) Five white youths were sentenced to life in prison today after pleading guilty to charges of robbing a Negro church at gunpoint during Sunday services and then raping two teen-aged choir members.
Production of steel edged upward last week, making its first gain after four consecutive weekly declines, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., June 26--Bert Elmer Swanson, a sociologist and political scientist, looks with professional dismay at people who deal in fantasies and talk their way around unpleasant realities.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 26 King Hussein of Jordan warned the General Assembly today that if it did not condemn Israel as an aggressor and force the return of Arab lands, the recent fighting would be only one clash in a long War.
DALLAS, Tex., June 26 (AP) The new president of the American Medical Association said today that the organization recognizes Medicare "but does not support or endorse it."
WASHINGTON, June 26 Interest rates on three-month Treasury bills dipped at today's auction, but the six-month bill rate rose sharply once again, the Treasury disclosed tonight.
Lincoln Center: "Jacobowsky and the Colonel," Hamburg State Opera, Metropolitan Opera House, 8 P.M.

The dastardly villains and beauteous maltreated maidens of old-time melodramas are playing a return engagement--of a sort--at the New York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West, in a show called "Theatrical Posters of Bygone Days, 1880-1920."

MOSCOW, June 26 (AP) The Government newspaper Izvestia published charges today that Svetlana Alliluyeva, Stalin's daughter, was a sick woman with a history of nervous breakdowns and attacks of hysteria.

Mildred Dunnock will be the ballet-narrator at the United States premiere of Claude Debussy's "Chanson de Bilitis" on Saturday night at the Caramoor Festival in Katonah, N. Y. The 18-minute work will be on the same bill with Carl Orff's "Catulli Carmina," which runs for 55 minutes.

HENDERSON, Ky., June 26 (AP)--The search for Don Hayes, an Illinois trotting track executive, and his wife ended today, in a cornfield, where the wreckage of their small plane was spotted by an oil worker.

HOLLYWOOD, June 26 (AP) Tommy Guinan, a brother of the late Texas Guinan, the hostess and operator of garish speakeasies during Prohibition in the 1920's and early 1930's, died of cancer today at Cedars of Lebanon Hospital. He was 70 years old.
HAVANA, June 26 Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin of the Soviet Union arrived in Cuba from New York today for talks with Premier Fidel Castro.
HUNTINGTON, L.I., June 26 Larry Whipple, an 18-year-old student from Seattle, won the only race today in the United States O.K. Dinghy open sailing championships on Huntington Bay.
AUSTIN, Tex., June 26 Mrs. Patrick J. Nugent took her plump five-day-old son Patrick Lyndon home from Seton Hospital today.
MINEOLA, L.I., June 26 Arthur Choice, a Negro businessman in the suburban community of Roosevelt, looked at his hands the other day and asked, "What have we got that's contagious?"

In a dramatic finish that had four of the five contestants only noses apart, Ogden Phipps's Lucretia Bori won the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday. The event was a five-furlong test for 2-year-old fillies, and Lucretia Bori with a dramatic closing rush took the verdict in 0:59.
WASHINGTON, June 26 The chairman of the Federal Reserve Board said today that the main need of the economy was "prompt" action by Congress on the Administration's proposed tax increase.
WASHINGTON, June 26--The F. D. A. has cleared up its longstanding backlog of new drugs awaiting approval, Dr. James L. Goddard, the agency's commissioner, said today.

JERICHO, Jordan, June 26 (AP) The Government tried in vain today to stop the flow of refugees from the Israeli-occupied west bank of the Jordan River. But efforts to persuade 2,000 to 3,000 refugees to go back to their homes or old refugee camps failed.
WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) The Justice Department authorized its United States attorneys today to prosecute concerns that illegally fix prices.
WASHINGTON, June 26 (UPI) The Defense Department made public today the names of 93 servicemen who died in recent military action in Vietnam.

Mr, and Mrs. Louis Wald of 2500 Johnson Avenue in Riverdale, the Bronx, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helene Janet Wald, to Burton Theodore Berinsky of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Manuel Berinsky of Boston.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., June 26 Directors of Sterchi Bros. Stores, Inc., with a retail furniture chain of 54 stores in seven Southeastern states, elected J. Mack Tenney of Birmingham, Mich., as president today. Owen C. Bowden of Knoxville, who has been both chairman of the board and president for 14 years, relinquished the presidency at his own request but will retain the chairmanship.
Dorothy Parker, the poet and satirist, left the bulk of her estate to the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. under a will filed in Manhattan Surrogates' Court yesterday.

Mr. and Mrs. Frank Joseph Manheim of 2 East 88th Street and Redding Ridge, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Katherine Quittner Manheim, to Christopher Worrall Ryan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Fortune Peter Ryan of New York and Murray Bay, Que.
KANSAS CITY, June 26 (AP) The first Negro moderator in the 98-year history of the Missouri Synod of the United Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A. was elected unanimously today at its annual meeting.

Technically Larry Richardson does a variety of things so well that he almost makes you think that he can do choreography to boot. His program of dances last night at the Village Theater, with Tamara Woshakiwska, Charlotte Honda and Margot Parsons, was replete with technical flashes but little choreographic cohesion.

RAPIDAN, Va., June 26 Mr, and Mrs. George Dandridge Williams have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Virginia Armistead Williams, to Peter von Schilling Stanley, son of Mrs. von Schilling Stanley of Richmond and of James Selwyn Stanley of Princeton, N. J., and Vedbaek, Denmark.
GENEVA, June 26 The General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade opened the way today for the admission of Argentina, Iceland, Ireland and Poland as regular member nations.

OAKLAND, Miss., June 26 James H. Meredith moved into the Delta region of Mississippi on his "walk against fear" today and found his own feet far more troublesome than the area's white segregationists.

DETROIT, June 26 (AP) Automobile assembly lines will begin slowing down this week for change-overs to 1968 models, after having produced last week the highest number of cars for any week so far in 1967.

GLASSBORO, N. J., , June 26 Bill Carey and his crew rolled up the weathered wooden snow fences that had held back the crowds. Section by section, the telephone company men dismantled the 140-foot tower that had beamed word of the Glassboro summit conference to the world.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 26 Mrs. Elinor Mackenzie Bangs Chatfield-Taylor of San Francisco and Robert Chatfield-Taylor of Manchester, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Joan Chatfield-Taylor, fashion editor of The San Francisco Chronicle, to Philippe Henry de Tessan of San Francisco. He is the son of Mrs. Georges Henry of Paris and the late Mr. Henry.
Still working in strange and mysterious ways, the Mets found their way out of the National League cellar last night with a 3-2 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates.
BRUSSELS, June 26 France fought hard today, against the opposition of her five Common Market partners, to stall negotiations on the British application for market membership.
NEWARK, June 26 About 1,800 truck drivers and brewery workers went on strike today against P. Ballantine Sons.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., June 26 Huffman Baines, the 82year-old uncle of President Johnson and the son of a onetime Texas Secretary of State, died in a rest home here early today.

PELHAM, N.Y., June 26 Robert T. Colwell of 657 Ely Avenue, a vice president and senior creative consultant of the J. Walter Thompson Company, died of a heart attack yesterday while playing golf at the Pelham Country Club. He was 64 years old.

ST. LOUIS, June 26 (UPI) Jim Cosman, a rookie making his first start of the season, pitched four-hit ball for 8 1/3 innings and drove in what proved to be the winning run tonight as the St. Louis Cardinals defeated the San Francisco Giants, 3-1.
ALGIERS, June 26--The Algerian Government today took another step in its anti-Zionist and anti-Anglo-American campaign, blacklisting a series of movies and a number of cinema performers.
LONDON, June 26 Sir Alan Bourne, the first director of Britain's Combined Operations Command in World War II, died Saturday at Torquay, England. He was 84 years old.

Fifty passengers rushed from a halted BMT subway car yesterday and joined a half-dozen patrolmen in tipping the car to free a boy trapped between the car and the platform of the Halsey Street station in Brooklyn.
THE public accounting profession, deeply troubled by questions raised regarding the quality of its work, is mulling over an additional means of monitoring performance.

MONTREAL, June 26 The proposition that crowded the the downtown areas of large cities can be improved by dispersing much of their activity to outlying areas drew sharp criticism today from a celebrated city planner.

BERLIN, June 6 Five former Nazi officials were arrested in West Germany today and flown to West Berlin for trial on charges of complicity in the mass murder of Jews and Polish workers during World War II.
