The Lindsay administration announced yesterday that it planned "a major reorganization" of the city's Bureau of Retirement and Pension.
If you throw something beautiful away, you might embellish a junk yard, but you'll blight the countryside, even if the object is a Schlitz beer can.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) The Senate Finance Committee approved today a House-passed bill to extend for three months, to Sept. 30, 1967, suspension of all duties on imports of nickel into the United States.
The 90-foot arm of a construction crane toppled into a three-story-deep excavation pit at Lexington Avenue and 51st Street yesterday afternoon as the operator jumped safely out of the cab.

WASHINGTON. June 26 President Johnson and his aides, reflecting on their meetings with Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin, have not lost hope that they can interest the Soviet Union in a more durable Middle Eastern settlement.

When Congress last year passed the Laboratory Animal Welfare Act, it reflected the nation's determination to establish minimum standards for the care of dogs and other animals used in medical research. But what Congress did, one man has now undone.

WASHINGTON, June 26 Strong support for the maritime program of Secretary of Transportation Alan S. Boyd was voiced today by a spokesman for a major ship operating group before the Senate Merchant Marine subcommittee.

Summer lies heavy over the streets of New York, Industrial and automobile fumes choke the breath. There are no air-conditioners to break the spell in the dank, cloned-in walk-ups. For children, on certain streets only, temporary relief comes from an open fire hydrant. But there must be better means of cooling off than running barefoot between parked cars on hot asphalt.

SIOUX FALLS, S. D., June 26 Mr. and Mrs. Ellsworth E. Evans have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sandra Elaine Evans, to Richard Michael T. Fee, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Fee of Austin, Minn.

NEW ORLEANS, June 26 A key investigator for District Attorney Jim Garrison quit his job today and said that he had found "no truth" to Mr. Garrison's contention that a conspiracy led to the assassination of President Kennedy.
Hilliard J. Coan, president of First National Stores, told the annual meeting of the company yesterday in Somerville, Mass., that it had a loss in the fiscal first quarter.

LAFAYETTE, La., June 26 Dr, and Mrs. Philip F. Dur have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Maria Elena Dur, to Philip Anthony Morris, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter F. Morris of Boston and Mattipoisett and Anna Maria, Fla.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., June 26 The Suffolk County Board of Supervisors created a $19,000a-year advisory post today and immediately filled it with a Supervisor who announced his retirement from the board.

WASHINGTON, June 26 Senator Frank Church, Democrat of Idaho, proposed today that the United States declare it will no longer give or sell arms to the Arab countries as a first step toward a general embargo or stringent limitation on weapons shipments to the Middle East.

For the first time since Nikita S. Khrushchey was removed from power in the Soviet Union in October, 1964 tape-recorded interviews, with silent films, mostly in color, showing him in and around his country home, have become available in the West.

When it comes to public relations, the expression, "When in Rome, do as the Romans do" isn't exactly accurate. More realistically, it should be, "When in Rome, follow Roman customs but use American P.R. techniques."
MONTGOMERY, Ala., June 26 Gov. Lurleen B. Wallace of Alabama is suffering from cancer, for the second time in less than two years, it was disclosed today.
WASHINGTON, June 26 (UPI) The Senate passed by voice vote and sent to the House today a bill to tighten Federal control over the operation by holding companies of savingsand-loan associations.

Premier Kosygin's stopover in Havana is not unlike Deputy Chairman Mikoyan's placating visit after the Cuban missile crisis in 1962. Then as now Premier Castro must have been rather fed up with Moscow, but with no desire, intention or possibility of breaking the close relations between the two countries. Cuba is still dependent on Russia for credits, economic help and arms.

TRENTON, June 26 Gov. Richard J. Hughes's choice as New Jersey's first statewide Public Defender Peter Murray, a soft-spoken legal aid official from Nutley was confirmed today at a special session of the State Senate.
From the Suez Canal to the Forest Hills Stadium via Gimbel's Toy Department is a roundabout path to success, but it is the one taken by Dimitri Toufexis, a 14-year-old keyboard prodigy.
Ernest J. Balez Jr., President since 1966 of the Standard Dredging Corporation, was elected here yesterday to the additional post of chairman.
BUENOS AIRES, June 27-- There is growing concern here over the Government's proposed law to repress all Communist activity.
LONDON, June 27 (AP)-- Dominion Day, a colt owned partly by Bing Crosby, was withdrawn today from the Irish Sweeps Derby to be run at Curragh, Ireland, Saturday.

HONG KONG, June 27--The official Chinese Communist daily, Jenmin Jih Pao, today linked the flight of a United States Air Force plane over Hainan Island yesterday to the talks between President Johnson and Soviet Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin in Glassboro, N.J.

ROME, June 27--A British delegate to the International Conference on Automation, Full Employment and a Balanced Economy, called upon the United States today to work harder at showing the world what is being done to solve civil rights problems.

YAKUM, Israel, June 27-- Gerosch Bent was driving a bus in Stockholm the day the Middle Eastern war broke out, Stefan Schwartz had just been released from the Swedish Royal Air Force and John Jacobs was in Rotterdam studying at a technical institute.

Addressed the national convention of the Jaycees, formerly the Junior Chambers of Commerce, at the Baltimore Civic Center; returned to Washington; announced the five-member delegation headed by Vice President Humphrey who will attend the inauguration of President Chung Hee Park of South Korea; lunched with Secre

WASHINGTON, June 27-- The record of the Americanowned fleet of foreign-flag ships in the Vietnam war was cited before a Senate subcommittee today as evidence that the Government could rely on such ships for sealift capability in emergencies.

WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP)--The American Farm Bureau Federation had used the farmer to build one of the nation's largest insurance and financial empires, Representative Joseph Y. Resnick, Democrat of upstate New York, said today.
KANSAS CITY, June 27--The New York Yankees slid past the Baltimore Orioles into seventh place tonight by splitting a double-header with the Kansas City Athletics.
The wholesale commodity price index rose to 98.3 on Monday, from 98 on Friday.
ROME, June 27--Pope Paul VI restored today the ancient but long-neglected office of permanent deacon and ruled that some of its occupants may be married.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 27 --An action asking the Federal District Court here to block the execution of all prisoners on Quentin's death row was from a last night by the N.A.A.C.P. Legal Defense and Education's Fund, Inc.

WASHINGTON, June 27-- President Johnson today named Clifford L. Alexander Jr. as the new chairman of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, the Government agency in charge of ending job discrimination in industry and labor.

BRUSSELS, June 27--The European Common Market today put its final seal of approval on the Kennedy round under which tariffs of the world's major trading nations will be cut by one third over the next five years.
The planned extension of the welfare stoppage today to the Children's Center in East Harlem carries to a new low the disregard of human values demonstrated by the Social Service Employees Union.

WEST YELLOWSTONE, Mont., June 27--The confusion dividing moderate Republican leaders a year before the Presidential nominating convention of 1968 is being dramatized daily in this tiny resort village at the annual Western Governors Conference.
SACRAMENTO, June 27 (AP)--Gov. Ronald Reagan said today he would sign his $5 billion budget even if the Legislature had not provided a tax increase to balance it.

NEW ORLEANS, June 27-- William Gurvich said today that District Attorney Jim Garrison had become so "obsessed" with his inquiry into the assassination of President Kennedy that he has considered raiding the local office of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

The troubled career of L'Alglon Apparel, Inc.--once one of the leading producers in the women's dress industry--entered a new phase yesterday with the announcement that Ben Milberg, a long-time executive of a factoring company, had been elected president.

BONN, June 27--Klaus Werner Epstein, chairman of the department of history of Brown University in Providence, R.I., died here last evening of injuries received in an automobile crash on June 23. He was 40 years old.

CROTON-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., June 27--Ren Snepvangers, acoustical engineer and inventor, died Monday of cancer at Phelps Memorial Hospital, Tarrytown. He was 67 years old and lived on Short Hill Road here.
The hippies arrested in Tompkins Square Park on Memorial Day were in Criminal Court yesterday for the beginning of their pretrial hearings before the same judge who had arraigned them.

Howard Gould, the last surviving son of Jay Gould, the railroad financier, left an estate with a net value of $64,392,318, of which about $50-million will go for payment of Federal and New York State taxes, according to an appraisal filed yesterday in the State Transfer Tax Department.
THE latest entry in the South Vietnamese presi dential race is Duong Van Minh, a slow-spoken, somewhat sluggish, diffident military man.

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., June 27--Wait A While, an aged bay gelding owned and ridden by James Geller, captured the working hunter championship after a hackoff with Cleister Farm's Peyton Place today at the Bedford Whip and Spur Junior Horse Show.
LONDON, June 27--Prince Charles, heir to the British throne, will be one of the Counselors of State who will act for Queen Elizabeth while she is visiting Canada.
Jan Oostermoyer, former president of the Shell Chemical Company, died Monday at a hospital in Phoenix, Aris., after in illness of several months, He was 70 years old.

BEDFORD, N.Y., June 27-- Mrs. Thomas William Stevenson has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Linda McKay Stevenson, to Theodore Martin Weicker, son of Lowell P. Weicker of Mill Neck, L.I., and Mrs. Howard C. Paulsen of New York.
MONTREAL, June 27--A specialist in urban parking problems urged city planners today to learn to live with the automobile instead of seeking to keep motor traffic out of downtown areas.

CAIRO, June 27--All diplomatic missions and United Nations agencies have been asked to close their offices in the Suez Canal Zone today. The Foreign Ministry of the United Arab Republic said the facilities may be reopened once all traces of aggression have been removed.

The International Advertising Association's World Advertising Conference opened yesterday in London with the big event a panel discussion by way of communications satellite between London, New York and Tokyo on "Money and Leisure --How They Change the World Consumer."

A Federal court refused yesterday to stop District Attorney Frank S. Hogan's office from asking that officials of milk companies involved in a price-fixing investigation sign waivers of immunity from prosecution.

The teachers union charged yesterday that the Board of Education was dropping 200 upper-grade teaching positions, thereby creating the threat of larger classes in these grades, in seeking funds to improve early-grade programs in ghetto schools.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 27 (AP)--The American Library Association has decided to move to Washington after more than half a century in Chicago.

NEW DELHI, June 27-- Home Minister Y.B. Chavan told Parliament today that one of its Congress party members from West Bengal had been assaulted, stripped of his clothes and forced to walk naked through the streets of a town where he had been addressing a political meeting.
It was a big day for 12-yearold Linda Smith. She was graduating from P.S. 140 in Jamaica, Queens. But she appeared to be almost as excited about her grandmother's graduation.

District Attorney Jim Garrison of New Orleans contends that Lee Harvey Oswald was set up by the real assassins of President Kennedy as a "decoy" with the hope that he would be killed by angry Dallas policemen.

LONDON, June 27 (Reuters) --The giant British Motor Corporation has appointed a 49year-old American, Filmer Paradise, to head its continental European manufacturing and sales network, it was announced here tonight.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, June 27--Britain's special envoy to Rhodesia, Lord Alport, met Prime Minister Ian D. Smith for 37 minutes today in the first official contact between British and Rhodesian officials in seven months.

The engagement of Miss Diana Halstead Otto to Jeffrey Morrow, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alan Bowers Morrow of Sewickley Heights, Pa., has been announced by the prospective bride's father, Konfried Karl Otto of Huguenot, S.I.

WASHINGTON, June 27-- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee today limited to 15 the number of countries eligible for foreign aid loans and forbade the President to increase the total without the prior consent of Congress.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., June 29 (AP)--The Air Force said today it would launch six military satellites with a single rocket on Saturday.
Record net earnings of General Mills, Inc., for the fiscal year ended May 28 were reported yesterday at $28,456,000, equal to $3.36 a share, or 9 per cent over the preceding fiscal year.
James D. McClimans has been named executive vice president of the Joseph Feiss Co., a subsidiary of the Phillips-Van Heusen Corporation.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, June 27 (Reuters)-- A man charged with having sexual relations with a colored (mixed-race) woman has been acquitted because the judge could not decide whether the defendant was white.

ATHENS, June 27--Helen Vlachos, a publisher, who closed her two conservative dailies and one picture magazine because of the censorship imposed by Greece's military regime, declared today that she would not resume publication until the full restoration of press freedom.

ALBANY, June 27--Constitutional Convention committees voted today to seek approval for the creation of a state department of criminal justice, the extension of legislators' terms to four years, and the retention of a separate Surrogates' Court and State Court of Claims.
TOKYO, June 27 (AP)-- Ichiro Kiyose, defense counsel for Japan's wartime Premier, Tojo, at the international tribunal after World War II, died of pneumonia today. He was 82 years old.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 27-- The Government of Lebanon has begun the difficult and delicate task of reviving one of this country's major enterprises, tourism, a $20-million-a-year revenue earner that the IsraeliArab war of three weeks ago stifled.

BANGKOK, Thailand, June 27--Gen. Duong Van Minh, exiled former chief of state of South Vietnam, cleared a minor hurdle today in his effort to return to Saigon and run for President in the Sept. 3 election.

The Terrace Room of the Plaza was the setting last night for the marriage of Miss Elaine Freed, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Reuben Freed of Southfields, N.Y., to Cantor George Lindenblatt. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jeno Lindenblatt of Budapest.

LOS ANGELES, June 27--Arden Mayfair, Inc., a large West Coast supermarket chain, held a special stockholder's meeting today but a conflict-of-interest dispute that was expected to disrupt the gathering failed to materialize.
Lady Malcolm DouglasHamilton gave a small reception yesterday afternoon in her home at 174 East 74th Street, to present her granddaughter, Miss Daphne E.M. Nash, to family friends.
"Tobacco Road," the secondlongest-running drama in Broadway history, will be converted into a folk musical for presentation here next March.
Interest rates climbed dramatically yesterday. In the hurly-burly of activity throughout the money and capital markets, these were the big developments:

The Consolidated Edison Company submitted data yesterday to the Public Service Commission to substantiate contentions that its construction costs, taxes, fuel transportation and other costs were higher here than in other laree cities.

THE Flying Tiger Line, Inc., with origins in World War II fighter planes that were decorated to resemble tiger sharks, disclosed yesterday some of the events that led to the resignation of Samuel B. Mosher as chairman.

Six playgrounds adjoining the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway in Brooklyn will be opened today, Robert Moses, chairman of the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority, and August Heckscher, Commissioner of Parks, announced yesterday.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, June 28 (AP)--A Vietcong mine blew up a jammed bus last night, killing 40 Vietnamese civilians and wounding 10.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 27--Navy fighter-bomber pilots attacked the Namdinh power plant, 46 miles southeast of Hanoi, yesterday.

A tapestry depicting the "second most influential" tea party in American history was unveiled yesterday afternoon by August Heckscher, the city's Administrator of Recreation and Cultural Affairs, in the lobby of the old Vanderbilt Hotel, Park Avenue and 33d Street, which is being converted into a commercial and residential building.

Mayor Lindsay said yesterday the city would be happy to use procedures established under its new Office of Collective Bargaining and go to fact-finding on all "appropriate issues" in an effort to end the nine-day welfare tieup.
MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 27 Robert E. Dwyer, president of The Anaconda Company from June, 1952, until his retirement in 1956, died here today. He was 81 years old and lived at 462 Park Street.

WASHINGTON, June 27 --President Johnson's chief economic adviser told Congress today that an income tax rise was needed to avert renewed inflation and higher interest rates later this year and in 1968.
The New York Mets, who climbed out of the National League cellar to ninth place Monday night, carried their mini-winning streak half a step forward yesterday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP)--President Johnson conferred today with King Phumiphol Aduldet of Thailand about Vietnam, problems in Southeast Aisa in general and security conditions in Thailand, where the United States maintains bomber bases and about 35,000 troops.

WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) --The new treaties governing control of the Panama Canal announced yesterday by President Johnson and President Marco A. Robles of Panama were criticized today by Representative Robert Taft Jr., Republican of Ohio, a member of the House Foreign Affairs Committee.
Vincent F. Albano Jr. was elected to a third two-year term as chairman and president of the New York County Republican Committee last night during the committee's biannual organization meeting.
Television stations of the American Broadcasting Company will broadcast live coverage of the Vatican consistory tomorrow.
BLOCK ISLAND, R.I., June 27--The big question in the third regatta of the Storm Trysail Club's Block Island Week today was as much the whereabouts of the weather mark as who won.
The blue-chip game of horse breeding' spiraled to new geewhiz heights yesterday with the announcement that Buckpasser had been syndicated at a total evaluation of $4.8-million.

Paperboard production fell 2.1 per cent with 461,000 tons in the week ended June 24 compared to the corresponding 1966 week, the Paperboard Group of the American Paperboard Association reported yesterday.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., June 27 --The last open housing bill before the General Assembly was killed tonight.

There are only five persons in the world known to have blood of the type Rh Null, and one of them arrived at Mount Sinai Hospital yesterday to help save the life of a premature baby born to another of the five.
"WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) --The Pentagon announced today that military reservists who have served two years' active duty would generally be exempt from weekly drills in the Ready Reserve.
The Manhattan Shirt Company announced here yesterday the election as directors of Vera Neumann, Frederick Werner Hamm and Irving Silverman.
A new hallucinogenic drug, described as much more powerful then LSD and similar in effect to a secret military nerve gas, is in widespread distribution in California.
The Muncipal Bond Women's Club of New York announced yesterday the election of Elizabeth Dickinson as president.
WASHINGTON, June 27-- New Yorkers lost another round today in their fight against a bill that would prevent most banks from selling lottery tickets.
WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP)--The Interstate Commerce Commission urged a Federal court today to allow the merger of the New York Central and Pennsylvania railroads to be completed immediately.

Total production of paper and paperboard is holding close to the 1966 levels, an analysis of figures released by the American Paper Institute disclosed yesterday. The finding is highly significant in view of repeated warnings of overproduction from industry leaders and developments during the day.

An investigation directed by United States Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau has found that 90 per cent of the trade-waste disposal in Westchester County is handled by companies controlled by members of the Genovese and Gambino families of the Mafia.
Frederick M. Reuss Jr., a Hollis attorney, announced yesterday that he would seek election in 1968 as a delegate to the Republican National Convention committed to Richard M. Nixon for President.
Manhattan's longshoremen "declared war" yesterday on the conditions and persons they believe responsible for the island's decline as a terminal for waterborne commerce.

WASHINGTON, June 27 (UPI)--John D. Butzner of Richmond, a United States district judge for the Eastern district of Virginia, was named by President Johnson today for advancement to United States circuit judge for the Fourth Judicial Circuit.

A neighborhood of 43 buildings containing cooperative apartments for 6,000 middle-income families will be built on 145 acres of unused land in the Canarsie section of Brooklyn. New York State will finance the development --the second largest housing project in the city--with a $121-million mortgage under the Mitchell-Lama Law.

Israel's latest move toward annexing Jerusalem's Old City flies in the face of friendly advice and can serve only further to complicate efforts to find a just and lasting solution to one of the Middle East's most difficult, chronic problems.

Miss Susan Carol Kahn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Kahn of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday evening to Joseph Stewart Bravman, son of Mr. and Mrs. M. Francis Bravman of Great Neck, L.I., and Charlemont, Mass.
EAST PROVIDENCE, R.I., a 27--Dr. Charles A. Kraus, one of the nation's most distinguished chemists, died this afternoon at the Hattie Ide Chaffee Nursing Home here. He was 91 years old.
WASHINGTON, June 27-- The Johnson Administration is a little steadier, a little more confident, and a little stronger politically as a result of its handling of the Middle Eastern crisis.

CHICAGO, June 27 (AP)-- Parsons College sought an injunction in Federal court today to prevent the North Central Association of Colleges and Secondary Schools from revoking the college's accreditation.

ALTHOUGH bridge players normally seek prestige, trophies, master-points or money, the game is sufficiently absorbing--like chess, but unlike other card games--to be played repeatedly without material objectives.
While forecasters are now in agreement that this year's mini-recession is just about ended, they are sharply divided over whether the economy will advance at a snail's pace or at a dangerous gallop.
JERICHO, Jordan, June 27-- Two Israeli pilots were exchanged today at the Allenby Bridge for 425 Jordanian prisoners of war and three Iraqi consular officials.
The General Foods Corporation, a long-time pioneer in transportation and distribution methods, has developed a new pneumatic bulkhead system designed to prevent the shifting of freight in transit.

The helmsman and designer of Dame Pattie, the Australian challenger for the America's Cup, expressed confidence yesterday that the 12Meter yacht had a "good chance" to win in the September series off Newport, R.I.

Miss Lucinda Josephine Gosling and Jean-Louis Pauzat were married yesterday afternoon in Paget, Bermuda. The Rev. Peter Evans (Church of England) and the Rev. C.A. Clark of St. Michael's Roman Catholic Church, performed Catholic Church, officiated in St. Paul's Church.

The board of directors of the National Association of Broadcasters resolved yesterday to fight in court the recent ruling by the Federal Communications Commission that radio and television stations that carry cigarette advertising must also provide time for warnings that cigarettes are harmful to health.
JERUSALEM, June 27--Parliament tonight passed a bill enabling the Minister of the Interior, Haim Moshe Shapiro, to proclaim Jerusalem a single city under Israeli administration.
DENVER, June 27 (AP)-- The Denver Broncos and the Miami Dolphins of the American Football League announced today a seven-player trade that sends Cookie Gilchrist, a fullback, back to Denver.

BUDAPEST--This city has more whipped cream and chocolate cake, moi e elegant cafes and good restaurants, more jokes, more poodles and many more pretty girls than all the other capitals of Eastern Europe.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 27 (AP)--The Hyak, world's largest double-end ferryboat, is ready to continue her Pacific Ocean trip from San Diego to the Puget Sound.

PARIS, June 27--Gen. JeanMarie Navelet, 55-year-old commander of the French Army's light Aviation Division, was killed today in a flight from Trieri to Freiburg, West Germany, when the single-engine plane he was flying in crashed in the Black Forest south of Baden-Baden.
PITTSBURGH, June 27--The merger of the Rockwell-Standard Corporation, North American Aviation, Inc,, and the Draper Company was approved today by shareholders of the three companies.

The House-Senate conferees on the Congressional redistricting bill have contrived one of the more astonishing legislative performances of the year. Out of a good Senate bill and a poor House bill they have produced a "compromise" that is worse than either.
WASHINGTON, June 27--A bill to extend the Teacher Corps sailed through the House today, praised by friends and many former foes. The vote was 311 to 88.
DETROIT, June 27 (AP)-- Chico Salmon drove in four runs with a pair of doubles and a homer as the Cleveland Indians defeated the Detroit Tigers, 8-1, tonight.
WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) --The organized illicit traffic in LSD is being tied in with "hardcore, Cosa Nostra-type crminal figures," House investigators were told today.
MADRID, June 27--Spain will complete payments Friday on debts for her civil war, which ended 28 years and three months ago.
The Music Critics Association has been awarded a one-year grant of $67,200 by the National Endowment for the Arts to plan and develop a monthly digest of music criticism.
Directors of Bobbie Brooks, Inc., voted yesterday in Cleveland to skip the quarterly dividend for the second consecutive three-month period.
PARIS, June 27 (AP)-- France exploded an atomic bomb "of low yield" at her Polynesian test center tonight, the Defense Ministry announced.

WASHINGTON, June 27--A lawyer for Capt. Howard B. Levy said today that the Army should be required either to substantiate its charges that he intended to defect to a Communist country or to release him from confinement.
The Harlem Cultural Festival got off to a swinging start last night with that oft-described but rarely encountered phenomenon--dancing in the streets.
The American Stock Exchange turned mixed yesterday in moderately active trading.
The City and State Universities will co-sponsor a University of the Air on television starting next fall that will offer a full day of college courses each week.

The marriage of Mrs. Helen MacLeod Woodhouse of New York, widow of James M. Woodhouse, and daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Cameron MacLeod of Bewyn, Pa., to Benjamin Chase Gifford, son of Mrs. Paul Gifford of Fall River and Westport, Mass., took place here yesterday afternoon.
About 27,000 people showed up at the Bronx Botanical Garden last night to find out what it was like to relax on a grassy-hillside watching the stars come out while listening to Puccini.
The New York Skyliners finally displayed the almost carefree, ebullient style that marks South American soccer by gaining an easy 4-1 victory over the Dallas Tornadoes last night.

WASHINGTON, June 27-- The House Judiciary Committee yielded today to pressure from the chairman of the Rules Committee, William M. Colmer of Mississippi, and approved a separate bill that would make it a Federal crime to cross state lines to incite a riot.
WASHINGTON, June 27-- The Federal Government was urged today to help consumers by releasing information about its tests on brand-name products.

ATHENS, June 27--The Athens police director has notified all night-club owners that the breaking of dishes and glasses by enthusiastic patrons, in the style of "Zobra the Greek," was no longer permitted.

John Mosler, chairman of the board of the Mosler Safe Company, has been re-elected president of the New York Urban League, and Dr. Albert C. Stewart, an official of the Union Carbide Company, has been re-elected chairman of the board.

JEBEL LIBNI, United Arab Republic June 27--Mayor Gen. Itzhak Rabin, Chief of Staff of Israeli armed forces, toured the conquered east bank of the Suez Canal today and then told the victorious troops that "never in history did the Jewish state have such a victory and such borders."

The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People announced yesterday a nationwide program that the organization said could halt all Federal and state sponsored construction, estimated at about $76.5-billion in the next fiscal year, unless Negroes were taken into building trades unions.
Miss Batya Goldstein, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Israel Goldstein, was married yesterday evening to David Mordecai Segal, son of Rabbi and Mrs. Bernard Segal. Both families are of Forest Hills, Queens.
GRENADA, Miss., June 27-- James H. Meredith heading a column of singing Negro men, reached the northern edge of this sometimes violent town tonight.
FORT SILL, Okla., June 27 (UPI)--Two soldiers were shot and killed and another wounded here today during a simulated combat exercise.
DETROIT, June 27 (AP)-- The auto industry is planning to produce 1.4 million units in July, August and September, 11 per cent over the same period last year, Ward's Automotive Reports said today.
The stock market continued to wrestle yesterday with prospects of higher income taxes and interest rates. The market lost.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 27--The Selection of nine recipients for the 1967-1968 Adlai E. Stevenson Memorial Fellowships was announced today by Gabriel D'Arboussier, executive director of the United Nations Institute for Training and Research.
Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower will pay his first visit this morning to "The Memorable Eisenhower Years," a show whose opening on May 16 he missed because of illness.

BALTIMORE, June 27 (AP) --Joe' Horlen scattered five hits tonight, hurling the Chicago White Sox to a 5-0 victory over the Baltimore Orioles, who lost Frank Robinson with a head injury in the fourth inning.
WASHINGTON, June 27-- The Department of Transportation issued a set of 13 standards today to be followed by the states in establishing safety programs for the battle against highway tragedy.

JERSEY CITY, June 27-- The chairman of the New York City Planning Commission suggested today that Mayor Lindsay be made a member of the proposed state commission to develop the Hackensack River Meadowland.

IN salute to the comic strip hero, a new "Charlie Brown Club House" on Gimbels' street floor offers an assortment of dolls, greeting cards, pillows, shirts, dresses, centerpieces and pennants, printed or appliqued with Charles Schulz's famous family.

The Hyatt Corporation of America, a leading hotel chain, announced yesterday the formation of a subsidiary, Hyatt Enterprises, Inc. It will operate certain of the Hyatt House Hotels and will also acquire 85 per cent of the stock of Northridge Industries, Inc., presently owned by the Hyatt Corporation. Northridge owns or operates Hyatt Lodes and Hyatt Coffee Shoppes.
LONDON, June 27 (AP)-- Leon Quartermaine, a star of the London and New York theater for more than 50 years, died in a hospital Sunday. He was 90 years old.
Four offerings of common stock reached the market yesterday and met a rousing reception by investors. All were oversubscribed and two went to premiums of more than a point.
Mayor Lindsay strongly endorsed yesterday the continuance of free concerts and other public events in the city's parks despite criticism of "commercial invasion" of the park.

More than 1,000 New York children, tripping over duffel bags, comic books, partly unwrapped sandwiches and each other, scrambled aboard trains and buses yesterday morning for summer vacations in the country under the sponsorship of the Fresh Air Fund.

The U.S.A. and the U.S.S.R. moved to the brink of both war and peace this month and successively backed away from each. How near we may have come to disaster may never be known, but it was probably closer than we got to accord in Glassboro. Nor is it likely that such compromises as a possible nuclear proliferation ban will soon lead to harmony.

The Soviet film, "War and Peace," has been acquired for distribution here and in other countries by the Walter Rcade Organization, it was announced yesterday. It will be released by Walter Reade in association with the Satra Corporation, which negotiated the agreement with the Russian Sovexportfilm under the cultural exchange program between the United States and the Soviet Union.

Organized confusion reigned supreme at Shea Stadium yesterday, where the New York Mets helped Paramount make a scene from "The Odd Couple" and the Pittsburgh Pirates helped the Mets fashion a 5-2 victory by batting out of turn.
PHUQUOC ISLAND, South Vietnam, June 24--The "cowboys" on this island just south of the Cambodian coast have now been joined by the Charlies to wait out the war inside barbed-wire enclosures.

Senator Robert F. Kennedy told graduates of Brooklyn's Erasmus Hall High School yesterday that the world they were entering was "in revolution and war" and that the "qualities of youth" were needed to solve its problems.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 27--Gideon Hausner, the Israeli Attorney General who prosecuted Adolf Eichmann for war crimes, spoke today in the General Assembly debate on the Middle Eastern crisis.

Sidney B. Kramer, a lawyer and former senior vice president of Bantam Books, succeeded John P.R. Budlong yesterday as president of New American Library, a book publishing subsidiary of the Times Mirror Company. The subsidiary's board of directors announced that Mr. Budlong had resigned for personal reasons.

Directors of the Wurlitzer Company elected yesterday W. N. Herleman as president of the Chicago-based musical instruments maker. The former executive vice president succeeds R.C. Rolfing, who continues as chairman and was designated chief operating officer.
HAVANA, June 27 (Reuters) --Premier Kosygin resumed talks with Premier Fidel Castro today.

BALTIMORE, June 27-- President Johnson roused an audience of young men and women to their feet here today with a passionate defense of the things that are right with "America" and, incidentally, with his Administration and policies.

FOR a man who has treated women as nicely as Vit torio De Sica has--as witness the several classic characters he has created with Sophia Loren--it is shocking and thoroughly bewildering to find him kicking them around as he does in his new picture, "Woman Times Seven," which opened at the Lincoln Art Theater last night.
Americans favor a treaty with the Soviet Union to halt the spread of nuclear weapons by 5 to 1, according to a Louis Harris survey.
Plans for a new national book supplement to be published on Sundays were announced yesterday by The Washington Post and The Chicago Tribune.

MARK DONOHUE is so busy these days moving from one auto racing scene to another that he has only a little time for talk. We cornered him at the breakfast table in Watkins Glen on Monday and, sharing his attention with his young son, Michael, learned of his imme mediate plans.
PARIS, June 27--Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin will meet President de Gaulle Saturday morning on his way back to Moscow from Cuba, the French Government announced today.
WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP)--Watson Davis, director emeritus of Science Service and a pioneer in interpreting science to the layman since 1920, died of cancer today, He was 71 years old.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 27--Secretary General Thant said today that the United Arab Republic was responsible for reviving the "direct confrontation" of forces with Israel that led to war after a decade of shaky armistice.
WASHINGTON, June 27-- Sweeping changes in American medical care were recommended today by an economist addressing a national conference on the cost of health.
NEWARK, June 27--A crowd of 450, chanting, stamping and clapping in protest, prevented the Board of Education from naming a new school board secretary tonight.
A sure sign that summer has arrived in the city, socially at least, is the opening of the St. Regis-Sheraton Roof, which took place last night.

MINEOLA, L.I., June 27-- A former aide to a Nassau County Supreme Court Justice was accused today of swindling local political and court officials out of $173,000 in a "get-richquick" scheme involving bail bonds.

MOSCOW, June 27 (AP)-- The Soviet Union has demanded the punishment of United States airmen responsible for the strafing of the Soviet merchant ship Turkestan off the North Vietnamese port of Campha June 2.
WEST PATERSON, N.J., June 27--A black bear weighing 200 pounds led a dog warden and the police on a chase through backyards today before escaping into the woods in Garret Mountain Park.

WASHINGTON, June 27-- Yields on new issues of ninemonth and one-year Treasury bills rose to their highest levels since December at today's regular monthly auction, the Treasury Department reported tonight.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 27--A United States Embassy spokesman said today that a Vietcong broadcast indicated that an American aid official held captive for two and a half years had been executed.

The United States Gypsum Company, which has successfully modernized some slum buildings here, reached a tentative agreement, yesterday to acquire the A.P. Green Refractories Company of Mexico, Mo. The proposed transaction involves stock valued at about $44-million.
Michael Calabrese of Queens, who vanished two-and-a-half years ago, was described in Federal Court yesterday as "a central figure" in a New York County investigation of police bribery.
Prices turned irregular on the London Stock Exchange yesterday.
WEST PATERSON, N.J., June 27--A black bear weighing 200 pounds led a dog warden and the police on a chase through backyards today before escaping into the woods in Garret Mountain Park.

WASHINGTON, June 27-- Yields on new issues of ninemonth and one-year Treasury bills rose to their highest levels since December at today's regular monthly auction, the Treasury Department reported tonight.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 27--A United States Embassy spokesman said today that a Vietcong broadcast indicated that an American aid official held captive for two and a half years had been executed.

The United States Gypsum Company, which has successfully modernized some slum buildings here, reached a tentative agreement, yesterday to acquire the A.P. Green Refractories Company of Mexico, Mo. The proposed transaction involves stock valued at about $44-million.
Michael Calabrese of Queens, who vanished two-and-a-half years ago, was described in Federal Court yesterday as "a central figure" in a New York County investigation of police bribery.
Prices turned irregular on the London Stock Exchange yesterday.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 27--The demand for the withdrawal of Israeli troops from the United Arab Republic, Syria and Jordan now has the public support of 42 delegations.

FALLSBURG, N.Y., June 27 --The largest American Orthodox rabbinic body today proposed a conference of major Jewish religious and secular groups to cope with the "great dangers" confronting 150,000 Jews in Arab lands.
THE man who has been described as a modern-day Cellini (by Mrs. John F. Kennedy) and Faberge reborn (by the Duchess of Windsor) takes his trendsetting responsibilities seriously.
King Hussein of Jordan said yesterday that he would "solicit he1p" from President Johnson today when he visited the White House for a luncheon meeting with the President and some Cabinet members.

BIMINI, The Bahamas, June 27--Adam Clayton Powell said today he would accept censure by the House of Representatives--but only of the type imposed on Senator Thomas Dodd, the Connecticut Democrat, "I will not accept a public censure in

THE FAMILY WAY, a comedy-drama with Hayley Mills, John Mills and Hywell Bennett, produced and directed in England by John and Roy Boulting and presented by Warner Brothers, at the Beekman Theater, Second Avenue and 65th Street, and the Embassy Theater, Broadway and 46th Street.

VAESTERAAS, Sweden, June 27 (UPI)--Ron Clarke of Australia took almost three seconds off the world record for the two-mile run tonight with a clocking of 8 minutes 19.8 seconds. Michel Jazy of France has held the official record of 8:22.6 since 1965.
PARIS, June 27--West Germany joined France today in refusing to vote for a program of mutual help among countries that consume oil.

CINCINNATI, June 27--A top executive of the Hilton Hotel Corporation publicly apologized here today for the existence of discriminatory personnel practices in Cincinnati's Netherland Hilton and Terrace Hilton hotels.

WASHINGTON, June 27--Both exports and imports declined in May, leaving the trade surplus little changed from the high level attained in April, the Commerce Depart ment reported today. The May export surplus was $426million, a slight dip from the $436-million figure attained in April, which was the highest in more than a year.
Good harvest weather for wheat meant bad news for holders of long positions in wheat futures trading yesterday. Prices set a string of new lows in dull trading.
WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) --The House Interior Committee began today what its chairman said would be months of consideration of various plans for a Redwoods National Park in California.

In a parking lot on the Bowery at Pell Street, opposite the curb where the Chinatown tour buses pull up, a teen-age rumble seemed about to erupt one recent afternoon. But the two groups withdrew in opposite directions after an exchange of ugly glances and fist-shaking.
WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP)--A "truth-in-lending" bill was reported to the Senate floor today, marking the first time in seven years of effort by its supporters that it has progressed that far.

GENEVA, June 27--The United States delegation of Government, employer and worker representatives split today when the International Labor Organization's annual conference adopted a budget of $24,836,091 for 1968.

ST. LOUIS, June 27 (UPI)-- Mike McCormick pitched a seven-hitter and Hal Lanier doubled home two runs during a three-run fifth-inning rally tonight to lead the San Francisco Giants to a 6-0 triumph over the St. Louis Cardinals.
Two city agency commissioners disagreed last night over whether an incinerator should be constructed on the site of the former Brooklyn Navy Yard.
The Fifth Avenue Association has unanimously endorsed the recently enacted state transportation program and will seek wide public support for the $2.5-billion bond issue in the November election.
Lincoln Center: Gunther Schuller's "The Visitation," Hamburg State Opera, Metropolitan Opera, 8 P.M.; New York Philharmonic, Philharmonic Hall, 8:30.
MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., June 27--The Chamber of Commerce here has asked Governor Rockefeller to investigate charges of underworld influence in the city.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 27--Miss Margaret Ann Troyano, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter J.J. Troyano, was married this afternoon to Ens. Roy Worsham Moore 3d, U.S.N. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Moore Jr. of Fairfield, Conn.

The announcement in Washington and Panama City that an agreement has been reached on new treaties covering the Panama Canal and the Canal Zone was well timed. It could not have been postponed much longer without danger of renewed nationalistic demonstrations in Panama.
THERE seems to be increasing evidence that the new teen-age sexual morality is more talk than action.
NORTH BENNINGTON, Vt., June 27--Mrs. Edith Arthur van Benthuysen McCullough, widow of Hall Park McCullough, died here today in her home, Hall Farm House. Her age was 86.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 27--The defending champion, Mrs. Billie Jean King, opened the traditional Ladies' Day in the Wimbledon tennis tournament today by heating Ingrid Lofdahl on center court, but she could hardly wait to get off the court.
Edward R. Rowley was elected yesterday as president of the National Lead Company. He succeeds Alfred H. Drewes, who died June 6 at the age of 53.

ADEN, June 27--The British Police Commissioner of Aden engineered a bold maneuver today to recover $11-million of the South Arabian Government's Treasury from the crater district of Aden, where Arab nationalist terrorists have held sway for the past week.
A $44,876 contract for reconstructing a five-block section of the center mall of the Grand Concourse between 153d and 158th Streets in the Bronx was let yesterday by the Department of Highways.
King Hussein of Jordan charged yesterday that Israel had "meddled with" the tape recording of his conversations with President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic.
LONDON, June 27 (AP)-- Senator Jacob K. Javits appealed to Britain and Western Europe tonight to disown President de Gaulle and join the United States in forming an Atlantic free-trade area.

WASHINGTON, June 27 (A.P.)--The Justice Department has completed its own investigation of the affairs of Senator Thomas J. Dodd and is now examining material that the Senate used in deciding to censure the Connecticut Democrat, officials said today.
BRADENTON, Fla., June 27 --Philip Tenney Brown, who had operated a recording studio for many years in New Rochelle, N.Y., died here today of cancer. He was 71 years old.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 27-- Barham R. Gary, general counsel and a director of the Annapolis Banking and Trust Company, died Saturday at the Anne Arundel General Hospital here. His age was 67.
Favorites, led by top-seeded George Seewagen Jr. of Bayside, Queens, swept into the fourth round, the round of 16, in the New York state tennis championships yesterday.
A high-ranking Justice Department official predicted yesterday that several labor union leaders, bankers and business men in the New York area would be indicted this summer on charges of corruption.
John C. Weiner Jr., 39 years old, was appointed yesterday as president of Moody's Investors Services, Inc., a financial reporting and investment advisory subsidiary of Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

But times have changed, and along with the change a revised estimate of Janacek. Ever since the war, there has been a sizable Jana- ...
What happens when one agency losses an account and another gains it?

Miss Diana Brody, daughter of Joseph Brody of 70 East 10th Street and the late Mrs. Brody, was married yesterday afternoon to Malcolm Scott Schoen. He is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Austin H. Schoen of New Rochelle, N.Y.
The United Federation of Teachers accused the Board of Education yesterday of breaking its promise to speed negotiations on a new contract.
HOUSTON June 28 (AP)-- Two 15-round fights were announced today for Aug. 5 in the Astrodome as part of the first round of an elimination tournament to determine a world heavyweight boxing champion.

WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) --Donald Richard Bussmeyer, 30 years old, "a hulking and heavily tattooed alleged bank robber," was added today by the Federal Bureau of Investigation to its list of 10 most wanted fugitives.
WASHINGTON, June 28--The Johnson Administration deplored Israel's annexation of Old Jerusalem today as a hasty and unilateral move that the United States could not recognize as valid.
Dr. M.T. Mehdl, secretary general of the Action Committee on American-Arab Relations, announced last night that more than 100 members would ...

HOUSTON, June 28 (UPI)-- Joseph Stassi of New York City, convicted of conspiring to smuggle heroin worth $4.5-million into the United States from Mexico, was sentenced today to 18 years in prison and a $20,000 fine.

The third annual Playwrights' Conference will be held from July 18 to Aug. 6 at the Waterford, Conn., headquarters of the Eugene O'Neill Memorial Theater Foundation. During that period, 17 new plays, including six short ones, will be "incubated" by professional actors and directors.
WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) --The promotions of four civilian officials of the Defense Department were approved today by the Senate Armed Services Committee.

Oskar Maria Graf, a German writer who was one of the earliest and most outspoken opponents of the Nazis, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived at 34 Hillside Avenue, upper Manhattan.

WASHINGTON, June 28.-- Consumer prices rose sharply again in May for the second straight month, the Labor Department reported today. The largest increases were in the prices of apparel, used cars, medical care and the cost of running a house.

WASHINGTON, June 29 The Federal Reserve Board announced today a new policy of making more of its records available to the public and publishing the decisions of the key Federal Open Market Committee three months after each committee meeting.
