The president of the nation's largest society of aerospace experts proposed yesterday a joint Soviet-American safety program to reduce the hazards of manned space flight.

WASHINGTON, June 29 A spokesman for the Department of Defense said tonight that the only signals sent to the Liberty by the Israelis were sent after an Initial air attack on the ship and thus her failure to respond properly "could not then be the reason for making the attack."

The teachers' union has proposed that an experimental nursery school be set up in a largely Negro and Puerto Rican area in the South Bronx to take care of children of 40 former teachers. The teachers would then be able to resume teaching in the district.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, June 29 (UPI) Jules Regis Debray, a French Marxist seized by Bolivian troops two months ago, denied today that he had been serving as a Communist guerrilla. His appearance touched off street demonstrations and demands of his execution.
Van Buren Sims, former board chairman of Lord Taylor, died yesterday in New York Hospital. He was 77 years old.
Mayor Lindsay announced a two-year, $50,000 contract had been approved for the study of designs for new police uniforms.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, June 30 The two generals who have ruled South Vietnam for more than two years are ready to step down, authoritative sources said today.

The union of the Methodist Church and the Evangelical United Brethren Church has received final approval, it was announced yesterday at the headquarters of the Methodist Church, 777 United Nations Plaza.
Lincoln Center: Hindemith's "Mathis der Maler," Hamburg State Opera, Metropolitan Opera House, 8 P.M.; New York Philharmonic, Philharmonic Hall, 8:30.
A group of Brooklyn Democrats in search of a Central Park field for a touch football contest may be forced to punt.

WASHINGTON, June 29 (UPI) The House overwhelmingly approved Weston, Ill., today as the site for an atom smasher for the Atomic Energy Commission. It acted over objections that Illinois lacked a housing law to prevent discrimination against Negro workers at the research facility.

WINCHESTER, Conn., June 29 Mrs. Eleanor A. Wilson Webster, the wife of Bethuel M. Webster, a member of the law firm of Webster, Sheffield, Fleischmann, Hitchcock Brookfield, died of a heart attack yesterday in her home on Grantville Road. Her age was 62. She also had a home at 520 East 86th Street, Manhattan.
Net income of the Kroger Company fell sharply in the three and six months ended June 17, it was reported yesterday in Cincinnati.
LONELYHEART 4122, by Colin Watson (Putnam, $3.95). Humorous detective story.

WASHINGTON, June 29 Thousands of the urban poor in 58 cities across the country will stage coordinated demonstrations tomorrow for "more money now" and against "poverty level" payments to the 8.5 million Americans on public assistance.

THE next major international event will be the European Championships, to be played in Dublin in September. This will have a bearing on the next world championship in the Bermuda Bowl series, which will be in South America in 1969, since 1968 is an Olympiad year.

Because of growing Federal concern over the congestion at Washington's National Airport, the Civil Aeronautics Board will formally take up the matter at a pre-hearing conference of interested parties on July 13. The conference will be followed by an official investigation, the first on the part of the C.A.B., into the best ways of relieving the heavy overcrowding at the capital's most convenient airfield.

Israel is making it clear that the main thrust of her diplomacy in the wake of her defeat of the military forces of three Arab states is aimed not at territory as such but at agreement with the Arabs, reached without third-party intervention.
SEOUL, South Korea, June 29 (AP) Vice President Humphrey arrived in this securitconscious South Korean capital today for the second lnaugural Saturday of President Chung Hee Park.
Private sanitation trucks will be banned from the garment district during the daytime for 30 days beginning July 5 in an experiment to reduce traffic congestion.

JUST about the worst thing that could happen to Sally Victor is a roomful of women taking off their hats to her. One of the city's most durable milliners, Mrs. Victor has spent almost a third of a century planting hats on as many heads as possible.
The Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn and the State University of New York announced last night that they had reached agreement "In principle" on affillating the two Institutions.
Mayer Lindsay asked New Yorkers yesterday to ring bells at 2 P.M. on July 4 in observance of Independence Day.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 29 Moslems and Christians denounced today the Israeli absorption of the Old City of Jerusalem.

Monique von Cleef, who was convicted with Albert James Beard, a former television actor, of operating a so-called torture-for-pleasure house in Newark, waived extradition on Manhattan Criminal Court and returned to New Jersey.
A new round of trade negotiations to increase the export earnings of developing countries was urged yesterday by the Committee for Economic Development.

SAN ANGELO, Tex., June 29 Col. Paul N. Ivancich, U.S.A.F., retired, has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Mary Ellen Ivancich, to Steven L. Cymrot, son of Benjamin Cymrot of Brooklyn, New York.

The road to Central Park is paved with good intentions. In this century alone, cafes, marionette theaters, drill grounds, parking lots, churches, airports, circuses, armories, housing projects and world's fairs have been suggested as "improvements." Some are more ridiculous than others, but all have been proposed (including selling off pieces of the park to balance the city's budget) in the name of fuller use or fun.
JERUSALEM, June 29 Thousands of Arabs and Israelis mingled freely and joyously today as Jerusalem's 19-year-old barriers disappeared.

FRANKFURT, June 29 (Reuters) In a move to spur West Germany's lagging economy, the central bank announced today an 8 per cent reduction in minimum reserve requirements for the country's banks. The reduction is effective Saturday.
Eight Apollo astronauts left Kennedy airport yesterday for the desolate, crater-pocked volcanic field of central Iceland, where they will spend eight days studying the region's geographical makeup.
WASHINGTON. June 29 (AP) The Post Office Department announced today that starting July 4 it would furnish anybody's last recorded change of address for a $1 fee.

The ability of the Military Sea Transportation Service to transport heavy lift military cargoes is scheduled to be more than doubled under the terms of an agreement with the Hudson Waterways Corporation.

Park Commissioner August Heckscher halted construction yesterday on the controversial Children's Farm in Prospect Park in Brooklyn. But the stop order came too late to save a stand of maple and pine trees and a stretch of green lawn favored by picnickers.
JAKARTA, Indonesia A few minutes after having been sworn in as Acting President of Indonesia in March, General Suharto set the tone of his administration in one sentence.
BALTIMORE, June 29 (AP) Tom Phoebus hurled a threehitter and received home-run support from Paul Blair and Russ Snyder as the Baltimore Orioles beat the Chicago White Sox, 4-1, tonight.
WASHINGTON, June 29 John P. Hiltz Jr., president and general manager of the Delaware Hudson Railroad, has been named the chief labor negotiator for the nation's railroads.
PORTLAND, Me., June 29 Israel Bernstein, a lawyer and civic leader here died of a heart attack in a hospital here Monday after a prostate-gland operation. He was 76 years old.

LONDON, June 28 To meet Increased costs resulting from the closing of the Suez Canal, the British Govermnent authorized today a temporary increase of twopence (2.3 cents) a gallon in the price of all petroleum products.
Three major league baseball players moved yesterday in New York State Supreme Court to enjoin Pocket Books, Inc., from publishing their biographies.
CHICAGO, June 29 The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People has formally broken with the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s Chicago Freedom Movement.
WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) The Senate passed without debate today a bill to establish a system of Federal magistrates in place of the present United States commissioners.
PARIS, June 29 For several years now President de Gaulie has come to be accepted by friends and enemies as the gadfly of the Western world.
The New Haven Railroad isn't', going to eliminate 17 of its long-haul passenger trains on duly 16 after all.

JACKSON HOLE. Wyo., June 29 The drive to enlist Republican Governors behind the Presidential candidacy of Gov. George Romney is failing to produce many recruits here, but its leaders remain undaunted.
WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) The Senate gave speedy confirmation today to promotions for four civilian officials in the Defense Department. By unanimous voice vote it approved.

ST. LOUIS, June 29 (UPI) Jim Hart drove in four runs with a single and homer during a wild 11-run first inning tonight as the San Francisco Giants scored their third consecutive victory over the leagueleading St. Louis Cardinals, 12-4.

CHICHESTER, England. June 29 (AP) Mike Jagger, leader of the Rolling Stones pop group, and Keith Richard, their lead guitarist, were sentenced to prison today after having been convicted on drug charges.
ROME, June 29 Pope Paul VI inaugurated a worldwide "year of faith" tonight at an open-air mass on the steps of St. Peter's basilica, and declared that it would contribute to peace and brotherhood.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 29 Federal Judge Robert F. Peckham listened for two hours today to arguments over a petition to stay the executions of all 58 prisoners on San Quentin Prison's "death row" pending a full hearing on their cases.
A creature of habit, Jim Bunning defeated the New York Mets for the Philadelphia Phillies last night, 1-0, with a threehitter at Shea Stadium before a crowd of 13,653.
DETROIT, June 29 (AP) Fred Whitfield, a pinch-hitter, capped a four-run eighth-inning rally with a three-run homer tonight that lifted the Cleveland Indians to a 5-3 victory over the Detroit Tigers.
Staten Island residents fought two battles yesterday against what they said were threats to the natural beauty of the island.
Acres and acres of empty lots lie unused along one side of Williams Street on Buffalo's East Side, the main Negro business street in the city.

WASHINGTON, June 29 Israeli diplomats were reported today to have assured the State Department that the Israeli municipal authority had been extended over Old Jerusalem merely to provide municipal services to inhabitants in sections occupied by Israeli forces.

TEL AVIV, June 29 (UPI) The official Israeli version of the attack on the United States intelligence ship Liberty off Sinal during the Middle East war is that the vessel answered an identification challenge with a signal that led the Israelis to believe she might be an Egyptian ship.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 29 Foreign Minister Abba Eban refused today to describe Israel's actions regarding the Jordanian part of Jerusalem as annexation.
OTTAWA, June 29--Queen Elizabeth II and Prince Philip arrived here tonight for a rousing centennial birthday celebration in the Canadian capital.

RIO GRANDE CITY, Tex., June 29 (AP) Labor lawyers told three Senators today of attempts to organize farm workers in Starr County, a lower Rio Grande valley agricultural center of 20,000 population with 40 sheriff's deputies and a host of Texas Rangers.

John Rogers Jr., who retired early this year as partner and director of Chubb Son, insurance company managers of 90 John Street, and as senior vice president and director of the Federal Insurance Company, died yesterday in his home at the Berkshire Hotel, Madison Avenue and 52d Street. He was 68 years old.

NAIROBI, Kenya, June 29, (Reuters) The Government of Kenya today declared the Chinese Charge d'affaires in Nairobi persona non grata and asked that he leave Kenya immediately. It also announced that Kenya's ambassador in Peking was being recalled for consultations.

WASHINGTON, June 29 President Johnson has started his campaign for re-election. He has been out on the stump three times in the last few days, testing the gullibility of the electorate, and judging by his opening themes we are in for seventeen months of bull-roaring exaggeration.

HONG KONG, June 29 Hsiao Ming, China's charge d'affaires in Burma, delivered a new protest today to the Burmese Government over mob attacks on Chinese individuals and property in Rangoon earlier this week.

WHEN "The Visitation" was over, its composer, Gun ther Schuller, came on the stage of the Metropolitan Opera to take a bow. Most of the audience sat on its hands. Of those that did respond, half cheered. The other half booed. Mr. Schuller grinned. There was more cheering, more booing. Then everyone went home convinced he was right.

PRINCETON, N. J., June 29--Miss Lauren Adams and Hubert C. Fortmiller Jr., of Concord, Mass., son of Dr. and Mrs. Fortmiller of Wellesley Hills, Mass., have made plans to be married Aug. 20 in Andover, Mass.

E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., said yesterday it expected earnings in the first half of 1967 to be down 27 to 28 per cent from the record $215,831,893, or $4.58 a share, earned in the corresponding span last year.
Winds, southeast at 10-to15 knots Friday, variable at 10 knots or less Friday night and Saturday, southwest at 10-to-15 knots Saturday night and Sunday.

MONTREAL, June 29 (AP) An application to revise rates and service conditions on telegrams moving between Canada and the United States has been filed with the Canadian Board of Transport Commissioners by Canadian National and Canadian Pacific Telecommunications.

A 31-year-old Post Office employe was stabbed last night after two men stopped his collection truck in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn and started an argument with him, the police said. He was reported to be in poor condition.

A Brooklyn rank-and-file longshoreman announced yesterday that he would try to oust Brooklyn's dock boss, Anthony Scotto, as an international vice president when the longshore union holds its annual elections in July.

WASHINGTON, June 29 Intercity truck tonnage and revenue freight traffic generated by carloadings in United States railroads in the week ended June 24 were both below the volume in the corresponding week of last year.

The use of college students as summer internes in government is steadily growing, to the mutual benefit of the students and the governmental offices in which they serve. This week Deputy Mayor Timothy W. Costello welcomed over 2,000 college students from 84 colleges and universities to the second summer of the city's Urban Corps.
WASHINGTON, June 29 The Government disclosed today tariff reductions ranging up to 50 per cent on about 6,000 imported products.

MONTREAL, June 29 Robert Lauren (Laurie) Hammer of Sarasota, Fla., a tall golfer who uses extralength clubs, led the Canadian open championship today with a 66. The 6-foot-5-inch professional gained a stroke advantage with a five-under-par round over this city's municipal golf course.
WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) The Peace Corps said today it had dismissed a 25-yearold volunteer who has been protesting in Chile against United States bombing in North Vietnam.
Mayor Lindsay contended yesterday that the work stoppage by caseworkers in the Welfare Department was "dying of its own weight" and that a "back-to-work movement" had begun.
In a major step to combat air pollution, the city announced yesterday it would install electrostatic precipitators in two Sanitation Department incinerators in Brooklyn.

The state faces the loss of $23-million in Federal road aid this year if the Transit Authority persists in letting advertising signs dangle from elevated structures over interstate expressways here, Federal and State highway officials warned yesterday.

Mrs. Joan Kahn Goldberg of New York, widow of Isidor Goldberg, founder of Pilot Radio, was married yesterday to Dr. David Arbuse of 4 East 72d Street, a retired Captain in the Navy Medical Corps. State Supreme Court Justice Samuel M. Gold performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis Sollfrey at 30 East 65th Street.
CAMBRIDGE, Md., June 29 State troopers began an intensified street patrol here today as racial animosity mounted over use of the city's only swimming pool.
WASHINGTON, June 29 Robert Moses charged today that Mayor Lindsay's proposal to keep Staten Island's greenbelt as a natural preserve could make the area "the most dangerous place in New York City."

CAIRO, June 29 (AP) The United Arab Republic charged tonight that Israeli troops had killed two Egyptian crewmen of a Suez Canal Authority launch and wounded three others in an incident on the canal zone cease-fire line.
WASHINGTON, June 29 Prof. Paul A. Samuelson of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, one of the nation's most noted economists, warned Congress today not to rush into a tax increase.

PHILADELPHIA, June 29 President Johnson went into one of the toughest parts of Philadelphia today, an area torn by Negro riots three years ago, to praise and encourage a group of people beginning the climb out of poverty.
A Federal judge reversed himself yesterday and dismissed a suit seeking weighted voting for the Suffolk County Board of Supervisors.
"The Great Blight Way," a 30-minute documentary about Times Square, will be presented by Channel 9 on Wednesday, July 12, at 10 P.M.

Israel has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission an offering of $500-million in 15-year, 4 per cent, dollarcoupon bonds, to be sold in five series of $100-million each during a five-year period.
A special telephone answering service has been set up in Washington for persons wishing to learn the new duty rates for specific items in the list of tariff reductions announced yesterday.

A small group of veterans of the big band era of jazz, led by Claude Hopkins, got the Jazz in the Garden concert series at the Museum of Modern Art off to a delayed start last night. The series had been scheduled to begin last Thursday but rain canceled that performance.

BLOCK ISLAND, R.I., June 29 Pinkletink III, 33 feet of fiber glass and as modern as a yacht can be, and Dolphin, 53 years old and still full of style, became the main candidates today for the outstanding sailboat title of the Storm Trysail Club's Block Island Race Week.

WHEN "The Big City" ("Mahanagar"), which opened at the 55th Street Playhouse yesterday, was shown here at the New York Film Festival In 1964, Bosley Crowther described it as a comedy-drama of modern Indian life that was in the rich character of the work of its director. Satyajit Ray.
DETROIT, June 29 The almost forgotten Prohibition party nominated its Presidential candidate for 1968 today and promptly marched off to picket a tavern.

WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) Barge lines and shippers supported legislation today that would permit water carriers to transport regulated and unregulated bulk commodities in a single tow. Railroads were opposed to the legislation.
ACCRA, Ghana, June 30 The military and police junta that has ruled Ghana since the overthrow of president Kwame Nkrumah in Febraury, 1966 brought civilians back into the Government today.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., June 30 (AP) Catherine Lacoste, a 22year-old amateur from France, shamed America's finest women pros with a one-under-par 70 today that sent her into a fivestroke lead after 36 holes of the women's national open golf championship.
WASHINGTON, June 30 Following are excerpts pertaining to student deferments from the Executive order amending the Selective Service regulations issued today by President Johnson:

MOORESTOWN, N.J., June 30 Mrs. Mary Lippincott Griscom, widow of Dr. J. Milton Griscom an ophthalmologist, died yesterday at Burlington County, Memorial Hospital in Mount Holly. She was 85 years old and a resident of Moorestown.
DUBLIN, June 30 (UPI) Mrs. John F. Kennedy was a dinner guest of Premier Jack Lynch tonight. It was her first public function since she arrived in Ireland two weeks ago.
WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) A tentative contract agree- ment was reported today in the 26-day-old strike against nine Radio Corporation of America plants in six states.

Because "Sweet Charity" is primarily a dancing show, and because Helen Gallagher is a very good dancer, the long-run, musical comedy hit at the Palace has not suffered a fatal blow with the departure of Gwen Verdon.

NEWPORT, R. I., June 30--After a steady, day-long rain, the 14th annual Newport Jazz Festival managed to begin tonight under dry but leaden skies. With rain clouds still hanging threateningly overhead, the opening-night audience at Festival Field was 5,000, about one-third of capacity.
The Bendix Corporation completed its acquisition of the Fram Corporation yesterday and said it would fight an expected action by the Federal Trade Commission to block the take-over.
The LTV Aerospace Corporation, a subsidiary of LingTemco-Vought, Inc., has received a $62.6-million Navy contract for production of light attack aircraft.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 30 Eighteen LatinAmerican nations submitted to the General Assembly today a draft resolution calling for withdrawal of Israeli forces from Arab territories and an end of the state of belligerency.
WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) The Pentagon says SR71 strategic reconnaissance planes will begin supersonic training flights tomorrow and may sweep populated areas with sonic booms.
Dr. Albert Bowers has been appointed executive vice president of Syntex Laboratories, Inc., the United States subsidiary of the Syntex Corporation.
HONG KONG, June 30 (AP) Sixteen Americans were unaccounted for in the crash here today of a Thai jet airliner.
LEE FERRY, Ariz., June 30 (AP) Four rafts loaded with Kennedys and their friends left today on a Colorado River expedition.
The Municipal Concerts Orchestra will open its 1967 series of free concerts in New York City parks with appearances in Washington Square on July 10 and 17.
The Chase Manhattan Bank sued yesterday to block the takeover of the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority, and its surpluses by the Metropolitan Commuter Transportation Authority.
Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday that guided wars of City Hall would be conducted beginning next Wednesday.
GREENWICH, Conn. There were no international incidents, just squeals of excitement and laughter as 30 children from 21 countries enjoyed a day in the country.

DOUALA, Cameroon, June 30 Lieut. Col. Odumegwu Ojukwu declared tonight that Nigeria was poised to invade and warned that his rebellious Eastern Region, which calls itself the Republic of Biafra, would wage an all-out offensive war if attacked.

Edward H. Selonick has been named president of the Hecht Company, Washington, D. C., a department store group operated by the May Department Stores Company, it was announced yesterday by Stanley J. Goodman, president ana chief administrative officer of the May Company.
The Kennedy Airport radar system failed yesterday for the second time in three days, causing delays of more than an hour for 23 incoming flights and up to 27 minutes for departures.

HAMMERINGS at Hammacher Schlemmer pre sage a not-too-distant day when it will be possible to select housewares in a provincial kitchen atmosphere and tablewares in formal 18thcentury English surroundings.
Sharman Douglas, who for 18 months acted as the city's host ess to foreign dignitaries, has resigned as assistant to John S. (Bud) Palmer, the Commissioner of Public Events.

BLOCK ISLAND, R.I., June 30 Two years ago when the Storm Trysail Club, an organization of offshore sailing men who have experienced extreme conditions at sea, started its Block Island Race Week as an experiment for cruising yachts patterned after Britain's Cowes Week, the second most successful helmsman was A.E. (Bill) Luders, a first-class skip- per and naval architect from Stamford, Conn.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (UPI) Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara ruled today there must be an open housing policy for military personnel renting apartments or trailer court facilities within seven miles of Fort George G. Meade, Md.
Parks Commissioner August Heckscher will swim at South Beach on Staten Island "If the weather is good" during an inspection tour of municipal beaches over the July 4th weekend.

ATLIT, Israel, June 30 (Reuters) An Egyptian general captured by the Israelis during the Middle East war said today that the United Arab Republic was awaiting delivery of Soviet-made ground-to-ground missiles.
YONKERS, June 30 Earle Whitman Allen, who retired four years ago as a vice president of the Chase Manhattan Bank, died yesterday in his home at 41 Cowdry Street, after a long illness. His age was 69.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, June 30 South Africa, tonight deported the Right Rev. Clarence E. Crowther, Anglican Bishop of Kimberley and Kuruman, a critic of the country's racial policies.
LANSING, Mich., June 30 (UPI) A coalition of Democrats and Republicans in the Michigan Senate Passed an income tax Package today and sent it to the House.
A charge that Pulitizer Prizes too often do not go to the most deserving candidates has been made by Herbert Brucker, a past president of the American Society of Newspaper Editors.

ST. KITTS, June 30 (AP) Leaders from Anguilla hald "an amicable discussion" here today with Premier Bradshaw, but one leader said afterward that his island would not rejoin the state of St. Kitts-Nevis-Anguilla.

COLUMBUS, Ohio June 3 (AP) The State Supreme Court today upheld, 5 to 2, Ohio's legislative reapportionment of 1965, under which members of the General Assembly now in session were elected in single-member districts.
IGOR STRAVINSKY's only a full-length opera, "The Rake's Progress," was presented Thursday night by the Hamburg State Opera at the Metropolitan Opera House.

The city and the Port of New York Authority will cooperate to develop plans for the land area adjacent to the proposed modern Hudson River Ship Terminal, Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday. The scope of the inland development, however; was not indicated.

BERLIN, June 30 An automobile crash in East Germany in which four Chinese Communist diplomats were killed has led to a major diplomatic incident between Peking and the East German Communist Government.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (UPI) Representative Robert L.F. Sikes, Democrat of Florida, announced today that he had resigned as a director of the National Rifle Association, a private group that has successfully blocked enactment of Federal gun control laws.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 30 Clark Graebner, one of the last two Americans in the men's singles, was beaten today as three Australians and a German reached the quarter-finals at Wimbledon on this flawless summer afternoon.

MONTREAL, June 30 Touring golf professionals said today they might be forced to charter a new organization "to perform business in 1968" if the Professional Golfers' Association executives did not relinquish veto power over activities of the tournament committeee.

WOODSTOCK, Conn., June 30 Miss Harriet Helen Ogsbury of New York and Watertown, N.Y., was married here at noon today to Prof. Richard A.E. Brooks of Vassar College. The Rev. Paul Lynn performed the ceremony in the First Congregational Church.
CAIRO, June 30--Worshipers at mosques throughout Cairo were urged today to continue waging a "holy war" in an effort to recapture Jerusalem.
DUBLIN, June 30 (UPI) Two American-owned horses are the top favorites in tomorrow's 101st running of the $224,000 Irish Sweeps Derby, in which 23 3-year-olds are scheduled to start.

CINCINNATI, June 30 (AP) Manager Walter Alston of the Los Angeles Dodgers named two of his own hurlers today to the eightman National League pitching staff for the annual All-Star Game to be played at Anaheim, Calif., July 11.
JACKSON HOLE, Wyo., June 30 Republican governors expressed support today for a wide-open 1968 nominating convention in which as many delegates as possible would be free to vote their own convictions.
SPOLETO, Italy, June 30 (AP) Italy's biggest annual cultural event, Gian Carlo Menotti's Festival of the Two Worlds, had today one of the least controversial openings in its 10-year history.
ADEN, June 30 An Aden Airways Viscount airliner was blown up today presumably by Arab nationalist terrorists, as the airline ended operations after 18 years of servie.
The St. Louis Cardinals, who had lost five of their last six games, corrected that trend last night in Shea Stadium.

HAVANA, June 30 (UPI) Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin and Premier Fidel Castro ended four days of secret talks with an exchange of embraces at the airport today as the Soviet leader left for Paris and a meeting with President de Gaulle tomorrow.

Craig Barton, executive director of the Martha Graham School of Contemporary Dance, and personal representative of Miss Graham, died Thursday night of a heart attack at the home of his brother, Donald, in Lawton, Okla. He was 58 years old and lived here at 129 East 17th Street.

WATERBURY, Conn. From the outside, the weathered, yellow brick building in this town looks like a part of a factory seen in virtually every mill town of New England, those bastions of ugliness dating back to the early 19th century. Although the structure was not put ...

William Barclay Harding, board chairman of Smith, Bar- ney Co., New York brokers, died yesterday at the Manmouth Medical Center. Long Branch N.J. He was 60 years old and lived on Redhill Road, Holmdell, N.J.
DETROIT, June 30 (AP) Johnny Podres, with relief help from Mike Marshall, pitched the Detroit Tigers to a 4-1 victory tonight over the league-leading Chicago White Sox.
DURANT, Miss., June 30 (AP) An aching foot overcame determination today as James H. Meredith stopped a few miles short of the little town of Durant, his goal for the day.
The Cerro Corporation and Pickands Mather Co. said yesterday that they had terminated merger discussions, begun in March, but declined to give detailed reasons for ending the talks.
ROME, June 30 Pope Paul VI today named Msgr. Luigi Raimondi, 54-year-old Nuncio to Mexico, to be his Apostolic Delegate, or papal representative, in the United States.
American manufacturers whose industries may face tougher competition from foreign producers expressed concern yesterday over the impact of the lower tariffs negotiated in the Kennedy round.
CHICAGO, June 30 (AP) Mrs. William Wrigley sued today for a legal separation from the 34-year-old president of the chewing gum company and of the Chicago Cubs baseball team.

AVON-BY-THE-SEA, N.J., June 30 Judge Alfred P. D'Auria of the New Jersey State Compensation Court and Mrs. D'Auria have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Judith Ann D'Auria, to E. Thomas Kenny, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward F. Kenny of New Brunswick.
WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) Senator George D. Aiken, Republican of Vermont, married Miss Lola Pierotti today. She has long been his chief assistant in his Senate office.
ALGIERS, Algeria, June 30 France formally handed over to Algeria today her last space test center in the Algerian Sahara Desert.
LUXEMBOURG, June 30 The European Coal and Steel Community is seeking a sharp reduction in the size and subsidy cost of the coal industry in the six member countries.
WASHINGTON, June 30 The Government ended its fiscal year today, apparently with the second largest deficit in the budget, since World War II.
JAKARTA, Indonesia On the walls of General Suharto's austere office in the Ministry of Defense and Security, fever charts record the rise and fall in the cost of essential commodities.

GLEN COVE, L. I., June 30--Webb Institute of Naval Architecture, the only fully accredited four-year college in this country exclusively teaching ship designing and construction, graduated 18 students today.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 30 Air Force pilots bombed the Hoalac air base, 20 miles west of Hanoi, yesterday cutting two runways and probably destroying two MIG's on the ground, a United States military spokesman said today.
BONN, June 30 (Reuters) West Germany will take back 20,000 gas masks supplied to Israel earlier this month because they were not used in the Israeli-Arab war, it was officially announced here today.

NEW ORLEANS, June 30 (UPI) Judge Bernard J.Bagert said today he believed Jayne Mansfield and Mickey Hargitay were never legally divorced, and he awarded custody of the actress's body to Mr. Hargitay and her mother, Mrs. Harry Peers of Dallas.

BEIRUT, Labanon, June 30 Shukri al-Kuwatly, a flery nationalist who twice served as president of Syria, died here early today in the American University Hospital at the age of 76. He had been rushed to the hospital last night after a heart attack.

WASHINGTON, June 30 The Federal Trade Commission asked Congress today to approve legislation requiring a health warning in all cigarette advertisements on the ground that the cigarette industry had not lived up to its promises to police its own advertising.

BONN, June 30 (AP) Chancellor Kurt Georg Kiesinger today canceled his plans to see President Johnson in Washington on July 7 and 8 because of a crisis in West Germany's seven-month-old coalition Government.
It was the last day of the public school term here yesterday, and most of the city's 1.1 million pupils were smiling. A few cried, and a very few studied.
A flood of new capital market offerings was announced yesterday during a bond market session in which some interest rates rose and others fell.
HONG KONG, June 30 Communist China broadened its attacks on the Burmese Government today by expressing approval for the "developing" revolutionary armed struggle of the Burmese Communist party.
ANAHEIM, Calif., June 30 The New York Yankees started a line-up with five hitters below 200 tonight, with predictable results.

PHILADELPHIA, June 30 (AP)--The San Francisco Giants routed the Philadelphia Phils, 12-3, with a 19-hit attack tonight in the second game of a twilight-night double-header after losing the opener, 10-3.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 30 The Mecca radio, the government transmitter of Saudi Arabia, has urged the Arab oilproducing countries to consider carefully the effects on their economies of their embargo on the export of petroleum to the United States, Britain and West Germany.
LEE, Mass., June 30 The inaugural program of the Jacob's Pillow. Dance Festival's 35th year had much of the atmosphere of a school assembly.
BUFFALO, Saturday, July 1 The police interrupted their massive armed patrolling of the East Side Negro ghetto for several hours last night, then swarmed back in force.

The weather played a dirty trick on the Metropolitan Opera and several thousand opera fans yesterday. The day's rain, overcast skies and generally unpromising weather were discouraging enough to keep the audience for "Tosca" down to about 8,000, when the opera was given on the Nether Mead of Prospect Park last night.

MONTREAL, June 30 Art Wall Jr., the winter of the title in 1960, assumed the lead after 36 holes in the Canadian open championship today with a score of 137. A one-under-par 70 over Montreal's municipal golf course gave the former Masters champion from Honesdale, Pa., a two-stroke margin.

Sunshine and intermittent rains in the Midwest provided good growing weather for wheat and corn and a bad trading climate in the futures market yesterday. Both grains showed weakness on the Chica go Board of Trade, partly because traders are convinced that crops will continue to be big, and partly because they like to be out of the market on a holiday weekend.
Fifteen platinum needles containing radium were lost in transit here from san Diego, Dr. Howard J. Brown, the city's Health Services Administrator, said yesterday.
Announcement has been made here of the engagement of Miss Angelike Jaeger, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Jaeger of West Berlin, to Martin Riskin of New York. A September wedding is planned.

Miss Judith Rose Latch, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Albert Latch of Fullerton, Pa., was married yesterday afternoon to Dr. William John Jameson Jr. His parents are Dr. Jameson of Schenectady, N.Y., and the late Mrs. Gladys Thompson Jameson.
An oil company executive replied yesterday to the Federal Trade Commission's allegation that the nation's 20 major oil companies engaged in "anticompetitive practices."

WASHINGTON, June 30 The Johnson Administration, surprised but privately encouraged by political developments in Saigon, sought today to maintain impartiality on the political infighting within the South Vietnamese military junta.
GENEVA, June 30 Fortysix nations today signed the documents putting into effect the biggest round of trade liberalization in history, the Kennedy round.
LONDON, June 30 Britain will cut her tariffs by an average of 38 per cent under the Kennedy round agreement signed today.
Operations of the Diners' Club, Inc., in fiscal 1967 "will be substantially improved over last year," Alfred S. Bloomingdale, chairman and president, predicted yesterday.
Two training programs designed to get welfare recipients into self-sustaining jobs were announced yesterday by Mayor Lindsay and Representative James H. Scheuer, Bronx, Democrat-Liberal.

The Ogden Corporation, which operates a diversified group of businesses through subsidiaries, plans to enter the frozen food field through the proposed purchase of Prosser Packers, Inc., and Andrews Cold Storage, Inc., of Prosser, Wash.
JERSEY CITY, June 30 (AP) Two brothers, who the police said had been involved in the 1964 firing of a bazooka at the United Nations, were ar- rested here last night.
The largest American-built commercial jetliner was certificated for airline operations yesterday by the Federal Aviation Administration.
MINEOLA, L.I., June 30 Prof. Harvey Gray, a judge at the 126th annual Long Island Fair, looked at a bunch of twoinch beans today, shook his head and then moved on to the full heads of cabbage.
WASHINGTON, June 30 (UPI) Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara today rescinded an order that required Pentagon officials to report conversations with newsmen to the public information office.

WASHINGTON, June 30 The first six months of a program under which domestic airlines offered incentives to shippers to use containers, have been declared a success by the nation's major carriers. But ground facilities, they said, must be improved to handle the larger boxes that will be used in the jumbo jets in service in 1971.

If the usual holiday pattern is borne out, six to seven hundred Americans will lose their lives in automobile accidents during this long Fourth of July weekend many of them the innocent victims of the folly, the carelessness or the negligence of others.

LENINGRAD, June 30 The White Nights Festival in Leningrad shows off two of the Soviet Union's most prized possessions, the Kirov Ballet and Leningrad itself. Better still, it is timed to coincide with Leningrad's most interesting time of the year the so-called white nights, when it never really gets dark and the city's mas sively romantic buildings stand silhouetted against the dusk, while lovers walk the streets all night holding hands in the endless twilight.
OTTAWA, June 30 Queen Elizabeth II completed a round of receptions and formalities today leading up to celebrations tomorrow marking Canada's 100th birthday.

SHERMAN OAKS, Calif., June-30 (AP) Bert Glennon, a pioneer Hollywood cameraman who filmed the original "Ten Commandments" with Cecil B. DeMille, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home here. He was 74 years old.
WASHINGTON, June 30 A University of Denver professor has invented a vehicle capable of rolling over rough terrain like a giant ball and still keeping its crew upright.
WASHINGTON, June 30 Thousands of welfare recipients staged coordinated demonstrations in cities and towns across the country today, protesting what they called inadequacies in the welfare system.

HENLEY-ON-THAMES, England, June 30 (AP) Three American crews advanced to the semi-finals of the Henley Royal Regatta today, with Cornell University still the United States' brightest hope for international honors.

AKRON, Ohio, June 30(UPI) Calilng a contract ofefr "miserable, inadequate and unacceptable," Walter P. Reuther, head of the United Automobile Workers, today promised the striking United Rubber Workers more funds if they were needed.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 30--Correspondents of The Chicago Daily News, The Washington Post, The New York Times and Time magazine were barred from a briefing at Independence Palace today by a general in the South Vietnamese Army.

SOME declarers are apt to go into a state of shock when they find all the missing trumps banked in one hand against them. But the seasoned performer takes such misfortunes in his stride, as New York veteran George Kennedy did on the diagramed deal from the Mixed Pair event in the recent Eastern Regionals.
The Board of Education offered the city's teachers yesterday a two-year $51.5-million package of salary increases and health and welfare benefits. The teachers' union immediately rejected the offer.
SPECULATIVE fireworks have been popping so loud of late that it is difficult to get a fix on the point of impact.

The midtown commercial theater was brilliantly supplemented this season (cynics say it should be put the other way around) by Off Broadway, Off Off Broadway, and especially by nonprofit theatrical enterprises.
WASHINGTON, June 30 At United States Court of Appeals unanimously upheld today the right of the Federal Communications Commission to regulate community antenna television systems.
GUNTERSVILLE, Ala., June 30 (AP) Lee Taylor Jr. of Downey, Calif., shattered the world water speed record today, averaging 285.2127 miles an hour in his jet-powered boat.

The Arabs of the Middle East, defeated by Israel three times in 20 years in formal warfare, are being advised by some of their supporters to revert to a modern form of the kind of guerrilla warfare T.E. Lawrence made famous in World War I.
Prices inched ahead throughout the day in a modest preFourth of July rally on the American Stock Exchange.
ANGUILLA, June 29 This rebellious Caribbean island of 5,000 people has pulled down two flags in the last month and now lives under no flag at all.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 30 Dr. and Mrs. William Taliaferro Close of Greenwich and Kinshasa, the Congo, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Tina Close, to Diarmid Alexander Campbell of Los Angeles, son of Mrs. Kier Arthur Campbell of Edinburgh and Argyle, of Scotland, and the late Mr. Campbell.

Canadians enter their second century of national existence today. It was on July 1, 1867, that a union of four provinces Quebec, Ontario, Nova Scotia and New Brunswick was created by the British North America Act.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) Hearings on Otto F. Otepka's appeal against his dismissal from the State Department were concluded unexpectedly yesterday evening, Irving Jaffe, the Government's counsel, said today.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 30 Cassius Clay, the deposed heavyweight boxing champion, called today for a conference of Negro leaders to "see who has the best solution" for solving the problems facing the Negro.

WATERTOWN, Conn., June 30 Mr. and Mrs. Richard Mackay Hunt of Watertown and Point Allerton, Mass., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lois Trowbridge Hunt, to Richard Maddox Combs Jr. of Bethlehem, Pa., and Keene Valley, N.Y. His parents are Mrs. Van Santvoord MerleSmith Jr. of Bethlehem and the late Lieutenant Combs, U.S.A.
Robert J. Gressens has been appointed president of the Automatic Electric Company, a subsidiary of the General Telephone and Electronics Corporation.
WASHINGTON, June 30 Its back to the mattress, the sugar bowl and the sock tonight for the money of thousands of cautious souls who had put their trust in the United States Post Office.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., June 30 The Reformed Church was the setting here this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Fay Martha Rand, daughter of Mrs. Eben Eaton Rand and the late Mr. Rand, to Christopher Chamberlin Cram, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ambrose Lanfear Cram Jr. The Rev. Dr. Charles Leonard Copenhaver performed the ceremony.

City Finance Administrator Roy M. Goodman announced yesterday that the city would mail out approximately one million city income tax refunds on schedule by July 15. He said that about $5-million would be refunded.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, July 1 Premier Nguyen Cao Ky has withdrawn from the Presidential race and has agreed to run for Vice President on the ticket of his rival, Lieut. Gen. Nguyen Van Thieu, the Chief of State.
VANCOUVER, B.C., June 30 (Canadian Press) Three Canadians plan to fly to the Soviet Union shortly to test fly the the world's biggest helicopter, the Russian MI-10.
MONTAUK, L. I., June 30--With a bagel as a bon voyage gift, William Wills, a bewhiskered 73-year-old mariner, set sail alone for England at 2:10 P.M. today on a tiny, bobbing sailboat.
PHILADELPHIA, June 30 (AP) William Maul Measey, a Philadelphia lawyer who once give a $400,000 castle to the Swiss Government, died here Wednesday. He was 91 years old.
A partner in a printing plant who felt uneasy about delivering his company's weekly payroll obtained a pistol permit Thursday.

Lincoln Center: Avron Coleman, cellist, and Ilene Furman, pianist, Library-Museum, 4 P.M.; Hamburg State Opera presenting Berg's "Lulu," Metropolitan Opera House, 8; New York Philharmonic, Philharmonic Hall, 8:30.
HONG KONG, June 30 (Reuters) A Thai International Airways jetliner carrying 80 persons, 59 of them Americans, plunged into Hong Kong harbor as it was approaching the airport for landing.

PHILADELPHIA, June 30--The marriage of Miss Cathy Jane McLaughlin, daughter of Mrs. Kenneth Massey Davis Jr., and William Edwin McLaughlin, to Corning Pearson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Pearson, took place this afternoon.
HARTFORD, Saturday, July (UPI) Colt Industries, Inc., producer of the M-16 rifle used in Vietnam, was struck at 12:01 A.M. today by Local 376 of the United Automobile Workers Union.
The Avco Corporation, diversified industrial producer, reported yesterday slightly lower earnings in the three and six months ended May 31, despite higher sales.
The Sakura Maru, the only vessel in the world built specifically as a floating fair, will welcome visitors today as the latest in a series of foreign ships in the city's port.
PATERSON, N.J., June 30 Harold Matzner, the 29-yearold Wayne publisher, pleaded not guilty here today to an indictment charging him with the murder of Mrs. Judith Kavanaugh, 21, a Clifton housewife.

The Dodge Manufacturing Company, which has openly favored a merger with the Reliance Electric Company over the merger proposals of the Emerson Electric Company, agreed yesterday to deliver a list of its common stockholders to Emerson.
Martha Graham will be guest of honor at a dinner at the Garden City (L.I.) Hotel, the proceeds of which will help support the Long Island Festival.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., June 30 President Johnson signed a proclamation today to reduce sharply a wide variety of dairy imports, including cheese, butter and butterfat mixtures.
A dismissed Peace Corps volunteer defended yesterday the rights of members to protest publicly against United States policies and specificially against American bombing of North Vietnam.

SEOUL, South Korea, June 30 The police arrested 150 students today in demonstrations against President Chung Hee Park's Government on the eve of the former general's inauguration as chief of state for a second four-year term.
CHICAGO, June 30 A clear plastic coating applied to the biting surface of teeth twice a year cuts decay 86 per cent, a two-year study shows.

SALT LAKE CITY, June 30 (AP) A woman was killed tonight in a violent explosion and flash fire at a residence near downtown Salt Lake City. The Federal Bureau of Investigation was called in after a large quantity of ammunition was found at the scene.
IRVINGTON, N.J., June 30 (AP) An 8-year-old blueeyed blonde who the police say committed seven burglaries in April and May has been arrested again.
CHICAGO, June 30 (AP) Home runs by Billy Williams and Ron Santo today paced the surging Chicago Cubs to a 7-5 victory over the Cincinnati Reds.
A State Supreme Court justice held the author of the best-selling book "How to Avoid Probate" in criminal contempt yesterday and issued an injunction against the book's sale and distribution.

WHITE PLAINS, June 30 Mrs. Ruth Lord Harris Nixon, a great-granddaughter of Eleazar Lord, founder and first president of the New York and Erie Railroad, predecessor of the Erie-Lackawanna Railroad, died yesterday in her home at 1 South Broadway after a long illness. Her age was 82, She was the widow of Russell T. Nixon, a shirt manufacturer.
Stock prices closed mixed yesterday as trading dwindled to the lowest level in a month.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, June 30 (AP) Carlos Ortiz is favored to retain the world lightweight boxing title tomorrow night against the challenge of Sugar Ramos of Cuba in a rematch of their disputed bout in Mexico City last Oct. 22.
MOSCOW, June 30 (UPI) President Nikolai V. Podgorny flew to Damascus today to confer with Syrian leaders on the aftermath of the Arab-Israeli war.
GLASSBORO, N.J., was known for its glassware long before its summit conferences.
WESTPORT, Conn., June 30 George Percival Hughes, a vice president of Snyder Black Schiegel, Inc., a White Plains lithographing concern, died in his home here Wednesday. His age was 76.

The published censored version of the Navy's court of inquiry into the tragedy of the Liberty the Navy communications ship that was attacked by Israeli forces during the brief Middle Eastern War leaves a good many questions unanswered.

" I WISH to assert firmly that [Vladimir] Nabokov should not be given over to the pedants and the puzzle-solvers," Andrew Field writes in his impressive and ambitious "critical narrative," "Nabokov: His Life in Art" (Littie, Brown, $8.95).

SAINT-CLOUD, France, June 30 Braulio Baeza, who has ridden the winners of more than 2,500 thoroughbred horse races in the United States and his native Panama, made his European debut today and finished fifth. Except for some improvers of the breed who had bet on his horse, no one complained.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 30 Secretary General Thant said today that he would appoint a high-ranking representative to obtain "on the spot" information on the safety and welfare of civilians in Arab territories occupied by Israel.

In a chapel of the Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration (Little Church Around the Corner) here yesterday afternoon, Miss Winifred Olivia Carlson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Emerson E. Carlson of Darien, Conn., became the bride of John Christoper Mead. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter W. Mead of Tenafly, N.J.
JERUSALEM, June 30 The people of the two former sections of Jerusalem continued today to move back and forth freely in the unified city, oblivious to the technical arguments over legal status.
One of the country's major Protestant denominations, the 3-million-member Lutheran Church-Missouri Synod, will hold its biennial convention in New York for one week, beginning Friday.

CHATHAM, N.J., June 30 Mrs. Marge Mason of Ridge- wood and La Junta White of Forest Hill won the Garden State Women's Golf Associa- tion better-ball team championship for the third time today at the Fairmount Country Club.
ATHENS, June 30 A leader of Greece's 10-week-old military junta described any talk of elections today as "premature."
WADESBORO, N.C., June 30 (UPI) Bombs blasted the property today of five Anson County school officials who had been working for the integration of the high school.

WHITE PLAINS, June 30 An officer of a Westchester garbage collection company was arrested today in what a District Attorney said was the first direct move against "the attempt of organized crime to take over the waste-disposal business in Westchester."
The New York Generals, who have scored nine goals in two recent National Professional Soccer League victories, meet the Philadelphia Spartans tonight at Yankee Stadium. Game time in is 8 o'clock.

MEXICO CITY, June 30 After nine months of negotiations, a 66 per cent interest in Azufrera Panamericans, S.A., de C.V., main operating subsidiary of the Pan American Sulphur Company of Houston, was sold today to Mexican interests for about $75.5-million.
In his history of what befell the Romans, Edward Gibbon records that spoils of war included "leopards with collars set with jewels" and "hounds with satin housings."
WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) Medals kept falling off the chest of Cyrus R. Vance, the resigning Deputy Secretary of Defense, today.
LONDON, June 30 (AP) Lord Brassey, developer of the sport of small hovercraft racing, died Wednesday. He was 62 years old.
NEW ORLEANS, June 30 Rear Adm. Ross P. Bullard assumed command of the Eighth Coast Guard District here today from Rear Adm. James D. Craik, who is retiring after a 38-year Coast Guard career.
A long line of rain drenched welfare clients paraded for more than three hours outside City Hall yesterday to emphasize their demands for improved treatment.

TOKYO, June 30 (AP) North Vietnam charged today that three foreign vessels had been hit by United States bombs in Haiphong's port, injuring one crew member of a Chinese Communist ship and damaging a British ship.
WASHINGTON, June 30 The commander of the Army base at Fort Leonard Wood, Mo., was accused today of using his rank to influence court-martial officers to impose generally heavy sentences.
CARRINGTON, N.D., June 30 (UPI) Larry Steinbach, a professional football player who later became a wealthy North Dakota rancher, died Tuesday. He was 66 years old.
MOSCOW, June 30--The Soviet Government charged today that United States planes attacked a Soviet merchant ship yesterday in a North Vietnamese port, the second such incident in four weeks.
The city Health Department closed yesterday its Criminal Court clinic where women accused of prostitution had been examined and treated for venereal disease.

A new billion-dollar transportation company was created at 12:01 A.M. today when the Seaboard Air Line and the Atlantic Coast Line railroads merged to form their ... new rail system the Seaboard Coast Line Railroad. It will mark the first large merger to be effected within the railroad industry since October, 1964, when the Norfolk Western Railway merged with the New York, Chicago St. Louis (Nickel Plate) and four other lines.
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., June 30 (AP) Pam Kruse cut 1.2 seconds off the world record for the 400-meter freestyle tonight while competing in the Fort Lauderdale open swimming and diving championships.

TOKYO, Saturday, July 1 (AP) The Chinese Government today celebrated the 46th anniversary of the Chinese Communist party and declared that the party had become "the mainstay of the international Communist movement."
EL SEGUNDO, Calif., June 30 Maj. Robert H. Lawrence Jr. of the Air Force, a Negro, was selected for the nation's space program today.

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., June 30 Winning the three repechage (second chance) races at 2,000 meters on Hunter's Island lagoon off Orchard Beach, William Maker of the Detroit Boat Club, John Nunn Rowing Association and Jeffrey Kreger of the Wyandotte Boat Club of Michigan qualified today for the singles sculls final in the trials for the Pan-American rowing championships.
CANDLEWOOD LAKE, Conn., June. 30--Russell G. Rankin a consulting associate and retired partner of Price Waterhouse Co., accountants, died yesterday of pneumonia in his home here. His age was 78.

ALEXANDRIA BAY, N.Y., June 30 Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Rowe Headra of Gouverneur and Schooner Island, have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Jane Hendra, to Eugene Michael Anthony Gervasi, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Henry Gervasi of Rome, Italy, and New York.

A selection of works from the Mrs. Albert C. Barnes Bequest will be shown at the Brooklyn Museum July 10 through Aug. 27. There are 23 paintings, Pastels, Water-colors and prints by American and European artists of the 19th and 20th centuries. The museum considers the bequest to be one of the most important gifts ever made to it.

ROME, June 30 The Pope's chief trouble shooter in Communist countries is a slightly built, agile bespectacled diplomat with a fondness for anonymity and a firm belief that the object of Vatican diplomacy is the good of souls.

GENEVA, June 30 A $10,000 check from a fund established by Mrs. Svetlana Alliluyeva, Stalin's daughter, was remitted today at Zurich by her Swiss lawyer, Willy Stahelin, to officials of the Pestalozzi Village ... for Homeless Children in central Switzerland.
A children's farm for Prospect Park was blocked yesterday on a technicality in State Supreme Court is Brooklyn after two years of litigation by opponents Of the project.
WASHINGTON, June 30 Manufacturers' inventories rose by $254-million in May, the smallest rise this year, the Commerce Department reported today.

Over a decade ago we abandoned the grand strategy of the threat of nuclear war on the U.S.S.R. as the most effective means of keeping the peace. With a sign of relief we moved to the current doctrine of controlled and essentially non-nuclear deterrence. We would now keep the peace at the perimeter of the U.S.S.R. and China by applying only that limited amount of force necessary to forestall aggression.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, said today that patriotism was being "treated as some kind of social disease to be tolerated, if not stamped out."
PARIS, June 30 The seizure of 13 paintings suspected of being forgeries was described by their dealer today as an effort by jealous American merchants to discredit the French art market.

EDINBURG, Tex, June 30 (AP) A Senate subcommittee chairman said today that the atmosphere and events in recent months in the Rio Grande Valley "comprise the most powerful testimony this subcommittee has ever received" to extend the protection of collective bargaining to farm workers.
A Brooklyn Federal judge yesterday prohibited the enforcement of a Hempstead (L.I.) town ordinance against excessive noise from aircraft using Kennedy International Airport.

George D. Widener's Bold Hour and George Robb's Tumiga head the field in the Saranac Handicap, the feature attraction at Aqueduct today. Although there are seven entrants in the mile race for 3-year-olds, these two will carry top weight of 123 pounds, with Bold Hour likely to be a slight favorite at post time.
A Criminal Court judge yesterday called 38 hippies "unwashed, unshod, unkempt and uninhibited" as he dismissed charges against them stemming from a mass arrest on Memorial Day.
HOUSTON, June 30 (AP) Claude Osteen clouted a home run into the right-field seats leading off the ninth inning tonight to give the Los Angeles Dodgers a 5-4 victory over the Houston Astros.
WASHINGTON, June 30 President Johnson signed today a four-year extension of the draft.
Four major lumber associations reported a decrease of 3.4 per cent in production for the week ended June 24 compared with the level in the correspon in 1966 week.

BALTIMORE, June 30 (AP) Vic Davalillo, who entered the game as a pinch-runner in the eighth inning, singled home a run in the 14th tonight, giving the Cleveland Indians a 6-5 victory over the Baltimore Orioles.
Sixth Avenue, which has been dug up, torn up and generally jammed up for the last three years, was finally opened up this week. It was a long-awaited but shortlived moment.

BUFFALO, June 30 Negroes in this racially strife-torn city charge that police-community relations here have been poor for a long time and that the roots of this discontent go far beyend the current disorders. The very presence of policemen often will incite disorder, some Negroes say.

SUMMIT, N.J., June 30 The marriage of Miss Susan Braden Oxman to John Edward Rhetts took place here this afternoon in the Unitarian Church. The Rev. Dr. William Rodda of Morrow Memorial Church in Maplewood performed the ceremony. A. reception was held at the Canoe Brook Country Club.

LONG BEACH, L. I., June 30 Louis H. Cohen president and founder of the George Umbrella, Company, Inc., with a factory here and offices at 35 West 35th Street in New York City, died today in Long Beach Memorial Hospital. He was 78 years old and lived at 27 West Beech Street.

RANGOON, Burma, June 30 (Reuters) The Burmese Government today imposed a onemonth ban on demonstrations and public assembly in the central Burmese town of Mandalay following nightlong anti-Chinese demonstrations.

GREAT BARRINGTON, Mass., June 30 Gone Flyin' captured one class and finished second in another today to pull into a five-point lead for the open jumper championship at the Great Barrington Horse Show.
OCEANPORT, N.J., June 30 (AP) Shore, owned by C.H. Wacker 3d and ridden by Don Brumfield, scored a two-length victory in the $6,500 Levee purse at Monmouth Park today.
Assemblyman Frank G. Rossetti, acting leader of the Manhattan Democratic organization, predicted yesterday that its executive committee would elect him to a full two-year term next Friday.
Prices on the London stock market drifted in a quiet session yesterday.

BERKELEY, Calif., June 30 (UPI) Mario Savio and Bettina Aptheker Kurzwell, leaders of the Free Speech Movement at the University of California three years ago, went to jail today for their part in the mass demonstrations that brought campus activities to a standstill.
PITTSBURGH, June 30, AP Steve Blass, a pitcher, rapped a two-run single in the eighth inning with two out tonight, giving the Pittsburgh Pirates a 3-1 victory over the Atlanta Braves.

BRIDGETOWN, Barbados Lord Nelson still stands triumphantly in Trafalgar Square here within a few feet of picturesque old trading schooners tied up in the careenage, a narrow inlet into Bridgetown from the Caribbean.

LAWRENCE TOWNSHIP, N. J., June 30--The Township Committee backed away early this morning from its approval of a zoning change that would have permitted E. R. Squibb Company, Inc., the pharmaceutical house, to locate in a rural residential section.

Mr. and Mrs. David Lidman of 390 West End Avenue have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Karen Ebba Lidman Jr., to Nader Panahi. He is the son of Mrs. Anna Panahi of Teheran, Iran, and the late Halil Panahi, who was a director of the government-controlled Iran Carpet Company.

BLOOMFIELD, Conn., July 1 --Miss Marian Rand Ferguson, daughter of Mrs. Samuel Ferguson Jr. and the late Mr. Ferguson, was married this afternoon at her mother's home to Robert Henry Abzug. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour W. Abzug of Great Neck, L.I.

WASHINGTON--With a terse announcement handed out to reporters assembled in the Fish Room of the White House, the Johnson Administration last week brought to a successful conclusion its first major foreign policy crisis. In the process, President Johnson may also have written a happy ending to one of the more inglorious chapters of "Yankee imperialism."

BALTIMORE, July 1 (AP) --Harry Dalton, the director of player personnel for the Bal- timore Orioles said today that Frank Robinson's condition had improved and the slugger's absence from the line-up would be on a "day-to-day basis."

TAIPEI, Taiwan, July 1--It was a big day for Taipei today. Its area was tripled, its population increased by several hundred thousand to 1.47 million, and its government was made responsible directly to the Chi nese Nationalist executive branch.

Parks Commissioner August Heckscher went swimming in the polluted waters off South Beach on Staten Island yesterday while City Council President Frank D. O'Connor called on the Federal Government to conduct pollution studies of all city's beaches.
WASHINGTON, July 1-- Negroes have not shared in the rapid growth of employment opportunities in Washington, a private report indicated today.

THE advantages of the view camera design, with its unequaled versatility and many controls, have been generally overlooked in an era dominated by the 35mm camera. Not that the two types are comparable, but it would seem that the miniature is too often used where the view camera could do a much better job, albeit with a good deal more effort.

Mr. and Mrs. William Cornelius McCreery of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Virginia Irene McCreery, to Barry Anthony Butler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick J. Butler of Newport, R.I.

CHICAGO, July 1--The nation's airline pilots are not happy about the safety aspects of civil aviation and will continue to press for improvements they consider essential for the safeguarding of passengers, the chief spokerman for the pilots said today.

REFLECTIONS July 4, 1776 was a day of great decision for the nation's founders. July 4, 1967 could be a day of great decision for individuals who want to do something about improving their environment, but just haven't gotten around to action.
The Rabbinical Council of America will publish a new English edition of the traditional daily prayer book to eliminate "archaic English that is unintelligible to the average worshiper."

The Urban League of Greater New York will benefit from the annual "Evening of Elegance" dinner dance to be held on July 21 at the home of Sidney Poltier, the actor, and his wife in Pleasantville, N.Y.
TOKYO, July 1 (Reuters)-- A large tanker is being en- larged for a Greek owner by a Japanese shipbuilding yard that employs a newly developed "welding on the sea" method.

Weldwood International, a wholly owned subsidiary of U.S. Plywood-Champion Papers, Inc., is planning to increase its direct purchases of Japanese plywood and other products from existing channels for export to the United States, it was made known last week by G. Arnold Smith, Weldwood International's vice president and import-export manager for PlywoodChampion.
LOS ANGELES, July 1-- Police treatment of Vietnam peace demonstrators during President Johnson's recent visit burgeoned this week into one of the biggest community issues here in years.

Officers of the American Jewish Congress, reporting on a visit to six Eastern European countries, say all are more responsive to the needs of the Jewish communities for schools, theaters and other cultural institutions than is the Soviet Union, which has a Jewish population of 2.8 million.

FALLS CHURCH, Va., July 1 --Miss Barbara Ellen Sullivan, daughter of Col. Martin F. Sullivan, U.S.A., and Mrs. Sullivan, was married this morning to Lieut. Robert J. McGinn, U.S.A.F., son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence J. McGinn of New York.
WASHINGTON, July 1-- Some drastic changes may lie ahead in the style and substance of American health care, experts said here this week.

WASHINGTON, July 1--The District of Columbia board of education voted tonight not to appeal a Federal court decree that bars discriminatory practices against Negroes in the public schools here and declares de facto segregation in Washington unconstitutional.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., July 1 (AP)--Barbara Friedrich of New Jersey's Shore Ath- letic Club bettered the meet record in the javelin throw with a tosa of 183 feet 8 inches today at the opening session of the Amateur Athletic Union women's national track and field championships.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, July 1 (Reuters) --A priest refused to celebrate a mass here today honoring the first anniversary of President Joaquin Balaguer's term of office because he considered it a political act.

The National Teacher Corps last week was de-nationalized, and thereby saved. THE volume of autobiographical musings entitled "The Difficulty of Being" was composed by Jean Cocteau in 1947. At the time of its writing, the author was 58 years old and internationally famous; he knew "everyone" in Europe and, even more important, "everyone" knew him. Whatever was the latest cry in literature, in art, in music and in fashion seemed to have him to thank for something.

MARYHILL, Wash.--Stonehenge on the Columbia River, about 100 mills east of Portland? Stonehenge is way over there in England, but an imaginative copy--not really a copy, since this one is complete, not in ruins--stands here in Maryhill. Nearly 40 years of weathering have made the huge, concrete, rough-surfaced slabs look like real rocks, at least in the dark.
