FISHER'S ISLAND, N.Y.-- While the New York-Washington axis commanded world attention, General de Gaulle has been holding his own series of Little Summits in Paris. These included two visits by Chairman Kosygin, one by Prime Minister Wilson, and successive talks with the President of Turkey, NATO's only Middle Eastern member, and the Premier of Rumania, most independent Soviet ally.

BUFFALO, Sunday, July 2-- After a night of relative calm, two fires broke out early this morning in the Negro ghetto here that has been the scene of sporadic disorder since Tuesday. Youths in the streets said the two fires had been set.

WASHINGTON--"Negotiate --don't litigate" is an honored adage among lawyers. But until recently, it appeared to figure little, if at all, in the tactics of Harlem's litigious Congressman-inexile, Adam Clayton Powell.

"They were wound up like clocks," said George Benson Jr., assistant director of Camp Hidden Valley in East Fishkill, N.Y. He was describing the 652 Fresh Air Fund children who had traveled by bus Thursday from the noise of New York City to the quiet of the 3,000acre Sharpe Reservation.
TEL AVIV, July 1--Twelve Arab civilians were shot and killed today by Israeli soldiers guarding food stores of the United Nations Relief and Works Agency in the Gaza Strip.

NEW HAVEN, July 1--Miss Martha Alter, daughter of the Rev. James Payne Alter and Mrs. Alter of Rajpur, India, was married here this afternoon to Lincoln Chih-ho Chen, son of Samuel Shi-tsai Chen of New York and the late Mrs. Chen. The Rev. Dr. David Nelson Beach, grandfather of the bride and pastor emeritus of the Center Church (First Church of Christ) here, performed the ceremony in the Dwight Chapel at Yale University.

JACKSON, Miss.--For the motorist speeding south from Memphis along United States Highway 51, the Mississippi landscape is a near blur of cotton field, cross roads grocery, small service station and occasional country settlement.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., July 1-- The defending champion, John Mangan of the New York Athletic Club, led the way through the quarter-finals of the 35th annual Paul Martin Memorial singles championship tournament today at Fox Meadow Tennis Club.
WASHINGTON--The long, hot summer is still ahead, but for the moment Lyndon Johnson's thoughts are on the frenzied fortnight just ended.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 1--The Constituent Assembly approved 17 presidential tickets today. They included that headed by Maj. Gen. Duong Van Minh, an exited former chief of state, and that of the ruling junta--Lieut. Gen. Nguyen Van Thieu with Premier Nguyen Cao Ky as his running mate.

COLLECTORS of British stamps have an eyepleasing treat in store. One week from to morrow three adhesives will be released in what could be a continuing series of colorful miniatures of paintings by distinguished British artists.

I USED to read a great deal when I was a small boy, a habit which was regarded by my friends as a disturbing deviation from the normal. They did everything to help me to overcome it and succeeded to such a degree that, like a reformed smoker, I tended to do my reading more and more in semi-concealment.
BONN, June 24--The chimney sweep, often thought of abroad as a refugee from Mary Poppins, is a skilled and re spected member of the community in Germany.

THE Mount Equinox hillclimb for sports cars to be run next Saturday and Sunday on the five-mile paved course in Manchester, Vt., is rated as probably the best as well as the longest of seven on the Sports Car Club of America calendar.

THE Russian Evolution has entered a new phase: Soviet cultural figures on group visits to the United States no longer mind disagreeing with each other publicly on matters concerning the American theater.

MEMPHIS, July 1--Miss Stephanie Marie von Lackum, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William J. von Lackum, was married this morning to Dr. Joel Edward Henkel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin V. Henkel of Short Hills, N.J., and Harwich, Mass.

Miss Gloria Nancy Sherman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour J. Sherman of Flushing, Queens, was married last night to Dr. Jeffrey Eugene Brownstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Brownstein of Yonkers. The ceremony was performed in the Whitestone (Queens) Hebrew Center by Rabbi Ezra Finkelstein.

WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) --The Government announced today the selection of 30 school districts around the country, including New York City and Rochester, to take part in an effort to continue the work begun by the Head Start program for poor children.
NEW DELHI--"The guillotine of the French Revolution would have been kinder," the maharajah said with a weary wave of the hand. "We wouldn't have had to live all these years in agony."

IN his introduction to this entertaining, wildly disordered and apparently uncopyrighted scrapbook, Derek Jewell, the jazz and auto editor of The (London) Sunday Times Magazine, tells about a woman in Buckinghamshire "who so loved her 1932 Austin that she could not bear the thought of anyone else owning it. She had it crushed into a column of metal, first to be an ornament in her garden, then to act as the headstone for her grave."

The city's Department of Marine and Aviation expects of add two new facilities to the Manhattan watefront--a new 3,000-foot cargo wharf and a landing facility for short takeoff planes--Commissioner Herbert B. Halberg said last week.
TOKYO, July 1 (UPI)-- Hsinhua, the official Peking press agency, announced today the death of the Foreign Trade Minister, Yeh Chi-chuang. He was 74 years old.

LOS ANGELES, July 1 (UPI) --Jim Barnes, a forward who jumped over to the American Basketball Association's Dallas entry, changed his mind and signed a 1967-68 contract with the Los Angeles Lakers, the N.B.A. club announced today.

WEST POINT, N.Y., July 1-- The Cadet Chapel of the United States Military Academy here was the setting this afternoon for the wedding of Miss Nancy Elizabeth West and Capt. Kenneth Michael De Gon, U.S.A., son of Dr. and Mrs. Kenneth C. De Gon of Denver. The bride is the daugther of Dr. and Mrs. William B. West of Port Chester.

Nine couples who wore wedding attire supplied free by Brooklyn stores were married yesterday in Prospect Park amid the jockeying of publicity representatives and the snarling of elbowing television crews.

An unparalled boom in nursing home construction over the last five years has produced an industry with an estimated annual income of $2-billion that can thank the Federal Medicare program for much of its growth.
Will the Soviet Union emerge with strengthened or weakened influence in the Arab world after the dust has settled and the passions have cooled?

MONTCLAIR, N.J., July 1-- Miss Molly Harvey Mortimer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey Ward Mortimer, was married today to Lieut. (j.g.) Kurt Gilbert Hammerstrom, U.S.N.R., son of Dr. and Mrs. Carl F. Hammerstrom of Jamestown, N.Y.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., July 1-- Miss Frances E. Delany, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Delany, was married this morn- ing to Ens. Justin Sparks McLaughlin, U.S.N.R., son of Capt. James McLaughlin, U.S.N., and Mrs. McLaughlin of Marshfield, Mass.

Condemning the Administra- tion's maritime policy as a "shortsighted, piecemeal approach to vital issues" the Seafarers International Union of North America announced last week that it would intensi- fy an "aggressive" campaign among members of Congress to reverse the decline in the nation's merchant fleet.
Banks, unlike most American corporations, are increasing their earnings this year.
The 9th summer road run of the Road Runners Club of New York will be held July 16 at 10 A.M. at Van Cortlandt Park, the Bronx.

"Two dollars for one dollar!" A cigar-smoking man wearing a brown suit and sporty tie shouted the words over and over at noon yesterday as he stood on the northeast corner of Broadway and 42d Street waving a fistful of Canadian $2 bills.

DETROIT, July 1 (AP)--Ron Hansan drove in three runs with his sixth homer and a two-run double tonight as the Chicago White Sox defeated the Detroit score 6-5. Hoye Withelm, a knockleball relief picher, cut...

PRINCETON, N.J., July 1 --Princeton University astronomers are studying new photographs that they hope will provide information on the atmosphere of Venus before the findings of the American Mariner 5 and the Soviet Union's Venus 4 rockets become avail able.

When Dr. Millard G. Roberts became president of Parsons College at Fairfield, Iowa, in 1955, neither the portly Presbyterian minister nor the liberal arts collegs whose stewardship he was assuming had stirred much attention in American higher education.
PARIS, July 1--A brother of King Faisal of Sandi Arabia was acquitted today of charges that he had passed a bad check in a gambling house.
JACKSON HOLE, Wyo., July 1-- The mood among the Republican Governors meeting and gossiping here is one of puzzled pragmatism. They are waiting for Godot, or somebody.
DUBLIN, July 1--Ribocco closed with a late rush and won the $224,000 Irish Sweeps Derby from Sucaryl today.
SEATTLE, July 1--Seattle will be the home of the first 50story building in the Pacific Northwest by the summer of 1969.

Wall Street technicians range from bullish to cautious in their market outlook, but generally they agree on this point--a decline below the 835 area in the Dow-Jones industrial average could signal danger.

HOPEWELL, N.J., July 1-- Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Douglas Edmunds Stuart of Hopewell and Greensboro, Vt., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Alison Margrethe Stuart, to Frederic Ashton de Peyster Todd, son of Mrs. and Mrs. James Todd of New York, Bedford, N.Y., and Edgartown, Mass.

CHICAGO--Organized medicine has spoken almost with a single voice, that of the American Medical Association, for decades. During the great debate of recent years on whether health care for the elderly and indigent should be tax-supported, A.M.A. opposition was vocal, determined and almost unchallenged within the medical profession.

HOMES being built today --the ground-hugging ranch, split-level and contemporary styles-- offer an absorbing landscape challenge. The new homeowner has wide latitude in the choice of plant materials for his garden's design.

MONTAUK, L.I., July 1 --Robert and Charles Langman knew what they wanted to build as a bachelor resort house and spent four years searching for the ideal site including many hours over eastern Long Island in rented seaplanes.

CORNWALL, Conn., July 1-- The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Frances Horan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis H. Horan of New York and Cornwall, to David Leighton Edgerly took place today. The bridegroom is a son of Mrs. Josephine K. Edgerly of Brownsville, Vt., and the late Dr. Sherburn Edgerly of Englewood, N.J.
Albert C. Purkiss, a vice president and director of Walston Co., Inc., investment house, died Friday at his home in Greenwich, Conn. His age was 59.
BOSTON, July 1--Gerald Eskenazi, the hockey writer of The New York Times, was appointed this week a director and chapter chairman of the National Hockey League Writers' Association.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 1 --Miss Barbara Rossington Whyte, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur G. Whyte Jr. of Old Greenwich, became the bride of John Justin Moeling Jr., son of Mrs. Moeling of Camden, Me., and the late Mr. Moeling, this afternoon in Christ Episcopal Church, the Rev. Bradford Hastings performed the ceremony.

ACCORDING to Andrew Field, Viadimir Nabokov is an author who has written "two of the eight masterpieces of the novel in this century," and yet even his admirers insist on mispronouncing his name. The receptionist at one of Nabokov's publishers said: "Mr. Field is here to read Nahba-cocoa's reviews!"
HONG KONG, July 1 (UPI) --At least 15 Americans were among the 24 persons killed when a Thai International Airways jet airliner crashed into Kowloon Bay yesterday, the airlines reported today.

The Commodore Hotel, which some realty men had considered a prime target for the wrecker's ball, will be renovated at a cost of $6-million so that it can compete with newer hotels and motels for the traveler's dollar.

AWAKENED at 9 A.M. by a telephone call from the British Press Attache's secretary saying she was sorry to hear I'd been sick in bed with fever the day before. Sleepily, I said we must have lunch sometime "after the war."

DAMASCUS, Syria, July 1 (Reuters)--President Nikolai Podgoray of the Soviet Union arrived here today for talks on the Middle East crisis after his plane had been delayed for three hours by what he called "arbitrary measures" by Iranian authorities.

WATERLOO, Iowa, July 1 (AP)--The Rath Packing Company and the United Packinghouse, Food and Allied Workers jointly announced today the signing of a new three-year contract covering workers here and at Houston and Dallas; Decatur, Ill., and Birmingham, Ala.

MOSPORT, Ont., July 1 (Canadian Press)--Bobby Unser of Albuquerque, N.M., today was declared the winner of the Indy 200 road race for Indianapolis championship cars as rain halted the meet little more than half-way through the 200-mile course.

ANNANDALE-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., July 1--In the Episcopal Chapel of the Holy Innocents today, Miss Virginia Smithers, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Sydney Smithers 3d of Red Hook, became the bride of Kenneth John Nyman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walfred Morgan Nyman of Cumberland, R.I.

A patent held by the GeorgiaPacific Corporation on a drilling mud made from pulp-mill spent sulphite liquors has been held valid by Federal Judge William N. Goodwin in an oral decision rendered in the Federal District Court in Seattle, the company reported last week.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., July 1 (AP)--Romulus Hanover, narrowly missing disaster at the three-quarter mark, won the $16,420 Springwood Pace tonight in 1:58 2-5, setting a Saratoga Raceway record.

GAINESVILLE, Fla., July 1 (AP)--Mike Mattox of Grace- land College in Lamont, Iowa, scored 3,5211 points in the first five events today to lead the United States Track and Field Federation national decathlon meet at the University of Florida.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., July 1 --Mr. and Mrs. John Laing Clark of Providence and Rockport, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Joanna Clark, to Officer Candidate Joseph Couse Swayze Jr., U.S.A.R., of Fort Benning, Ga., son of Mr. and Mrs. Swayze of Glen Ridge and Hamburg, N.J.

THE United States and Canadian Governments are both continuing their efforts to prevent runaway conditions in the sil ver market. Although Washington and Ottawa are not acting jointly, they are both working toward the same end --to keep the price of silver bullion below the point where it would be profitable for private smelters to withdraw and melt large quantities of the silver coins currently in circulation.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sunday, July 2--Fighting broke out between Israeli and Egyptian forces on the Israeli-occupied east bank of the Suez Canal yesterday, breaking the ceasefire that ended the war in the Middle East on June 11.

PARIS, July 1--France disclosed today that she would maintain an independent role in space exploration with the announcement that funds would be appropriated for a new satellite-launching rocket, the Super Diamant or Diamant B.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 1--A 19-year-old youth was fatally injured here last night when his car was forced off the North Highway into a tree by a jeep that had been stolen. The police said the jeep had been stolen earlier in the evening from Southampton.

LAWRENCEBURG, Tenn., July 1 (AP)--An earthen dam, weakened by more than two inches of rain in recent days, held most of its 3.6 billion gallons of water firm today. But the threat of a torrential flood remained for three small communities in middle Tennessee.

STANTON, Del., July 1 (AP) --George R. Wallace's Zapata captured the $28,950 Sussex Turf Handicap today at Delaware Park as Ogden Phipps's heavily backed Poker finished fifth.

Miss Martha Ellen Wheelock, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Frederic M. Wheelock of Toledo, Ohio, was married yesterday afternoon to Dallas Gene Alinder, son of Mr. and Mrs. Russell Alinder of Buffalo, N.D. The Rev. Charles Minifie performed the ceremony in St. Thomas Episcopal Church.
PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., July 1--James B. Moore's Lure won Resolute Class honors as 104 boats sailed with the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club in the first of three Cow Bay Area holiday weekend regattas.

JACKSON HOLE, Wyo.--The Republican party's meandering search for a Presidential candidate brought its governors to the verge of the breath-taking Grand Teton mountains last week--but no closer to a decision.

FALLS VILLAGE, Conn., July 1--Miss Kathleen Elizabeth Moore, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert B. Moore, was married this morning at the home of her parents to David Craig Meade, son of Mr. and Mrs. M. Craig Meade of Levittown, Pa.
WASHINGTON, July 1--The House Ways and Means Committee, in recent closed sessions, has rewritten major provisions of the Administration's Social Security bill to reduce its prospective costs.

CORNING, N.Y.--Two unusual displays form the core of special summer exhibitions at the Corning Glass Center. The ma jor display consists of 50 pieces from the first "Toledo Glass National." The other, "Islands in Crystal," is a new collection of Steuben glass based on a single theme.

George Seewagen Jr. of Bayside, Queens, the top seeded player, and Peter Fishbach of Great Neck, L.I., seeded fifth, advanced to the final round of the New York State tennis championships yesterday at the North Shore Tennis and Racquets Club, Bayside.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., July 1 --Catherine Lacoste, the amateur from France, clung to a five-stroke lead today over Margle Masters of Australia with one round to go in the Women's National Open golf tournament.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 1-- In All Saints Episcopal Chapel here this afternoon, Miss Barbara Bowne Rose, daughter of Edward Clark Rose Jr., was married to Second Lieut. Nixon Waln Hare, U.S.M.C. son of Mr. and Mrs. Emlen Waln Hare. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Harry I. Lauer, vicar of the chapel. A reception was given by the bride's father and stepmother at Princeton University's Ivy Club.

DENNIS, Mass., July 1--Miss Eleanor Crawley Romig was married here this afternoon to Louis Emile Henri Jaquinet. The Rev. Milton G. Kessler performed the ceremony at the Union Church (United Church) of Christ. He was assisted by the Rev. David W. Romig of the Sea and Land Presbyterian Church in New York, who is a brother of the bride.

MIAMI, July 1--Thousands of Cuban city workers, who only a fortnight ago had returned to their homes and jobs after several months of canecutting, are being mobilized again for what the Castro Government calls "the battle against weeds."

The United States and Canadian operations of Upton Bradeen James, Ltd., have been acquired by the Sterling Precision Corporation, it was announced last week by J. Russell Duncan, chairman of Sterling, and Charles S. Bradeen, president of Upton.

GANGTOK, Sikkim, June 20 --Facing the green, mistshrouded Himalayas, open-sided tents had been set up on the palace lawn. Buddhist prayer flags fluttered in the cool air. Officers of the Indian Army garrison chatted amiably with Sikkimese officials and their wives.

A 29-year-old Queens man was arraigned in Federal Court here yesterday on charges of printing and selling Diners' Club credit cards. The organization has reported it received $50,000 in bogus billings as a result of the scheme.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., July 1--Miss Linda Jean-Schaffner, daugther of Prof. and Mrs. Charles E. Schaffner, was married today to Timothy John Sharp, son of Mr. and Mrs. Eliot H. Sharp of Brooklyn Heights and Awosting, N.J.
Construction work is being completed on the first apartment house to be built on the lower portion of Central Park West since World War II.
BROADWAY, where wars are generally fought in private, may soon become a stage for open warfare--appropriately enough, over a queen.
YONKERS, JULY (UPI)-- Speedy Play, driven by Stanley Dancer, held off a stretch bid by Critics Choice and won the $10,000 Queens Handicap by a neck tonight at Yonkers Raceway.
MORRISTOWN, N.J., July 1 (AP)--A Morris County judge yesterday declared the ailing financier, Allan P. Kirby, mentally incompetent and appointed his two sons as guardians.
Fifteen years in a ship's life means a vessel has completed three-quarters of her commercial usefulness.

WASHINGTON--An Administration official was chided the other day about President Johnson's seeming inability to persuade Congress to enact a tax increase. The official replied simply, "We can't get a Mother's Day Resolution this Congress."

The first year of Medicare, which ended yesterday, has left the nation's 1,007 commercial health insurance companies with fewer customers, sharply reduced premium income and a greater opportunity for profits.
BUENOS AIRES, July 1-- Argentina did not celebrate the first anniversary of its last revolution this week--at least in any public way.
BERNARDSVILLE, N.J., July 1--Miss Nancy Lee Vanderbilt, a senior at Skidmore College, and Donald C. Abood, a Union College graduate, plan to be married.
A four-bedroom, singlestory house with 1,250 square feet of living space is priced at $14,990 at a new development, Hawthorne Estates, in Farmingville, L.I.

FARMINGTON, N.M.-- This state's remote Route 17, which can be found in the northwestern corner of New Mexico, offers a wide variety of highcountry scenery. Too, it has recently become the site of a major Federal engineering project.
College football coaches at a clinic in Monticello, N.Y., indicated last week that there was a rising tide of dissatisfaction with the game's controversial punting rule.
LLOYD HARBOR, L.I., July 1--Underworld leaders searching for a quiet home in the suburbs were warned away from Suffolk County this week.
Hoping for more people than shirts, the New York Generals will stage their first give-away day of the Na- tional Professional Soccer League season on Tuesday, July 4.
Two men were seized by the police in the Bronx yesterday and charged with possession of pure heroin, which, the police said, was worth $5-million.

Six insurgents who tried unsuccessfully in the June 20 primary to unseat Republican district leaders affiliated with Representative Paul A. Fino's Bronx organization have asked the State Supreme Court to order new elections.
TEL AVIV, July 1--An Israeli Army communique said earlier today that an Egyptian force had established a beachhead on the Israeli-occupied eastern bank of the Suez Canal.
BALTIMORE, July 1 (AP) --John O'Donoghue hurled seven innings of one-hit relief today as the Cleveland Indians defeated the Baltimore Orioles, 6-0.

MONTREAL, July 1--Art Wall Jr. retained the lead today in the $200,000 Canadian open gold championship with a 54hole aggregate of 207. As one hole--the par-3 17th, with a grassless green--proved a disaster area for scoring, Wall finished with a third round of 70 to maintain a two-stroke advantage.
LENINGRAD, July 1--The weakness of Soviet ballet is Soviet choreography, and today this is perhaps as clearly recognized here as in the rest of the world.

For the second consecutive year, a Mozart Festival will be presented at Philharmonic Hall during August. The 26-concert series, running from the 2d to the 31st, will be underwritten by the Lincoln Center Fund and given in association with the impresarios Jay K. Hoffman and George Schutz.
President Johnson, whose political sagacity is not to be underrated, has developed in recent days the probable theme of his campaign for re-election.

SAINT-CLOUD, France, July 1--Assagai, America's thoroughbred racing champion on grass, makes his first overseas start tomorrow in the $230,000 Grand Prix de Saint-Cloud. If he wins, it will be another example of how he has become the wrong horse at the right time.

MANHASSET, L.I., July 1 --Dr. Thomas J. Anderson Jr., of 600 Hunt Lane, retired chairman of the economics department at the New York University School of Commerce, Accounts and Finance, died yesterday in North Shore Hospital. His age was 68.
PORT CLINTON, Ohio, July 1 (UPI)--Ten persons were killed today in two plane crashes on opposite ends of the state.

WAYZATA, Minn., July 1-- Mr. and Mrs. Charles B. Sweatt of Wayzata and Palm Beach, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Elizabeth Sweatt, to Gerald Dexter McGee, son of Mrs. James L. Ferguson and Norman S. McGee of Westport, Conn.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 1 (UPI)--The National Young Republican chairman, Jack McDonald, denied today that the organization was at odds with other elements of the Republican party.
DURANT, Miss., July 1 (UPI) --James H. Meredith passed near his boyhood home today on his "march against fear" into Mississippi.
MORRISTOWN, N.J., July 1 --Miss Frances Edwina Bramhall and Herman Wittgens of Seattle and Grand Rapids, Mich., will be married here on Aug. 12 in St. Peter's Episcopal Church.

OCEANPORT, N.J., July 1-- Bill Boland and Bob Ussery were both concerned with keep- ing their mounts away from the rail today on a drying-out track in the $38,525 Molly Picher Handicap at Monmouth Park.
THE high point of the 1967 Metropolitan League matches was the meeting between the perennial rivals--the century-old Manhattan Chess Club and the 50--year-old Marshall Chess Club.
CHICAGO, July 1 (AP)-- Ernest H. Wood's Margarethen finished with a rush to win the $44,200 Beverly Handicap today before 25,106 at Arlington Park.

THIS is in the nature of a report from a rank-and-file American citizen to other r-and-f American citizens about their country's pavilion at Expo 67. There has been a great deal of comment and controversy generated by that big round dome, and the representations of life in America that it contains.

WASHINGTON, July 1 (UPI) --Contract agreement was reached today between the Order of Railway Conductors and Brakemen and the nation's railroads. The agreement ended one of the three strike threats against the railroads this year.

ESTORIL, Portugal--For only 14 cents, a visitor to Lisbon can take a suburban electric train to this seaside town, which has been the favorite resort of exiled royalty since World War I. Fourteen cents is the second-class fare for the halfhour ride; the first-class rate is 21 cents.
To the Editor: AFTER reading George Heinemann's article, "Do the Young Really Like Danger?" I thought perhaps someone could tell me what I could do to help banish the "terror" cartoons from TV.

THE Middle Atlantic Regional Lily Group, affiliated with the North American Lily Society, will hold its fifth-annual show on Saturday and next Sunday at the headquarters of the Pennsylvania Horticultural Society, 325 Walnut Street, Philadelphia. Hours are 2 to 5 P.M. Saturday and noon to 5 P.M. Sunday.

"I don't intend to go sour on you, but..." This is the way Bradford Mitchell began his acknowledgement at an industry luncheon last week honoring him on his retirement as public relations director for the American Merchant Marine Institute.

CAIRO, July 1--Delegations from 45 African and Asian nations, including the Soviet Union but not China, assembled in Cairo today to give the Arab world moral support in its struggle with Israel.
YONKERS, July 1--Miss Francesca Paula Graziano, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony J. Graziano of New York, was married this afternoon to Dr. Robert V. Piluso, son of Mrs. Carmel Piluso of Tuckahoe.

LONDON, July 1--King Hussein of Jordan, who will see Prime Minister Wilson here on Monday and President de Gaulle in Paris on Tuesday, said today that there could be peace in the Middle East if the Arabs were given justice.
The New York Mets, whose victories seldom come easily, were handed a gift triumph by the league-leading St. Louis Cardinals, 6-4, yesterday in Shea Stadium to the delight of most of the 27,931 fans.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., July 1 (UPI)--A Titan 3-C rocket carried six military satellites into orbit today. One of its missions was to improve Pentagon communications with Vietnam.
BALBOA, C.Z., July 1-- Total transits through the (Pan- ama Canal during the fiscal year that ended reached about 14,000 compared with 13,304 the previous year.

PORTLAND, Ore., July 1-- The Portland school board voted unanimously yesterday to eliminate all high school athletics in 1967-68.

PHILADELPHIA, July 1-- Miss Angela Schrode, daughter of Dr. Paul F. Schrode of Wynnewood and the late Mrs. Claude Rains, the former Miss Rosemary MsGroarty, of West Chester and Sandwich, N.H., was married today to Daniel Whepley Moger Jr. son of Mr. and Mrs. Moger of Riverside, Conn.

ADEN--Just six months before its scheduled independence, the British crown colony of Aden was wallowing last week in political chaos and economic paralysis despite the presence of 6,000 British troops there to maintain law and order.
PARIS, July 1--France has adopted a policy of precarious, nonpolitical asylum for deserters from the United States Army who want to live here.

Pendleton Lewis of Stonington and Siasconset, Mass., to James Palmer Whitlock Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Whitlock of Hillside and Bay Head, N.J.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 1 (UPI)--Desert Love rallied through the stretch today to score an upset victory in the 26th running of th $57,600 Vanity Handicap for the fillymare championship of the Hollywood Park meeting.

President Johnson's standing with the American people has shown a dramatic improvement as a result of his handling of the Middle East crisis and his talks with Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin of the Soviet Union, a Louis Harris poll indicates.

The shotgun wedding that has relegated Air Vice Marshal Ky to second place on the presidential slate headed by General Thieu, the Chief of State, is a major defeat for Saigon's controversial Premier. Whether it will bring an advance toward open elections and representative government is still an open question, but there are some reasons for hope.

ATLANTA, Ga.--This burgeoning Southern metropolis has gone the pheasant-and/or-baseball-under-glass concept one step further. It has under glass, and all in air-conditioned comfort, a spanking new $18-million-plus hotel that at first glance makes the vistor think that perhaps he is in a modern-day version of the gallerias in Naples or Milan.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., July 1 --Miss Sarah Greenleaf Beebe, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Greenleaf Beebe of Englewood and Cotuit, Mass., was married this afternoon to Dix Fletcher Davis, son of Mrs. George Shattuck Davis of Sterling, Mass., and the late Mr. Davis.

APART from the recent strike of maintenance workers that turned apartment house tenants into elevator operators and garbage collectors, it is probable that nothing especially dramatic has struck 190 Riverside Drive since it went up in 1909. Nothing, that is, until a recent hot, muggy morning when a Hollywood troupe, headed by Jack Lemmon and Walter Matthau, settled into its soft, tarry roof to shoot a scene for "The Odd Couple."

NEW CANAAN, Conn., July 1--Miss Jill Gunner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert C. Gunner of Wilton, was married this afternoon to Walter H. Cornish 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Cornish of Bernardsville, N.J.
The Teamsters Joint Council said yesterday that the city's welfare load had reached "disastrous dimensions." It urged the City Council to set up a special committee to oversee the Welfare Department.
WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) --Dr. Justin Meredith Andrews, an authority on malaria, died Thursday of a heart attack at his home in Largo, Fla. He was 64 years old.
WASHINGTON, July 1 (UPI) --Sheldon M. Cohen, Commissioner of the Internal Revenue Service, said today that contributions by business to local governments for summer youth programs are tax deductible.

ROME, July 1--A new, unofficial Roman Catholic publication devoted to improving Christian-Jewish relations says in a report on efforts to eliminate anti-Semitic pasages from catechisms that the campaign has fallen short of expectations raised by the Ecumenical Council.

Frederick Dieckmann, who retired about 10 years ago as president of the Reliable Van and Storage Company in Brooklyn, died of a heart attack Friday in Torrington, Conn. He was 66 years old and lived in Woodbury, Conn.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., July 1 --The old First Presbyterian Church of Huntington was the setting this morning for the marriage of Miss Corliss Dale Hewitt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Latham Hewitt, to Second Lieut. Jan Phillp Askman, U.S.A., son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip R. Askman of South Hamilton, Mass.
A New York interior de- signer has made her own declaration of independence from modern-style decor in the public areas of large apartment buildings.

The American Stock Exchange has just completed the busiest month in its 118-year history, but the records set by trading volume were overshadowed by an acute wave of speculative fever that has created concern throughout the financial community.

The meetings at Glassboro have left the impression that because President Johnson and Premier Kosygin both have grandchildren, the world of tomorrow will be better. The two men seemed to have agreed on nothing very useful for improving it right away, but when they talked of their grandchildren, it is said, their effusions about the great future they hope to secure for their posterity were eloquent and heartening.

TODAY'S students have a special thing going with the movies. They get turned on when the projector gets turned on. Increasingly film is becoming the medium in which they both find and express themselves most directly.

HONG KONG, July 1--Jenmin Jih Pao, the Peking organ of the Chinese Communist party, scorned today the aspiration voiced in the United States by Premier Kosygin that there should be an end to all wars.
EVANSTON, Ill., July 1--The American Academy of Pediatrics, citing a 75 per cent increase in injuries to school bus passengers in five years, called today for strict standards of safety on buses.

HONOLULU, July 1--Dr. Oliver M. Lee lost this week his appeal to the University of Hawaii regents from his impending ouster as a political science professor because of a controversial "primer for sabotage" issued by students.

DETROIT, July 1 (UPI)-- Officials fearful of a repeat of last year's Gold Cup race in which Chuck Thompson was killed have sternly warned drivers that no rough stuff will be tolerated in tomorrow's world championship power boat race on the Detroit River.
BOSTON, July 1 (UPI)--A mother of eight last week saw two of her children, on successive days, "die" before her eyes --only to be revived by a medical team at St. Elizabeth's Hospital.

HONG KONG, July 1--The major Maoist ideological journal has hailed the 46th anniversary of the Chinese Communist party by proclaiming the overthrow" of Lin Shao-chi, the chief of state, and a "handful" of "party people" associated with him.

RICHMOND, July 1--Dr. and Mrs. James Thomas Gianoulis have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Evangeline Gianoulis, to Newby Toms, son of Mrs. Zach Toms of Richmond, formerly of New York, and the late Mr. Toms.

CAIRO, July 1--The high command of the Egyptian armed forces announced late tonight that Egyptian and Israeli troops had been fighting on the east bank of the Suez Canal since 8:30 P.M. (1:30 P.M., New York time).

In the top-spin world of table tennis, Communist China not only is recognized, but is re- vered. The cultural revolution, as Mao Tse-tung calls it, prevented China's best players from competing in the recent world championships at Stockholm. The singles title was won by Nobuhlo Hasewage of Japan, but his was a hollow triumph.

Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday that the techniques of "instant rehabilitation," an experimental process that has been used to renovate a decay- ing tenement in 48 hours, would be applied to nine buildings in East Harlem. Because of costs involved, however, work will stretch over a two-week period.
It would be fine if all boat launching ramps were aloped at a standard angle, but unfortunately, lake and river banks vary from place to place and water depth changes with the seaons.

With the exception of Cape Cod, the summer resort business is thriving from Maine to Long Island, and it is being stimulated in New England and New York State by Montreal's Expo 67.

John N. Penick of 1140 Fifth Avenue, a partner in the law firm of Penick Nelson of 41 East 42d Street, died Wednesday night of cancer in the Harkness Pavilion of the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. His age was 71.

Archibald F. McGrath, former general, counsel and board chairman of the J.S. McGrath Corporation, one of the major stevedoring concerns on the Atlantic Coast, died yesterday in Lond Island College Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived at 161 97th Street, Brooklyn.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., July 1 --The marriage of Miss Mary C. Roberts, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Charles D. Roberts, to Patrick M. Schrafft took place today. The bridegroom is the son of Mrs. Robert Balbach Schrafft of Annisquam, Mass., and the late Mr. Schrafft.
GREAT BARRINGTON, Mass., July 1--Gone Flyin' clinched the open jumper championship of the Great Barrington horse show tonight--just as he had done in five of his six previous efforts this year.

Alfred Kussel, who retired 10 years ago as president of Peter A. Zucchi, Inc., designers of furniture and interiors, died of a heart attack here Friday. He was 85 years old and lived at 524 East 20th Street.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 1--Roy Emerson and Maria Bueno were out of Wimbledon today.

ALL first novels are promising, though in some cases you rather hope the promise will not be kept. In others-- John Yount's first novel, "Wolf at the Door," for example-- there is more than simply the promise of good things to come. There is already a substantial gift, and Mr. Yount (a 32-yearold North Carolinian who teaches at the University of New Hampshire) can already call himself a writer.

The American Friends Service Committee, the Quaker social action group, is increasing its program of training draft counselors to meet an increase in the number of young men in the metropolitan area seeking advice on alternatives to military service.

Issues on the American Stock Exchange and the over-thecounter market held their own last week. The American exchange's index of stock prices closed at $19.96, up 6 cents for the week. Amex stocks opened weaker on Monday, advanced on Tuesday and reached a high-water mark on Wednesday of $20.04.

BERLIN, July 1--Walter Ulbricht called on East Germans today to go to the polls tomorrow and endorse his policy of Communism at home and coolness toward improved relations with West Germany. The parliamentary elections, with a single list of candidates, are considered routine.

RAHWAY, N.J., July 1-- --Seymour Williams, who re- tired in 1950 as architectural supervisor of school buildings for the state's Department of Education, died today at the Rahway Memorial Hospital. He was 84 years old, and lived at 385 Central Avenue.
AACHEN, Germany, July 1 (AP)--Mrs. Mary Chapot of Peapack, N.J., riding White Lightning, finished fifth today in the opening event of the armual Aachen Horse Show.

The moonbound flavor of the 20th century is about to join the earth-hugging Victorian stateliness of the 19th century in a $1.5-million expansion project at the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers.

General Electric Company's top marketing and public relations post has been assigned to Oscar L. Dunn, a 53-year-old native of Vincennes, Ind.

GLASSBORO, N. J., July 2-- Seventeen residents of Glassboro, the site of the Johnson- Kosygin meetings last month, asked President Johnson today for his "immediate assistance" in obtaining $60,000 to send 100 people from this borough to the Soviet Union on a threeweek exchanee visit.
JERUSALEM, July 2--The Israeli Government announced today that it would allow the Arab refugees who left the west bank of the Jordan River after the Israelis occupied it to return to their homes.
CHICAGO, July 2 (AP)--The amazing Chicago Cubs, behind the three-hit pitching of Ferguson Jenkins, scored their sixth straight victory today by defeating the Cincinnati Reds, 4-1.

The Marine Floridian, the newest tanker in Texas Gulf Sulphur Company's fleet, completed her maiden voyage yesterday by delivering a cargo of liquid sulphur to the company's terminal at Carteret, N.J.

CAIRO, July 2--A military spokesman announced today the destruction of six Israeli tanks and three armored vehicles in new fighting with Israel that erupted last night and resumed at noon today after a pause of several hours.
WASHINGTON, July 2-- Stanley R. Levine, a jewelry merchant, died today at the age of 53.
AACHEN, Germany, July 2 (AP)--Alwin Schockemoehle of West Germany, riding pesgoe, placed caution ahead of speed today and won the Jump of Champions at the 31st international equestrian tournament.

MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., July 2--Temple Emanu-El was the setting this afternoon for the marriage of Mass Diane Joan Eder, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Eder, to Dr. Theodore Paul Pincus. He is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph A. Pincus of New York.
Four of the eight dangerous radium needles still missing from a shipment that arrived here last week were found yesterday. Three were located in Los Angeles and one in Elkhart, Ind.

CORNWALL, Ont., July 2 --Queen Elizabeth II boarded the royal yacht Britannia for an overnight cruise to Expo 67 this evening after a pleasant Sunday-afternoon, drive through the Ottawa Valley. A crowd of 1,000 or more waved her "bon voyage" as she and her husband, the Duke of Edinburgh, were piped aboard.

MONTREAL, July 2--The United States touring golf professionals are "adamant" in their decision to boycott the Professional Golfers' Association championship tournament in Denver beginning July 20, Gardner Dickinson reiterated today.

Shrimps and prawns have emerged from their long-time role as delicacies for the preferential diner, to the status of a thriving industry, Dr. Shao Wen Ling of the Food and Agriculture Organization said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 2(AP)-- A Congressional report said today that the Fidel Castro regime in Cuba supported guerrilla forces in four Latin American nations, plotted against others, and was also busily at work in Africa.
BOSTON, July 2--Efforts to reach the first new contract between stevedores and longshoremen in the Port of Boston since 1958 continued last week.
WASHINGTON, July 2-- San Pablo, Calif., could have been called the Little City with the Big Inferiority Complex--until 1967.
ANAHEIM, Calif., July 2-- The California Angels rallied twice today before a Bat Day crowd of 39,048 persons and defeated the New York Yankees, 6-4.

NUKUALOFA, Tonga, July 2 (AP)--Taufaahua Tupou IV will be crowned King of Tonga Tuesday, and the happy people of this mid- pacific kingdom can hardly wait for the four days of celebration that will follow.

MONTREAL, July 2--The French - Canadian province of Quebec has paused this summer to bask in world acclaim for Expo 67 to consider the high cost and headlong pace of its accelerated drive for greater autonomy.

WHITE PLAINS, July 2-- Miss Ellen Steinam, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Nathan Steinam of Larchmont, was married this afternoon to Joel Paul. Mellis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Mellis of New York.
WASHINGTON, July 2--New York City received an estimated total of $578-million in Federal aid for its expense budget programs in the fiscal year that ended Friday.
KUTZTOWN, Pa., July 2-- This quiet town of 3,000 in the rolling Pennsylvania Dutch farm country swelled with traffic and with pride this morning, the second day of its 18th annual folk festival.

Cy Feuer and Ernest Martin, who have produced 10 musicals since their partnership began in 1948, are planning their first nonmusical play. WASHINGTON, July 2--The day before the Johnson Administration decided to cut back this year's wheat acreage by 13 per cent a Presidential advisory committee told Mr. Johnson that it was "unthinkable that this country would consider a reduction in our own food production."
NAUGATUCK, Conn., July 2 --Lewis Acker Dibble, an industrialist, died yesterday off emphysema in his home at 17 Beecher Street. His age was 82.

BIR GIFGAFA, United Arab Republic, July 2--Egyptian and Israeli forces exchanged fire today across the Suez Canal in the third clash at the water-way within 24 hours.
LOS ANGELES, July 2 (AP) Dr. Carlyle F. MacIntyre, a poet and translator, died Friday in Stuttgart, Germany, the University of California at Los Angeles announced today. He was 67 years old.

Two United States flag steamship companies have been charged by a Federal Maritime Commission Examiner with unfairly charging one Government agency more than another for carrying household goods to and from Europe.
ALBANY, July 2--The state plans to use portable buildings to try to correct overcrowded conditions at its schools for the mentally retarded, Governor Rockefeller's office announced today.

The purchasing power of the dollar dropped 2.8 per cent last year, the First National City Bank reported in its Monthly Economic Letter for July.

BUFFALO, July 2--Mr. and Mrs. William Pierce Franklin have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Barnard Franklin, to Howard Truman Saperston Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Saperston. The couple plan to marry Sept. 9.

BABYLON, L.I., July 2--Ten skippers scored repeat victories today in the second session of racing in the Babylon Yacht Club's Fourth of July weekend regatta. The series concludes on Tuesday.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., July 2-- The administration plans to close down Hofstra University's radio station and the station's student staff plans a marathon protest broadcast scheduled to begin tomorrow.

The Port of New York Authority has finally broken through the last barrier in the way of the World Trade Center. The building of the project, which will transform the face of lower Manhattan, is in full swing.
