ROME, July 2--The Rev. Pedro Arrupe, Superior General of the Society of Jesus, says his order is moving toward a "more personal style" of religious life that places more responsibility on the individual Jesuit and gives him a greater role in decision-making.
If Dr. Willard E. Edwards had his way, today would be the Fourth of July instead of tomorrow. And all future Fourths of July would fall on Mondays.

HONG KONG, July 2 (Reuters)--Cattle, pigs and poultry arrived here by rail, road and junk from Communist China today, ending a food strike organized by local leftists that nearly doubled the cost of most foodstuffs in this British colony.
Controller Mario A. Procaccino announced yesterday that the city would sell $102,030,000 of bonds on July 13.

WASHINGTON, July 2--The Joint Chiefs of Staff have warned the Johnson Administration that of Gen. William C. Westmoreland's minimum request for 70,000 more troops is not met, the United States will run a high risk of losing the initiative in the ground war in South Vietnam.
WASHINGTON, July 2 (UPI) --Lieut. Gen. Gordon B. Rogers, U.S.A., retired, died today at Walter Reed Army Medical Center. He was 65 years old.

The Boeing Company announced over the weekend that it was considering calling for redemption all of its outstanding 5 per cent convertible subordinated debentures due in 1991. These total about $130million.
The president of the Social Service Employes Union said yesterday that private talks were being held in an attempt to resolve the two-week work stoppage by Welfare Depart- ment caseworkers.
BERLIN, July 2 (AP)--East German voters endorsed today the only choice available to them--a slate of Communist picked candidates for the national Chamber of Deputies and local parliaments.
Even the Fourth of July isn't enough to cause activity in Wall Street's capital markets to slow down.
Heavy fog disrupted operations last night at Kennedy Airport.
CHANNEL 2 preempted "Candid Camera" and "What's My Line?" last night for a look at innovations in art using advances in technology as an instrument of expression.

PHILADELPHIA, July 2-- Mahlon Kline Jordan, vice President of Smith Kline French Laboratories and president and board chairman of the Avoset Company, the company's food products subsidiary, died yesterday in Hawaii.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 2--Western powers op- posed to a Yugoslav resolution on an Arab-Israeli settlement blocked an attempt by its spon- sors today to gain time to revise it and canvass for votes.

PASSAIC, N. J., July 2-- St. John's Episcopal Church was the setting this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Barbara North, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clifford Hartley North of Wayne, to Charles Richmond DeBevoise. He is the son of Mrs. Nicholas Procopi of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and Allen Niles DeBevoise of Naples, Italy.
Fourth of July holiday weekenders planning to bake themselves red on white sands face a blue Monday today, according to the Weather Bureau.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 2-- Last year Buddy Rich was the darling of the Newport Jazz Festival. He served as the house drummer, accompanying and sitting in with a variety of instrumentalists and singers, helping to make every performance in which he took part a bright spot.

LENINGRAD, July 2--Most Soviet ballet authorities agree that the traditional differences separating the old St. Petersburg Ballet from the ballet in Moscow have now disappeared, and that the styles of Leningrad's Kirov Ballet and Moscow's Bolshoi are identical, Personally, I take leave to differ.

Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Phillips of 1010 Fifth Avenue have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Pamela Maria Phillips, to Kevin Christopher McMahon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald J. McMahon of Scarsdale, N.Y.
All United States and markets will be closed tomorrow, July 4, in observance of Independence Day.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., July 2 (AP)--The temperature was 82 today as Phil Sequin of the Ottawa Ski Club soared off the 40-meter Olympic ski Jump at Lake Placid for a leap of 121 feet and the victory in Class 'A' competition at the 20th annual summer. ski jump. Sequin had 211.6 points.

Howie Eisenberg and Kenny Davidoff, seeded second, and Joe Danilczyk and Artie Reyer, seeded fourth, moved into the semi-final round of the National Amateur Athletic Union onewall handball championship yesterday at the Coney Island Municipal courts, Brooklyn.

HONG KONG, July 2--Mao Tse-tung's little red book of quotations is now circulating in 100 countries, Hsinhua, the official Chinese Communist press agency, announced today, it called the book "a spiritual atom bomb of unparalleled might."
THE HAGUE, July 2--The vast majority of Dutch laborers have left for their annual summer vacations undisturbed by any worries over unemployment.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 2 --Miss Ellen Zetzel, daughter of Dr. Louis Zetzel and the late Mrs. Muriel Bashlow Zetzel, was married today to Mark Lambert, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Lambert of North Miami Beach. Rabbi Bruce Ehrmann performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's father and stepmother.
GOODMAN, Miss., July 2 (UPI)--James H. Meredith began the last leg of his 175mile march through Mississippi today, ignoring a steady downpour that drenched him and his band of 30 demonstrators.

SEOUL, South Korea, July 2--Vice President Humphrey, meeting here with leaders of several friendly Asian countries, has conveyed a strong plea from Washington that these states do more on their own for economic and social development.

SEVERAL declarers went down in a slam on the diagramed deal, played in a Westchester sectional tournament recently, and discovered after the hand was over that they should have made it. The reader who wishes to test himself should cover the East-West cards and plan the play in six hearts after a spade lead.

TURKU, Finland, July 2 (UPI) --Ron Clarke of Australia won the 5,000-meter run in 13 minutes 32.4 seconds today at the international track and field meet in honor of Finland's onetime great long distance runner, Paavo Nurmi.

The city has persuaded nearly 1.3 million residents to Sign up for Medicaid, the Federal-state-local program that provides free medical services for families that need them but are unable to pay for them.

MANHASSET, L.I., July 2-- Frederic Parkhurst Benedict of 40 Knightsbridge Road, Great Neck, a lawyer for the New York Procurement District of the Department of Defense died yesterday in Manhasset Hospital. His age was 68.

COVENTRY, England, July 2 (Reuters)--The representative of Pope Paul VI in Britain, Archbishop Igino Cardinale, was interrupted by an Anglican priest today while speaking from the pulpit in the Anglican cathedral here.
Dr. Moses Charles Simon, ear, nose and throat specialist, died yesterday in Brooklyn Jewish Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived at 901 Avenue O. Brooklyn, where he also had his office.
ALGIERS, July 2--Algerian security officials continued today to interrogate former Premier Tshombe.
LONDON, July 2(Reuters) --Sean Connery, who plays James Bond, special agent 007, in films, has been summoned to appear in court by a London policeman named James Bond, who is traffic sergeant 21.

A nonprofit corporation composed of foundations and businesses is being organized to sponsor the development of Welfare Island, the desolate strip of land in the East River whose bright promise has remained unrealized since the city bought it in 1828.

Halle Stieglitz, a brokerage concern, announced over the weekend the admission as new general partners of AlFred. Benjamin Jr., John P. Beyersdorf, Robert A. W. Brauns, Joseph F. Meyers and Kjell W. pettersen.
The first New York showing of "The Wonder of Water," a motion picture produced by the American Waterways Operators, Inc., is Scheduled for Thursday at the downtown Athletic Club, 19 West Street.
BUFFALO, July 2--Sixty young Negroes met today in this riot-torn city to form a "federation of young black adults to articulate our generation's anguishes and hopes."

DAYTONA BEACH, July 2-- David Pearson of Spartanburg, S. C., drove a 1967 Ford at an average speed of 179,051 miles an hour today to qualify for Tuesday's Firecracker 400 at the 2.5-mile Daytona International Speedway. Five other cars traveled at speeds of 178,323 down to 173,126 m.p.h. to assure themselves places in the starting line-up of 40.
JOHN C. MEYER of Yale, who captured first place in the National Intercollegiate Chess Championship at Penn State, considered the following two games his bestplayed in the event.

SAINT-CLOUD, France, July 2 --Ernest Masurel's Taneb, a 19-1 shot who hadn't won a horse race in 10 months, captured the $232,500 Grand Prix de Saint-Cloud today. Charles W. Engelhard's Assagai, the American turt champion, finished fourth in the field of eight after leading until the top of the stretch.
KINSHASA, the Congo, July 2--The Government announced today that it would ask Algeria to extradite former Premier Moise Tshombe to Kinshasa, where he faces a death sen- tence.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., July 2 (AP)--Jaime Fillol of Chile and the University of Miami beat the defending champion, Joaquin Loyo-Mayo of Mexico, in the final of the Tennessee Valley invitation tennis tournament today, 6-4, 4-6, 7-5. A rainstorm forced a 90-minute delay in the third set.
Two policewomen struggled with a burglary suspect on a Lower East Side street yesterday afternoon while dozens of shoppers and strollers stood by impassively and watched.

MONTREAL, July 2--Billy Casper, after trailing by four strokes with nine holes to play, tied Art Wall Jr. for the Canadian open golf championship today. Sinking birdie putts on the last two holes to finish with a 69, Casper brought his 72-hole aggregate to 279. Wall three-putted at the home green of Montreal's municipal course for a 72 that created the deadlock.
Dr. Stephen L. Tillim emerged from an operating room at St. Vincent's Hospital, where he had assisted in the setting of a fractured leg, lowered his surgical mask and told a visitor:

ADEN, July 2--Informed sources said today that British colonial authorities were pressing the pro-Western Government of South Arabia to give way to a broader-based regime, including disaffected military officers with support among Arab nationalists.
A new work, a visiting conductor and a gifted young soprano were brought together by the New York Philharmonic on Saturday night for a Lincoln Center Festival '67 concert at Philharmonic Hall.

"ARABIAN NIGHTS," anyone? Try a genie named Guy Lombardo. On Saturday evening, a nearly capacity audience flocked to the 8,400seat Jones Beach Marine Theater for the third season of the thumping, jumping, big musical mishmash. It opened Mr. Lombardo's 10week 13th summer at Jones Beach.
WARSAW, July 2 (AP)--A Polish writer presented today a report on what he said was the interrogation of three captured American servicemen in Hanoi.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, July 3--Fifty-one marines were killed, 170 were wounded and 34 were missing in the first day of a bitter battle near the demilitarized zone, a military spokesman announced this morning.
AMMAN, Jordan, July 2-- Informed sources said today that the United States was holding up two development loans to Jordan because of uncertainty about the kingdom's future.

ROME, July 2--Achille Manzotti sent his drumsticks crashing into a pair of cymbals. The spotlight turned from purple to pink, and Augusto Ancelotti, twanging an electric guitar, began to sing with an Italian accent, "Winchester Cathedral..."

LENOX, Mass., July 2-- Weather and music were at odds Friday night for the opening of the 30th Berkshire Festival. The weather was bad, the music was good. Sporadic drizzles during the day had left Tanglewood, the site of the festival, chilly and damp. The possibility of more rain was ever-present.
A British churchman told a New York City congregation yesterday that Christianity must shed its image of "Gothic arches" and "isolation."
Efforts have begun to restore a 13-block stretch of Rockaway Beach in Queens, where an eroded beachfront now runs in a thin strip beneath wooden ramps and staircases hanging in mid-air.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., July 2 (AP)--Catherine Lacoste, an amateur golfer referred to as France's sensational "Crocodile Kid," withstood rain, pressure and a rash of five straight bogeys today to win the 22d women's national open golf championship.
TENAFLY, N.J., July 2-- Dr. Archibald H. Stockder, a professor emeritus of the Columbia University School of Business, died yesterday in his home at 5 Coppell Drive. His age was 77.

WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) --The body of a 71-year-old man was found in a seldom used stairwell at the Washington Hospital Center yesterday, eight days after he was report- ing missing from the same hospital.
A Queens man, who was helping his son fly a gasoline powered model airplane in Flushing Meadow Park, was killed yesterday afternoon when he was struck by another model plane.
LAKE GENEVA, Wis., Monday, July 3 (UPI)--The police imposed a 1 A.M. curfew on this resort town today after hundreds of vacationing young people surrounded the police station and stoned it.

WASHINGTON, July 2--According to the United States Chamber of Commerce, housing conditions in the United States have improved and the stock of substandard housing has declined dramatically since 1950.

BOSTON, July 2--Mr. and Mrs. F. Murray Forbes Jr. of Boston and Manchester have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marjorie Forbes, to Bruce Russell McGraw; son of the Rev. and Mrs. Bruce G. McGraw of West Hempstead, L. I.
DETROIT, July 2 (AP)-- Mickey Stanley and Bill Freehan hit home runs and Joe Sparma pitched a six-hitter to day as the Detroit Tigers defeated the Chicago White Sox, 3-0.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 2 (UPI)--Production workers at the Lycoming Division of the Avco Corporation, producer of helicopter engines for Vietnam, voted 1,600 to 600 today to accept a new three-year contract and end a strike threat.
Turnover on the New York and American Stock Exchanges in the first half of 1967 set records--and it gave technical analysts something to think about.
The appointment of Madeline R. Burgess as manager of Chase Manhattan Bank's branch at 83 Street and East End Avenue was announced over the weekend.

Howard J. Samuels, the Democratic candidate for Lieutenant Governor last fall, has rented a Manhattan apartment to facilitate the handling of his business and civic activities, leading to speculation that he plans to run for Mayor in 1969.
WASHINGTON, July 2--A recent court decision in Ohio may give civil rights groups a new weapon with which to attack job discrimination.
MADRID, July 2--Spain's Minister of Industry, Gregorio Lopez Bravo, lashed out at his critics during the weekend. But he conceded that the national economy was undergoing some "difficult" moments.

Five South American countries--Argentina, Bolivia, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay-- are beginning a study of the 1.2-million-square-mile Rio de la Plata basin to determine its potential for integrated development.

COHASSET, Mass., July 2-- Walter Huston Lillard, headmaster of Tabor Academy in Marion from 1916 to 1942, died Friday of a heart ailment in the New England Medical Center Hospital in Boston. He was 85 years old.
Walter J. Hoffman, a retired vice president of the First National City Bank, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home in Southbury, Conn. He was 73 years old.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 2 --In Temple Israel today, Miss Rosalie Bea Goode was married to Paul Stephen Fried, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Fried of New York. The bride is the daughter of Mrs. Harry kaplan of Columbus and the late Lieut. Alexander David Goode, one of four Army chaplains on the transport Dorchester when she was torpedoed in the North Atlantic during World War II.
The Wells Fargo Bank, one of the dozen biggest banks in the country and the largest to report second-quarter results, disclosed a slight decline in earnings yesterday.

GOSHEN, N. Y., July 3 Despite some fine driving Stanley Dancer, Dick Thomas and Carmine Abbatiello did not emerge as the heroes of the day as the 129th harness racing meething at Historic Track got under way two hours late this afternoon.
WASHINGTON, July 3 The National Heart Institute has begun a concerted effort to prove the value of an additive for enhancing the quality and useful lifetime of donated blood.
HONG KONG, July 3 The food situation was returning to normal in Hong Kong today after a four-day shortage engineered by Communists here and in China.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., July 3 (AP) The Navy announced the award today of a contract worth newly $25-million to construct a combat stores ship at the National Steel and Shipbuilding Company, whose workers are on strike.
PEN ARGYL, Pa., July 3 (AP) A Methodist minister read from the Scriptures today at private rites for Jayne MansHeld attended by her family and Mickey Hargitay, her second husband.
ATLANTA, JULY 3 (UPI) The Chicago Cubs routed the Atlanta Braves tonight, 12-6, in a slugging duel that included a record-tying, first-inning outburst of five homers.

"LOOK. No seams!" a student boasted, holding aloft a dress she had recently completed. Making a garment without visible seams is one of the proudest achievements of many students learning dress designing and clothing construction at the French Fashion Academy, 600 Madison Avenue (near 57th Street).

ALBANY, July 3 About 50 mentally retarded youths at Creedmoor State Hospital in Queens Village will begin attending special classes next month to learn such basic educational skills as reading and writing.

Tom Seaver, in beating the San Francisco Giants, 5-3, for the New York Mets before 40,297 persons at Shea Stadium last eight, pitched the kind of game that makes a deeper impression on professional baseball men than on statisticsoriented fans.

SANTA CLARA, Calif., July 3 (UPI) Leslie Bush, Wyn Young and Rich Gilbert of the University of Indiana and Anne Petersen of Phoenix, Ariz., won berths yesterday on the United States 10-meter platform diving team for the Pan-American Games at Winnipeg, July 24, though Aug. 7.
Samuel Strelzoff was appointed yesterday as senior vice president of the Chemical Construction Corporation, a chemical plant construction subsidiary of the Electric Bond and Share Company.
GENEVA, July 3 The International Committee of the Red Cross announced today that its representatives now had free access to all Arab territory under Israeli control.
WASHINGTON, July 3 The Treasury bill rate took one of the largest week-to-week jumps on record at today's auction, the Treasury disclosed tonight.
WASHINGTON, July 3 The growth of consumer credit continued its unusually slow pace in May, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
ATHENS, July 3 Three persons were killed tonight and 32 injured, 7 of them critically when a platform set up for crowds to watch King Constantine's arrival collapsed at the airport of Corfu Island.

A 23-year-old burglar, who was arrested Sunday after a struggle on the lower East Side with two policewomen, has been sentenced to a year in prison. The man, Jose Rivera of 243 Mulberry Street, pleaded guilty to charges of grand larceny and violation of the weapons law.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 3 In the St. Barnabas Episcopal Church here at noon today, Miss Randall Caroline Watson of Philadelphia, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Larkin Dauglass Watson of Greenwich, Conn., became the bride of Carl Gunnar Forsberg, son of the Rev. Arne Forsberg and Mrs. Forsberg of Stockholm.

WASHINGTON, July 3 The Treasury may ask Congress next week for a change in the law to try to cut back on a fraudulent evasion of the interest equalization tax on purchase by Americans of foreign securities.

WASHINGTON, July 3 Dr. Carl F. Hansen, Superintendent of Education for the District of Columbia, announced today that he would resign because of his disagreement with a Federal court's desegregation decree that is supported by his employer, the city school board.

The National Broadcasting Company has offered District Attorney Jim Garrison of New Orleans prime television time to reply to its criticism of his conduct of an investigation into the assassination of President Kennedy.
The Lukens Steel Company, the first major steel producer to report half-year results, reported yesterday that sales and earnings fell in the 12 weeks and 24 weeks ended June 17.
Reform leaders will caucus tomorrow night to decide whom to support in the selection of the New York County Democratic leader.

Gray Drug Stores, Inc., based in Cleveland, is increasing its chain to more than 200 stores, through the multimillion-dollar acquisition of the 12-unit Bargain City Stores, it was announced yesterday.
NUKUALOFA, Tonga, Tuesday, July 4 (Reuters) King Taufaahau Tupou IV was crowned today in a Methodist ceremony in a small wooden chapel on the grounds of his palace here.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 3 Laurence Michelmore, Commis sioner General of the United Nations Relief and Work Agency for Palestine Refugees, today urged Arabs who fled the west bank area to return to their homes.
The Standard Prudential United Corporation, a factoring and equipment leasing company, announced yesterday the election of Arthur L. Carter as a director.

Sitting on the stage of the Alvin Theater at the delightful birthday party that the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers gave Richard Rodgers last week when he reached 65, one was impressed by the aptness of the setting.
Most Issues on the London Stock Exchange eased fractionally yesterday for lack of support, although the under- tone remained firm. Renewed Middle East tension, the Nigerian...
BUFFALO, July 3 Fifty Negro youngsters reported to Federal agencies this morning for their first day of work.
Buckpasser, his streak of 15 victories broken when he attempted to race on strange footing with strange footwear, will be back on normal ground at Aqueduct today.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., July 3 The Roman Catholic Bishop here has suspended a priest for writing a series of articles on birth control for The Arkansas Gazette last month.

WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) A State Department official indicated a lack of enthusiasm today for a proposal that the Johnson Administration put up $60,000 to finance a trip to the Soviet Union by 100 residents of Glassboro, N.J., the site of the President's meetings with Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin last month.

The real estate concern of Brener Lewis, Inc., established in 1948 and dissolved in January, 1966, has been re-established by the original partners, Daniel A. Brener and Edward R. Lewis. The offices are at 400 Madison Avenue, at 48th Street.

ST. LOUIS, July 3 (UPI) Doubles by Lou Brock and Dal Maxvill were the big hits in a seven-run first-inning rally that lifted the St. Louis Cardinals to a 7-3 victory over the Cincinnati Reds tonight in a game marked by a near free-for-all on the field.

THE football season is sneaking up on us, with the professional football squads getting ready to open training camps from one end of the country to the other. Twenty big league coaches will watch anxiously when the hardening-up process begins in earnest because it is only through hitting and being hit that these muscular meatballs can be launched on the crash pro gram go necessary for their future survival.
The first shots have been fired in what could develop into a battle to the finish between l3 local-Service airlines and private air-taxi operators for control of so-called. "com- muter" lines.
MANILA, July 3--Twenty-one miners who were buried by a cave-in Wednesday near Bagulo, 125 miles north of here, were rescued this afternoon.

Aleksei I. Adzhubei, son-inlaw of Nikits S. Khruschev and former editor of Izvestia, Played an incidental role in making the home motion pictures that the National Broadcasting Company will show next Tuesday in the first television interview with the former Premier of the Soviet Union.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 3 The Lebanese Government is admitting United States citizens despite notations in their passports declaring them invalid for travel to Lebanon.
PARIS, July 3 (Reuters) A new company offficially came into being here today aimed at helping the flow of business within Europe and between Europe and the United States.

AQUEBOGUE, L. I., July 3 Long Island's farmers complained today that the quality of fresh fruits and vegetables was being threatened by the limited hours that the new Hunts Point Market in the Bronx is open.

AGANA, Guam, July 3 (AP) The Pacific Far East Line's freighter Guam Bear, which was badly damaged in January when it collided with the tanker Esso Seattle, was sunk today with demolition charges set off by the United States Navy.
SAO PAULO, Brazil, July 3 (AP) Policemen broke into dormitories at the University of Sao Paulo before dawn today and evicted 108 student squatters.
The Metropolitan Museum of Art will open a Visitors' Center tomorrow in the Great Hall inside the main entrance at Fifth Avenue and 82d Street.

ENGLEWOOD, N. J., July 3 The Rev. David Mason, from 1946 to 1952 international treasurer of the Christian and Missionary Alliance, with an office in New York, died today in Englewood Hospital after a long illness. He was 84 years old and lived here at 166 Grand Avenue. The Christian and Missionary Allianc is an international Protestant organization for mission work.

WALDEN, N. Y., July 3? Henry N. Smith, former general counsel of the New York State Insurance Department, died in his summer home at Lake Osiris today, of a heart attack. He was 57 years old and lived at 80-75 surrey Place, Jamaica Estates, Queens.

Total assets of the Security National Bank of Long Island rose to $552,599,463 on June 30 from $463,357,930 a year earlier, it was reported yesterday. Deposits totaled $502,377,- 704 compared with $389,801,493, up 29 per cent.
Bristol Siddeley Engines, Ltd., of Britain, has decided not to extend its option to build an American engine that is considered a candidate for the proposed European airbus.

WASHINGTON, July 3 The Securities and Exchange Commission will make available to the public for the first time, under the new law, its administrative manuals setting forth the standards its staff uses in passing on various type of securities cases.
TEL AVIV, July 3 Israel said that Egyptian and Israeli forces exchanged fire across the Suez Canal today for the third consecutive day.

NEWPORT, R. I., July 3 Distance lent considerable enchantment to the final two damp days of the Newport Jazz Festival, From Japan, Germany and California came musicians who sparked these last stages of the four-day festival, which ended this evening.

YONKERS, July 3 Three quick-thinking and quick-moving, shirt-sleeved young men possibly saved George Phalen's life, after he had been thrown from the sulky of the pacer lie was driving in the second event at Yonkers Raceway tonight.
Handy Harman will increase its quotation for silver here by 0.4-cent to $1,305 a troy ounce effective tomorrow, the major processor and fabricator said yesterday.
A 400-pound Siberian tigress at the Bronx Zoo presented her four 19-day old cubs to the public yesterday.

INDIANAPOLIS, July 3 (AP) Doug Ford, a member of the players committee, said today that the committee wanted the professional Golfers' Association to relinquigh the veto only in relation to tournament operations.

A BUSY professional life tends to be incompatible with high-level tournament bridge, which inevitably consumes a great deal of time and energy. Neverthless, it is possible to find representatives of almost every major profession among the world's leading players.

WASHINGTON, July 3 Hugh O'Connor, former infor mation specialist in community relations for the Office of the Assistant Secretary of Defense for Public Information, died yesterday in his home here after a long illness. He was 73 years old and had suffered from arteriosclerosis, heart disease and other ailments.
The Alvin Theater became the property yesterday of the owners of the Playhouse in an exchange agreement negotiated by Rockefeller-Time real estate development interests, known as Rock-Time Inc.
Premier Mohammed Ahmed Mahgoub of the Sudan charged early today that 150 Ethiopian soldiers has crossed the border into Sudan.
JERUSALEM, July 3 (Agence France-Presse) Many gravestones removed from the Jewish cemetery on the Mount of Olives were used to build Jordanian Army Camps at Al Azariya and Sur Bahir.
ALGIERS, July 3 (AP) The Algerian Government said tonight it had a "duty" to deal with former Premier Moise Tshombe of the Congo in accordance with its "resolutely anti-imperialist" policies.

MIAMI, July 3 Two works by the late Constantin Aramescu, the exiled Rumanian sculpfor who died here last year at the age of 52, will be shipped by air this week from Miami to Bucharest to become part of the permanent collection of the Museum of Art of the Socialist Republic of Rumania.

MOSCOW, July 3 Soviet officials with censorship powers over new plays have come under attack here as incompetent meddlers who worry more about safeguarding their bureaucratic careers than about the welfare of the theater."

ST. LOUIS, July 3 (UPI) The dismissal of an antipoverty worker who had refused to ask welfare recipients about their sex lives was upheld by the board of directors of the St. Louis Human Development Corporation, it was announced today.
RELEIGH, N.C., July 3 The General Assembly agreed tonight on a plan for realigning North Carolina's 11 Congressional districts. It could lead to two contests between incumbents in the 1968 elections.
CINCINNATI, July 3 (UPI) Trouble erupted again in the predominantly Negro Avondale section tonight.

The Department of Real Estate will offer at auction 181 city-owned properties on July 20 at the Roosevelt Hotel. Eleven parcels are in Manhattan, 81 in Brooklyn, 40 in the Bronx, 26 in Queens and 23 in Staten Island. Upset or minimum prices range from $25 to $310,000.
The bartender at Oscar's Delmonico said business was down 75 per cent. Mrs. Benjamin Loox, who has run a Broad Street newsstand for 37 years, said sales were less than half of normal.
A booming tanker-charter market as a result of the closing of the Suez Canal has averted a frieght war that dry- cargo tramp shipowners feared would take place this summer.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 3 In a letter to Abdul Rahman Pazhwak, president of the General Assembly, Baron Sigismund von Braun, West Germany's permanent observer, asserted today that, contrary to East Eurogean allegations, his Government had supplied only 2 per cent of the total arms deliveries to the Middle East in the last 12 years.

WASHINGTON, July 3 Dr. Carl F. Hansen broke his own ground rules today at a news conference he called to announced his resignation as Washington's Superintendent of Education. The action was somehow characteristic.
GRAND CANYON, Ariz., July 3 (UPI) Senator Robert F. Kennedy hiked seven miles in 117-degree heat today to complete a four-day raft trip through the Grand Canyon along the Colorado River.
SEARSPORT, Me., July 3 (AP) The victims of an amphibious plane crash in Penobscot Bay were identified today as a family of four from Croton, N. Y., and a pilot from Hastings, N. Y.

ROME, July 3 (AP) Pope Paul VI has suspended the powers of the Most Rev. Nicholas P. Eike of Pittsburgh, Bishop of the Catholic Ruthenian rite, by naming an apostolic administrator to direct the diocese.
ZEIZEIA, Jordan, July 3? Palestinian refugees, interviewed at a camp here today, rejected Israel's offer to let them return home and shouted that all Israelis were "kaza- been"--liars.

The Kysor Industrial Corporation which has sued the recently acquired Dexter Industries, Inc., charging overstatement of earnings through manipulation of inventories, before the acquisition, is withholding interim financial reports for its fiscal fourth quarter ended May 31, until a complete audit of Dexter records is completed.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 3 Dr. and Mrs. Alexander Wolsky have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Catherine Wolsky, to Jacques Monteil, son of Sena tor and Mrs. Andre Monteil of Paris and Quimper, France.
The New York Life Insurance Company announced yesterday the election of Lee A. Buck and Forrest E. Huffman as vice presidents.

PICKENS, Miss., July 3 (AP) Weary and glum, James H. Meredith said today that he would be glad to see the end of his symbolic walk across Mississippi "because I just can't stand to see my people so afraid."
The conviction of an avowed conscientious objector for failing to submit to induction into the armed forces and a twoyear prison term were reinstated yesterday by the United States Court of Appeals.

MOSCOW, July 3 (Reuters) Izvestia, the Soviet Government newspaper, described Mao Tsetung tonight as a frightened, reactionary, dictatorial, egotistical incompetent who has kept his people poor so that he could build up an arsenal of nuclear weapons for Communist China.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, July 4 United States marines caught a large force of North Vietnamese troops yesterday on the southern edge of the demilitarized zone between North and South Vietnam. Seventy-five of the enemy were reported killed in heavy artil- lery barrages.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 3 The Presidential ticket headed by Lieut. Gen. Nguyen Van Thieu was termed illegal by a civilian candidate today and the general was urged by another civilian rival to resign from office for the election campaign.

CLINTON, N. C., July 3 The Clinton First Methodist Church was the setting this evening for the marriage of Miss Erma Gail Kendall, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John Kendall, to Frederick Gray Meyer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederic Hays Meyer of Darien, Conn.
BOSTON, July 3 A power failure blacked out most of Cape Cod tonight. The blackout began at 5:29 P.M. when a 115,000-volt overhead line on rocky, hilly terrain came down in West Barnstable.
WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) The Department of Defense listed today 67 United States servicemen killed in action in Vietnam.
The bond market seemed full of holiday spirit yesterday as long-term and short-term interest rates moved independently in opposite directions.
PRAGUE, July, 3 (Reuters) Jan Benes, Czechoslovak writer and artist, went on trial here today charged with subversive activities, speculation and attempted fraud.
The Small Business Administration went into slum areas yesterday in conjunction with the city's Manpower and Career Development Agency to make it simpler for local businessmen to obtain loans.
RANGOON, Burma, July 3 (Reuters) A crowd of about 500 university students in Moulmein, in southern Burma, burned effigies of Mao Tsetung today in a new outbreak of anti-Chinese demonstrations.
TOKYO, July 1 (Reuters) Japan began liberalizing conditions for direct capital investment in her industries today, marking the first step toward an era of an open economy.

MEXICO CITY, July 3 The Institutional Revolutionary party, which has dominated Mexican politics for more than three decades, appears to have made nearly a clean sweep of the congressional and state elections yesterday.

Grain and soybean futures drifted lower yesterday under aggressive liquidation on the Chicago Board of Trade. With the New York markets closed, activities in commodities in this country centered on the board and the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, which held abbreviated sessons. There was little outside interest and most of the board trading was confined to local professionals and commercial interests. Both indulged mainly in hedging activities.
TEL AVIV, July 3 Three civilians were killed and 12 injured today when a western Galilee ammunition dump went up in flames, sending shells and bullets in all directions ...
MONTREAL, July 3 Queen Elizabeth II hailed Expo 67 today as a "fantastic creation," even though she saw much of it from under an umbrella in a heavy rain.
PHILADELPHIA An old house "just isn't square," said Samuel Maitin, standing on a sloping floor in the attic of his 1810 remodeled house.
GLENEAGLES, Scotland, July 3 (AP) Jude Poynter of Palm Desert, Calif., lead the field today in the first qualifying round of the second seniors international amateur golf championship here.
ATLANTA, July 3 (AP) A small crowd of Negao youths hurled bottles at policemen today and for about three hours milled around outside a store where a Negro man had been arrested.
One of the biggest problems the park department faces today is cleaning up. The department is spending $10.5 million about a quarter of its budget just to pick up litter this year.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 3 (UPI) Letters and manuscripts from the last 10 years of Ernest Hemingway's life have been given to the Houghton Library of Harvard University by Dr. and Mrs. Edmundo Lassaile.

ST.THOMAS, Virgin Islands, July 3 (UPI) Peter Adams, president of what he describes as the new Republic of Anguilla, announced today that a referendum would be held soon to allow the 6,000 people of the island a chance to demonstrate whether they desire independence.

A DEW-DRIPPING punch bowl filled with a cooling beverage and garnished with fresh fruits can be an oasis at a pool party, summer reception or teen-age barbecue. Here ase recipes for two non-alocholic punches, two that pack a punch, and one for a cooling banana-rum drink to make in small quantities.

Maritime employment for economically or educationally deprived youths 16 to 2l years old is being encouraged by the Maritime Administration this summer as part of President Johnson's Youth Opportunity Campaign.

BRUSSELS, July 3 Expansionary measures were recommended today to get the European Common Market countries out of a slump that for the first time in a decade has hit both North America and Western Europe simultaneously.
The Transit Authority adopted yesterday a record high operating budget with an expected deficit that could jeopardize the 20-cent fare.
The city and a union of Welfare Department caseworkers, who have been in disagreement over a new contract, disagreed further yesterday on whether anyone was trying to mediate the dispute.
Health Department workers with Geiger counters searched streets leading from the Lincoln Tunnel yesterday for four dangerous radium needles missing from a shipment here last week.
SAKONNAKHON, Thailand, July 1 The low, green Phuban Mountains, which can be seen to the south across a plain of scrub forest, serve as refuge for about 1,000 guerrillas of the United Patriotic Front.
MOSCOW, July 3 (AP) Premier Aleksel N. Kosygin declared tonight that the positions of France and the Soviet Union were close together on the Vietnamese and Middle Eastern questions.
LONDON, July 3 (AP) Spain today rejected a British plan for a free vote by Gibraltar residents to decide the disputed future of the colony.
ROME, N. Y., July 3 They started to dig the Erie Canal here on July 4 just 150 years ago, and it Seems impossible today that a mere four-foot deep ditch could have done what everyone agrees it did.
LAKE GENEVA, WIS. July 3 (UPI) Hundreds of youths left this resort community tonight after a show of force by the National Guard and staged hitand-run raids on three other lake communities.
WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) Senator Stephen M. Young Democrat of Ohio, disclosed today his financial holdings and said his income in 1966 totaled $52,044,46.
The Department of Housing and Urban Development has delayed announcing its selection of cities to participate in the Fedaral model cities program because of a last-minute rush of applications.
TRENTON, July 3 The New Jersey Supreme Court unanimously overturned a key provi- sion of the state's reapportionment law today.
WASHINGTON, July 3 The men who grapple with the problems of beautifying America's cities have a wary eye cocked on Vietnam.
WASHINGTON, July 3 A sense of frustration over the war in Vietnam is growing within the military establishment.

CHICAGO, July 3 (AP) Brooks Robinson's sacrifice fly in the 14th inning gave the Baltimore Orioles a 1-0 victory over the American League leading Chicago White Sox tonight. The loss was the fourth for Chicago in its last five games.
A cordless extension telephone is being developed by Bell Telephone Laboratories and will soon be put into the field for testing, it was announced yesterday.

HONG KONG, July 3 Reports from Peking last weekend that Mao Tse-tung's Cultural Revolution had "overthrown" Liu Shao-chi, the chief of state, and a handful of his associates have not been borne out in subsequent reports.
City planners and the Department of Marine and Aviation disagree over the future use of the waterfront in lower Manhattan.
PITTSBURGH, July 3 (AP) Bill Mazeroski and Willie Stargell drove in five runs between them and Tom Sisk pitched a five-hitter as the Pittsburgh Pirates beat the Los Angeles Dodgers tonight, 5-2.

VALLEY STREAM, L. I., July 3 The marriage of Miss Judy Ellen Lipton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Lipton of Laurelton, Queens, to Michael Jan Ackerman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Ackerman of Laurelton, took place tonight in Temple Hillel. Rabbi YaakoV Pollak performed the ceremony.
Two knife-wielding men attacked three taxi drivers within an hour yesterday morning in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn.

The National Teacher Corps has come out of the Congressional wringer relabeled Teacher Corps. Apparently the "national" designation filled some Representatives and even members of the professional education Establishment with feat that a Federl army of radical youths might take over the local schools.

WASHINGTON, July 3 (UPI) Representative Edwin E. Willis, chairman of the House Committee on Un-American Activities, charged today that Communists had been involved in a "great majority" of rallies protesting the Vietnam war.
RIDGEWOOD, N. J., July 3 Matthew S.Crinkley, vice chairman of the board of American Export Isbrandtsen Lines, died here yesterday at Valley Hospital of a heart attack.
Price changes were announced yesterday by E. I. du Pont de Nemours Po., Inc., on seven of its l3 grades of Elvax vinyl resins used in coatings for packaging materials and adhesives.

Mr. and Mrs. Michael J. Healy of Long Island City, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Bernadine Patricia Healy, to Gregory Bartlett Buckley. He is the son of Dr. and Mrs. George J. Bulkley of Winnetka, Ill.
WASHINGTON, July 3 Registrations of security issues at the Securities and Exchange Commission last month reached a record $5.6-billion, the S.E.C. reported today.
TRENTON, July 3 (AP) Alton W. Van Horn of Elizabeth has been elected president of the New Jersey Real Estate Commission.

WASHINGTON, July 3 A cutback in the profits that the American Telephone and Telegraph Company is permitted on its long-distance and international business is expected to be ordered this week by the Federal Communications Commission.
PHILADELPHIA, July 3 (UPI) Carl Asplundh Sr., a founder of one of the world's largest tree service companies, died yesterday at his home in suburban Bryn Athyn. He was 63 years old.
MONTREAL, July 3 Billy Casper won the Canadian open golf title in a playoff today by defeating Art Wall Jr. by four strokes, 65 to 69.
Early morning cloudbursts flooded highways and streets here yesterday, disrupting subway service and snarling rushhour traffic.

CANBERRA, Australia, July 3 (Reuters) American investment controls 8 per cent of all Australian company assets and the percentage will probably rise it Britain joins the Common Market, the United Stated Ambassador, Edward Clark, said over the weekend.

PHARR, Tex., July 3 Trinity Episcopal Church here was the setting this evening for the wedding of Miss Louise Anne Pagenstecher of New York, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Francis Alexander Pagenstecher 2d of McAllen, to James William Simpson. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Myers Simpson of Columbia, S.C.

WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) The Justice Department and the Interstate Commerce Commission joined today in a move to consolidate all the cases dealing with a mass of Eastern railroad mergers into one court.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., July 3 Alexander Mayer Jr. of Woodmere, seeded fourth, and Warren Lucas of Saddle Brook, N.J., fifth, reached the second round of the Eastern Junior (18 years and under) tennis championship today at the Port Washington Tennis Academy.

Israeli Foreign Minister Abba Eban's semantic step backward from the "annexation" of Jordanian Jerusalem holds the door ajar for Israel to make a magnanimous gesture that could significantly advance the prospects of lasting peace.

CEDARHURST. L. I., July 3 Mr. and Mrs. Edward N. Carpenter have announced daughter, Miss Katherine Eaton Carpenter, to David Keith McCallen of Santa Monica, Calif, who appears in "The Man From U.N.C.L.E." television series. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. David McCallum of London and Arundel in Essex, England.

OXFORD, Miss., July 3 Faculty and student groups at the University of Mississippi have filed a suit in Federal District Court here to enjoin a state college board ban on a scheduled campus speech by Aaron Henry, state president of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.
ANAHEIM, Calif., July 3 (AP) Tony Conigliaro, Mike Andrews and Reggie Smith hit home runs as the Boston Red Sox trounced the California Angels, 9-3, tonight for their fourth straight victory.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., July 3 President Johnson forwarded to Congress today a report on surface mining that recommends. Federal Intervention where states fail to curb wasteful and destructive practices.

SEOUL, South Korea, July 3 Riotous student demonstrations against President Chung Hee Park's Government resumed in Seoul today with the reopening of the universities for the examinations that conclude the spring term.

WASHINGTON, July 3 The United States Health Service and the National Institute of Mental Health today announced a grant of $1.5-million to help build the Washington Heights Community Mental Health Center in New York City.
More than 2,700 sweltering people jammed the office of the United States Passport Agency in Rockefeller Center yesterday.
ADEN, July 3 British troops and armor drove into an Arab quarter seized by rebel nationalists 16 days ago and recaptured it with ease today.

The Pittsburgh Plate Glass Company said yesterday it would build a major float glass plant near Meadville, about 70 miles north of Pittsburgh. Industry sources estimated it could cost in excess of $20million.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., July 3 James McClusltey, who retired on May 31 as national director of supply of the Boy Scouts of America, died today at Muhlenberg Hospital, Plainfield. He was 65 years old and lived at 617 Shackamaxon Road, Westfield.
WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) Federal agencies will begin working tomorrow under a new Freedom of Information Act, but few of them expect important changes in the way they disclose public records.
MIAMI BEACH, July 3 (AP) Commissioners of 11 major athletic conferences, voted today to endorse the new National Collegiate football rules, including the controversial ruling on punt returns.
Bells will ring, fireworks will boom, bands will play and traffic will jam today as americans celebrate the 191st anniversary of the signing of the Declaration of Independence.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., July 3 The Tennessee Valley Authority and a committee representing 160 retail distributors announced today electric rate increases for residential and industrial consumers to be put into effect next month.
Speculative interest remained at a high level yesterday on the American Stock Exchange, even though trading volume tapered off slightly because of the approaching July 4th holiday.
WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) Perry A. Fellows, former chief engineer for the Works Progress Administration, has died in Africa at the age of 80, it was reported today.
If a popularity poll were taken on this, the birthday of the Republic, as to where Alexander Hamilton stands in the regard of the townspeople, the answer very likely would be low.

Herbert Paris, general manager of the Hamburg State Opera, which ended its highly praised engagement at the Met ropolitan Opera House Sunday night, believes the structure of his company is as unusual as its musical theater concept.
The city's hospitals obtained more than 1,000 Medicaid applications yesterday as the $8 fee for non-Medicaid patients was charged for the first time in clinics and emergency rooms.
Steel production in the first six months of this year was the lowest for a first half since 1964, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
John A. Barr and James S. Kemper Jr. were elected yesterday to the board of the Stewart-Warner Corporation, producer of auto parts. The elections increase the size of the board to nine members.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., July 3 Minnesota won its fifth straight game tonight and Fritz Peterson lost his eighth straight when the Twins defeated the New York Yankees, 3-0.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., July 3 Leon Mohill, a New England news dealer, died in Halfa, Israel, on Friday after a long ill ness. He was 66 years old and had homes here and in Israel. Burial was in Ein Hashofet Kibbutz in Israel today.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., July 3 (UPI) Twelve-day-old Patrick Lyndon Nugent slept contentedly today in his grandfather's arms during a picture-taking session although the President tickled, petted and chucked him under the chin to wake him up.

Ernestine Evans, an editor and writer who was regarded as an authority on children's books, died yesterday after a long illness at Manhattan State Hospital. She was 77 years old and lived at 212 East 48th Street.

UNION, S. C., July 3 The engagement of Miss Caroline Gordon Richardson to Thomas McKeen Cutler has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Henry Burchill Richardson, parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is the son of Mrs. Flora Campbell Cutler of Darien, Conn., and Benjamin Crawford Cutler of Bronxville, N. Y.
The wholesale commodity price index rose to 97.8 on Friday from 97.6 on Thursday.
MINNEAPOLIS, July 3 (UPI) Trials to pick eight United States. Pan-American Games teams began tonight with 56 wrestling bouts which resulted in the elimination of 12 grapplers.

A good deal of American industry is up in arms over the tariff reductions made by the United States in the Kennedy Round of trade negotiations. Such a reaction was to be expected. The object of the entire exercise was to do away the tariffs that protect domestic industries. The protests of chemical, textile and other business executives are therefore a measure of the success of the new agreement.
WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) The United States Public Health Service today asked the police across the nation to report whether seat belts were in use at the time of traffic accidents.

CINCINNATI, July 3 (AP) Humphery Hose of Venezuela opened the annual tri-state tennis tournament today by upsetting eighth-seeded Lenny Schloss of Baltimore, 8-6, 6-3. He went on to beat Chuck Hanley, a home-town entry, 6-1, 6-3.

WHILE New York State tax officials scratch their heads over the lackluster performance of the lottery, traders are having the time of their life in Wall Street.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 3 Joseph J. Weed Jr. of the host Larchmont Yacht Club won the annual single-handed race of the International One Design Class on Long Island Sound today.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., July 3 A.J. Foyt of Houston, a three-time winner at Indianapolis in open cockpit cars and a winner at Le Mans, France, last month in a Ford sports car, hopes to win the Firecracker 400 for late model stock Cars for the third time here tomorrow.

TRENTON, July 3 Crawford Jamieson, a New Jersey State Senator from 1936 to 1942 and a member of the New Jersey public Utility Commission from 1942 to 1945, died Saturday in Mercer County Hospital. He was 65 years old.
TEANECK, N.J., July 3 Miss Judith Sheryl Berson and Thomas Lawrence were married here this evening at the Ambassador catering hall by Rabbis Solomon Rothstein and Robert Aronowitz.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 3 (AP) President Nikolai V. Podgorny of the Soviet Union arrived today for talks on the Middle East.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 3 The United States said today that it did not recognize Israel's unilateral action in Jerusalem as determining the future of the holy places or the status of the city in relation to them.

WASHINGTON, July 3 The Navy, with the encouragement of officials from the Department of Defense and the Army, is pressing studies of an antimissile missile system based on warships and large submarines.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., July 3 President Johnson announced today the resignation of Bernard L. Boutin as administrator of the Small Business Administration.
DETROIT, July 3 Sales of new cars in June topped those of a year earlier, the second straight gain for the automobile industry.
A new weapon has been developed for the C-47 gun planes being used by American forces in Vietnam, Aviation Week Space Technology reports.

If this measurement could be carried over to politics, then the next President would be Lyndon B. Johnson, who is suddenly leading the polltakers' league.

LONDON, July 3 (AP) Britain has decided to bow to a demand for withdrawal of her forces from Libya, official sources reported tonight.

HONG KONG, July 4 Communist China protested again to the Burmese Government today and issued a new set of demands of Rangoon.

ATHENS, July 4 A mission of six from the International Federation of Journalists arrived in Athens today for talks with the Leaders of Greece's revolutionary regime on this country's controlled press.

NEW DELHI, July 4--A deep rift is developing in the left Communist party in West Bengal over the issue of whether a movement with revolutionary aims can participate in an elected government that promises nothing more than palliating reforms.

WOOSTER, Ohio, July 4 (AP)--Dr. Howard F. Lowry, President of the College of Wooster for the last 23 years, died today, apparently of a heart attack, while on a business and pleasure trip to San Francisco. He would have been 66 years old on July 26.

ATLANTA, July 4(AP) Mack Jones and Rico Carty combined for five home runs and powered the Atlanta Braves to and 8-3, 4-2 sweep opf their day-night program with Chicago today. The losses dropped the Cubs to second place in the National League.

District Attorney Jim Garrison of New Orleans set two conditions last night for his acceptance of an invitation by the National Broadcasting Company to reply to its criticism of his investigation of the Kennedy assassination.

PARIS, July King Hussein of Jordan talked with President de Gaulle for an hour and a quarter this morning and said he was "very satisfied with this meeting."

CINCINNATI, July 4 (AP) Reinforced police squads kept a tight watch on Cincinnati's predominantly Negro Avondale area today is an effort to prevent a recurrence of last night's violence, which brought rock-throwing, window-smashing, looting and fires.
OCEANPORT, N.J., July 4 That $92,000 spent by Martin Andersen for, Quillo Queen as an untried yearling is beginning to look like a real bargain.
